# 庄子集释

*The Collected Annotations on the Zhuangzi* (Qing Dynasty) by Guo Qingfan
*Preface and Catalogue of the Classic Exegetical Writings* by Lu Deming of the Tang Dynasty

**Zhuangzi**
The Zhuangzi is attributed to Zhuang Zhou, a native of Meng County in the state of Liang. His surname was Zhuang, his given name Zhou (Sima Qian records his courtesy name as Zixiu). During the Warring States period, he served as an officer of the Lacquer Garden and was a contemporary of King Hui of Wei, King Xuan of Qi, and King Wei of Chu (Li Yi states he was a contemporary of King Min of Qi). The states of Qi and Chu once offered him the position of prime minister, but he declined. While others of his time valued rhetorical persuasion, Zhuangzi alone held his pursuits in lofty esteem, living with ease and contentment. Following the principles of the Laozi, he composed a work of over one hundred thousand characters, advocating freedom through natural spontaneity and the equality of all things. His writings are largely allegorical, ultimately converging upon principle, and cannot be rigidly interpreted by their surface meaning. Yet Zhuangzi’s vast talent and world-renowned eloquence, with its profound and florid diction—often appearing paradoxical—left his grand vision insufficiently expounded. Later hands added interpolations, gradually obscuring the original text. Thus, Guo Xiang (Zixuan) remarked: *“Those of limited talent recklessly inserted strange theories—such as the opening sections of ‘Yan Yi’ and ‘Yi Xiu,’ or the chapters ‘Wei Yan,’ ‘You Fu,’ and ‘Zi Xu’—amounting to roughly three-tenths of the text, all cunningly interwoven.”*

The *Han shu*’s *Yiwen zhi* records fifty-two chapters of the *Zhuangzi*, corresponding to the editions annotated by Sima Biao and Meng Shi. Its language is often fantastical, at times resembling the *Classic of Mountains and Seas* or divination manuals, leading commentators to exercise subjective judgment in their selections. The “Inner Chapters” are universally acknowledged by all schools, while the remainder may include “Outer” sections but lack “Miscellaneous” ones. Only Guo Xiang’s annotations truly align with Zhuangzi’s intent, which is why they are prized by later generations. Xu Xianmin and Li Hongfan both produced phonetic glosses based on Guo’s edition, and this work likewise adopts Guo’s version as its foundation.

Cui Zhuan’s commentary comprises ten fascicles and twenty-seven chapters (Cui was a native of Qinghe and served as Gentleman-Consultant during the Jin Dynasty). It includes seven “Inner Chapters” and twenty “Outer Chapters.”

Xiang Xiu’s annotations comprise twenty fascicles and twenty-six chapters (alternatively recorded as twenty-seven or twenty-eight chapters, also lacking “Miscellaneous” chapters; phonetic glosses in three fascicles).

Sima Biao’s annotations comprise twenty-one fascicles and fifty-two chapters (styled Shaotong, a native of Henei, who served as Gentleman-Secretary during the Jin Dynasty; seven “Inner Chapters,” twenty-eight “Outer Chapters,” fourteen “Miscellaneous Chapters,” and three chapters of exegesis; phonetic glosses in three fascicles).

Guo Xiang’s annotations comprise thirty-three fascicles and thirty-three chapters (styled Zixuan, a native of Henei, who served as Registrar to the Grand Mentor during the Jin Dynasty; seven “Inner Chapters,” fifteen “Outer Chapters,” and eleven “Miscellaneous Chapters”; phonetic glosses in three fascicles).

Li Yi’s collected explanations comprise thirty fascicles and thirty chapters (styled Jingzhen, a native of Xiangcheng in Yingchuan, who served as Assistant to the Chancellor during the Jin Dynasty and styled himself Master of the Mysterious Dao; alternatively recorded as thirty-five chapters, with phonetic glosses in one fascicle).

The Meng lineage’s annotations comprise eighteen fascicles and fifty-two chapters (the annotator’s identity remains undetermined).

Wang Shu’s *Exegeses* comprise three fascicles. (Styled Mu[gap], a native of Langye, a recluse of the Song Dynasty. Also recorded as *Annotations*.)

Li Gui’s *Phonetic Glosses* comprise one fascicle.
Xu Miao’s *Phonetic Glosses* comprise three fascicles.

**Preface to the *Zhuangzi* by Cheng Xuanying**

**Preface to the *Zhuangzi***
Composed by Cheng Xuanying, Dharma Master of Xihua in the Tang Dynasty

The *Zhuangzi* serves to expound the profound roots of the Dao and virtue, to elucidate the wondrous purport of the profound mystery, to unfold the serenity of non-action, and to illuminate the obscure darkness of solitary transformation. It subdues the nine schools and encompasses the hundred masters, truly the supreme teaching within the realm and the subtle words beyond forms.

The author, surnamed Zhuang, named Zhou, styled Zixiu, was born in Meng County of Suiyang in the state of Song. He studied under Master Chang Sang and was posthumously titled the Perfected One of Nanhua.

At the beginning of the Warring States period, during the decline of the Zhou Dynasty, he lamented the meager karma of sentient beings and grieved the decay of the Dao and virtue. Thus, with fervent resolve, he composed this treatise.

Its words are vast and expansive; its purport, deep and far-reaching. Not within the hearing of lesser scholars, how could shallow minds fathom it?

The term *zi* ("Master") is an honorific for one of virtue, as the ancients referred to their teachers as *zi*. It may also denote the title of this work—not merely the collective name for the three Inner Chapters, but the common designation for all schools.

The term *Inner Chapters* signifies their distinction from the Outer, with *pian* ("chapters") referring to bound bamboo slips. In antiquity, bamboo was cured to make slips, bound with leather thongs. Bound slips formed chapters, much as connected sheets form scrolls today. Thus, Yuan Kai stated: "Great matters were recorded on *ce* (bamboo tablets), while minor ones were noted on *jian* (wooden slips)." The Inner Chapters discourse on the fundamental principles, while the Outer Chapters recount events and traces. Though events may be manifest, they are not understood without principle; though principle is subtle, it is not revealed without events. To first clarify the wondrous principle, the Inner Chapters are placed first.

As the principles in the Inner Chapters are profound, each chapter bears a distinct title outside the text. Guo Xiang further appended annotations beneath these titles, as seen in *Free and Easy Wandering* and *The Equality of Things*. From the Outer Chapters onward, titles are taken from the first two characters of each chapter, such as *Webbed Toes* and *Horses’ Hooves*.

Regarding *Free and Easy Wandering*, interpretations have varied across the ages. Here, I broadly outline the essentials in three explanations:

First, Gu Tongbai stated: "*Xiao* means to dissolve; *yao* means distant. Dissolving all encumbrances of action and perceiving afar the principle of non-action—wandering thus is called *xiaoyaoyou*."

Second, Zhi Daolin stated: "Treating things as things yet not being treated as a thing by them, one is thus free and unbound by them. Mysterious resonance is swift without haste, hence distant yet capable of all. Wandering the world thus is called *xiaoyaoyou*."

Third, Mu Ye stated: "*Xiaoyao* is the name for unrestrained self-contentment. With perfect virtue inwardly full, one is ever at ease; responding to things with forgetfulness, where does one not penetrate? Wandering the world thus is called *xiaoyaoyou*."

The Inner Chapters clarify the fundamental principles; the Outer Chapters recount events and traces; the Miscellaneous Chapters intermingle principles and events.

Though the Inner Chapters elucidate fundamental principles, they are not without accounts of events; though the Outer Chapters recount events and traces, they abound in subtle principles. The division into chapters is merely based on what each emphasizes.

The reason *Xiaoyaoyou* stands as the first chapter is this: it speaks of those who have attained the Dao—whose wisdom and virtue are luminous and keen, whose every achievement is fitting, and who wander freely in encounter with all things. Thus, it names the chapter after *xiaoyaoyou*. The sagely person without dependencies reflects circumstances like a mirror, having mastered the two wisdoms of provisional and ultimate truth. Therefore, they can bring all realms into great harmony, and so *Qiwulun* follows. Having pointed to the hooves and the heavens, merging the myriad things as one, with a mind serene and still, one can thereby nurture life and safeguard well-being—thus *Yangshengzhu* follows. Having forgotten both good and evil, with both realm and wisdom perfected, one can adapt to change and follow transformation, thereby navigating the human world—thus *Renjianshi* follows. With inner virtue complete, one can extend it outwardly to engage with things, rising and falling with them while inwardly and outwardly merging in profound resonance—thus *Dechongfu* follows. Like still water or a flowing mirror, engaging with things without attachment, forgetting both virtue and form, one reaches the ultimate union of inner and outer—thereby able to shape and perfect all beings, and so *Dazongshi* follows. The true sages of antiquity, knowing both Heaven and humanity, shared the same work as creation itself, responding while remaining quiescent. Thus, they could guide and govern all beings—hence *Yingdiwang* follows. The chapters from *Pianmu* onward all take their titles from the first two characters of each, without further significance, and so their order is not discussed here.

Since ancient times, reclusive scholars of the Jin and Han dynasties have all studied and interpreted these texts. Though their commentaries leave no room for criticism, filled with elegant phrasing, they all delve into hidden meanings. I, Cheng Xuanying, though unworthy and dull, began my study in youth and have devoted thirty years to deep reflection. Following Guo Xiang’s commentary on the thirty chapters, I have composed this exegesis, totaling thirty fascicles. Though my words may be coarse and my insights clumsy, they at least trace the contours of the text’s intent. I dare not presume to leave this for later generations; it merely serves to record what I might otherwise forget.

**[Collation Note]** (1) The character "蹄" is erroneously interpolated in the Song edition; following the meaning of *The Equality of Things and Opinions* ("Heaven and earth are one finger; the myriad things are one horse"), it has been deleted.

**Preface to the *Zhuangzi***

The *Zhuangzi* may be said to have grasped the root. Thus, it never conceals its unbridled words, though they meet with no consensus, they alone resonate.

To respond without convergence is to be correct yet useless; words untethered to things and affairs, though lofty, remain unenacted. Compared to those who abide in stillness, unmoving, and rise only when compelled, there is indeed a distinction—this may be called knowing the heart without intent.

When the heart is without contrivance, it responds to stimuli as they arise, adapting to the moment, speaking only with restraint. Thus, it embodies transformation, flowing through the ages and obscuring things—how could it ever contrive opposition, encountering the singular, and wander in discourse beyond the bounds of convention? This is why it stands unorthodox yet crowns the hundred schools.

Though Zhuangzi himself may not have fully embodied it, his words attain perfection. They penetrate the unity of heaven and earth, order the natures of the myriad things, comprehend the changes of life and death, and illuminate the Dao of inner sageliness and outer kingship. Above, they know the Creator as no-thing; below, they know things as self-created.

His words are vast and expansive, his purport profound and wondrous. The utmost Dao fuses subtlety with elegance; serene and unconstrained, it is free yet not arrogant. Thus it is said: unaware of where propriety leads, one acts wildly yet treads the great square; chewing contentedly, one rejoices in tranquility, drumming one’s belly and wandering in boundless obscurity.

The perfected person (or humane one) reaches the extremity of no-partiality; filial piety and compassion culminate in mutual forgetting. Ritual and music revert to innate ability; loyalty and trust emanate from celestial radiance. Employing this radiance, one’s uncarved simplicity naturally forms. Thus, the sacred vessel transforms alone in the realm of profound obscurity, its source and flow deep and enduring.

Where its long waves surge, where its lofty winds fan, it harmonizes with the fittingness of things and accords with the people’s wishes. It broadens the narrow, unties the entangled, and though the work of liberation remains undone, arrogance and ostentation scatter of themselves.

Thus, reading his book, one feels transcendent, as if already sufficient—traversing Kunlun, crossing the great void, and wandering the courts of the indistinct and fleeting. Even the greedy and restless, if they but briefly grasp its lingering fragrance, savor its overflowing currents, and dimly perceive its echoes and shadows, may yet feel the joy of forgetting form and attaining self-contentment. How much more so for those who plumb its distant depths and delight in eternal years!

Thus it extends, remote and pure, departing from the dust and returning to the ultimate obscurity.

*Written by Guo Xiang of Henan, styled Zixuan.*

*Collected Annotations of the Zhuangzi* (Qing Dynasty), by Guo Qingfan.

**Volume One (Part One)**
*Inner Chapters*
1. "Free and Easy Wandering" (First)

*[1] Exegetical Record*
The term *inner* (内) is established in contrast to *outer*. The *Shuowen* states: "A *pian* (篇) is a book." The character is formed from *bamboo* (竹); the variant with *grass* (艹) refers to a plant name and is incorrect.

*[2] Commentary*
Though small and great differ, when each roams in the field of self-contentment, things follow their nature, affairs match their capacities, and each attains its proper place—then "free and easy wandering" is one and the same. How could there be room for victory or defeat among them?

◎ Guo Qingfan’s note: Liu Yiqing’s *A New Account of the Tales of the World*, in the section on literature, states: "The 'Free and Easy Wandering' chapter of the *Zhuangzi* was long considered difficult; even eminent scholars could only ponder and savor it without extracting principles beyond those of Guo Xiang and Xiang Xiu. When Zhi Daolin was at White Horse Monastery, he conversed with Attendant Censor Feng and touched upon 'free and easy wandering.' Zhi boldly established a new principle beyond the two masters and set forth a distinctive interpretation outside the views of all the worthies. These were matters even the most eminent scholars had failed to fathom, and later generations adopted Zhi’s reasoning."

Liu Xiaobiao’s commentary records the "free and easy wandering" theories of Xiang Xiu and Guo Xiang: "The great Peng soars ninety thousand *li*, while the quail rises from the elm or sandalwood—though small and great differ, each follows its nature. If it attains its proper place, then 'free and easy wandering' is one and the same. Yet the myriad things all rely on something to depend upon; only when they obtain what they depend on can they achieve 'free and easy wandering.' Only the sage merges with things and follows the great transformations, thus able to be without dependence and always pervade. Not only does he pervade himself, but he also ensures that those who depend on something do not lose what they depend on. If they do not lose it, then they are one with the great pervasion."

Zhi’s *Treatise on Free and Easy Wandering* states: "'Free and easy wandering' elucidates the mind of the perfected person. Zhuangzi expounded the great Dao and lodged his meaning in the Peng and the quail. The Peng, with its vast path of sustenance, loses its ease in external matters; the quail, laughing at the distant from its proximity, harbors self-conceit within. The perfected person rides the celestial norm and roams joyfully, wandering boundlessly in freedom. Treating things as things yet not being treated as a thing by things, he is so distant that nothing can grasp him. With mysterious responsiveness that does not act, he is not swift yet moves swiftly—thus he is 'free and easy' and nothing is not fitting. If one has desires and attains what suffices, being content with what suffices, one may feel a joy akin to natural spontaneity—like the hungry who eat their fill or the thirsty who drink their fill. Yet how could they forget the steamed grain or abandon the goblet of fine wine? If it is not supreme sufficiency, how can it be called 'free and easy wandering'?" This is what the annotations of Xiang and Guo did not fully exhaust.

*Exegetical Record*
*Xiao* (逍) is pronounced *xiao* (销), also written as *xiao* (消).
*Yao* (遥) is read as written, also written as *yao* (摇).

◎ Guo Qingfan’s note: The characters *xiaoyao* (逍遥) are not included in the *Shuowen*; the form *xiaoyao* (消摇) is correct. The *Rites of Zhou*’s *Tan Gong* reads *xiaoyao* (消摇) at the gate; the *Records of the Grand Historian*’s "Biography of Sima Xiangru" reads *xiaoyao* (消摇) in the manner of a sheep; the *Jingshan* commentary on the *Tai Xuan Jing* reads, "Though one may wish to *xiaoyao* (消摇), Heaven does not permit it here"; the Han dynasty *Kaimu Stone Inscription* reads, "The radiance of culture shines with *xiaoyao* (消摇)"; the *Wen Xuan*’s "Nine Arguments" by Song Yu reads, "I idly *xiaoyao* (消摇) and wander"; the *Book of Later Han*’s "Biography of Prince Cang of Dongping" reads *xiaoyao* (消摇) and *xiangyang* (相羊). In all these cases, the character is written with *water* (氵) as *xiao* (消) and with *hand* (扌) as *yao* (摇).

The Tang dynasty monk Zhanran’s *Fuhang Zhiguan* quotes Wang Maoye: "*Xiaoyao* (消摇) means the sense of harmonious ease and leisure. When the supreme principle is inwardly sufficient, there is no time when one is not at ease; when the mind abides in responsiveness to things, there is nowhere one does not pervade. Roaming the world with this, it is called *xiaoyao* (消摇)." It also states: "The principle has no hidden depths—it is *xiao* (消) and fitting; form has no great or small—it is *yao* (摇) and pervading. Thus it is called *xiaoyao* (消摇)." This explanation of *xiaoyao* surpasses those of the Confucians.

*You* (游) is read as written, also written as *you* (遊).
"*Xiaoyaoyou* (逍遥游)" is the chapter title, its meaning taken from leisurely roaming without constraint, delighting in self-contentment.

◎ Guo Qingfan’s note: My late father, the Vice Minister, said: "In the 'World' chapter, Zhuangzi himself states that his Daoist arts are replete and cannot be stopped—above, he roams with the Creator."

The opening chapter is titled *Xiaoyaoyou* ("Free and Easy Wandering"), wherein Zhuangzi employs his boundless, unbounded words to express his own analogy.

The commentary states that though small and large differ, their *xiaoyao* is one—this seems to miss Zhuangzi’s intent.

◎ Another note: The *Wen Xuan* annotation to Pan Anren’s *Qiuxing Fu* cites Sima Biao: "To speak of *xiaoyao* and non-action is to say one can wander the great Dao." This is omitted in the *Shiwen*.

*"Fu xiao da"* (夫小大) is pronounced *fu* (音符).
*"Zhi chang"* (之场) is read *zhi liang* (直良反).
*"Shi cheng"* (事称) is read *chi zheng* (尺证反).
*"Ge dang"* (各当) is read *ding lang* (丁浪反).
*"Qi fen"* (其分) is read *fu wen* (符问反).

【Collation Notes】
(1) Supplemented from the Tongzhi Hall edition of the *Jingdian Shiwen*.
(2) In the Song edition of Zhao Jianyi, *ge* (各) is written as *ming* (名).

---

In the Northern Darkness there is a fish, its name is Kun. The Kun is so vast that no one knows how many thousands of *li* it spans. It transforms into a bird, its name is Peng. The Peng’s back is so immense that no one knows how many thousands of *li* it stretches; when it rises in flight, its wings are like clouds hanging from the sky. This bird, when the seas surge, will journey to the Southern Darkness. The Southern Darkness is the Celestial Pond.

【Annotation】
The darkness (*ming*) is like the sea, taking its vast and boundless expanse, hence it is called *ming*. Dongfang Shuo’s *Shizhou Ji* states: "The *ming* sea has no wind, yet its waves rise a hundred *zhang*." Within this vast sea dwells this great fish, illustrating the spontaneity of things’ natures—thus it begins the chapter. The *Xuan Zhong Ji* records: "In the east there is a great fish; a traveler takes a day to pass its head and seven days to pass its tail. When it spawns for three days, the azure sea turns red." Thus we know great things arise in great places—how could this be limited to the Northern Darkness alone?

【Pronunciation and Exegesis】
*"Bei Ming"* (北冥) is also written as *ming* (溟), pronounced *mi jing* (觅经反), meaning the Northern Sea. Ji Kang says: "It takes its name from its vast and boundless expanse." Emperor Jianwen of Liang states: "Its depths are fathomless, hence it is called *ming*." Dongfang Shuo’s *Shizhou Ji* says: "Waters of black hue are called the *ming* sea, where waves rise a hundred *zhang* without wind."

◎ Guo Qingfan’s note: Hui Lin’s *Yiqie Jing Yinyi*, in the second fascicle of the *Mahāyāna Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra*, cites Sima [Biao]: "*Ming* refers to the northern and southern poles, far from the sun and moon, hence the name *ming*." This is omitted in the *Shiwen*.

*"Kun"* (鲲) is pronounced *kun* (徐音昆) by Xu, and *hou wen* (李侯温反) by Li—it is the name of a great fish. Cui Zan says: "*Kun* should be *jing* (鲸)," and Emperor Jianwen concurs.

◎ Guo Qingfan’s note: Fang Yizhi states: "*Kun* originally names small fish, but Zhuangzi uses it for a great fish—his explanation is correct." The *Erya*’s *Shi Yu* glosses *kun* as "fish roe." All fish roe are called *kun*; the *Lu Yu*’s "Fish Prohibitions" mentions *kun* and *er*, with Wei Zhao’s note: "*Kun* is fish roe." Zhang Heng’s *Xijing Fu* speaks of "gathering *kun* and *er*," with Xue Zong’s note: "*Kun* is fish roe." The *Shuowen* lacks a *kun* seal. Duan Yucai says: "Fish roe before hatching are called *kun*. *Kun* is the *luan* (卵) character; Xu Shen writes it as □, pronounced in ancient times like *guan* or *kun*. The *Liji*’s *Neize* mentions 'soaked fish roe sauce,' with Zheng [Xuan] reading *luan* as *kun*. All unhatched are called *luan*; hatched are called *zi*. *Kun* is fish roe, hence Xu Shen subsumes it under □." Zhuangzi calling an immense fish *kun* is a parable of *qiwu* ("equalizing things"), what is meant by "indulging in the boundless to suit oneself." The *Shiwen* cites Li Yi: "*Kun* is the name of a great fish," while Cui Zan and Emperor Jianwen say it should be *jing*—both are mistaken.

*"Qi ji"* (其几) is read *ju qi* (居岂反), the same below.

【Annotation】
As for the reality of Peng and Kun, I do not know it in detail. Zhuangzi’s great intent lies in *xiaoyao*, wandering freely, non-action, and self-contentment—thus he exhausts the extremes of small and large to clarify the fittingness of one’s allotted nature. Those of far-reaching vision should grasp its essential convergence and overlook its incidental expressions; there is no need to quibble over every detail with the living. If it does not harm the grand purport, all may be disregarded.

【Exegesis】
Now, the four seasons race like the wind, and the three luminaries roll like lightning—thus one bears mountains and ridges to abandon the old, and raises boats and valleys to hasten toward the new. Therefore, the transformation of fish into bird is meant to illustrate the grand principle of change.

【Annotation to *Shiwen*】
*Peng* (鹏): *Budeng* (步登) reflex.
Xu reads it as *peng* (朋).
Guo reads it as *fudeng* (甫登) reflex.
Cui reads it as *feng* (凤), saying: "Peng is the ancient form of the character *feng* (凤), not the *feng* that comes bearing auspicious omens."
The *Shuowen* states: "*Peng* (朋) and *peng* (鹏) are both ancient forms of *feng* (凤)." The character *peng* (朋) depicts birds in formation. When the *feng* takes flight, flocks of birds follow in the tens of thousands—hence the character *peng* (朋) was later used for "faction" or "clique."
The *Zilin* states: "*Peng* (鹏) means faction or clique; in antiquity, it was used as the character *feng* (凤)."
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The original text read *yipeng* (以鹏); now, following the sense, it has been emended to *yipeng* (以朋).
◎ Qingfan notes: The *Guangchuan Shu Ba* and *Baohuo Zhong Ming*, as well as *Tongya* 45, both cite Sima as saying: "*Peng* (鹏) is *feng* (凤)." This is omitted in the *Shiwen*.
*Fuzhuang* (夫庄): read as *fu* (符).

The openings of all verses are identical.
*Xingfen* reads *fu* (符), *wen* (问) reversed; the same applies below.
*Daguan* reads *gu* (古), *luan* (乱) reversed.
*Yiyao* reads *yi* (一), *yao* (遥) reversed.

[Commentary 3] [Sub-commentary]
The fish is described in terms of its vastness to show that its head and tail are beyond knowing; the bird is spoken of in terms of its back to likewise suggest that its length is unfathomable. Thus the following text states, "None have known its full extent."
With wings outstretched in fury, feathers bristling in agitation, it prepares to ride the wind and strike the waters. Then, cutting through the clouds, bearing the azure sky upon its back, it soars and wheels, brushing the heavens, casting its shade and spreading its shadow like the drifting clouds that descend from the edge of the sky.

[Exegesis]
*Sima Biao* says: "Like clouds hanging at the edge of the sky."
*Cui* says: "*Chui* (垂) means 'edge'; its vastness is like a cloud covering one side of the sky."

[Commentary 4] [Annotation]
Only the dark sea suffices to turn its body; only ninety thousand *li* suffice to bear its wings. Is this mere fondness for the marvelous? It is simply that great things must arise from great places, and great places must give rise to such great things—this is the natural principle, not to be feared as a loss. Why then trouble the heart over such matters?

[Sub-commentary]
*Yun* (运) means "to turn." *Shi* (是) is a demonstrative. This *peng* bird is so massive that without turning in the sea, it cannot ascend; all this is inevitable, not a matter of preference. Moreover, as its form transforms, its nature changes with it. Once a fish, it swam in the Northern Sea; now a bird, it soars toward the Southern Darkness. Though its rise and fall differ in nature, its freedom remains the same—just as life and death, gathering and dispersal, are but encounters with circumstances, and the myriad transformations have never ceased to be the self. The transformation from fish to bird, journeying from north to south, signifies this: the bird is a creature of the void, and the south is the direction of the morning star; the fish is a creature of stagnation, and the north is the realm of darkness. This illustrates turning toward light and away from darkness, abandoning stagnation to seek progress—hence the use of the southern bird and northern fish to point the way of the Dao. The great sea and vast rivers originate from creation, not human effort, and so are called the "Heavenly Pool."

[Exegesis]
*Haijun* (海运): *Sima* says: "*Yun* (运) means 'to turn.'"
*Xiang Xiu* says: "Without the sea, it cannot move, hence 'sea-turning.'"
*Jianwen* says: "*Yun* (运) means 'to shift.'"
◎ *Qingfan* notes: The *Yupian* defines *yun* (运) as "to move." The *Huntian Yi* states: "The heavens move like a wheel's hub," meaning the heavens' motion is ceaseless. Here, *yun* should also be glossed as "to move." *Zhuangzi* speaks of the *peng* moving ceaselessly over the sea, then shifting to the Heavenly Pool to rest. (The *Shuowen* defines *xi* (徙) as "to move"; *Duan*’s commentary: "To go and stop, then finally stop, is to shift one's place.") The following text, citing the *Qi Xie* on the sixth-month rest, confirms this. *Guo*’s interpretation—"only the dark sea suffices to turn its body"—and the exegesis citing *Sima* and *Xiang Xiu* are both incorrect.
*Qi hao* (岂好): *hu* (呼), *bao* (报) reversed; the same applies below.
*Dachu* (大处): *chang* (昌), *lü* (虑) reversed; the same applies below.
*He cuo* (何厝): *qi* (七), *gu* (故) reversed. Originally written as *cuo* (措).
◎ *Lu Wenchang* says: According to the *Shuowen*, *cuo* (厝) means "whetstone," while *cuo* (措) means "to place"; the two are often conflated in common usage. Here, *Zhuangzi*’s annotation uses *cuo* (措), which aligns with the *Shuowen*.
[Collation]
(1) The ancients often mixed these usages; henceforth, they are distinguished by meaning and not repeated.
(2) Emended following the *Wenxuan*.

The *Qi Xie* is a record of anomalies. It states: "When the roc migrates to the Southern Darkness, it strikes the water for three thousand *li*, spirals upward on the whirlwind for ninety thousand *li*, and departs only after a six-month rest. The *ye ma*, the dust motes—all living things are blown about by one another’s breath. Is the deep blue of the sky its true color? Or is it simply so distant that it has no end? From above, the view below must appear the same.

◎ **Annotation**: A wing so vast cannot easily lift; thus, it must spiral on the whirlwind before ascending, and only after ninety thousand *li* can it fully sustain itself. With such wings, how could it suddenly take flight and descend after a few *ren*? All this is unavoidable, not a matter of preference.

◎ **Exegesis**: *Qi* is the surname, *Xie* the given name—a person’s name. It may also refer to a book’s title, as the state of Qi possessed such a work of *pai xie* (jesting and harmonious) records. *Zhi* means "to record"; *ji*, "to strike"; *tuan*, "to spiral"; *fu yao*, "whirlwind." The book attributed to Qi Xie records many strange and marvelous events, which Zhuangzi cites as evidence to affirm the truth of his own words. When the great roc sets out for the Southern Abyss, it cannot take flight abruptly. Instead, it beats its wings, stirring the water for three thousand *li*, stumbling forward before finally lifting off. Then, twisting and turning, it stirs the wind with furious flapping, riding the currents upward in a spiral. After traversing ninety thousand *li* and half a year’s time, it arrives at last, composed and content, to rest. This is merely sufficient—how could it be a matter of choice?

◎ **Phonetic Glosses**:
*Qi Xie*: *hu jie* (户皆) reversed. Sima [Biao] and Cui [Yan] both say it is a person’s name. [Wang] Jianwen says it is a book.
◎ **Yu Yue** notes: Given that the text below reads, "Xie states," it is more fitting to take it as a person’s name. If it were a book’s title, it could not simply be called *Xie*.
*Zhi guai*: *Zhi* means "to record"; *guai*, "anomalies."
*Shui ji*: Cui [Yan] says: As it prepares to fly, it beats its wings, striking the water in a stumbling motion. *Liang* (踉): *liang* (亮). *Qiang* (跄): *qi liang* (七亮) reversed.
*Tuan*: *tu duan* (徒端) reversed. Sima [Biao] says: "to spiral upward." Also pronounced *bo*. Cui [Yan] says: "to flap its wings and spiral upward."
◎ **Lu Wenchang** notes: It should read "originally written as *bo* (搏), pronounced *bo*." In his gloss on *tuan zhi* (抟埴) in the *Kaogong Ji*, Lu [Deming] also gives *bo* as Liu’s pronunciation, failing to distinguish the characters—an error.
◎ **Qing Fan** notes: The *Yiqiejing Yinyi* (72) cites Sima [Biao]: "*Ji* means 'to move.'" This is omitted in the *Shiwen*. The *Wenxuan*’s *Jiang Wentong Zati Shi* annotation cites Sima: "*Tuan* means 'circular.' *Fu yao* is an upward-moving wind; circular flight ascending is like *fu yao*." The *Fan Yanlong Guyi Zeng Wang Zhongshu Shi* annotation cites Sima: "*Tuan* means 'circular.' Circular flight ascending is like *fu yao*." The *Zhang Jingyang Qiming* annotation, the *Taiping Yulan* (9 and 927), and the *Chuxue Ji* (1) all cite Sima: "*Fu yao* is an upward-moving wind." The citations vary slightly, differing somewhat from the *Shiwen*.
◎ **Further note**: The *Shuowen* defines *tuan* as "to make circular with the hands," anciently borrowed as *zhuan* (专). The *Hanshu Tianwen Zhi* reads: "When *qi* is low, it spreads; when *qi* of the masses is *tuan*..." Yan Shigu’s annotation: "*Tuan* means 'concentrated.'" The *Jiyun* defines *tuan* as "to monopolize" (with *shan* also carrying the sense of "concentration") and "to gather." *Tuan fu yao er shang* means "to concentrate the wind’s power and ascend." The *Shiwen*’s citations do not capture the meaning of *tuan*.
*Fu yao*: Xu [Shen] pronounces it *yao*—a wind’s name. Sima [Biao] says: "An upward-moving wind is called *fu yao*." The *Erya* says: "*Fu yao* is called *biao*." Guo Pu says: "A violent wind rising from below."
◎ **Lu Wenchang** notes: "From below upward" is inverted; corrected here according to the *Erya* annotation.
*Er shang*: *shi zhang* (时掌) reversed. Same as the annotation.
*Zi sheng*: *sheng* (升). Same below.
*Jue ran*: *xi que* (喜缺) reversed. Same below.
*Shu ren*: *se zhu* (色主) reversed. Same below.
*Fei le*: *yue* (岳), or *wu xiao* (五孝) reversed.

◎ **Annotation**: The great bird departs for half a year before resting at the Celestial Pond; the small bird flies for half a morning before alighting on the elm or sandalwood. Though their capacities differ, in following their nature, they are one.
◎ **Phonetic Glosses**:
*Qiang*: *qi yang* (七羊) reversed.
*Fang*: *fang* (方).
◎ **Jia Shifu** notes: "Departs with a six-month rest" means "riding the long wind," forming a parallel with the later phrase "if the season does not permit, it alights on the earth." Zhuangzi’s prose often cannot be interpreted strictly at the level of individual words.

◎ **Annotation**: All these are what the roc relies upon to fly. The "wild horses" are roving *qi*. *Erya* states: "Beyond the city lies the outskirts; beyond the outskirts, the pasture; beyond the pasture, the wilds." This speaks of the time of spring’s vitality, when yang *qi* stirs into motion. Gazing afar at the marshes and wetlands, one sees them surge like galloping horses—hence the name "wild horses." Dust is raised earth; the finest dust is called "motes." Between heaven and earth, the *qi* of living things breathes and stirs, mutually propelling one another to lift the roc aloft. Now, the four modes of birth teem in profusion, the myriad things differ in form and disposition, and their needs and dependencies vary. Thus the roc beats its wings that span the sky, riding the winds in freedom; the cicada spreads its wings of sudden ascent, darting to the elm or sandalwood in contentment. All follow their nature in movement, endowed by the workings of creation. They harbor no attachment to far or near, nor do they entertain thoughts of pride or arrogance. Those who embody this spirit—how could they speak of striving or emulation?

◎ **Phonetic Glosses**:
*Ye ma* (野马): Sima [Biao] says: "The roving *qi* in marshes during spring." Cui [Yuan] says: "The *qi* between heaven and earth surges like wild horses."
*Chen ai* (尘埃): Pronounced *āi*. Cui [Yuan] says: "The *qi* between heaven and earth billows thickly like rising dust."
*Xiang chui* (相吹): Pronounced as written. Cui [Yuan]’s version reads *chui* (炊).
◎ **Qingfan’s Note**: The characters *chui* (吹, "blow") and *chui* (炊, "steam") were interchangeable in antiquity. *Jiyun* states: "*Chui* (炊) means rising through cumulative motion." *Xunzi*’s "Zhongni" chapter reads, "can be steamed and □," while this book’s "Zai You" chapter reads, "in ease and nonaction, the myriad things steam and accumulate"—both gloss *chui* (炊) as interchangeable with *chui* (吹).
◎ **Further Note**: Master Zhuang first states that the roc’s flight and rest each accord with its nature, then elaborates that "wild horses" and "motes" are all living things propelled by mutual breath—an analogy for the roc’s pure adherence to spontaneity, just as "wild horses" and "motes" rise through cumulative motion without deliberate intent. Guo [Xiang]’s interpretation of "what the roc relies upon to fly" appears mistaken.
*Suo feng* (所冯): Pronounced *pí bīng*. Also written as *凭*.
◎ **Lu Wenchang’s Note**: The present annotation uses *凭*; this has been corrected.

**[4] [Commentary]**
Now observing the deep blue of heaven, we cannot know whether this is truly heaven’s proper hue, or whether heaven is simply so distant as to be boundless. When the roc gazes down upon the earth from above, it appears no different from how man gazes up at heaven from below. Thus, it halts its plans to journey south, for the roc knows not the distance in *li*—it merely presses forward with what suffices to sustain its flight and departs.

**[Subcommentary]**
Gazing upward at the vault of heaven, one finds it vast and remote; the azure expanse stretches high and far, its measure beyond reckoning. How could this hazy blue truly be heaven’s proper color? Yet the roc, dwelling in the midst of heaven, and man, dwelling upon the earth below, see no difference in their perspectives—the roc’s downward gaze is no different from man’s upward gaze. If man cannot discern heaven’s true color, how could the roc know the earth’s distance? With strength sufficient to sustain itself, it reaches the Southern Darkness; the roc’s calculations extend no further than this.

**[Philological Notes]**
*《色邪》* Pronounced *yú jiē*, an auxiliary particle expressing uncertainty. The same applies hereafter.
◎ **Lu Wenchang’s Note**: Formerly pronounced *yú jiē*; now corrected according to the *Yi*’s *Shiwen*.

**[Textual Collation]**
(1) *Que wu* notes: The *Wen Ru Hai* edition also reads *则* (thus).
(2) *Que wu* reads *则* as *而* (and).
(3) Zhao Jianyi’s edition reads *足自* (sufficient in itself) as *自足* (self-sufficient).
(4) The character *埴* is emended according to the *Kao Gong Ji*.
(5) The above thirty-eight characters were originally misplaced beneath the preceding commentary.
(6) The character *地* (earth) is emended according to the *Xu Guyi Congshu* edition.
(7) Zhao’s edition omits the character *矣* (thus).

Moreover, if the accumulation of water is not deep, it will lack the strength to bear a great vessel. Pour a cup of water into a hollow in the hall, and a mustard seed may serve as a boat; place a cup there, and it will run aground—water too shallow for a vessel so large. If the accumulation of wind is not deep, it will lack the strength to bear great wings. Thus, only at ninety thousand *li* does the wind lie beneath it, and only then can it ride the wind. With the azure sky at its back and nothing to obstruct its path, only then does it set its course for the south.

**[1] [Commentary]**
All this clarifies why the roc flies so high: because its wings are vast. A small substance requires no great support, so a great substance cannot rely on something small. Thus, principle has its ultimate limits, and things have their fixed bounds; each suffices for its task, and their success is one and the same. If one loses the essence of life by pursuing it beyond what is most fitting—if one’s affairs exceed one’s strength and one’s actions fail to accord with one’s nature—then even wings spanning the heavens cannot escape exhaustion, and even the most powerful flight cannot avoid distress.

**[Subcommentary]**
*且夫* (Moreover) is a borrowed phrase, a casual introductory term. *夫* (Now) marks the beginning, the opening thread of discourse.

Accumulation means gathering. Thickness means depth. A cup is a small vessel. A hollow is a sunken depression, referring to the low-lying ground of a hall or courtyard. A mustard seedling is a blade of grass. To be stuck means to adhere. This introduces the analogy.

If one overturns a cup of water into the sunken ground of a hall, and uses a blade of grass as a boat, it will float and drift without obstruction. But if one instead uses the cup as a boat, it is inherently impossible. Why? Because the water is shallow and the boat is large, it will stick to the ground and fail to move. Thus, a great boat requires deep water, while a tiny mustard seedling does not wait for a mighty current. If their sizes are fitting, then all things may roam freely.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*且夫*: pronounced *fú*.
*覆*: pronounced *fú*; Cui’s edition writes *杯* as *杯*.
*坳堂*: pronounced *yújiāo*, or *wūliǎo*; Li also reads *yījiǔ*. Cui says: "The path of the hall is called a hollow." Sima says: "To level the ground." Zhi Dun says: "It refers to ground with hollows and mounds."
*芥*: pronounced *jímài*; Xu reads *gǔmài*; another reading is *gǔxiá*. Li says: "A small blade of grass."
*则胶*: Xu and Li read *gǔxiào*; another reading is the standard pronunciation. Cui says: "To stick to the ground." Li says: "To adhere."
*称事*: pronounced *chìzhèng*. The same applies thereafter.

The *濟* is pronounced *zǐxì*, and in some editions written as *齊*, read as the standard pronunciation. The *之生* in some editions is also written as *主*. The *至當* is pronounced *dīnglàng*, and the same applies thereafter.

**[Section 2] [Exegesis]**
This is a combined metaphor. If the water is not deep and vast, then a great boat cannot be borne afloat; if the wind is not lofty and strong, the great wings cannot soar to the heavens. Thus, the small bird flies for half a morning, darting up to the elm and sandalwood; the roc of ninety thousand *li* rides the whirlwind that stirs beneath it.

**[Section 3] [Commentary]**
The reason it now plans to journey south is not that it delights in height or yearns for distance, but because without the accumulation of wind, obstruction and blockage cannot be overcome. This is the roc’s freedom of the Way.

**[Exegesis]**
*培* means "to bear." *夭* means "to break." *阏* means "to block." Initially relying on the whirlwind, it can ascend; bearing the weight of accumulated wind, it then takes flight. Thereafter, it bears the azure sky above and rides the spine of the wind below, soaring to the heavens in a single bound, journeying for six months before coming to rest. Nets and snares cannot reach it, arrows and traps do not encroach—how could calamities of breaking or blockage ever befall it? Truly, by relying on what is fitting and attaining its proper place, it roams freely to the Southern Sea—is this not fitting indeed!

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*而後乃今培*: pronounced *péi*, meaning "to bear." Xu reads *fúbēi*, and another pronunciation is *fúběi*. In some editions, it is written as *陪*.
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The current edition writes "three" as "one," which is incorrect.
◎ Qing Fan’s case: Wang Niansun says: *培* is akin to *馮* (to ride). *馮* means "to mount." The wind is beneath the roc, hence it is said to "bear"; the roc is above the wind, hence it is said to "ride." Only after ninety thousand *li* is it above the wind, and only then can it ride the wind, thus it is said: "and only then does it now bear the wind." If *培* were glossed as "weight," it would have no connection to the preceding text. *馮* and *培* are phonetically close, hence their meanings are also related. In the *Book of Han*, Zhou’s enfeoffment was changed to *剻城侯*; Yan Shigu says: *剻* is pronounced *péi* in Lü Chen’s *Characters*. The *Annals of Chu and Han* writes it as *馮城侯*. *陪* and *馮* are phonetically close, which serves as evidence. (The ancient pronunciation of *馮* is in the *蒸* rhyme group, while *陪* is in the *之* group. The sounds of the *之* group are close to the *蒸* group, hence *陪* and *馮* are also phonetically close. The *Shuowen* says: *陪* means "to fill." Wang Yi’s commentary on the *Li Sao* says: *馮* means "to fill." Since *陪* and *馮* are phonetically close, both are glossed as "to fill." Wen Ying’s commentary on the *Book of Han*’s "Annals of Emperor Wen" says: *陪* means "to assist." Zhang Yan’s commentary on the *Tables of Officials and Nobles* says: *馮* means "to assist." The *Shuowen* says: *倗* means "to assist." *陪*, *馮*, and *倗* are phonetically close, hence all are glossed as "to assist." The *Shuowen* says: *倗* is from *人* with *朋* as its phonetic, read like *陪位*. ** is from *邑* with *崩* as its phonetic, read like *陪*. In the *Book of Han*, Wang Zun’s biography mentions the bandits of Mount Nan, *傰宗* et al.; Su Lin says: *傰* is pronounced *péng*. Jin Zhuo says: it is pronounced *bèi*. In the *Mozi*, the *Shangxian* chapter says: "In defending a city, one must *倍畔*"; the *Feiming* chapter writes *倍* as *崩*. These are all examples of this.)
Now, according to the *Shuowen*: *培* means "to augment." *培風* means using the wind to augment the strength of the great wings, aiding their high flight. Master Lu’s gloss of "weight" is unclear; Wang’s interpretation is more fitting.
*背負青天*: One reading connects *背* to the preceding sentence.
*夭*: pronounced *yúbiǎo*. Sima says: "to break."
*阏*: Xu reads *yúgé*, and another pronunciation is *yè*. Sima says: "to stop." Li says: "to block."
◎ Qing Fan’s case: The *Wen Xuan* commentary on Liu Xiaobiao’s *Bianming Lun* cites Sima as saying: *夭* means "to break"; *阏* means "to stop." This is to say, there is nothing that breaks or stops it from passing through. This is more detailed than the citation in the *Exegetical Notes*.

**[Collation Notes]**
(1) *生* is amended according to the *Exegetical Notes* and the *Shide Tang* edition.
(2) *是* is supplied according to Liu Wendian’s *Supplemented and Corrected Edition*.
(3) Amended according to the exegesis below: "the small bird darts up to the elm and sandalwood."
(4) ** is amended according to the *Book of Han*.

The cicada and the fledgling dove laugh at it, saying: "We dart up and fly, striking the elm and sandalwood, and sometimes fail to reach them, falling to the ground—what need is there to journey ninety thousand *li* to the south?" Those who travel to the nearby wilderness carry three meals and return with their bellies still full; those who journey a hundred *li* must pound grain for provisions the night before.

Those who journey a thousand *li* must gather provisions for three months.

How little do these two creatures know!

**[Annotation]**
If one is content with their nature, then even the great Peng has no cause to esteem itself above the small bird, nor does the small bird envy the celestial pond, for its glory and desires are already fulfilled. Thus, though great and small differ, their freedom is one and the same.

**[Exegesis]**
The *tiao* is the cicada, which emerges in the seventh or eighth month, its body a deep purple-green; it is also called the *diaoliao*. The *yujiu* is the *hujiu*, the same as the present-day speckled dove. *Jue* describes sudden swiftness. *Qiang* means to gather or to dart. *Fang* is sandalwood. *Kong* means to cast, to draw, or to exhaust. *Xi* means "why." *Zhi* means "to go." Hearing of the vastness of the Peng bird, which relies on wind and water to soar aloft, the cicada and dove mock its great size and toil, delighting in their own small forms and ease. Their leaps rise no higher than a few *ren*, darting to the elm and sandalwood to roost; sometimes they fail to reach the next grove, alighting on the ground to rest before taking flight again. Free and content in their nature, they find joy in this. Why must one endure six months of travel, a journey of ninety thousand *li*, braving hardship to reach the south? Those who, in their smallness, laugh at the great, boasting of their own limits while failing to attain freedom—such a thing has never been.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Tiao* is pronounced *tiao*. Sima [Biao] says: the cicada.

**"Xuejiu"** is read as written. Another pronunciation is *yujiao* (于角反). Originally also written as *xue* (鸴), with the same pronunciation. Some versions write it as *yu* (鸒), pronounced *yu* (预). Cui [Yan] says: *Xue* is read as *hua* (滑); *huajiu* (滑鸠) is another name for *huadiao* (滑雕). Sima [Biao] says: *Xuejiu* is a small turtledove. Li [Yi] says: It is a *gudiao* (鹘雕). The *Mao Shi Caomu Shu* states: *Gujiu* (鹘鸠) is the *banjiu* (班鸠). Jianwen [Xiao Gang] says: As in the *Yue Ling*, "the calling turtledove brushes its feathers." **Qingfan’s note:** Yu Yue says: The *Shiwen* states: *Xue* is sometimes written as *yu* (鸒), pronounced *yu* (预). According to the *Wen Xuan*’s Jiang Wenchong’s *Za Ti Shi* ("Beneath the mugwort, the *yu* flies"), Li Shan’s commentary cites this passage from *Zhuangzi* to explain it. He also quotes Sima [Biao] saying: *Yujiu* (鸒鸠) is a small bird. Mao Chang’s *Shi Zhuan* says: *Yusi* (鸒斯) is *beiju* (鹎居); *beiju* is the crow. Pronounced *yu* (豫). Thus, the version Li [Yi] relied upon originally wrote *yu* (鸒), not *xue* (学). The *Shiwen*’s citation of Sima [Biao]—"*Xuejiu* is a small turtledove"—is a later emendation, not the original text. **Now, according to the *Shiwen*: *Xue* is also written as *xue* (鸴).** The *Shuowen* states: *Xue* (鸴) is *hanxue* (雗鸴), the mountain magpie, a bird that knows what is to come. Sometimes written as [missing character]. The *Erya*’s *Shi Niao* says: *Xue* (鸴) is the mountain magpie. Those who write it as *xue* (学) are likely using *xue* as a loan character. *Jiu* (鸠) is the general name for the five turtledoves; *xue* (鸴) and *jiu* (鸠) are thus two different creatures. The explanations cited in the *Shiwen* do not clearly distinguish them.

**"Wo jue"**—Xiang [Xiu] and Xu [Yuan] read it as *que* (缺反), while Li [Yi] reads it as *xue* (穴反). Li Yi says: It describes swiftness. **"Qiang"** (抢) is read as *qiang* (七良反). Sima [Biao] and Li [Yi] say: It means "to alight." Cui [Yan] says: It means "to attach." Zhi Dun says: *Qiang* means "to dash." **Yu Yue says:** Wang [Niansun]’s *Jing Zhuan Shi Ci* states: *Ze* (则) means "or." He cites the *Shiji*’s *Chen Chengxiang Shijia* ("or else I will regret it later") as evidence.

Here the term *ze* (则) should likewise be glossed as "or." *Yu* (榆) is pronounced *yú* by Xu [Shen]; it is the name of a tree. *Fāng* (枋) is pronounced *fāng* by Xu. Li [Yi] says: It is sandalwood. Cui [Yan] says: It is the trunk. Or else: It is the name of a tree. ◎ Lu Wenchang says: The current text reads "Cui says: It is a tree," which is redundant with what follows; the character *xi* (系) is an error.

*Kòng* (控) is read as *kùgòng*. Sima [Biao] says: It means "to cast." He also says: It means "to pull." Cui [Yan] says: It means "to knock." ◎ Yu Yue says: The character *ér* (而) below should be followed by *tú* (图). The preceding passage reads, "And only now will I plan to fly south," and this continues the thought. The *Wen Xuan* commentary cites it as: "How can I traverse ninety thousand *li* and *plan to fly south*?"

**Note [2]:** The farther one travels, the more provisions one must gather; thus, the larger the wings, the thicker the accumulated *qi*.

**Explication:** *Shì* (适) means "to go." *Mǎngcāng* (莽苍) is the color of the outskirts—distant and indistinct. *Guǒrán* (果然) describes a state of fullness. Traveling to the outskirts, one departs and returns within three meals; the journey is not far, and the stomach remains full. For a journey of a hundred *li*, the distance is somewhat greater, and one must pound grain for a single night’s provisions. For a journey of a thousand *li*, the road is long, and one must gather three months’ worth of food to sustain the round trip. Thus, Guo [Xiang]’s commentary states: The farther one travels, the more provisions one must gather; the larger the wings, the thicker the accumulated *qi*.

**Pronunciation and Meaning:** *Mǎng* (莽) is read as *mòlàng* or *mòláng*. *Cāng* (苍) is read as *qīdàng* or with its standard pronunciation. Sima [Biao] says: *Mǎngcāng* is the color of the near outskirts. Li [Yi] says: It means "near the wilds." Zhi Dun says: It refers to the space between graves. Cui [Yan] says: It is the color of the grassy wilds. *Sāncān* (三餐) is read as *qīdān*. *Guǒrán* (果然) is read with its standard pronunciation or as *kǔhuǒ*. All commentators say: It describes a state of fullness. *Chōng* (舂) is read as *shùróng*. *Liáng* (粮) is read as *liáng*.

**Note [3]:** The two creatures refer to the *peng* and the cicada. Comparing the great to the small equalizes their differing inclinations. Why do their inclinations differ? Do they knowingly choose difference? All things are thus by nature, not by design. This is the essence of *xiaoyaoyou* (逍遥).

**Explication:** Guo’s commentary states: The two creatures are the *peng* and the cicada; comparing the great to the small equalizes their differing inclinations. The great *peng* rides the wind for ninety thousand *li*, while the small bird darts between the elm and the sandalwood—though their distances differ, their suitability to their natures is the same. Neither knows the extent of its journey; each takes what suffices and sustains itself, its heavenly mechanism unfolding of itself, without knowing why. Since neither intends superiority or inferiority, how can there be preference for one over the other? The attainment of *xiaoyaoyou* lies herein!

And calling the *peng* a "creature" (*chong*) follows the *Da Dai Liji*, which states: "In the east, the scaled creatures number three hundred and sixty, with the winged dragon as their chief; in the south, the feathered creatures number three hundred and sixty, with the phoenix as their chief; in the west, the furred creatures number three hundred and sixty, with the *qilin* as their chief; in the north, the shelled creatures number three hundred and sixty, with the spirit turtle as their chief; in the center, the naked creatures number three hundred and sixty, with the sage as their chief." Thus, in general parlance, the *peng* is termed a "creature." ◎ Yu Yue notes: The "two creatures" refer to the cicada and the turtledove mentioned above, which mock the *peng*—so small that they cannot comprehend the *peng*'s greatness. Guo's commentary, which takes the "two creatures" as the *peng* and the cicada, is mistaken.

**Textual Notes:**
(1) The character *qiang* (抢) is emended following the original text of the *Shiwen*; the same applies below.
(2) The *Quemiu* and the Jiangnan old edition include the words *er zhi* (而止) after *fang* (枋).
(3) The *Quemiu* edition reads *guo* (果) as *ke* (颗).
(4) The *Quemiu* edition includes the words *bi ye* (彼也) above and below this sentence.

Lesser knowledge does not reach greater knowledge; short years do not reach long years. How do we know this is so? The morning mushroom knows not the dark and the dawn; the cicada knows not spring and autumn—these are short years. South of Chu lies the *Mingling*, for which five hundred years make a spring, five hundred years an autumn. In high antiquity there was the great *chun* tree, for which eight thousand years made a spring, eight thousand years an autumn. Yet Pengzu alone is renowned for his longevity—how pitiful that the multitude should compare themselves to him!

**Commentary:** All things have their nature, and each nature has its limit. All are like years and knowledge—how could they be attained by striving? From this point through the mention of Liezi, examples of long and short years and knowledge are adduced, each credible in its own way, yet none sufficient to surpass the others. Only the person free from dependence, who forgets self and others, who obscures these manifold differences, finds all ways equally attained while claiming no merit. Thus, one who unites the great and the small is one who is neither great nor small; if there were great and small, then even the great *peng* and the sparrow, the minister and the wind-rider, would alike be burdened by things. One who equalizes life and death is one who is neither alive nor dead; if there were life and death, then even the great *chun* and the cicada, Pengzu and the morning mushroom, would be equally cut short. Therefore, to wander where there is neither small nor great is to wander without end; to be obscured where there is neither life nor death is to be without limit. But if one’s *xiaoyaoyou* is bound to a particular realm, then though one be set free to wander, there will still be an end—one remains dependent.

**Commentary:** All things receive *qi* differently and are endowed with distinct allotments. In knowledge, some are bright, some dim; in years, some are short, some long. Thus, the morning mushroom, the *Mingling*, the minister, and Master Rong are all like years and knowledge—how could they be attained by striving? Hence, we know that the natures of things differ and cannot be forcibly imitated.

**Explanatory Notes:**
*Xiaozhi* (小知): read as *zhi* (智, "knowledge"); the base text also writes it as *zhi*. The same applies to *dazhi* (大知) and the commentary below. *Nianzhi* (年知) follows this pattern.
*Qishang* (跂尚): read as *qichi* (丘豉反). The same applies below.
*Leiwu* (累物): read as *leiwei* (劣伪反). The same applies below.

**Commentary:**
*Xi* (奚): means "how."
*Ran* (然): means "thus."
How do we know that years and knowledge do not reach one another to such a degree? This is a hypothetical question to which the following provides the answer.

**Commentary:**
This answers the preceding question.

The "morning mushroom" refers to a fungus that grows when the weather is stagnant and rainy, sprouting from manure piles through heat and steam. It thrives in damp shade but dies upon exposure to sunlight. It is also called the "great zhi" (芝), born at dawn and perishing by dusk—hence the name "morning mushroom." The last day of the lunar month is called *hui* (晦), while the first day is called *shuo* (朔). If it encounters prolonged overcast conditions, it withers within days, never enduring a full thirty-day month—thus it knows nothing of *hui* or *shuo*.

The *huigui* (蟪蛄) is the summer cicada. It emerges from wheat stalks—also called "wheat nodes"—living from summer to autumn, and so knows nothing of spring or winter. The mushroom is born at dawn and dies by dusk, while the cicada grows in summer and perishes in autumn. Such is the brevity of their lifespans—hence they are called "lesser years."

---

The *Mingling* (冥灵) and the great *chun* (椿) are both names of trees, with the sprouting of leaves marking spring and their falling marking autumn. The *Mingling* grows south of Chu, taking two thousand years as a single year. The phrase "of ancient times" refers to the era of Fuxi. The great *chun* tree flourished in that distant age, taking thirty-two thousand years as a single year. The *Mingling* blooms once every five hundred years, while the great *chun* sheds its leaves once every eight thousand years—both spanning such vast springs and autumns that they are called "greater years."

A single name for it is *shunchun*. This differs slightly from what is cited in the *Explanations of Text*.

Now, when the disparity between lifespans is as vast as this, compared to what ordinary people find lamentable, it is indeed lamentable. Yet ordinary people never lament such things, for each being’s nature has its own limit. If one truly knows these limits, then even the slightest difference cannot be bridged—what in the world is there left to grieve? For things never diminish the great out of desire for the small, but invariably envy the great out of the small. Thus, the distinction between great and small has its own fixed allotment, beyond the reach of envy or desire. If this is so, then the burden of envy and desire can be severed. Grief arises from this burden; when the burden is cut off, grief departs. And where grief departs, there has never been a case of one’s nature and life failing to find peace.

---

*Pengzu* was surnamed *Jian* and named *Keng*, a great-great-grandson of Emperor Zhuanxu. Skilled in nurturing his nature and adept at regulating the cauldron, he presented pheasant soup to Yao, who enfeoffed him at Pengcheng. As his Way could be taken as a model, he was called *Pengzu*. Living through the Xia and Yin dynasties into the Zhou, he reached eight hundred years of age. *Te* means "alone." Because of his long life and longevity, his fame alone resounded through the world. Yet when ordinary people compare themselves to Pengzu, it is deeply lamentable—yet they do not lament, for Pengzu was endowed by nature with far-reaching longevity, not of the same *qi*-kind as themselves. They set him beyond their speech, not daring to sigh in sorrow. Thus, knowing that life has its bounds, how could it be only Pengzu whom they fall short of by a hair’s breadth? In this way, the *chun* tree and the mushroom, Pengzu and the short-lived, are all equalized. Each abides within its allotted portion, and nature and life find peace.

---

*Pengzu*: Li [Yi] says: His name was *Keng*. A minister of Yao, enfeoffed at Pengcheng. Living from the Yu and Xia through to the Shang, he reached seven hundred years of age, hence his renown for long life. The *Shiben* states: Surnamed *Jian*, named *Keng*, he served as *Shoucangshi* in the Shang and *Zhuxiashi* in the Zhou, living eight hundred years. *Jian* is pronounced *jian*. Another account says he was Laozi. Cui [Yuan] says: A minister of Yao, he served through the Yin era, living seven hundred years. Wang Yi’s commentary on the *Chuci* *Tianwen* states: *Peng Keng* is *Pengzu*, who served Emperor Yao. Even at seven hundred years, Pengzu still lamented his lack of longevity, regretting that his pillow was too low and his spittle did not reach far enough. A great-great-grandson of Emperor Ku.

Lu Wenchang notes: The *Yupian* gives *Jian* as *zijian*, a surname, which matches this exactly. This was the ancient pronunciation; those who alter it to *jian* based on the *Guangyun* are incorrect.

Wang Qingfan notes: The *Shenxian Zhuan* says: Pengzu’s personal name was *Keng*, a great-great-grandson of Emperor Zhuanxu. By the end of the Yin dynasty, he was seven hundred and sixty-seven years old and showed no signs of aging. He then went west of the Flowing Sands—he did not die of old age. Now, according to the *Records of the Historian*, *Chu Shijia*: Zhuanxu begot *Cheng*, *Cheng* begot *Juan Zhang*, *Juan Zhang* begot *Chong Li*. *Chong Li* was killed by Emperor Ku, who appointed his younger brother *Wu Hui* to succeed *Chong Li* as *Huozheng*. *Wu Hui* begot *Lu Zhong*, *Lu Zhong* begot *Pengzu*. Tracing the lineage, Pengzu was the son of *Lu Zhong*, a great-great-grandson of Zhuanxu, what the *Li* calls a *laisun*. Cheng Xuanying’s commentary mistakenly follows the *Shenxian Zhuan* in calling him a great-great-grandson of Zhuanxu. The *Explanations of Text* cites Wang Yi’s *Chuci Zhangju*, making him a great-great-grandson of Emperor Ku, which is also incorrect. (Emperor Ku was the nephew of Zhuanxu, named [ ]. Pengzu was the great-great-grandson of Zhuanxu’s son *Cheng*, making him Emperor Ku’s great-great-grandnephew.)

*Te wen*: Read as written. Cui’s version has *dai wen*.

"The *Zhi Xuan* is pronounced as *xuan*. The *Hao Fen* is pronounced *fu wen* (符问), or alternatively *fang yun* (方云)."

**[Collation Notes]**
(1) The *Que Wu* cites Cheng Xuanying’s edition, which includes the phrase "此大年也" (*this is great longevity*) under the "Autumn Floods" section.
(2) The character explanations are omitted here following the annotations below.
(3) "枕高" (*pillowing the heights*)—the original text of the *Shi Wen* is also erroneous; it has been corrected here according to Wang Yi’s commentary on the *Chuci*.

---

"When Tang questioned Ji, it was thus. In the farthest north of the uninhabited wilds lies the Dark Sea, which is the Celestial Pond. There is a fish there, several thousand *li* in breadth, though none know its length; its name is Kun. There is a bird there, named Peng, whose back is like Mount Tai, whose wings are like clouds hanging from the sky. It mounts the whirlwind, spiraling upward on the *yang* vortex for ninety thousand *li*, piercing the clouds, bearing the blue heavens on its back, and only then does it set its course southward, bound for the Southern Darkness. The marsh wren laughs at it, saying: 'Where does it think it’s going? I leap and flutter upward, but a few fathoms at most before descending, wheeling among the mugwort and wormwood—this is the utmost of flight! Where does it think it’s going?' Such is the distinction between small and great."

**[1] [Annotation]**
When Tang questioned Ji, it was also said that all things have their limits; when allowed to follow their nature, they flourish. Thus Zhuangzi affirmed the question as correct.

**[Exegesis]**
Tang was a descendant of Emperor Ku and a scion of Xie, surnamed Zi, named Lü, styled Tian Yi. His mother, Fu Du, saw a white vapor piercing the moon and conceived Tang. He was broad below and tapering above, nine *chi* in height. He served the Xia as a feudal lord, possessing sagely virtue, and the feudal lords rallied to him. When Jie’s tyranny prevailed, Tang was imprisoned in the Xia Terrace. Later freed, he allied with the feudal lords at Jingbo, confronted Jie at the ruins of Kunwu, and fought a great battle on the plains of Mingtiao, where Jie fled to Nanchao. After vanquishing Jie, Tang offered the realm to Wu Guang, who refused. Tang then ascended the throne, establishing his capital at Bo, which was later renamed Shang—the founding sovereign of Yin. Ji was a worthy of Tang’s time, also called Tang’s erudite. The *Liezi* refers to him as Xia Ge; *Ge* and *Ji* are phonetically akin, likely a scribal error. As Ji was a worthy, Tang treated him as a teacher, and thus Tang questioned Ji, seeking the ultimate Dao. Ji replied that the natures of things differ, each possessing its inherent allotment; to follow and proceed directly, allowing them to unfold naturally. Tang’s inquiry was profound, imbued with abstruse subtlety, and Zhuangzi affirmed its correctness, hence "it was thus."

**[Shi Wen]**
*Ji*: Li (Yi) says: a worthy of Tang’s time. Another says: Ji Zi. Cui (Yuan) says: the name of those who, like Qi Xie, knew of the *Mingling* and *Da Chun*. Jian (Wen) says: One version: *Tang* means vast, *Ji* means narrow.

◎ Yu Yue says: Li’s note that Ji was a worthy of Tang’s time is correct. Jian Wen’s claim that *Tang* means vast and *Ji* narrow, treating them as adjectives, likely stems from one who has not read the *Liezi*. (This entire passage is based on the *Liezi*; the preceding discussion of Kun and Peng, as well as the *Mingling* and *Da Chun*, all appear in the "Tang’s Questions" chapter.)

◎ Qing Fan’s note: In the *Liezi*’s "Tang’s Questions," Yin Tang questions Xia Ge. Zhang’s commentary: Xia Ge is Xia Ji, styled Zi Ji, a worthy minister of Tang’s time. *Ge* and *Ji* were anciently interchangeable in sound and usage. The *Lunyu*’s "Ji Zicheng" appears in the *Hanshu*’s "Table of Ancient and Modern Persons" as "Ge Zicheng." The *Shijing*’s "匪棘其欲" is cited in the *Liji*’s "Fang Ji" as "匪革其犹." The *Hanshu*’s "Zhuzao Marquis Ge Zhu" is glossed in the *Shiji Suoyin* as *Ge* pronounced *Ji*. All attest to this.

**[2] [Exegesis]**
*Xiu* means length.

The earth takes grass as its hair; in the frigid, frozen lands of the north, where no grass or trees grow, it is called *Qiongfa*—the so-called "land without hair." The Kun fish spans thousands of *li* in breadth, yet none know its length, making clear its vastness.

Now, the Kun and Peng of the Dark Sea have already appeared in the preceding text. Their reappearance here serves to affirm that the earlier citation from *Qi Xie* is sound and authoritative. By now invoking the *Liezi* as further evidence, the text reaffirms its truth with solemn care, reinforcing its meaning.

**[Exegesis of Terms]**
*Qiongfa*: Li [Yi] says: *Fa* means "hair." Sima [Biao] says: It is the land without hair beneath the northernmost pole. Cui [Yuan] says: It is the land without hair in the north. Note: *Mao* refers to grass. Geographical texts state: Mountains take grass and trees as their hair.

◎ Qing Fan’s note: To the north of *Qiongfa*, the *Liezi* reads "to the north of *Qiongfa*’s north." The *Beishi*’s "Biography of the Rouran" states: The Rouran are descendants of the Xiongnu, their origins untraceable. When cut down, they flee to the wilds of *Qiongfa*; when pursued, they vanish into the land of no people. *Qiongfa* thus denotes the most remote and desolate of regions.
*Qi Guang*: Pronounced *gu kuang*.
*Shu Qian*: Pronounced *se zhu*. The same applies below.

**[3] [Exegesis]**
The Peng’s back is vast and immense, its form resembling Mount Song and Mount Hua. The whirling wind twists and coils like a ram’s horn. Then, soaring to graze the azure heavens and cleaving through the clouds, it stirs with fury and surges forth, plotting its course toward the Southern Sea. Thus, in the *Tang’s Questions* chapter of the *Liezi*, Yu-kou states: "How could the world know of such a creature?" When Great Yu traveled, he saw it; Bo Yi named it; and Yi Jian heard of it and recorded it.

**[Exegesis of Terms]**
*Yangjiao*: Sima [Biao] says: The wind spirals upward like a ram’s horn.
*Er Shang*: Pronounced *shi zhang*. The same applies below.

**[4] [Commentary]**
Each attains perfection by fulfilling its nature, and exhausts its utmost by following its own course. Earlier, it was said that the two creatures differ in wing, and thus their destinations vary—one soars over the celestial pond, the other fulfills its will among the elm and sandalwood—each sufficing in its own form without knowing why. Now, the distinction between small and great is spoken of again: each possesses its natural endowment, neither attainable through longing nor lamentable in their difference. Thus, they are restated to clarify this.

**[Exegesis]**
*Qie* means "furthermore," also serving as a grammatical particle.
*Chi* refers to a small marsh.
*Yan* is the sparrow.
Eight *chi* make one *ren*.
*Aoxiang* means to frolic or play.
Yet the sparrow, a small bird, freely roams the marsh, leaping and bounding within the mugwort and wormwood, content in its domain. Thus, it mocks the Peng’s journey of ninety thousand *li*, delighting instead in its flight of a few *ren*. This illustrates the divergence of nature between great and small, and the non-duality of each finding its own sufficiency.

**[Exegesis of Terms]**
*Qie shi*: Read as written; formerly *zi yu* (子余反). The same applies below.
*Chi*: Read as written. Sima [Biao] says: a small marsh. Some texts write it as *chi* (尺), as does Cui’s edition. Jianwen says: writing it as *chi* (尺) is incorrect.
*Yan*: Pronounced *yu jian* (于谏反). The character is also written as 鴳. Sima [Biao] says: *yan* is the sparrow.
◎ Qingfan’s note: *Chi yan* (斥鴳) in the *Exegesis of Terms* is written as *chi yan* (尺鴳) in Cui’s edition, which is correct. The *Shuowen* states: *yan* is the *yan gu* (鴳雇). (The *Jianwei Sheren*, Li Xun, and Sun Yan’s *Erya* commentaries all say: *ju* (鴳) is also called *yan*, the sparrow, as does Guo’s annotation.) *Chi* (斥) and *chi* (尺) are interchangeable in ancient script. The *Wen Xuan*’s annotation to Cao Zhi’s *Qi Qi* states: "The sparrow flies no higher than a *chi*, illustrating its weakness," which clarifies the meaning of *chi* (尺). The *Huainanzi*’s Gao annotation says: "The sparrow of the marsh flies no farther than a *qing* or *mu*, symbolizing its frailty." The *Wen Xuan*’s annotation to Song Yu’s *Dui Chu Wang Wen* on the *chi ze* (尺泽) says: "*Chi ze* means small." Xiahou Zhan’s *Di Yi* writes: "The *chi yan* cannot ascend the mulberry or elm," where the character is correctly written as *chi* (尺). The *Yiqiejing Yinyi* states under *chi yan*: "The sparrow’s length is only a *chi*, hence its name." The *Exegesis of Terms*’s citation of Jianwen saying "writing it as *chi* (尺) is incorrect" is mistaken.
*Teng yue*: Pronounced *you ruo* (由若反).
*Aoxiang*: Pronounced *wu dao* (五刀反).
*Peng hao*: Pronounced *hao dao* (好刀反).
**[Collation]**
(1) *Taishan*: Zhao Jianyi’s edition writes *dashan* (大山); the Shidetang edition writes *Taishan* (泰山).
(2) The character *you* (由) is amended following the Shidetang edition.

Thus, those whose knowledge suffices for one office, whose conduct matches one village, whose virtue aligns with one ruler, or whose influence sways one state—when they regard themselves, it is much like this. Yet Song Rongzi would still laugh at them. Moreover, though the whole world praises them, they are not spurred on; though the whole world blames them, they are not disheartened. They discern the boundary between inner and outer, distinguish the realm of honor and disgrace—this is all. In their dealings with the world, they are not frantically active. Even so, they have yet to establish themselves. Liezi rode the wind and traveled, effortlessly and skillfully, returning after fifteen days. In attaining good fortune, he was not frantically active. Though he avoided walking, he still relied on something. As for one who rides the purity of Heaven and Earth, harnesses the transformations of the six *qi*, and roams the boundless—what does he rely on? Thus it is said: the perfected person is without self, the spirit-like person is without achievement, the sage is without name.

**[1] [Commentary]**
This is also like a bird finding contentment in its own domain.

**[Exegesis]**
*Gu* (故) continues the previous statement; *fu* (夫) introduces what follows. A *guo* (国) is a state of five ranks; a *xiang* (乡) consists of twelve thousand five hundred households. Some possess the wisdom and ability to govern an office; some have renowned reputations, matching the standards of their village; some possess vast virtue, enabling them to face south as rulers, pacifying and nurturing the people of their state. These three differ in endowment and vary in excellence, yet in their sufficiency, they are not unequal. Regarding their own capacities, it is like a bird finding contentment in its own domain.

**[Exegesis of Terms]**
*Zhi xiao*: Pronounced *zhi* (智); below, *hu jiao* (户教反).
*Xing*: Pronounced *xia meng* (下孟反).
*Bi*: Pronounced *pi zhi* (毗至反) or *fu zhi* (扶至反). Li [Yi] says: to match.
*Er zheng*: Read as written. Sima [Biao] says: to verify. Cui and Zhi say: to accomplish.
◎ Qingfan’s note: *Er zheng yi guo* (而征一国) lacks a gloss in the *Exegesis of Terms* and Guo’s commentary. Cheng’s exegesis reads *er* (而) as a connective particle, which is incorrect. *Er* (而) should be read as *neng* (能), as *er* and *neng* were interchangeable in ancient pronunciation. *Guan* (官), *xiang* (乡), *jun* (君), and *guo* (国) correspond to *zhi* (知), *ren* (仁), *de* (德), and *neng* (能), showing that *er* (而) is not a connective particle. The *Huainanzi*’s *Yuan Dao* chapter says: *er yi shao zheng duo* (而以少正多), with Gao’s annotation: "*Er* means *neng* (能)." The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Qu Si* and *Bu Qu* chapters also gloss *er* as *neng*. The *Mozi*’s *Shang Tong* chapter states: "Thus, the ancient sage-kings were *er* (能) and careful in elevating unity to establish leaders," and "Why is the world well-governed? Because they were *er* (能) in unifying principles to govern." The *Fei Ming* chapter says: "Not *er* (能) in correcting their ears’ and eyes’ desires." The *Chu Ci*’s *Jiu Zhang* says: "Who in the world *er* (能) knows it?" The *Qi Ce* says: "Who *er* (能) will go with me to the feudal lords?" In all these cases, *er* is equivalent to *neng*. The *Shu Jing*’s *Yao Dian* says: *rou yuan neng er* (柔远能迩), while the Han dynasty *Du You Ban* stele writes *er* (而). The *Gao Yao Mo* says: *neng zhe er hui* (能哲而惠), while the *Wei Wei Heng Fang* stele writes *neng zhe neng hui* (能悊能惠), and the *Shiji*’s *Xia Ben Ji* writes *neng zhi neng hui* (能智能惠).

The *Li Yun Zheng Yi* states: "Liu Xiang’s *Shuo Yuan* writes the character *neng* uniformly as *er*. This is an example of that."

[2] [Annotation] Not yet able to equalize, hence there is laughter.
[Commentary] *Zi* is a title for one of virtue, surnamed Rong, a native of Song. *You ran* means "thus." Though Master Rong was able to forget being, he had not yet relinquished non-being, hence the laughter. Those attached to official ranks remain bound by titles and emoluments, while those of empty indifference still harbor derision, seeing thus as cause for inequality. Previously, the lesser laughed at the greater, showing that the greater do not boast; now, the greater laugh at the lesser, so the lesser do not aspire. Those whose nature and destiny remain unsettled have simply not yet heard of this principle.

[Textual Notes]
*Song Rongzi*: Sima [Qian] and Li [Xun] say: a native of the state of Song. Cui [Yuan] says: a worthy man.
*You ran xiao zhi*: Cui and Li say: *you* describes the manner of laughter. The case holds that *you* means "to consider laughable."

[3] [Annotation] To examine and find contentment in oneself.
[Commentary] *Ju* means "all." *Quan* means "to encourage." *Ju* means "resentment and dejection." Master Rong, following his nature and embracing the Dao, towered loftily above the common world. Even if all the world praised him, it would not increase his encouragement; if the entire realm slandered him, it would not add to his dejection—he examined and found contentment in himself.

[Textual Notes]
*Yu zhi*: pronounced *yu*.
*Jia ju*: *ci lü* rhyme, meaning "to defeat."

[4] [Annotation] Inwardly the self, outwardly things.
[Commentary] Master Rong knew that inwardly there was no true self and outwardly no true things, so he cast aside both inner and outer, forgetting both self and things. Thus, he was settled in the distinction between inner and outer, unwavering and unerring.

[5] [Annotation] Honoring oneself and humiliating others.
[Commentary] He forgot encouragement and dejection in the face of praise or blame, merging poverty and success with honor and disgrace. Thus, he could turn his illumination inward to clarify the mind’s wisdom, and through profound insight discern the realm of things—no longer inwardly the self and outwardly things, nor honoring himself and humiliating others.

[Textual Notes]
*zhi jing*: pronounced *ju ling*. ◎Qing Fan notes: The *Shiwen* writes *jing*, interchangeable with the ancient character for "realm."

[6] [Annotation] Nor could he surpass this.
[Commentary] *Si* means "this." *Yi* means "to cease." Master Rong’s wisdom and virtue ceased at this point.
[Textual Notes]
*neng fu*: pronounced *fu you*.

[7] [Annotation] Sufficient in himself, thus at ease in the world.
[Commentary] *Shu shu* means "eagerly, restlessly." Master Rong followed his nature, empty and indifferent, advancing straightforwardly with the principle, never employing his wisdom to seek or his mind to strive for the Dao. Dwelling beyond things, he was not restless.
[Textual Notes]
*shu shu*: pronounced *shuo*. The same below.

Xu pronounced *suo lu* with an alternative reading *sang lü*. Sima [Biao] says: "like *jiji* (restlessly)." Cui [Yuan] says: "a sense of urgency." [Emperor] Jianwen reads it as *suo yu*, meaning "to calculate." *Gu xian* is pronounced *xian*, originally also written as 閒.

[8] [Annotation] He was only able to affirm himself, yet could not attain the state of "nothing that is not permissible."
[Commentary] *Shu* means "to establish." Master

"Coldly" describes a cool appearance. The *Wen Xuan* annotation to Jiang Wenchong's *Miscellaneous Styles* poem cites the same gloss. The *Shiwen* omits this.

[10] [Annotation] If one relies on external conditions, then even riding the wind cannot circumnavigate the world in a single moment.
[Commentary] A *xun* is ten days. Having attained the Dao of wind immortality, he roamed the world, returning home every fifteen days. Yet he could not ride all things without exception, and thus could not circumnavigate the world in a single moment.

[11] [Annotation] He naturally rode the wind—this was not something he sought with restless effort.
[Commentary] *Zhi* means "to attain."
