Yet Ziqi has forgotten both state and knowledge, severed both self and things, while Ziyou remains unenlightened and expresses astonishment. Therefore, he demonstrates the power of leaning against the armrest, asking, "Do you understand?"

(2) [Commentary]
*Lai* means "flute." Flutes vary in length, and their notes differ in pitch, producing sounds of myriad differences—short and long, high and low. Though the sounds differ, the measure from which they arise is one. Thus, there is no distinction of superior or inferior among them. Extending this to the winds and things, though their sounds differ, they are the same in essence, each taking form of its own accord. In this way, the *lai* of heaven and earth is revealed.

[Annotation]
The human *lai* is the flute, twelve inches long, with sixteen pipes, resembling a phoenix’s wing, created by Shun. Flutes vary in length, each receiving its due, just as the winds and things all partake of spontaneity. Thus, these two worthies are invoked to illustrate the meaning of the three *lai*, which is explained below.

[Phonetic Glosses]
*女闻* is read as *汝*. The same applies below. The original also writes *汝*.
◎ Lu Wenchang asks: Why does the first *汝* not uniformly use *女*?
*人籁* is read as *lì dài*.
*籁夫* is read as *lài fú*.
*参* is read as *cēn*.
*差* is read as *cī*.
*所错* is read as *suǒ cuò*.
*见矣* is read as *xiàn yǐ*.

[Collations]
(1) The character *人* is deleted following the commentary.

Ziyou said, "May I ask about its method? (1)"

(1) [Annotation]
*方* means "the Daoist art." Though he has heard the names, he does not grasp their meaning, so he asks about the method of the three *lai*.

Ziqi said, "The great clod exhales *qi*, and its name is wind. (1) It alone does nothing, but when it acts, the myriad hollows roar. (2) Have you alone not heard its long sighing? (3) The towering forests and jagged cliffs, (4) the hollows of great trees a hundred spans around—resembling noses, mouths, ears, beams, rings, mortars, depressions, and puddles; (5) some rushing, some whistling, some scolding, some inhaling, some crying, some wailing, some moaning, some biting—(6) the first sings *yu*, and the followers sing *yong*. A gentle breeze yields a small harmony; a whirlwind, a great harmony. (7) When the fierce wind subsides, all hollows become empty. (8) Have you alone not seen their quivering, their fluttering? (9)"

(1) [Commentary]
The "great clod" is nothingness. As for exhaling *qi*, how could there be a thing? *Qi* simply exhales of itself. The arising of things—none does not arise of itself. Thus, the body of self-arising is vast, and so it is named the "great clod."

[Annotation]
The "great clod" is the name of the Creator, also called spontaneity. The principle of spontaneity gives life to the myriad things, yet it does not know why it is so. Within the great clod, *qi* is exhaled and called wind.

[Phonetic Glosses]
*大块* is read as *kǔ guài* (Li: *kǔ duì*; *Shuowen* agrees, calling it a vulgar character). Xu: *kǒu huí*; Xu and Li also read *hú zuì*; Guo also reads *kǔ wěi*. Sima says: "The appearance of great simplicity." Some versions write *大槐*; Ban Gu’s version is the same. The *Huainanzi* writes *大昧*. Some commentators take it as "nothingness," some as "primordial *qi*," some as "chaotic wholeness," some as "heaven"—all are mistaken.
◎ Qing Fan’s case: The *Yiqiejing yin yi* (95), citing the *Zhengwu jing* (5), quotes Sima as saying, "The great clod is heaven," differing from the *Shiwen*.
◎ Yu Yue says: The "great clod" is earth. *块* is an alternate form of *之*. The *Shuowen* (Earth section): "，a clod." It refers to what the *Zhongyong* calls "a handful of earth," which, when accumulated to vastness, becomes earth. Thus, earth is called the "great clod." Sima’s "appearance of great simplicity" and Guo’s "the great clod is nothingness" both miss the meaning. This passage originally explains the earthly *lai*, so how could the "great clod" be anything but earth?
*噫* is read as *yì jiè*. The commentary is the same.

(1) *Yīn* is pronounced as *yīn*.

(2) **Commentary:** It speaks of wind as having no deliberate action; when it acts, the myriad hollows all rage and stir to produce sound.
**Subcommentary:** *Is* refers to this wind. *Acts* means arises. It says this great wind only remains still; if it moves and acts, then the myriad distinct hollows all drum and roar in fury.
**Pronunciation Notes:** *Myriad hollows* (*wàn qiào*): *kǔ diào* (苦吊) reflex. *Rage and roar* (*nù xiāo*): *hú dāo* (胡刀) reflex; Xu’s version reads *xǔ kǒu* (許口) reflex, also *hú dào* (胡到) reflex.

(3) **Commentary:** The sound of a long wind.
**Pronunciation Notes:** *Liùliù* (翏翏): *liáng jiù* (良救) reflex, also *liù shōu* (六收) reflex. The sound of a long wind. Li’s edition writes *liù* (飂), same pronunciation. Also *lì zhú* (力竹) reflex.

(4) **Commentary:** What the great wind fans and stirs.
**Subcommentary:** *Liùliù* is the sound of a long wind. *Wèi jiā* (畏佳) is the appearance of being fanned and stirred. As the *liùliù* clear gusts strike and shake the mountains and forests, they cause the trees’ branches to sway and flutter in *wèi jiā* agitation. All the world sees this—how could you alone not hear it? The following text states...

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Wèi* (畏): *yú guǐ* reflex. Guo’s version reads *wū zuì* reflex. Cui’s edition writes *wēi*. *Jiā* (佳): *zuì guǐ* reflex. Xu’s version reads *zǐ wéi* reflex. Guo’s version reads *zǔ zuì* reflex. Li’s version reads *zhū guǐ* reflex. Li Yi states: *wèi zhūi* is the appearance of mountains and hills. ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: *Jiā* was originally written as *zhūi*; modern editions of the *Zhuangzi* all use *jiā*. The *Yunhui* under the *zhi* rhyme cites this passage, suggesting it may also be read as *zhuī*. Though the pronunciations here (though all level tones) differ, they are in fact close to the original sound of *jiā*, and thus the text has been emended following the majority of editions.

(5) **Commentary:** This briefly enumerates the likenesses of the various apertures.
**Subcommentary:** Apertures are holes in trees. *Jī* are the wooden blocks atop pillars—what we now call *dou*. *Quān* are animal enclosures. Trees being a hundred spans in girth, their cavities are likewise numerous and strange. Thus some resemble human mouths or noses, some resemble animal pens, some resemble human earholes, some resemble the *jī* of a house, some are hollowed and swollen, and some are sunken and uneven. Their forms are endless; this merely lists eight examples. It is just as in the world, where the myriad things, though of different kinds, may be ugly or beautiful—all receive this from the workings of creation.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Zhī qiào* (之窍): Cui’s edition writes *kuǎn*. *Sì bí sì kǒu* (似鼻似口): Sima states: This refers to the apertures being stirred by the wind, resembling either a human nose or a human mouth. *Sì jī* (似枅): *jī* reflex, also *jiān* reflex. The *Zilin* states: The square timber atop a pillar. Simplification states: The *bolu*. *Sì quān* (似圈): *qǐ quán* reflex. Guo’s version reads *quán*, meaning a cup or ring. Xu’s version reads *qí ruǎn* reflex, referring to the enclosures for sheep and pigs. *Sì jiù* (似臼): *qí jiǔ* reflex. *Wā zhě* (洼者): *wū xié* reflex. Li’s version reads *yú huā* reflex, also *wū guāi* reflex. Guo’s version reads *wū wā* reflex. Sima states: Like something hollowed and curved. *Wū zhě* (污者): *wū* reflex. Sima states: Like something sunken and low.

(6) **Commentary:** This briefly enumerates the differing sounds of the various apertures.
**Subcommentary:** *Jī* is like the sound of rushing water. *Hè* is like the sound of an arrow’s shaft-hole. *Chì* is a sharp shout. *Xī* is like the sound of breathing. *Jiào* is like a cry. *Háo* is like a wail. *Yǎo* is deep, like a deep valley. *Yǎo* is a mournful, plaintive sound. Briefly listing the tree’s apertures yields eight kinds; when the wind blows through the tree’s holes, it likewise produces eight sounds. It is just as humans, though differing in endowment, vary in myriad ways—each moves according to its nature, yet all are equal. Even if one considers differences in size, premature death, or longevity, these are not enough to create disparity.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Jī zhě* (激者): *jīng lì* reflex, like the rushing of water. Li’s version reads *gǔ diào* reflex. Sima states: A sound like an urgent call. Li’s version also reads *qū diào* reflex. ◎ Qingfan notes: The *Yiqiejing Yinyi* (68) cites Sima as saying: "Flowing swiftly is called *jī*." The *Yinjing Lüyi Xiang* (14, 78, 90) and the *Gaoseng Zhuan* (13) all concur. The *Wenxuan* (Lu Ziliang’s *Shixing* poem annotation) and the *Xuanying Zongjing Yinyi* (14) also agree, differing from the *Shiwen* citation. *Hè zhě* (謞者): *xiào* reflex. Li’s version reads *xū jiāo* reflex. Simplification states: Like the sound of an arrow’s flight. Sima states: Like the sound of *huān hè*. ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: Originally read as *kǎo*, an error. The modern commentary reads *xiào*, which is followed here. *Chì zhě* (叱者): *chāng shí* reflex. Xu’s version reads *qī* reflex. Sima states: Like a sharp shout. *Xī zhě* (吸者): *xǔ jí* reflex. Sima states: Like the sound of exhalation and inhalation. *Jiào zhě* (叫者): *gǔ diào* reflex. Guo’s version reads *gǔ yòu* reflex. Li’s version reads *jū yào* reflex. Sima states: Like a cry. *Háo zhě* (号者): *háo* reflex. Guo’s version also reads *hù bào* reflex. Sima states: Like a wail. ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The *zhě* was originally omitted; it has been added here to match the other entries. *Yǎo zhě* (宎者): Xu’s version reads *yú yáo* reflex, also *yǎo* reflex, also *yú diào* reflex. Sima states: The deep one, like something profoundly *yǎo*. *Yǎo zhě* (咬者): *yú jiāo* reflex, also *jiǎo* reflex. Sima states: A mournful, plaintive sound like *yǎo yǎo*. Also *xǔ bài* reflex.

(7) **Commentary:** Though the notes and tones of sound may transform in a thousand ways, in their harmonies and responses, whether great or small, none fail to match what they receive and each fits its allotted portion.
**Subcommentary:** *Líng* is a gentle wind. *Piāo* is a fierce wind. *Yú* and *yóng* are the sounds of trees swaying back and forth as the wind blows through them. Thus the *línglíng* clear breeze produces a soft harmony, while the violent *piāo* wind produces a loud harmony—each matches what it receives, with no superiority or inferiority, just as the myriad things receive their qi naturally.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Chàng yú* (唱于): Read as written. *Chàng yóng* (唱喁): *wǔ gōng* reflex. Xu’s version also reads *yú* reflex, also *wǔ dòu* reflex. Li states: *Yú yóng* is the sound of mutual harmony. *Líng fēng* (泠风): *líng* reflex. Li states: *Línglíng* is a gentle wind. *Xiǎo hè* (小和): *hú wò* reflex. The same applies below and in the commentary. *Piāo fēng* (飘风): *bí yáo* reflex, also *fú yáo* reflex. Li’s version reads *fū yáo* reflex. Sima states: A swift wind. The *Erya* states: A whirling wind is called *piāo*. *Bù chèn* (不称): *chǐ zhèng* reflex. *Qí fèn* (其分): *fú wèn* reflex. The same applies below where not specified.

(8) **Commentary:** *Jì* means to cease. When a fierce wind arises, the myriad apertures are full; when it ceases, the myriad apertures are empty.

Though emptiness and fullness differ, their attainment of their own nature is the same.

**Commentary:**
*Lì* means great or fierce. *Jì* means to cease. When a great wind ceases, the myriad apertures are empty; when it stirs, the myriad apertures are full. Though emptiness and fullness differ, each attains its own state—this is the same. How much more do the four seasons’ waxing and waning, the two forces’ generation and destruction, proceed without intent to nurture or harm, and without design to bless or destroy!

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Lì fēng* (厉风): Sima states: a great wind. Xiang and Guo state: a fierce wind.
*Jì* (济): *zǐ xì* reflex. Xiang states: to cease.
◎ Qing Fan notes: *Lì fēng jì*—*jì* means to cease. The *Odes*’ *Yong Feng* reads *zài chí piān xuán jì*, and the Mao commentary states: *jì* means to cease. When the wind ceases, the ten thousand sounds fall silent, hence it is said the myriad apertures are empty.

(9)
**Commentary:**
*Tiáotiáo* (*diāodiāo* → *dāodāo*) is the appearance of movement and shaking. Though the sounds of things differ, and the movements of their forms likewise vary, their attainment of uniformity is the same. How could *tiáotiáo* alone be right and *dāodāo* alone be wrong?

**Commentary:**
*Ér* means "you." *Tiáotiáo* (*diāodiāo* → *dāodāo*) is the appearance of movement and shaking. Though the forms of things differ and their movements likewise vary, though there are distinctions between *tiáo* and *dāo*, ultimately there is no difference of right and wrong. How much more do fullness and emptiness, gathering and dispersal, life and death, success and failure follow the natural principle of things, inevitably so—how could there be right and wrong, approval or disapproval among them?

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Tiáotiáo* (调调): *tiáo* reflex.
*Dāodāo* (刀刀): Xu: *dū yáo* reflex. Xiang states: *tiáotiáo dāodāo* both describe the appearance of movement and shaking.
◎ Lu Wenchang states: The old text uniformly wrote *diāo*, a vulgar form; now corrected to the proper character.
*Dòngyáo* (动摇): Read as written, or *yáng zhào* reflex.
**Collation Notes:**
(1) *Quēwù* cites Li’s edition: *liù* written as *liù*, *lì jiù* reflex.
(2) The character *dāo* follows the Shide Tang edition and Lu’s collation; the commentary and sub-commentary below are likewise corrected.
(3) Below, two characters—*zuò yīn*—are suspected to be missing.
The *Zhi Bei You* chapter reads: "That which lives is *yīnyì* of things," and the pronunciation notes give *yīn* as *yīn* reflex, citing Li and Guo: *yīnyì* is the appearance of qi gathering. *Yīn* qi is also qi gathering.
(4) The character *xǔ* follows the original edition of the pronunciation notes.
(5) The Baojing Hall original block-print edition writes *wéi* as *shuí*, an error. This text originally wrote *wéi*, which is also incorrect. The character should be *suī*.
(6) *Yóu* and *yóu* were interchangeable in ancient times; henceforth, they are distinguished by meaning.
(7) The character *wū* follows the original edition of the pronunciation notes.
(8) The character *zhòng* follows the Shide Tang edition and the commentary above. The Zhao Jianyi edition also writes *yì*.
(9) The character *yě* is supplied following the sentence structure of the preceding and following text.

Ziyou said: "The earthly *lài* is simply the myriad apertures; the human *lài* is simply the bamboo flutes. May I ask about the heavenly *lài*?"

(1)
**Commentary:**
The earthly *lài* refers to apertures and cavities; the human *lài* refers to flutes and pipes—both are visible to the eye and thus knowable. Only the heavenly *lài* is profoundly mysterious and difficult to grasp at once. I humbly present my ignorance and ask to resolve my doubts.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Bǐ zhú* (比竹): *pí zhì* reflex, or *bì lǚ* reflex. Li: *fú bì* reflex. The commentary is the same.

Ziqi said: "Now, the blowing of the ten thousand [winds] differs, yet each is made to be itself. All attain their own nature—who is the one that rouses them?"

(1)
**Commentary:**
This is the heavenly *lài*.

The heavenly *lài*—how could there be yet another separate thing? It is simply the assemblage of the myriad apertures and bamboo flutes, joined with all living kinds, converging to form as one Heaven. The non-existent, being non-existent, cannot generate the existent; the existent, before it comes to be, cannot act as generator. Then who is it that engenders engendering? It is but the self-engendering of the clod-like. Self-engendering—it is not that I engender. Since I cannot engender things, and things cannot engender me, then I am self-so. Being self-so, it is called "Heaven-so." "Heaven-so"—it is not made, and thus is spoken of as Heaven. *(Speaking of it as Heaven)*—this is to clarify its self-so nature; how could it refer to the azure expanse? Yet some suppose that the heavenly *lài* compels things to follow its command. But if Heaven itself cannot possess itself, how could it possess things? Thus, "Heaven" is the collective name for the ten thousand things; none is singled out as Heaven—who then would command things? Therefore, things each self-engender without any source—this is the Dao of Heaven.

**Commentary:**
Now, "Heaven" is the collective name for the ten thousand things, an alternate designation for the self-so—how could it refer to the azure expanse? Thus, the heavenly *lài*—how could there be another separate thing? It is simply the bamboo flutes and myriad apertures joined with all living kinds. Tracing who it is that engenders engendering, it is no-thing. Thus, externally it does not depend on things, internally it does not rely on the self; it engenders clod-like, as solitary transformation. Hence Guo’s commentary states: "Being self-so, it is called 'Heaven-so.'" Speaking of it as "Heaven-so" clarifies its self-so nature. And yet it says, "the blowing of the ten thousand [winds] differs." Now, wind is but one body, while apertures are myriad and distinct; though their sizes differ, each accords with what it receives, all following their own knowing—how could they rely on another? This is the heavenly *lài*. Thus we know that spring’s birth and summer’s growth, the eye’s seeing and the ear’s hearing, whether taking from the near body or entrusting to distant things, all are without knowledge of their *how*, utterly unable to discern their *why*. Each is made to be itself, each portion sufficient in its lot, moving in accord with its nature, not by mind or wit—this is what is meant by "nurturing them, poisoning them." Such is the great meaning of the heavenly *lài*.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Qǐ fù*: *fú yòu* reflex.
*Mò dí*: *dīng lì* reflex.

◎ Qing Fan’s note: *Wen Xuan* (Selections of Refined Literature), in the commentary to Xie Lingyun’s poem "On the Ninth Day, Following Duke Song at the Xima Terrace Assembly to Send Off Magistrate Kong," cites Sima [Biao] as saying: "Blowing the ten thousand" refers to the heavenly *qi* blowing and warming, giving life to the ten thousand things, each with its distinct form and *qi*. *Yǐ* 已 means "to stop," allowing each to attain its nature and come to rest. The same citation appears in the commentary to Xie Lingyun’s poem "On the Road, Recalling the Mountains" and Jiang Yan’s poem "Miscellaneous Styles." The *Shiwen* is missing.

【Another note】All things attain this of themselves—who is the master that enrages them into being thus? This further clarifies the heavenly *lài*.

【Exegesis】"Self-taking" is like "self-attaining." The winds and apertures differ, so their forms and sounds vary; yet in each taking its own sufficiency, they are never unequal. But when they rage and stir into sound, who makes them thus? This is to show that the myriad living things, tangled and diverse, each taking from its allotted portion, are never insufficient. Whether flying or walking, who makes them thus? Thus we know that in their drumming and rousing, none knows its master. This is to further clarify the meaning of the heavenly *lài*.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Cǐ zhòng*: *zhí yòng* reflex.

【Collation Notes】
(1) Four characters added following the Shide Tang edition.
(2) The characters "Lingyun" amended following the original *Wen Xuan* text.

The great knowledge is at ease, the small knowledge is at odds;
The great words blaze, the small words chatter.
In sleep, their spirits intertwine; in waking, their forms open,
Engaging with others in construction, daily battling with the heart.
Some are slack, some deep, some dense.
Small fears make one tremble; great fears leave one dispirited.
Their release is like the trigger of a crossbow—this is what is meant by "overseeing right and wrong";
Their retention is like a sworn oath—this is what is meant by "guarding victory."
Their decline is like autumn and winter, speaking of their daily consumption;
What they drown in, what they do, cannot be restored.
Their satiation is like a sealed letter, speaking of their aging and decay;
The heart near death cannot be made to revive.
Joy and anger, sorrow and delight, thought and sighing, change and dread, coquetry and ease, opening and posturing—
Music emerges from emptiness, steam gives rise to mushrooms.
Day and night succeed one another before us, yet none knows where they sprout.
Ah, ah! Morning and evening attain this—this is how they come to be!

【Note to first line】This likely refers to differences in knowledge.
【Exegesis】*Xiánxián* 闲闲 means "at ease." *Jiànjiàn* 闲闲 means "discerning." Those of great wisdom and broad capacity follow their nature in emptiness and indifference, without right or wrong; those of small knowledge and narrow ability are constrained in spirit, taking and rejecting. Taking and rejecting lead to separation and discernment; without right or wrong, one is at ease and expansive.
【Pronunciation Notes】
*Dà zhī*: read as *zhì*. The same applies below and in the notes.
*Xiánxián*: Li [Yi] says: "without bearing." Jianwen says: "the appearance of vastness."
*Jiànjiàn*: *gǔ xián* reflex, having something to separate.
◎ Yu Yue says: *Guangya* *Shigu* defines *xián* as "to observe." *Xiǎo zhī jiànjiàn* should follow this meaning, referring to those who like to observe others. The *Shiwen*’s "having something to separate" is incorrect.

【Note to second line】This likely refers to differences in speech.
【Exegesis】*Yányán* 炎炎 means "fierce." *Zhānzhān* 詹詹 means "verbose." Great words expounding principle are like a raging fire burning across the plain, sweeping clean without residue. The petty words of the Confucians and Mohists are mired in contention, merely verbose without benefiting the teaching.
【Pronunciation Notes】
*Yányán*: *yú lián*, *yú fán* two reflexes, also read as *tán*. Li [Yi] writes *dàn*, *tú làn* reflex. Li Yi says: "the same as *shìfēi* 是非 (right and wrong)." Jianwen says: "the appearance of flourishing."
*Zhānzhān*: read as *zhān*. Li Yi says: "the appearance of petty disputation." Cui [Zhuo] writes *yán* 阎.

【Note to third line】This likely refers to differences in waking and sleeping.
【Exegesis】The common and vulgar, their spirits restless and agitated, cling to external circumstances without pause. Thus in their dreaming, their spirits wander and intertwine; in their waking, their forms open to take in the world.
【Pronunciation Notes】
*Hún jiāo*: Sima [Biao] says: "spirits intertwining."
*Qí jué*: *gǔ xiào* reflex.
*Xíng kāi*: Sima [Biao] says: "eyes open, mind awakened."

【Note to fourth line】This likely refers to differences in interaction.
【Exegesis】*Gòu* 构 means "to join." *Jiào* 窖 means "deep," as in digging a pit to store grain. *Mì* 密 means "hidden." In engaging with worldly affairs, joining root and dust, the deluded mind grows heavy, insatiable in its thirst for days. Thus they cherish every moment, their hearts battling with the sun. As their minds chase after circumstances, their natures vary endlessly—roughly speaking, there are these three distinctions.
【Pronunciation Notes】
*Yǔ jiē wéi gòu*: Sima [Biao] says: "human interactions, constructing bonds of affection."
*Màn zhě*: *mò dàn* reflex. Jianwen says: "relaxed in mind."
*Jiào zhě*: *gǔ xiào* reflex. Sima [Biao] says: "deep." Li [Yi] says: "a pit." Note: a pit dug to store grain is called *jiào*. Jianwen says: "deep in mind."

【Note to fifth line】This likely refers to differences in fear and trembling.
【Exegesis】*Zhuìzhuì* 惴惴 means "apprehensive." *Mànmàn* 缦缦 means "dispirited." Circumstances may comply or resist, but the heart is ever anxious, fearing they will not come to pass, filled with dread. Thus small fears make one tremble in apprehension, while great fears leave one dispirited and dejected.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Xiǎo kǒng*: *qū yǒng* reflex. Same below and in the commentary.
*Zhuìzhuì*: *zhī ruì* reflex. Li [Yi] says: "appearance of caution."
*Ěryǎ* says: "fear."
*Mànmàn*: Li [Yi] says: "appearance of equanimity toward life and death."
*Jì*: *qí jì* reflex.

【Six】
【Exegesis】*Jī* is the trigger of a crossbow. *Guā* is the nock of an arrow. *Sī* means "to govern." The heart, when set upon pursuing an object, is as swift as an arrow’s nock; when moved to resist harm, it is as fierce as a crossbow’s trigger. It is governed solely by the judgment of right and wrong, with no other consideration.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Jī guā*: *gǔ huó* reflex. *Jī* is the crossbow’s trigger. *Guā* is the arrow’s nock.
◎Qing Fan’s note: *Wenxuan*’s commentary on Bao Mingyuan’s *Ku Re Xing* cites Sima [Biao] as saying: "When right and wrong, good and ill contend and collide, calamity and ruin arrive as swiftly as the release of a crossbow’s trigger."
The *Pronunciation Notes* omit this.
◎Further note: *Jī* refers to the crossbow’s trigger. (See Zheng’s commentary on the *Book of Changes*’ *Appended Judgments*.) *Shiming* says: "A crossbow (*nǔ*) is so called because it is *wrathful* (*nù*). The part that hooks the string is called the *tooth* (*yá*); outside the tooth is the *frame* (*guō*); below the frame is the *hanging blade* (*xiàn dāo*). Together, they are called the *trigger* (*jī guā*), for they are as ingenious as a machine."

【Seven】
【Note】This likely refers to differences in movement and stillness.
【Exegesis】*Zǔ* means "to invoke." *Méng* means "to swear." The mind, when engaged in judging right and wrong, is like one invoking a curse or swearing an oath. When the heart seizes upon an object, it is no different from pledging an alliance. Firm and unyielding, its resolve lies in overcoming things.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Zǔ*: *cè jù* reflex.
*Méng*: *míng* sound; Xu [Shen] reads *wǔ gēng* reflex; Guo [Pu] reads *wǔ bìng* reflex.

【Eight】
【Note】Such is the daily decline and decay.
【Exegesis】In autumn’s withering and winter’s desolation, the scenes of things shift as swiftly as the crossing of arms. How could the deluded ever awaken? Yet they contend over vain right and wrong, never realizing that each day brings new decay. Human aging follows the same pattern.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Qí shā*: *sè jiè* reflex; Xu [Shen] reads *sè lì* reflex. Same in the note.

【Nine】
【Note】Such is the drowning that carries one away.
【Exegesis】Long mired in the realm of objects, one’s deeds have long strayed from the Dao and departed from truth. To seek a return to life’s source is now impossible.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Nì*: *nú dí* reflex; Guo *nú jiǎo* reflex.

【Ten】
【Note】Such is the drowning in desire that deepens with age.
【Exegesis】Drowning—submerged and lost. The deluded, sunk in desire, cling to their delusions as if bound by cords. Not only in youth do they indulge, but even in old age their drowning grows deeper.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Yàn*: *yú yè* reflex; Xu *yú rǎn* reflex, also *yú gǎn* reflex.
*Jiān*: Xu *gǔ xián* reflex.
*Xù*: Also written *yì*; *yì* sound; Guo *xǔ jué* reflex, also *yǐ zhì* reflex.

【Eleven】
【Note】Such is the pursuit of gain and disregard for calamity, where hidden schemes achieve their ends.
【Exegesis】*Mò* means “none”; *yáng* means “life.” The heart, mired in stagnation, nears the realm of death. To seek a return to the Way of life is impossible.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Jìn sǐ*: *jìn* as in “near.”
*Fù yáng*: *yáng* refers to life.

◎ Jia Shifu says: Daily the heart contends, its changes endless. The arbiter of right and wrong possesses a mechanism of ten thousand responses; the one who clings to victory holds a single fixed view. Some grow weary and seek to return, yet their killing is as autumn’s decree; some remain sunk in delusion, drowning in their deeds. There are those who seal their mechanism so tightly that no breath of living humanity remains. The conflicts of human hearts each reflect the mechanism they harbor—probe and grasp it.

【Twelve】
【Note】These are but differences of nature and disposition.
【Exegesis】The common and deluded, clinging to what opposes or accords with them, rejoice in accord and grieve in opposition. Yet grief and joy weigh heavier, while delight and anger are lighter. Delight brings gladness to the heart; joy moves the body to dance. Anger stirs immediate resentment; grief wracks the whole frame with wailing. Anxiety weighs future possibilities; sighing laments what has passed. Change alters what was; submission bends without resistance. Frivolity is light and restless; excess is lavish and unrestrained. Unleashing opens the floodgates of desire; affectation is seductive and alluring. The minds of beings shift endlessly—here, in brief, are twelve transformations. Examine them closely, and the dispositions of things become clear.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Āi lè*: *luò* sound.
*Zhé*: *zhī shè* reflex; Sima: “motionless appearance.”
*Yáo*: Guo *yáo* sound; Xu and Li *chì diào* reflex.
*Yì*: *yì* sound.
*Tài*: *chì dài* reflex; Li also *nú zài* reflex.

【Thirteen】
【Note】These are but differences of circumstance and change. From here above, a rough sketch of the boundless spontaneity of Heaven’s piping; from here below, the elucidation of boundless naturalness. Things each arise naturally, not knowing why they are so yet being so—thus, though forms differ endlessly, their *thusness* is ever the same.
【Exegesis】The flute’s hollow allows the birth of refined music; the steam of damp heat gives rise to morning mushrooms. So too the ten thousand things of the Two Modes: empty, insubstantial, untrue, arising from nothing—like mushrooms and music. If all is fleeting illusion, where is there room for delight or anger?

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Zhēng*: *zhī yīng* reflex.
*Chéng jùn*: *qí yǔn* reflex; Xiang: “to congeal.”
*Yǐ shàng*: *shí zhǎng* reflex.

【Fourteen】
【Note】Day and night alternate, the old giving way to the new. The ten thousand things of heaven and earth transform and renew daily, advancing with time—what thing initiates this? It is simply so of itself.
【Exegesis】Day and night turn in endless cycles, succeeding one another, each becoming the other’s predecessor. Trace their roots, and their form remains unknown.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Méng*: *wǔ gēng* reflex.

【Fifteen】
【Note】Speaking of their self-arising.
【Exegesis】*Yǐ* means “to cease.” Tracing day and night, their before and after are unknowable; to speculate is futile—better to cease. Yet if we further trace dawn and dusk, re-examining dusk and dawn, their origin remains unfathomable, their beginning and end unknown. To clarify the ten thousand phenomena of the world as empty and untrue, to trace life and death, is to find their essence utterly still. Thus the *Laozi* says: “Pursue it, and its head is not seen; follow it, and its tail is not seen.” The principle is just so.

【Pronunciation Notes】
*Dàn mù*: Also written *mò*; same sound.

【Collation Notes】
(1) *Quē wù* cites the Jiangnan ancient manuscript: *xù* written as *yì*.
(2) Supplemented following the example of the line below.
(3) *Nù* also: following *Shì míng*, emended; the three characters *guō zé kuò* below also deleted following *Shì míng*.
(4) *Shì dé táng* edition: *qí* written as *zì*.

---

Not the absence of another, not the absence of self—nothing to grasp. This is near enough, yet one knows not what compels it. As if a true master existed, yet no trace is found. It may act and be trusted, yet its form is unseen—it has sentience but no form. The hundred bones, nine orifices, six viscera—all are complete within me. With whom should I feel kinship? Do you delight in them all? Or is there a private preference? Are they all servants and maids? Are servants and maids insufficient to govern one another? Do they take turns as lord and subject? Or is there a true lord present? Whether one seeks and finds its truth or not, it neither adds to nor diminishes its reality.

Having once received this completed form, one does not forget it until its end. Buffeted and worn by things, one’s course runs on like a galloping steed—none can halt it. Is this not sorrowful? A lifetime spent in toil, yet no success is seen; wearily exhausted, one knows not where to return. Is this not lamentable? Men call it "not dying"—what benefit is there? The form dissolves, the heart follows suit—can this not be called great sorrow?

Is man’s life inherently so deluded? Am I alone deluded, while others remain undeluded? If one follows the heart’s settled inclinations and takes them as teacher, who is without a teacher? Why must there be those who know the succession of minds and yet still choose their own? Even fools share in this.

To possess right and wrong before the heart is fully formed—this is like arriving in Yue today yet having set out yesterday. Thus, to take non-being as being: even if the divine Yu were here, he could not comprehend it—how much less can I?

The myriad things and myriad sentiments each pursue or abandon differently—it is as though some true master were causing them to be so. Yet when one arises to seek traces of this true master, one ultimately finds nothing. Thus it is clear that all things are self-so, with no agent making them so.

The limbs differ in form, their functions distinct, as if governed by a true nature—yet in the end, no master is found. From whence do these first signs arise?

---

Now, the traveler trusts in himself and thus can proceed. Trusting in oneself and acting, moving as one’s will desires, the heavenly mechanism unfurls of itself, and one moves in accord with one’s nature—self-sufficient, self-reliant, what need is there for external aid?

---

One does not see the form by which such proceeding is attained.

All things trust in themselves to proceed, yet the appearance of such trust is not seen.

---

The sentiment accords with the thing, and thus the form is not separately perceived.

There is the wisdom of what can be done, yet no tangible form of self-trust.

---

Entrusting all to the natural, nothing fails to endure. The hundred bones, the nine orifices—eyes, ears, nose, tongue, mouth, and the two lower passages—the six viscera—large intestine, small intestine, bladder, and the triple burner—and the five organs—liver, heart, spleen, lungs, and kidneys—are all complete. The bones form the outer structure, the organs and viscera lie within, and the orifices connect inner and outer. These three aspects together constitute the body, and thus it is said that all endure.

The *Xiao Erya* aligns with Emperor Jianwen’s annotation: "to encompass."

---

**Note 8:** It simply exists of itself.

**Note 9:** If one explains everything, it implies partiality. With partiality, one cannot encompass and preserve all; thus, things exist without explanation and arise without action.

**Commentary:** The six senses and nine orifices all belong to one body—how could there be favoritism or private attachment? If one harbors affection, it is already partiality. To claim the body as private is unreasonable. All things are entrusted to their natural place, governed by their inherent function. This holds true for the body and for all things alike.

**Exegetical Note:** *"All explain"* is pronounced *yuè*, as in the annotation. Most modern editions use the character for "joy" (*yuè*). The same applies hereafter.

---

**Note 10:** If all things were private, ambition would exceed proper bounds, superiors and inferiors would encroach upon one another, and none would fulfill the roles of minister or servant. Those with the capacity of ministers and servants who do not accept their appointed tasks have lost their way. Thus, the relationship between ruler and minister, superior and inferior, inner and outer, hands and feet, is the natural principle of Heaven—how could it be the doing of the True Person?

**Commentary:** Ministers and servants are the lowly roles of men and women. Even within a single body, there is a distinction between ruler and minister: when seeing color, the eyes act as ruler while the ears serve as ministers; when walking, the feet act as ruler while the hands serve as ministers. This arises from Heaven’s principle—how could it be a human contrivance? It is not a matter of intentional favoritism but of natural hierarchy. Guo’s annotation states: "Those esteemed by the times become rulers; those whose talents do not match the age become ministers." Governing the state and governing the body differ not in principle.

---

**Note 11:** Ministers and servants merely fulfill their proper roles; this is not insufficient for mutual governance. Mutual governance resembles the hands, feet, ears, and eyes—each limb and part has its function and serves one another in turn.

**Commentary:** Ministers and servants perform their duties, each with its proper role. Just as the hands grasp and the feet walk, their functions are naturally sufficient—why would the feet walk because the hands are insufficient? The mechanism of Heaven unfolds spontaneously, without deliberate intent, yet all is governed. This example of hands and feet clarifies all other matters.

**Exegetical Note:** *"And in turn"* is pronounced *gēng*.

---

**Note 12:** Those esteemed by the times become rulers; those whose talents do not match the age become ministers. Like Heaven’s natural height and Earth’s natural lowness, the head resides above and the feet below—how could they alternate? Though there is no misplacement in their proper roles, they are inherently correct.

**Commentary:** The head naturally resides above, the feet naturally below; the eyes can see color, the ears can hear sound. Their use or disuse depends on the time, hence the distinction between noble and base. How could one impose preferences on high and low, alternating roles as ruler and minister? Simply entrusting all to their natural place ensures inherent correctness.

**Exegetical Note:** *"To alternate"* is pronounced *dì*; Xu also pronounces it *dì*. *"Does not match"* refers to response. *"No misplacement"* is pronounced *cuò*, as in "to interweave." The same applies below.

---

**Note 13:** Entrusting all to their nature ensures spontaneity, not artifice.

**Commentary:** Simply letting go without deliberate intent—this is the wondrous Dao of the True Ruler, dwelling within. Alternate interpretation: The True Ruler refers to the True Master mentioned earlier. The mind’s preferences—colors like blue and yellow—have no inherent nature; they arise from conditions, neither self nor other, neither non-existent nor existent. Thus, the text poses a hypothetical question to clarify that no True Ruler exists.

---

**Note 14:** Those who attain their true nature and employ their inherent capacities, even if they are menial servants, remain unmoved by praise or blame, content in their work. Thus, whether known or unknown, all remain naturally at ease. But if one opens the path of opportunism, inferiors encroach upon superiors, things lose their authenticity, and people forget their roots—then praise and blame cause one to lose composure.

**Commentary:** When mind and circumstances interact, desire and attachment arise. Thus, when one obtains what one seeks, it is deemed beneficial; when one does not, it is deemed harmful. This describes how the deluded mind clings to gain and loss, disturbing the heart. From the perspective of the Dao’s wisdom, nothing harms or benefits one’s true nature.

**Jiā Shìfù states:** "Self and other take shape and give rise to right and wrong. The right and wrong formed in the mind become its master through prior influence. Affirming this and negating that, one is enslaved by others—yet the hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera are all subsumed and follow. If this subsumption and following serve another’s will, is there truly a distinction between the mind’s mastery and its enslavement? The mind’s mastery, with its right and wrong, what does it have to do with others? Seeking to align with others’ sentiments by affirming or negating brings no benefit; failing to do so brings no harm. Yet once the form of right and wrong is constructed, the mind is enslaved to follow it, guarding it unchangingly for a lifetime—this is what is called a *fixed mind*. The *fixed mind* is what ministers and servants serve."

**Exegetical Note:** *"Even if"* is pronounced *fúyòu*. The same applies below.

"《毁誉》" is pronounced *yú*. "《物丧》" is pronounced *xīlàng*.

**[15]**
**Commentary:** Each nature has its own allotment, thus the wise preserve their wisdom to the end, while the foolish cling to their folly until death—how could there be one who alters their nature midway?

**Explication:** The endowment of form and nature has its own limits; one cannot transform folly into wisdom, nor can one exchange ugliness for beauty. Thus, once form and nature are complete, they do not perish midway. One can only guard what lies within their allotment and await the exhaustion of their Heaven-appointed years.

**[16]**
**Commentary:** The myriad beings, each with their own tendencies, clash in opposition and accord. Each trusts their own partial view and indulges their conduct, yet none can turn back. These—compared to what the multitude deems lamentable—are indeed lamentable. Yet the multitude has never taken this as lamentable, for such is their nature. Each being’s nature is thus; what among them is worthy of lament?

**Explication:** *Rèn* means opposition; *mǐ* means accord. The myriad beings, each with their keen passions, pursue objects. Since objects may oppose or accord, the mind clings to right or wrong. Their conduct spans years, swift as galloping steeds; they know only to covet objects, never ceasing. Measuring the principles of things, this is deeply lamentable.

**[17]**
**Commentary:** The passions of beings are boundless, and those who know contentment are few. Thus, having gained this, they do not stop but pursue that. All exhaust themselves in lifelong servitude, never sating their aspirations, ceasing only in death. Therefore, their success is never seen to arrive.

**Explication:** In the floating competition of beings, those who know contentment are rare. Thus, having gained this, they do not rest but pursue that. They spend their lives in exhaustion, their lives consumed by greed, chasing shadows and grasping at wind—when will their achievements ever be complete?

**Pronunciation Note:** *"Those who know contentment are few"* is pronounced *zhě xiǎn*.

**[18]**
**Commentary:** All beings employ their forms and bones in service of what they love, becoming wearied and enfeebled. Yet they do not know the ultimate aim of this love!

**Explication:** *Niérán* describes the appearance of exhaustion. Their love is fervent, their minds and spirits labored, their forms and souls worn out, enfeebled and distressed. Yet they simply trust their hearts, loving this and coveting that, demanding meaning from their intentions—yet they know not where it leads. Such extreme foolishness is deeply pitiable.

**[Pronunciation Note:]**
*"Niérán"* is pronounced *nǎi jié* in the Lu Deming reading, while Xu Shen and Li Si read it as *nǎi xié*. Cui [Shu] glosses it as "the appearance of forgetfulness." Emperor Jianwen of Liang says: "the state of fatigue and illness." ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: In modern annotated editions, *niè* is often written as *ěr* (薾). The *Shuowen* cites the *Book of Songs*: *"Bǐ ěr wéi hé"*—its pronunciation and meaning differ from this. ◎ Qingfan observes: In Sima [Biao]’s text, *niè* is written as *ěr*. The *Wen Xuan* commentary on Xie Lingyun’s *"Passing by the Beginning Peace Villa"* quotes Sima: *"Ěr* means 'extreme.'" The *Pronunciation Note* omits this. *"Suǒ hào"* is pronounced *hū bào*; the same applies below.

**[19]**
**Commentary:** In truth, this is no different from death.
**Explication:** *Xī* means "what." So mired in obsession, exhausted yet unceasing—this harms one’s conduct and offers no benefit to spirit or *qi*. It may be called "though living in days, one’s years are as dead."

**[20]**
**Commentary:** Their hearts and forms race together, worn out yet never returning. Compared to what ordinary people pity, this is true great sorrow. Yet ordinary people never regard this as sorrow—thus what they *do* pity is not worth pitying.
**Explication:** *Rán* means "thus." Thoughts shift moment by moment, the new ceaselessly flowing away. As they transform into old age, the mind’s awareness grows dim, form and spirit both altered—this is what is meant by "thus." No worldly sorrow surpasses this.

**[21]**
**Commentary:** All the above matters arise without knowing *why* they arise—hence they are called *máng*. Now, those who do not know do not know *how* they know yet know nonetheless; the living do not know *how* they live yet live nonetheless. Though the myriad things differ, in that life does not arise from knowledge, none are different—thus the world is without exception *máng*.
**Explication:** *Máng* means "dark and deluded." Ordinary people in life are so benighted—everyone in the world is confused; is there even one who is not deluded? Yet Master Zhuang, a true person embodying the Dao, wields wisdom with clarity. He humbly aligns with the dust of the world, hence the phrase *"yet I alone am máng."* Guo’s commentary slightly diverges; I do not follow it here.

**[Pronunciation Note:]**
*"Máng hū"* is pronounced *mò gāng*, or alternatively *máng*. *Máng* means "dark and deluded." Emperor Jianwen of Liang says: *Máng* means "the same."

**[22]**
**Commentary:** That by which the heart governs the body’s functions is called the *established heart*. If one takes one’s own established heart as a teacher, then each person has their own teacher. Since each has their own teacher, entrusting them to it is fitting.
**Explication:** *Chéng xīn* refers to rigid attachment to partial views, clinging to one school’s biases. Following such a fixed and obstinate heart as one’s standard—this is how the world is, so who is without a teacher?

**[23]**
**Commentary:** To replace the unformed with the formed is not knowledge—it is merely the heart’s self-satisfaction. Thus the foolish also take their established hearts as teachers, unwilling to use what they deem "short" and abandon what they deem "long."
**Explication:** The deluded and confused stubbornly cling to right and wrong. Why must they know others’ strengths to replace their own weaknesses? They only seek to dismiss others as "short" and claim their own as "long." Such people are everywhere; the foolish are always among them.

**[Pronunciation Note:]**
*"Yǔ yǒu"* is pronounced *yù*. ◎ Jia Shifu says: The *Shuowen* defines *dài* as "to replace." Today one deems something right, tomorrow wrong—yet it is already fixed in the heart. Right and wrong emerge endlessly, hence *"knowledge replaces."* The heart deems something right, then takes what it calls "right" as right; it deems something wrong, then takes what it calls "wrong" as wrong—hence *"the heart takes for itself."* *"Ér shě"* is pronounced *shě*; the character is also written as 舍, with the same pronunciation below.

**[24]**
**Commentary:** If one sets out for Yue today, how could one have arrived yesterday? Without the heart’s formation, how could right and wrong arise? That right and wrong exist is something no group can avoid—thus the perfected person accords with both.
**Explication:** The road to Wu and Yue is long; one must travel for days to arrive. If one sets out this morning, how could one have arrived yesterday? This illustrates that right and wrong, self and other, arise from deluded hearts. If the heart has not yet arisen, from where could right and wrong come? Thus, one first distinguishes and then right and wrong arise; one first sets out on the road and then reaches Yue.

**[Pronunciation Note:]**
*"Xī zhì"*—Cui [Shu] says: *Xī* means "evening." Xiang [Xiu] says: *Xī* means "yesterday." ◎ Jia Shifu says: Right and wrong arise from interaction between self and other. Yet the heart must first have a standard of right and wrong, then deem something right and affirm it, or deem something wrong and reject it. The heart responds endlessly to the myriad things, so right and wrong also become endless. Right and wrong arise from the human heart—this is why public opinion is never uniform.

**[25]**
**Commentary:** In principle, there is no right or wrong, yet the deluded take it as existing—this is taking what is not as if it were. Once the deluded heart is formed, even a sage cannot dispel it; thus one entrusts it to its natural state without forcing knowledge.
**Explication:** Yu the Great, styled Wenming, was Gun’s son and Qi’s father. The *Laws of Posthumous Titles* state: "Flowing like a spring is called *Yǔ*"; another says: "Succeeding through abdication and achieving merit is called *Yǔ*." In principle, there is no right or wrong, yet the deluded take it as existing—this is taking what is not as if it were. Once delusion has taken root, the deluded heart is formed; even a divine person like Yu the Great cannot make them awaken. Master Zhuang, deeply compassionate in his salvation, could only lament—thus he entrusted it to its natural state without forcing knowledge.

**[Pronunciation Note:]**
*"Bù qiǎng"* is pronounced *qí zhàng*. **[Textual Note:]**
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition has 有若 (*yǒu ruò*) where others have 若有 (*ruò yǒu*).

(2) The Zhao edition originally composed its own chapter titles. (3–4) The character *bǐ* and this character follow the Song edition and the Shidetang edition. (5) The Shidetang edition writes *ěr*. (6) The character *jiē* is supplied following the Daozang edition of Jiao Hong.

Now, speech is not like the blowing of wind. Those who speak have their say, yet what they speak of remains unsettled. Is there truly speech? Or has there never been speech? Does it differ from the chirping of fledglings—does it possess distinction, or does it lack distinction?

Where does the Dao conceal itself to produce truth and falsity? Where does speech conceal itself to produce right and wrong? Where does the Dao go that it does not abide? Where does speech abide that it cannot be trusted?

The Dao is obscured by minor accomplishments; speech is obscured by florid embellishment. Thus arise the right and wrong of the Confucians and Mohists, each affirming what the other negates and negating what the other affirms. If one wishes to affirm what the other negates and negate what the other affirms, then nothing surpasses illumination.

**[Annotation 1]**
Each has what they expound, hence it differs from the blowing of wind.

**[Explication]**
Both names and speech, like the blowing of wind, are forms of sound, yet those who speak must possess explanation and distinction—thus it is said they "have speech."

**[Pronunciation Note]**
*Chuī yě*: read as written, or *chì ruì* as in Cui’s note. Cui says: "Blowing, like the sound of pipes."

**[Annotation 2]**
What I deem right, others deem wrong; what others deem right, I deem wrong—thus it remains unsettled. This unsettledness arises from the partiality of self and other.

**[Explication]**
Though there is this speech, distinct from the blowing of wind, all say "I am right" and "they are wrong." Since self and other are partial, it remains uniquely unsettled.

**[Annotation 3]**
Does one take it as speech? Yet it is insufficient to settle anything.

**[Annotation 4]**
Does one take it as no speech? Yet each has already spoken from their own position.

**[Explication]**
*Guǒ* means "determined." This deems it right, that deems it wrong; this deems it wrong, that deems it right. Since right and wrong are unsettled, what does speech truly expound? Thus it is insufficient to claim there is definite speech. Yet with partial views on both sides, each clings to right and wrong, and from their own position, it cannot be said there is no speech.

**[Annotation 5]**
Speech and the chirping of fledglings share the same end—whether they possess distinction or lack distinction cannot truly be settled. The sentiments of the world need not be the same, yet what is spoken cannot differ, hence right and wrong arise in profusion, with no way to settle them.

**[Explication]**
*Biàn* means "distinction." When a birdling seeks to emerge from its egg and chirps, this is called the sound of a fledgling; speech that is still encased is also called a fledgling. With partial clinging on both sides and right and wrong unsettled, how does it differ from the sound of fledglings—possessing sound but no distinction? Thus, to claim that speech differs from the sound of fledglings may not suffice to establish distinction.

**[Pronunciation Note]**
*Kòu*: *kǔ dòu* as a fanqie, or Li reads it as *gòu*. Sima says: "A birdling about to emerge."

**[Explication 6]**
*Wū hū* means "in what" or "where." The Dao, empty and all-pervading, is neither true nor false—where could it conceal itself to give rise to truth and falsity?

**[Pronunciation Note]**
*Wū hū*: pronounced *wū*; the same below. *Zhēn wěi*: one edition writes *zhēn guǐ*; Cui’s edition writes *zhēn rán*.

**[Annotation 7]**
The Dao is nowhere absent! Where does speech conceal itself to produce truth and falsity, giving rise to the profusion of names for right and wrong?

**[Explication]**
The ultimate teaching and ultimate speech are neither right nor wrong—where do they conceal themselves to produce right and wrong?

**[Pronunciation Note]**
*Dào yān*: *yú qián* as a fanqie.

**[Annotation 8]**
It abides everywhere.

**[Explication]**
*Cún* means "to be present." The Dao, which shapes and nurtures living beings, pervades all without ceasing—where is it not present? Thus it is present in falsity and truth, yet neither true nor false.

**[Annotation 9]**
It is all permissible.

**[Explication]**
The mysterious Dao and true speech give life and take it away according to things—where is it not permissible? Thus it affirms what can be affirmed and negates what can be negated, yet neither negates what is not nor affirms what is not.

**[Explication 10]**
"Minor accomplishments" refers to benevolence, righteousness, and the Five Virtues—small paths that achieve some attainment, hence called minor accomplishments. In an age of shallow customs and frivolous times, only benevolence and righteousness are practiced, and the great Dao cannot be enacted. Thus it is said the Dao is obscured by minor accomplishments, yet the Dao cannot truly be obscured. Hence Laozi says: "When the great Dao is abandoned, there is benevolence and righteousness."

**[Annotation 11]**
Minor accomplishments and florid embellishment conceal themselves within the Dao, yet the Dao cannot be concealed. Thus truth and falsity, right and wrong, operate within florid embellishment and halt at what is truly fitting; they appear in minor accomplishments and vanish in great wholeness.

**[Explication]**
"Florid embellishment" refers to ornate, disputatious words and flowery speech. Precisely because it clings to florid disputation, it obscures the ultimate speech. Thus Laozi’s scripture says: "Trustworthy words are not beautiful; beautiful words are not trustworthy."

**[Pronunciation Note]**
*Shí dàng*: *dīng làng* as a fanqie. The rest can be inferred and will not be repeatedly noted. *Jiàn yú*: *xián biàn* as a fanqie.

**[Explication 12]**
Long ago, there was a man of Zheng named Huan who studied in the land of Qiu. After three years, his skills were perfected, and he transformed into a Confucian. Confucians trace their lineage to Yao and Shun, take the regulations of Wen and Wu as their model, practice the Dao of benevolence and righteousness, and distinguish the positions of high and low—hence they are called Confucians. Huan’s younger brother was named Di; Huan transformed his brother, and he became a Mohist. Mohists follow the Dao of Yu: they esteem worthiness, revere ritual, practice frugality and universal love, and wear themselves to the bone to save the common people—this is called Mohism.

Huan and Di, though kin as brothers, each adhered to a different teaching and ceaselessly disputed one another’s right and wrong. Huan resented his brother so deeply that he died of indignation. Yet the conflict between self and other, right and wrong, has endured since ancient times. The intensity of such contention arose with these two worthies, who are thus singled out as the ringleaders of factional strife. This shows that when the Dao is lost, words are obscured, and the scrutiny of right and wrong begins.

**[Explication 13]**
**Annotation:** As Confucians and Mohists disputed one another’s right and wrong, the world became divided between Confucians and Mohists. Thus, the Hundred Schools arose, each prizing its own views and never stepping beyond its own bounds.

**Explication:** The world takes itself as right and others as wrong; others likewise deem you wrong and themselves right. Thus, each uses its own right to affirm the other’s wrong, and its own wrong to negate the other’s right.

**[Fanqie]**
*Gēng xiāng*: *gēng* as a fanqie.

**[Explication 14]**
**Annotation:** Those who affirm right and wrong are what Confucians and Mohists affirm; those who negate right and wrong are what Confucians and Mohists negate. Now, to affirm what Confucians and Mohists negate and negate what Confucians and Mohists affirm is to seek to clarify the negation of right and wrong. To clarify the negation of right and wrong, nothing surpasses using Confucians and Mohists to mutually illuminate one another. When they mutually illuminate one another, what they affirm is not truly right, and what they negate is not truly wrong. If what is negated is not wrong, then there is no wrong; if what is affirmed is not right, then there is no right.

**Explication:** The world deems others wrong and itself right. To invert wrong into right and right into wrong, nothing surpasses using self and other to mutually illuminate one another. When they mutually illuminate one another, what is negated is not truly wrong—thus there is no wrong—and what is affirmed is not truly right—thus there is no right. With no right, there is no wrong, and one realizes that right and wrong are both illusory.

◎ **Jia Shifu’s note:** Guo Xiang says, “Those who affirm right and wrong are what Confucians and Mohists affirm; those who negate right and wrong are what Confucians and Mohists negate. Now, to affirm what Confucians and Mohists negate and negate what Confucians and Mohists affirm, nothing surpasses using Confucians and Mohists to mutually illuminate one another, so that what they affirm is not truly right and what they negate is not truly wrong.” Upon examining the books of Mozi and Mencius’s refutations of Yang and Mo, one sees Confucians and Mohists disputing one another’s right and wrong, each clinging to its own views to seek victory. Mohists affirm what Confucians negate, and Confucians negate what Mohists affirm. The formation of right and wrong, the division of self and other, arise from this. Self and other take opposing forms, and right and wrong stand in duality—thus, the right and wrong they uphold are not true right and wrong, for the distinction between self and other remains. Nothing surpasses using the clarity of one to mutually verify the other. Guo Xiang’s annotation is mistaken.

**Textual Notes:**
*[Fanfu]* reads *fāng fú* (芳服). The same below.
**Emendation:** (1) The character *qiú* follows the *Yufu* chapter.

---

Things are nothing that is not "that," things are nothing that is not "this." From the perspective of "that," one does not see; from self-knowledge, one knows. Thus it is said: "That" emerges from "this," and "this" likewise depends on "that." This is the doctrine of "that" and "this" arising in mutual opposition. Yet even as they arise, they are already dying; even as they die, they are already arising. Even as "right" is affirmed, "wrong" is affirmed; even as "wrong" is affirmed, "right" is affirmed. Affirming "right" because of "wrong," affirming "wrong" because of "right."

Therefore, the sage does not proceed by this path but illuminates it by means of Heaven—this too is a matter of dependence. "This" is also "that," and "that" is also "this." "That" has its own right and wrong, and "this" has its own right and wrong. Is there truly a "that" and "this"? Or is there truly no "that" and "this"? Where "that" and "this" find no counterpart, this is called the *pivot of the Dao*. Once the pivot is grasped at the center of the ring, it responds to the infinite. "Right" is one infinity, and "wrong" is another infinity. Thus it is said: nothing surpasses using clarity.

To illustrate the non-"finger"-ness of a finger by means of a finger is not as good as illustrating the non-"finger"-ness of a finger by means of a non-finger. To illustrate the non-"horse"-ness of a horse by means of a horse is not as good as illustrating the non-"horse"-ness of a horse by means of a non-horse. Heaven and Earth are one finger; the myriad things are one horse.

---

**Annotations:**
1. **Commentary:** All things regard themselves as "right," hence nothing is not "right"; all things regard others as "that," hence nothing is not "that." If nothing is not "that," then there is no "right" in the world; if nothing is not "right," then there is no "that" in the world. Without "that" and without "right," this is the profound unity.
   **Exegesis:** As the commentary states: all things regard themselves as "right," hence nothing is not "right"; all things regard others as "that," hence nothing is not "that." If nothing is not "that," then there is no "right" in the world; if nothing is not "right," then there is no "that" in the world. Without "that" and without "right," this is the profound unity. This commentary exhausts the principle; no further explanation is needed.

2. **Exegesis:** When one is regarded as "that" by "that," one does not see oneself; when one knows oneself as "right," one then knows. The partiality of things is universally like this. If one could truly see the other’s perspective and one’s own, then there would be no "right" and no "wrong."

3. **Commentary:** The partiality of things means that none see what the other sees but only know what they themselves know. Knowing what they themselves know, they regard themselves as "right." Regarding themselves as "right," they regard the other as "wrong." Thus it is said: "That" emerges from "this," and "this" likewise depends on "that"—"that" and "this" arise in mutual dependence.
   **Exegesis:** Now, "that" opposes "this," and "right" depends on "wrong"—this is the general structure of discourse. The statement "that emerges from this" expresses a subtle principle, emphasizing the angle of "that." It aims to show that by illustrating "that," one clarifies "this," and by illustrating "right," one clarifies "wrong." Yet "that" and "this," "right" and "wrong," arise in mutual dependence. When one seeks to analyze them, their very essence is emptiness.

4. **Commentary:** The transformations of life and death are like the progression of the four seasons: spring, autumn, winter, summer. Thus, though the states of life and death differ, in each finding peace where they are, they are the same. Now, the living regard life as life, while the dead regard life as death—thus there is no life. The living regard death as death, while the dead regard death as life—thus there is no death. Without life and without death, without "right" and without "wrong," the debates of Confucians and Mohists are something with which I cannot agree. Yet when each obscures their own position, I cannot disagree either.
   **Exegesis:** *Fāng* means "just now." The mutual opposition of "that" and "this," "right" and "wrong," is no different from the doctrine of life and death. Life and death alternate like the succession of cold and heat. The living regard life as life, while the dead regard life as death. Likewise, those who affirm "right" regard "right" as "right," while those who negate it regard "right" as "wrong." Thus, one affirms "wrong" because of "right," and affirms "right" because of "wrong." Affirming "right" because of "wrong" means there is no "right"; affirming "wrong" because of "right" means there is no "wrong." Thus, without "right" and without "wrong," without life and without death, without "right" and without "wrong," what debate is there between "that" and "this"?

5. **Commentary:** The open-minded one relies on the world’s "right" and "wrong" to be without "right" and "wrong." Thus, not proceeding by the path of "right" and "wrong," and having no concern that "right" and "wrong" are not properly aligned, one simply illuminates their natural state without being swayed.
   **Exegesis:** *Tiān* means "nature." The sage, in profound understanding, does not proceed by affirming "right" or negating "wrong," but simply abides in emptiness and stillness, illuminating with the wisdom of nature. Only by means of this "right" and "wrong" does one attain non-"wrong" and non-"right," never abandoning existence to separately verify non-existence.

6. **Commentary:** I am also regarded as "that" by "that."

7. **Commentary:** "That" also regards itself as "right."
   **Exegesis:** I regard myself as "right," yet I am negated by "that"; I regard "that" as "wrong," yet "that" also regards itself as "right."

8. **Commentary:** "This" regards itself as "right" and negates "that"; "that" regards itself as "right" and negates "this." Thus, "this" and "that" each have their own "right" and "wrong" within their own framework.
   **Exegesis:** "This" regards itself as "right," and "that" regards itself as "right"; "this" negates "that," and "that" negates "this." Thus, each has its own "right" and its own "wrong."

9. **Commentary:** Now, if one wishes to regard "that" as "that," "that" regards itself as "right"; if one wishes to regard "right" as "right," "right" is regarded as "that" by "that." Thus, the existence or non-existence of "that" and "right" is not yet definitively settled.
   **Exegesis:** "That" and "this," "right" and "wrong," stand in mutual opposition. When one examines them in reverse, their entire substance is floating and insubstantial. Though one regards oneself as "right," this is not without basis.

To be negated by "that" is to lack "this." The existence or non-existence of "that" and "this" cannot yet be determined.

**Exegesis:** 《彼复》pronounced *fúyòu*, same below.

**10. Commentary:** "Occasional" means "opposition." "That" and "this" stand in opposition, yet the sage accords with both. Thus, the one without intent merges with things, never having any opposition in the world. (The *pivot* is the essential.) Abiding in this pivot and converging at the profound extremity, one responds to the boundless.

**Exegesis:** "Occasional" means "opposition." The *pivot* is the essential. To embody the emptiness of both "that" and "this," the illusoriness of both "right" and "wrong," and to perceive with concentrated spirit without opposition in the world—this is to converge at the profound extremity and grasp the pivot of the Dao. Earlier, a hypothetical question was posed about existence and non-existence, with affirmation and negation unsettled; here, "that" and "this" are further clarified as inherently empty. The former is shallow, the latter profound—hence their sequence.

**Exegesis:** 《道枢》pronounced *chǐzhū*. The *pivot* is the essential. 《以应》means "to respond." As in the previous note, subsequent instances may be inferred and will not be repeatedly annotated.

**11. Commentary:** Now, "right" and "wrong" reverse endlessly, pursuing one another without cease—hence they are called a *ring*. The center of the ring is empty. If one takes "right" and "wrong" as a ring and attains its center, one attains neither "right" nor "wrong." Having neither "right" nor "wrong," one can respond to "right" and "wrong." Since "right" and "wrong" are endless, so too is the response.

**Exegesis:** The absolute transformation beyond dependence is the origin of the Dao and the essential of learning—hence it is called the *pivot*. The *ring* is metaphorically two apertures; the *center* is the true emptiness of the one Dao. The center of the ring is empty, illustrating the absence of both "right" and "wrong." Since "right" and "wrong" are endless, so too is the response.

◎ Jia Shifu says: As "right" and "wrong" transform, the Dao abides therein—hence it is called the *pivot of the Dao*. Grasping the pivot of the Dao and roaming within the ring, the *center* is emptiness. "Right" and "wrong" reverse endlessly, pursuing one another like a ring. Roaming within emptiness, one is not enslaved by "right" and "wrong" and can thus respond without end.

◎ Qingfan notes: The Tang Buddhist Zhanran’s *Zhiguan Fuxing Chuan Hongjue* cites an ancient commentary on the *Zhuangzi*: "The interior of a circular ring is empty and boundless—hence it is called the *center of the ring*."

**12. Commentary:** In the world, none do not regard themselves as "right" and none do not negate others. Thus, one "right" and one "wrong" proceed endlessly. Only one who enters emptiness and attains the center remains unbound, riding it to roam.

**Exegesis:** There are none who do not regard themselves as "right"—hence "right" is endless. There are none who do not negate others—hence "wrong" is endless. Only one who forgets both self and other, relinquishes both "right" and "wrong," and attains the Dao within the ring can thus accord with all beings and ride it to roam.

**13. Exegesis:** "Finger" refers to a finger of the hand. "Horse" refers to a gaming piece. "Metaphor" means "comparison." People cling to "right" and "wrong," their sentiments differing between self and other. Thus, if one uses one’s own finger to compare with another’s finger, the other’s finger becomes a "non-finger." If one then uses the other’s finger to compare with your finger, your finger becomes a "non-finger" relative to the other’s. The same principle applies to fingers as to horses. Among all dharmas, the finger is uniquely venerated to illustrate that nothing is more immediate than the body or more essential than the finger, while nothing is more distant than external things or more decisive in victory and defeat than the horse. Thus, these two examples are used to illustrate "right" and "wrong."

**14. Commentary:** To regard oneself as "right" and negate others is the common sentiment of self and other. Thus, if one uses one’s own finger to illustrate another’s finger, the other’s finger becomes a "non-finger" relative to one’s own. This is using a finger to illustrate the "non-finger" nature of a finger. If one then uses the other’s finger to illustrate one’s own, one’s own finger becomes a "non-finger" relative to the other’s. This is using a "non-finger" to illustrate the "non-finger" nature of a finger. To clarify the absence of both "right" and "wrong," nothing is better than mutual illustration through reversal. Through mutual illustration, self and other are alike in regarding themselves as "right" and alike in negating one another. Being alike in negation, the world has no "right"; being alike in self-affirmation, the world has no "wrong." How can this be demonstrated? If "right" were truly "right," the world would have no one to negate it. If "wrong" were truly "wrong," the world would likewise have no one to affirm it. Now, with no fixed ground for "right" or "wrong," all is confusion and disorder—showing that these petty distinctions are merely each clinging to their own biases while converging in uniformity. Looking up and down, none are otherwise. Thus, the perfected person knows that heaven and earth are one finger, and the myriad things are one horse. Hence, they abide in vast tranquility, and heaven, earth, and the myriad things each attain their place, converging in self-contentment, without "right" or "wrong."

**Exegesis:** Though the world is vast, it can be encompassed by one finger. Though the myriad things are many, they can be governed by one horse. How is this known? Now, through mutual illustration by reversal of "right" and "wrong" between self and other, what is affirmed is not truly "right," and what is negated is not truly "wrong." Thus, the two poles and the myriad things are without "right" or "wrong."

**Exegesis:** 《天地一指也万物一马也》Cui says: "A finger is one part of the hundred limbs; a horse is one thing among the myriad things." 《浩然》pronounced *hùlǎo*.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) "The *pivot* is the essential" is supplemented from Jiao Hong’s edition.
(2) "With" and "again" are emended to "this" following the Song edition.
(3) "That" is emended to "again" following Jiao Hong’s edition.
(4) "Then the world" is supplemented from Jiao Hong’s edition.

Is it acceptable? Is it unacceptable? The Dao is enacted and thereby completed. Things are named and thereby affirmed. Why is it affirmed? It is affirmed as affirmed. Why is it not affirmed?

"Not affirmed as not affirmed. Things inherently have what they affirm, things inherently have what they approve. There is nothing that is not affirmed, nothing that is not approved. Thus, I cite the stalk and the pillar, the leper and Xi Shi, the expansive and the cunning, the strange and the monstrous—all are pervaded by the Dao and united as one. Their division is their formation; their formation is their destruction. For all things, there is no formation or destruction, but they return to being pervaded and united as one. Only the enlightened know this unity, and for this reason, they do not employ it but lodge it in the ordinary. The ordinary is employment; employment is pervasion; pervasion is attainment. Attaining this, one is nearly there. Proceeding from this is sufficient. Proceeding thus without knowing why it is so is called the Dao. To exhaust one’s spirit and clarity in uniting them while not knowing their sameness is called 'morning three.' What is 'morning three'? The monkey keeper distributed chestnuts, saying, 'Three in the morning and four in the evening,' and all the monkeys were angry. He then said, 'Then four in the morning and three in the evening,' and all the monkeys were pleased. Names and realities were not diminished, yet joy and anger were employed—this too proceeds from this. Therefore, the sage harmonizes them with right and wrong and rests in the celestial potter’s wheel. This is called 'walking the two paths.'"

**Annotations:**
1. *Xi Shi*: A renowned beauty of ancient China.
2. *Celestial potter’s wheel* (*tiānjūn* 天钧): A metaphor for the natural order or spontaneity of the Dao.
3. *Walking the two paths* (*liǎngxíng* 兩行): A term denoting the simultaneous affirmation of dualities without contradiction.

"The *tíng* (莛) is pronounced *tíng* in Xu’s reading and *tǐng* in Li’s. Sima [Biao] says: it is a roof beam. The *yíng* (楹) is pronounced *yíng*. Sima says: it is a roof pillar." Yu Yue notes: "Sima takes *tíng* as a roof beam and *yíng* as a roof pillar, hence Guo [Xiang] says *tíng* is horizontal while *yíng* is vertical." However, the *Shuowen* states: *tíng* means a stem. The interpretation of *tíng* as a roof beam is not its original meaning. The *Hanshu*’s *Biography of Dongfang Shuo* records using a *tíng* to strike a bell, and the *Wenxuan*’s *Responding to the Guest’s Difficulties* writes *tíng* as *tíng*. Li’s annotation cites the *Shuo Yuan*: "To erect the world’s resonant bell and strike it with a *tíng*—how could it produce sound?" *Tíng* and *tíng* are interchangeable. Thus, in ancient texts, *tíng* refers to something small. *Tíng* and *yíng* are distinguished by size, just as *Lì* and *Xī Shī* are distinguished by beauty and ugliness. The old interpretation is incorrect.

"*Lì* (厉) is read as written, meaning 'ugly.' Li pronounces it *lài*. Sima says: it means 'leprosy.' *Xī Shī* (西施): Sima says she was *Xià Jī*. In fact, she was the beautiful woman sent by Goujian to the King of Wu. *Huī* (恢) is pronounced *kuāi* in Xu’s reading and *huǐ* in Guo’s. The *Jianwen* edition writes it as *diào*. Lu Wenchong notes: "*Diào* is pronounced *dì*. The following character is synonymous with *guǐ* (诡). *Diàoguǐ* appears below. *Jiǎo* ( ) is pronounced *jiǔwěi* in Xu’s reading and *jiǔbǐ* in Li’s. Li says: it means 'perverse.' *Juéguài* (谲怪) is pronounced *jué*. Li says: *jué* means 'deviant,' and *guài* means 'strange.'"

Jia Shifu says: "Regarding 'can' and 'cannot,' 'so' and 'not so,' the enlightened discard them without use, yet lodge use within non-use—thus they are united as one. *Yíng zòng* (楹纵) is also written as *cóng* (从), both pronounced *jiōng*."

**9. Annotation:** Things may be scattered in one context yet complete in another.
**Exegesis:** Things may be scattered here yet complete there, illustrating that gathering and scattering are not constant—one cannot cling to fixed notions. This further elaborates the principle of non-duality.

**10. Annotation:** What I call completion, others may call destruction.
**Exegesis:** What is completion here may be destruction there. The application of things differs, as in the case of scattered fur forming a coat or felled trees becoming a house.

**11. Annotation:** Completion and destruction arise from self-perception without seeing the other. Thus, there is neither completion nor destruction, just as there is neither right nor wrong.
**Exegesis:** Completion and destruction, right and wrong, arise from partiality. Since completion and destruction are not fixed, and right and wrong have no basis, there is no completion or destruction—they are united as one.

**12. Exegesis:** *Yù* (寓) means 'to lodge,' and *yōng* (庸) means 'to employ.' Only those who grasp the Dao, concentrating their spirit in profound insight, can transcend dualistic bias and unite them as one. For this reason, they accomplish without claiming success, employ without conscious use, and lodge their function in the multitude of things.

**13. Annotation:** The enlightened are not confined to one side, so they spontaneously forget themselves and lodge their function in self-use. In self-use, all things flow smoothly and find their own fulfillment.
**Exegesis:** Those who achieve great deeds yet attribute success to others, who govern the multitudes yet lodge their function in the people—are they not sages? Thus, they respond without intention, their spirit unobstructed, embodying the Dao and attaining the profound pearl at the Red Waters.

**14. Annotation:** *Jī* (几) means 'exhaustive.' The ultimate principle is fully realized in self-attainment.
**Exegesis:** *Jī* means 'exhaustive.' Attainment is neither internal reliance on the self nor external reliance on things—it is without thought, without action, without learning, without dependence. Spontaneously attained, it has no origin, harmonizing with principle and thus exhausting its subtlety.
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Jī* (几) is pronounced *jī*, meaning 'exhaustive.' The same below."

Xu finished dressing and turned away.

**15. Annotation:** The enlightened follow without contrivance.
**Exegesis:** Those who grasp the Dao act without intention, remain without attachment. Thus, they follow right and wrong yet transcend right and wrong, follow self and other yet transcend self and other. They merely follow—how could they impose their feelings?

**16. Annotation:** When the enlightened follow, do they know they follow what is good and thus follow it? They do not know why they follow; they simply follow spontaneously—this is called the Dao.
**Exegesis:** "Thereupon" signifies continuity from what precedes. The perfected person, free of intention, responds to stimuli as a bright mirror or an empty valley reflects all things.
