They follow the myriad beings, echo the multitudes, yet know not why they do so or why they respond. How could they harbor feelings of approval or disdain, or be bound by gain and loss? To model oneself after others—this is the Dao of spontaneity.
**Phonetic Annotation:** *"Called the Dao"*—Xiang and Guo treat this as a full stop. Cui reads *"called the Dao’s labor,"* explaining: following nature is the Dao’s work.

**17. Exegesis:** The mysterious Dao is wondrously one, ever serene and undisturbed—not unified through the labor of mind or intellect. Yet fools exhaust their spirit in chance debates, seeking unity. They differ not from those who fail to attain unity and are thus unworthy of reliance. Not knowing the supreme principle, they remain unaware that principle unifies itself—how could unity require the imposition of intention?

**18. Exegesis:** This introduces a parable.
◎ Jia Shifu notes: *"Called ‘morning three’"* clarifies that "morning three" is the point. Since the acorns are distributed in the morning, the monkeys rejoice at four but rage at three—both judgments fixate on a single corner. Thus, this is called "following."

**19. Annotation:** When the enlightened attain unity, do they labor their spirit? If one exhausts their spirit to achieve unity, they are unworthy of reliance and differ not from those who fail to attain unity. They are like the deluded monkeys, following their preferences and insisting on their own rightness.
**Exegesis:** This explains the parable. *Ju* (狙) means macaque. *Fu* (赋) means to distribute. *Xu* (芧) are acorns, resembling chestnuts but smaller. *Liezi* states: In Song there was an old man who kept monkeys and understood their ways. He teased them, saying: *"I will give you acorns—three in the morning and four in the evening. Is that enough?"* The monkeys rose in anger. He then said: *"I will give you four in the morning and three in the evening. Is that enough?"* The monkeys all prostrated themselves in delight. Morning three and evening four, morning four and evening three—both sum to seven. The name is unchanged, the quantity undiminished, yet they alternate between joy and rage, so foolish and deluded. They, too, follow their preferences and insist on their own rightness. Likewise, those who exhaust their minds, embellish their words, and forcibly unify the myriad things—how do they differ from the deluded monkeys?
**Phonetic Annotation:** *"Ju Gong"* (狙公): seven *xu* rhyme, also *zīlǜ* rhyme. Sima explains: *Ju Gong* is the official in charge of monkeys. Cui explains: one who raises apes and monkeys. Li explains: an old monkey. *Guangya* states: *ju* means macaque. *"Fu xu"* (赋芧): *xù* rhyme, Xu reads *shí rǔ*, Li reads *yǔ*. Sima explains: acorns. *"Morning three, evening four"* (朝三暮四): Sima explains: three measures in the morning, four in the evening. *"Preferences"* (所好): *hūbào* rhyme. The same below.

**20. Annotation:** Without partiality, one entrusts all to spontaneous equilibrium.
**Exegesis:** *Tianjun* (天均) is the principle of natural balance. The sage who grasps the Dao, empty and unattached, harmonizes right with non-right, unites wrong with non-wrong. Thus, they rest their intellect in the realm of equilibrium and still their heart in the境 of spontaneity.
**Phonetic Annotation:** *"Tianjun"* (天钧): also written as *Tianjun* (天均). Cui explains: *jun* means potter’s wheel.

**21. Annotation:** Entrusting oneself to the world’s right and wrong.
**Exegesis:** Not departing from right and wrong yet transcending right and wrong—this is called "walking both paths."
**Collation Notes:**
(1) The Zhao Jiayi edition omits *"ge"* (各).
(2) *"Lai"* (赖) is amended following the annotation below.

The ancients—their knowledge reached its utmost.
Wherein did it reach its utmost?

There are those who hold that things have never yet begun to exist—this is the utmost, the ultimate, to which nothing can be added. Next are those who hold that things exist, yet boundaries have never yet arisen. Next are those who hold that boundaries exist, yet right and wrong have never yet arisen. The manifestation of right and wrong is the reason the Dao suffers loss. The reason the Dao suffers loss is that attachment takes shape. Is there truly completion and loss? Is there truly no completion and loss? Where there is completion and loss, this is why Master Zhao plays the zither; where there is no completion and loss, this is why Master Zhao does not play the zither. Master Zhao’s playing of the zither, Master Kuang’s tapping of his baton, and Master Hui’s leaning against the catalpa tree—these three men’s knowledge reached its utmost, all being at their peak, and thus their deeds are recorded at life’s end.

Only because they were fond of it did they differ from others; because they were fond of it, they desired to make it clear. Yet what they sought to make clear was not something that could be made clear, and so they ended in the obscurity of "hard and white." Moreover, Master Zhao’s son spent his life following the threads of his father’s art, yet in the end achieved nothing. Could this be called achievement? Even I, too, would have achieved something. Could this not be called achievement? Then neither things nor I have achieved anything.

Thus, the dazzling confusion of doubt is what the sage contemplates. To act without employing it yet lodge it in the ordinary—this is called "illuminating through clarity."

Though Zhao Wen had mastered the art of zither-playing, how could two others share the same skill? Moreover, upon examining the records, there is no mention of Hui Zi’s proficiency in the zither. As for "leaning on the wu," it merely refers to resting one’s arms upon a wu-table while discoursing—akin to those who recline upon a low table. *Ji* means "exhaustion." Zhao Wen excelled in zither-playing, Shi Kuang possessed a sublime understanding of musical harmony, and Hui Shi delighted in debating names and principles. The natures of these three men were endowed by Heaven, each employing their own abilities to illuminate the world. Yet the world remained unmoved, and they themselves grew weary, leading them to prop up their staffs and doze or rest their heads upon the table in slumber. Thus, the full extent of their abilities was exhausted in this manner.

Zhao Wen’s son, in turn, carried on his father’s legacy to its end, yet ultimately achieved nothing. Moreover, if these three could be called accomplished, then even I—lacking such accomplishment—could also be deemed accomplished. Thus, neither things nor I have achieved anything.

This dazzling confusion of doubt is what the sage contemplates. The sage does not display this to dazzle others, nor does he abandon himself to chase after things. Instead, he follows along, allowing each to obscurely fulfill its own capacity. Thus, he achieves partial completion without omission. Now, these three men sought to illuminate others with their own preferences—was this not delusion?

For the sage is one who has transcended the self.

Thus, when faced with the dazzling confusion of doubt, one maps and bounds it; when encountering the vast and strange, one unifies and harmonizes it. Allowing each of the myriad differences to rest in what they find restful, and the multitude of people not to lose what they deem right—then the self is not employed by things, and the uses of the myriad things are fully realized. When all things employ themselves, who is right and who is wrong? Therefore, even in the face of unbridled transformations and the peculiar and extraordinary, by bending to follow them and entrusting them to their own use, though their uses may be myriad and diverse, they become distinctly clear of themselves.

The sage, in harmony with Heaven and Earth in virtue, matches the sun and moon in brightness. Thus, he conceals his traces to blend with the common, veils his brilliance to engage with things, never dazzling the multitude nor confusing the people. Nor does he pride himself to lead others, but rather sets boundaries within each one’s allotted part, forgetting his concerns to accord with the myriad things, thereby entrusting use to the multitude of talents. Such a way of directing the mind may truly be called sagely illumination and genuine understanding.

Now, let there be words here—are they of the same kind as this, or not?

Whether they be of the same kind or not, if they are taken together as a kind, then they differ in no way from those. Yet, though it be so, let me attempt to speak of it.

There is that which has a beginning; there is that which has not yet begun to have a beginning; there is that which has not yet begun to have that which has not yet begun to have a beginning. There is being; there is non-being; there is that which has not yet begun to have non-being; there is that which has not yet begun to have that which has not yet begun to have non-being.

Suddenly, there is being and non-being, yet we do not know which of the two—being or non-being—is truly being or truly non-being. Now, I have already spoken, yet I do not know whether what I have spoken is truly speech or truly not speech.

In all the world, nothing is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small; nothing lives longer than a child who dies young, yet Pengzu died prematurely. Heaven and Earth were born together with me, and the myriad things and I are one.

Since we are already one, can there be speech? Since we have already called it one, can there be no speech? One and speech make two; two and one make three. Proceeding from this, even the cleverest reckoner cannot reach an end—how much less can ordinary people! Therefore, from non-being to being, we arrive at three—how much more if we proceed from being to being! Do not proceed thus; follow this instead.

[11] **Commentary:** To say there is no right or wrong is itself another assertion.
**Exegesis:** *Jifu* (即复) is read as *fúyòu* (扶又反).

[12] **Commentary:** Yet one does not know whether such speech pertains to being or non-being, and thus the mind becomes utterly free of even the slightest trace of attachment.
**Exposition:** *Wei* (谓) means "speech." Master Zhuang again refrains from speaking. Though the principle emerges through verbal instruction—such as the earlier request to "try speaking"—once this speech is employed to elucidate the principle, one cannot determine whether such speech is definitively speech or definitively not speech. This is to show that the realm of principle transcends both silence and speech, just as teaching transcends both non-being and being. Fearing that scholars might become attached to words, he thus expresses himself in this manner.
**Exegesis:** *Xiānjiè* (纤介) is read as *gǔmài* (古迈反), or alternatively as *jiè* (界).
**Note by Lu Wenchang:** In modern editions, *jiè* (介) is written as *jiè* (芥).

[13] **Commentary:** When things are compared by form, a great mountain is indeed greater than the tip of an autumn hair. Yet if each abides by its own nature and attains its utmost, then a large form is not excessive, nor is a small form deficient. If each is sufficient in its nature, then the tip of an autumn hair is not merely small in its smallness, nor is a great mountain merely great in its greatness. If sufficiency in nature is deemed greatness, then nothing in the world is more sufficient than the tip of an autumn hair; if sufficiency in nature is not deemed greatness, then even a great mountain may be called small. Thus it is said: "Nothing in the world is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small." If a great mountain is small, then nothing in the world is great; if the tip of an autumn hair is great, then nothing in the world is small. Without small or great, without long life or early death, the cicada does not envy the great *chun* tree but rejoices in its own contentment, and the marsh pheasant does not prize the celestial pond but finds glory in its own sufficiency. If one is content with Heaven’s natural endowment and at peace with one’s nature and destiny, then even Heaven and Earth are not long-lived enough to surpass one’s own birth, and the myriad things are not distinct enough to differ from one’s own attainment. Thus, how could the birth of Heaven and Earth not be simultaneous with mine, and how could the attainment of the myriad things not be one with mine?
**Exposition:** In autumn, animals grow fine hair, the tip of which is exceedingly minute—hence the term "tip of an autumn hair." A child who dies in infancy is called a *shāngzǐ* (殇子). *Tài* (太) means "great." All things, in their arising, differ in form and *qi*: some are small, some large, some short-lived, some long-lived. Yet if we speak in terms of their nature, none is not self-sufficient. Thus, if sufficiency in nature is deemed greatness, nothing in the world is greater than the tip of an autumn hair; if having no excess is deemed smallness, nothing in the world is smaller than a great mountain. If a great mountain is small, then nothing in the world is great; if the tip of an autumn hair is great, then nothing in the world is small. Just as small and great are thus, so too are early death and long life. Therefore, though the Two Modes (Heaven and Earth) are vast, their nature is equal in sufficiency; though the myriad things are numerous, their principle of self-attainment is one. Previously, it was shown that there is no end or beginning, no being or non-being; here, it is shown that there is no small or great, no early death or long life.

Here is the translation:

---

**Exegetical Notes:**
*"Autumn hair"* (秋豪) is read as written. According to the character, it should be written as *háo* (毫). Sima [Biao] says: rabbit fur forms in autumn. Wang Yi’s commentary on the *Chu Ci* states: it refers to fine hair. Since hair becomes soft and fine in autumn, it is used as a metaphor for smallness.
*"Great mountain"* (大山) is pronounced *tài*.
*"Short-lived child"* (殇子) refers to one who dies young. Some say: those who die before nineteen are called *shāng*.

**[14] [Commentary]**
The myriad things, though myriad in form, are the same in self-attainment—their attainment is one. Having already attained oneness, there is no principle to speak of.

**[15] [Commentary]**
Names and terms arise from what is not understood. When things cannot clarify their own oneness and instead pursue one another, they are called "one" to correct them. Once called "one," this is already speech.

**[Exegesis]**
The mysterious Dao is silent, its principle beyond form and sound. To guide the lost, terms and names arise. Thus, though the One is the profound origin, it remains within the realm of names and teachings. If it is called "one," how can it be said to be without speech?

**[16] [Commentary]**
To speak of the One with speech—yet the One is not speech—is to make the One and speech two. The One is already one; speech makes it two. With one and two, can this not be called three? To speak of the One with one word is already to reach three; how much more so when tracing its branches and the myriad things’ diverse names? Even with skilled calculation, none can enumerate them. Thus, those who speak of the One do not differ from others, while those who forget the One attain oneness without speech.

**[Exegesis]**
The wondrous principle of the One is beyond speech; thus, to speak of the One is not the One. The One is already one; speech speaks of it again. With one and speech, two names arise. Comparing the later two names to the earlier wondrous One, with one and two, can this not be called three? From three onward, even one skilled in calculation cannot count the numbers—how much less can ordinary people!


**[Exegetical Notes:]**
*"Diverse names"* (殊称) is read *shū zhèng*.
*"Skilled calculation"* (善数) is read *shàn shǔ*.

**[17] [Commentary]**
The One is without speech; with speech, it reaches three. How much more when tracing its endless numbers—can they be exhausted?

**[Exegesis]**
*Self* (自) means "from"; *proceed* (适) means "to go." The ultimate principle is without speech; speech gives rise to names. Thus, from no speech to speech, as soon as speech arises, it reaches three. How much more from speech to speech, where branches flow and diverge—can they be exhausted? This shows that all myriad dharmas originally have no names; from nothing, they arise, and thus reach this state.

**[18] [Commentary]**
Each rests in what it can do—this is most correct.

**[Exegesis]**
All dharmas are empty and illusory—why single out names and speech? Thus, non-being is not truly non-being, and being is not truly being. Names and numbers of being and non-being are all quiescent in themselves. Since they do not proceed from non-being to being, how could they proceed from being to being? Thus, there is no need to deliberate on going or coming; one simply follows the nature of things.

---

**Collations:**
(1) The *Zhao Jianyi* edition writes *yí* (遣) as *wèi* (遗), and the same below.
(2) The *Zhao* edition writes *jì* (寄) as *cháng* (尝).
(3) The phrase *"if each is sufficient"* (苟各足) is supplied from the *Zhao* edition and the *Shide Tang* edition.
(4) The character *"if"* (若) is emended to *"not"* (非) following the *Zhao* edition and the *Shide Tang* edition.
(5) The character *"fate"* (命) in the *Zhao* edition is written as *"portion"* (分), while the *Shide Tang* edition writes *"fate"* (命).
(6) The character *"with"* (与) is supplied from the *Shide Tang* edition.
(7) The *Zhao* edition writes *wàng* (忘) as *wáng* (亡).

---

The Dao has never had boundaries; speech has never had constancy. Yet for the sake of this, there are demarcations—let us speak of these demarcations: there is left, there is right; there are relationships, there are duties; there are divisions, there are distinctions; there is competition, there is contention—these are called the Eight Virtues. Beyond the Six Directions, the sage acknowledges but does not discuss; within the Six Directions, the sage discusses but does not debate. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* and the chronicles of former kings’ aspirations—the sage debates but does not argue. Thus, division implies what is not divided; distinction implies what is not distinguished.

It is asked: Why? The sage embraces it; the multitude debates it to show one another. Thus, it is said: distinction implies what is not seen.

The great Dao is not named; great disputation does not speak; great benevolence is not benevolent; great integrity is not modest; great courage is not aggressive. When the Dao is made manifest, it is not the Dao; when speech is disputatious, it does not reach; when benevolence is constant, it does not succeed; when integrity is pure, it is not trusted; when courage is aggressive, it does not succeed. These five nearly approach the proper direction. Thus, to know to stop where one does not know—this is perfection.

Who knows the disputation of no speech, the Dao of no Dao? If one can know this, it is called the Heavenly Treasury. Pour into it and it is not filled; draw from it and it is not exhausted. Yet one does not know whence it comes—this is called the Preserved Light.

**[1] [Commentary]**
It is obscurely present everywhere.

**[Exegesis]**
The Dao is present everywhere, and wherever it is present, there is nothing. Vast and unbounded, what boundaries could it have?

**[Exegetical Notes:]**
Cui [Zhuan] says: In the "Equalizing Things" chapter, this connects to the preceding chapter, yet Ban Gu places it in the Outer Chapters.

**[2] [Commentary]**
From differing perspectives, thus right and wrong have no fixed standard.

**[Exegesis]**
The Dao’s principle is empty and all-pervading, without limit or boundary. Therefore, teachings adapt to things, and no constant standard abides.

**[3] [Commentary]**
The Dao has no boundaries, so the myriad things freely follow their own divisions.

**[Exegesis]**
*Zhen* means boundary. Since principle has no edge or limit, and teachings shift with things, what is deemed "right" varies, and divisions differ.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Wei shi* (為是): *yu wei* (于伪) pronunciation.
*You zhen* (有畛): Xu’s *zhi ren* (之忍) pronunciation; Guo and Li’s *zhen* (真) pronunciation. Refers to boundaries and divisions.

**[4] [Exegesis]**
This sets forth a hypothetical question to introduce what follows.

**[5] [Commentary]**
Each suits its own convenience.

**[Exegesis]**
Left pertains to yang; right to yin. Though principle is serene and still, teachings must follow the moment. Divisions differ, and ascents and descents vary, hence east and west, left and right, spring and autumn, life and death.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*You zuo you you* (有左有右): Cui’s version reads *you* (宥), meaning "to be at ease." ◎Lu Wenchang notes: The old text mistakenly reads *you* (有); the following line reads *zai you* (在宥), so it clearly should be *you* (宥). Now corrected.
*Yi bian* (异便): *bi mian* (婢面) pronunciation.

**[6] [Commentary]**
Each thing has its principle; each affair has its fitting course.

**[Exegesis]**
*Lun* means principle; *yi* means fitting. Amid the tangled throng of things, principle resides; among the varied affairs of the world, each follows what is fitting and convenient.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*You lun you yi* (有伦有义): Cui’s version reads *you lun you yi* (有论有议). ◎Yu Yue notes: The *Exegetical Notes* state that Cui’s version reads *you lun you yi* (有论有议), which should be followed. Below, it says: "Beyond the six directions, the sage preserves but does not discuss; within the six directions, the sage discusses but does not debate." It also says: "Thus, division is where there is no division; disputation is where there is no disputation." What is called *fen bian* (分辩) there corresponds to *you fen you bian* (有分有辩) here; thus, what is called *lun yi* (论议) there corresponds to *you lun you yi* (有论有议) here.

**[7] [Commentary]**
Grouped by kind and distinguished by category.

**[Exegesis]**
*Bian* means to distinguish. Though birds and beasts are many, each has its group; though the natures of things are myriad, each follows its own kind.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*You fen* (有分): Pronounced as written. The commentary is the same.
*Lei bie* (类别): *bi lie* (彼列) pronunciation. The same below.

**[8] [Commentary]**
Pursuing together is called *jing*; contending in debate is called *zheng*.

**[Exegesis]**
The natures of things are dull and foolish; each clings to its own boundaries. Thus, they pursue victory and defeat together, contending over right and wrong.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*You zheng* (有争): The *zheng* of strife. The commentary is the same.

**[9] [Commentary]**
Summarizing and distinguishing them, these eight virtues emerge.

**[Exegesis]**
*De* is the name for function. The functions of living things transform endlessly; summarizing them, these eight kinds appear. This explains the meaning of *you zhen* (有畛) above.

**[10] [Commentary]**
Beyond the six directions refers only to what lies outside the inherent nature of things. Though principle exists beyond the nature of things, it does not pertain to what lies within their nature, and thus does not move the sage. Therefore, the sage does not discuss it. If he were to discuss it, he would be leading the myriad things to learn what they cannot. Thus, he does not discuss what lies beyond, and the eight divisions become one in self-attainment.

**[Exegesis]**
The six directions are heaven, earth, and the four quarters. Beyond the six directions lies what is outside the inherent nature of living things, the realm of the profoundly mysterious Dao. The profound source transcends the bounds of the four propositions; the wondrous principle is beyond the six directions. Since it cannot be debated by the divine mouth, it is preserved but not discussed.

**[11] [Commentary]**
Expounding their natures and settling them.

**[Exegesis]**
Within the six directions lies the inherent nature bestowed upon living things. All preferences and aversions arise from deluded feelings; tracing their root, they are equally empty. The sage responds to their impulses, expounding accordingly. Since it is based on emptiness, there is nothing to debate in detail. Thus, below it says, "I too speak deludedly."

**[12] [Commentary]**
Following their established traces and congealing at the ultimate of rightness, not clinging to what one deems right to condemn others.

**[Exegesis]**
*Chun qiu* refers to eras; *jing* to canons. The former kings were the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors. *Zhi* means to record. Those who took Xuanyuan and Zhuanxu as their ancestors, who took Yao and Shun as their models, who recorded eras to create canons, who guided living people and transmitted them through the world—though the sage’s discussions benefited their times, he ultimately did not cling to right or debate wrong, nor stagnate in established traces.

**[13] [Commentary]**
Each thing divides itself; each affair distinguishes itself. To wish to impose one’s own divisions is to fail to see their self-distinction.

**[Exegesis]**
Principle has no division, yet things have right and wrong. Thus, within what has no boundary or division, there arise views of division and disputation. These belong to one-sided scholars and stagnant people—how could they analyze the subtle or distinguish affairs?

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Gu fen* (故分): Pronounced as written. The same below and in the commentary.

**[14] [Exegesis]**
A hypothetical question to raise doubts and develop meaning.

**[15] [Commentary]**
To harbor no disputation is the sage’s embrace; the sage has no embrace.

**[Exegesis]**
The sage who comprehends principle unites mind with the Dao. Thus, he can embrace self and others, encompass right and wrong, like withered wood or dead ash, utterly without distinction.

**[16] [Commentary]**
Not seeing their self-disputation, he disputes what he knows to show them.

**[Exegesis]**
The multitude of people is but another name for sentient beings. Ordinary and deluded, they cling to their ignorance, failing to comprehend emptiness and delusion. Thus, they dispute what they know and display their perceptions of things. Not only do they fail to see how others distinguish themselves, but they also do not reflect upon their own subtle Dao. Hence, it is said there are things they do not see.

**[17] [Commentary]**
Entrusting it to self-reference, there is nothing to be called.

**[Exegesis]**
The great Dao is vast and empty, wondrously beyond form and name. Since it is neither color nor sound, it cannot be named. Those who embody the Dao are likewise silent.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Bu cheng* (不稱): Pronounced *chǐ zhèng* in the fanqie system; the same applies to the commentary.

**[18] [Commentary]**
They distinguish themselves.

**[Exegesis]**
Having awakened to the true source, there is nothing to be said. Thus, though they carve and adorn the myriad things, their words amount to silence.

**[19] [Commentary]**
Existing without attachment.

**[Exegesis]**
Nurturing all beings, they overflow with boundless love yet remain without intention—like the verdant spring, not acting out of benevolence.

**[20] [Commentary]**
For one who is utterly sufficient, the coming and going of things is not of the self. Thus, there is no room for conceit or satisfaction.

**[Exegesis]**
Those who profoundly awaken see through both emptiness and existence, knowing the myriad realms to be illusory and not a single thing worth coveting. Both self and other are empty—what is there to yield or relinquish?

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Bu qiàn* (不嗛): Pronounced *qī diàn* in the fanqie system according to Guo; *qiān* according to Xu.

**[21] [Commentary]**
Without direction, there is no movement that is not harmonious—thus, no peril is beyond traversing.

**[Exegesis]**
*Zhì* means opposition. Within, they harbor boundless compassion; without, they extend it to all beings. Thus, they humbly align with the dust of the world, bestowing grace to save the multitudes. Emptying the self to meet each moment, they never act in discord.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Bù zhì* (不忮): Xu’s fanqie reads *zhī shì*; alternatively *qí*, or Li’s *zhī yí*. "Harm" or "injury." Li: "vigorous."

**[22] [Commentary]**
To illuminate this by that is to lose both.

**[Exegesis]**
Parading one’s merit and fame before others—this is mere excess and deceit, not the true Dao.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Dào zhāo* (道昭): pronounced *zhào*.

**[23] [Commentary]**
Unable to reach the measure of one’s inherent nature.

**[Exegesis]**
Failing in profound silence, they remain mired in names and words, their ornate phrases and hollow arguments never penetrating deep principle.

**[24] [Commentary]**
Things bear no constant affection; to cling to constant affection is to fail in universality.

**[Exegesis]**
Unable to forget attachment or relinquish knowledge, to merge self and other in profound unity, they persist in harboring kindness and clinging to kinship. Aspiring to success, they find no moment to realize it.

**[25] [Commentary]**
Radiant purity and unyielding integrity—these belong to the covetous of reputation, not to true integrity.

**[Exegesis]**
Standing aloof from the world, towering above the crowd, their intent lies in fame, not in genuine integrity.

**[26] [Commentary]**
The bravery of opposition and defiance is loathed by all under heaven; no ground remains for them to tread.

**[Exegesis]**
Abandoning compassion for boldness, they defy the sentiments of all beings. Hated by the multitude, they can achieve nothing.

**[27] [Commentary]**
These five—all inflict harm by striving after the external, unable to rest in their original nature. To seek without end what cannot be sought is like a circle emulating a square, or a fish yearning to soar as a bird. Though they aspire to phoenixes and model themselves on sun and moon, the closer they draw to such ideals, the farther they stray from reality. The more they learn, the more their nature is lost. Thus, when all things are equalized, the burden of partiality vanishes.

**[Exegesis]**
*Wán* means "round." *Jī* means "near." The five refer to the preceding *Dào zhāo* and the like. Those who study the Dao must conceal their brilliance; yet they flaunt their abilities and display them before the world—how distant this is from the Dao! It is like admiring squares while learning circles, or loving flight while delighting in swimming. Though they long for phoenixes, they will never gain the power of soaring; though they model themselves on sun and moon, how can they achieve even a fraction of their efficacy?

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Wán* (): Cui’s pronunciation *wán*; Xu’s *wǔ wán*. Sima: "round." Guo: *tuán*.
*Ér jī* (而几): Xu’s fanqie *qí yī*.
*Xiàng fāng* (向方): also written *xiàng*, same pronunciation. Below follows this pattern.
*Jìn bǐ* (近彼): "near" as in proximity.
*Yuǎn shí* (远实): *yú wàn*.

**[28] [Commentary]**
What lies beyond knowing belongs to the realm outside one’s inherent nature. Thus, to halt within the bounds of what one knows is to reach perfection.

**[Exegesis]**
Realms vary in magnitude, wisdom in clarity and obscurity. What lies beyond one’s wisdom need not be forcibly known. To know one’s limit is the ultimate achievement in learning.

**[29] [Commentary]**
Vast and unencumbered, they entrust all to spontaneity.

**[Exegesis]**
*Shú* means "who." *Tiān* means "nature." Who knows the wordless words, the Dao that is not a Dao? Those who accumulate such discernment to connect with all things may be said to unite with the treasury of nature.

**[30] [Commentary]**
The heart of the perfected is like a mirror: it responds but does not retain. Thus, it remains vast and unaltered by gain or loss.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Zhù yān* (注焉): Xu’s fanqie *zhī yù*.

**[31] [Commentary]**
The advent of the supreme principle is naturally without trace.

**[Exegesis]**
The vast ocean, profound and boundless, defies measurement of its shores. A hundred rivers pour into it without filling it; the Tailuo abyss drains it without exhausting it. The great sage who embodies the Dao is likewise: myriad affairs arise without disturbing their spirit, a thousand difficulties confront them without unsettling their thoughts. Thus, they embrace all existence and harbor all beings. It is like a mirror hung high in a hall—things come, and it reflects them. The wisdom that enables reflection knows not whence it arises. This may be called reflecting while forgetting, forgetting while reflecting.

**[32] [Commentary]**
Entrusting it to its own clarity, its light is never dimmed.

**[Exegesis]**
*Bǎo* means "concealment." To forget while reflecting, to reflect while forgetting—thus they veil their light, and their light grows ever brighter. This concludes the preceding discussion of the treasury of heaven.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Bǎo guāng* (葆光): pronounced *bǎo*. Cui: "as if present, as if absent—this is called *bǎo guāng*."

**[Collation Notes]**
(1) The missing character in *quèwù* is rendered as *zhōu* in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript.
(2) The three characters *ruò lùn zhī* are supplemented according to the Zhao edition and the Shidetang edition.

Thus, in ancient times, Yao asked Shun: “I wish to attack Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao, yet when facing south I remain unsettled. What is the reason for this?”

Shun replied: “Those three lords still dwell among the weeds and brambles. Why should you be unsettled? In ancient times, when ten suns appeared together, all things were illuminated—how much more so for one whose virtue surpasses the sun!”

**[1] [Commentary]**
His grasp of the Dao of tranquil acceptance was not yet expansive, so he felt no joy while holding court. To convey the principle of luminous unity, he posed this self-questioning query to prompt the Great Sage’s response.

**[Exegesis]**
*Shìrán* describes a joyful countenance. Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao were the names of three minor frontier states during Yao’s reign. “Facing south” signifies the ruler’s position. Shun was the sixth-generation descendant of Zhuanxu. His father was Gu Sou, his mother Wu Deng, and he was conceived when she was moved by a great rainbow. Born at Yao Village, he took the surname Yao; dwelling by the Gui River, he was also called Gui. His eyes had double pupils, so he was styled Chong Hua. Renowned for his benevolence and filial piety in his village, Yao heard of his virtue, gave him his two daughters in marriage, and enfeoffed him at Yu. At thirty, he oversaw the hundred offices; at thirty-three, he received Yao’s abdication. After ascending the throne, he established his capital at Puban. He ruled for forty years before yielding to Yu. Later, he passed away and was buried in the wilds of Cangwu. As the three states had failed in tribute, punishment was warranted, yet the matter remained unresolved, so he felt no joy while holding court. To illustrate the principle of the unity of all things, he framed the dialogue between the two sages.

**Annotations and Text:**

《宗脍》: *Zongkuai* (Xu: "gu" as in "ancient," "wai" reversed)
《胥》: *Xu* (Xu: "xi" as in "xu")
*Huaxu* state.
《敖》: *Ao* (Xu: "wu" as in "five," "gao" as in "high")
Sima [Biao] says: *Zong*, *Kuai*, and *Xuao* are the names of three states.
Cui [Zhuan] says: *Zong* is one, *Kuai* is two, *Xuao* is three.
《听朝》: *Ting chao* (Xu: "zhi" as in "distant," "yao" reversed)

**Section Two**
**Note:** That in which things find repose is not base; thus, the mugwort and artemisia are the wondrous abodes of the Three Lords.
《妙处》: *Miao chu* (Xu: "chang" as in "anxiety," "lü" reversed)

**Section Three**
**Exegesis:** The Three Lords are the rulers of the three states. Mugwort and artemisia are humble grasses, yet even the sparrow finds them sufficient for its carefree wandering. How much more, though the lands of these lords be modest, are they not enough for the Three Lords to nurture themselves? Yet they remain unsettled—what is the meaning of this?

**Section Four**
**Note:** When the double brightness ascends to heaven, the Six Directions are all illumined; there is no mugwort or artemisia that is not bathed in its light.
《重明》: *Chong ming* (Xu: "zhi" as in "dragon," "long" reversed)
《光被》: *Guang bei* (Xu: "pi" as in "skin," "ji" reversed)

**Section Five**
**Note:** Though the sun and moon shine without partiality, there are still places they do not reach; virtue, however, attains all. Now, to seize the aspirations of the mugwort and artemisia and force them to comply—how could this be vast in the utmost Dao? Thus, the spirit remains unresolved. If things flow according to their nature, each resting in what it finds restful, whether distant or near, hidden or deep, left to their own course, all attain their fullness—then nothing is amiss for them, and nothing is not joyful for me.

**Exegesis:** "Advance" means to transgress. The *Huainanzi* states: In ancient times, during Yao’s reign, ten suns appeared together, scorching the crops, killing the grasses and trees, and causing the giant boars and long serpents to become harms to the people. Thereupon, Yao sent Yi to shoot the ten suns; he brought down nine of them. Below, he slew the long serpents to rid the people of harm. When the ten suns ascend to heaven, the Six Directions are all illumined, yet beneath the overturned basin, hidden places remain unlit. But where the sagely virtue reaches, no darkness is left unillumined. To wield these two wisdoms and surpass the Three Luminaries, then to raise weapons and force compliance—how could this be called the vast and unobstructed Way of tranquil acceptance?

◎ Jia Shifu says: To attack a state is the accumulation of views on right and wrong. Yet here, there is an unresolved feeling, as the distinctions of human relations, righteousness, debate, and contention wage war within and go unrecognized. As for the Three Lords, amid the mugwort and artemisia, they do not engage in debate to distinguish themselves. All things receive the sun’s illumination and cannot escape its form; yet if one were to burden it with ten suns, all seeking to illuminate the myriad things, the spirits of the myriad things would surely be exhausted. The sun’s illumination is without intent. To seek to distinguish right and wrong with virtue, and moreover to do so with intent, is to surpass even the sun’s illumination. Where, then, can one place one’s hands and feet?

◎ Qing Fan’s collation: The *Wen Xuan* commentary on Xie Lingyun’s poem "On Traveling to Jingkou’s Beigu, in Response to an Imperial Edict" cites Sima [Biao] as saying: When the yang brilliance (light) adorns the heavens, there is nothing it does not illumine. The *Annotations* omit this.
《神解》: *Shen jie* (Xu: pronounced "xie")
**Collation:** (1) The character "light" is amended according to the original text of the *Wen Xuan* commentary.

Nie Que asked Wang Ni, “Do you know wherein all things are alike in their rightness?”

**Section One**
**Exegesis:** Nie Que was the teacher of Xu You and a disciple of Wang Ni, both worthy men of Yao’s time. Through these two, the principle of equality is illustrated. Things are inverted in their sentiments, each holding to its own views and differing from others; all deem themselves right and others wrong. Do you know whether this is so or not?
《啮》: *Nie* (Xu: "wu" as in "five," "jie" reversed)
《缺》: *Que* (Xu: "qiu" as in "hill," "yue" reversed)
《王倪》: *Wang Ni* (Xu: "wu" as in "five," "ji" reversed; Li: pronounced "yi")
The *Lives of Eminent Recluses* states: Wang Ni was a worthy man of Yao’s time. The *Heaven and Earth* chapter says he was Nie Que’s teacher.

Wang Ni said, “How would I know?”

**Section One**
**Note:** What is alike is not necessarily right, and what differs is not uniquely wrong. Thus, neither self nor other can correct the other, and there is no use for knowledge.

**Exegesis:** Wang Ni answered Nie Que: “Each has its own right and wrong, resulting in no arbiter. If I were to use knowledge to know the other, my knowledge would still be right or wrong. So how would I know?” This means there is no use for knowledge.

**Nie Que asked, “Do you know what you do not know?”**

**Section One**
**Exegesis:** “Since you do not know wherein all things are alike in their rightness, do you at least know what you yourself do not know?” This is a step toward entering subtlety, a progression of thorough inquiry, using the master and disciple to reveal the profound meaning.

Wang Ni said, “How would I know?”

**Section One**
**Note:** If one knows what one does not know, this is already to have knowledge. Having knowledge, one cannot entrust things to their own rightness.

**Exegesis:** If one uses knowledge to know what one does not know, the “not knowing” is still knowledge. Thus, he reiterates, “How would I know?” and answers again with “not knowing.”

**“Then are things without knowledge?”**

**Section One**
**Exegesis:** He presses further: “Since you yourself have no knowledge, do things also lack knowledge?”

Wang Ni said, “How would I know?”

**Section One**
**Note:** To know nothing at all is to be vast and unburdened, leaving nothing unentrusted.

**Exegesis:** It is not only that I do not know; I also do not know things. Only when things and self, inner and outer, are all forgotten is there nowhere to apply knowledge.

**“Nevertheless, let me try to speak of it. How do I know that what I call knowing is not not-knowing? How do I know that what I call not-knowing is not knowing?”**

**Section One**
**Note:** Because he does not know, he does not dare to speak definitively but only tentatively.

**Exegesis:** *Ran hu* (然乎) means "nevertheless." Since there is no knowledge, in principle there is nothing to be said—nothing can be asserted with certainty, hence the tentative attempt.

**Note:** Fish swim in water, a capacity shared by all aquatic creatures, and all call this "knowing." Yet from a bird's perspective, what was called knowing is now not-knowing. The dung beetle's knowledge lies in rolling its ball, while those who mock it prize storax resin. Thus, what is commonly called knowledge cannot be taken as an absolute standard.

**Exegesis:** For some things, what is known here is unknown there, and what is known there is unknown here. Fish and birds, water and land—this is the meaning. Thus, knowing is not-knowing, and not-knowing is knowing. How could ordinary people comprehend this principle?

**Explanatory Notes:**
*Yong ju* (庸讵): Xu’s edition reads *ju* (巨). Guo pronounces it *ju*. Li explains: *yong* means "to use"; *ju* means "how"; together, they mean "what use is it?" Fu Qian says: *ju* means "not yet."
*Fu wei* (复为): Pronounced *fu you*.
*Jie* (蛣): Pronounced *qiu yi*.
*Qiang* (蜣): Pronounced *qiu liang*. The *Erya* states: *jie qiang* is the dung beetle.
**Note:** What is called "not-knowing" is simply a matter of difference—it is also a kind of knowing in its own right.

**Exegesis:** What is called "not-knowing" means only that there is no mutual understanding, not that there is no knowledge at all.

◎ Qingfan’s note: The *Wen Xuan* commentary on Pan Anren’s *Autumn Stirrings Rhapsody* cites Sima’s gloss: *yong* means "what use is it?" This is omitted in the *Explanatory Notes*.
◎ Further note: *Yong ju* means "how could it be?" *Ju* and *ju* (距/巨) are interchangeable; sometimes written as *qu* (渠). Examples:
- *Records of the Grand Historian*, "Biography of Gan Mao": "How could you rebuke me?"
- *Huainanzi*, "Among People": "How could this not become good fortune?"
- *Han Feizi*, "Difficulties": "Why would Wei be so resistant?"
- *Xunzi*, "Proper Norms": "How could one with such fixed views consider being insulted as no disgrace?"
- *Xunzi*, "Regulations of a King": "How could they escape this burden?" All attest to this usage.

Moreover, I once tentatively asked you: when people sleep in dampness, they suffer from lumbar ailments and partial paralysis—is this so? When they dwell in trees, they tremble with fear—do apes and monkeys react thus? Among these three, who knows the correct dwelling? People eat domesticated animals, elk and deer eat fine grass, centipedes relish snakes, and owls delight in mice—among these four, who knows the correct flavor? Apes and monkeys take each other as mates, elk couple with deer, and mudfish swim with fish. Mao Qiang and Li Ji are considered beauties by humans; yet when fish see them, they dive deep, when birds see them, they fly high, and when elk and deer see them, they flee swiftly. Among these four, who knows the correct beauty of the world?

From my perspective, the origins of benevolence and righteousness, the paths of right and wrong, are tangled and confused—how could I discern their distinctions?

---
**Annotations from Commentary:**
1. Since I do not know what is correct, I tentatively ask you.
2. This briefly cites three examples to illustrate the differing conveniences of the myriad things.
3. This briefly cites four examples to illustrate that beauty and ugliness have no fixed standard.
4. This briefly cites four examples to show that what the world favors differs. To condemn what differs is to have no way of knowing what is necessarily the same.

The *Shiwen* glosses:
- *Biān* (猵) is read with the *mian* (面) rhyme, Xu with the *fumian* (敷面) rhyme, or alternatively the *fuwei* (敷畏) rhyme; Guo and Li pronounce it as *piān* (偏).
- *Jū* (狙) is read with the *qiyu* (七余) rhyme.

Sima Biao states: *Jū* is also called *gézāng* (獦牂), resembling an ape but with a dog’s head, and it mates with female apes.
Cui states: *Biānjū* (猵狙) is another name for *gézāng*; the male mates with female apes.
Xiang Xiu states: *Biānjū* takes apes as its mates.
*Gé* (獦) is pronounced as *gé* (葛).

*As female* (為雌) is read as *qī* (妻), or alternatively as the character’s standard pronunciation.

◎ Qing Fan’s note: The *Taiping Yulan* (910) cites Sima Biao: *Biānjū* resembles an ape but with a dog’s head, preys on macaques, and prefers to mate with male apes—differing from the citation in the *Shiwen*.

*Mao Qiang* (毛嫱) is read by Xu with the *zailiang* (在良) rhyme.
Sima Biao states: Mao Qiang was an ancient beauty, or alternatively, a favored concubine of the King of Yue.

*Li Ji* (麗姬) is read with the *lizhi* (力知) rhyme, consistent below.
Li Ji was the favored concubine of Duke Xian of Jin, later made his consort. Cui’s version reads *Xi Shi* (西施).

*Ju* (決) is read with the *xique* (喜缺) rhyme.
Li states: It denotes swiftness.
Cui states: To flee swiftly without looking back is called *ju* (決).
Xu reads it with the *guhui* (古惠) rhyme; Guo pronounces it as *guxue* (古穴).

*Zou* (驟) is read with the *shijiu* (士救) rhyme, or alternatively the *zaigou* (在遘) rhyme.

◎ Qing Fan’s note: *Jue zòu* (決驟) is synonymous with *jué zào* (決躁). (*Shuowen* and *Guangya* both define *zào* (躁) as swiftness.) The *Yi Jing* (*Xici Zhuan* [*Shuogua Zhuan*]) states: "It is decisive and swift" (*zào* [躁] being interchangeable with *zào* [躁]). The *Zhengyi* reads *jué zòu* (決驟), explaining it as embodying firmness and vigor. The proper character should be *jué qù* (趹趣). The *Shuowen* defines *jué* (趹) as the gait of a horse, and elsewhere as *tí* (踶, rearing). The *Huainanzi* (*Xiuwu*) reads *chì jué qù* (敕蹻趹), with Gao You’s note: *jué* (趹) means *qù* (趣, hastening). It is also interchangeable with *jué* (駃). The *Guangya* defines *jué* (駃) as galloping. The *Records of the Grand Historian* (*Zhang Yi Zhuan*) states: "Probing ahead and hastening behind, hooves spanning three *xun*." The *Suoyin* explains: "This describes the swiftness of a horse’s gait." This aligns with Cui’s definition of *ju* (決) as fleeing swiftly without looking back.

*What is favored* (所好) is read with the *huba* (呼報) rhyme.

**[5] Commentary:**
What benefits one may harm another, and since the "other" and "self" in the world are boundless, the contest of right and wrong knows no constancy. Thus, only by refraining from disputation and allowing each to be self-so does all attain a state of unobstructed harmony.

**Explication:**
All things are manifold yet never apart from the self. Thus, practicing benevolence and upholding righteousness yield differing gains and losses: what benefits me may harm another, and what is right for them may be wrong for me. Viewed from shifting perspectives of self and other, the paths of right and wrong, the threads of benevolence and righteousness, become tangled and confused—like a chaotic medley of dishes, devoid of fixed principles. How then can I discern their distinctions?

**Phonetic Glosses:**
*Fánrán* (樊然) reads *fán* (烦).
*Yáoluàn* (殽乱) reads *hù jiāo* (户交) in Xu’s recension.
Guo [Pu] writes *sǎn* (散), reading *xī dàn* (悉旦).
◎Qing Fan’s note: *Yáo* (殽) in Guo’s text is incorrect. The *Shuowen* defines *yáo* (殽) as "mixed and jumbled," while *sǎn* (散) means "scattered meat." Their meanings do not align. (The character *zá* (杂) is a corruption of *lí* (离); see *Shuowen Kaozheng*.) In clerical script, *yáo* (殽) is sometimes written as □ (see the *Han Dynasty Xiaokeng Jun Shrine Stele*), resembling *sǎn* (散); *sǎn* (散) may also appear as □ (see *Li Xi’s Xiqiao Yifu Pavilion Inscription*), resembling *yáo* (殽). The confusion between *yáo* (殽) and *sǎn* (散) arises from their graphic similarity. The *Tai Xuan Jing* (*Yuan Ying*) states: "Day and night *yáo*—their fortunes and misfortunes intermingle." Modern editions erroneously write *sǎn* (散) for *yáo* (殽). The *Huainanzi* (*Yuandao*) reads: "Not mingling with things, to the utmost purity," and the *Jingshen* chapter: "Not mingling with things, and the world submits of itself." Modern editions both mistakenly write *sǎn* (散). (Gao You’s note: *Sǎn* (散) means "scattered appearance." Yet no classical text glosses *sǎn* (散) as "chaotic." Thus, *sǎn* (散) should uniformly be corrected to *yáo* (殽).)
*Zhī jìng* (之竟) reads *jìng* (境). Most modern editions write *jìng* (境); follow this below.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The Zhao Jianyi edition omits *gù* (故).
(2) The Zhao edition omits the phrase "略举二字及以字之字."
(3) *Dòng* (动) is amended per the original text of the *Zhengyi*.
(4) *Hòu* (后) is supplied per the original text of the *Records of the Grand Historian*.

Nie Que said: "If you do not know benefit and harm, does the Perfect Person truly not know benefit and harm?"
**[1] Commentary:**
Not yet having attained the subtlety of non-knowing, one still suspects the Perfect Person ought to know. This is a knot yet untied.

**Explication:**
Nie Que, failing to grasp the mutual non-knowing of self and other, raises the doubt of benefit and harm. He asks: "You are a Perfect Person—should you not know benefit and harm? If you do not discern them, you wander in darkness like one lost at night." He poses this challenge, hoping for a further reply.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*Wèi jiě* (未解) reads *xiè* (蟹).

Wang Ni said: "The Perfect Person is divine! A great marsh may burn, yet they feel no heat; the Yellow River and Han River may freeze, yet they feel no cold; swift thunder may shatter mountains and whirlwinds shake the sea, yet they feel no alarm. Such a one rides the *qi* of clouds, **[3]** mounts the sun and moon, **[4]** and roams beyond the four seas. **[5]** Death and life bring no change to them—**[6]** how much less the mere threads of benefit and harm!" **[7]**
**[1] Commentary:**
Without intent, yet nothing is not accorded.

The *shu* (annotation) states: "Perfect" (*zhi*) refers to the wondrous ultimate substance; "divine" (*shen*) refers to its unfathomable function. The sage empties the self and responds to things without fixed form—knowing yet not knowing, disputing yet not disputing. How could one fathom the Perfect Person through names, words, thoughts, or conjectures!

**[2] Commentary:**
One whose spirit is whole and complete, whose body merges with things, though traversing the most extreme changes, never ceases to be oneself. Thus, the mind remains utterly unobstructed, free of even the slightest hindrance.

The *shu* (annotation) states: *Hù* means "to freeze." When marshes burn and rivers freeze, when thunder roars and shatters mountains, when whirlwinds surge and shake the seas—the Perfect Person, spirit congealed and unmanifest, body merging with things, remains untouched by water or fire as calamity, undisturbed by wind or thunder as terror.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*Hù* (冱) is read *hù* (户故反). Xu also reads *hù* (户各反). Li reads *hù* (户格反). Xiang says: "to freeze." Cui says: *Hù* means "to dry up."

◎ Jia Shifu says: Great floods may rise to the heavens without drowning them; great droughts may melt metal and stone, scorch mountains and earth without heating them. Able not to treat things as affairs, the workings of heaven and earth naturally abide in one’s heart—thus, external conditions cannot become burdens. This is how Zhuangzi envisioned himself, and so he repeatedly speaks of it.

*Chài* (虿) is read *chài* (敕迈反), also *zhì* (音豸). *Jiè* (介) is read *gài* (古迈反), also *jiè* (音界).

**[3] Commentary:**
Riding things to move, not moving oneself.

The *shu* (annotation) states: "Such being so"—that is, being thus. Empty and serene, without intent, like the *qi* of clouds, they shelter and nurture all beings, moving in accord with things.

**[4] Commentary:**
There is day and night, but no death and life.

The *shu* (annotation) states: The alternation of darkness and light brings the distinction of day and night; abiding in compliance and ease, there is no difference wrought by death and life. Yet they govern and bear all things, carrying the living—hence the name of "riding" and "mounting."

**[5] Commentary:**
Only by lacking knowledge and entrusting all things to their own course can one gallop through the ten thousand things without exhaustion.

The *shu* (annotation) states: Movement and stillness coincide, response and merging occur as one. Sitting upright at the center of the cosmos, the mind roams beyond the four seas.

**[6] Commentary:**
Taking change as their substance, death and life are as one.

**[7] Commentary:**
How much less can benefit and harm, compared to death and life, disturb the mind?

The *shu* (annotation) states: Benefit and harm are but gains and losses in the course of life. Since death and life are like day and night, riding transformation to roam freely—how could benefit and harm, compared to death and life, ever disturb the mind?

**Textual Note:**
The character *piāo* (飘) is supplied from Zhao Jianyi’s edition. The character *chài* (虿) is amended following the Shidetang edition.

Ququezi asked Master Changwu: "I have heard from the Master that the sage does not engage in affairs, does not pursue profit, does not avoid harm, does not delight in seeking, does not follow the Dao; without speech, there is speech; with speech, there is no speech—and roams beyond the dust and grime. The Master considered these careless words, but I regard them as the practice of the wondrous Dao. What do you think?"

**[1] Commentary:**
Affairs come of themselves, and principle responds of itself—one does not follow and engage with them.

The *shu* (annotation) states: "Affairs" means "matters." *Zhū* (诸) means "at." Quque was a disciple of Changwu, hence he called his teacher "the Master." The sage who embodies the Dao forgets the self and merges with things; though involved in affairs, they do not treat them as tasks. Dwelling amidst the dust of the world, utterly without intent—how could they fix their mind or harbor feelings, following after things? Quque, wishing to seek further instruction, thus recounted what he had heard before.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*Qúquè* (瞿鹊) is read *qújū* (其俱反). *Chángwúzi* (长梧子): Li says: "He dwelled beneath the long catalpa, hence the name." Cui says: "His name was Qiu." Jianwen says: "He was the border warden of Changwu." *Fūzǐ* (夫子): Xiang says: "Quque’s teacher."

◎ Yu Yue says: Ququezi must have been a figure after the seventy disciples, and the "Master" from whom he heard these words refers to Confucius. Below, Master Changwu says, "This is what the Yellow Emperor heard at Ying, yet how could Qiu (Confucius) know it?" Qiu is Confucius’ given name. Since Ququezi was recounting Confucius’ words, he said, "How could Qiu know it?" But readers, not grasping this, mistakenly took *Qiu* as Master Changwu’s own name, hence the *Shiwen* states: "Master Changwu, Cui says his name was Qiu." This is entirely incorrect. Below, it says, "Qiu and you are both dreaming; I say you are dreaming, but I am also dreaming." Here, *yú* (予) refers to Master Changwu himself. Having said "Qiu and you are both dreaming," and then "I am also dreaming"—how could *Qiu* be Master Changwu’s name?

**[2] Commentary:**
Advancing directly, without avoiding or seeking.

The *shu* (annotation) states: "Avoid" means "to shun."

Embracing the pivotal moments of adversity and prosperity as ordained by fate, and comprehending that profit and harm arise in their due seasons, one thus advances by reason without avoiding or seeking.

**[3] Commentary:**
Seeking it brings no joy; taking it directly incurs no anger.

**[Sub-commentary:]**
Profound awakening arises from divergence. Thus, when things seek it, there is no delight.

**[4] Commentary:**
This is the solitary arrival.

**[Sub-commentary:]**
The sagely wisdom congeals in stillness, illuminating things without attachment. It neither advances nor retreats, neither arises nor ceases—how could one who walks the empty and penetrating supreme Dao do so with a mind clinging to conditions?

**[5] Commentary:**
All that bears a name is not what I call it; each merely names itself. Thus, there is no "that" with designation and no "this" without designation.

**[Sub-commentary:]**
*Wei* (谓) means verbal teaching. The perfected person who embodies the Dao is empty, level, silent, and transcendent. Descending from the root to manifest traces, they respond and thus penetrate all. Therefore, in governing through principle, they teach without designation; in teaching, they govern through designation without designation.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*Chēngwèi* (称谓): *chǐzhèng* (尺证) *fǎn* (反). Below follows this pattern.

**[6] Commentary:**
All that is not true nature is but dust and defilement.

**[Sub-commentary:]**
Blending radiance with the dust, dwelling in defilement yet unstained—thus, though amidst the clamor of the vulgar, the mind roams beyond the dust and grime.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*Éryóu* (而游): Cui’s edition reads *érshī* (而施).

**[7] Sub-commentary:**
*Mènglàng* means "rough and careless." *Xī* is "what"; *ruò* is "like"; together, "how." The so-called non-reliance on the Dao and the like is the thorough investigation of principle and the exhaustion of nature. Quque intended to practice the wondrous Dao, while Changwu offered only careless remarks. Not knowing how the principle stands, by what standard is rightness to be judged?

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*Mèng* (孟): read as written. Xu: *wǔdǎng* (武党) or *wǔzàng* (武葬).
*Làng* (浪): read as written. Xu: *lìdàng* (力荡).
Xiang: *Mènglàng* sounds like *mànlán* (漫澜), meaning "without direction or choice."
Li: "like *jiàoluè* (较略), 'approximate.'"
Cui: "the appearance of imprecision."
◎ Qingfan’s note: *Wen Xuan*’s *Zuo Taichong’s "Wu Capital Rhapsody"* commentary cites Sima: "*Mènglàng* is rustic speech." The *Shiwen* omits this.
Also: *Mènglàng* is like *mòluò* (莫络), meaning "not detailed." (See Liu Kui’s commentary on Zuo Si’s *Wu Capital Rhapsody*.) *Mòluò* is also written as *mólüè* (摹略). *Mozi’s "Minor Selection"* reads: "*Mólüè* encompasses the thusness of the myriad things." *Mólüè* is a term of summation. *Mòluò*, *mólüè*, and *mènglàng* are all phonetic shifts of the same word.
*Zhīxíng* (之行): read as written, or *xiàmèng* (下孟).

Changwuzi said: "This is what the Yellow Emperor himself found perplexing—how could I, Qiu, presume to know it? Moreover, you are far too hasty in your calculations: seeing an egg, you demand the crowing of the rooster at dawn; seeing a slingshot, you crave the roasted owl.

**[1] Sub-commentary:**
*Tīngyíng* describes the appearance of doubt and confusion. The supreme Dao is profoundly mysterious; it cannot be fathomed through names and words. Even the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors, though sages, could not exhaust its wonders through discourse—they remained perplexed to the end. Who am I to claim understanding? Some versions write *huáng* (黄, "Yellow") instead of *huáng* (皇, "August"), referring to Xuanyuan.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*Huángdì* (皇帝): Some editions write *Huángdì* (黄帝).
◎ Lu Wenchang: *Huáng* (皇) and *huáng* (黄) are interchangeable. The current text reads *Huángdì* (黄帝).
*Tīng* (听): *chìdìng* (敕定).
*Yíng* (荧): sounds like *yíng* (莹, "polished jade"). Some write *yíng* (莹), *yújiǒng* (于迥).
Xiang and Sima: "*Tīngyíng* means doubt and confusion."
Li: "the appearance of dimness."
Cui: "slightly bright but not fully clear."
Xiang and Cui’s edition writes □*róng* (□荣).
◎ Lu Wenchang: *Zihui Bu* states: □ appears in Buddhist texts. *Sui Han* says: □ is the same as *huī* (辉, "radiance").

**[2] Commentary:**
Things have their natural course; principles have their ultimate limits. Following them directly leads to a silent, spontaneous accord—beyond words. Thus, speech is careless, and hearing is perplexed. Even the Yellow Emperor could not free the myriad things from doubt, leaving them perplexed to the end. Therefore, the sage entrusts matters to what lies beyond the dust and grime, merging mysteriously with what transcends sight and sound. Illuminated by Heaven, they do not oppose calculation; left to their own nature, they do not force clarity. Now, Quque, upon hearing careless words, takes them for the practice of the wondrous Dao—this is no different from seeing an egg and demanding the rooster’s crow at dawn or seeing a slingshot and craving the roasted owl. Those who cannot rest in the proper time and follow the natural order, who probe change and seek transformation, who contemplate death while alive, and who cling to "this" to debate "that"—these are all reckless calculators.

**[Sub-commentary:]**
The *xiāo* is the owl, as described in Jia Yi’s *Fu*. It is the size of a hen, resembles a turtledove, and is greenish-blue. Its meat is delicious and suitable for stews or roasts, found in the Jiangnan region. Yet an egg has the potential to become a rooster, though it cannot crow at once; a slingshot may bring down an owl, though it cannot yet be roasted. Likewise, teachings may elucidate the wondrous principle, but at the time of teaching, they are not the principle itself. Quque, having just heard words, takes them for the wondrous Dao—this is too hasty a calculation.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*Qiě nǚ* (且女): sounds like *rǔ* (汝). Same below.

"《亦大》" is pronounced *tài*; Xú and Lǐ read it as *chìzuǒ*.
The annotation is the same.
"《时夜》": Cuī states: *shíyè* means "keeper of the night," referring to the rooster.
"《见弹》" is pronounced *túdàn*.
"《鸮》" is pronounced *yújiāo*.
Sīmǎ states: a small turtledove, suitable for roasting.
The *Máo Shī Cǎomù Shū* states: it is as large as a turtledove, green in color, and its meat is very fine.
"《虽复》" is pronounced *fúyòu*.
The same applies below, and the annotation in the following chapter follows this pattern.

**[Collation Notes:]**
(1) The character *huáng* is amended according to the Shìdétáng edition.
(2) The *Zhào Jiànyì* edition omits the character *fū*.

I once spoke recklessly to you,
and you listened recklessly in turn.
Why cling to sun and moon at your side,
or grasp the cosmos in your embrace?
For their lips meet,
yet their confusion and turbidity remain,
using these to vie for honor.

The multitude toils endlessly,
while the sage appears foolish and dull,
unifying the myriad ages into a single purity.
All things are thus,
yet they entangle one another with these.

**[Annotation:]**
To speak is to be reckless, so I tentatively spoke recklessly.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
"《尝为》" is pronounced *yúwěi*.

**[Annotation:]**
If one listens earnestly to reckless words, it is again too hasty a calculation.
So why not listen recklessly as well?

**[Sub-commentary:]**
*Yú* means "I."
*Xī* means "why."
The ultimate principle is wordless; to speak is reckless.
I tentatively spoke recklessly to you—why not listen recklessly as well?
Moreover, *xī* is the sound of "why."

The sage regards life and death as day and night, drawing on the analogy of the sun and moon; embraces the myriad things as one body, holding the cosmos in his embrace.

**[Annotation:]**
*Bàng* means "to rely upon."
*Xié* means "to hold within."
The four directions of heaven and earth are called *yǔ*; past and present are called *zhòu*.
The sage who aligns with the principle forgets things and forgets self, then encompasses all existence, merging life and death into oneness. Thus, Guo’s commentary states: "regards life and death as day and night, drawing on the analogy of the sun and moon; embraces the myriad things as one body, holding the cosmos in his embrace."

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
"《旁日月》" is pronounced *bó zàng* (Xu: *fú zàng*).
Sima: "to rely upon."
Cui’s version reads *bàng*.
◎ Lu Wenchang: The official edition emends *bàng* to *páng*, which is not necessarily correct.
◎ Jia Shifu: Guo Xiang punctuates "why listen recklessly" as a complete phrase, but a careful reading suggests "why rely upon the sun and moon, hold the cosmos" forms the next clause—what method does one employ to transcend beyond heaven and earth?
Qingfan notes: *Bàng* is a loan for *fàng*. *Fàng* means "to rely upon." In the *Analects*, "acting in reliance upon profit," Zheng and Kong both gloss *fàng* as "to rely upon." In the *Mozi*, "acting in reliance upon models," *fàng* also means "to rely upon." It is also written as *fāng*. In the *Book of Songs*, "the turtledove relies upon it," meaning the magpie has a nest and the turtledove relies upon it (see Wang’s *Explications of Classical Meanings*). It is also written as *páng*. *Bàng rìyuè* means "to rely upon the sun and moon." The interpretation should follow Sima’s gloss of "to rely upon"; Cui’s version reading *bàng* is incorrect.
"《挟》" is pronounced *hù dié* (Cui: *fú*).
"《宇宙》" is pronounced *zhì jiù*.
The *Shizi* states: "The four directions of heaven and earth are called *yǔ*; past and present are called *zhòu*."
The *Shuowen* states: "What the boat and carriage cover is called *zhòu*."

**[Annotation:]**
By valuing some things, hierarchy arises, and with it confusion, obscurity, and disorder—none can rectify it, each asserting their own partial truth. Thus, the Dao of spontaneous harmony is best left unspoken, entrusted to its own natural course. *Mǐnrán* means "without waves or boundaries."

**[Sub-commentary:]**
*Mǐn* describes the appearance of no distinction.
*Zhì* means "to entrust."
*Gǔ* means "chaos."
*Hūn* means "obscurity."
*Lì* refers to servants and the like, a term of low status. Human sentiments are inverted, falsely clinging to hierarchy. If the sage wishes to dispel this delusion, the Dao of (effortless) harmony and unity is best left to chaos and obscurity, following its natural course, treating all as equal—whether servant or noble.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
"《□》" in some editions appears as *□*. Guo: *mǐn* (Xu: *wǔ zhěn*; Li: *wǔ fěn*), describing the appearance of no waves or boundaries. Sima: "harmony." Xiang: *chún*, like the meeting of two lips.
◎ Lu Wenchang: In the present commentary, *bō* appears as *bèi*, likely an error.
"《滑》" Xu: *gǔ mò*; chaos. Xiang: *gǔ*, same pronunciation. Cui: *hù bā*, meaning "wooden mouthpiece."
"《涽》" Xu: *hūn*. Xiang: *gǔ hūn*, meaning "indeterminate." Cui: *shēn*, *wǔ zhōng*, meaning "rope."
◎ Lu Wenchang: Originally *hūn*. The Song edition uses the *shì* radical, and the gloss *hūn hūn* also uses *shì*; this edition follows that form.

The pursuit of right and wrong is a realm of reckless galloping. **[5]** **[Annotation:]**
The appearance of *tun*-like ignorance, moving straight forward without hesitation. **[6]** **[Annotation:]**
**[Subcommentary:]**
*Yiyì* describes the restless, driven demeanor. *Yútún* depicts the look of ignorance. Ordinary people chase after external objects, toiling endlessly without rest; those who embody the Dao abandon knowledge and perception, moving forward in *tun*-like ignorance.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*《芚》* Xu: *tú bēn* (rhymes); Guo: *zhì běn*; Sima: "chaotic, undifferentiated." Cui: "thick and rich in texture" or "bound." Li: *chǒu lún*.

**[7]** **[Annotation:]**
*Purity* means unadulterated. To survey ten thousand years and compare their changes—ordinary people call this *mixed*, hence they toil restlessly, straining body and mind, moving from this to that. Only the great sage, free from attachment, advances in *tun*-like simplicity, merging with transformation as one. In this unity with change, they constantly wander in solitude. Thus, though intermingling across countless ages, with a thousand differences and ten thousand variations, when the Dao acts, it brings completion—past and present become one completion. When things are named as such, the ten thousand things become one "as such." Nothing is not "as such," no time is not complete—this may be called *purity*.

**[Subcommentary:]**
The sage harmonizes their virtue with the two primal forces and unites their body with the ten thousand things, thus adapting to change and aligning with the world. Though passing through ancient and modern times, experiencing both peace and peril, intermingling with the dust of the world, with a thousand differences and ten thousand variations, they remain serene and unperturbed, unmoved by trifles, embracing singular purity and abiding in the wondrous ultimate.

◎ Jia Shifu:
Ordinary people are restless, comparing today with tomorrow. What they see as right today, they may see as wrong tomorrow; what they see as wrong today, they may see as right tomorrow. The sage, in *tun*-like ignorance, does not employ such distinctions but lodges them in the ordinary. They survey ten thousand years to exhaust their capacity. *One* means undifferentiated, without separation of self and other; *completion* means joyful, without distinction between "as such" and "not as such"; *purity* means tranquil, without debate over right and wrong. The sage responds to the changes of the ten thousand things with this approach, mutually enfolding them in boundlessness—this is what it means to survey ten thousand years and achieve singular completion and purity.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*《怵心》* *chù lǜ*; *《参糅》* *rú jiù*.

**[8]** **[Annotation:]**
Nothing is not "as such."

**[9]** **[Annotation:]**
*Enfolding* means accumulation. Accumulating "as such" over ten thousand years makes ten thousand years one "as such"; accumulating "as such" over the ten thousand things makes the ten thousand things entirely "as such." Thus, one does not know where life and death, before and after, self and other, victory and defeat reside.

**[Subcommentary:]**
The sentiments of things have been entrenched for a long time. Thus, when discussing the ten thousand things horizontally, none do not claim "I am right, others are wrong"; when recounting past and present vertically, all insist "I am right, others are wrong." Though the ten thousand things are many and past and present are distant, the accumulation of right and wrong never ceases. The sage follows the world’s rise and fall, moving yet always still, intermingling countless ages in pure, unchanging unity.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*《相蕴》* Also written as *缊*. Xu: *yú fèn*; Guo: *yú běn*; Li: *yú wèn*. Meaning "accumulation."

**[Collation Notes:]**
(1) Zhu Guiyao’s edition includes *ruò* after *xī*.
(2) Zhao the Remonstrator’s edition uses *□*, same below.
(3) *Quēwù* cites Liu: same edition, *tún* written as *mào*, glossed: *tún*, *zhì běn* (rhymes), meaning "the appearance of ignorant, straightforward movement."
(4) The character *wéi* follows the Fù Sòng edition.
(5) The *Shì Détáng* edition writes *bō* as *bèi*; this edition follows the original text of the *Shìwén*.
(6) The character *mù* follows the *Shì Détáng* edition.
(7) The character *yún* is supplemented following the *Shì Détáng* edition.

How do I know that delighting in life is not a delusion? **[1]**
How do I know that hating death is not like a youth lost and unable to find their way home? **[2]**
Lady Li was the daughter of the border warden of Ai. When the state of Jin first took her, she wept until her tears soaked her collar. Yet once she reached the king’s palace, shared his bed, and ate fine meats, she regretted her tears. **[3]**
How do I know that the dead do not regret their initial longing for life? **[4]**

**[1]** **[Annotation:]**
Life and death are one, yet one delights only in life, desiring to oppose transformation—how is this not delusion?

**[Subcommentary:]**
The forge shapes the ten thousand things without partiality; transformation and death are of a single principle. Yet to delight only in life and hate death—how is this not delusion?

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*《予恶》* *wū*; below, *wū hū* all the same. *《说》* *yuè*; annotation same. *《相背》* *pèi*.

**[2]** **[Annotation:]**
Losing one’s former home in youth is called *weak loss*. Those who suffer *weak loss* become content with their new place and do not know to return to their homeland. How do I know that life is not *weak loss*? How do I know that death is not a return, yet one hates it?

**[Subcommentary:]**
*Weak* refers to youth; *loss* means to lose. It describes those who, in their youth, encounter chaos, lose their homeland, settle in foreign lands, and do not know to return—this is called *weak loss*. Emerging from nothing into being is called *life*; returning from being to nothing is called *death*. To cling to life and hate death—is this not *weak loss*, not knowing the way home?

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*《恶死》* *wū lù*; annotation same. *《弱丧》* *xī làng*; annotation same. *《少而》* *shào ér*. *《焉知》* *yú qián*; below same.

**[3]** **[Annotation:]**
Within a single lifetime, emotions change like this.

At such a time, one does not know the other—how much less can one know the transformations of life and death! **[Subcommentary:]**
Formerly, Duke Mu of Qin and Duke Xian of Jin jointly attacked the state of Li Rong and obtained a beautiful woman and two jade rings. Qin took the rings while Jin took the woman—she was the daughter of the border guard of Ai in the state of Li Rong. *Kuang* means "correct." When she first left Li Rong, parting from her kin and homeland, her longing for her native soil moved her to tears that soaked her lapels. Later, upon arriving in the state of Jin, she was favored with great honor, sharing the same royal couch with Duke Xian in feasting and repose, and offered sumptuous viands to fill the kitchens. As her affections shifted, she came to regret her earlier weeping. Within a single lifetime, emotions change like this—how much less can one know the difference between life and death! Zhuangzi spoke in parables, hence he referred to Duke Xian as "the king." **[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*《至于王所》* Cui [Yun] says: During the Warring States period, the feudal lords presumptuously styled themselves as kings, thus Duke Xian is here called "the king." *《筐》* In some versions, written as *kuang*. Xu [Shen]: *qi kuang* rhyme.

"《床》" Xu pronounces as *chuang*. Sima [Biao] says: *kuang chuang* means a restful couch. Cui [Yun] says: *kuang* means square. Another opinion: it means a proper couch.

**[Note 4]** **[Annotation]** *Qi* means to seek.
**[Exegesis]** *Qi* means to seek. When Lady Li arrived in Jin, she regretted her earlier weeping—how could the dead not likewise regret their initial desire to live while alive!

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*《蕲》* Pronounced *qi*, meaning to seek.

**[Textual Note:]**
(1) The Zhao Jianyi edition omits the two characters *suo wei* below.
(2) The Zhao edition lacks the character *zhi*.

One who dreams of drinking wine wakes to weep; one who dreams of weeping wakes to hunt. While dreaming, one does not know it is a dream. Within the dream, one may even interpret the dream—only upon waking does one realize it was a dream. Yet there is a great awakening, after which one knows this was the great dream. The foolish, however, believe themselves awake, priding themselves on their knowledge: "You are a lord!" "You are a herdsman!" How rigid! Confucius and you—we are all dreaming. When I say you are dreaming, I too am dreaming. Such words are called *diaogui* (perverse consolation). Even ten thousand generations later, should a great sage arise who understands this, it would be as if encountering them at dawn or dusk.

**[Note 1]** **[Annotation]** This refers to the mutability of waking and dreaming. If circumstances change, emotions differ, then the desires of life and death cannot be the same. Thus, one who delights in life while alive will delight in death when dead. Though life and death differ, each attains its wish equally—what attachment remains?

**[Exegesis]** The change between life and death is like the difference between waking and dreaming. Since waking and dreaming are distinct, so too are the feelings of life and death. Yet if one wakes to misfortune but dreams of joy, why should death not bring delight and life sorrow? Thus, the distinction between waking and dreaming cannot be clung to.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*《乐生》* Pronounced *le*, as below.

**[2] [Annotation]**
From this perspective, at the moment of death, one does not recognize it as death but instead finds contentment in fulfilling their will.

**[Exegesis]**
When one is about to dream, they do not know it is a dream—just as, when one is about to enter death, they do not know it is death. Each fulfills their will; what is there to cling to?

**[3] [Annotation]**
As for the dreamer who, within a dream, interprets that very dream, this differs not at all from the waking state.

**[4] [Annotation]**
In whatever one encounters, there is nothing lacking—why then, while alive, should one fear death?

**[Exegesis]**
When a person is in the midst of sleep and dreams, they take it as reality, even interpreting the dream’s omens and pondering its fortune or misfortune. Only upon waking do they realize it was a dream. Thus, one delights in life while alive and delights in death when dead—why, then, should one fear death while living?

**[Phonetic Gloss]**
*《觉而》* Pronounced *jiào*. The same applies below and in the annotations.

**[5] [Annotation]**
The great awakened one is the sage. The great awakened one knows that all who harbor anxieties and concerns remain unawakened.

**[Exegesis]**
The bustling masses, the teeming multitudes—all gallop through the realm of striving and action, lost in the great dream. Only the sage who embodies the Dao is luminously and uniquely awake, knowing that all who harbor anxieties and concerns remain unawakened.

**[6] [Annotation]**
The foolish, lost in the great dream, believe themselves awake. Thus, they furtively exalt what they favor as rulers and degrade what they despise as herdsmen, joyfully clinging to the prejudices of their own household. This is truly narrow-minded.

**[Exegesis]**
The deluded masses, benighted as if wandering in darkness, slumber in dreams yet believe themselves awake. Furtively, they debate based on their limited knowledge, elevating what they favor as rulers and equating what they despise with herdsmen. To hold such sentiments is truly narrow-minded. Cattle are tended by *herdsmen (牧)*, horses by *grooms (圉)*.

**[Phonetic Gloss]**
*《窃窃》* Sima: "Like *察察* (keen scrutiny)."
*《牧乎》* Cui’s edition reads *跂乎*, glossed as *踶跂* (the appearance of a stubborn sheep).
*《所好》* Pronounced *hūbào*.
*《所恶》* Pronounced *wūlù*.

**[7] [Annotation]**
Those who cannot forget words and attain spiritual comprehension are not truly great awakened ones.

**[Exegesis]**
