When the mantis flares its arms in anger against the wheel tracks of a chariot, though it relies on the beauty of its talent, it cannot possibly fulfill its task. This is like Yan He attempting to match his own abilities against the power of the heir apparent—how is it different from the mantis brandishing its arms against the wheel tracks?

**Phonetic Gloss**:
*Bù shèng* (不胜): *shēng* (音升).

◎ Qingfan notes: The *Imperial Digest* (vol. 946) cites Sima: "It is not that it lacks fine talent—it is simply unequal to the task." The *Phonetic Gloss* omits this.

**【2】**
*Commentary*: To amass your talent, to boast of your excellence, and to challenge this man is the path to danger.

*Exegesis*: *Jī* means to accumulate. *Ér* means "you." *Jī* means peril.

Having been entrusted as tutor to the heir apparent, one ought to be cautious and vigilant. Yet now you accumulate talent and boast of your own excellence, provoking his power and authority—this will surely lead to peril and ruin. Do you not understand the way of those who raise tigers? They dare not feed it living creatures, for fear of its rage when killing them. They dare not give it whole prey, for fear of its fury when tearing it apart. They time its hunger and satiety, and thus appease its wrathful heart. Though tigers and humans are of different kinds, the tiger flatters and fawns upon its keeper—this is because it is compliant. Thus, what it kills is what resists it.

**【1】**
*Commentary*: They fear that the tiger, harboring a killing intent, will become enraged.

*Exegesis*: Do you know the method by which the world raises tigers? One must not offer living swine or sheep to fierce beasts, lest they grow furious in the act of killing.

◎ Jia Shifu notes: "How close it is!"—referring to the tiger’s enraged gaze upon the mantis, nearly approaching it. This is one who fails to measure his own talent. The tiger’s wrath can be tamed; the finest horse, if made to chafe at the bit, break its head, and shatter its chest in fury, is no different—simply do not provoke it. What advantage does the mantis gain by clashing with the chariot tracks? Why does it do this?

**Phonetic Gloss**:
*Wèi qí* (为其): *yú wěi* (于伪) *fǎn*. The same below.

**【2】**
*Commentary*: If the tiger is made to tear its food apart itself, it will grow enraged through exertion.

*Exegesis*: Do you know that even when offering dead prey to beasts, one must first divide it? If the tiger is made to tear it apart itself, one fears it will grow enraged through exertion.

*Phonetic Gloss*:
*Fēn zhī* (分之): read as written.

**【3】**
*Commentary*: Know the cause of its rage and comply with it.

*Exegesis*: Know the times of its hunger and satiety, grasp the bounds of its joy and anger, and be attuned to the patterns of things—how could danger or ruin then arise?

**【4】**
*Commentary*: Comply with the Dao, and even different species will grow affectionate; defy its rhythms, and even the closest kin will take up arms against one another.

*Exegesis*: For compliance brings delight and submission—even tigers and wolves may be tamed and befriended. Defiance brings slaughter and harm—even the closest kin may turn to armed conflict. The way of pleasing others is the same; the method of engaging with things is no different.

◎ Jia Shifu notes: To understand the heart of rage is to have a means of acting. What is called "compliance" does not mean indulging its desires, but neither allowing killing without guiding its rage nor permitting division without releasing its rage. If one simply avoids provoking its rage, its heart will always find its own way to expression—then it is compliant. The lover of horses gathers their dung in baskets and collects their urine in shells. Yet when a gadfly alights upon one and the master fails to stroke it in time, the horse may break its bit, smash its head, and shatter its chest. Love may reach its limit, and care may be lost—can one not be cautious?

【1】**Annotation:** Though dung and urine are most base, to gather them in precious vessels is the utmost in love for horses.
**Subcommentary:** *Shen* are large clams. To value a horse’s excrement is to prize it highly. Though dung and urine are most base, to collect them in large clams is to be so bound by affection that one goes to such lengths.
**Phonetic Glosses:** *Sheng shi* (盛矢) reads *chéng*; the same below and in the annotation. *Shi* (矢) may also be written *shǐ* (屎), with the same meaning. *Yǐ shèn* (以蜃) reads *shèn* (Xú: *shì zhěn* 反), a type of clam. *Nì* (溺) reads *niào* (奴吊反).

【2】**Annotation:** Swarming densely upon the horse.
**Phonetic Glosses:** *Pū* (仆) reads *wén* (音文); some editions write it □, with the same meaning. *Méng* (虻) reads *méng* (孟庚反). *Pūyuán* (仆缘) reads *pǔmù* (普木反) or *fūmù* (徐敷木反). Xiàng says: *pūpūrán* (仆仆然) describes the dense swarming of gadflies on the horse. Cuī reads it as written, glossing it as *púyù* (仆御).
◎ **Wang Niansun notes:** Both Xiàng’s and Cuī’s interpretations are incorrect. *Pū* (仆) means *to cling*; it describes gadflies clinging to the horse’s body. *Pū* and *fù* (附) are similar in sound and meaning. In the *Greater Odes* ("Jìng zuì" 既醉), the *Máo Commentary* glosses *pú* (仆) as *fù* (附). The *Zheng Commentary* says: "The great mandate of Heaven clings to you." The *Wen Xuan* annotation to the *Zǐxū Fù* quotes the *Guǎngyǎ* as saying: "*Pú* means to cling to a person." (Note: This line does not appear in the current *Guǎngyǎ*; *Guǎngyǎ* may be a corruption of *Guǎngcāng*.) *Qúnzhuó* (群着) reads *zhíluè* (直略反).

【3】**Annotation:** Though one seeks to remedy the trouble, startling the horse by acting unexpectedly.
**Phonetic Glosses:** *Ér fǔ* (而拊) reads *fǔ* (李: *fǔ*, 又 *fù*; 一音 *fù*). Cuī’s edition writes it *fǔ* (府), reading *fù* (附).

【4】**Annotation:** Taking it unawares, one startles it into such a state.
**Subcommentary:** *Pū* (仆) means *to gather*. *Fǔ* (拊) means *to pat*. *Xián* (衔) means *the bit*.

Just then, horseflies gathered in swarms upon the horse. The master, cherishing his steed, suddenly patted it, intending to remove the nuisance. Without regard for timing, he startled the horse unawares, causing it to bolt in terror. Thereupon, the horse snapped its bit and reins, tore apart its bridle, and trampled its rider, crushing his head and shattering his chest.

【5】**Annotation:** Though the intent was to eliminate the harm, acting impulsively in patting it led to such destruction—losing what he sought to cherish. Thus, in engaging with the world, one must exercise utmost caution in matters of adversity and compliance.

**Subcommentary:** *Wáng* (亡) means *to lose*. His intent (now corrected to *zhì* 至) was to cherish the horse, yet by damaging it, he lost what he loved. In human affairs, the principle is the same: when stimuli and responses fall out of alignment, disaster follows. The lesson of patting the horse should be heeded with great care.

◎ The late Master of the Jiā clan remarks: As people interact to form society, beauty and ugliness arise, compliance and defiance diverge, and adversity and compliance take shape. From this, great calamities emerge. To say others are unfit for companionship is to overlook one’s own unfitness to engage with them. In dealing with oneself, to remain without utility is to attain the Way. Virtue dissipates in pursuit of fame, and wisdom arises from contention—this is the central theme of the present chapter. Only by relinquishing fame and contention in the five concluding passages can one move freely within the human world.

**Phonetic Glosses:** *Shuàirán* (率然) reads *shuàilǜ* (疏律反). Some editions write *zú* (卒), reading *qīhū* (七忽反).
**Collation:** The character *zhì* (至) is amended following the main text and Guo’s annotation.

When the artisan Shí traveled to Qí and reached Qūyuán, he saw an oak enshrined as a local earth deity. The tree was so vast it could shade thousands of oxen, its girth requiring a hundred spans to encircle. Its height towered seventy *rèn* above the mountains before branches emerged, and its lateral boughs—ten or more—could each be fashioned into a boat. Spectators thronged like a marketplace, yet the master carpenter paid no heed and passed by without pause.

【1】**Subcommentary:** *Zhī* (之) means *to go to*. *Qūyuán* is a place name. Its roads wind like the Huányuán Pass west of Mount Sōng—this is of the same kind. *Lì* is the name of the tree; *shè*, the earth deity. Earth altars are called *shè* (社), meaning "to sprout," for they bring forth the myriad things. *Jiàng* is the general term for craftsmen; *Shí* is the given name of this skilled artisan. Traveling from Lǔ to Qí, he passed through the winding roads and saw this extraordinary tree—gnarled and useless. This illustrates that to navigate the human world, one must treat the useless as useful.

**Phonetic Glosses:** *Qūyuán* (曲辕) reads *yuán* (袁). Sīmǎ explains: *Qūyuán* means winding roads. Cuī says: It is the name of a road. *Lì* (栎) reads *lìdí* (力狄反). Lǐ explains: It is the name of a tree; another says: *qiú* (梂).
◎ Lú Wénchāo notes: *Qiú* (梂) appears as *cǎi* (采) in most editions, an error. Here corrected following the Song edition.

【2】**Subcommentary:** *Xié* (絜) means *to bind*. The *lì* tree of the earth shrine stood far taller than ordinary trees, its branches and leaves casting shade over thousands of oxen. Measured with a rope, its circumference spanned a hundred *chǐ*. The Jiangnan Zhuāng edition often speaks of it shading an ox, omitting "thousands"—this version appears corrupt. Moreover, the tree of Shāngqiū could shelter a thousand chariots; how could the tree of Qūyuán shade only one ox? By this comparison, the version with "thousands" is correct.

**Phonetic Glosses:** *Bìniú* (蔽牛) reads *bìshì* (必世反). Lǐ explains: Oxen standing beside it would not be seen. *Xié* (絜) reads *hùjié* (户结反) in Xiàng and Xú, and *hǔjié* (虎结反) in Xú—meaning *to bind*.
◎ Qìngfān notes: The *Wén Xuǎn* annotation to Jiǎ Yì’s *Guò Qín Lùn* cites Sīmǎ: *Xié* means *to encircle*. This is omitted in the phonetic glosses.

【3】**Subcommentary:** Seven *chǐ* make one *rèn*. This tree soared over seventy *chǐ* before its branches emerged, blocking the sun and scraping the clouds. Its lateral boughs—ten or more—were each large enough to make a boat. Such was its form.

**Phonetic Glosses:** *Shírèn* (十仞): The *Xiǎo Ěr Yǎ* states: Four *chǐ* make one *rèn*. (Note: Seven *chǐ* make one *rèn*.) Cuī’s edition writes *qiān rèn* (千仞). Some say: Eight *chǐ* make one *rèn*. *Páng shíshù* (旁十数) reads *suǒjù* (所具反). Cuī explains: *Páng* means lateral branches.
◎ Yú Yuè notes: *Páng* should be read as *fāng*, as the characters are interchangeable. The *Shàng Shū*’s *Gāo Yáo Mó* reads *fāng shī xiàng xíng* (方施象刑), while the *Xīn Xù*’s *Jié Shì* reads *fāng zuò páng* (方作旁). The *Fǔ Xíng* reads *fāng gào wú gū* (方告无辜), while the *Lùn Héng*’s *Biàn Dòng* reads *fāng zuò páng* (方作旁)—all attest to this interchange. The *Zài Yòu* chapter’s *chūrù wú páng* (出入无旁) means *chūrù wú fāng* (出入无方), providing further evidence of this substitution in the present text. The *Shī Jīng*’s *Zhēng Yuè* reads *mín jīn fāng dài* (民今方殆), with the Zhèng commentary: *Fāng* means "about to." Thus, *qí kěyǐ wéi zhōu zhě fāng shíshù* (其可以为舟者方十数) means "those that could be made into boats were about ten or more." The phonetic glosses cite Cuī: *Páng* means lateral branches, likely unaware that *páng* is a substitute for *fāng*, thus mistaking a grammatical particle for a concrete term.

【4】**Subcommentary:** *Chuò* (辍) means *to stop*. The tree was extraordinarily large, drawing crowds of onlookers. Only the artisan Shí recognized its uselessness and passed by without a glance.

**Phonetic Glosses:** *Guānzhě* (观者) reads *guānhuàn* (古奂反), also *guān* (官). *Jiàngbó* (匠伯): *Bó* is the courtesy name of Shí. Cuī’s edition also writes *Shí* (石).
◎ Qìngfān notes: The *Wén Xuǎn* annotations to Hé Yàn’s *Jǐng Fú Diàn Fù*, Wáng Zǐyuān’s *Dòng Xiāo Fù*, Xī Shūyè’s *Qín Fù*, Sīmǎ Shàotōng’s poem *Zèng Shān Tāo*, and Zhāng Jǐngyáng’s *Qī Mìng* all cite Sīmǎ: *Jiàng Shí* has the courtesy name *Bó*. This is omitted in the phonetic glosses. *Bùchuò* (不辍) reads *dīngliè* (丁劣反).

【Collation:】(1) The Shìdétáng edition omits the phrase "thousands of," aligning with the *Phonetic Glosses*; the omission is cited as an error, while the Jiāngnán Lǐ edition and Zhāng Jūnfáng’s edition retain it.

The disciple, weary of gazing, ran to catch up with Artisan Shí and said, “Since I took up the axe to follow you, Master, I have never seen timber so magnificent as this. Why does the Master refuse to look and walk on without pause?”

【1】**Subcommentary:** The disciple, astonished by the grandeur of the sacred oak, halted to observe it. Proud of his long apprenticeship, he had never seen timber so vast (and strange). Perplexed by the artisan’s indifference, he ran to catch up and inquired.

**Phonetic Glosses:** *Yàn* (厌) reads *yúyàn* (于艳反), also *yúzhān* (于瞻反).

Artisan Shí said, “Enough! Say no more! It is a *sàn*-wood. If fashioned into a boat, it would sink; as a coffin or outer coffin, it would swiftly rot; as a vessel, it would quickly break; as a door or gate, it would ooze sap; as a pillar, it would be devoured by worms. This is a worthless tree, of no use whatsoever—thus it attains such longevity.”

【1】**Subcommentary:** *Yǐ* (已) means *to cease*. Artisan Shí, recognizing the great tree’s worthlessness—unfit for worldly use—rebuked his disciple for wasting words and bade him stop.

【2】**Subcommentary:** The oak is heavy; as a boat, it would sink. Prone to decay near soil, as a coffin it would swiftly perish. Such a diffuse and useless tree fulfills its natural span, for it is precisely its worthlessness that grants it idleness.

**Phonetic Glosses:** *Sànmù* (散木) reads *xīdàn* (悉但反), Xú [Xuǎn] reads *xīdàn* (悉旦反). The same applies below.

「《则速》*read as written*. Formerly, Cuī’s edition had *shù* (数). *Xiàng* reads *suǒ lù* (所禄反). The same applies below. 《腐》*fǔ*, *fú fǔ* (扶甫反).」

【3】**Subcommentary:** Among human utensils, value lies in durability. Since the oak is brittle and porous, its early ruin is beyond doubt!

【4】**Subcommentary:** *Mán* refers to the oozing of sap. *Dù* are the worms within wood. As doors or gates, it exudes sap and resin; as beams or pillars, it is infested and unstable.

**Phonetic Glosses:** 《液》*yè*, pronounced *yì*. 《樠》*mán*, *máng yán* (亡言反). Xiàng [Xiàng Xiū] reads *lǐ mò gān* (李莫干反); Guō [Xiàng] reads *wǔ bàn* (武半反). Sīmǎ [Biāo] says: *yè* means "fluid"; *mán* refers to resin flowing thickly. Cuī [Yī] says: "black fluid." ◎ Lǐ Zhēn notes: *Guǎngyùn* 22 *yuán*: *mán* is the heartwood of pine, also a tree name. *Shuōwén*: *mán* is pine heartwood. Duàn [Yùcái]’s commentary: "Likely an omission; should read ‘pine heartwood; also called a tree name.’" The edition Lù [Démíng] relied upon was an ancient *Shuōwén*. Since pine heartwood contains resin, *yè mán* precisely captures this meaning—resin flowing like pine heartwood. This is the subtlety of Zhuāngzǐ’s wordplay. Neither the subcommentary nor the phonetic glosses clarify the sense. Further, *Guǎngyùn* defines *□* as pine resin; Duàn says this is a corruption of *mán* as "pine resin." I suspect *□* is an alternate form of *mán*. 《蠹》*dù*, *dīng gù* (丁故反).

【5】**Commentary:** Not among the ranks of usable timber—hence called a "worthless tree."

**Subcommentary:** Idle, brittle, and porous, it is a useless tree, unfit for any application—thus it escapes early demise.

The carpenter returned home. The oak of the shrine appeared to him in a dream, saying: "With what would you compare me? Would you liken me to the *patterned trees*? Consider the hawthorn, pear, orange, and pomelo—fruit-bearing kinds: when their fruit ripens, they are stripped, and in stripping, they are humiliated. Their great branches break, their small branches are torn. This is how their abilities bring suffering to their lives. Thus they do not complete their natural span but perish midway, self-destructing against the common world. All things are no different. As for me, I have long sought worthlessness, nearly dying before attaining it—yet now I have found it to be my great use. Had I been of use, could I have grown so vast? Moreover, you and I are both things—how can one thing pass judgment upon another? And you, a nearly dead worthless man—what could you know of a worthless tree?"

【1】**Commentary:** All usable timber is called *patterned wood*.

**Subcommentary:** *Wū hū* means "in what." *Ruò* means "you." *Yú* means "I."

The wood that can be used is called *patterned wood*. The master carpenter returned to his rest, and the oak of the sacred altar appeared to him in a dream, asking: "With what will you compare me? Shall you take me for a worthless, scattered tree? Or shall you liken me to a useful, patterned wood?"

The master carpenter awoke and interpreted his dream. His disciple said: "If you sought worthlessness, why then serve as a sacred altar?"

**Commentary:** All things are harmed by their own usefulness.

**Subcommentary:** That which grows on trees is called *fruit*—such as crabapples and pears; that which grows on the ground is called *gourds*—such as melons and calabashes. How could you compare me to such things?

Is it not that the flavor of these fruits and gourds, though pleasing to the taste, brings suffering to their lives once their seeds ripen? They are stripped and humiliated, their great branches broken, their small branches torn. Is this not because their sweetness becomes the very cause of their bitter existence? Such is the meaning of "humiliation." Though they sprout in spring and fall in autumn, completing their natural span, they are struck down midway—this is called "untimely death." Yet the world, both sentient and insentient, all things with form, are cut short in their prime by their own usefulness. Thus it is said: "All things are no different." *Pou* means "to strike."

The oak had long been watched by others, but only now did the master carpenter truly see it.

To accumulate worthlessness is to attain the great use of preserving life.

The oak had long sought worthlessness, nearly dying before attaining it—yet now it had found its great use. Had it been useful, would it have grown so vast? Moreover, you and I are both things—how can one thing pass judgment upon another?

If it had been useful, it would long since have been felled.

You and I are both creations of the same transforming power—how could one thing truly know another? *Nai he zai* is a rhetorical question.

The oak spoke in jest to the master carpenter. The carpenter had deemed it worthless, calling it a "scattered tree," while the oak, though capable, considered itself useless. Thus it called the carpenter a "scattered man." Those who flaunt their abilities in the world court untimely death, while I, through my scattered worthlessness, have preserved my life. You, a nearly dead scattered man—what could you know of a scattered tree? This was spoken in a dream to jest with the master carpenter.

The master carpenter awoke and pondered the dream in his sleep, recounting it to his disciples.

His disciples asked, “If it sought worthlessness, why then did it become a shrine tree?”

The master replied, “Hush!”

"Hush! It merely lodged there of its own accord—taking it as the scorn and reproach of those who fail to understand it. Had it not become a shrine tree, it might well have been felled! Moreover, what it preserves differs from the common—yet to measure it by praise is indeed far off the mark!"

---

**[1] [Annotation]** The shrine came to lodge there on its own; the tree did not seek to become a shrine.

**[2] [Annotation]** This tree regards the shrine as one who fails to recognize its worth, bringing only humiliation and affliction—how could this be honor?

**[Commentary]** *Ruò* (若) means "you." *Bǐ* (彼) refers to the shrine. You must be discreet and guard your words. The spirit of the shrine came to lodge here of its own accord; it is not that this tree (*lì*, 栎) *delights* in becoming a shrine.

**[3] [Annotation]** *Gòu* (诟) means humiliation. To think that the shrine spirit, failing to grasp that the tree values uselessness as its true use—cherishing the preservation of its life—would arbitrarily come to lodge here, heaping scorn and affliction upon it, turning it into a disgrace—how could this be honor?

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Gòu* (诟): Li [Yi] reads *hū dòu* (呼豆) in reverse; Xu [Shen] reads it as *gòu* (垢).

"The character *lì* (厉) is read as written. Sima [Biao] says: *Gòu* means humiliation; *lì* means affliction.

**[3] [Commentary]** The tree, originally regarding uselessness as its true use, would thus—even if not made into a shrine—ultimately avoid the harm of being cut down.

**[Exegesis]** Fundamentally, by being sparse and unfit for use, it preserves the Dao of its life. Even if it were not a shrine tree, how could it ever draw near to the harm of being cut down?

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Qiě jī* (且几): Read as *jī* (机), or alternatively as *qí* (祈).
*Jiǎn hū* (翦乎): Read as *zǐ qiǎn* (子浅) in reverse. Cui [Shu] writes it as *qián yú* (前于).
◎ Qing Fan notes: *Hū* (乎) is written as *yú* (于) in Cui’s version; *yú* here means *hū*. In the *Lunyu* (*Wei Zheng* chapter), it is written *xiào hū wéi xiào* (孝乎惟孝), where both the Huang Kan edition and the Han Stone Classics write *yú* (于). In the *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Shen Ying* chapter), it is written *rán zé xiān wáng shèng yú* (然则先王圣于), where Gao [You]’s commentary states: *yú* means *hū*. These are all examples of this usage.
*Bù jìn* (不近): The *jìn* (近) here means proximity. The same applies below.

**[4] [Commentary]** That [tree] regards having no safeguard as its safeguard, while the multitude regards having safeguards as their safeguard.

**[Exegesis]** The sparse tree preserves its life through uselessness, while those of fine timber perish young due to their talent—this is why they differ.

**[5] [Commentary]** Benefiting others and nurturing things, restraining the people from wrongdoing—this is the meaning of the shrine. As for the useless, they are tranquil and do not act, yet the various talents act of their own accord. Those who act of their own accord each attain their proper place without interference—this is how the useless preserve their lives. You praise it as a shrine—how could it possibly draw near [to harm]?

**[Exegesis]** The scattered wood, unfit for use, is endowed by the Creator; relying on its uselessness, it preserves its life. Yet the shrine spirit lodges here, bringing humiliation and affliction, and now you further praise it with the meaning of the shrine—this is even more mistaken.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Yì yù* (义誉): Read as *yú* (余). The commentary is the same.
◎ Lu Wenchang says: In the current text, *yù* (誉) is written as *yù* (喻).
*Zhǎng wù* (长物): Read as *dīng liǎng* (丁两) in reverse.
*Bó rán* (泊然): Read as *bù gè* (步各) in reverse.
*Bù yǔ* (不与): Read as *yú* (余).

**[Textual Note]** (1) The character *yù* (喻) is amended following the Shide Tang edition and Lu’s collation.
(2) The character *běn* (本) is amended following the exegesis and the Shide Tang edition.
(3) The characters *zì* (自) and *yǐ* (以) are deleted following the Song edition."

South伯子綦 wandered in the hills of 商丘 and saw an extraordinary great tree. A thousand chariots could shelter beneath its shade, finding refuge in the coolness of its canopy.

子綦 exclaimed, “What tree is this? It must possess some extraordinary quality!”

Looking up at its slender branches, he saw they were gnarled and twisted, unfit for beams or rafters. Looking down at its massive roots, he saw they were split and fissured like an axle, unfit for coffins or outer caskets. Tasting its leaves, his mouth grew inflamed and ulcerated. Inhaling its scent, he became wildly intoxicated, raving for three days without cease.

**[Annotation 1]** *Its branches cast such deep shade that a thousand chariots could shelter beneath them.*
**[Exegesis]** *伯* means "elder." His Dao is most venerable, worthy to be the elder of all things, hence he is called *伯*—here, 南郭子綦. 商丘 is a place name in the region of 梁宋. A team of four horses is called a *chariot*. *藾* means "shade." In the land of 宋, 子綦 passed through 商丘 and encountered this great tree, unlike any ordinary one. Its trunk was massive, its branches and leaves luxuriant, casting deep shade that sheltered vast space—enough to cover a thousand chariots and shield their horses.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *《南伯》* Li [Yuxi] says: This is 南郭. *伯* means "elder."
*《商之丘》* Sima [Biao] says: This is present-day 睢阳 County in 梁国.
*《千乘》* *Shèng* rhymes with *zhèng*.
*《隐》* Cui [Yuan] says: Harmed by heat.
*《将芘》* Also written as *庇*. Xu [Shen] reads *fǔ zhì*; also *bēi wèi*. Cui’s edition writes *比*, glossing it as *芘*.
*《所藾》* Pronounced *lài*. Cui’s edition writes *赖*. Xiang [Xiu] says: "Shade, sufficient to shelter a thousand chariots." Li [Yuxi] concurs.
*《所阴》* Pronounced *yú zhèn*.

**[Exegesis 2]** Having seen this tree, 子綦 did not recognize its name but suspected it possessed some extraordinary power, hence its great size.

**[Exegesis 3]** *轴解* means "split like an axle," referring to the heartwood’s spiral grain. The inner coffin encases the body; *棺* means "complete." The outer casket encases the coffin.

The ridgepole and beams must be straight; what is gnarled and crooked is thus unfit. The coffin and outer casket rely on solidity; what splits and scatters is thus unstable.

**[Exegesis 4]**
To lick the leaves with the tongue is to blister and injure the lips and mouth; to inhale their scent with the nose is to induce unceasing intoxication and stupor. *Chéng* means the sickness of wine.

Ziqi says: "This is indeed a useless tree, yet it has grown to such great size! Alas, the spirit-like person—such is their uselessness!"

**[Exegesis 1]**
A body wholly without use may be called the great talent of preserving life intact; though all deem it useless, this is in truth the wondrous utility of aiding things. Thus it escapes the axe’s early doom and shelters a thousand chariots.

**[Commentary]**
The king who is "useless" among the hundred officials allows each to manage their own affairs: the clear-sighted see for him, the keen-eared hear for him, the wise counsel for him, the brave shield him. What does he do? He abides in profound stillness alone. And since none of the many talents fail in their proper place, this "uselessness" is precisely what all talent depends upon. Thus the world delights in exalting him without tiring, and he rides the myriad things without harming them.

**[Exegesis]**
The utmost person is divine—so unfathomable that even yin and yang cannot gauge them. Moving unseen among the common, their harmonious radiance does not dazzle. Thus they strike deep roots and firm their stem, attaining long life and enduring vision, bearing all things like a boat, shading and covering the black-haired people. Like that oak of the earth-altar, or this extraordinary tree, one sighs in admiration at the spirit-like person’s use: what seems useless is in fact the greatest talent.

In the **Collation Notes**, the Zhao Jianyi edition reads *chén* (臣) instead of *chéng* (乘).

In the state of Song, there was a place called Jingshi, where catalpa, Chinese catalpa, cypress, and mulberry thrived. Those trees that grew to the size of a hand’s embrace or less were felled by those seeking pegs for gibbons; those of three or four spans around were felled by those seeking timber for lofty beams or fine boats; those of seven or eight spans around were felled by the households of nobles and wealthy merchants seeking single-plank coffins. Thus, before completing their natural span, they met an untimely end beneath the axe—such is the peril of being useful.

Therefore, in sacrificial rites, a bull with a white forehead, a pig with an upturned snout, or a man afflicted with hemorrhoids were deemed unfit for the river. The shamans and invocators knew this well: these were considered inauspicious. Yet this is precisely what the spirit-like person regards as the greatest auspice.

**[Exegesis]**
Jingshi is a place name. In the region of Jingshi within the state of Song, catalpa, cypress, and mulberry—these three kinds of trees—grew perfectly straight, fit for use as timber. Here, the text briefly illustrates how fine timber meets an early end due to its usefulness, contrasting it with the earlier passage on the scattered, "useless" trees that preserve their lives.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Jingshi*: Sima Biao explains this as a place name. Another interpretation holds it as a village name. *Yi qiu bai sang* (宜楸柏桑): Cui notes that the land of Jingshi was suited to these three trees. Li comments that these three are "fine timber."
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: In modern editions, *qiu* (秋) is written as *qiū* (楸).

**[Exegesis]**
A tree that can be clasped with both hands is called *gǒng*; with one hand, *bǎ*. *Jūhóu* refers to macaques. *Yì* means a stake or post. Trees of this size were felled to make pegs or poles for striking or restraining macaques.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Gǒng*: Pronounced *gōngyǒng*. *Bǎ*: Pronounced *bǎyǎ* (Xu) or *fǔyǎ* (alternate). Sima Biao: "Clasped with both hands is *gǒng*; with one hand, *bǎ*." *Érshàng*: Pronounced *shízhǎng*. *Jū*: Pronounced *qīyú*. *Hóu*: Pronounced *hóu*. *Zhīyì*: Pronounced *yǐzhí* or *yángzhí* (Guo), or *bā* (Sima). Li: "Used to perch and play with macaques." Cui’s edition reads *bá*, pronounced *bá*, meaning a cangue.

**[Exegesis]**
*Lì* refers to roof beams or small boats. *Gāomíng* means honor and renown. Trees of three or four spans in girth were sought by those desiring fine beams for high roofs or prestigious boats.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Sānwéi*: Cui: "A span of eight *chǐ* is one *wéi*." *Zhīlì*: Read as *lì* or *lǐ*. Sima Biao: "A small boat, or a roof beam."
◎ Qingfan notes: *Míng* means "great." The passage refers to those seeking grand and imposing structures, using trees of three or four spans. (The interpretation of *míng* as "great" is discussed in the *Tiānxià* chapter, under "three hundred famous mountains.")

**[Exegesis]**
*Shànbàng* refers to coffins. It may also denote a single, unjointed side of a coffin. Trees of seven or eight spans were felled by the wealthy and merchant classes seeking large planks for coffins.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Qiúshàn*: Also written as *shàn* (擅), pronounced *shàn*.
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: In older editions, *shàn* was incorrectly written with the *shì* (示) radical. The same error appears in the commentary; this has been corrected. *Bàng*: Pronounced *bógāng*. Cui: "*Shànbàng* means a coffin." Sima Biao: "A single side of a coffin is called *shànbàng*."

**[Commentary]**
Those with useful timber cannot escape its value.

**[Exegesis]**
Because they are useful, they do not live out their natural years but are cut down midway by craftsmen—such is the harm wrought by their own utility.

**[Commentary]**
In exorcisms, shamans discard these three: a bull with a white forehead, a pig with an upturned snout, and a man with hemorrhoids. Only the finest, unblemished animals are deemed fit for use.

**[Exegesis]**
*Sǎng* means the forehead. *Kàng* means high. *Zhì* refers to anal fistulas. When shamans prepare dogs for sacrifices or select pigs and cattle for exorcisms, they must choose animals of pure color and fine quality, demonstrating reverence as if the spirits were present. Thus, a pig with a high snout or broken forehead, a calf with a white forehead (not pure red), or a man with hemorrhoids—all are unclean and unfit for the sacred river or sacrificial rites. In ancient times, people were drowned in the river to appease the River Earl; when Ximen Bao served as magistrate of Ye, he put an end to this practice—this is one such example.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Gùjiě*: Pronounced *gǔmài* (Xu) or *jiāmài* (alternate), with the same pronunciation in the commentary. Xiang: *gǔxiè*.

**[Phonetic Glosses]**
*Sǎng*: Pronounced *xīdǎng* (反切). Sima [Biao] says: the forehead.
*Kàngbí*: Xu [Shen] reads *gǔzàng* (反切). Sima says: "high"; the forehead is broken, so the nose is high. Cui [Yuan] says: "upturned."
*Zhì*: Xu reads *zhílǐ* (反切). Sima says: "hidden sores."
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The character *yún* (云) was missing in old editions; now restored.
*Shì Hé*: Sima says: refers to drowning people in the river as sacrifice.
*Xīngjù*: Pronounced *xùyíng* (反切).

**[Text and Commentary]**
**[7]** *[Annotation]* Shamans and invocators also know that the unfit are preserved intact.
**[8]** *[Annotation]* That which preserves life whole is what the world calls auspicious. Yet shamans and invocators deem the unfit inauspicious and reject them—thus, what they call inauspicious is precisely what preserves life whole, which is the greatest auspice. The spirit-like person is one who follows things without preconceived intent. Therefore, what the world calls the greatest auspice, the spirit-like person does not oppose.

**[Exegesis]**
Women are called *wū* (shamans); men are called *xí* (mediums). *Zhù* (invocators) are those who hold tablets and recite sacrificial texts. *Xiáng* means "good." When shamans, invocators, and scribes perform exorcisms, they know these three kinds of beings are unfit for offerings and thus discard them as inauspicious. Yet the spiritually sagely person, attuned to the transformations of creation, knows that the unfit and useless are thereby preserved whole. Thus, the claims that a white forehead, a high nose, or hemorrhoids are inauspicious—these are merely the vulgar sentiments of petty shamans, not the true wisdom of the great! Therefore, those whose faculties are incomplete are precisely what the spirit-like person deems auspicious and supremely good.

**[Textual Collation]**
(1) The characters *zhī yǐ* (之以) are transposed following the *Shìdétáng* edition.
(2) *Yì* lacks the phonetic *qiěyáng*; Guo [Xiang]’s note likely omitted the characters *qiāng* (戕). The *Guǎngyùn* (11, *táng* rhyme) states under *qiāng*: *qiāngkē*, also written *zāngkē*, pronounced *láng*. The *Hànshū Dìlǐzhì* annotation for *Zāngkē* Commandery reads: *zāngqiāng* refers to mooring stakes. Thus, Guo’s original text likely read *qiāng* (戕), identical in meaning to *yì* (杙) but differing in form and pronunciation. Its pronunciation *qiěyáng* (且羊反) confirms that *qiāng*, not *yì*, was intended.

**The Uselessness of the Crippled**
*Zhīlí Shū*’s body was so disjointed that his chin nestled into his navel, his shoulders towered above his crown, his hunched spine pointed heavenward, his five viscera’s *shù* points faced upward, and his thighs pressed against his ribs. Though he sewed and washed clothes to feed himself, and played the flute to scatter grain, enough to feed ten men, when the ruler conscripted warriors, *Zhīlí* rolled up his sleeves and wandered among them; when the ruler imposed great labor, *Zhīlí* was exempted due to his chronic ailment; and when the ruler distributed grain to the sick, he received three *zhōng* of grain and ten bundles of firewood. One whose form is as disjointed as *Zhīlí*’s can still nourish his body and live out his natural years—how much more so one whose virtue is disjointed!

**[Exegesis]**
**[1]** His four limbs were fractured, his hundred bones splayed apart, forcing his chin and cheeks to recede into his navel while his shoulders rose above his crown. Such a grotesque form earned him the name *Zhīlí* ("Disjointed").
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Zhīlí Shū*: Sima [Biao] says: a description of a body broken and incomplete. *Shū* is his name.
*Yí*: Pronounced *yǐzhī* (反切).
*Yú dǐng*: Read as written; originally *xiàng* (项), also read as written. Sima says: "his spine is curved, his neck contracted." The *Huáinánzǐ* states: "his spinal column rises above his crown."

**[2]** *Huìcuō* describes a towering protrusion. *Wǔ guǎn* refers to the *shù* points of the five viscera. These points lie along the back; in ancient times, topknots were positioned near the crown’s rear. Now, *Zhīlí*’s deformities—hunched back and lowered head—cause his visceral *shù* points and topknot to face upward, while his thighs and calves contract toward his ribs.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Huì*: Xu reads *gǔwài* (反切); Xiàng reads *gǔhuó* (反切). Cui [Yuan] says: *huìcuō* refers to the cervical vertebrae.
*Cuō*: Xu reads *zǐwài* (反切); Xiàng and Xu read *zǐhuó* (反切). Cui says: *huìcuō* refers to the cervical vertebrae.
*Zhǐ tiān*: Sima says: *huìcuō* means "topknot." In ancient times, topknots were centered on the nape; with a curved spine and lowered head, the topknot thus pointed heavenward. Xiàng says: "his shoulders rise sharply, forming a *huìcuō* shape."
◎ Li Zhen notes: Cui’s claim that *huìcuō* refers to the cervical vertebrae is correct. (*Dàzōngshī* chapter: "The *jùzhuì* points heavenward"; Li [Yi] says: *jùzhuì* refers to the cervical vertebrae, resembling a growth—this confirms Cui’s interpretation.) The *Sùwèn*’s *Cìrè Piān* states: "The depression above the third cervical vertebra marks the center." Wang [Bing]’s annotation: "This illustrates the general numbering of spinal vertebrae." Shen Tong’s *Shì Gǔ* says: "The twenty-one vertebrae below the *dàzhuī* (great vertebra) are collectively called the spine or spinal vertebrae." Cui’s identification of *huìcuō* as the cervical vertebrae is supported by the *Nànjīng*’s 45th difficulty: "The bones converge at *dàzhù*." Zhang’s annotation: "*Dàzhù* is an acupoint behind the first cervical vertebra; all bones branch downward from this framework, hence the bones converge at *dàzhù*." This confirms that *huìcuō* derives its meaning from the convergence of bones and lies between the *dàzhuī* vertebrae. *Cuō* in the *Táng* dynasty’s *Chūxué Jì* (Vol. 19) is written as  (木节), resembling spinal nodes. The character  (from 木) better conveys the meaning. Note: The chin and shoulders pertain to external description; *huìcuō* and the five *guǎn* pertain to internal description. The chin recedes, so the shoulders rise; the cervical vertebrae point heavenward, so the visceral *shù* points face upward—these conditions arise from mutual causation. (*Língshū Bèishù Piān*: The *shù* points of the lungs lie between the third vertebrae; the heart’s between the fifth; the liver’s between the ninth; the spleen’s between the eleventh; the kidneys’ between the fourteenth.) Sima’s interpretation of *huìcuō* as "topknot" represents a separate meaning. The *Shījīng* (*Xiǎoyǎ Tàilì*) states: "*Zīcuō*, a black cloth cap." The *Máo* commentary: "*Zīcuō* is a black cloth cap."

The *Zhèngyì* states: The term *cuō* refers to a small tuft holding the topknot in place. Based on this, interpreting *huìcuō* as a topknot would likewise mean a small tuft holding the hair, hence the name. *Huì* (會) and *kuài* (□) are interchangeable. The *Shuōwén* states: "*Kuài* (□) refers to the bone pin used to gather the hair." The *Wèifēng* ("Huì Biàn Rú Xīng") passage is cited by Xǔ Shèn as *kuài* (□). The *Zhōulǐ* ("Huì Wǔcǎi Yù Qí") annotation reads: "Old texts write *huì* (會) as *kuài* (□)." The *Shì Sānglǐ* ("Kuò Biàn Yòng Sāng") commentary states: "Taking *jì* (髻) as *kuò* (髺) derives from the idea of gathering the hair." *Huì* (會) and *kuò* (髺) are also interchangeable. The *Jíyùn* includes the character *cuō* (□), pronounced *cuō*, meaning "topknot." This is likely a later, colloquial creation of a specialized character for "topknot" based on *huìcuō*. ◎ Qìngfān’s note: The *Shìwén* cites Cuī’s commentary, stating that *huìcuō* refers to the cervical vertebrae and should be written as *zhuó* (□). The *Yùpiān* defines *zhuó* (□) as "wooden mallet," pronounced *cúhuó*. *Cuō* (撮) and *zhuó* (□) are phonetically similar. The *Shīzǐ* ("Xíng Xiǎn Yǐ Cuō") states: "*Cuō* refers to a carrying vessel," pronounced identically to *zuān* (钻). The *Zhōulǐ* ("Sāng Dàjì") annotation reads: "*Chūn* is the carriage for the coffin; *zǎn* (攒) means 'to gather.'" The *Shīzǐ* term corresponds to the *Zhōulǐ*’s *zǎn*. The *Guǎn* text writes *cuō* as *guǎn* (筦). The *Zài Shàng* commentary by Lǐ states: "*Guǎn* (管) refers to the *shù* points; the *shù* points of the five viscera all lie above." The *Liǎngbì* text alternatively writes *pái* (牌), identical in pronunciation. Xú Yòufǔ reads it as *bì*. Cuī’s commentary states: "A hunchback’s abdomen lies within the thighs." The *Wéi* (為) is read as *xūjié* (许劫). Sīmǎ’s commentary states: "The spine curves while the thighs stand upright, hence they are paired." 【3】【Commentary】 *Cuòzhēn* (挫针) means sewing clothes. *Zhìxiè* (治繲) means washing and bleaching. *Hú* (糊) means feeding; it refers to laboring with one’s bodily strength to sustain life. 【*Shìwén*】 *Cuò* (挫) is read by Xú as *zǐwò* (子卧) and by Guō as *zūhé* (租禾). Cuī’s commentary states: "To press." *Zhēn* (针) is read as *zhíjīn* (执金). Sīmǎ’s commentary states: "*Cuòzhēn* means sewing clothes." *Zhì* (治) in *zhìxiè* is read as *jiàimài* (佳卖). Sīmǎ’s commentary states: "Washing clothes." Xiàng’s reading is the same. Cuī writes it as *□*, pronounced identically.

《糊口》 Xú pronounces it as *hú*. Lǐ states: "It means to eat." Cuī notes: "The character may also be written as 互 or □."

【4】【Commentary】 *Cè* refers to a small dustpan. *Jīng* means rice. This describes sweeping the marketplace, winnowing with a dustpan, scattering dust, and sifting the fine from the coarse. Another interpretation: *gǔcè* refers to casting milfoil stalks to divine hexagrams. *Bōjīng* means discerning good and ill fortune by judging the subtle and the numinous. Some sweep markets to feed their households; others sell divination to sustain their lives. What they earn can nourish ten people.

【*Shìwén*】《鼓策》 Chū pronounces it as *chūgé*; Xú alternatively as *jiá*. Sīmǎ states: "*Gǔ* means to winnow; a small dustpan is called *cè*." Cuī states: "*Gǔcè* means to manipulate milfoil or drill tortoise shells." 《播精》 Pronounced as written; alternatively as *suǒ*, in which case the character should be 數. *Jīng*: Sīmǎ states: "To sift rice is called *jīng*." Cuī states: "*Bōjīng* means divining hexagrams and interpreting omens." *Gǔcè bōjīng* refers to fortune-telling. ◎ Qìngfān notes: *Jīng* should be 糈 in error. Guō Pú’s commentary on the *Nánshān Jīng* reads: "糈 is pronounced *xiān lǚ*; in present-day Jiāngdōng, the sound is *qǔ*." (*Shìwén* reads *qǔ*; the character should be 糈. The character 精 has no ancient pronunciation *qǔ* and was mistaken for 糈 due to their similar forms.) The *Shuōwén* states: "糈 means provisions." 《以食》 Pronounced *sì*.

【5】【Commentary】 (Relying) on their uselessness, they do not hide themselves away.

【Commentary】 When frontier regions are in turmoil and conscription seeks brave men, those maimed or infirm, unfit for battle, remain unafraid, rolling up their sleeves to roam freely. Relying on their uselessness, they do not flee or conceal themselves.

【*Shìwén*】《攘》 Pronounced *rú yáng*. 《臂于其闲》 Pronounced as written. Sīmǎ states: "闲 means within." Cuī writes it as *攘臂于其开*, stating: "开 means the space within a gate." 《窜匿》 Pronounced *nǚ lì*.

【6】【Commentary】 Because they are unfit for corvée labor.

【Commentary】 When the state imposes heavy corvée duties, those with chronic illnesses are exempted from service.

【7】【Commentary】 They are not conscripted for labor but receive gifts.

【Commentary】 Six *dàn* and four *dǒu* make a *zhōng*. When rulers pity the widowed and orphaned and show compassion for the poor and sick, those severely disabled receive abundant provisions. Thus, as Guō’s commentary states, they are not conscripted for labor but accept gifts.

【*Shìwén*】《三锺》 Sīmǎ states: "Six *hú* and four *dǒu* make a *zhōng*." ◎ Lú Wénchāo notes: "Old editions mistakenly wrote 六 as 斛; this has been corrected." 《不与》 Pronounced *yù*.

【8】【Commentary】 The spiritual person is of no use to things, yet all things attain their proper use. They ascribe merit and fame to the multitude of talents, merging with things without a trace. Thus, they avoid the harms of the human realm and abide in the substance of constant beauty—this is to fragment one’s virtue.

【Commentary】 To fragment one’s form is akin to forgetting form; to fragment one’s virtue is akin to forgetting virtue. How much more so for one who is maimed and infirm—this is truly forgetting form. Yet, not being a sage, they have not yet forgotten virtue. To forget virtue is to comprehend all things yet return wisdom to foolishness, to illuminate the Three Luminaries yet return brightness to obscurity. Thus, they accomplish without claiming, act without relying, ascribe merit and fame to the multitude of talents, and merge with things without a trace—this is to forget virtue. If forgetting form suffices to nourish the body and live out one’s years, avoiding the harms of the human realm, how much more so for one who forgets virtue! The superiority and inferiority, the shallowness and depth, cannot be spoken of in the same breath. Thus, we know that to fragment one’s virtue—this is the mark of the sage alone!

The *Shide Tang* edition omits the characters "而游" (1). The character "簸" is amended following the *Shide Tang* edition (2). According to the *Shiwen*, it does not mention the pronunciation "精" for "取"; its reference to "一音所" pertains to the character "播," hence it states that the character should be written as "數." Guo’s explanation is gravely mistaken (3). The character "恃" is amended following the commentary and the *Shide Tang* edition (4).

Confucius traveled to Chu, where the madman of Chu, Jie Yu, wandered near his gate and sang:
“O phoenix! O phoenix! How your virtue has declined!
The age to come cannot be awaited; the age past cannot be pursued.
When the world possesses the Dao, the sage brings completion;
when the world lacks the Dao, the sage preserves life.
In this present time, one can but barely escape punishment.
Blessings are lighter than feathers, yet none know how to bear them;
calamities are heavier than earth, yet none know how to avoid them.
Enough! Enough! Bestow virtue upon others no more!
Perilous! Perilous! To tread where lines are drawn upon the ground!
Beware the thorns! Beware the thorns! Do not harm my path!
My path is crooked and uneven—do not harm my feet!”

(1) *Commentary*: One should follow the times and proceed straightforwardly, fulfilling what is fitting in the convergence of circumstances. The rise and fall of the world are so vast as to be imperceptible, hence the question: *How has it come to this?*
*Subcommentary*: *How has it come to this?* means *How could it be thus?* *Traveled* means *went to*. At the time, Confucius journeyed from Lu to Chu and lodged at an inn. In Chu, there was a worthy man named Lu Tong, styled Jie Yu, who, knowing Confucius had traveled far to offer counsel, sang this song in mockery. *O phoenix! O phoenix!* Thus he lamented the sage, likening him to the auspicious bird that appears when the Dao prevails. When the world possesses the Dao, it should manifest; when it lacks the Dao, it should withdraw. How could one bear such sagely virtue and yet go to a declining and disordered state?

(2) *Commentary*: One should simply respond to what is fitting in the present moment.
*Subcommentary*: The age to come, though there may be a lord who embraces the Dao and could be served, is as fleeting as a galloping horse, and thus cannot be awaited. The age past, with its sage rulers like Yao and Shun, has long since transformed, and cannot be sought again. One should simply respond to what is fitting in the present moment, without need to gaze ahead or look behind.

(3) *Commentary*: Entrust it to its natural course, and principle will spontaneously bring about completion or preservation. Completion and preservation are not of my doing—how could they change their rhythm with order or chaos? When order prevails, one naturally seeks completion, thus abandoning completion without failure. When chaos reigns, one naturally seeks to preserve life, thus forgetting life without perishing.
*Subcommentary*: When a lord possesses the Dao and the age is enlightened, the sage spreads the Dao and enacts teaching, bringing completion to the world. When one encounters a benighted ruler and an age of decline, one may only preserve life and avoid harm, concealing one’s brilliance and obscuring one’s traces.
*Phonetic Gloss*: *How could they* is read *yu wei*. *Order and chaos* is read *zhi li*.

To align with the lower realm.

*Commentary*: Without peering ahead or glancing behind, one fully meets the present moment, merging obscurely with the age as one—only then can the wondrous accord be preserved and penal law be avoided.

*Subcommentary*: *Fang* means "to meet." In this time of ruin and disorder, precisely the age of the declining Zhou, one treads with caution and speaks with restraint, barely escaping punishment and execution. Yet to cling to traces and respond to summons—is this not delusion? These are the words of Jie Yu, mocking Confucius.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Jin* is read *jin*.

*Commentary*: Feet capable of walking are set free; hands capable of grasping are left unburdened. One listens to what the ears hear, sees what the eyes see, knows to halt at what lies beyond knowing, and ceases at what lies beyond ability. Employing what is self-employable, acting as is self-actable, indulging the nature within without the slightest attachment to what lies beyond one’s lot—this is the utmost ease of non-action. There has never been a case where non-action failed to preserve one’s nature and life; nor has there ever been a principle by which preserving nature and life did not bring good fortune. Thus, good fortune is nothing other than what was earlier called preservation—it is not borrowed from external things, nor does it bear the weight of a goose feather! To move in accord with one’s nature, never exceeding proper measure—this is the utmost ease under heaven. To lift what lifts itself, to bear what bears itself—this is the utmost lightness under heaven. Yet because knowledge injures the nature by its boundlessness, and the heart disturbs the true by its likes and dislikes, people abandon this utmost ease of non-action to pursue the utmost difficulty of action, discard this utmost lightness of self-lifting to take up the utmost burden of bearing others—this is the common affliction of the world.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Utmost ease* is read *zhi yi*. The same below.

"《知以》" is read as "wisdom."
"《欲恶》" is read *wulu*.

**6**
*Commentary*: When one lifts what is within one’s nature, even bearing ten thousand *jun* brings no sense of weight; when external things are imposed, though the burden weighs no more than a *zizhu*, one may yet be unequal to the task. What is internal is fortune—thus fortune is utmost lightness. What is external is misfortune—thus misfortune is utmost heaviness. That misfortune, so heavy, is never avoided—this is the world’s great delusion.

*Exegesis*: The faculties of seeing, hearing, knowing, and ability all have their limits. To remain within those bounds is to preserve life; to seek beyond them is to court premature death. Preserving life is thus fortune, while premature death is misfortune. Yet the fortune within one’s bounds is lighter than a goose feather, and though covetous strivers do not know it is already borne within them, the misfortune beyond one’s bounds is heavier than the earth itself, and deluded souls do not know to shun it from themselves. This is the common affliction of the vulgar world, and thus the burdens of Confucius and Lu are cited to illustrate its weight.

*Phonetic Gloss*: "《知避》" was formerly written as *置*, glossed as "to set aside." "《不胜》" is read *sheng*.

**7**
*Commentary*: To draw a line on the ground and bid a man follow it is to leave tracks that cannot be concealed; to possess one’s own [virtue] and confront things is to fail to merge with them. Thus the great person does not illuminate the self to dazzle others but lets others find their own illumination, does not impose virtue upon others but entrusts them to their own [virtue]. Thereby one pervades and unites the myriad things, mysteriously merging self and other, blending utterly with the world to share a single fortune both within and without.

*Exegesis*: *Yi* means "to halt." *Dai* means "danger."

Confucius was born at the end of the declining Zhou, in an age of dissipation and decadence. Clinging to the sagely traces, he traveled from state to state in response to summons, yet repeatedly met with rejection and slander. Thus it is said: to speak again and again is not as good as halting and refraining from action. If one were to employ the Five Virtues to govern the common people, setting aside the self to imitate things, it would surely bring danger to oneself—just as drawing lines on the ground to make tracks and bidding others run after them is but a waste of cunning labor, with no way to conceal them. To lead things with one’s own [virtue] follows the same principle.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Huadi* is read *huo*.

**8**
*Commentary*: *Miyang* means "lost yang." By losing yang and embracing solitude, not swayed by externals, one’s own conduct remains whole. If all under heaven preserve their own wholeness, then all who bear the name of "self" will be wholly preserved.

*Exegesis*: *Mi* means "lost." *Yang* means "brightness" or "movement." Lu Tong advised Confucius to conceal his traces and hide his brilliance, advocating the non-action of solitary reliance and forgetting the bright wisdom of responding to things. Thus, one halts within one’s proper bounds, without harming the wholeness of one’s life-conduct.

*Phonetic Gloss*: Sima [Qian] says: *Miyang* means "concealed yang," referring to feigned madness.

**9**
*Commentary*: To bend and complete one’s conduct is self-sufficient.

*Exegesis*: *Xi* means "emptiness." *Qu* means "compliance." Emptying the heart and following the nature of things, all who bear the name of "self" become self-sufficient.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Xiqu* is read *quni* (去逆反). Character books write it as □. *Guangya* says: □ means "bent."
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: According to the present *Shuowen* and *Guangya*, both write it as .
◎ Qingfan notes: *Xi* is written as  in the *Shiwen* cited by the *Exegesis*, which is correct. *Shuowen*:  means "bent conduct," from ⻌ and *zhi* phonetic. *Guangya*:  means "bent." *Jiyun* writes it as , saying: "It means a thing is bent. Also, it means to receive in a bent manner." *Yupian* reads it as *qiuji* (丘戟反). *Shuowen* further says: □ (read like *yin*) means "concealed," depicting a bent and hidden form. Originally written with □ as □, now written as .

*Collation*: (1) *Quewu* cites the Zhang Junfang edition, where "one’s conduct" is written as *xiqu*. (2) "Govern" and "chaos" (治者乱者): the Shidetang edition omits the two *zhe* (者) characters. (3) The character *de* (德) is amended following the Zhao Jianyi edition.

The mountain tree brings ruin upon itself; the fat of the lamp consumes itself. The cassia is edible, so it is felled; the lacquer is useful, so it is cut. All people know the use of what is useful, but none know the use of what is useless.

**1**
*Exegesis*: *Kou* means "to fell." Trees in the mountains, such as catalpa and catalpa ovata, being of useful timber, are wantonly felled. Fat provides bright illumination, filling lamps and torches, and because it is useful, it is burned. Not only fat and wood—this applies to people as well.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Shanmu zikou ye gaohuo ziqian ye* is read *ziran* (子然反). Sima [Biao] says: The tree grows the axe-handle and thus is felled; the fat ignites fire and thus consumes itself. Cui [Zhuan] says: The mountain has trees, so it is burned by fire.

**2**
*Exegesis*: The heart of the cassia is pungent and fragrant, so it is hewn; the lacquer is used for vessels, so it is cut. Both are destroyed by the axe for their abilities.

**3**
*Commentary*: What is useful serves others as a function; what is useless preserves its own life. Those who cut their flesh and skin for the world are what the world knows. To allow the common people not to lose their own wholeness while both self and other attain harmony—this is so subtle that one remains unaware of its wonder within oneself.

*Exegesis*: Catalpa, cypress, orange, and pomelo; fat, fire, cassia, and lacquer—these are useful. The crooked-trunked tree, the tree of Shangqiu, the white-foreheaded ox, the high-nosed pig—these are useless. Yet the world all flaunts its talents as the use of what is useful, unaware that the fragmentation of its virtue is the use of what is useless. Thus Guo’s commentary says: What is useful serves others as a function; what is useless preserves its own life.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Menran* is read *moben* (亡本反).

**Book 2, Part 2**
**Inner Chapters: "Virtue Fills the Symbol" (Dechongfu) V**
**Inner Chapters: "Virtue Fills the Symbol" (Dechongfu) V**

**1**
*Commentary*: Virtue fills the inner, and things respond to the outer. Inner and outer merge mysteriously, so true as if a tally command, yet the physical form is forgotten.

*Phonetic Gloss*: Cui [Zhuan] says: This is the verification of abandoning form and discarding knowledge, filling it with virtue.

In Lu there was a man named Wang Tai who had lost his feet. Those who followed him in study were as numerous as those who followed Confucius. Changji asked Confucius, saying: "Wang Tai is a man who has lost his feet, yet those who follow him in study divide Lu equally with you. He stands without teaching, sits without discussing, yet those who go to him empty return full. Is there truly a teaching without words, a formless shaping of the heart? What manner of man is he?"

**1**
*Annotation*: His surname was Wang, given name Tai, a native of Lu. To be amputated of one foot is called *wu* (兀). Though his form was maimed, his heart was truly empty and forgotten, thus his virtue filled the tally and he was placed at the head of this chapter.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Wu* (兀者): pronounced *wuhu* (五忽反), also read as *jie* (界). Li [Yun] says: to be amputated of a foot is called *wu*. Note: in seal script, the characters for *wu* (兀) and *jie* (介) are similar. *Wang Tai* (王骀): pronounced *tai* (台), Xu [Shen] also reads it as *dai* (殆). A person’s name.

**2**
*Commentary*: The number of disciples was comparable to that of Confucius.
*Annotation*: *Ruo* (若) means "like." Those who accompanied Wang Tai in travel and study were comparable in number to the followers of Confucius.
*Phonetic Gloss*: *Cong zhi* (从之): read as written; Li [Yun] also reads it as *caiyong* (才用反). The same below. *Xiang ruo* (相若): *ruo* means "like"; the disciples were comparable in number to those of Confucius.

**3**
*Annotation*: His surname was Chang, given name Ji, a worthy man of Lu. Wang Tai traveled and taught, outwardly forgetting his bodily form while inwardly filling his virtue. Thus, those who followed him in study numbered three thousand, dividing Lu equally with the disciples of Confucius. Chang Ji, not yet comprehending his essence, was thus perplexed.
*Phonetic Gloss*: *Chang Ji* (常季): Some say he was a disciple of Confucius.

**4**
*Commentary*: Each attained what they sought and was thus fulfilled.
*Annotation*: Though his disciples were many, he never lectured or expounded. Standing, he did not teach; sitting, he did not discuss. Those who came sought instruction with empty hearts and returned with full understanding. Alternate interpretation: those who came without learning or virtue also departed empty.
*Phonetic Gloss*: *Li bu jiao zuo bu yi* (立不教坐不议): Sima [Biao] says: standing, he did not instruct; sitting, he did not discuss.

**5**
*Commentary*: He marveled that one with a maimed form could have a heart so full. For when the heart is whole, it leaves the body behind, forgets the five viscera, and wanders alone—yet the world cannot depart from it.
*Annotation*: He never taught his disciples through words or discussion. Though maimed in form, devoid of appearance, his profound Dao and supreme virtue filled his inner heart. There must have been something to this, for the multitude followed him.
*Phonetic Gloss*: *Wu zang* (五藏): pronounced *cailang* (才浪反). The same below.

**6**
*Annotation*: Chang Ji marveled that one so maimed could gather such a vast following. To reveal the beauty of his filled virtue, he thus posed this question.

Confucius said: "This Master is a sage. I have merely lagged behind and not yet followed him. I shall take him as my teacher—how much more should those inferior to me! Why limit it to Lu? I shall lead all under Heaven to follow him."

**1**
*Annotation*: Master Yan [Confucius] addressed Wang Tai as "Master," replying to Chang Ji: "Wang Tai is a sage who embodies the Dao. You fail to recognize such a man, hence your doubt. I have merely fallen behind and not yet gone to study under him. I shall revere him as my teacher and seek his instruction—how much more should those of later learning, inferior to me! To seek his guidance and hold his words in reverence is only fitting."

**Annotation on "丘也直后而未往耳"**
Li [Yu] says: "He merely remains behind the multitude and has not yet gone to study under him."

◎Qing Fan’s note: *Zhi* (直) here means "only." *Lüshi Chunqiu* ("Loyalty and Integrity"): "Only Wang Zijing adorned himself for him but did not kill him." Gao You’s commentary: *Zhi* means the same as *te* (特, "only"). In the *Odes* ("Yong Feng," "Bo Zhou"), *te* (特) is written as *zhi* (直). The *Records of the Grand Historian* ("Biography of Shusun Tong"): "I was only jesting," where the *Han History* writes *zhi* as *te*.

**2**
*Annotation*: When the spirit is whole and the mind complete, the body merges with things. One who merges with things cannot be distanced by all under Heaven—how could it be limited to a single state!
*Exegesis*: *Xi* (奚) means "why." "Why merely rely on the single state of Lu? I shall guide all within the realm to follow his abundant virtue, yet still fear I may not fully grasp his Way."

**Annotation on "能远"**
Yu Wan’s pronunciation.

Chang Ji said: "That man is maimed, yet his following surpasses even yours, Master. His distinction from the common is indeed vast. If this is so, how does he employ his mind uniquely?"
**1**
*Exegesis*: *Wang* (王) means "flourishing." *Yong* (庸) means "ordinary." *Xiansheng* (先生) refers to Confucius. That Wang Tai, though maimed, has disciples and followers more numerous than Confucius himself. Such strangeness and wonder surpass the ordinary—his difference from common people is surely great.
*Annotation*: *Er wang* (而王): Yu Wan’s pronunciation. Li [Yu] says: "to surpass." Cui [Yuan] says: "to rule as lord." *Qi yu yong yi yuan yi* (其与庸亦远矣): "He differs from the common." Cui [Yuan] says: *Yong* means "ordinary people."

**2**
*Exegesis*: *Ran* (然) means "thus." Wang Tai’s abundant virtue draws all things to him—what art does he employ in his mind? Chang Ji, not idly, raises this doubt.

Confucius said: "Death and life are indeed momentous, yet he does not change with them. Though heaven and earth should collapse, he would not be lost with them. He examines the flawless and does not shift with things, guiding the transformations of things while guarding their essence."
**1**
*Annotation*: Though people change daily, death and life are the greatest of changes.
**2**
*Annotation*: He moves with change, so death and life do not alter him.
*Exegesis*: Mountains and boats may vanish, firewood and fingers may flow away—though all things undergo such changes, none surpass death and life in magnitude. Yet Wang Tai’s mind merges with the Creator, shifting with transformations, his traces blending with the world. He moves with life and death, so change cannot change him.

**3**
*Annotation*: This is compliance.
*Exegesis*: *Yi* (遗) means "loss." Though the round heavens should topple and the square earth crumble, he remains unmoved by peril, thus never losing himself.
*Annotation*: *Sui tian di fu* (虽天地覆): Fang Fu’s pronunciation. *Zhui* (坠): also written as *dui* (队), Zhu Lei’s pronunciation. Li [Yu] says: "Even heaven and earth cannot change him—how much less life and death!"

**4**
*Annotation*: Clarifying the inherent constancy of nature and destiny.
◎Qing Fan’s note: *Wu jia* (无假) is likely a corruption of *wu xia* (无瑕, "flawless"), meaning he examines his own flawlessness, thus allowing things to shift without being enslaved by them. The *Huainanzi* ("Spiritual Essence") reads *shen hu wu xia* (审乎无瑕). *Xia* (瑕) and *jia* (假) share the same phonetic root, leading to frequent interchange. In the *Records of the Grand Historian* ("Hereditary House of Zheng"), "Fu Jia" (甫假) appears in the *Zuozhuan* as "Fu Xia" (傅瑕). In the *Rites* ("Tan Gong"), "Jian Jia" (肩假) appears in the *Han History*’s "Table of Ancient and Modern Persons" as "Gong Jian Xia" (公肩瑕), providing further evidence.

**5**
*Annotation*: Allowing things to shift of themselves.
*Exegesis*: His numinous mind rests in tranquility, his wondrous essence aligned with the true origin. United with the Dao, he is not swayed by things.

**6**
*Annotation*: Taking transformation as destiny, without opposition or conflict.

**7**
*Annotation*: Never departing from the ultimate perfection.

*Exegesis*: Comprehending the allotted destiny and becoming one with external things, he moves solely with destiny and things, acting without deviating from tranquility—thus he ever abides in his fundamental origin.

*Master Chang said, “What does this mean?”*
*Exegesis*: The meaning runs deep and is difficult to grasp; he seeks further clarification to resolve his doubts.

*Confucius said, “Viewed from what makes them different, the liver and gallbladder are as far apart as Chu and Yue. Viewed from what makes them the same, the myriad things are all one. One who is thus—unaware of what the ears and eyes deem fitting, yet roaming his mind in the harmony of virtue—sees only their unity and perceives no loss. To him, losing a foot is like shedding dirt.”*

*Annotation*: When natures of pleasure and suffering diverge, judgments of beauty and ugliness turn opposite.
*Exegesis*: Though the myriad things arise in profusion, they all return to emptiness and quiescence. Inverted distinctions—clinging to right and wrong—arbitrarily erect divisions within the profound Dao. How is this different from the liver and gallbladder, born of the same body, yet deemed as distant as Chu and Yue, separated by thousands of miles? Those who cleave to differences are all alike in this.

*Annotation*: Though what they deem beautiful differs, all share the capacity for beauty. If each cherishes what they find beautiful, then the myriad things share one beauty; if each affirms what they affirm, then the world shares one affirmation. Were one to emphasize differences and treat them as distinct, nothing in the world would not be different. Yet one of vast and boundless vision—who governs heaven and earth, encompasses the myriad things—knows that differences need not be treated as such. Thus, emphasizing what is shared, nothing in the world would not be the same. Further, knowing that sameness is not absolute, one embraces what is absent, and then right and wrong, beauty and ugliness, all dissolve into nothingness. From those of middling understanding down to the crawling insects, none fail to esteem themselves and disparage others, to find themselves beautiful and others ugly. Yet this is merely clarity about oneself and obscurity about others. As for those of profound penetration and merging insight, they illuminate the world through the world itself. If the world says, “I am not,” then they reveal that nothing in the world is not; if the world says, “That is,” then they reveal that nothing in the world is so. Without “is” and without “is not,” all blends into one—thus they ride change and follow transformation, encountering things without fear.

*Exegesis*: One of profound penetration and vast vision sees the two poles and the myriad things as a single finger or horse. Thus, he forgets himself and follows things, perfectly attuned to all beings. Yet those who see sameness see sameness, and those who see difference see difference. The ultimate discussion of the wondrous realm transcends both sameness and difference.

*Annotation*: What is fitting arises from what is not fitting. Without beauty and without ugliness, nothing is unfitting. Without anything unfitting, one forgets what is fitting.
*Exegesis*: The ears and eyes deem fitting what pertains to sounds and sights. Yet ordinary sentiments make distinctions, becoming mired in sounds and sights, thus producing what is fitting and unfitting, permissible and impermissible. But Wang Tai, merging all things and equating life and death, how could he harbor judgments of beauty and ugliness within the senses and their objects?

*Annotation*: Utterly forgetting what is fitting, nothing is not entrusted. Entrusting all without exception, nothing is unattained; nothing unattained, nothing is not harmonious. Thus, the mind wanders freely between virtue and the Dao, unbounded and unfettered, nothing not fitting, nothing not fittingly so.
*Exegesis*: Having merged all things and forgotten what the ears and eyes deem fitting, he roams the realm of virtue and the Dao, freely entrusting himself to the ultimate境.

*Annotation*: Embracing the wondrous mind of the utmost subtlety, nothing is not the same. Nothing not the same, then in life and death, transformation and change, nowhere is not oneself. Thus, life is the time of my gathering; death is my following. Time is my assembly; following is my dispersal. Though assembly and dispersal differ, both are mine—life is merely my moment, never a gain; death is also myself, never a loss. In the change of life and death, all is one. Having witnessed this oneness, one sheds all attachments, merges self and other, treats life and death as waking and dreaming, the body as a temporary lodging. Departing life is like casting off sandals; severing a foot is like discarding dirt—I have never seen this ensnare the mind.
*Exegesis*: *Wu shi* (物视), “seeing things,” means to regard things. Wang Tai equates life and death, levels self and other. Life is my time, yet he sees no gain; death is my following, yet he sees no loss. Regarding the myriad things, he merges them into one. Thus, though maimed of foot, he sees it as discarding dirt.

Common Season said: "He cultivates himself through his knowledge, attaining his mind through his mind. Having attained his constant mind, why should things gather most to him?"

*Exegesis*:
*[1] Note*: This suspects Wang Tai has not yet forgotten knowledge to preserve himself.
*Subcommentary*: "He" refers to Wang Tai. It means Wang Tai cultivates goodness and refines himself, yet still employs mind and knowledge. This suspects he has not yet forgotten knowledge to entrust himself to solitude.

*[2] Note*: This suspects he has not yet relinquished mind to attain himself.
*Subcommentary*: This suspects Wang Tai cannot forget concerns to entrust himself to attainment, still using mind to attain mind. Now, attaining the mind means no thought, no deliberation, forgetting knowledge, forgetting awareness—like dead ashes or withered wood, utterly devoid of emotion. Placed within the square inch of the heart, it arises beyond sight and hearing, equal to the two poles’ covering and bearing, compliant with the three luminaries’ illumination. It mingles with dust and filth without disturbing its spirit, treads upon hardship and obstruction without offending its thoughts. This is not attainment as attainment, yet attainment lies in non-attainment—this is true attainment. If one attains it through the artifice of mind and knowledge, it is not genuine attainment.

*[3] Note*: Attaining the constant mind is level passage. This suspects he does not achieve level passage to encounter things, thus always making things come to him.
*Subcommentary*: "Most" means to gather. If one can achieve emptiness, forgetting, and level equanimity, attaining the true constant mind, one should certainly harmonize with light and conceal brilliance, no different from the common. How could one stand apart from things, causing the multitude to return to him!

◎ My late father remarked: Knowledge manifests externally, while the mind abides within; through knowledge one attains the mind, following the external to preserve the internal. The mind is the unceasing true mechanism; the constant mind is the unerring fundamental substance. Through the mind one attains the constant mind, embodying the Dao through realization.

*Shuowen* states: "最 (*zuì*) means to encroach and seize," akin to saying nothing can encroach upon it. Guo Xiang’s punctuation is erroneous.
◎ Qingfan’s note on *Shuowen*: " (*cuì*) means to accumulate, composed of □ (pronounced *mò dí*) and 取 (*qǔ*), with 取 also indicating pronunciation." Xu Kai explains: "In antiquity, the character for 'gathering things' was written as ." As people commonly see 最 but rarely , all instances of  in texts and transmissions are written as 最.

Confucius said: "People do not mirror themselves in flowing water but in still water. Only stillness can still the many stillnesses. Receiving its mandate from the earth, only the pine and cypress remain verdant through winter and summer; receiving its mandate from heaven, only Shun alone is upright. Fortunate to rectify his own life, he thereby rectifies the lives of all. The proof of preserving the beginning lies in the substance of fearlessness. A single brave warrior, boldly entering the nine armies—even one who seeks fame and can compel himself to such extremes—still behaves thus. How much more so one who governs heaven and earth, stores the myriad things, merely lodges within the six bodily forms, mirrors the ears and eyes, knows what knowledge knows, yet whose mind never perishes! He will choose a day to ascend to the celestial realm, and people will follow accordingly. How could he deign to make things his concern!"

【一】*Note*: The stillness of water that enables reflection is not stillness pursued for the sake of reflection. Thus, when Wang Tai gathered the multitude, the people naturally turned to him—how could he have drawn them to follow him!

*Subcommentary*: "Mirror" means to reflect. Still water allows reflection because it is clear; Wang Tai gathered the multitude because he was serene. Still water has no intention to reflect things, yet things mirror themselves in it; Wang Tai had no intent to attract followers, yet the people naturally flocked to him.

*Exegesis*: "鉴" is pronounced *jiàn* (ancient *zhàn* rhyme). "Flowing water" in Cui’s version is written as *mèi* water, which he notes may also be written as *liú*. ◎ Qingfan’s note: "Flowing water" contrasts with "still water" in the text. Cui’s version as *mèi* is incorrect. In clerical script, *liú* (流) is sometimes written as □ (see the *Posterior Stele of Shi Chen’s Sacrifice at the Confucian Temple*), resembling *mèi* (沬) in form, hence Cui’s error. The *Huainanzi*’s *Shuoshan* chapter states, "People do not mirror themselves in *mèi* rain," with Gao’s commentary: "*Mèi* rain may also be written as *liú* puddles." This further confirms *mèi* as a corruption of *liú*.

【二】*Note*: If one acts deliberately, one cannot abide in the stillness of the myriad things.

*Subcommentary*: "Only" means alone. Only stillness—water’s inherent tranquility—can still the many stillnesses, that is, cause things to pause and reflect. This is akin to Wang Tai’s empty forgetfulness and serene quiescence, enabling him to contain and still the multitude. By this power, he became the gathering point for all.

【三】*Note*: The pine and cypress uniquely receive the concentrated qi of nature, thus standing as the finest among trees—not through any deliberate effort.

*Subcommentary*: All grasses and trees rely on the fertile earth. Yet those endowed with firmness and vigor, remaining undiminished through the harsh winter, like the pine and cypress that preserve their verdure year-round, receive qi naturally, without contrivance. Wang Tai’s gathering of the multitude follows the same principle.

【四】*Note*: Those who uniquely receive the upright qi of nature are exceedingly rare. Among lower beings, only the pine and cypress; among higher beings, only the sage. Thus, all that is not upright comes to seek rectification. If all things were verdant, the pine and cypress would hold no distinction; if all people were upright, none would admire the great sage and turn to him.

*Subcommentary*: Humans, endowed with the three powers, receive their mandate from heaven, their forms round-headed and square-footed, their kinds innumerable. Yet one who embodies uprightness and true qi, like Yu Shun, is unique—not by effort, but by natural disposition. Wang Tai’s alignment with the Dao follows the same principle. Guo’s note, "Among lower beings, only the pine and cypress; among higher beings, only the sage," refers to the fact that human heads are above (and removing the head causes death), while tree heads are below (and removing the root causes death). Thus, humans are called "upper beings," trees "lower beings." Upper beings consume those beside them, and those beside consume the lower. Lower beings are grasses and trees; those beside are insects and beasts.

【五】*Note*: He was fortunate to rectify himself, not to rectify others by rectifying himself.

*Subcommentary*: Receiving qi from the supreme, he rectified the Dao of life—not by intention, but by fortunate adherence to nature. Having rectified himself, he could rectify others. Rectifying self and others, benefiting self and others, his conduct was complete within and without—this is the great sage. Yu Shun exemplified this, as did Wang Tai. Yet Shun received the abdication of others, thus serving as the model.

【六】*Note*: He does not abandon fame yet leaves nothing unaddressed.

*Subcommentary*: "Proof" means completion, verification. The Son of Heaven commands six armies; the feudal lords, three—hence "nine armies." There may be one man, endowed with brave and martial qi, preserving the mind that guards the good beginning, verifying the integrity that fulfills the end, harboring a fearless will within, displaying a valiant bearing without. He enters the nine armies to seek fame and position, yet can subdue his heart to pursue reputation, forgetting life and death. How much more so Wang Tai! The state of embodying the Dao is described below.

*Exegesis*: "保始之征" (*bǎo shǐ zhī zhēng*): Li explains, "Proof means completion; beginning and end can be preserved and completed."

《Nine Armies》: Cui (version corrected to Li) states: "The Son of Heaven commands six armies; the feudal lords, three—together they form nine armies." Jianwen explains: "Military texts speak of attacking the nine heavens and seizing the nine lands, hence the term 'nine armies.'" *Ziyao* reads *yao* (遥) as *yao* (一遥反).

【Seven】*Note*: Profoundly embodying all without exception.
*Subcommentary*: Governing the two poles is called "officiating Heaven and Earth"; embracing the cosmos is called "storing the ten thousand things." Even a brave warrior entering the army, seeking only fame and position, can disregard life and death, forgetting them entirely. How much more so one who officiates the two poles and unites the ten thousand things, seeing death as life—is this not fitting!

【Eight】*Note*: What is called a temporary lodging.
*Subcommentary*: *Yu* (寓) means "to lodge." The six limbs refer to the head, torso, and four limbs. Wang Tai regards the singular body as insubstantial, penetrating the reality of the ten thousand existences.
