Thus he mingles the dust and filth of the vulgar world while lodging spirit within form—merely a transient encounter, how could it be a binding attachment!
*Exegesis*: *Six Limbs*: Cui explains: "Hands, feet, head, and body."

【Nine】*Note*: Humans employ ears and eyes, yet he employs ears and eyes without needing ears and eyes.
*Subcommentary*: *Xiang* (象) means "to resemble." Harmonizing light and dust, he seems to employ ears and eyes, yet does not require them.

【Ten】*Note*: When knowledge moves with transformation, there is nowhere it does not profoundly merge—this is the oneness of knowledge. When the heart flows with life and death, there is no time it is not alive—this is the heart that has never died.
*Subcommentary*: *One knowledge* is wisdom. *What is known* is the realm. The wisdom that knows illuminates the realm it knows; realm and wisdom merge profoundly, with no discrepancy between them. Thus knowledge and non-knowledge become one. Though he follows transformations in form and principle, the heart has never perceived death—how could there be room for stagnation in between!

【Eleven】*Note*: It is merely a matter of not missing the convergence; this person makes no choices, following Heaven’s course and acting in due time. Thus those who borrow and imitate are ranked highest by this standard.
*Subcommentary*: That Wang Tai—does he select auspicious days to ascend the mysterious Dao? Not at all; he simply abides in emptiness and forgetfulness, merging with it. The perfected person is without intention, like still water reflecting—yet the world’s borrowed and false men follow him by this means.
*Exegesis*: *Bi qie* (彼且) is read as written; Xu reads *ziyu* (子余反), and the same below. *Jiaren* (假人): Gu reads *guya* (古雅反), meaning "to borrow"; Xu reads *xia* (遐), connecting it to the previous phrase, with "person" belonging to the next clause.
◎Qingfan’s note: *Dengjia* (登假) is equivalent to *dengge* (登格). *Jia* and *ge* were interchangeable in antiquity. The *Book of Songs* writes *zouge* (奏格) or *zoujia* (奏假) as evidence. The *Erya* states: *Ge* (格), *zhi* (陟), *deng* (登), and *sheng* (升) all mean "to ascend." Though it says *deng* (登) and then *ge* (格), ancient texts often used reduplicative language. The *Chu Ci*’s *Li Sao* reads *zhi sheng huang zhi he xi* (陟升皇之赫戏兮), where *zhi* (陟) also means "to ascend."

【Twelve】*Note*: His tranquility and indifference preserve his wholeness.
*Subcommentary*: Only that Wang Tai, profoundly merging with the true and uniting with the Dao—illusory things naturally come to him, yet how could he ever take them as his own concern!

*Collation Notes*:
(1) *Quemiu* cites the Zhang Junfang edition, where *ye* (也) below includes *zheng* (正).
(2) Yu Yue notes that the following *zai* (在) is a corruption of *zheng* (正).
(3) *Quemiu* cites the Zhang Junfang edition, where this sentence reads: "Yao and Shun alone are correct, [correct] at the head of the ten thousand things."
(4) The Tang manuscript writes *guan* (官) as *gong* (宫).
(5) The Shide Hall edition omits *ye* (耶).
(6) Zhao Jianyi’s edition writes *zhong* (锺) as *zhong* (种).
(7) The character *Li* (李) is amended following the Shide Hall edition.

Shentu Jia, an amputee, studied under Bohun Wuren alongside Zichan of Zheng. Zichan said to Shentu Jia: "If I leave first, you stay; if you leave first, I stay." The next day, they again sat together in the same hall on the same mat. Zichan said to Shentu Jia: "If I leave first, you stay; if you leave first, I stay. Now I am about to leave—can you stay, or not? Moreover, when you see the one in power, you do not yield—do you consider yourself equal to the one in power?"

【One】*Subcommentary*: His surname was Shentu, given name Jia, a worthy man of Zheng and an amputee. His surname was Gongsun, given name Qiao, style Zichan, a worthy minister of Zheng. Bohun Wuren was the honorific title of their teacher. *Bo* (伯) means "elder"; *hun* (昏), "obscure." His virtue stood as the elder of things, concealing his light as if obscure, utterly forgetting self and others—hence the name Bohun Wuren. Zichan and Shentu Jia both studied the mysterious Dao; though their paths diverged, they shared the same teacher. Thus these three are cited to illustrate the fullness of virtue.
*Exegesis*: *Shentu Jia*: Li explains: "Shentu is the clan; Jia, the given name."

The *Miscellaneous Chapters* renders this as "Màorén."

【Two】*Annotation*: He felt shame at walking alongside an amputee.
*Subcommentary*: Zichan, holding power at the center of the path, enjoyed glory, wealth, and nobility; Shentu Jia, his form maimed and incomplete, had lost all appearance of dignity. Though Zichan had studied under Bohun Wuren, he had not yet forgotten or relinquished such concerns, still clinging to honor and disgrace. Ashamed to be seen with one whose form was impaired, he took precautions in advance, ensuring they would not walk side by side.
*Exegesis*: *Amputee*: Pronounced *yuè*; also *wǔguā* in some readings.

【Three】*Annotation*: He questioned him directly, wishing to ensure they would not walk together.
*Subcommentary*: Zichan retained a sense of honor and disgrace, while Shentu had forgotten all distinctions of noble and base. Though words had been spoken earlier, Zichan had paid them no heed, so they still shared the same hall when at rest and the same seat when seated. Seeing this, Gongsun (Zichan) questioned him directly.

【Four】*Annotation*: He always considered his own position in government superior, so he simply said, "Are you equal to one in power?"—thus revealing his lack of deference.
*Subcommentary*: To *violate* is to avoid. Their paths of advancement differed, and their stations of noble and base were not the same. I hold power in court and am thus exalted and great; you are lowly, your form impaired—you ought to show me respect. Yet instead of yielding, you seek to place yourself on equal footing.
*Collation*: The Zhao Jianyi edition includes the character *yě* (也) after *xùn* (逊).
Shentu Jia said: "In the master’s gate, is it truly the case that one in power is held in such regard? Do you delight in your own power and thus place others behind you? I have heard it said: ‘When a mirror is bright, dust does not settle; if dust settles, it is no longer bright. To dwell long with the worthy is to be without fault.’ Now, what you take as greatest is the master—yet you still speak in this way. Is this not a fault?"

【One】*Annotation*: This concerns the dwelling of virtue, not the reckoning of rank.
*Subcommentary*: The *master* is Bohun Wuren. The master’s gate of the Dao is profoundly enlightened to the myriad wonders, blending honor and disgrace, equalizing life and death. Is it certain that one who takes pride in holding power must be like this?
*Exegesis*: *Dwelling*: Pronounced *chǔ* (昌慮反).

【Two】*Annotation*: He mocked his pride in his position and desire to place himself before others.
*Subcommentary*: You still take pleasure in glory and boast of your governance, pushing others behind while seeking to place yourself first. With such intentions, how can you be said to study the Dao?
*Exegesis*: *Delight*: Pronounced *yuè*; the annotation reads the same.

【Three】*Annotation*: To serve a clear master yet still not shed one’s mean and stingy heart—this is truly a fault.
*Subcommentary*: *Mirror* means reflection. When a mirror is bright, dust and grime do not settle; if they settle, it is not a bright reflection. Likewise, dwelling long with a worthy person leaves no room for fault; if fault remains, that person is not truly wise. Now what you value as weighty and great is the master’s Dao. Yet the master’s Dao consists in withdrawing the self and emptying the mind, while you remain self-important, deeply at odds with its wondrous essence. To speak as you do—is this not a fault?

Zichan said: “Since you are already thus【One】, you still contend with Yao in goodness. Do you not reckon your virtue【Two】sufficient to reflect upon yourself?”
【One】*Annotation*: Thus means your form is impaired.
【Two】*Annotation*: This means you do not examine yourself but instead belittle those in office, wishing to stand alongside the virtuous. Weighing your virtue, it is not enough to remedy the fault of your impaired form.
*Subcommentary*: *Reflect* means to return. Shentu Jia’s form is impaired as it is, yet he does not know himself. Instead, he seeks to run abreast with me—this is truly contending with Yao in goodness. Though you possess virtue, how can it suffice in words? Even if virtue were used to mend impairment, it would not yet be restored.
*Exegesis*: *Contend in goodness*: Read as written.

*Collation*: (One) The missing character in the corrupted text is not present in the Li or Zhang editions.

Shentu Jia said: “Those who describe their faults to claim they should not have perished are many【One】; those who do not describe their faults yet should not have remained are few【Two】. Knowing there is nothing to be done and accepting it as fate—only those with virtue can do this【Three】. To wander within Yi’s drawn bow.”

The center is the central ground; yet whether one hits it or not is a matter of fate.【Four】 People who mock my lack of wholeness with their own completeness have been many【Five】—I would flare up in anger at them【Six】. But when I came to the Master’s place, I would cast off that anger and return to myself【Seven】. Did I not know that the Master cleansed me with goodness【Eight】? For nineteen years I have wandered with you, Master, yet you have never once treated me as one who is maimed【Nine】. Now you wander with me within the bounds of form, yet you seek me beyond form—is this not an error【Ten】?”

【One】*Annotation*: Many describe their own faults to claim they should not have perished.
【Two】*Annotation*: Few remain silent about their faults, accepting that they should not have survived.
*Exegesis*: Those who parade their own merits, shifting blame to others and insisting they bear no fault—such people are many in the world. Those who do not display their faults, taking blame upon themselves and accepting that they should not live—such people are few. Zheng Zichan’s extravagance and self-regard were of this kind.
【Three】*Exegesis*: *If* means to yield. Though one’s form is inherently impaired by fate, and though one may possess knowledge and plans, there is nothing to be done—one can only accept and yield to it, and all one’s actions will then be fitting. Without great virtue, who could do this?
*Exegesis*: *Knowing there is nothing to be done* is read as written, or alternatively as *wisdom*.
【Four】*Annotation*: Yi was an ancient master archer. The range of his bow and arrows was called *gòu zhōng* (the drawn bow’s reach). When profit and harm contend, the world is all Yi—those who do not forget themselves, who forget knowledge and flow with things, all wander within Yi’s drawn bow. Even Zhang Yi’s outward striving or Shan Bao’s seclusion could not escape the central ground; whether one hits or misses the mark depends solely on fate. Yet the petty-minded each encounter their own circumstances, unaware that fate is simply as it is. Those who escape the harm of bow and arrow consider themselves skillful, delighting in their own cleverness. When they do not escape, they resent their own folly, their wills wounded and spirits humiliated—such people have not yet grasped the nature of fate. My life is not something I myself produce; thus, within a single lifetime, across a hundred years, in all my sitting and rising, walking and stopping, moving and resting, inclinations and aversions, emotions and nature, knowledge and abilities—all that I possess, all that I lack, all that I do, all that I encounter—none of it is truly me. It is simply the principle of things as they are. To arbitrarily generate joy or sorrow within this is to go against nature and lose oneself.
【Five】*Exegesis*: Yi was a skilled archer in the time of Yao. Wherever his arrows reached was called *gòu zhōng*. His arrows never missed; within the drawn bow’s reach, all was inevitably harmed—whether bird or beast, few escaped. Those who did were merely spared by fate; escape or failure to escape had nothing to do with skill. Those who do not forget their form or abandon their knowledge all wander within Yi’s drawn bow. Thus, Shentu Jia’s maimed foot was suddenly struck by one of Yi’s arrows, while Zichan’s whole body happened to escape the central ground. Since this was not a matter of human effort, there is no cause for self-satisfaction.
*Exegesis*: *Yi* is pronounced *yì*; Xu reads it as *hú xì*. A skilled archer; the Xia dynasty had one. Another says: the usurper of the Xia throne. *Gòu* is pronounced *gòu*, meaning to draw a bow. ◎My late father remarks: The *Yùpiān* states: *gòu* means to draw a bow or crossbow. The *Book of Han*, in the biography of Zhou Yafu, says: *gòu* bows and crossbows were drawn to full tension. To wander within Yi’s drawn bow is to encounter danger everywhere. Yet there is always a central ground; to position oneself as not hitting the mark is to place oneself on the bowstring or arrow shaft, where one may be struck by the very tension. In wandering, whether one hits or misses is merely a matter of chance—there is nothing to be done, and accepting it is fate. This speaks to the maimed foot not being one’s fault. *Central* is read as written. *Center* is pronounced *yú liáng*; the old reading was *yú cāng*. Guo says: the range of bow and arrow is called *gòu zhōng*. *Central ground* is pronounced *dīng zhòng*; below, *not hitting the mark* and the annotation’s *central ground*, *hitting or not hitting the mark*, are the same. *Shan Bao* is pronounced *shàn*.
【Five】*Annotation*: All this stems from not knowing fate and thus indulging in such mockery.
【Six】*Annotation*: Seeing their ignorance of fate, he grew angry—this too was ignorance of fate.
*Exegesis*: *Fúrán* expresses a violent, rebellious heart. Not knowing the mandate of heaven, people recklessly judge wholeness and impairment, praising their own intact forms while deriding the maimed. Such people are many in the world. Enraged by their ignorance, he flared up in anger—this too was ignorance of fate.
*Exegesis*: *Fúrán* is pronounced *fúfú*.
【Seven】*Annotation*: Seeing the perfected person’s knowledge of fate and forgetting of form, he cast off his former anger and returned to his true state.
*Exegesis*: When he went to Bohun’s place and received the teaching of wordlessness, he abandoned his former anger and returned to his original nature.
【Eight】*Annotation*: Did he not know that the Master cleansed him with the good Dao? Or was he able to reflect on himself? This was to forget his form and leave behind his burdens.
*Exegesis*: Having arrived at the Master’s gate and entered the empty chamber, he cast off his anger and returned to his usual self. Did he not know that the Master washed his heart with the water of goodness? Or was it his own nature that enabled him to reflect? In seeking the cause, he could not determine its source. This was to forget the heart of learning and leave behind its entanglements.
【Nine】*Annotation*: Because he forgot his form.

*Exegesis*: I wandered with Bohun in the Dao and virtue, thus able to exhaust the subtle essentials of yin and yang and reach the ultimate refinement of the profound principle. Having abandoned knowledge and forgotten form, how could I be aware of my own mutilation!

*Explication*: The *Zhiwu Jie* edition also writes 兀 as 兀; both are acceptable.

【Ten】*Annotation*: The bodily form is external; one’s virtue resides within. Now you wander with me in virtue, not in bodily form—yet you seek my external adornments. Is this not mistaken!

*Exegesis*: As Guo’s annotation states: “The bodily form is external; one’s virtue resides within. Now you wander with me in virtue, not in bodily form—yet you seek my external adornments. Is this not mistaken!” This note requires no further explanation.

*Explication*: 《子索》 appears in one hundred variant readings in the *Collected Commentaries*. The annotation is the same.

*Collation*:
(1) The *Shi De Tang* edition writes 众.
(2) The *Quewu* edition, citing Zhang Junfang’s text, adds “吾之自寤邪” after 邪.
(3) The *Shi De Tang* edition omits 矣.
(4) The Zhao Jianyi edition adds 我 after 知.
(5) The Zhao edition omits 也.
(6) The *Shi De Tang* edition omits 矣.
(7) The *Shi De Tang* edition writes 遗 as 遣 and omits 矣.
(8) 能 is supplied based on the annotation.
(9) The present edition writes 兀.
(10) 好 is amended based on the annotation.

Zichan abruptly changed his expression and altered his demeanor, saying, “Sir, you need not elaborate further!”

*Annotation*: Having awakened, he found further words superfluous.

*Exegesis*: 蹴然 describes a look of startled shame. Zichan had not yet forgotten attachments or relinquished desires, often placing himself before others. Once reproached, he was struck with alarm, altering his haughty bearing to an ugly countenance. Realizing his error, he saw no need for further explanation.

*Explication*: 《蹴》 is read in six variant pronunciations. 《乃称》 is read as written, meaning “to raise” or, alternatively, as *cheng* (尺证反).

There was in Lu a mutilated man, Shushan Wuzhi, who came to see Confucius on his heels.

Confucius said, “You were not careful, and already suffered such misfortune. Though you come now, what can be done?”

Shushan Wuzhi, the mutilated man, replied, “I merely failed to recognize priorities and recklessly used my body—thus I lost my foot. Yet now I come, for what is more honorable than the foot still remains. Therefore, I strive to preserve it whole. Heaven covers all without exception; Earth bears all without omission. I took you, Master, for Heaven and Earth—how could I have known you would be thus?”

*Annotation*: 踵 means "frequently."

*Exegesis*: Shushan is his courtesy name. 踵 means "frequently." Though maimed, this man of Lu retained his desire to learn, coming repeatedly to seek a teacher and inquire after the Dao. Lacking toes, he was thus named.

*Explication*: 《叔山无趾》 is read as *zhi* (止). Li [Yun] says: Shushan is his surname, Wuzhi his courtesy name. ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: "courtesy name" is likely an error for "surname." 《踵》 is read *zhong* (朱勇反). Xiang and Guo say: "frequently." Cui says: lacking toes, he walked on his heels. 《见》 is read *xian* (贤遍反).

*Exegesis*: "You were not careful in cultivating yourself, transgressed the law, and previously suffered punishment—enduring hardship and calamity, your body maimed to this degree. Now you come seeking further instruction—what can be done?"

*Explication*: 《子不谨前》 is a complete sentence. Alternatively, the sentence may end at *jin* (谨).

*Annotation*: One who lives naturally allows principle to unfold of itself. Simply doing nothing and letting life take its course—this is valuing the body and recognizing priorities. But to forget one’s natural life, to be cautious and self-important—this is recklessly using the body without recognizing priorities. Thus the five organs war within, and hands and feet are maimed without.

*Annotation*: Losing one foot is not enough to diminish one’s virtue. Clearly, the body is but a temporary lodging.

*Annotation*: Abandoning self-importance and caution, letting life unfold naturally—this is striving to preserve it whole.

*Exegesis*: Wuzhi was deferential in conduct, valuing virtue and slighting the body. He sought only to borrow fame, not knowing to prioritize the Dao of preserving life whole. Thus he transgressed the law and suffered mutilation. Though his form was damaged, his virtue remained—so he came repeatedly, striving to preserve his virtue whole. Comparing virtue to the body, he said what was more honorable than the foot still remained. *Cun* (存) means "to remain."

*Explication*: 《去其》 is read *qu* (羌吕反).

*Annotation*: Heaven does not act for the sake of covering, yet it always covers; Earth does not act for the sake of bearing, yet it always bears. If Heaven and Earth acted for the sake of covering and bearing, they would rest at times. If a boat could sink yet act to keep a man afloat, it would sink at times. Thus, when things act for a purpose, they cannot fully sustain life.

*Explication*: 《不为》 is read *wei* (于伪反). The same applies to *bu wei* (不为) and *er wei* (而为) below.

*Annotation*: To reproach him for not being careful is to fall short of Heaven and Earth.

*Exegesis*: Heaven and Earth nurture all, covering and bearing without partiality. The sage’s virtue aligns with these two forces—surely he should be universally inclusive, not rejecting the maimed. How could the Master’s heart of saving all be thus? Confucius said, “I am indeed crude.”

*Exegesis*: What Confucius spoke of were but the traces of the sages. Wuzhi sought to learn the Dao of preserving life whole. Answering a shallow question with depth revealed his crudeness.

Wuzhi departed. Confucius said, “Disciples, take heed! Though Wuzhi is mutilated, he still strives to learn and make amends for past wrongs. How much more should one of whole virtue do so!”

*Annotation*: Hearing what he heard and departing, he preserved his non-action.

*Exegesis*: *Fuzi* (夫子) refers to Wuzhi. *Hu* (胡) means "why." Confucius, feeling his own crudeness and much ashamed, humbled himself to Wuzhi, inviting him in to expound what he had heard of the inner Dao. Yet after long dwelling in a thatched hut and offering straw dogs repeatedly, Wuzhi, disliking the words, departed in silence.

*Annotation*: One of whole virtue forgets life upon birth.

*Exegesis*: *Mian* (勉) means "to encourage."

Though Wuzhi is maimed and crippled, he yet preserves life whole in truth, mending his losses and repenting his past conduct. How much more should the worthy and the gentleman, whose form and virtue are both complete, forget life upon birth and let virtue fill them within! Such is the model for disciples to emulate.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Qianxing* (前行) is read *meng* in the lower tone.

Wuzhi said to Lao Dan, “Is Confucius yet far from the perfected person? Why does he so deferentially take you as his teacher? He seeks to make his name known through strange and wondrous marvels, unaware that the perfected person regards these as his own fetters.”

*Annotation*: He found it strange that Confucius should again study under Lao Dan.
*Exegesis*: *Binbin* (宾宾) describes a reverent and diligent demeanor. The man of profound virtue exhausts principle and fathoms the subtleties, forgetting words and abandoning learning, following his nature and born with knowledge. Yet Confucius clings to written texts and adheres to the traces of the sages, deferentially and diligently inquiring of Lao Dan about ritual. By your measure, he is not yet like the perfected person—why then does he study under you?

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Yu Lao* (语老) is read *yuju* in the falling tone. *Binbin* (宾宾): Sima Biao says it means “a reverent appearance.” Zhang Yi says it means “to esteem the worthy.” Cui Zhuan says it means “to show partiality.”

**Chapter Six: The Great and Venerable Teacher**
*Annotation*: Though heaven and earth are vast and the myriad things abundant, what they honor and take as their teacher is the non-hearted.
*Phonetic Gloss*: *Da zongshi* (大宗师): Cui Zhuan says, “To abandon form and forget life is to take this as the great and venerable teaching.”

One who knows what Heaven does and what man does has reached the utmost. One who knows what Heaven does is born of Heaven; one who knows what man does uses what his knowledge knows to nourish what his knowledge does not know, thus fulfilling his Heaven-appointed years without dying prematurely—this is the fullness of knowledge.

*Annotation*: One who knows what Heaven and man do knows that both are natural. Thus he inwardly releases his person and outwardly darkens himself to things, becoming one with the mysterious multitude, letting things take their course so that nothing is left undone.
*Exegesis*: *Tian* (天) refers to spontaneity. *Zhi* (至) means “to reach the ultimate.” What Heaven does includes the three luminaries’ waxing and waning, the four seasons’ birth and killing, the unfolding and rolling up of wind and clouds, and the cold and warmth of thunder and rain. What man does includes grasping with the hands and walking with the feet, seeing with the eyes and hearing with the ears, knowing skill and clumsiness, and all that he enacts. Knowing what Heaven does, one sees that all is self-so, not the result of cultivation or effort, nor dependent on knowledge or power. Thus he inwardly releases his person and outwardly darkens himself to things, gazing upon the vastness with equanimity, becoming one with the mysterious multitude, exhausting principle and fulfilling his nature—hence he is called “utmost.”

*Annotation*: *Tian* (天) refers to spontaneity. The doer cannot do, and what is done is self-done; the knower cannot know, and what is known is self-known. Self-known is not known, and not-knowing is where knowledge arises; self-done is not done, and not-doing is where doing arises. Doing arises from not-doing, so not-doing is the master; knowledge arises from not-knowing, so not-knowing is the origin. Thus the true person abandons knowledge yet knows, does not act yet acts, is born spontaneously, attains through sitting in forgetfulness, so that knowledge is called “cut off” and doing is said to “depart.”
*Exegesis*: Clouds move and rain falls, rivers and mountains, valleys and streams—these are not the work of man but are born of Heaven. Knowing what is known, all is spontaneous. This explains the earlier “knowing what Heaven does.”
*Phonetic Gloss*: *Tian er sheng* (天而生): Xiang Xiu and Cui Zhuan read it as *shi er sheng* (失而生). *Zhi cheng* (知称) is read *chizheng* in the falling tone.

*Annotation*: Man’s life is a form of seven feet, yet the Five Constants are all present, so even this small body encompasses Heaven and Earth to sustain it. Thus Heaven and Earth and the myriad things, all that exists, cannot be without one another for a single day. If one thing is lacking, the living have no means to live; if one principle is not fulfilled, one’s Heaven-appointed years have no way to be completed. Yet what the body possesses, knowledge may or may not know; what principle contains, action may or may not enact. Thus what knowledge knows is little, while what the body possesses is much; what action does is small, while what principle contains is vast. Those above cannot measure it and seek to make it complete. What man knows need not be the same, and what he does must not differ—difference breeds artifice, and where artifice is complete, the true is never preserved. Some love knowledge and tirelessly exhaust their limbs, but what they love is no more than a branch, and the root is harmed along with it—this is using what they know to harm what they do not know. As for the fullness of knowledge, one who knows what man does knows its limits, so he acts without forcing; one who knows what man knows knows its bounds, so he uses it without excess. Thus he does not use the boundless to exhaust himself, and within his single body, what he knows and what he does not know meet in darkness and are both preserved—this is using what he knows to nourish what he does not know.
*Exegesis*: What man does refers to the functions of his four limbs and hundred parts. What knowledge knows refers to the eye knowing colors, taking color as what is known. What knowledge does not know refers to the eye knowing colors but not knowing sounds, taking sound as what is not known. Yet the eye sees for the hands and feet, the feet walk for the ears and nose—though they do not intentionally aid one another, their assistance is accomplished. Thus the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, four limbs, and hundred parts serve one another, each with its own office.

The brightness and darkness of the heart, too, have their limits—using what lies within its proper bounds, it never forces knowledge. Thus he employs what his knowledge knows to nourish what his knowledge does not know, and so fulfills his Heaven-appointed years without untimely demise. One who can do this may be called one whose knowledge is most excellent.

*Exegesis*: 《不丧》*xī làng* (息浪), same below. 《或好》*hū bào* (呼报), same below. 《不强》*qí liǎng* (其两).

Yet there is still affliction. For knowledge depends on something else to be fitting, and what it depends on is inherently unstable. How can we be certain that what I call Heaven is not truly man, or that what I call man is not truly Heaven?

*Annotation*: Though knowledge may be excellent, it does not compare to forgetting knowledge and entrusting oneself to Heaven, which is free from affliction.
*Exegesis*: Though knowledge may be most excellent, it still entails affliction—it does not compare to forgetting knowledge and following the solitary Dao.
*Annotation*: Knowledge cannot be without "can" or "cannot," and so it must depend on something. But one who entrusts himself to Heaven and lives accordingly meets things as they come and is fitting.
*Annotation*: What knowledge depends on is inherently unstable.
*Exegesis*: Knowledge must confront its object; without an object, it cannot be fitting. Since objects arise and perish unpredictably, knowledge too is contingent and impermanent. Only when both object and knowledge are forgotten, when subject and object are both transcended, can one be without "can" or "cannot"—and only then is there no affliction.
*Annotation*: My life has its limits—this is Heaven. The heart desires to extend it—this is man. Yet what man calls "man" is in truth nothing other than Heaven. Heaven is the natural; all things are natural. Thus order and chaos, success and failure, encounter and non-encounter are not the work of man but all arise naturally.
*Exegesis*: Whether we look near to the body or far to things, the functioning of knowledge is nothing but the natural. Thus Heaven and man are ultimately one in principle. Call it Heaven, and it is man; call it man, and it is Heaven. How could the common run understand this truth? The "I" here refers to Zhuangzi himself—one who merges Heaven and man, blending self and other.
*Exegesis*: 《庸讵》*qí shù* (其庶). 《则治》*zhí lì* (直吏).

Only with the true person does true knowledge arise. What is the true person? The true persons of old did not resist the few, did not dominate success, and did not scheme for scholars. Such a one, when he errs, feels no regret; when he is fitting, feels no self-satisfaction. Such a one climbs high without trembling, enters water without getting wet, enters fire without feeling heat. This is how knowledge ascends to union with the Dao.

*Annotation*: Only with the true person does all knowledge in the world attain its truth and remain unconfused.
*Exegesis*: The sage, in perfect union with the true and the Dao, forgets self and abandons things. With such sagely virtue, true knowledge arises—thus the true person is one, free from affliction. The form of the true person is described below.
*Exegesis*: A hypothetical question to clarify the meaning.
*Annotation*: If he does not resist even the few, then what he desires will be many.
*Exegesis*: "Few" means scarcity. Drawing from the ancients to guide the present, he exalts the root and restrains the branches, empties his heart to follow things, and fully complies with the myriad beings. Even if what comes is meager, he never resists.
*Annotation*: He does not rely on his achievements to put himself before others.
*Exegesis*: Acting without reliance, growing without domination—how could he dominate success and seek to put himself before others?
*Annotation*: He lets his heart proceed directly, and scholars naturally gather—this is not achieved through scheming.
*Exegesis*: With emptiness and tranquility, scholars gather of themselves—this is not the result of deliberate scheming.
*Exegesis*: 《不谟》*mò hū* (没乎).
*Annotation*: He simply preserves what is fitting without erring—he does not weigh gain and loss in his heart.
*Exegesis*: When the time has passed, he feels no regret; when his lot is fitting, he does not take it as a personal achievement.
*Exegesis*: *Yú Yuē* says: "To err" means to make a mistake in affairs. "To be fitting" means to act appropriately. Ordinary people, when they err in affairs, feel regret; when they act appropriately, they take it as a personal achievement. The true person is not like this. Hence it is said: when he errs, he feels no regret; when he is fitting, he feels no self-satisfaction. The main text clearly speaks of "erring," but Guo Xiang’s annotation says "preserves what is fitting without erring," which is incorrect.
*Annotation*: When knowledge ascends to the Dao, it is as distant as this. The principle is inherently complete—it is not that he fears death. Thus when the true person walks on land, it is not to avoid getting wet; when he distances himself from fire, it is not to escape heat; when he does not err, it is not that he deliberately acts fittingly. Though he does not take heat as heat, he never rushes into fire; though he does not take wetness as wetness, he never steps into water; though he does not take death as death, he never loses his life. Thus life—does it live itself by living? Achievement—does it achieve itself by achieving? One who entrusts himself to things and yet lacks nothing is a true person—how could he have fixed intentions toward what he encounters?
*Exegesis*: "Trembling" means fear; "wet" means damp; "ascends" means rises; "attains" means reaches.

The true person comprehends the non-duality of life and death, embodying the oneness of safety and peril—thus he enters water and fire without the slightest concern, ascends heights and treads perilous paths without the least alarm. The one of true knowing possesses this power, ascending to the profound Dao, and thus attains such mastery.

*Exegesis*:
- "Not trembling" (*buli*): pronounced *li*.
- "Not wet" (*buru*): *er zhu* (fanqie).
- "Ascends" (*dengjia*): *geng bai* (fanqie), meaning "to reach."
- "Distances from fire" (*yuanhuo*): *yu wan* (fanqie).
- "Fixed intentions" (*yougai*): *gu ai* (fanqie).

The true persons of antiquity:
- In sleep, they did not dream;
- In waking, they knew no sorrow;
- In eating, they found no savor;
- In breathing, their breath was deep and profound.

The true person’s breath reaches the heels, while the common person’s breath barely passes the throat. Those who are cramped and constrained—when they speak, their words choke in their throats like vomit. The deeper one’s cravings and desires, the shallower one’s celestial mechanism.

The *Exegesis* states: Dreams arise from deluded thoughts and wandering emotions. The true person, free from emotional entanglements and devoid of discursive thought, thus remains serene in sleep, undisturbed by dreams. Upon waking, they abide in constant contentment, untouched by sorrow.

*Phonetic Gloss*:
- "In waking" (*qi jue*): pronounced *gu xiao*.

*Annotation*:
3. "They found no savor": They ate merely to sustain life.

*Exegesis*:
Dwelling among the common folk, they partook of food without attachment to flavor, thus remaining unaware of its sweetness.

*Annotation*:
4. "Reaches the heels": The breath originates from the very root.

*Exegesis*:
The heel is the base of the foot. The true person’s mind and nature are harmonious and unhurried, their wisdom steady and still. Even their breathing is slow and measured, rising from the heels—this illustrates its depth and tranquility.

*Phonetic Gloss*:
- "Deep, deep" (*shen shen*): Li explains: the appearance of inner breathing.
◎ Jia Shifu says: To abide in the realm of no-breath, and thus draw breath deeply—calm and still, without egress or ingress, without coming or going—such that pent-up anger cannot bind, and deep desires cannot assail. The hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera all remain untouched by its circulation, and in retreat, it lodges in the heels, nourishing itself in the profound, vast, and boundless.
- "With the heels" (*yi zhong*): pronounced *zhang yong*.
Wang Muya says: The breath arises from the heels, pervading the entire body and penetrating deeply.

*Annotation*:
5. "Their qi is not smooth and flowing."

*Exegesis*:
*Yi* (嗌) means the throat; *wa* (哇) means vomiting. Ordinary people, their minds restless and competitive, speak and breathe only through the throat. Agitated in spirit and hurried in breath, they cannot attain deep stillness. Bent and constrained, their qi fails to harmonize, and their throats constantly feel as though choked with vomit.

*Phonetic Gloss*:
- "With the throat" (*yi hou*): Xiang explains: panting breath, regulated by the throat, caused by the pursuit of desires.
- "Their *yi*" (*qi yi*): pronounced *yi*. Guo pronounces it *e*, meaning the throat.
- "Like vomiting" (*ruo wa*): pronounced *huo wa* (fanqie), or *hu gua*, or *yujia* (fanqie). Cui reads it *yu jia* (fanqie), meaning "bound," as in qi obstructed in the throat. Simplified Text says: *wa* means vomiting.

*Annotation*:
6. "Deeply rooted in tranquility, they return to oneness and desirelessness."

*Exegesis*:
Those who indulge in sensory pleasures and are burdened by deep desires possess only shallow celestial mechanisms. Had their wisdom been profound and far-reaching, how could this be so?

*Phonetic Gloss*:
- "Their desires" (*qi shi*): pronounced *shi zhi*.

The true persons of antiquity:
- Did not rejoice in life, nor abhor death;
- Their departure brought no delight, their return no resistance;
- They came and went with effortless ease.
- They did not forget their origin, nor seek their end;
- They accepted what came and rejoiced in it, then forgot and returned to it—
This is called not using the mind to abandon the Dao, nor using human effort to assist Heaven.
This is called the true person.

*Annotation*:
1. "They merged with transformation itself."

*Exegesis*:
Qi gathers to form life, and life is my present state; qi disperses in death, and death is my natural course. Having merged with transformation, they harbored no joy or aversion.

*Phonetic Gloss*:
- "Rejoice in life" (*yue sheng*): pronounced *yue*.
- "Abhor death" (*wu si*): pronounced *wu lu*.

*Annotation*:
2. "They remained composed and yielded to it."

*Exegesis*:
When the time came to be born, they felt no joy; when the time came to die, how could they resist or avoid it?

*Phonetic Gloss*:
- "No delight" (*bu xin*): pronounced *xin*, or *qi*.
- "No resistance" (*bu ju*): also written as *ju*, pronounced *ju*.
Li explains: Delight in emergence leads to striving for life; resistance to entry leads to aversion to death.

*Annotation*:
3. "Entrusted to the supreme principle, they came and went without difficulty."

*Exegesis*:
*Xiaoran* (翛然) means unencumbered. Freely transformed, they roamed in accord with principle. Though they came and went in life and death, they harbored no attachment.

*Phonetic Gloss*:
- "Xiaoran" (*xiao ran*): pronounced *xiao*. Also written as *shu*. Xu pronounces it *shu*; Guo and Cui read it *jiu*. Xiang explains: *xiaoran* means naturally and effortlessly so. Guo and Cui say: the appearance of coming and going without difficulty. Sima explains: *shu* means swift. Li concurs.
◎ Lu Wenchao says: The old text mistakenly wrote *jiu* as *dong*; corrected here following the Song edition.

*Annotation*:
4. "They forgot both beginning and end in transformation—how could they merely forget life and still seek meaning in death?"

*Exegesis*:
Beginning means birth; end means death. Having transcended both birth and death, they were free from attachment. How could they merely forget life while still seeking meaning in death? They regarded beginning and end as equal, finding contentment in whatever they encountered.

*Phonetic Gloss*:
- "Still seek" (*you fu*): pronounced *fu you*. Same below.

*Annotation*:
5. "They did not question what they received, but met all with equanimity."

*Exegesis*:
They rejoiced in whatever they encountered.

*Annotation*:
6. "Their return was not guided by knowledge—this was the ultimate."

*Exegesis*:
They returned to the state before birth.

*Annotation*:
7. "Humans are born tranquil—this is Heaven’s nature. Moved by things, they stir—this is the desire of nature. When things ceaselessly move humans, and humans endlessly pursue desires, Heaven’s principle is extinguished. The true person knows that using the mind opposes the Dao, and assisting Heaven harms life, so they do not act thus."

*Exegesis*:
"This is called" refers to the preceding passage, summarizing its meaning. *Juan* (捐) means to abandon. The foregoing wisdom, which forgets life, can be said to discard the mind of acceptance and rejection, abandoning the empty and unobstructed Dao. It also does not employ human distinctions to augment Heaven’s natural endowment. Those who can do this are called true persons.

**Exegesis of Text**:
*Juan* (捐): Xu pronounces it with the *quan* (全) rhyme. Guo writes it as *yi* (揖), with the *ru* (入) rhyme. Cui says: "Some write it as *ji* (楫), the means by which a boat is rowed."
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: "*Yi* (揖) was formerly miswritten as *ji* (楫). Given that below it says 'some write it as *ji*,' here it should be *yi*."
◎ Yu Yue says: "The character *juan* (捐) is erroneous. The *Exegesis of Text* states: 'Guo writes it as *yi*, Cui says some write it as *ji*, the means by which a boat is rowed'—this meaning is even more incomprehensible. I suspect all are errors for *bei* (偝). *Bei* is the character *bei* (背, 'to turn one’s back'), hence Guo’s commentary says, 'The true person knows that using the mind turns one’s back on the Dao, and assisting Heaven harms life.' Thus, the version Guo relied upon originally wrote *bei*."
*Ze bei* (则背): Pronounced *pei* (佩).

**Collation**:
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition writes *shou* (受) as *ai* (爱).
(2) "Not using the mind to *juan* (捐) the Dao" should be "not using the mind to *sun* (损) the Dao." *Sun* (损, 'to diminish')—in the present edition, the character is damaged and mistakenly written as *juan* (捐). The *Suoyin* commentary to the *Records of the Grand Historian*, in the "Biography of Jia Yi," correctly cites this passage as *sun* (损).

If this is so, then:
Their minds are steadfast,
Their demeanor serene,
Their brows broad and unadorned.
Chill as autumn,
Warm as spring,
Their joy and anger flow with the four seasons,
Harmonizing with things as is fitting, yet none know their limit.

**Annotation**:
1. "Their minds are steadfast": Where they dwell, they find peace as their resolve.
**Exegesis**: If, as previously stated, one does not *sun* (损) the Dao with the mind, this is to harbor resolve and strength, enabling such a state. Thus, the *Laozi* says, "Those who act with strength possess resolve."
◎ Jia Shifu says: Guo Xiang’s commentary, "Where they dwell, they find peace as their resolve," should read "their minds are steadfast." The *Shuowen* states: "Resolve (*zhi*, 志) is that toward which the heart (*xin*, 心) directs itself." The *Book of Documents* says, "Like archery, it has its aim"—Kong’s commentary explains: "As in archery, which has its aim, the mind directs itself toward hitting the mark." In Buddhist texts, the nature and characteristics are thus and unchanging, eternally abiding—this is what is meant by "their minds are steadfast."
◎ Qingfan notes: The *Shuowen* does not contain a seal script for *zhi* (志); the citation likely comes from the *Zilin* or other character dictionaries.
**Exegesis of Text**: "Their minds are steadfast" should be "their minds forget." *Zhi* (志) is a graphical error for *wang* (忘).

2. "Their demeanor serene": Though they act, they do not disrupt tranquility.
**Exegesis of Text**: *Rong* (容) is also written as *ji* (寂). Cui’s edition writes it as *jia* (家). Lu Wenchang notes: "The old edition mistakenly wrote *jia* (家); now corrected. See the preceding discussion. The present text writes it as *ji* (寂)."

3. "Their brows broad and unadorned": *Kui* (頯) describes the appearance of great simplicity.
**Exegesis**: *Sang* (颡) means the forehead. *Kui* (頯) describes great simplicity. When the true person descends into the world, their vital essence stands apart from the ordinary. Not only is their wisdom bright and empty, their resolve vast and universal—their bearing is also refined and elegant, their appearance dignified and solemn. The "sun-moon angles" (of physiognomy) belong to this category.
**Exegesis of Text**: *Qi sang* (其颡): Cui pronounces it *xidang* (息党). Cui says: "It means *tu* (突)." *Kui* (頯): Xu pronounces it with the *qugui* (去轨) rhyme; Guo with the *kudui* (苦对) rhyme; Li pronounces it *qiu* (仇), also *kui* (逵), meaning "authority." Wang says: "Unadorned and plain." The *Xiang* edition writes it as *kuang* (□), stating: "*Kuang* (□) describes great simplicity." The *Guangya* says: "*Kuang* (□) means great," pronounced *wuzui* (五罪).

4. "Chill as autumn": They do not kill things to display authority.
**Exegesis of Text**: *Qiran* (凄然): Pronounced *qixi* (七西).

5. "Warm as spring": They do not give life to things out of benevolence.
**Exegesis of Text**: *Nuanran* (暖然): Pronounced *xuan* (暄); Xu pronounces it *kuanwan* (况晚).

6. "Their joy and anger flow with the four seasons": Those who embody the Dao and harmonize with change share the warmth and severity of cold and heat, yet never act with intent. Nevertheless, they manifest warmth and severity, the rhythms of life and death—thus, their joy and anger are named by analogy.
**Exegesis**: The sage is without intent; responding to stimuli, they act accordingly, adapting kindness or severity to the moment. Like autumn’s descent of frost, they are not intentionally stern; like spring’s nurturing of life, they do not deliberately bestow kindness. Thus, the true person moves like thunder, stirs like wind, flourishes like trees in bloom—covering and supporting, they align with the two poles; their joy and anger flow with the four seasons.

7. "Harmonizing with things as is fitting, yet none know their limit": Without intent toward things, they do not disrupt what is fitting for them. When nothing is unfitting, none can fathom their limit.
**Exegesis**: The true person engages with the world, responding to stimuli and adapting to the times. In their interactions with things, they always act fittingly. Yet with a mind empty and compassionate, they constantly aid others, their measure equal to the great void—thus, none know their limit. Therefore, when the sage employs military force, they may destroy a state yet not lose the people’s hearts. Their beneficence extends to ten thousand generations, yet they do not act out of love for others. Thus, those who delight in connecting with things are not sages; those who show partiality are not benevolent; those who rely on timing are not worthy; those who do not communicate benefit and harm are not gentlemen; those who act for fame and lose themselves are not scholars; those who sacrifice themselves without authenticity do not serve others. Men like Hu Bujie, Wu Guang, Boyi, Shuqi, Jizi, Xuyu, Jita, and Shentu Di—these are those who serve others’ service, follow others’ paths, yet do not follow their own.
**Exegesis**:
(1) Yao attacked Congzhi, Yu attacked Youhu, Cheng Tang destroyed Xia, and King Wu of Zhou overthrew Yin—all acted in accord with Heaven above and human affairs below. Thus, they raised weapons to console the people and punish wrongdoing. Though they annihilated states, they did not lose the people’s favor.
**Exegesis of Text**: Cui says: "They destroy enemy states yet win their people’s hearts."
(2) They destroy where the people’s hearts desire destruction, thus not losing the people’s hearts. When the bright sun ascends the sky, the six directions are all illuminated—not out of love for others that it shines upon them.

Thus, when the sage dwells in the world, he warms it as the spring sun naturally harmonizes—those who receive his nurturing grace offer no thanks. He chills it as the autumn frost naturally descends—those who wither and fall bear no resentment.

**Exegesis**: Bestowing benefit and moisture, his deeds equal the spring sun—not merely for a moment, but extending through ten thousand generations. Yet like straw dogs or the common people, he harbors no partial affection.

**Annotation (3)**: The sage takes no delight; he simply does not obstruct, and things naturally flow through.

**Exegesis**: A mirror hung high reflects whatever comes before it—neither welcoming nor sending off, how could it have emotion? The great sage responds to the moment in the same way. Harmony without leading is not the same as delighting in connection. Thus, those who impose their intent upon things are not sages.

**Annotation (4)**: Perfect benevolence has no favorites; it abides by principle and sustains itself.

**Exegesis**: Perfect benevolence has no favorites—for if it had, it would not be perfect benevolence.

**Annotation (5)**: Those who observe the heavens are not as worthy as those who forget time and naturally align with it.

**Exegesis**: Those who track the waxing and waning of celestial signs and await the movements of heavenly timing—this is mere petty wisdom, not the mark of a truly worthy one!

**Annotation (6)**: Unable to unify the paths of right and wrong and pursue benefit while avoiding harm, one injures virtue and burdens what is fitting.

**Exegesis**: Those who cannot unite success and failure, equalize benefit and harm, and instead choose between glory and disgrace, clinging to right and wrong—such a one cannot even free himself, how can he lead others?

**Annotation (7)**: The true scholar forgets fame and finds self-fulfillment, so his name matches his reality, and good fortune responds to his person.

**Exegesis**: Those who distort their conduct to seek fame lose their true nature—these are mere followers of convention, not scholars of the Dao.

**Textual Note**: *Xing ming* (行名) is read with *ming* as in "fame." *Fu ying* (福应) is read as "fortune responds."

**Annotation (8)**: Losing one’s nature and distorting oneself to follow others—one is enslaved much, how can one enslave others?

**Exegesis**: Those who distort their conduct and lose their truth to seek fame—these are the ones who are driven and enslaved by others, how can they drive others?

**Annotation (9)**: All these abandon the self to imitate others, following them to the point of self-harm.

**Exegesis**: Hu Buxie, a worthy of old—some say a worthy of Yao’s time who refused Yao’s abdication and drowned himself in a river. Wu Guang, a man of the Yellow Emperor’s time, seven feet tall. Others say he lived in the Xia era, consumed herbs to nurture his nature, loved to play the zither, and when Tang offered him the throne, he refused and carried a stone to sink himself in Lu River. Boyi and Shuqi, the two sons of the Lord of Guzhu in Liaoxi, descendants of Shennong, of the Jiang clan. When their father died, they yielded the throne to each other and refused to succeed him. Hearing that the Earl of the West was virtuous, they went to observe him. When King Wen died and King Wu attacked Yin, Boyi and Shuqi grasped his horse’s bridle to remonstrate. King Wu did not heed them, so they hid on Mount Shouyang in Hedong, refusing to eat Yin’s grain, and starved to death. Jizi, a worthy minister of King Zhou of Yin, who remonstrated but was not heeded and was enslaved. Xuyu was Jizi’s name. Another explanation: he was Wu She’s son, named Yuan, styled Zixu, a minister of King Fuchai of Wu. He remonstrated faithfully but was not heeded, had his eyes gouged out, and died, his corpse sunk in the river. Jita, surnamed Ji, named Ta, a recluse of Tang’s time. Hearing that Tang had offered the throne to Wu Guang, he feared it would extend to him and drowned himself and his disciples in Kuanshui. Shentu Di heard of this and threw himself into the river. These several men all distorted their emotions and feigned conduct, stubbornly set on establishing their names, drifting beyond their proper bounds—thus they came to this. Starving themselves, drowning themselves, shortening their lifespans and cutting short their fates, their fragrant names and fine reputations were transmitted in the historical records. Yet these were merely driven by others—how could they drive others? Delighting the ears and eyes of the multitude, how could they truly satisfy their own natures?

**Textual Note**: *Hu Buxie*—Sima Biao says: an ancient worthy. *Wu Guang*—Huangfu Mi says: a man of the Yellow Emperor’s time, his ears seven inches long. *Boyi and Shuqi*—the two sons of the Lord of Guzhu. *Jizi Xuyu*—Sima Biao says: Xuyu was Jizi’s name, as recorded in the *Shizi*. Cui agrees. Another account: the *Shizi* says: Jizi Xuyu painted his body with lac to feign leprosy, let his hair loose, and pretended madness. Another says: the *Shizi* says: it was Bigan, and Xuyu was his name. ◎ Qing Fan’s note: the *Zhengyi* of the *Book of Documents*, the *Zhengyi* of the *Zuozhuan* for the fifteenth year of Duke Xi, and the *Zhengyi* of the *Lunyu* all cite Sima Biao: Jizi’s name was Xuyu, differing from the *Shiwen*. *Jita*—read *ta* as in "what."

Shentu Di was a man of the Yin dynasty who carried a stone and drowned himself in the Yellow River. Cui’s edition reads "Situ Di." *Jieshe*—pronounced *she*, as below. **Collation Notes**: (1) The Shide Tang edition omits the character *meng*. (2) The Shide Tang edition writes *xiao* as *xun*.

The true persons of old bore a demeanor lofty yet not crumbling,
as if insufficient yet not propped up;
expansive in their angularity yet not rigid,
stretched in their emptiness yet not florid.
How radiant, as if rejoicing!
How constrained, as if compelled!
How pressing, advancing my countenance,
how companionable, halting my power!
How stern, as if worldly!
How towering, as if beyond control!
How linked, as if fond of seclusion,
how muddled, forgetting their words!

With punishment as their body,
with ritual as their wings,
with knowledge as their timing,
with virtue as their guide.

With punishment as their body, they were supple in their execution;
with ritual as their wings, they moved through the world;
with knowledge as their timing, they acted only when unavoidable;
with virtue as their guide, they walked as far as those with feet could reach the hills—
yet others truly took them for diligent practitioners.

Thus, their liking was one,
their disliking was one.
Their oneness was one,
their not-oneness was one.
Their oneness joined them to Heaven’s company,
their not-oneness joined them to human company.
Heaven and humanity do not overcome one another—
this is called the true person.

**Annotations**:
[1] In harmony with things yet not cliquish.
[Commentary] *Demeanor*—traces. *Righteous*—fitting. Descending into the world’s traces, they followed what was fitting for things, emptying themselves to achieve balance, never partial or partisan.
◎ Yu Yue says: Guo’s annotation glosses *yi* as "fitting" and *peng* as "clique," imposing meaning on the text, which is mistaken. Here it describes their *demeanor*—how could it speak of their virtue? *Yi* should be read as *e* ("lofty"). *E* and *yi* both derive from the phonetic *wo*, so they are interchangeable. The *Tian Dao* chapter says *er zhuang yi ran* ("and their demeanor lofty"), where *yi ran* is *e ran* ("lofty"). *Peng* should be read as *beng* ("crumbling"). The *Yi Jing*’s *Fu* hexagram says *peng lai wu jiu* ("friends come without blame"), which the *Han Shu*’s *Wuxing Zhi* quotes as *□ lai wu jiu* ("□ comes without blame"), confirming this. *Their demeanor lofty yet not crumbling* means their bearing was towering and grand yet not collapsing. The *Guang Ya*’s *Shi Gu* defines *e* as "high," and its *Shi Xun* defines *e e* as "high." "High" and "grand" are close in meaning, so the *Wen Xuan*’s *Xijing Fu* says *shen shan e e* ("divine mountains towering"), and Xue Zong’s annotation reads: *e e* means "tall and grand." The *Tian Dao* chapter’s *yi ran* can be explained the same way. Guo, unaware that *yi* is a loan for *e*, glosses it as "fitting" here and as "a self-sustaining demeanor" there, both relying on the original character’s meaning, which is incorrect.

[2] Empty and without surplus, like insufficiency; yielding to all yet never failing to rise—like insufficiency yet not propped up.

[Commentary] Concealing brilliance and embracing emptiness, they alone seemed as if their spirit and wisdom were insufficient; moving in accord with their nature, floating freely in self-contentment—thus they had nothing to rely upon or receive.

[Phonetic Gloss] *Bù chéng*: read as written. Li [Yi] says: "to welcome." Also pronounced *zhěng*. *Bù shàng*: *shí zhǎng* (fanqie).

[3] [Annotation] Constantly roaming in solitude yet not rigidly adhering to it.
[Commentary] *Gū* means "alone"; *jiān* means "rigid." Wandering freely, unconstrained, at ease in self-possession—they roamed the realm of solitary transformation without clinging to it.
[Phonetic Gloss] *Yú hū*: read as written; also pronounced *yù*. [Xiang] Xiu says: "a hesitant appearance." ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: "同" should be an error for "向."
*Qí gū*: pronounced *gū*. Wang [Bi] says: "*Gū* means standing apart from the crowd." Cui [Zhuan] says: "*Gū* means angular." ◎ Yu Yue says: Guo’s annotation—"constantly roaming in solitude yet not rigidly adhering"—reads *gū* as "alone," yet this does not correspond to the meaning of "not rigid." The *Shiwen*’s citation of Cui—"*gū* means angular"—also fails to align with "not rigid." Both are likely incorrect.

The mastery of nurturing life lies in never having encountered the *jī* and *qìng* of the sinews, let alone the great *gū*!
[Phonetic Gloss] Cui [Zhuan] says: "not entangled in the bones." It is suspected that this *gū* character is the same as that *gū* character. The entanglement of bones is the utmost in rigidity; if *gū* is not rigid, this is called the True Person. Cui failed to recognize that *gū* and *gū* are the same character, hence the differing glosses before and after. ◎ Li Zhen says: "In the phrase *yú hū qí gū*, paired with *zhāng hū qí xū*, the character *gū* is entirely incongruous. According to the annotations and commentaries, *gū* is glossed as 'solitary.' The *Shiwen* cites Wang [Bi], saying: '*Gū* means standing apart, unsupported.' Both convey the meaning of 'alone.' It is evident that the original text must have read *gū* as *gū* (孤), a phonetic loan. The *Erya*’s *Shi Di* section reads: '*Gū*-bamboo north of the door,' and the *Shiwen* notes: 'Originally written as *gū* (孤).' This is proof of the interchangeability of *gū* and *gū*. The solitary and independent are upright and angular, hence the character may also be borrowed as *gū*. As for the two characters *yú hū*, which recur in the phrase *yú hū zhǐ wǒ dé yě* below, it is suspected that an error has occurred here. The annotation reads: 'constantly roaming in solitude.' If we seek its meaning from the word *yóu* (游, 'to roam'), it may originally have been the character *yǔ* (□) or *yù* (). The *Shuowen* states: '*Yǔ* means walking in ease'; *yù* means hastening steps. Both accord with the meaning of *yóu*."

[4]
[Annotation] Vast and unburdened, they attain to true substance.
[Commentary] *Zhāng* means "expansive." The numinous abode is broad and unobstructed, equal in measure to the void, yet their wisdom and virtue are genuine, hence they are not superficial.

[5]
[Annotation] The Perfect Person is without joy, yet harmoniously at ease, thus appearing joyful.
[Commentary] *Bǐngbǐng* is the appearance of joy. Adapting to change and following transformation, they find contentment in whatever they encounter. Truly forgetting joy and anger, they are thus said to *seem* joyful.
[Phonetic Gloss] *Bǐngbǐng*: Xu [Xuan] reads *bǐng*; Guo [Xiang] reads *fǔxìng*. Xiang [Xiu] says: "an appearance of joy." Jianwen [of Liang] says: "an appearance of brightness."

[6]
[Annotation] In movement and stillness, in action and rest, they always abide in the ultimate of necessity.
[Commentary] *Cuī* means "to move"; *jǐ* means "to stop." The True Person, serene and still, responds to things without fixed direction. Compelled, they then move—not by initiating action, but responding only when unavoidable.
[Phonetic Gloss] *Cuī hū*: read *qiān zuì* (Yu [Yue]) or *xī zuì* (Xu [Xuan]); Guo [Xiang] reads *qiě léi*. Xiang [Xiu] says: "an appearance of movement." Jianwen [of Liang] says: "an appearance of swiftness."

[7]
[Annotation] They do not allow things to harm themselves.
[Commentary] *Chù* means "to gather" or "to accumulate." The mind is like still water, thus able to gather and benefit all beings. Therefore, they respond without attachment, bestow without depletion, and whether things suit or benefit them, their spirit and countenance remain undiminished.
[Phonetic Gloss] *Chù hū*: Also written as *chù*; read *chì liù*. Sima [Biao] says: "an appearance of rising indignation." Wang [Bi] says: "abundant in virtue and fullness." Jianwen [of Liang] says: "to gather."

[8]
[Annotation] They have no fixed direction.
[Commentary] Though they respond to movement and follow the world, engaging with things and seizing opportunities, they always remain at ease and without action, acting through true virtue—what is called "moving yet ever still."

[9]
[Annotation] The Perfect Person is without peril, yet moves in step with the world, thus appearing perilous.
[Commentary] *Lì* means "danger." The True Person is one with safety and peril, oblivious to fortune and misfortune, yet blending their light with the world, they *seem* perilous. Like Confucius besieged by the people of Kuang or King Wen imprisoned in Youli, though they encountered danger, they did not abandon the practice of non-action.
[Phonetic Gloss] *Lì hū*: read as written. Cui [Zhuan] writes it as *guǎng*, saying: "to encompass is to be broad." ◎ Yu Yue says: Guo Xiang’s annotation is entirely untenable. If following his interpretation, it should read "the world seems perilous," not the reverse—"seeming like the world." Now, I propose that *shì* (世) is a phonetic loan for *tài* (泰). In the *Rongru* chapter of the *Xunzi*, it says: "*Qiáoxiè* is the calamity of man." Liu Taigong’s *Buzhu* states: "*Qiáoxiè* is a variant of *jiāotài* (骄泰)." Elsewhere in the *Xunzi*, it may appear as *dà* (汏), *shì* (忕), or *tài* (泰), all interchangeable. *Lòuxiè* (漏泄) rhymes with *wàidàhàibài* (外大害败), and is also read as *tài*. Further evidence is found in the *Jiazi*: "*Jiǎnxiè* cannot obtain scholars." Thus, reading *shì* as *tài* is akin to reading *xiè* as *tài*. Fierceness (*měnglì*) corresponds to arrogance (*jiāotài*), and the *Shiwen* notes that *lì*, written as *guǎng* by Cui, means "broad"—also corresponding to *tài*, as *tài* means "great." If read literally as *shì* (世), the meaning becomes entirely incoherent. ◎ Qing Fan notes: *Lì* should follow Cui’s version as *guǎng*, which is correct. Guo Xiang’s annotation, "moving in step with the world," implies the meaning of "broad and great." Yet to say they are "without peril" and then "seem perilous" is contradictory. In classical texts, *lì* (厉) and *guǎng* (广) are often confused. For example, in the *Liyue* chapter of the *Liji*, it says: "The Son of Heaven then *lì*-adorns," while the *Shize* chapter of the *Huainanzi* writes it as *guǎng*-adorns. In the *Pingjin Hou Zhuan* of the *Shiji*, it says: "*Lì* the worthy and grant them emoluments," and Xu Guang notes: "*Lì* is also written as *guǎng*." In the *Rulin Zhuan*, it says: "to *guǎng* worthy talent," while the *Hanshu* writes *guǎng* as *lì*. In the *Dili Zhi* of the *Hanshu*, it says: "Qi Commandery’s *guǎng*," and the *Shuowen*’s water section notes that *guǎng* is mistakenly written as *lì*. All these are evidence. ◎ Further note: Yu Yue’s proposal that *shì* is a phonetic loan for *tài* is correct. In antiquity, there was no *tài* character; it was written as *dà* (大). The characters *dà* (大) and *shì* (世) were homophonous and synonymous in ancient times, hence interchangeable. The *Liji*’s *Quli* chapter says: "One does not dare to share a name with the heir apparent," and the commentary notes: "*Shì* may also be written as *dà*." In the *Chunqiu*’s 30th year of Duke Wen, it says: "The *dà*-chamber’s roof collapsed," while the *Gongyang Zhuan* writes it as *shì*-chamber. The *Wei Taishu Yi* of the *Gongyang Zhuan* is written as *Shi Shu Yi* in the *Lunyu*. The *Yue Daxin* of the *Gongyang* is written as *Yue Shixin*. The *Zi Dashu* of Zheng in the *Lunyu* is written as *Shi Shu*. All these are evidence.

[10]
[Annotation] Lofty and free, they are self-possessed.

The exegesis states: The sage’s virtue is vast and great, towering and loftily remote, transcending the world’s bounds—thus it cannot be restrained or controlled.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*《謷乎》* wǔ gāo fǎn; Xú wǔ dào fǎn.
Sīmǎ explains: the appearance of far-reaching aspiration.
Wáng explains: rising high above the common.

[11]
**Annotation:** Boundless and profoundly distant, none perceive its gate.

**Exegesis:** *Lián* means "long." The sage’s virtue is distant and enduring, continuous and unfathomable. The mind’s path is cut off—who perceives its gate? Muffled and silent, it seems as though barred, no sound or sight of others heard.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*《连乎》* read as written.
Lǐ explains: *lián* is the appearance of continuity.
Cuī explains: obstructed and linked, pronounced *niǎn*.
*《似好》* hū bào fǎn, same below.

[12]
**Annotation:** Unknowing and unrecognizing, the celestial mechanism stirs of itself—hence its *mèn*-like state.

**Exegesis:** *Mèn* is the appearance of absence of mind. Yielding and at ease, effortless and serene, the Dark Pearl is obtained at the Red Waters—thus words are forgotten. From the foregoing, the perfected person’s self-cultivation and benefiting of others, inner and outer virtues, have been set forth in sequence. From this point onward, the perfected person’s methods of governing and benefiting the world are elucidated.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*《悗乎》* wáng běn fǎn. The character may also be written as *免*.
Lǐ explains: the appearance of unmatchedness.
Wáng explains: neglect and oblivion.
Cuī explains: compliance and gentleness.

[13]
**Annotation:** Punishment is the embodiment of governance, yet it is not of my making.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*《治之》* zhí lì fǎn.

[14]
**Annotation:** Ritual is how the world conducts itself—it is not I who establish it.

**Exegesis:** Employing penal law as governance is the foundational principle of rule; employing music as guidance is the ornament of all things.

[15]
**Annotation:** Knowledge is the movement of the times—it is not I who initiate it.

[16]
**Annotation:** Virtue is what others follow—it is not of my creation.

**Exegesis:** *Xún* means to comply. Employing wisdom to illuminate the moment ensures timeliness is not lost; engaging with others through virtue accords with their dispositions. The foregoing briefly outlined these principles; what follows provides further explanation.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*《为循》* The original may also be written as *xiū*; both are acceptable.
◎ Yú Yuè remarks: Lu [Deming]’s claim that both are acceptable is incorrect. In the passage below, “those with feet reach the hill,” the character *xún* is clearly correct. The *Shuowen* states: *xún* means “to follow in sequence.” If written as *xiū*, it would lack meaning.
◎ Qìngfān notes: The character *xún* is indeed correct. The *Guangya* defines *xún* as “to follow.” The *Commentary on the “Bei Feng”* of the *Book of Songs* states: “to follow” means *xún*. In clerical script, the characters *xún* and *xiū* are easily confused. In the *Yi Jing*, the *Xici* passage “the cultivation of virtue” is glossed in the *Shiwen* as *xún* in Ma’s version. In the *Zuozhuan*, the *Jin Yu* line “Shū played the *xiū* sound” is written as *xún* in the *Justice* commentary to the *Rites of Zhou*. In the *Records of the Grand Historian*, the *Biography of Shang Yang* states, “Tang and Wu did not follow the ancients and yet reigned as kings,” where the *Suoyin* notes that the *Book of Lord Shang* writes this as *xiū*. In the *Guanzi*, the *Nine Guards* chapter reads, “follow names to supervise realities,” where modern editions erroneously write *xiū*. All these are examples of the same confusion.

**[17]**
**Annotation:** Ren Zhi’s suicide was an act of self-governance, and thus, though it was killing, it was lenient.
**Subcommentary:** *Chuo* means leniency. The purpose of employing penal law as the foundation of governance is to halt killing with killing, to punish one and deter ten thousand. Thus, though it is killing, it is lenient and simple.
Therefore, the benevolent are the people’s enemies, while the law is the people’s father.
**Phonetic Gloss:** *Chuo hu* (綽乎): *chang lüe* (昌略) in reverse.
**Cui’s Version:** *Nao* (淖).

**[18]**
**Annotation:** It accords with what the world practices, and thus there is nothing it does not accomplish.
**Subcommentary:** Though ritual is but the thinnest of loyalty and trust, it is the foremost means of governing the world. Hence, “without learning ritual, one has no means to stand”; “do not act without ritual, do not speak without ritual.” If a person lacks ritual, why do they not swiftly die? Thus, ritual is essential to governance! It upholds human relationships and is the reason it flourishes so widely in the world.

**[19]**
**Annotation:** High and low receive one another—this is an irreversible flow. The small and the great form groups—this is an inevitable circumstance. Vast and without emotion, it is the repository of all knowledge. To bear the convergence of a hundred streams and dwell at the pinnacle of those who guide others—what is there to do? Entrust oneself to the world’s wisdom, commit to what must be, and yield it all to the world.
**Subcommentary:** Responding to stimuli in accord with the moment, wielding supreme knowledge to meet the times, principle has no visible or audible form, yet circumstances possess an inescapable momentum. Thus, the true master is vast and without attachment, entrusting all to the collective wisdom, abiding in the convergence of what must be, and riding it as one would wander.

**[20]**
**Annotation:** The mound is that by which things are rooted. In terms of nature, it is the root of nature. All things have their own sufficiency, and this sufficiency lies in their root. Yielding to the self-following of the myriad virtues, this is like those with feet reaching their root. When the root is attained, principle is exhausted.
**Subcommentary:** The mound is the root. Engaging with things through virtue, one accords with their nature. Each nature has its own allotment, and when one abides within that allotment, it is sufficient. Accord with this root-nature, and thus one reaches the mound.
**Jia Shifu’s Note:** Kong Anguo said, “The records of the Nine Provinces are called the *Nine Mounds*.” The *Zeyang* chapter of the *Zhuangzi* also speaks of “the words of mounds and villages.” Thus, all dwellings are called mounds. The ruins of Zhuanxu are called the *Imperial Mound*. Those with feet who can walk will ultimately return to their dwelling. Following ritual is like resting in the comfort of one’s home—those with feet will inevitably arrive.

**[21]**
**Annotation:** All these come to completion from that, and their completion does not lie within oneself. Thus, though one dwells at the pinnacle of a myriad affairs, one remains ever at leisure and at ease, suddenly unaware of affairs passing through the body, oblivious to words issuing from the mouth. Yet the great delusion of people is to truly believe that the perfected person acts with tireless effort.
**Subcommentary:** The perfected person moves like drifting clouds and rests like the valley spirit, with realm and wisdom utterly forgotten, the empty mind responding to the mysterious. How could they harbor attachment to things or be bound by emotions to salvation? Yet the common people, clinging to their paths, see the boat as the means to ferry all beings, the pavilion as the means to nurture the multitude, and truly believe the sage labors without rest. How could they know that above the Fen River, one is serene and profoundly still? Thus, the preceding text states, “Who would trouble themselves with things as affairs?”

**Phonetic Gloss:** *Chang xian* (常闲): read as *xian* (闲).

**[22]**
**Annotation:** Constantly without mind and in accord with that, thus likes and dislikes, approvals and disapprovals, are no different from those of others.
**Subcommentary:** Having forgotten attachment to beauty and ugliness, one also casts aside love and hatred. Thus, likes and dislikes arise from the emotions of the common, yet the sage’s wisdom is empty and all-embracing, never failing to be one with them.

**[23]**
**Annotation:** That it is one is the work of Heaven; that it is not one is the work of man. The true person is one with Heaven and man, equalizing self and other, not differing in their oneness from their non-oneness.
**Subcommentary:** Its oneness is sagely wisdom; its non-oneness is the emotions of the common. Yet since the sage and the common are not two, the non-one is also subsumed into the one.

**[24]**
**Annotation:** That there is nothing which is not one—this is Heaven.

**[25]**
**Annotation:** That it is “that” and “this,” “I” and “me”—this is man.
**Subcommentary:** To be one with Heaven and man, to equalize the myriad manifestations, is to be of the same kind as the mysterious Heaven. To be “that” and “this,” “I” and “me,” is to be of the same kind as the common multitude.

**[26]**
**Annotation:** The true person is one with Heaven and man, equalizing the myriad manifestations. The myriad manifestations do not oppose one another, Heaven and man do not overcome one another. Thus, they are vast and without anything that is not one, obscure and without anything that is not present, and mysteriously identical with that and this.
**Subcommentary:** Though Heaven is without that and this, and man possesses right and wrong, when one examines this resolutely, all returns to emptiness and quiescence. If Heaven were superior and man inferior, how could they be called equal? This is to blend Heaven and man into one, to obscure the distinction between victory and defeat. Those who embody this can be called true persons.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) *Que wu* cites the text: the *Hai*, *Cheng Yuan Ying*, and *Zhang Junfang* versions write *xi hu* (喜乎) as *xi ye* (喜也).
(2) It also cites the text: the *Cheng* and *Zhang* versions repeat the character *Cui* (崔), and *yi hu* (已乎) is written as *yi ye* (已也).
(3) It also writes *shi hu* (世乎) as *shi ye* (世也).
(4) The *Zhao Jianyi* version writes *qun* (群) as *jun* (君).
(5) The *Song* version writes *zai* (在) as *ren* (任).

Life and death are fate; their constancy of night and day is Heaven.
What man cannot partake in—these are all the conditions of things.
They take Heaven as their father and still cherish it—how much more that which transcends it!
They take having a lord as better than themselves and still die for it—how much more that which is true!

**[1]**
**Annotation:** The constancy of day and night is the Way of Heaven. Thus, to know that life and death are the extremes of fate is not arbitrary—it is like night and day. To what could they be bound?

The constancy of dawn’s brightness and night’s darkness is the eternal Way of Heaven; the coming and going of life and death is the allotted fate of man. Heaven cannot be without day and night—how then can man be without life and death? Thus, to follow change and drift with the current, to what could I be bound?

**[2]**
**Annotation:** The true person obtains day in the day and night in the night. Taking life and death as day and night, how could there be anything one does not attain! That man has things he cannot attain and yet harbors sorrow and joy in his breast—these are all the conditions of things, not the principle.

Life and death, day and night, are the eternal Way of man and Heaven, never separate from the self—what is there to be bound to? Yet the vulgar crowd resists the workings of creation, unable to rest in their time and abide in their lot, to go along with change. They rejoice in life and abhor death, harboring sorrow and joy in their hearts. This is but the stagnant emotion of ordinary things—how could it be the penetrating wisdom of the true person!

**[3]**
**Annotation:** *Zhuo* (卓) refers to solitary transformation. The efficacy of mutual dependence is not as great as the perfection of solitary transformation. Thus, what man depends upon is Heaven; what Heaven gives birth to is solitary transformation. All men take Heaven as their father, and so even the changes of day and night, the cycles of cold and heat, they dare not resent, but follow Heaven and rest in it. How much more that which is *zhuo*—solitary transformation—reaching the mysterious and obscure realm! How could one not submit to it? Having submitted, then life and death, change and transformation, are but to follow fate.

*Zhuo* refers to solitary transformation. The multitude of men, receiving qi from the azure vault, take Heaven alone as their father, cherishing and revering it. Even the alternation of day and night and the shifts of cold and warmth, they cannot reverse or resist. How much more the abstruse and recondite realm of the perfect Way, the consummation of solitary and natural transformation, giving birth to Heaven and Earth, opening and closing yin and yang! One can only rest in it and submit—how could one resist and not comply!

**[4]**
**Annotation:** The *zhen* (真, true) is that which does not borrow from things but is natural. The natural cannot be avoided—how could it be merely the command of a lord!

*Yu* (愈) means "superior." The *zhen* is the solitary transformation just mentioned. Men take the lord and king alone as superior to themselves in honor and nobility, and still lay down their lives and devote themselves, not daring to avoid it. How much more the ultimate of the mysterious Way, the principle of the natural! Could one desire not to comply? To arrange and entrust oneself to transformation is surely fitting.

When the springs dry up, fish find themselves together on dry land. They moisten one another with their breath, wet one another with their foam—better to forget one another in the rivers and lakes. Rather than praise Yao and condemn Jie, it is better to forget both and be transformed by the Way.

The great clod burdens me with form, labors me with life, eases me with old age, and rests me with death. Thus, to be good to my life is to be good to my death.

**[1]**
**Annotation:** Rather than be insufficient and love one another, how much better to have abundance and forget one another!

This begins with a metaphor. In the vastness of rivers and lakes, fish swim freely, each with enough deep water, no longer coming and going. They forget one another, and affection is cut off. But when the springs dry up, sturgeon and salmon are distressed, stranded together on dry land, their tails and gills exposed. Then they wet one another with foam, moisten one another with breath, coming and going in affection, drawing ever closer. Compared to the rivers and lakes, this is far removed. It is like the age of the great Way, when things each roamed freely, the sounds of chickens and dogs not reaching one another. When the pure wind scattered and the turbid waves arose, teachings emerged from principle, and the traces of sages appeared.
