They prided themselves on limping and hobbling as benevolence, on tiptoeing as righteousness. Fathers and sons, brothers, harbored emotions and deceived one another. The sage felt shame—rightly so. Thus, we know that fish lose water and so moisten one another with breath and foam, just as men lose the Way and so cling to one another in affection.

**[2]**
**Annotation:** Praise and blame both arise from insufficiency. Thus, the perfectly sufficient forgets good and evil, leaves behind life and death, and becomes one with change and transformation. Vast and unobstructed, there is nothing it does not accommodate—how could it know where Yao and Jie reside?

This completes the metaphor. Tang Yao was a sage-king, and Xia Jie a mediocre lord. Thus, to praise Yao as good and condemn Jie as evil, to take Yao and Shun as models to exhort posterity, is the foundation from which benevolence and righteousness arise. How much better to be without good and without evil, to forget both good and evil! To be without "is" and without "is not," to cast off both "is" and "is not"! Then, to go forth from life and enter death, to roam along with change and transformation; to come and go without destination, to tread the mysterious Way and find contentment in oneself.

How could this compare with those who warm and moisten the sagely traces, speaking of them as equals!

The bodily forms of birth, aging, and death—all are myself. Thus, the body bears me, birth labors me, old age rests me, and death gives me repose. Though these four transform, they have never ceased to be myself—why should I regret them?

The Great Clod is nature. The body is a constructed thing; birth, the beginning of nurturance; old age, the years of maturity; death, the day when qi disperses. Yet the one who bears the form must endure toil in life; in old age, lacking ability, one finds brief ease; in death, returning to nothingness, one rests by principle. Though these four transform, they have never ceased to be myself—so why should I feel any regret?

Death and life are both matters of fate. Without goodness, there is death; with goodness, there is life—not goodness alone. If, then, you deem my life to be good, then my death is good as well.

The bodily forms of birth, aging, and death—all are myself. Thus, if one deems the goodness of my life to be good, then my death may also be deemed good.

To hide a boat in a ravine or conceal a mountain in a marsh is called secure. Yet in the dead of night, a man of strength may carry them away, and the unwitting do not know it. Though one hides things great or small as is fitting, there is still escape. But to hide the world within the world is to find no escape—this is the great truth of all things.

Yet men rejoice merely in possessing human form. If the human form itself undergoes ten thousand transformations without end, how immeasurable would its joy be! Thus, the sage wanders where things cannot escape and all abide.

To excel in youth, excel in age, excel in beginning, excel in end—men still emulate this. How much more, then, should they emulate that on which the ten thousand things depend and by which the single transformation is sustained!

To speak of death and life as transformations inescapable, one first sets forth the extreme of what cannot be escaped, then clarifies it with the sign of inevitable change, to follow transformation without attachment.

The power of the powerless is none greater than that of transformation. Thus it lifts heaven and earth to hasten toward the new, bears mountains and peaks to abandon the old. Without the slightest pause, it has already traversed the new—so heaven and earth and the ten thousand things are never without change. The world is ever renewed, yet men regard it as old; the boat is daily altered, yet they see it as before; the mountain is daily transformed, yet they view it as of old. Now they clasp an arm and lose it—all has departed in darkness. Thus, the self of before is no longer the self of now. The self and the present pass together—how could they ever cling to the old? Yet the world does not perceive this, stubbornly believing that what it now encounters can be bound and held. How deluded!

In the darkness of midnight, this illustrates the profound obscurity of the true principle. The "man of strength" is the work of creation. To hide a boat in the sea’s ravine is fitting; to conceal mountains in the marsh is proper. Yet the power of creation bears them away and hastens onward—change is ever renewed, swift as flowing water. The deluded, their minds dull and foolish, truly believe that boat and mountain stand firm, unmoving and steadfast. How could they know that in darkness all shifts without cease? Yesterday’s self and today’s self are just the same.

Not knowing to embody transformation and seeking to hide things so they do not change—though one hides them most deeply and securely, each in its proper place, one cannot prevent their daily alteration. Thus, those who hide and possess cannot halt their escape; those who do not hide and yield to change cannot be altered by change.

To hide a boat in a ravine or a mountain in a marsh is to hide the great; to hide a person in a room or an object in a vessel is to hide the small. Though great and small differ, all hiding is fitting, yet thoughts still flow and shift, ever renewed. Thus, the Way of transformation admits no escape.

To hide nothing and entrust all to it is to be one with things, to be undivided from change. Thus, there is no outer, no inner, no death, no life—embodying heaven and earth and uniting with transformation, one seeks escape and finds none. This is the great truth of constant abiding, not the petty intent of a single corner.

To hide the world within the world—is this truly hiding? It is to hide nothing at all. Thus, one equalizes life and death, obscures change, roams freely within the cosmos, and rides creation in play. Since one alters what cannot be altered, where is there escape? This is to embody the stillness of all things and grasp the true essence of the great Dao—how could it be the delusion of the vulgar or the petty wisdom of the worldly?

V.

Man’s form is but one encounter among the myriad transformations—nothing to rejoice in exclusively. Within the boundless, all that one meets is like man; why should only the human form bring joy while other things yield no delight?

◎ Qingfan’s note: *Wen Xuan* commentary on Jia Yi’s *Fu on the Owl* cites Sima [Biao] as saying: “It will again transform into nothingness.”

VI.

Originally not human, one transforms into human—yet in becoming human, one loses what was before. To lose what was before and rejoice is to rejoice in what one encounters. Transformations are endless; what is there one will not meet? Meeting and delighting in it, how could delight have any limit?

VII.

The sage roams the paths of transformation, drifts upon the ceaseless current of renewal. The myriad things and myriad changes—he changes with them. Since transformations are boundless, he too is boundless. Who can escape him? In life, one is as if gone; in death, one is as if present—so when is one not present?

VIII.

This is to equalize within the span of a hundred years, not to be young in goodness and old in decline. Yet one has not embodied transformation or equalized life and death. Still, in its even purity, it is enough to serve as a teacher for others.

◎ "Goodness and decline" (Cui’s edition reads "cunning," same pronunciation). Anciently written as *yao* (夭), pronounced *yu* in *biao*. Simplified text reads *yao* (夭). ◎ Lu Wenchong notes: Current text reads *yao* (夭). ◎ Qingfan’s note: The character *yao* (妖) is correctly written as *yao* (夭). *Yao* and *yao* were interchangeable in antiquity. *Records of the Grand Historian: Annals of Zhou*: "The abandoned child of a palace concubine," where Xu Guang notes: *yao* (妖) is written as *yao* (夭). Cui’s reading of *jiao* (狡) is incorrect. ◎ "Young in goodness" (*shao*), rhyming with *zhao*. ◎ "Old in decline" (*bi*), pronounced *bi*. Also written as *bi* (鄙). ◎ "Even purity" (*suì*), rhyming with *sui*.

IX.

This is to be profoundly one with the myriad things and embody transformation. Thus, to be revered by all under heaven is only fitting.

To be bound is to belong. Human understanding varies in brightness and obscurity. Even within a hundred years, within a single lifetime, some move with ease and equanimity, rarely stirred by joy or sorrow, untroubled by longevity or early death, youth or old age.

Though one may not yet transcend life and death, if one harbors no aversion, this alone suffices to serve as a teacher and guide for all things, for people to emulate and follow. How much more so when one merges with the myriad things, obscurely uniting with transformation! Belonging to the perfected person, this necessarily relies on sagely wisdom, serving as the master and model for all things—is this not fitting indeed!

◎ The Dao possesses sentiment and sincerity, yet is without action or form. It can be transmitted but not received, attained yet not seen. It is self-originating and self-rooted; before the existence of heaven and earth, it has endured since antiquity. It spirits forth ghosts and gods, empowers emperors, gives birth to heaven and earth. It exists before the Great Ultimate yet is not lofty; it dwells below the Six Poles yet is not deep. It precedes the birth of heaven and earth yet is not ancient; it endures beyond remote antiquity yet is not old.

Fuxi attained it and thereby harnessed heaven and earth. The Fu Xi clan attained it and thereby embraced the Mother of Qi. The Northern Dipper attained it and thus remains unerring through all ages. The sun and moon attained it and thus never cease. Kanhuai attained it and thereby embraced Kunlun. Feng Yi attained it and thereby roamed the great rivers. Jian Wu attained it and thereby dwelt upon the great mountains. The Yellow Emperor attained it and thereby ascended the cloudy heavens. Zhuan Xu attained it and thereby resided in the Dark Palace. Yuqiang attained it and stood at the North Pole. The Queen Mother of the West attained it and sat upon Shaoguang, her beginning and end unknown. Peng Zu attained it, reaching from the age of Yu to the Five Hegemons. Fu Yue attained it and thereby assisted Wu Ding, governing all under heaven, riding the Eastern Cord and the Tail of the Winnowing Basket, aligning with the ranks of stars.

Lǐ is pronounced like *shǐ*. Sima: "Name of an ancient sovereign."

*Yǐ qiè*: Xu: *kǔ jié* (to bind); Guo: *kǔ xì* (to connect). Sima: "The essential; having grasped the essential of Heaven and Earth." Cui: "To complete."

**Section Eight**
Commentary: Fu Xi was one of the Three Sovereigns. He could subdue oxen and ride horses, tame and domesticate animals, hence the name Fu Xi. *Xí* means "to unite." *Qì mǔ* is the mother of primordial *qi*, corresponding to the Dao. Having attained the supreme Dao, he could inscribe the Eight Trigrams, unfold the six lines, harmonize *yin* and *yang*, and unite with primordial *qi*.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Fú Xī*: pronounced *Xī*. Cui’s version reads *Fú Xī Shì* (Fu Xi Clan).
*Yǐ xí qì mǔ*: Sima: "*Xí* means 'to enter'; *qì mǔ* is the mother of primordial *qi*." Cui: "To take the root of primordial *qi*."

**Section Nine**
Commentary: *Wéi Dǒu* is the Northern Dipper, the guiding cord of all stars, hence called *Wéi Dǒu* ("Mainstay Dipper"). *Tè* means "deviation." *Gǔ* means "beginning."

Having attained the supreme Dao, he could traverse the cycle of beginning and end, sustain Heaven and Earth, and keep his mind free from deviation.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Wéi Dǒu*: Li: "The Northern Dipper serves as the guiding cord of all under Heaven." ◎Lu Wenchang: "Modern editions read 'all under Heaven' as 'Heaven’s.'"
*Zhōng gǔ*: Cui: "*Zhōng gǔ* means 'eternal.'" Zheng Xuan’s annotation to the *Rites of Zhou*: "*Zhōng gǔ* is akin to 'constant.'"
*Bù tè*: Pronounced *tā dé* in reverse, meaning "deviation." Cui’s version reads *dài*.

**Section Ten**
Commentary: The radiance of the sun and moon bears witness to the singular Dao, thus they traverse the cycle of beginning and end in illumination, ceaseless and without respite.

**Section Eleven**
Commentary: *Kūn Lún* is the name of a mountain, located north of the Northern Sea. *Kān Pī* is the name of a spirit of Mount Kūn Lún. *Xí* means "to enter." *Kān Pī* has the face of a human and the body of a beast; having attained the Dao, he entered Mount Kūn Lún to become its spirit.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Kān Pī*: Xu reads *fú méi*; Guo reads *fū bēi*. Cui’s version reads *Pī*. Sima: "*Kān Pī* is the name of a spirit, with the face of a human and the form of a beast." The *Huainanzi* reads *Qīn Fù*.
*Kūn Lún*: *Kūn* may also be written as *Mín*, both pronounced *kūn*. Below, *lún* is read *lì mén*. *Kūn Lún* is the name of a mountain.

**Section Twelve**
Commentary: His surname was *Féng*, given name *Yí*, a native of *Tóng Xiāng* in *Huá Yīn*, *Hóng Nóng*, born in the village of *Dī Shǒu Lǐ*. Having ingested the Eight Minerals, he attained water immortality. *Dà Chuān* refers to the Yellow River. The Heavenly Thearch bestowed upon *Féng Yí* the title of *Hé Bó* (River Earl), and thus he roamed and dwelled within the great rivers of *Méng Jīn*.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Féng Yí*: Sima: The *Qīng Líng Zhuàn* states: "*Féng Yí* was a native of *Dī Shǒu* in *Tóng Xiāng*, *Huá Yīn*. Having ingested the Eight Minerals, he attained water immortality and became the *Hé Bó*." Another account: "On the *gēng zǐ* day of the eighth month, he bathed in the river and drowned." Yet another: "He drowned while crossing the river."
*Dà Chuān*: The Yellow River. Cui’s version reads *Tài Chuān*.

**Section Thirteen**
Commentary: *Jiān Wú* is the name of a spirit. Having attained the Dao, he dwelled on the Eastern Marchmount as the spirit of Mount Tài.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Jiān Wú*: Sima: "A mountain spirit who did not die, living until the time of Confucius."
*Dà Shān*: Pronounced *tài* or read as written.

**Section Fourteen**
Commentary: The Yellow Emperor was *Xuān Yuán*. He mined copper from Mount Shǒu and cast tripods at the foot of Mount Jīng. When the tripods were completed, a dragon descended to the tripods to welcome the Emperor. The Emperor then led his ministers and seventy-two members of his inner court, ascending to Heaven in broad daylight, riding clouds and mounting the dragon, transforming into an immortal and departing.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Huáng Dì*: Cui: "Having attained the Dao, he ascended to Heaven."

**Section Fifteen**
Commentary: *Zhuān Xū*, grandson of the Yellow Emperor, was also known as Emperor Gāo Yáng or the Dark Emperor. At the age of twelve, he donned the cap of adulthood; at fifteen, he assisted *Shǎo Hào*; at twenty, he ascended the throne. He mined copper from Mount Yǔ to forge tripods, capable of summoning the spirits of the Four Seas, possessing numinous efficacy. He passed away at the age of ninety-seven, having attained the Dao and become the Emperor of the North. *Xuán* is the color of the North, hence he dwelled in the Dark Palace.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Zhuān Xū*: Pronounced *zhuān*; below, *xū* is read *yù*.
*Xuán Gōng*: Li: "*Zhuān Xū* was Emperor Gāo Yáng. The *Xuán Gōng* is the palace of the North." The *Monthly Ordinances* states: "Its Emperor is *Zhuān Xū*, its spirit is *Xuán Míng*."

**Section Sixteen**
Commentary: *Yú Qiáng* is the name of a water spirit, also called *Yú Jīng*. He has the face of a human and the body of a bird, rides dragons in his travels, and is a descendant of *Zhuān Xū* and *Xuān Yuán*. Though he attained the Dao, he did not occupy the throne of an Emperor but became a water spirit. As the water position corresponds to the North, his title is the Northern Culmen.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Yú Qiáng*: Pronounced *yú*; Guo reads *yǔ lóng*. Sima: The *Shān Hǎi Jīng* states: "On an islet in the Northern Sea, there is a spirit with the face of a human and the body of a bird, wearing two blue serpents as earrings and treading upon two red serpents, named *Yú Qiáng*." Cui: The *Dà Huāng Jīng* states: "The spirit of the Northern Sea is named *Yú Qiáng*, with the divine tortoise as his emissary." The *Guī Cáng* states: "In ancient times, the son of King Mu divined with milfoil before *Yú Qiáng*." According to the *Hǎi Wài Jīng*: "The Northern *Yú Qiáng* has a black body and limbs, riding two dragons." Guo Pu considered him a water spirit with the face of a human and the body of a bird. *Jiǎn Wén* states: "The spirit of the Northern Sea, also named *Yú Jīng*, is a grandson of the Yellow Emperor."

**Section Seventeen**
Commentary: *Shǎo Guǎng* is the name of a mountain in the Western Culmen. The Queen Mother of the West is the essence of the Great Yin, with a leopard’s tail, tiger’s teeth, and a fondness for laughter. During the reign of Emperor Shùn, the Queen Mother dispatched an envoy to present a jade ring; during the reign of Emperor Wǔ of Hàn, she offered green peaches. Her appearance resembled that of a girl of sixteen or seventeen, exceedingly graceful and proper. She constantly resided on Mount *Shǎo Guǎng* in the West, beyond the cycles of life and death, hence none know her beginning or end.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Xī Wáng Mǔ*: The *Shān Hǎi Jīng* states: "She resembles a human, with a dog’s tail, disheveled hair, wearing a *shèng* ornament, skilled in whistling, and dwelling on the shore of the sea." The *Hàn Wǔ Nèi Zhuàn* states: "The Queen Mother of the West and the Upper Prime Lady descended to the Emperor, their beauty that of divine immortals."
*Shǎo Guǎng*: Sima: "The name of a cave." Cui: "The name of a mountain." Another account: "The name of the empty realm in the West."

**Section Eighteen**
Commentary: *Péng Zǔ* was a great-great-grandson of Emperor *Zhuān Xū*. Enfeoffed at *Péng* City, his Dao was worthy of being ancestral, hence he was called *Péng Zǔ*. Skilled in nurturing his nature, he was one who attained the Dao. The Five Lords were: *Kūn Wú* as the Lord of Xià, *Dà Péng* and *Shǐ Wéi* as the Lords of Yīn, and *Qí Huán* and *Jìn Wén* as the Lords of Zhōu, together forming the Five Lords. *Péng Zǔ* attained the Dao, thus enjoying longevity, living from the time of *Yǒu Yú* through the Yīn and Zhōu dynasties, for a total of eight hundred years.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Péng Zǔ*: Explanation found in the *Xiāo Yáo* chapter. Cui: "He lived for seven hundred years." Another account: "He was considered an immortal who did not die."

**Section Nineteen**

*The Five Lords*: Read as *bó* (lords). Alternatively pronounced *bà* (hegemons). Cui and Li state: "The Lord of Xià was *Kūn Wú*, the Lords of Yīn were *Dà Péng* and *Shǐ Wéi*, and the Lords of Zhōu were *Qí Huán* and *Jìn Wén*."

**Commentary**: The Dao is non-action. This speaks of attaining it through the Dao, thereby clarifying that it is self-attained. Being self-attained means the Dao cannot cause one to attain it; if I have not attained it, neither can I force attainment. Thus, all who attain it neither rely on the Dao externally nor depend on themselves internally—they spontaneously attain it and transform alone. The difficulty of life lies precisely in this spontaneous attainment and self-possession. Having attained life, why fret over failing to attain it and thus act upon it? Therefore, striving for life ultimately fails to preserve life, for life does not originate from oneself, and such striving injures one’s true life.

**Exegesis**: *Wǔ Dīng* was the name of an Yīn king, styled *Gāo Zōng*. *Gāo Zōng* dreamed of obtaining *Fù Yuè* and dispatched envoys to seek him throughout the realm. He was found at *Fùyán*, a rammed-earth worksite in *Héběi* County of *Shànzhōu*, and served as *Wǔ Dīng*’s minister, bringing sudden peace and prosperity. *Fù Yuè* was the essence of a star. There is a single star of *Fù Yuè* above the *Jī* and *Wěi* constellations. Since *Jī* and *Wěi* are among the twenty-eight lunar lodges, sustaining the eastern quadrant, it is said he "rode the eastern cord and mounted the *Jī* tail," and "stood among the ranked stars," for he aligned with stars like *Jiǎo* and *Kàng* in their celestial array.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Fù Yuè*: Pronounced *yuè*.
*Obtained him as minister*: *Xiàng*, read *xiàng* (to assist).
*Wǔ Dīng ruled all under heaven, rode the eastern cord, mounted the *Jī* tail, and stood among the ranked stars*: Sima states: "*Fù Yuè* was a minister of Yīn. *Wǔ Dīng* was the Yīn king *Gāo Zōng*. The eastern cord lies between *Jī* and *Dǒu*, the eastern strand of the Milky Way." The *Star Canon* says: "There is one star of *Fù Yuè* above the tail, meaning he rode the eastern cord and mounted the space between the *Jī* tail." Cui states: "When *Fù Yuè* died, his spirit rode the eastern cord and lodged in the dragon’s tail, becoming a constellation. Today, there is a *Fù Yuè* star above the tail." Cui’s edition adds below: "Born without parents, upon death he ascended in three years and his form vanished—this speaks of the spirit’s ineffable nature," totaling twenty-two characters.
*Spontaneously*: *Jué rán*, read *qú wù*.
**Collation Notes**
(1) The *Shì Dé Táng* edition omits *wéi* (to act).
(2) The ancient character follows the main text.
(3) The *Shì Dé Táng* edition reads *shén* (spirit) as *rén* (person).
(4) The *Shì Dé Táng* edition omits *fú* (therefore).

**Nán Bó Zǐ Kuí** asked *Nǚ Yǔ*: "You are advanced in years, yet your complexion resembles that of a child—how is this so?"

**Commentary**: *Kuí* is likely a corruption of *Qí*, as in *Nán Guō Zǐ Qí* from the *Rén Jiān Shì* chapter. *Nǚ Yǔ* was an ancient adept of the Dao. *Child* here means an infant. *Nǚ Yǔ* had long heard the perfect Dao, enabling him to cultivate and nourish life. Though aged, he retained the complexion of youth and the radiance of vitality. Being unlike ordinary people, *Zǐ Kuí* asked how he achieved this.

**Exegetical Notes**
*Nán Bó Zǐ Kuí*: Li states: "*Kuí* should be *Qí*, a phonetic error."
*Nǚ Yǔ*: Xu reads *yǔ*, Li reads *jǔ*. Another account: "She was a woman."
*Advanced in years*: Read *zhàng*.
*Child*: Originally *zǐ*, now corrected to *rú*, read *rú* (child). Li states: "A weak child."
**Note by Lú Wénchāo**: The current text reads *dīng zhàng*, consistent with other instances.
**Note by Lú Wénchāo**: The current text reads *rú*, which is the correct form.

He replied: "I have heard the Dao."

He replied: "Having heard the Dao, I let life unfold naturally—thus my qi and complexion remain whole."

**Commentary**
Hearing the Dao allows one to preserve life in its entirety, which is why one reverts to youth and regains the radiance of a child.

Nán Bó Zǐ Kuí asked: "Can the Dao be learned?"

**Commentary**
Witnessing such an extraordinary countenance, he was filled with admiration and thus inquired about the method.

**Textual Note**
The *Zhào Jiànyì* edition omits the character *Dao*.

He said: "Alas! How could it be? You are not the right person. Now, Bǔliáng Yǐ possesses the talent of a sage but lacks the Dao of a sage, while I possess the Dao of a sage but lack the talent of a sage. I wished to teach him, hoping he might indeed become a sage! Otherwise, imparting the Dao of a sage to one with the talent of a sage would be easy. Yet I still maintained my practice and instructed him: after three days, he could transcend the world; having transcended the world, I maintained my practice further, and after seven days, he could transcend things; having transcended things, I maintained my practice further, and after nine days, he could transcend life. Only after transcending life could he attain morning clarity; attaining morning clarity, he could perceive the solitary; perceiving the solitary, he could transcend past and present; transcending past and present, he could enter the realm of neither death nor life. That which takes life does not die; that which gives life does not live. As for the Dao, it sends nothing away, welcomes nothing; destroys nothing, completes nothing. Its name is *yīngníng*. *Yīngníng* is that which is completed only through embrace."

**Commentary**
"Alas! How could it be?" means it is impossible. Nǚ Yǔ’s spirit was inwardly still, while his appearance outwardly radiant. Zǐ Kuí, seeing his countenance, eagerly requested to learn. Finding his question inappropriate, Nǚ Yǔ dismissed him as unfit.

**Phonetic Gloss**
*È è kě*: Both read as *wū*. Below, *è hū* is the same.

**Commentary**
Bǔliáng is a surname of the Jī clan; Yǐ is his given name. Emptiness and tranquility constitute the Dao; wisdom and acuity constitute talent. Bǔliáng possessed external talent but lacked inner tranquility, while Nǚ Yǔ possessed the Dao of emptiness but lacked keen talent—each was limited to one side, neither fully perfected. Yet when comparing talent to the Dao, talent is inferior while the Dao prevails.

**Phonetic Gloss**
*Bǔliáng Yǐ*: Read as *yú qǐ*, or alternatively *qí qǐ*. Li states: "Bǔliáng is the surname; Yǐ is the given name."

**Commentary**
*Shù* means to admire; *jǐ* means near; *guǒ* means certain.

The superior scholar, upon hearing the Dao, still relies on diligent practice—without diligent practice, the Dao cannot be attained. Thus, though one may receive instruction, one must cultivate and study, admiring and drawing near to the mysterious Dao, resolutely becoming a sage. If this is not so, the teachings may be easily imparted, but the effort of cultivation and preservation is what makes attainment difficult. Now, though Nǚ Yǔ has long heard the supreme Dao and inwardly embodies stillness and tranquility, even in transmitting it, she must guard it herself. How much more so for the beginner—there is no room for slackness. Even if one speaks of it with the mouth and hears it with the ears, what benefit is there? Thus, it is not knowing that is difficult, but practicing that is difficult.

**Phonetic Gloss**
*Yì yì*: Read as *yǐ chǐ*.

**Commentary**
*Wài* means to abandon.

**Commentary**
*Wài* means to forget. To be a teacher is not easy; transmitting the Dao is exceedingly difficult. Just as she was about to instruct others, she concentrated her spirit and stilled her thoughts, cultivating and preserving it for a full three days. Once her mind was empty and tranquil, all phenomena became void—thus, all beneath heaven and upon the earth were entirely nonexistent.

**Phonetic Gloss**
*Cān rì*: Read as *sān*.

**Commentary**
*Wù* refers to things needed morning and night, intimately tied to oneself and difficult to forget.

**Commentary**
The myriad phenomena of the world are distant and thus easily forgotten; the things that sustain the body are close and thus difficult to abandon. Only after guarding it for seven days was she able to let them go. As Guo’s commentary states: *Wù* refers to things needed morning and night, intimately tied to oneself and difficult to forget.

**Commentary**
To dissolve the body and depart from form, to sit in forgetfulness and lose the self—after long practice, the abandonment deepens.

**Commentary**
To forget life is not to loathe death; not loathing death, whatever one encounters is accepted with equanimity. Suddenly unobstructed, one sees the moment and acts—this is *zhāo chè*.

**Commentary**
*Zhāo* means dawn; *chè* means clarity. Seeing life and death as one, forgetting both self and things, wisdom shines forth like the morning sun breaking through—thus it is called *zhāo chè*.

**Phonetic Gloss**
*Néng zhāo*: Read as written. Li reads it as *chú yáo*. The same below.
*Chè*: Read as written. Guo and Sima state: *Zhāo* means dawn; *chè* is the Dao of profound attainment. Li states: One who can perceive with clarity does not require a full morning to achieve far-reaching insight.
*Bù wù*: Read as *wū lù*. The same below.
*Huòrán*: Read as *huàn huó*.

**8. Commentary**
To accept whatever one encounters, forgetting all that precedes or follows—this is to perceive the *Alone*.

**Commentary**
The supreme Dao is serene, transcending speech and form, neither non-being nor being, neither past nor present. It comes and goes alone, free from dependence or opposition. To behold this sublime realm is called *seeing the Alone*. Thus the *Laozi* says: "Silent and unmoving, it does not change."

**9. Commentary**
To proceed together with the *Alone*.

**Commentary**
Following the daily renewal of creation, moving with transformation without being swayed by external conditions—thus there is no distinction between past and present.

**10. Commentary**
Attachment to life gives rise to death; aversion to death gives rise to life. Only when there is no attachment and no aversion can there be neither death nor life.

**Commentary**
"Past and present" are but convergences. The distinction between past and present, the separation of life and death—these are the inverted views of the deluded. Time flows ceaselessly, ever new, without past or present; thus the Dao neither departs nor arrives, neither dies nor lives. Who but the disciple of *Nü Yu* can grasp this truth?

**11. Commentary**
*Shā* means extinction; *sǐ*, death, is also extinction. To say that this death has not yet perished, or that this life has not yet arisen—both death and life enter into the state of neither death nor life. Thus, in embodying the Dao, there is no arising or ceasing. If the Dao neither arises nor ceases, how can the emotions feel joy or aversion? To follow it is to find all things fitting.

**Phonetic Gloss**
*"Shā shēng zhě bù sǐ"*: Li says: *Shā* means "to lose"; to lose life is not to die. Cui says: To eliminate the pursuit of life is to "kill life."
*"Shēng shēng zhě bù shēng"*: Li says: To cling to life is not to live. Cui says: To constantly pursue life is to "generate life."

**12. Commentary**
To allow things to follow their own course—thus nothing is not escorted.

**13. Commentary**
To allow things to come of their own accord—thus nothing is not welcomed.

**Commentary**
*Jiāng* means "to send off." The Dao, as a thing, aids and saves without fixed method. Though it neither perishes nor arises, it also arises and perishes. Thus it welcomes boundless life and sends off measureless death.

**14. Commentary**
To allow things to destroy themselves—thus nothing is not destroyed.

**15. Commentary**
To allow things to complete themselves—thus nothing is not completed.

**Commentary**
Without sending, yet sending—nothing is not destroyed; without welcoming, yet welcoming—nothing is not brought to completion.

**16. Commentary**
One who merges with things is entangled when they are entangled, yet never fails to remain at peace.

**Commentary**
*Yíng* means disturbance; *níng*, stillness. The sage, compassionate and beneficent, aids all beings with the Dao. Though nameless in essence, they assume names in response to things. Moving yet ever still, though entangled, they remain at peace.

**Phonetic Gloss**
*Yíng*: Guo reads as *yíng*; Xu as *yú yíng*; Li as *yú yíng*. Cui says: To be bound or attached.
◎ Jia Shifu says: Zhao Qi’s commentary on the *Mencius* defines *yíng* as "pressure." When the views of life and death press upon the mind, and the mechanisms of welcoming, completing, destroying, and sending press from without—yet the heart remains unmoved—this is called *yíng níng*. Placing oneself amid the tumult of flourishing change, where conflicts and collisions abound, yet the mind remains fundamentally at peace—this is near to perfection. Thus it is said: "Only after entanglement does one achieve completion."

**17. Commentary**
If things are entangled yet one alone remains untangled, this is ruin. To be entangled yet follow along—thus nothing fails to be perfectly accomplished.

**Commentary**
Only by harmonizing light and dust, moving yet ever still, can one then respond to the entanglements of things and skillfully bestow life and completion.

**Textual Note**
(1) The missing character in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript adds *gù* ("thus") before *shā*.
(2) The Shide Hall edition reads *yǐ* ("already") as *yǐ* ("thus").

Nanbo Zikui said, “Where alone did you hear this?”

**Commentary**
Zikui marveled at Yuyu’s discourse, so lofty and wondrous was its Dao, and thus asked, “From what place did you alone come to hear this?” From this point onward, there are nine layers: the first six pertain to teaching, the latter three to principle—all are the words by which Yuyu instructed Zikui.

She replied, “I heard it from the son of Deputy Ink. The son of Deputy Ink heard it from the grandson of Recitation. The grandson of Recitation heard it from Gazing Clarity. Gazing Clarity heard it from Whispered Assent. Whispered Assent heard it from Waiting Service. Waiting Service heard it from Singing Praise. Singing Praise heard it from Dark Obscurity. Dark Obscurity heard it from Triply Remote. Triply Remote heard it from Doubtful Origin.”

**Commentary**
*Zhu* means “of.” *Fu* means “deputy.” *Mo* means “ink”; ink refers to writing. Since principle gives rise to teaching, writing is called the “deputy.” Just as fish are caught only through the trap, principle is made clear only through teaching. Thus I heard it from writing, for it was by means of written words that understanding first arose.

**Exegetical Note**
Li [Yi] says: *Fu mo* means “that which can serve as deputy to the dark and the inked.” Cui [Yuan] says: All these names below are those of ancients, or perhaps merely figurative—there were no such persons.

**Commentary**
What faces the text is called *fu mo* (“deputy ink”); what turns away from the text is called *luo song* (“recitation”). At first, one relies on the text to generate understanding, thus grasping and reciting it. Next, one gradually awakens to its principle, and so recites it in a flowing manner. Moreover, since teaching arises from principle, it is called the “son”; and since recitation arises from teaching, it is called the “grandson.”

**Exegetical Note**
Li [Yi] says: *Song* means “to penetrate.” It encompasses and flows without obstruction.

**Commentary**
*Zhan* means “to see,” and also “to reach.” Through diligent recitation and the accumulation of effort over time, one gradually perceives the ultimate principle, and the inner chamber of the spirit becomes luminous.

**Exegetical Note**
*Zhan ming*: pronounced *zhan*. Li [Yi] says: “Spiritual clarity, thoroughly penetrating.”

**Commentary**
*Nie* means “to ascend,” and also “to whisper in the ear.” Having delved deeply into recitation and awakened to principle through teaching, the heart rejoices, and one privately assents, whispering to oneself. Though one has heard the Dao, one does not yet dare to practice it openly—this is also a gradual ascent into the wondrous subtlety of the profound.

**Exegetical Note**
*Nie xu*: Xu [Yun] reads *nie* as *nie* (to grasp). Li [Yi] says: *Xu* means “to grant.” To grasp and preserve it, without bestowing it anywhere.

**Commentary**
*Xu* means “to await.” *Yi* means “to employ,” and also “to practice.” Though one privately assents and the light of wisdom gradually brightens, one must still rely on teaching and follow it diligently, practicing without laziness. If one slackens and does not practice, the Dao cannot be attained.

**Exegetical Note**
*Xu yi*: Xu [Yun] reads *xu* as *xu* (“to await”); Li [Yi] reads it as *ru* (“weak”), saying: “Weakness is service.” Wang [Bi] says: *Xu* means “to wait”; *yi* means “to nurture and transform.”

**Commentary**
*Ou* means “song.” Having awakened to principle through teaching and practiced in accord with understanding, one’s abundant kindness becomes manifest, and songs of praise fill the roads.

**Exegetical Note**
*Yu*: pronounced *wu*, or as written. *Ou*: Xu [Yun] reads it as *wu hou*; Li [Xiang] reads it as *xiang yu*, saying: *Ou* means “to nurture,” the appearance of desiring transformation. Wang [Bi] says: *Ou* means “song.”

**Commentary**
Dark Obscurity is so named because it is what is called “non-being” yet is not non-being.

**Commentary**
*Xuan* is the name for what is profound and distant. *Ming* is the term for what is dark and still. Having inwardly merged virtue and outwardly manifested its fragrance, one gradually ascends to the ultimate void, thus reaching Dark Obscurity.

**Exegetical Note**
Li [Yi] says: *Xuan* is a forced name for what is dark; when one looks upon it, it is obscure. Xiang [Xiu] and Guo [Xiang] say: It is so named because it is what is called “non-being” yet is not non-being.

**Commentary**
One who ascends by means of names to reach non-being must attain non-being beyond names. Thus, though it is called Dark Obscurity, it is still not the ultimate, and so it is further entrusted to Triply Remote—this is the “profound within the profound.”

**Commentary**
*Can* means “three.” *Liao* means “remote.” The first is the remoteness of being, the second the remoteness of non-being, and the third neither being nor non-being—thus it is called “triply remote.” Though the realm of Dark Obscurity is wondrous, it is not yet the ultimate, and so only when one reaches the triply remote does one enter the doubly profound.

**Exegetical Note**
*Can*: pronounced *can*. *Liao*: Xu [Yun] reads it as *liao*. Li [Yi] says: *Can* means “lofty.” Lofty, distant, and vast—it cannot be named.

**Commentary**
The principle of spontaneity is such that it is formed through the accumulation of practice. One ascends from the near to the far, refines from the coarse to the fine, and thus only after seven layers does one reach the name of non-being, and only after nine layers does one doubt that non-being is the origin.

**Commentary**
The Dao transcends the four propositions and leaves behind the hundred negations; names and speech are cut off, and the mind’s knowing ceases. Though one has reached the triply remote, its wondrousness is not yet exhausted. Beyond the triply remote lies the root of the Dao—what is called the realm of the doubly profound, the gate of the myriad wonders. Even so, it is difficult to speak of it with precision. Thus, though it is not the origin, it is the origin; though it is the origin, there is no definite origin to which it can be traced. Doubtfully naming it the origin, yet there is no certain origin to which it can be traced—thus it is called Doubtful Origin.

**Exegetical Note**
Li [Yi] says: One further doubts that non-being is the origin, for the origin is not the name of non-being. *Yan cu*: pronounced *yan cu*. *Qi chong*: pronounced *qi chong*. The same below.

Zisi, Ziyu, Zili, and Zilai said to one another, “Who can take non-being as the head, life as the spine, and death as the tailbone? Who knows that death and life, existence and extinction, are of one body? I would befriend such a one.”

Four men looked at one another and smiled, their hearts in perfect accord, and so they became friends.

**Exegetical Note**
The identities of Zisi and the other three are unverified. Observing their thoughts and conduct, they were all men beyond the mundane world, their affections as pure as still water, forging a bond of unadorned fellowship. They shared a mutual resonance in the realm of the empty and profound, and a communion of wordless understanding in the supreme Dao. Now, man arises from the void and nothingness, and nothingness precedes all—thus nothingness is taken as the head. From nothingness life emerges, and life follows in sequence—thus life is taken as the spine. Having been born, one must die, and death comes last—thus death is taken as the tailbone. Such is the natural order. Though head and tailbone differ, they belong to the same body; though death and life appear distinct, they share a single source. One who grasps this truth finds all circumstances fitting, how then could there be joy or aversion toward existence or extinction? Whoever understands this, I would befriend.

**Phonetic Gloss**
*Zisi*: Cui [Yuan] says: In the *Huainanzi*, he is called Ziyong, who at fifty-four suffered from a hunched back.
◎ Qingfan’s note: Cui’s text reads Ziyong, which is correct. The present version of the *Huainanzi*’s “Spiritual Essence” chapter writes Ziqiu, differing from Cui’s edition. Gu Qianli says: *Qiu* should be *yong*. The *Baopuzi*’s “Abundant Analogies” chapter states, “Ziyong marveled at the greatness of heavenly principles,” where the character is correctly written as *yong*. *Yong* and *qiu* are graphically similar, and such mutual errors abound in the classics and transmitted texts.
*Ziyu*: Also written as *Yu*, pronounced *yu*.
*Zili*: Pronounced *li xi*.
*Tailbone*: Pronounced *ku gao*.

Their gaze met and the Dao was present—thus they looked at one another and smiled. Their hearts moved in harmony with the profound principle—thus they were in perfect accord. Soon after, Ziyu fell ill, and Zisi went to inquire after him. He said, “How wondrous is the Creator! To reduce me to this crooked state! My back is hunched, my spine curved, my five viscera exposed above, my chin tucked into my navel, my shoulders towering above my crown, and my nape pointing skyward.” The qi of yin and yang had fallen into disorder, yet his heart remained at ease and untroubled. Hobbling to the well, he gazed at his reflection and said, “Alas! The Creator has once again reduced me to this crooked state!”

Friendship required that he visit his ailing companion, so he followed the principle of things and went—unfettered by what lay beyond the bounds of proper conduct.

"Great indeed is the Creator!" *Wei* means "great." *Zaowu* is akin to *zaohua*, the creative force. *Juju* describes a cramped, contracted, and unyielding state. The vast furnace of creation forges all things without partiality—how could it single out my body alone to afflict with this cramped and twisted malady? In this light, it is nothing but fate. Ziyu, understanding the principle, thus sighed these words.

The hunchbacked curve of his spine left his back bones exposed. Bent forward and unable to straighten, his viscera pressed upward; his chin sank into his navel, his shoulders rose above his crown, and his nape curved like a hook, the great vertebra jutting like a growth. The qi of yin and yang had fallen into disorder and disharmony, leaving his entire body stricken with this severe affliction.

Yet he did not take it as a calamity. Life and death are but one body—how could illness and suffering disturb his heart? Though his form was crooked and contracted, his spirit remained at ease, untroubled by it all.

*Piánxiān*: the gait of one dragging a limp. Hobbling with effort, he approached the well and gazed at his reflection. Seeing his own appearance, he could not help but sigh in lament. For the great Dao follows nature, and the Creator treats all things equally—how could it single me out alone for this cramped and twisted fate? He voiced this sigh to make plain the principle of things.

Zisi said, "Do you resent it?"

Ziyu replied, "No, why should I resent it? Suppose the gradual transformation turned my left arm into a rooster—I would use it to crow at the hours of the night. Suppose it turned my right arm into a crossbow—I would use it to hunt owls for roasting. Suppose it turned my tailbone into a wheel and my spirit into a horse—I would ride them, needing no other mount.

Moreover, to gain is a matter of timing, to lose is a matter of following the natural course. Abiding in the proper time and following the natural course, sorrow and joy cannot enter. This is what the ancients called 'suspended release,' yet those who cannot release themselves are bound by things. Furthermore, things have long been unable to overcome Heaven—what is there for me to resent?"

"In the phrase *'I would use it to crow at the hours of the night'* (《予因以求时夜》), one edition omits *'seek'* (求). *'Crossbow'* (弹) is pronounced *tú dàn*. *'Owl'* (鸮) is pronounced *hù jiāo*. *'Roast'* (炙) is pronounced *zhì*.

When one encounters the proper time, the world calls it *'gain.'*

Time does not pause even for a moment; following its course and departing, the world calls it *'loss.'*

Gain is birth, loss is death. Sudden gain comes when the time accords with life; swift loss follows when death aligns with principle. Thus, abiding in the proper time, one does not rejoice in life; dwelling in the natural course, one does not resent death. Since there is neither joy nor aversion, how can sorrow or delight enter?

If one cannot release oneself, the myriad things will bind one together. Therefore, those who can release themselves are unbound by anything, while those who cannot release themselves are bound by everything.

Abiding in the natural course and forgetting time, one remains detached and unentangled—this is what the ancients called *'suspended release.'* But those who, while alive, fret over death and harbor aversion in their hearts cannot release themselves inwardly and are thus bound by external things."

(As previously noted, "suspended release" signifies freedom from all attachments.)

Guo Xiang comments: *"Suspended release"* means being unbound by anything.

Another passage states: Heaven cannot be without day and night—how can I be without death and life, and why should I resent them?

The commentary explains: The dark heavens above still alternate between day and night; how much less can man, dwelling in the world, avoid the transformations of life and death? Moreover, things cannot overcome Heaven—this has always been so. Who am I to harbor aversion alone?

Shortly after, Zilai fell ill, gasping as if on the verge of death. His wife and children gathered around, weeping. Zili went to visit him and shouted: “Away! Begone! Do not disturb the transformation!” Leaning against the doorframe, he said to him: “How wondrous is the Creator! What will it make of you next? Where will it send you? Will it fashion you into a mouse’s liver? Or into the arm of an insect?”

Zili’s commentary states: *Huán* means "to encircle." *Chuǎnchuǎn* describes labored breathing. Shortly after Ziyu finished speaking, Zilai fell ill once more, his breath raging as if near death. As the moment of passing approached, his wife and children gathered around him, weeping.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Chuǎnchuǎn* is read *chuǎnzhuǎn* (川轉反), or alternatively *chǐruǎn* (尺軟反). Cui’s edition writes it as *zhuìzhuì* (惴惴). *Huán ér* is read as written, or Xu pronounces it *huàn*. Li explains: "to encircle."

---

The annotation explains: Death and life are but waking and dreaming. In principle, one should accept sleep—why wish to be startled from it? The transformation of death is likewise fitting; there is no cause to be alarmed by it.

The commentary states: *Chì* is a sound of rebuke. The man who roams beyond the worldly sees death and life as one, yet when a friend nears the end, he visits with harmonious light. Thus he rebukes the family, bidding them stand back, for the transformation should not be disturbed.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Chì bì* is read *chìshī* (昌失反). *Wú dá* is read *dīngdá* (丁達反). Cui’s edition writes it as *dá* (靼), pronounced *dá*. *Dá* means "to startle." Zheng Zhong’s annotation of the *Zhouli Kaogongji* reads: "cannot be startled," confirming this.

---

The commentary states: *Yòu* means "again." *Xī* means "what." *Shì* means "to go." Leaning against the doorframe, he observed the transformation and spoke to him. He marveled at the great Creator, vast and impartial, who by chance made him a man, only to return him to change in an instant. Beyond this, where would he go? Into what would he transform? Would his five viscera become a mouse’s liver? Or his four limbs the arm of an insect? Yet wherever transformation leads, all is fitting.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Yǐ qí* is read *yúqǐ* (于綺反). As Xiang explains: "merely discarded into the earth." Wang says: "taking the most insignificant and base." *Chóng bì* (虫臂) is also written as *chóng cháng* (虫肠). Cui’s edition concurs.

---

Zilai said: "For parents, a child follows their command, whether east or west, north or south. Yet the yin and yang of Heaven are even more to man than parents. If they bring me near death and I refuse to heed them, then I am the one who is obstinate—what fault lies with them?

The great earth bears me in form, wearies me with life, eases me with age, and rests me in death. Thus to honor my life is to honor my death.

Now, if a great smith were to cast metal, and the metal leapt up crying, ‘I must become a *Mo* sword!’ the smith would surely deem it an ill-omened metal. Yet when one is cast into the form of a man and cries, ‘A man! A man!’ the Creator must surely deem him an ill-omened man.

Now, if I take Heaven and Earth as a great furnace and the Creator as a great smith, where could I go and not be fitting?" Then he fell into a deep slumber and awoke with a start.

---

The annotation explains: From ancient times, some have defied their parents’ commands, but none have defied the changes of yin and yang or resisted the cycles of day and night.

The commentary states: From here onward is Zilai’s response to Zili as he neared death. A filial son obeys his parents’ commands without hesitation—how much more so the yin and yang of creation, which surpass even one’s parents! Thus while defying a parent’s teaching may occur in the world, resisting yin and yang has never been done.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Bù chì* is read *shīzhī* (詩知反).

---

The annotation explains: Death and life are but day and night, not so distant. When the time for death comes, it is not forbidden, yet to stubbornly refuse it is to resist principle and hasten one’s end. The swiftness of death arises from my obstinacy, not from death itself. *Bǐ* refers to death; since I am alive, I regard death as *bǐ* (the other).

The commentary states: *Bǐ* refers to the Creator. Within the workings of creation, I am brought near death. If I detest death and refuse to follow, then I am the one who resists yin and yang, who rebels against transformation. The fault lies with me—what crime is theirs? Guo’s annotation takes *bǐ* as death.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Bǐ jìn* is read as written. *Zé hàn* is also written as *hàn* (捍), read *hándàn* (胡旦反), or *hàn* (旱). The *Shuowen* states: *hàn* means "to resist."

---

The annotation explains: Principle is always thus.

The commentary states: This reiterates the earlier passage to confirm its meaning. The words are precise, hence their repetition. The explanation of the text does not differ from the previous intent.

---

The annotation explains: "A man! A man!"—he wishes only to remain a man. This is like the metal leaping up, for all know such metal is ill-omened, yet they cannot allow it to transform of its own accord. The Dao of transformation encounters all things without exception. Now, to encounter the form of a man—was this done intentionally? Life is not made by design; it arises of itself in time. To cling to it is surely delusion!

The *Commentary* states: *Xiáng* (祥) means "good." *Fàn* (犯) means "to encounter." *Mò* (镆) is the name of an ancient fine sword. In former times, Ganjiang of Wu forged swords for the King of Wu. His wife was named Moye, so the male sword was named Ganjiang and the female sword Moye. The great furnace and mighty forge smelt and cast metal and iron, shaping them according to the size of the vessel, all without exception. Yet the metal within the furnace suddenly leapt and bounded, earnestly entreating to become a fine sword. The smith was astonished and sighed, deeming it inauspicious. This is like the great forge of nature, carving and shaping all forms—birds, beasts, fish, and insects—each made in its kind. If by chance it becomes a man, one rejoices and cherishes it, earnestly entreating to remain a man. Yet within the workings of creation, this is deemed an ill omen.

The *Exegesis* reads: *Wǒ qiě* (我且) is read as written. Xu reads it as *zǐyú* (子余反). *Mò* (镆) is pronounced *mò* (莫). *Jī* () is read *sìjiē* (似嗟反). *Mò* is the name of a sword.

The *Annotation* explains: All know that metal bound to a fixed form is inauspicious. Thus, by clarifying that one is no different from such metal, the attachment to form may be dissolved. Once dissolved, there is nothing that cannot be.

The *Commentary* states: The two forces of creation are like a furnace and forge, molding and shaping all things, hammering and tempering all living beings. Vast and impartial, they nurture all equally. Whatever is encountered is fitting—what aversion or delight could there be? In the unfolding of transformation, there is nowhere it cannot go.

The *Exegesis* reads: *Dàlú* (大炉) is read *liènú* (劣奴反). *Wū* (恶) is read *wū* (乌). *Kějiě* (可解) is read as written, as below.

The *Annotation* explains: One remains at ease in waking and sleeping, unburdened by thoughts of life and death.

The *Commentary* states: *Chéngrán* (成然) describes a state of leisurely detachment; *qúrán* (蘧然) describes a state of startled joy. *Mèi* (寐) means "to sleep," likened to death. *Jué* (觉) means "to wake," likened to life. Though waking and sleeping differ, when has one not been at ease and carefree? Though life and death are distinct, have they ever not followed fate in free wandering? This concludes the passage where Zilai treats life and death as waking and sleeping.

The *Exegesis* reads: *Chéngrán* (成然) is read as written; Cui concurs. Li says: *Chéngrán* describes a state of relaxed release. Some versions write it as *xū* (戌), read *xù* (恤). Jianwen says it should be *miè* (灭). Another version writes it as *kuò* (□), read *hūkuò* (呼括反), meaning "to look upward." Another version writes it as *éran* (俄然). *Qúrán* (蘧然): Li reads it *qú* (渠). Cui writes it as *jù* (据), also read *qíjù* (其据反). *Qúrán* describes a state of having form. *Jué* (觉) is read *gǔxiào* (古孝反).

Where the Cui edition adds the line *"Fārán hàn chū"* (发然汗出), it notes: "Without constraint, the fluids flow freely." Cui comments: "When *róng* and *wèi* (营卫) harmonize and circulate, one does not fear transformation."

**Collation Notes:**
(1) In the Zhao Jianyi edition, *hàn* (悍) is written as *hàn* (捍).
(2) The character *zhī* (之) is omitted following the Shide Tang edition.
(3) The *Quēwù* (阙误) cites an ancient edition where *chéng* (成) is written as □, stating: "□ is pronounced *hūguō* (呼聒切), meaning 'to look upward.'" It also reads *hōng* (烘), with *méng* (蒙) and □, meaning "obscure."

Zisang Hu, Mengzi Fan, and Ziqin Zhang became friends, saying to one another: "Who can join together in non-joining, act for one another in non-acting? Who can ascend to heaven and wander through mist, twisting and turning without limit, forgetting life and facing no end?" The three looked at one another and smiled, their hearts in perfect accord, and so became friends.

**Note 1:**
**Commentary:** Those who embody heaven and earth and darkly merge with transformation—though hands and feet serve different functions, and the five viscera have distinct offices—never join together, yet all joints harmonize as one. This is joining in non-joining. Never acting for one another, yet inner and outer mutually aid each other. This is acting in non-acting. If one were to strain the mind to care for the limbs or move the thighs and arms to manage the viscera, the more one tended to them, the more inner and outer would falter. Thus, one who takes the world as a single body harbors no partiality in action.

**Exegesis:** These three were all transcendent men, darkly merged with transformation, unified in life and death. With shared aspirations and conduct, they became friends. Each followed their true nature and expressed their sentiments, saying: Who can be friends in the spontaneity of emptiness? This is joining without joining, acting without acting—acting without intent to act, joining without intent to join. Like the five viscera, six senses, four limbs, and hundred bones, each has its office and function, mutually serving one another. Yet where is the heart in joining, or attachment in closeness or distance? Though without intent to act for one another, the work of mutual aid is accomplished. Thus, to join in non-joining and act as friends in non-acting—such is the meaning here.

**Philological Notes:**
*Xiāngyǔ* (相与): as written. Cui says: "like kinship." Alternatively read *yù* (豫).
*Xiāngwéi* (相为): as written. Alternatively read *yúwěi* (于伪反).
*Àiwéi* (爱为): read *yúwěi* (于伪反).

**Note 2:**
**Commentary:** Without anything one cannot undertake.

**Exegesis:** *Náo tiǎo* (挠挑) means "to turn and twist." Ascending to heaven shows lofty lightness; wandering through mist shows non-attachment. Thus, one can follow transformation without end, turning and twisting with the Creator.

**Philological Notes:**
*Náo* (挠): Xu reads *érshǎo* (而少反); Guo, Xu, and Yao read *xūyáo* (许尧反).
*Tiǎo* (挑): Xu reads *túliǎo* (徒了反); Guo and Li read *túyáo* (徒尧反). Also written as *zhào* (兆). Li says: "*Náo tiǎo* means 'to turn and twist,' to turn and twist in the vast and boundless." Jianwen says: "the name of circulation."

**Note 3:**
**Commentary:** Forgetting life, one forgets all, and so can follow transformation and change, all without end.

**Exegesis:** *Zhōngqióng* (终穷) means death. Forgetting life and forgetting death, life and death merge as one, and so one follows transformation without end.

**Note 4:**
**Commentary:** If so, how can this be called friendship? It merely illustrates the utmost closeness without the nearness of partial affection.

**Exegesis:** Words forgotten in the realization of meaning, they looked at one another and smiled. Minds darkly merged with the realm, their hearts were in perfect accord. With shared transcendence, they became friends.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) In the Shide Tang edition, *biàn* (变) is written as *ér* (而). The Zhao Jianyi edition omits *fū* (夫) and *zhě* (者).
(2) In the Shide Tang edition, *guān* (官) is written as *guǎn* (管). The Zhao edition renders these two lines as: "though hands, feet, and five viscera differ."

Later, Zisang Hu died, his body unburied. Confucius, hearing of it, sent Zigong to assist with the rites. One strummed a zither, another plucked a lute, and together they sang in harmony: "Alas, Zisang Hu! Alas, Zisang Hu! You have returned to your true nature, while we remain as men—alas!" Zigong hurried forward and said: "May I ask if singing before the corpse is in accord with ritual?"

**Note 1:**
**Exegesis:** *Mò* (莫) means "none."

The three gazed at one another, silent and wordless. In but a brief moment, Zisang Hu died. When Confucius heard of it, he sent Zigong to offer condolences and instructed him to provide for the funeral arrangements and receive the guests. This was to reveal the distinction between those within and beyond the worldly norms—thus, the roles of the Master and Qin Zhang were invoked.

**Collation Notes:**
*Mòrán* (莫然) is read as written. Cui [Yuan] says: "settled."
*Yǒu xián* (有闲) is read as written. Cui [Yuan] and Li [Xun] say: "a moment." Originally also written as *wéi xián* (为闲).
◎Qing Fan’s note: *Yǒu* (有) in the *Shiwen* is written as *wéi* (为). *Wéi xián* (为闲) is equivalent to *yǒu xián* (有闲). The meaning of *wéi* (为) as "to have" is widely attested. In the *Mencius*, *Teng Wen Gong* chapter: "Whether one will be a gentleman or a rustic," Zhao Qi’s annotation says: "*Wéi* (为) means 'to have'—even a small state has gentlemen and rustics." Again, in the *Disciple* section: "The disciples were silent for a moment," the annotation says: "*Wéi xián* (为闲) means 'a brief moment.'" In the *Jin Xin* chapter: "*Wéi xián* (为闲) without use," the annotation says: "*Wéi xián* (为闲) means 'a moment.'" In the *Liang Hui Wang* chapter: "Simply extend what they do," the *Shuo Yuan*, *Gui De* chapter, quotes *Mencius* with *wéi* (为) as *yǒu* (有). In the *Yan Ce*: "Thus, I dare not offer excuses," the *Xin Xu*, *Za Shi* chapter, writes *wéi* (为) as *yǒu* (有). All serve as evidence.

**[Section 2]**
**[Subcommentary]** *Qū* (曲) means "thin" or "flimsy." Some weave coarse mats or play the zither and sing in harmony, rejoicing together without a trace of sorrow. This is what is called "forgetting life in life," the ultimate attainment beyond the worldly realm.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Biān qū* (編曲): *Bì lián* (必連) in Fanqie; *Bù qiān* (布千) in *Zìlín*; *Fǔ tiǎn* (父殄) in Guo’s reading; *Fǔ lián* (甫連) in *Records of the Grand Historian*.
Li [Yun] says: *Qū* (曲) refers to silkworm trays.

*Xiāng hè* (相和): *Hú wò* (胡卧) in Fanqie.

**[Section 3]**
**[Commentary]** Weeping when others weep is a mark of worldly convention. To equalize life and death, forget grief and joy, and sing before a corpse—this is the ultimate attainment beyond the worldly realm.

**[Subcommentary]** "Alas, come!" is the sound of the song. The lines from "Sanghu" onward are the lyrics of their harmony. *Yī* (猗) is the sound of their responsive singing. For from nonbeing arises being, and this is called life; from being returns nonbeing, and this is called death. Now that you have returned to emptiness and stillness, you have reverted to the root and returned to the true. Yet I still dwell as a sojourner among men, a traveler who has not returned to his mulberry and catalpa. Thus, to equalize life and death, I utter this sigh of *yī*.

◎ Li Zhen says: "Alas, come!" is the sound of the song, yet it is also an expression of lament. *Shì Míng: Shì Yányǔ* states: *Jiē* (嗟) means "to assist"; when words are insufficient to express one’s intent, one utters this sound to aid oneself. *Lái* (來) means "grief"; it draws grief into oneself, hence the words are spoken with a lowered head to summon it. Mencius, turning back, and Ziqin Zhang lament that Sanghu has already returned to the true, and so they sing this song.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Wǒ yóu* (我犹): Cui’s edition has *dú* (独).
*Rén yī* (人猗): *Yú yí* (于宜) in Fanqie. Cui says it is a particle.
*Āi lè* (哀樂): Pronounced *luò* (洛).

**[Section 4]**
**[Subcommentary]** The rites of the worldly realm value restraint and decorum. Even when a neighbor dies, one does not pound grain in mourning. How much less should one remain indifferent before a friend’s corpse, playing the zither and singing as usual—how could this be in accord with ritual? Zigong, astonished at this, hastened forward to ask.

**[Collation]**
(1) The *Shì Dé Táng* edition has *shì* (侍) instead of *dài* (待). *Quē Wù* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition as having *shì* (侍).
(2) The character *shǐ* (使) follows *Shì Míng*.

The two looked at each other and laughed, saying: "How could he know the meaning of ritual!"

**[Commentary]** One who understands the meaning of ritual must wander beyond to order what is within, guard the mother to preserve the child, and follow the truth of one’s feelings without deviation. If one is instead constrained by reputation and bound by form, then filial piety cannot bear sincerity, and kindness cannot bear reality. Father and son, elder and younger brother, harbor feelings and deceive one another—how could this be the great meaning of ritual?

**[Subcommentary]** The great ritual moves in harmony with Heaven and Earth, unbound by form or name. It directly attains authenticity, following feelings without restraint. How much more so when one profoundly unites life and death—how could grief or joy remain in the heart? Yet Zigong is a Confucian scholar of the worldly realm, his nature still partial and attached. He values only coarse traces and has not grasped the wondrous root. What does such a person know of the depth of ritual? To be mocked by those beyond the worldly realm is only fitting.

**[Exegesis]**
*《恶知》* pronounced "wū," same below.
*《称情》* pronounced "chènɡ qínɡ" (chǐ zhènɡ fǎn).
Zǐgòng returned and reported to Confucius, saying: “What manner of men are they? They cultivate no conduct, yet cast off their bodily forms. Facing the corpse, they sang—countenance unchanged—beyond any name to call them. What manner of men are they?”

**[1]**
**[Subcommentary]**
*命* means "name." Zǐgòng returned to report to the Master, saying: Those two men’s feelings and affairs are hard to fathom. They cultivate their own virtue and power, yet possess no ritual propriety, forgetting and casting off bodily form, merging life and death as one. Facing the funeral, they sang with joy—spirit and form unchanged. Since their Dao cannot be fathomed, it is difficult to name them.

**[Exegesis]**
*《无以命之》* Cui and Li say: *命* means "name."

Confucius said: “They are those who wander beyond the bounds of the world, while I wander within them. Outer and inner do not reach one another, and had I sent you to offer condolences, I would have been crude indeed. They are now becoming companions to the Creator, wandering in the single qi of Heaven and Earth. They regard life as an excrescent hanging tumor, death as the bursting of an abscess. If this is so, how could they know where life and death, before and after, reside? Borrowing from other things, entrusting themselves to a shared body, they forget their liver and gall, abandon their ears and eyes. Reversing and repeating, beginning and ending, they know not where it starts or ends. Vast and drifting beyond the dust and grime, they wander carefree in the work of non-action. How could they possibly trouble themselves with the muddled rites of worldly custom, performing for the eyes and ears of the crowd?”

**[1]**
**[Commentary]**
There is an ultimate principle where inner and outer merge. None who attain the utmost wandering beyond fail to merge with the inner, just as none who merge within fail to wander without. Thus the sage constantly wanders beyond to merge within, acting without intent to follow what is, so that though all day long he manifests form, his spirit and qi remain unchanged. Though he bends and rises amid ten thousand affairs, he is serene and at ease. To see form without reaching spirit is the common burden of the world. Thus, seeing him move among things, none can say he has left things behind or departed from men. Seeing him transform in body and respond to affairs, none can say he sits in forgetfulness, self-content. How could one say the sage is not thus? One must say this is not the ultimate principle. Therefore, Zhuangzi, in clarifying the lineage of the great stream to awaken the world, does not directly attribute this to Confucius. Otherwise, some might rely on what they see to reject it. Thus he transcends the sage’s inner traces and entrusts the beyond to those few. One should forget this entrustment to seek the great meaning of his composition. Then the Dao of wandering beyond to merge within will be clearly and naturally evident, and Zhuangzi’s book will indeed be seen as a discourse that traverses the vulgar to surpass the world.

**[Subcommentary]**
*方* means "realm." Those two men equalize life and death, unbound by the traces of teaching, so their minds wander beyond the universe. While Confucius and Zǐgòng, great Confucians of their age, practice the righteousness of mourning and the rituals of measured conduct, are keenly intent on grief and joy, and wander within the bounds of the world—this is how they differ.

**[Exegesis]**
*《而淡》* pronounced "dàn" (tú zhàn fǎn).
*《而离》* pronounced "lí" (lì zhì fǎn), same below.
*《而应》* means "response," same below.
*《数子》* pronounced "shù zǐ" (suǒ zhǔ fǎn).
*《坦然》* pronounced "tǎn rán" (tǔ dàn fǎn).
◎ Qìngfān notes: *Wén Xuǎn*’s commentary on Xiè Língyùn’s poem "Departing the Capital for My Prefecture" and Xiàhóu Xiàoruò’s *Eulogy for Dōngfāng Shuò* both cite Sīmǎ’s gloss: *方* means "constant," saying they wander in mind beyond the constant teachings. The *Exegesis* omits this.

**[2]**
**[Commentary]**
Condolence is a mundane affair of the bounded world. To apply it to those beyond is crude indeed.

**[Subcommentary]**
Profound and Confucian principles are divided; inner and outer ways differ. Judging by superiority and inferiority, they do not reach one another. Using the vulgar rites of the bounded world to offer condolences to those beyond is like reusing straw dogs—crude in the extreme.

**[Exegesis]**
*《使女》* pronounced "rǔ," same below.

**[3]**
**[Commentary]**
All are obscured in it, thus there is no duality.

**[Subcommentary]**
Comprehending the transformations of yin and yang, one joins the Creator in forming pairs; embodying the undifferentiated unity of the ten thousand things, one roams within the single qi of the Two Modes.
◎ Wang Yinzhi notes: In the "Fit for Emperors and Kings" chapter, it says, *"I am about to join the Creator in forming pairs,"* and Guo [Xiang] comments: *"Allowing others to act of themselves."* In the "Revolutions of Heaven" chapter, it says, *"Qiu does not join in transformation to form pairs,"* and Guo comments: *"One who joins in transformation to form pairs allows things to transform of themselves."* Now, Guo did not understand the meaning of the word *ren* ("pairs"). *Ren* means "to pair"; *wei ren* ("to form pairs") is like saying "to form a pair." The *Doctrine of the Mean* says, *"The humane are those who form pairs,"* and Zheng [Xuan]’s commentary reads: *"Read as the *ren* in *xiang ren’ou* (‘to form a mutual pair’), meaning to preserve one another with human intention."* The *Mao Preface* to the *"Fei Feng"* poem says: *"Those who can divide and cook as pairs, those who can assist in governing the people along the Zhou Way as pairs."* The *Rites of Betrothal* commentary says: *"Bowing at every gate is to show respect by forming a pair."* The *Rites of Feasting a Great Officer* commentary says: *"Bowing at every turn and at the stele is to form a pair with one another."* Thus, *ren* and *ou* share the same meaning, which is why the Han era had the phrase *"forming mutual pairs."* The *"Originating in the Dao"* chapter of the *Huainanzi* says, *"Joining the Creator in forming pairs,"* the meaning of which is the same as here. (High commentary: *"For governance,"* which is incorrect. See the *Huainanzi* for cross-reference.)
The *"Equalizing Customs"* chapter says: *"Above, one befriends the divine luminaries; below, one joins the Creator in forming pairs."* This is clear evidence.
◎ Qingfan notes: The *Wen Xuan* commentary on Yan Yanzhi’s *"Preface to the Third Day of the Third Month at the Winding Waters"* cites Sima [Biao] as saying: *"The Creator is the Dao."* The commentaries on Ren Fang’s *"Letter to the Chief Clerk of the Grand Marshal,"* the *"Edict of Empress Xuande,"* Lu Ji’s *"Inscription on the Stone Pass,"* and Shen Yue’s *"Stele Inscription for the Deceased Prince of Anlu of Qi"* all cite Sima [Biao] as saying: *"The Creator refers to the Dao."* The *Exegesis* omits this.

**[4]**
**[Commentary]**
Like a wart that hangs of itself, a growth that attaches of itself—this is the qi gathering in its time, not something to delight in.

**[Exegesis]**
*《縣》* pronounced *xuán*. The commentary is the same.
*《疣》* pronounced *yóu*.

**[5]**
**[Commentary]**
Like an abscess that bursts of itself, an ulcer that festers of itself—this is the qi dispersing of itself, not something to regret.

**[Subcommentary]**
Those three masters were men who embodied the Dao, who comprehended life and death and were obscured in transformation. Thus, when qi gathers and life arises, it is like a wart or growth attaching and hanging—nothing to delight in; when qi scatters and death comes, it is like an abscess or ulcer bursting and festering—nothing to regret.

**[Exegesis]**
*《決》* Xu [Shen] reads *gǔ xuè*.
*《肒》* pronounced *huàn*.

◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The current text’s main passage also writes *疣* (with *尤* altered to *丸*), while the pronunciation and meaning give *疣*, read *hú qiú*; this is likely an arbitrary emendation. *《溃》* is read *hú duì*.

◎ Qing Fan’s collation: The *Yiqiejing Yinyi* (vol. 16, under the *Dafangguang Sanjie Jing*) cites Sima [Biao]’s gloss: “Floating heat is an *jū*; blockage is a *yōng*.” The same citation appears in vol. 30 (*Chiren Pusa Jing* 2), vol. 37 (*Zhunti Tuoluoni Jing*), and vol. 95 (*Zhengwu Jing*). The *Shiwen* omits this.

**[6]**
**[Commentary]**
Death and life alternate without end; moving with them, there is nowhere one cannot go—thus one does not know where victory or defeat lies.

**[Subcommentary]**
*先* means “victory”; *后* means “inferiority.” Warts, growths, abscesses, and ulcers are all ailments, yet qi gathers and scatters, and illness knows no victory or defeat. If one compares this to life and death, how can one know where superiority or inferiority lies?

**[7]**
**[Commentary]**
*假* means “to rely upon.” Now, in death and life, gathering and scattering, transformations are boundless—all are different things. There is nothing different that does not rely upon something, so what is relied upon, though different, together forms a single body.

**[Subcommentary]**
Water, fire, metal, and wood—different things rely upon one another; the many depend on this lodging to form a single body. Thus we know the bodily form has always been empty and false.

**[8]**
**[Commentary]**
Entrust it to the principle and proceed in darkness.

**[Subcommentary]**
Having realized that bodily form is empty and false, with nothing to delight in or cherish, one can inwardly forget the viscera and outwardly forget the sense organs.

**[9]**
**[Commentary]**
If even the five viscera are forgotten, what thing is left to recognize? Never having begun to recognize, one can thus roam freely on the path of transformation, darkly merging with the waves of reversal, and not know where beginning and end reach their limit.

**[Subcommentary]**
*端* means “thread”; *倪* means “boundary.” *反复* means “coming and going”; *终始* means “life and death.” Having forgotten bodily form and disabled the senses, one can go and come with life and death, moving together with transformation. Since transformation has no limit, none can know its threads or boundaries.

**[Exegesis]**
*《反复》* read *fāng fú*.
*《端倪》* some editions write *淣*, same character; read *yá*. Xu [Shen] reads *yì*.

**[10]**
**[Commentary]**
The so-called "non-doing as vocation" is not mere folded-hands silence; the so-called "beyond dust and grime" is not seclusion in mountains and forests.

**[Subcommentary]**
*芒然* describes the appearance of utter unknowing. *彷徨* and *逍遥* are both names for self-contented ease. *Dust and grime* refer to the conditioned things of form and sound. Having already relinquished bodily form, one here further forgets mind and intellect, thus roaming beyond the bonds of worldly dust, delighting in the clear and boundless realm, and making this non-doing one’s vocation.

**[Exegesis]**
*《芒然》* read *máng rán*. Li [Yi] says: the appearance of being unbound.
*《彷》* read *páng*. *《徨》* read *huáng*.
*《尘垢》* read as written. Cui [Zhuan] writes *冢□*, saying: *冢* read *zhǒng*; *□* same as *垢*. The people of Qi call wind-dust *□*.
◎ Lu Wenchang says: Formerly *□* was written *逢*; now it is written *摓*, a corruption of *□*. Here corrected.

**[11]**
**[Commentary]**
What they display for the multitude is all dust and grime—it is not the dark reality beyond the realm.

**[Subcommentary]**
*愦愦* means "confused and chaotic." Those several masters are lofty, empty, and serene, arranging nothing and following transformation, following their nature and acting with authenticity. How could they force themselves to observe ritual forms, bind themselves to worldly customs, or display solemn demeanor to please the eyes and ears of the crowd?

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*《愦愦》* read *gōng-nèi* (反切); the *Shuowen* and *Cangjie pian* both gloss it as "chaotic." *《以观》* read *gǔ-luàn* (反切), meaning "to display." The commentary is the same.

**[Collation Notes]**
(1) In the Shide Tang edition, *肒* is written as *疣*; the commentary is the same.
(2) The character *冥* follows the Zhao Jianyi edition. The same applies below. In the Shide Tang edition, the first *冥* is mistakenly written as *私*, and the second as *弘*.
(3) The character *见* follows the Shide Tang edition.
(4) The character *郑* follows the *Zhongyong* commentary.
(5) In the Shide Tang edition, *极* is written as *及*.

Zigong said: "In that case, to which *Dao* does the Master adhere?"

**[Commentary]**
Zigong had not heard of *xing* and the *Dao* of Heaven, so he saw what the Master adhered to but not *how* he adhered to it. That by which he adhered was non-adherence—how could the world perceive this?

**[Subcommentary]**
The *Dao* within the world and the *Dao* beyond it differ in depth. Not knowing which *Dao* the Master followed, Zigong, as disciple to teacher, raised this doubt.

Confucius said: "Qiu is a man under Heaven’s punishment. Nevertheless, I share this with you."

**[Commentary]**
Taking the *Dao* within the world as shackles, it clarifies that what is prized lies in the *Dao* beyond it. Those who roam beyond rely on what is within; those who depart from humanity align with custom. Thus, those who possess all under Heaven do not take all under Heaven as their own. Only by relinquishing things can one enter the multitude; only by sitting in forgetfulness can one respond to affairs. The more one relinquishes, the more one attains. If one dwells in this ultimate state, then even if one wished to cast it aside, principle would naturally come of its own—this is what neither Heaven nor humanity can pardon.

**[Subcommentary]**
The sagely traces and rituals of propriety are but shackles upon form and nature. Since Confucius adhered to the *Dao* within the world, he was by natural principle a man under Heaven’s punishment. Thus, the *Dechongfu* chapter states: "How can one escape Heaven’s punishment?"

**[Commentary]**
Though bound by the world’s shackles, he merely shared this with you. It makes clear that he himself ever remained beyond them.

**[Subcommentary]**
Confucius, the sage, harmonized his light with things and rode the waves of the world, valuing these common rites. Though he descended into the *Dao* within the world and shared it with you, his mind roamed beyond it, detached and unclinging.

Zigong said: "May I ask about this *Dao*?"

**[Commentary]**
He asks about the meaning of roaming beyond while sharing within.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Dao* here means "way." He asks: "Though your traces mingle in the world, your mind roams beyond it—how does this mysterious union of inner and outer come about?"

Confucius said: "Fish come together in water; humans come together in the *Dao*. Those who come together in water dig ponds to secure their sustenance; those who come together in the *Dao* find stability without effort. Thus it is said: Fish forget one another in rivers and lakes; humans forget one another in the arts of the *Dao*."

**[Subcommentary]**
*Come together* means "to go toward." For fish, nothing suits their nature more than deep water; for humans, nothing fulfills their intent more than the arts of the *Dao*. Though their emotions and wisdom differ, both follow this same pattern. This briefly sets forth the meaning, which is explained below.

**[Exegesis]**
*Xiangzao* (相造): read with the falling tone *qibao* (七报反), meaning "to go toward." The same applies below.

**[Annotation 2]**
Though what they go toward differs, both achieve their ends by acting without contrivance—uniting the outer with the inner—so that sustenance is secured and stability arises. All things follow this pattern without exception, yet none are aware of it, and thus the state of *wuwei* (non-action) is realized.

**[Subcommentary]**
This explains the preceding meaning. The Yangtze, lakes, Huai, and seas are all called "heavenly ponds." Fish dwell in the vastness of water, burrowing into mud and sand to nourish and sustain themselves. Likewise, humans abide in the great *Dao*, cultivating clarity and emptiness to nurture their nature, wandering freely without entanglement—thus attaining the tranquility and joy of their inherent stability.
