It is also said: "gold-adorned axes and halberds."

---

Now, the unprohibitable nature of Robber Zhi arises from the weight of what he steals. The weight of that gain arises from the sagely not treating it lightly. Thus, the eradication of theft lies in devaluing goods, not in exalting sageliness.

---

That Robber Zhi could command ninety thousand followers and rampage across the world was also due to the Five Virtues. Without sagely wisdom, how could this have been achieved? Thus, one knows that the driving of horses and plundering of people—unrestrainable as they are—originate in the errors of the sages’ creation of laws. Hence it is said: "Fish cannot be removed from the depths; the state’s sharp instruments cannot be displayed to others." Those sages are the state’s sharp instruments, not what should be made manifest to the world. Therefore, abolish sageliness and discard wisdom, and great theft will cease; cast away jade and shatter pearls, and petty theft will not arise; burn tallies and break seals, and the people will return to simplicity and rusticity; smash measuring cups and snap steelyards, and the people will not contend; annihilate and destroy the world’s sagely laws, and only then can the people be engaged in discussion. Uproot and disorder the six pitch-pipes, melt and sever the *yú* and *sè*, stop up Master Kuang’s ears, and the world’s people will begin to contain their hearing; obliterate patterns and disperse the five colors, glue shut Li Zhu’s eyes, and the world’s people will begin to contain their vision. Break and discard hooks and cords, cast away compasses and squares, snap off the fingers of Master Chui, and the world’s people will begin to possess their own skill. Thus it is said: "Great skill appears clumsy." Eradicate the conduct of Zeng and Shi, gag the mouths of Yang and Mo, cast aside benevolence and righteousness, and the world’s virtue will begin to attain profound unity. When people contain their vision, the world will not be dazzled; when people contain their hearing, the world will not be burdened; when people contain their knowledge, the world will not be deluded; when people contain their virtue, the world will not be perverse. Those like Zeng, Shi, Yang, Mo, Master Kuang, Master Chui, and Li Zhu all externally established their virtue and thereby confused and disordered the world—such are the methods that have no use.

---

Fish that lose the depths are captured by men; sharp instruments made manifest become resources for thieves—thus they cannot be displayed to others.

---

To lose is to be deprived. Sharp instruments refer to sagely traces. To display is to make manifest. Fish deprived of water are seized by creatures; sharp instruments made manifest are grasped by men—thus they cannot be.

---

The sages—these are men like Yao, Shun, Wen, and Wu. My late father observed: If one borrows the sages’ wisdom to reap their benefits, the world will all borrow and employ them, making them indeed the world’s sharp instruments. The world borrows the sages as sharp instruments, yet only fears that others will uncover what they conceal—thus there are none who can make them manifest.

---

Displaying sharp instruments to the world provides resources for its thieves and bandits.

---

The sages govern the world by responding to things and adapting to the times, yielding or wielding weapons, their conduct and concealment not uniform—they cannot be rigidly grasped and made manifest to the world. If grasped and acted upon, their flaws will inevitably emerge, as with King Kuai of Yan and the Duke of Bai.

---

To remove what thieves rely upon is to halt them without imposing prohibitions.

When sagely wisdom is discarded, all things under heaven abide by their proper roles, and theft ceases of itself.

To devalue what is prized is to end transgression without resorting to punishment.

Jade is left in the mountains, pearls in the rivers—when jewels and treasures are no longer esteemed, how can there be theft and excess?

To eliminate what deceit depends upon is to leave no means for cunning and artifice.

Seals and tallies serve as tokens of sincerity. Yet deceitful men rely on them to advance their schemes. Burn them, shatter them, and one may return to simplicity and rustic purity.

For what is small and level serves as the tool of what is great and uneven.

Scales and measures determine quantity and weight. Once stolen, they become the thief’s own resource. Smash and destroy them, aligning with the wisdom of the ancients, and strife will vanish.

When nothing is feigned outwardly, one’s inner nature remains whole and unspoiled, free from self-betraying words.

To exhaust and destroy: to annihilate and ruin. The sagely laws refer to the Five Powers. Having shattered the ways of the Three Kings and ruined those of the Five Emperors, the thatched hut and all else are obliterated, straw dogs no longer displayed. Forgetting the trap and the snare, self and other merge into profound unity—only then may one discuss the most subtle realms and expound upon the distant reaches of the Dao and virtue.

What is prized—sounds and sights, separation and distance—are what those with ears and eyes cherish. Yet life is allotted its portion, and to be drawn by what one prizes is to lose one’s nature and life. If instead one destroys what is prized and abandons external things to follow one’s own nature, then hearing and sight remain whole, and each person preserves their true essence.

The *yu* resembles the *sheng*, with pipes arranged within a gourd and reeds placed at the ends of the tubes. The *se* is eight feet and one inch long, one foot and eight inches wide, with twenty-seven strings, crafted by Fuxi. When the ears are seduced by the five notes, one admires the acuity of Master Kuang; when the eyes linger on dark and bright hues, one yearns for the vision of Li Zhu—thus the heart-mind races wildly, and ears and eyes are utterly exhausted.

Thereupon, one pulls out the pipes and severs the strings, melts away warp and weft; destroys the melody of *Huanghua*, discards the song of *Baixue*; erases the patterns of *fufu*, scatters the hues of red and purple. Thus, one glues shut the eyes of Li Zhu and removes the pretense of imitation; stops up the ears of Kuang and Gu and dispels the leaders of disorderly crowds. Only then do all people attain self-mastery, and things no longer diminish the self. The ears reach the limit of what they can hear yet return to hearing silence; the eyes indulge their power of sight yet inwardly perceive no color. The celestial mechanism unfolds of itself, reaching the perfection of non-action—how could there be any distinction of brightness or darkness, superiority or inferiority?

Thus, the world attains peace, and the myriad things share in virtue. Following one’s own hearing and seeing, each person preserves their acuity. To *preserve* is to nurture within.

The *se* was originally also written as *sheng*. To *stop up* Kuang and Gu: Cui’s edition has *stop up* as *block*, meaning to obstruct. ◊ Lu Wenchang notes: The present edition lacks the character *Gu*.

The spider and the dung beetle, though base, weave webs and roll pellets—if they did not seek this from master craftsmen, it is because each thing possesses its own ability. Though their abilities differ, none dares deviate from what they practice, and so what is skillful may appear clumsy. Thus, one who excels in employing others has those capable of squares make squares, those capable of circles make circles, each entrusted with what they can do. People rest in their natures, not demanding of the common folk the skill of Gongshu. Therefore, when the many arts do not imitate one another, they appear clumsy, yet when all under heaven rely on their own abilities, great skill is achieved.

To employ their innate abilities is to discard compass and square, rendering the fingers of the master craftsman superfluous.

Hooks curve; plumb lines straighten; compasses circle; squares square. Gongshu was a craftsman of Yao who devised the methods of compass and square—also said to be a minister of Shun. To *break* is to snap or sever. Gongshu, endowed with natural ingenuity, wielded hooks and plumb lines, carved and cut diverse forms, and established compass and square, thereby leading the black-haired people of the world to blindly imitate, abandoning themselves to follow things—this is the very cause. If one were to cast aside compass and square, sever hooks and plumb lines, and snap the fingers of Gongshu, then each person would master their own inner skill. It is like the spider’s web and the beetle’s pellet—what do they have to do with the work of craftsmen? It is the ingenuity of the celestial mechanism! The saying originates from the *Laozi*.

To *break*: Guo and Li read *shì* (burn), Xiang and Xu read *yào* (melt). Cui says: to burn and sever. The *yu*: Xu reads *yú*. The *se*: originally also written as *sheng*. ◊ Lu Wenchang notes: The old edition mistakenly wrote *name* instead of *sound*; corrected according to the *Dasheng* chapter. The *spider*: read *zhī*. The *beetle*: read *jié*. The *dung beetle*: read *qiāng*.

To remove the leaders who disrupt the multitude is to allow the world each to return to its place and unite in the mysterious virtue.

To *cut away*: to eliminate. *To clamp*: to shut. *To cast aside*: to reject. *Mysterious*: origin, the Dao. Zeng Shen was supremely filial, Shi Yu was loyal and upright, Yang Zhu and Mo Di were endowed with vast eloquence. These four masters, by their innate nature, led the scholars of the world to abandon themselves and imitate things, thereby disrupting the multitude and losing their original nature. Thus, one must cut away acts of loyalty and trust, clamp shut mouths of vain disputation, cast aside the stumbling benevolence, and discard the striving righteousness. Then things do not lose their truth, people all attain their own fulfillment, follow their nature and preserve its principle—thereby merging with the mysterious Dao.

*Of conduct*: Meng reads *xíng*. *To clamp*: Li reads *jùyán*, also *qíyán*. *To cast aside*: reads *rúyáng*. *The leader*: also written as *rate*, reads *suǒlèi*.

To *melt*: to disperse. *Burden*: care and suffering. Merely flaunting one’s intelligence brings about the accumulation of cares, causing the people to stumble and disperse. If one could embrace intelligence within and not display it outwardly, then all things would be content and free from care.

*Not to melt*: Zhu reads *shī*, reads *zhuó*. Cui says: not to destroy. Xiang reads *yào*.

If one can know one’s inner portion, cultivate virtue without excess, then one naturally treads the central path of the turning circle, roams the world without confusion—how could there be inversion or perversion in between?

*Not perverse*: reads *pìyì*.

These several figures, each endowed with diverse gifts, caused the world to leap and imitate them. In imitation, one loses oneself; losing oneself through them, they become the source of disorder. The greatest affliction of the world is the loss of oneself.

The aforementioned masters, all endowed with exceptional qualities, could not conceal their brilliance or hide their radiance. Instead, they stirred the waves and provoked the俗, flaunting their names to attract followers and dazzle the multitude. The world, bereft of virtue, failed to return to its root—this is the cause of losing one’s origin.

*To dazzle*: Xu reads *yào*. The *Three Cang* says: firelight consuming. Sima and Cui say: to scatter. *These several*: reads *suǒzhǔ*.

As for the proper use of standards: sight does not exceed what is seen, so all eyes are clear; hearing does not exceed what is heard, so all ears are keen; action does not exceed what is possible, so all skills are masterful; knowledge does not exceed what is known, so all natures are content; virtue does not exceed what is attained, so all virtues are fitting. Why establish what lies beyond one’s nature, causing the world to rush about and be unable to return to itself?

To act in accordance with nature, and every act arises from nature—this is the subtlety of standards. Yet the followers of Zeng and Shi, by drawing others to themselves, brought no benefit to their age and instead harmed posterity. Though they set these standards, they were ultimately of no use.

Do you alone not know the age of utmost virtue? In ancient times, there were Rongcheng, Datíng, Bohuang, Zhongyang, Lilu, Lixu, Xuanyuan, Hexu, Zunlu, Zhu Rong, Fuxi, and Shennong. In those days, the people used knotted cords for records. They found their food sweet, their clothing beautiful, their customs joyful, and their dwellings peaceful. Neighboring states were within sight, the sounds of chickens and dogs were within hearing, yet the people grew old and died without ever traveling between them. In such an age, there was perfect governance.

Now, however, it has come to this: the people crane their necks and stand on tiptoe, saying, “In such-and-such a place there is a worthy,” then carry provisions and rush toward them. They abandon their parents at home and forsake their lords’ affairs abroad. Footprints crisscross the borders of the feudal lords, and carriage tracks extend beyond a thousand *li*. This is because those above excessively favor knowledge.

*Enough to record essentials.*

The twelve rulers above were all ancient emperors. At that time, there were no historical records, nor was the order of their succession known. They carved wood for contracts and knotted cords for trust. Above and below were at peace, and human hearts were pure. Thus the *Yi* says: In high antiquity, governance was by knotted cords; later sages replaced them with written contracts.

*Rongcheng*: Sima says: These twelve were all ancient emperors. *Li*: Xu reads *lìchí*, Li reads *lí*. *Xu*: Xu reads *chìliù*. *Fuxi*: reads *xī*.

*What is fitting is always sweet; what is proper is always beautiful. If one longs for extravagance and excess, there will never be satisfaction.*

*Dissatisfaction*: reads *kǒuqiàn*.

*Content with their portion, thus sweet; free from adornment, thus beautiful; undivided, thus joyful; tranquil, thus at peace.*

*Joyful*: reads *lè*.

*Utmost in having no desires.*

The villages and towns stood close together, not far apart, so that the crowing of roosters and the barking of dogs could be heard from one to another, reaching each other. Yet each nature was self-sufficient, with no demands upon the world, and they met their end by Heaven’s decree without coming or going—this was the perfection of non-action.

*Variant*: One version reads *without coming and going to each other*.

Collation: The Guo edition from the Yuanjia era and the Cui edition from the Yonghe era both omit the character *with*.

Such was the time when, free from desires and seeking nothing, one embraced the Dao and held fast to virtue—was this not perfection!

*Perfection of governance*: reads *zhìlì*. The annotation is the same.

The traces of perfect governance still led to such abuses.

*Yíng*: means *to wrap*. This was also the wind of perfect governance, spread abroad as teaching, valuing these written traces and causing people to study them. The path of exalting the worthy was opened, and people sought teachers and inquired after the Dao, stretching their necks and lifting their feet to travel far to other lands. Wheeltracks crisscrossed, footprints overlapped, and they wrapped their provisions and carried their burdens, undaunted by a thousand miles. Within, they abandoned their parents and were unfilial; without, they left their lords and were disloyal. Thus the traces of perfect governance led to such abuses.

*Neck*: reads as written. Li reads *jùyíng*. *Yíng*: reads *yíng*. Cui says: means *to wrap*. The *Guangya* says: means *to carry*. *Provisions*: reads *liáng*. *And hasten*: Qiyu reads *qīyú*; Xu reads *qīyù*.

◎ Qingfan’s note: *Guǐ* means *to clear tracks*. The *Shuowen* says: *Guǐ* means *the clearance of a chariot*, from *chē* (cart) and *jiǔ* (nine) as phonetic. (Note: *Chè* means *to penetrate*, hollow and open. The classics and commentaries often gloss *guǐ* as *the front of a chariot’s shaft*, but this is likely a corruption of *fàn*. The *Shuowen* says: *Fàn* means *the front of a chariot’s rail*, from *chē* and *fán* as phonetic.) Since chariot tracks and footprints are paired in the text, it is clear that *guǐ* refers to chariot tracks. (The *Kaogongji*’s *Jiangren* says *all accommodate the strength of nine tracks*, and Zheng’s annotation says: *Guǐ* means *the breadth of clearance*. *Jié* means *to intersect*.) Chariot tracks can run parallel or cross diagonally. When they cross diagonally, they intersect; *intersecting tracks* thus means *intersecting clearances*. The *Guanzi*’s *Xiao Kuang* chapter says *chariots do not intersect tracks*, where *chè* means *tracks*. Gao’s annotation: *Jié* means *to intersect*. The tracks of chariot wheels run lengthwise and crosswise, intersecting one another, hence called *intersecting tracks*. The *Records of the Grand Historian*’s *Biography of Sima Xiangru* says *intersecting tracks to reach the shafts*, and the *Suoyin* cites Zhang Yi’s annotation: *Jié* means *to bend*; *guǐ* means *chariot tracks*. Originally traveling west, they turned east, so the tracks also curved eastward.

Those above—namely, rulers who delight in knowledge—by knowing and delighting in it, incur such faults.

They exalted the traces of perfect governance and delighted in the knowledge of ordering things, thus bringing about these abuses.

*Above delights*: reads *hàobào*. The annotation below is the same.

If those above truly delight in knowledge and lack the Dao, then the world will be thrown into great chaos. How do we know this is so?

When the knowledge of bows, crossbows, nets, arrows, triggers, and traps becomes excessive, birds are thrown into chaos in the skies. When the knowledge of hooks, bait, nets, weirs, and fish traps becomes excessive, fish are thrown into chaos in the waters. When the knowledge of snares, fences, nets, and traps becomes excessive, beasts are thrown into chaos in the marshes. When the knowledge of deceit, gradual corruption, cunning, obstinacy, sophistry, disputation, and the distinctions of same and different becomes excessive, the common folk are bewildered by argumentation.

Thus the world is repeatedly thrown into great chaos, and the blame lies in delighting in knowledge. Therefore, the world all knows to seek what it does not know but does not know to seek what it already knows; all knows to condemn what it does not consider good but does not know to condemn what it already considers good. This is why there is great chaos.

Thus above, it obscures the brightness of the sun and moon; below, it scorches the essence of mountains and rivers; and in between, it disrupts the operations of the four seasons. Even the trembling insects and the fluttering creatures—none fail to lose their natures. How extreme is the chaos brought to the world by delighting in knowledge!

This has been the case since the Three Dynasties and after. Abandoning the people of diverse natures, they delight in the flattery of the restless; forsaking the tranquility of non-action, they delight in the clamor of empty words—and clamor has already thrown the world into chaos!

The ruler above, unable to practice non-action and tranquility, to be empty and in accord with the Dao, but instead ordering things with knowledge, will surely bring ruin to them, thus causing great chaos. Laozi said: *To govern the state with knowledge is the state’s thief.*

This is a hypothetical question to reveal the cause.

The more densely one attacks, the more skillfully one evades, so that even birds and beasts cannot be captured with knowledge—how much less so with people! Therefore, those who govern the world must not rely on knowledge; relying on knowledge is not subtle.

*Nets* are small and have handles, resembling the *Bì* constellation, hence the name *bì*. *Yì* refers to shooting with an arrow tied to a string. *Gǔ* are all nets. *Gǒu* is a curved weir, also a fish trap, made by sharpening branches—like today’s deer-antler spears or horse pikes—using ropes and wooden fences to catch beasts. *Jūfú* is a rabbit net. Since one uses knowledge to order things, how can there be no boiling turmoil? Thus, those who govern the state must not employ knowledge.

*Crossbow*: reads *nǔ*. *Bì, yì, triggers, and traps*: Li says: *Bì* is a rabbit net; *yì* is shooting with a tethered arrow; *jī* is the trigger of a crossbow. *Knowledge*: reads *zhì* here and below, as well as in the annotation and *knowledge of deceit*. *Hook and bait*: reads *rúzhì*. *Nets*: reads *zēng*. ◎ Lu Wenchang says: The current text writes *wǎng* as *net*. *Gǒu*: reads *gōu*, a fishing hook.

Bait is fish bait. The *Guangya* states: *gǔ* is called *wǎng*. *Zēng* is a fish net. The *Erya* states: a widow’s *gǒu* is called □.

◎ Wang Niansun says: *Diào* was originally written as *钓*, and *钓* is *gōu*. The current text writes *钩* because later scholars, knowing only that *钓* means "to fish," were unaware that it also serves as an alternate name for *gōu*, and thus altered it arbitrarily. Now, consider the *Guangya*, which states: *Diào* is *gōu*. The *Tian Zifang* chapter says: King Wen observed Zang and saw a man fishing, yet his *diào* did not fish—he did not hold his *diào* as one who fishes, but as one who *diào*s constantly. (Of these six *diào* characters, only the two in "his *diào*" and "hold his *diào*" refer to *gōu*; the remaining four are read as "to fish.") The *Mohist Canon*’s *Mo Pian* states: "Like wielding a *diào* over a deep abyss"; the *Huainanzi*’s *Shuō Shān* chapter says: "Holding a *diào* to ascend a mountain, raising an axe to enter the depths"; its *Shuō Lín* chapter says: "A one-eyed net cannot catch birds; a *diào* without bait cannot catch fish"; Dongfang Shuo’s *Qi Jie* says: "To use a straight needle as a *diào*—what fish could one catch?" Thus, the ancients called *gōu* *diào*.

Furthermore, the *Shiwen* states: *ěr* is read *rúzhì*; *zēng* is read *zēng*; *gǒu* is read *gǒu*—these are the pronunciations for *ěr*, *zēng*, and *gǒu*. Below, it states: *Diào* is *gōu*; *ěr* is fish bait. The *Guangya* says: *Gǔ* is called *wǎng*; *zēng* is a fish net. The *Erya* says: a widow’s *gǒu* is called □. These explain the meanings of the six characters *diào*, *ěr*, *wǎng*, *gǔ*, and *gǒu*. Later scholars, having already altered the *diào* in the main text to *gōu*, further changed the six characters in the *Shiwen*—*gǒu* read *gǒu*, *diào* is *gōu*—to *gǒu* read *gōu*, *diào* is *gōu*, compounding the error. Moreover, in the *Waiwu* chapter, Ren Gongzi made a great *gōu* with thick black silk; the *Shiwen* notes: *Gōu* was originally also written as *diào*, and the latter is correct. The *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on the *Qi Qi*, Fu Xian’s annotation to his poem *Zeng He Shao Wang Ji*, Xie Lingyun’s commentary on *Qi Li Lai*, and the *Taiping Yulan*’s *Zichan* section, volume fourteen, all cite this passage as *diào*. In the *Liezi*’s *Tang Wen* chapter, Zhan He used a flaxen needle as a *diào*; later scholars altered *diào* to *gōu*, unaware that the *Yulan* cites this passage as *diào*. Further below, in "casting the line and sinking the *diào*," modern editions write *gōu* instead of *diào*, another alteration by later scholars. The *Yunfu Qunyu*’s entry for *diào* cites the *Liezi*’s "casting the line and sinking the *diào*," showing that the edition it consulted still used *diào*. In the *Zhan Guo Ce*’s *Qi Ce*, "Have you not heard of the great fish of the sea? Nets cannot restrain it, *diào* cannot pull it"—later scholars altered *diào* to *gōu*, unaware that the *Yulan*’s *Lin Jie* section, volume seven, cites this as *diào*, and the *Huainanzi*’s *Ren Jian* chapter also uses *diào*. In the *Huainanzi*’s *Shuō Shān* chapter, "People do not cherish the pearls of the Yangtze and Han but cherish their own *diào*," Gao You’s commentary states: *Diào* is *gōu*. Later scholars, having already altered the *diào* in the main text to *gōu*, further changed the commentary to read *gōu* and *diào*, compounding the error. This arose because later scholars, unaware that *diào* is an alternate name for *gōu*, altered what they did not know based on what they did know, and the ancient meanings gradually vanished.

*Xuē* is read *qiào*. *Gé* is read *gǔbǎi*. Li says: *Xuēgé* are used to deploy nets. *Luōluòjū* is read *zǐxié*. *Fú* is also written as *fú*, read *fú*. The *Erya* states: bird nets are called *luō*; rabbit nets are called *jū*; *jué* is called *fú*; *fú* is an overturned cart. Guo Pu says: This refers to today’s *fānchē*.

◎ Jia Shifu says: The *Shiwen* cites Li’s note: *Xuēgé* are used to deploy nets. The *Shuowen* states: *Gé* means "long wood." Xu Kai says: Long branches are *gé*. *Xuēgé* means to scrape and cut them. Zheng’s commentary on the *Zhouli*’s *Yongshi* refers to *zuò’è*. The *Book of Documents*’ *Fei Shi* says *dù nǎi huò*. The *Zhengyi*’s *huò* is a beast-catching trap. Zuo Si’s *Wu Du Fu* says *qiàogé zhōu shī*, where *qiào* and *xuē* share the same meaning. *Gé* implies resistance. *Xuēgé* and *luōluò* are both used to block and intercept birds and beasts. The *Hanshu*’s *Chao Cuo Zhuan* says *wéi zhōng zhōu hǔluò*; Yan Shigu’s commentary states: This means to enclose and block. *Xuēgé* is the *huò* in pit traps. *Luōluò* shares the same meaning as the *bìyì* above. The *Yupian* states: *Yì* is a stake, also written as *yì*. The *Erya*’s *Shi Gong* says: *Yǐn* is called *yì*; Guo Pu’s commentary states: This is a stake. *Bìyì* means to deploy *yì* to stretch *bì*. In the *Ren Jian Shi* chapter, the stakes for monkeys are used to tether them. The *Shuowen* states: *Shuài* is a bird-catching *bì*. The *Book of Songs*’ *Xiao Ya* says *bì zhī luō zhī*. Bird nets are also called *bì*. Li’s note—"rabbit nets are called *bì*; tethered arrows are called *yì*"—is incorrect.

【Four】【Annotation】What those above possess in abundance, those below cannot secure in their scarcity. By nature scarce yet chasing abundance, one becomes lost.

【Exegesis】Cunning and deceit gradually poison and harm things. *Jié gǔ* means "slippery and cunning," also "treacherous and crafty." *Jiě gòu* means "deceit and falsehood." The cleverness of *gǔjī jiānbái* and the sophistry of *juéguǐ tóngyì* surely undermine truth and offer no benefit to worldly teachings. Thus, from afar, they resemble the inarticulate, while the foolish masses are misled by petty arguments.

【Shiwen】*Jiàn dú*: Li says: The poison of gradual infiltration runs deep without notice. Cui says: *Jiàn dú* means "profound harm." ◎ Qingfan notes: *Zhī* is interchangeable with *zhì*, meaning "cunning." The *Huainanzi*’s *Zhu Shu* commentary states: *Gù* means "crafty." The *Guanzi*’s *Xin Shu* says to discard *zhī* and *gù*; the *Xunzi*’s *Fei Shi Er Zi* says *zhī ér xiǎn*; the *Huainanzi*’s *Yuan Dao* says *ǒu zhì gù*—all share the meaning of this *zhī* character.

"Gradual" means deception. The *Xunzi*’s *Discourse on Military Affairs* employs *jiàn* in this sense: when upright discourse above embraces peril and danger, deception and falsehood arise below—all denoting the meaning of deceit. (Li Yi’s interpretation of *jiàn* as "the poison of gradual infiltration" misses the mark entirely.)

The *Book of Documents* states, "The people arise in mutual deception." Wang Niansun says: *Jiàn* means deception, for when the common people rise to deceive and cheat, the subsequent text reads, "None adhere to trustworthiness," thus overturning oaths and covenants. Those who gloss *jiàn* as "gradual transformation" fail to connect it with the following text.

*Jié* is pronounced *hùjié*; *gǔ* is pronounced *gānbā*. *Jié-gǔ* refers to what is difficult to manage. Cui says: "tangled and contorted." Li pronounces it *gǔ* (as in *gǔjī*, "slippery and artful"). Another interpretation: *jié-gǔ* refers to perverse speech.

*Jiě* is pronounced *kǔxiè*; *gòu* is pronounced *kǔdòu*. Sima and Cui say: *jiě-gòu* means "obstructed and angular." Another interpretation: "devious and crooked words."

【Five】【Commentary】*Měiměi* describes a state of confusion and obscurity. When one forgets personal concerns and follows things as they are, the world remains clear and harmonious; when one clings to traces and employs cunning, the world falls into great disorder. Thus, the muddled state of superiors and inferiors arises from the love of cleverness.

【Shiwen】*Měiměi*: Li says: "akin to *hūnhūn* (confused)." ◎ Qingfan notes: *Měiměi* is equivalent to *mèngmèng*. The *Erya*’s *Explanation of Terms* states: *Mèngmèng zhūnzhūn* means "chaos." The shift from *mèng* to *měi* parallels that from *méng* to *méi* (as in *méng* [ridgepole], now written *méi*). (The *Fangyan* says *méi* is called *méi*; Guo’s annotation: "The modern character is *méi*.")

【Six】【Commentary】To abandon what one knows in pursuit of what one does not know is to forsake the self and imitate others, exceeding one’s proper bounds.

【Exegesis】What one knows lies within one’s proper bounds; what one does not know lies beyond them. To forsake the internal in pursuit of the external—how could this not be delusion?

【Shiwen】*Shě jǐ*: pronounced *shě*; the same below.

【Seven】【Commentary】To esteem what one deems good is the origin of contention and rivalry.

【Exegesis】What is deemed not good refers to Jie and Zhi; what is deemed good refers to the sagely traces. Robber Zhi practiced evil to seize Dongling, while Tian Heng followed sagely traces to usurp the state of Qi. Thus, though Zang and Gu pursued different paths, both lost their sheep; though Yi and Zhi acted differently, both harmed their nature. The foolish masses recklessly pass judgment, declaring things good or not good—yet such distinctions are truly unreliable.

【Eight】【Commentary】Fortune and misfortune, regret and shame arise from action. Yet the movements of knowledge can indeed shake heaven and earth, governing the multitudes of beings. How, then, can a ruler fail to forget his knowledge?

【Exegesis】This continues the preceding discourse. Precisely because rulers have employed knowledge and clung to traces, the world has fallen into great disorder. *Bèi* means chaos; *shuò*, dissolution; *duò*, ruin. Creatures that cling to the earth are called *zhuìruǎn*; those that flit through the air, *xiāoqiào*—all are small and insignificant. Yet clinging to traces and employing knowledge brings such grave harm that it can stir yin and yang, shake heaven and earth, cause the sun and moon to eclipse, the mountains and rivers to collapse and dry up, disrupt the order of heat and cold, and make wind and rain untimely. Creatures of flight and walk, water and land lose their original nature—so poisonous is the love of knowledge.

【Shiwen】*Shàng bèi*: Li and Guo say: "must inwardly rebel"; also pronounced *pèi*. Sima says: "refers to eclipses." *Xià shuò*: *shīyuē* rhyme. Cui says: "means dissolution." Sima says: "means collapse and exhaustion." Cui and Xiang originally wrote *lì*, same as *shuò*. Xu pronounces it *yào*. *Zhōng duò*: *xǔguī* rhyme, means "ruin." *Zhī shī*: *shǐchǐ* rhyme. *Zhuì*: also written as *□* or *chuǎn*, *chuānyǎn* rhyme. Xiang pronounces it *chuǎi*. *Ruǎn*: *ěrzhuǎn* rhyme. Cui says: "*xuānruǎn* are wriggling insects." Another says: "*zhuìruǎn* refers to legless creatures." *Xiāoqiào*: *xiāo*; below, *qíráo* rhyme. Cui says: "*xiāoqiào* are plants." Li says: "refers to creatures like *xuān* in flight."

【Nine】【Commentary】*Tūntūn* describes teaching others by one’s own example.

【Exegesis】*Zì* means "from." The Three Dynasties refer to Xia, Yin, and Zhou. *Zhǒngzhǒng* describes the simple and unadorned; *yìyì*, the frivolous and cunning. *Shì* means "abandon." *Tūntūn* means teaching others by one’s own example. In the most ancient age of perfect simplicity, when the world was unspoiled, people emulated the round heaven in clarity and emptiness, modeled the square earth in tranquility and stillness, united the myriad things as one family, and lived like birds and beasts in ignorance. But when purity dissolved and craftiness arose, the Way was abandoned and virtue forsaken. The sagely traces of the Five Emperors became manifest, and the Three Dynasties employed knowledge to an even greater degree. They forsook the simple and unadorned, cherished the frivolous and cunning, abandoned the self-contentment of desirelessness, and delighted in teaching others with a mind of intention—thus throwing the world into chaos. Is this not lamentable?

【Shiwen】*Zhǒngzhǒng*: Xiang pronounces it *zhāngyǒng*; Li says: "means cautious." Another says: "means honest and sincere." *Ér yuè*: pronounced *yuè*, same below. ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: "The modern text writes *yuè*." *Yìyì*: Li says: "means cunning." Another says: "means acting for others." *Tián*: *túqiān* rhyme. *Dàn*: *túzhàn* rhyme; Xu pronounces it *dàgǎn*. *Tūntūn*: Li pronounces it *zhīrùn*, also *zhīchún*; Guo pronounces it *dūn*, meaning "teaching others by one’s own example," same below. Sima says: "means lacking in knowledge." Xu pronounces it *xǔpēng*, also *xǔgāng*; Xiang originally wrote *tūn*, pronounced *hēng*. Cui’s text has the first instance as *hēnghēng*, meaning "lacking knowledge and dull." Another says: "*hēnghēng* means robust." ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: "The modern text writes *tūntūn* in both instances. According to the *shuōwén*, it may also be pronounced *hēng*." 【Collation】(1) Zhao’s *Jiànyì* edition writes *chuǎn*. (2) The *Shìdétáng* edition writes *mín* as *jī*; Zhao’s edition writes *mín*. (3) The *Shìdétáng* edition writes *wǎng*; this text follows the *Shiwen* in emending it. (4) The original *Shiwen* lacks the character *yīn*. (5) The character *zuò* follows the *Zhōulǐ* Zheng annotation in emendation. (6) The character *□* follows the *Huáinánzǐ* in emendation. (7) The character *□* follows the *Fāngyán* in emendation. (8) Zhao’s edition writes *zhǐ* as *zhèng*.

**Outer Chapters: "In Yu" XI**
**XI. Outer Chapters: "In Yu"**
【One】【Shiwen】The chapter is named for its theme. ◎ Qingfan notes: The *Wenxuan* quotes Sima: "*Zài* means observation; *yòu*, leniency." The *Shiwen* omits this. I have heard that to "be *in yòu* with the world" is not to "govern the world." To *zài* it is to fear the world’s corruption of its nature; to *yòu* it is to fear the world’s alteration of its virtue.

【Two】If the world neither corrupts its nature nor alters its virtue, does it need governing? In ancient times, when Yao governed the world, he made the world joyful, each delighting in their nature—this was not *tián*. When Jie governed the world, he made the world weary, each suffering in their nature—this was not *yú*. That which is neither *tián* nor *yú* is not virtue. There is nothing in the world that is not virtue yet can endure for long.

【Five】

【I】
◎ Annotation: To *yòu* is to let things be at ease, which is governance; to govern them is to bring chaos. Man’s life is upright by nature, and if nothing sways it, then nature and destiny will not transgress, and desires and aversions will not err. Those above cannot be without action, and whatever those above do, the people all rush toward it—thus there are enticements and longings for desires, and the people’s nature becomes corrupted. Therefore, what is prized in a sage-king is not that he can govern, but that he does nothing and lets things act of themselves.

◎ Subcommentary: *Yòu* means leniency; *zài*, ease. *Zhì* means control. As the parable says, I have heard that when the worthy and sage entrust things to their own ease and leniency, the world is at peace; but if they establish teachings to control the common people, things lose their nature—like Bo Le training horses.

◎ *Shiwen*: *Wén zài yòu* (聞在宥): *yòu* is read as leniency. *Zé zhì* (則治): *zhì* is read as *zhílì* (直吏). The same applies to *zhì luàn* (治乱) below. *Yù wù* (欲恶): *wù* is read as *wùlù* (乌路). *Hào yù* (好欲): *hào* is read as *hūbào* (呼报).

【II】
◎ Subcommentary: Nature is the principle bestowed at birth; virtue is the name for meritorious conduct. Thus, the teaching of *zài yòu* is given to prevent the transgressions of alteration and corruption. If one does not let nature be at ease, one fears that things will become corrupt and lose their nature. If one does not *yòu* them, one fears that they will imitate others and their virtue will change.

【III】
◎ Annotation: Without governance, there is no alteration or corruption.
◎ Subcommentary: When nature is upright and virtue is settled, why trouble with the administration of government? Having governance is not as good as having none; having action is not as good as having none.

◎ *Shiwen*: *Yǒu zhì tiānxià zhě zāi* (有治天下者哉): Cui’s edition reads *yǒu zhì tiānxià zhě cái shī* (有治天下者材失), with a note: "To govern forcibly is to fail in one’s capacity."

【IV】
◎ Annotation: Though Yao *zài yòu*-ed the world, his traces were those of governance. Though governance and chaos differ, in their loss of the world’s *tián* and *yú*, in making things vie for esteem and fear contempt, and in their lack of self-attainment, they are the same. Thus, to praise Yao and blame Jie is not as good as forgetting both.

◎ Subcommentary: *Tián* means stillness; *yú*, joy. *Cuì* means sorrow. Yao ruled the people with virtue, and the people sang and played *jirang*, yet this violated their still nature. Jie harmed things with cruelty, and things suffered sorrow and exhaustion, violating their joyful nature. Though the governance of Yao and Jie differed, in causing things to lose their nature, they were equal.

◎ *Shiwen*: *Rén lè* (人乐): *lè* is read as *luò* (洛). *Tián* (恬): read as *túqiān* (徒谦). *Cuìcuì* (瘁瘁): read as *zàijì* (在季), meaning illness. The *Guangya* says: sorrow. Cui’s edition reads *zuì* (醉). *Yú* (愉): read as *yú* (瑜); Xu reads it as *yù* (喻). *Gù yù* (故誉): read as *yú* (余).

【V】
◎ Annotation: Only when there is *tián* and *yú* with self-attainment can there be long endurance.
◎ Subcommentary: Yao made the people not *tián*, and Jie made them not *yú*, neither accorded with the pure and harmonious nature. If one seeks long endurance, there has never been such a thing in the world. Is great joy not excessive? It aids the yang. Is great anger not excessive? It aids the yin. When yin and yang are both aided, the seasons do not arrive on time, the harmony of cold and heat is not achieved, and does this not instead harm man’s form?

If man’s joy and anger lose their proper place, if his dwelling is without constancy, if his thoughts and considerations do not attain self-mastery, if his way is not brought to completion—then the world begins to become twisted, perverse, aloof, and fierce, and afterward there arise the conduct of Robber Zhi and Zeng Shen and Shi Yu. Thus, to reward the good of the whole world is insufficient, and to punish the evil of the whole world is not enough. Therefore, the greatness of the world is insufficient for reward and punishment.

From the Three Dynasties onward, they have been clamorous, taking reward and punishment as their constant task—when do they have leisure to settle the feelings of their nature and destiny?

【I】
◎ Subcommentary: *Pí* means to aid. Joy arises from the *hún*; anger, from the *pò*. Man is endowed with yin and yang and shares the same *qi* as the Two Modes. Yao made the hundred clans joyful, aiding the yang’s warmth and ease; Jie made the people angry, assisting the yin’s gloom and severity. When man’s joy and anger exceed their measure, heaven loses its constancy: the height of summer is not hot, the depths of winter have no frost. Having lost harmonious *qi*, and with heavenly disasters added, people suffer many illnesses—is this not instead harming the form? One must not act or establish laws, for it will inevitably lead to injury.

【Exegesis】
*《毗于》* is read as written. Sima [Biao] says: "to aid." Another gloss: "to combine." ◎ Yu Yue notes: The *Exegesis* reads *pí* as written, and Sima says "to aid," with another gloss "to combine." Yet the following text states, "yin and yang combine in *pí*, the four seasons fail to arrive, and the harmony of cold and heat is not achieved"—thus the gloss "to aid" is already untenable, and if taken as "to combine," it is even more mistaken. This *pí* should be read as *píliú* (violent joy). The *Er Ya*’s *Exegesis of Terms* states: "*Píliú* means violent joy." When spoken together, it is *píliú*; when separated, it may be shortened to *liú*, as in the *Poem* "Sang Rou": "they pluck and gather its *liú*." Or it may be shortened to *pí*, as in the present text: "*pí* to yang, *pí* to yin." *Bàolè* (violent joy) is rendered by Mao’s commentary as *bàoshuò* (scorching). Zheng’s annotation says: "When plucked and gathered, it becomes scorched and sparse." Thus *bàoshuò* means "to peel and fall." Joy pertains to yang; anger, to yin. Hence excessive joy harms yang, and excessive anger harms yin. "*Pí* to yin, *pí* to yang" means to harm the harmony of yin and yang, so the four seasons fail to arrive, and the harmony of cold and heat is not achieved. If one follows Sima’s gloss of *pí* as "to aid," the next three sentences become incoherent. The *Huainanzi*’s "Original Dao" chapter states: "Great anger ruptures yin; great joy topples yang"—this is precisely the same meaning.

【II】
◎ Annotation: These are all like Yao and Jie, causing things’ joy and anger to exceed their measure and thus leading to such calamities. Man, situated between heaven and earth, is most capable of disturbing the multitude of beings and agitating yin and yang through the spiritual awareness of joy and anger. Thus, between gain and loss, when joy and anger gather in the hearts of the hundred clans, the harmony of cold and heat is ruined, the seasons’ rhythms are disrupted, the hundred norms fall into chaos, and the myriad affairs collapse.

◎ Subcommentary: By clinging to joy and anger, the hundred clans’ deliberations lose their truth. Once they deviate from the model of the law, this is ruin indeed.

【Exegesis】
*《思虑》* is read *sīlǜ* (deliberations). *《大过》* is read *tà* (excess).

【III】
◎ Annotation: Longing for reward gives rise to goodness, so rewards cannot suffice.

【Exegesis】
*《乔》* is read *xiāo* by Xiang, *qiāoyāo* by Guo, and *jiāo* by Li. *《诘》* is read *qì* by Li and *qǐliè* by Xu. Cui says: "*Qiáojié* means discontent." *《卓》* is read *chuò* by Guo, *dīngjiǎo* by Xiang. *《鸷》* is read *chì* by Li, *zhūlì* by Xiang, and *chìlì* by another. Cui says: "*Zhuōzhì* means unruly conduct." *《之行》* is read *zhīxíng*.

【IV】
◎ Annotation: Fearing punishment brings cessation, so punishments cannot prevail.

◎ Subcommentary: *Qiáo* means deceit and falsity; *jié*, reproach and interrogation; *zhuó*, aloofness; *zhì*, ferocity. Thus, they become deceitful and reproachful, aloof and unyielding, harboring ferocity and arrogance, lightly overpowering others. Beginning with Yao, followed by the evil of Robber Zhi and the goodness of Zeng and Shi, once good and evil are manifest, rewards and punishments are tied to them. Longing for reward, they do good; fearing punishment, they cease evil. Yet the axes of the world are insufficient to punish evil, and the treasuries of the cosmos are insufficient to reward good. *Jǐ* means "to suffice."

【Exegesis】
*《能胜》* is read *néngshèng* (to prevail).

【V】
◎ Subcommentary: If one forgets rewards and punishments, natural truth suffices.

【VI】
◎ Annotation: Forgetting rewards and punishments to be naturally good—only then is one’s nature and destiny greatly sufficient. Rewards and punishments are how the sage-kings address merit and fault, not to manifest encouragement or deterrence. Thus, when governance reaches its perfection, they are abandoned, and only then can one return to unity. Yet from the Three Dynasties onward, they have followed these traces, clamoring and competing with them, ultimately taking what is entrusted as their task—when do they have leisure to settle the feelings of their nature and destiny?

◎ Subcommentary: *Xiōngxiōng* means clamor, the act of competing. Fearing the executioner’s axe and coveting the chariot and cap of office, their hearts harbor a hundred anxieties, and their affairs branch into myriad paths, clamoring and competing without cease. Since the Xia and Yin, this trend has gradually fanned into flame. Rewards and punishments entangle and disturb, leaving them frantically busy all day—how could they have leisure to settle their nature and destiny?

【Exegesis】
*《匈匈》* is read *xiōngxiōng*.

【Collation】
(1) The character *为* is deleted following *Zhuzi Pingyi*.
(2) The Zhao Jianyi edition has *失* as *夭*; the Shidetang edition has *失*.

Moreover, is it delight in beauty? This is indulgence in sensuality. Is it delight in keen hearing? This is indulgence in sound. 【I】 Is it delight in benevolence? This is disorder in virtue. Is it delight in righteousness? This is perversion of principle. 【II】 Is it delight in ritual? This is competition in technique. Is it delight in music? This is competition in excess. 【III】 Is it delight in sagacity? This is competition in artifice. Is it delight in knowledge? This is competition in fault. 【IV】 If the world seeks to settle the feelings of its nature and destiny, these eight may exist or not—it matters not. 【V】 If the world does not seek to settle the feelings of its nature and destiny, these eight begin to shred, crumple, and entangle, throwing the world into chaos. 【VI】 Yet the world begins to revere and cherish them—how deeply deluded the world is! 【VII】 Is it merely a matter of error to be discarded? They fast and purify themselves to speak of them, kneel and sit to present them, drum and sing to extol them—what have I to do with such things? 【VIII】

【I】
◎ Subcommentary: *Yuè* means attachment. *Yín* means clinging. Longing for Li and yearning for Kuang, they become mired in sound and sensuality.

【Exegesis】
*《而且》* is read as written or *zǐyú* by Xu. *《说明》* is read *yuè* (delight), the same below.

【II】
◎ Subcommentary: Virtue knows no hatred or love; partial love disrupts virtue. The Dao knows no right or wrong; imposing wrongness violates the Dao. *Bèi* means opposition.

【Exegesis】
*《是悖》* is read *bìnèi* by Xu, or *púmò* in another pronunciation.

【III】
◎ Subcommentary: Ritual consists of raising hands, kneeling, and bowing—its forms rise and fall in gradation. Music consists of *Xiánchí* and *Dàxià*, its pitch-pipes and eight timbres. Delighting in ritual only aids superficial skills; loving music further fosters the excess of palace tones and lewd sounds.

【Exegesis】
*《是相》* is read *xīliàng*, meaning "to assist." The same applies below and in the commentary.
*《于技》* is read *qǐ* by Ji, or *qí* by Li. Cui’s reading is the same, glossing it as "improper."

【IV】
◎ Commentary: When aligned with the Dao, there is no delight; delight in it brings the calamity of excess and opposition. *Xiāng* means "to assist."

◎ Subcommentary: Delighting in sagely traces assists the world’s arts; loving schemes and calculations exacerbates the blemishes of right and wrong.

【Exegesis】
*《说知》* is read *zhì*.
*《于疵》* is read *jīsī*.

【V】
◎ Commentary: Existence and extinction have no fixed abode; entrusting oneself to the portion one has received, then one’s nature and destiny are at peace.

◎ Subcommentary: The eight are: acuity, discernment, benevolence, righteousness, ritual, music, sageliness, and wisdom. It is said that people receive different portions, their natures and dispositions each distinct. Those like Li Kuang, Pang Degong, Zengzi, and Shi Yu, who possess these by their original portion, may preserve them; the multitude, whose nature and portion fundamentally lack them, vainly emulate and stray from authenticity—it is fitting that they let them go.

【VI】
◎ Commentary: To insist on preserving these eight is to be unable to follow nature freely, thus becoming like minced meat, coiled and cramped.

◎ Subcommentary: *Luǎnjuǎn* describes a posture that does not unfold or relax. *Cāngnáng* depicts haste. All beings under heaven, knowing only what lies beyond their portion, cannot rest in what is given, coil themselves in self-constraint, vie in ostentatious human affairs, hasten in competition, and chase after things—all because they do not forget the eight, leading to such corruption.

【Exegesis】
*《脔》* is read *lìzhuǎn*. Cui’s version writes it as *栾*.
*《卷》* is read *juǎnmiǎn*; Xu reads it *jūrǔan*. Sima states: *Luǎnjuǎn* depicts a state of not extending or relaxing. Cui concurs. Another gloss: "to pull and drag one another."
*《獊》* is read *cāng*. Cui’s version writes it as *戕*.
*《囊》* is read as written. Cui states: *Qiāngnáng* is like *qiāngrǎng*.
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: Modern editions write *獊* as *怆*.

【VII】
◎ Commentary: Not being able to relinquish them is already an error. To then exalt and revere them as precious—how can this not be utter delusion?

◎ Subcommentary: The previous eight disorder the warp of the world; not being able to forget them is already great confusion. To then honor and esteem them as models—how grievous this is!

【Exegesis】
*《乃复》* is read *fúyòu*.

【VIII】
◎ Commentary: It is not merely that they pass away like temporary lodgings—rather, they are treasured and valued to such an extent.

◎ Subcommentary: The meaning of the eight principles is like that of straw dogs: once past, they ought not be retrieved. Yet in earnest prohibition and solemn purification, with formal declarations of ritual propriety, rulers and ministers kneel and sit, presenting offerings to one another, striking up the songs of *Jiǔsháo*, dancing the measures of *Dàzhāng*. To prize and esteem a thatched hut so highly—Zhuangzi witnessed this and could do nothing.

【Exegesis】
*《而去》* is read *qǐlǜ*.
*《之邪》* in Cui’s edition, only this character is written as *邪*; all others write it *咫*.
*《齐戒》* is also written *斋*, both read *zhāijiè*.
*《跪》* is read *qíguǐ*; Guo reads it *wēi*.
【Collation】
(1) The character *邪* is amended following the Shide Tang edition.
(2) The Shide Tang edition writes *怆*, with the same note. Zhao Jianyi’s edition writes *伧*.

Thus, when the noble person must perforce govern the world, there is nothing better than non-action. Through non-action, the sentiments of one’s nature and destiny are then at peace.

【I】
Therefore, one who values one’s person over governing the world may be entrusted with the world; one who cherishes one’s person over governing the world may be charged with the world.

【II】
◎ Commentary: If one lightly regards one’s person to pursue gain, abandoning oneself to chase after things, then one’s person cannot even be at peace—what can one do for the world?

◎ Subcommentary: Valuing one’s person over profit, placing oneself within and things without, preserving and cherishing one’s spirit, not dissipating it in the world—such a one may be entrusted to sit above the ten thousand things and transform the world.

【III】
◎ Commentary: To unravel or display them is to harm them.

◎ Subcommentary: The five viscera are the abode of essence and spirit; acuity and discernment are the functions of the ears and eyes. If one distinguishes the sentiments and perceptions of the five viscera and flaunts the functions of acuity and discernment, then the spirit gallops within, and the ears and eyes are exhausted without.

【Exegesis】
*《无解》* is read as written; another reading is *xiè*, meaning "to scatter."

【IV】
◎ Commentary: In movement and stillness, silence and speech, one constantly lacks any deliberate intention, entrusting all to nature.

◎ Subcommentary: The sage is as still as a corpse in quiescence, as dynamic as a flying dragon in activity—how could there be any distinction between quiescence and activity, principle and teaching? Thus, in stillness there is movement: still as a corpse, yet a dragon appears; silent as an abyss, yet thunder resounds. This illustrates that stillness is movement, movement is stillness; principle is teaching, teaching is principle—they are not two.

【Exegesis】
*《龙见》* is read *xiànbiàn*. Xiang’s edition writes it *睍*; Xiang reads it *xiàn*, while Cui reads it *睍*.

【V】
◎ Commentary: The spirit moves in accord with things; heaven follows the Dao in its course.

◎ Subcommentary: The spirit, as spoken of in its wondrous relation to the ten thousand things, is both dynamic and quiescent, its power equal to the azure sky, following and nurturing living things.
◎ Jia Shifu states: Still as a corpse, yet a dragon appears—unseen, yet manifest; silent as an abyss, yet thunder resounds—unmoving, yet transformed; the spirit moves and heaven follows—non-action yet accomplishment.

【VI】
◎ Commentary: Like motes of dust moving of themselves.

【Subcommentary】*Lei* means dust. Unhurried and at ease, free and unforced, in emptiness and tranquility—like the wind stirring fine dust, akin to floating things in the void, the yang *qi* drifting lightly, following its course and lingering as it wills.

【Exegesis】*Cóngróng*: read as *qīróng*. *Chuī*: read as *chāngshuì*, also *chāngguī*. Some editions write it as *吹*, same meaning. *Lèi*: read as *lièwěi*. Sima explains: *chuīlèi* is like rising movement. Xiang and Guo say: like motes of dust moving of themselves.

【VII】
◎ Commentary: Let it be as it is by nature.

◎ Subcommentary: Self and things merge indistinguishably, all in accord with nature—why trouble with effort or leisure to impose further governance? Cui Qu asked Lao Dan: “If one does not govern the world, how can the human heart be settled?” Lao Dan replied: “Take care not to disturb the human heart. The human heart pushes downward yet strives upward; up and down it is imprisoned and tormented. Soft and yielding, it yet overcomes the hard and strong. Sharpened and carved, it burns like scorching fire, freezes like congealing ice. Swift as a nod, it twice touches the ends of the four seas. At rest, it is deep and still; in motion, it hangs high as heaven. Proud and unruly, it cannot be tethered—is this not the human heart alone?”

【I】
◎ Commentary: To disturb it harms its innate goodness.

◎ Subcommentary: Cui Qu, surname Cui, given name Qu, origin unknown. Having asked, “If one leaves the heart in freedom without governance, how can goodness be realized?” The reply: “Leave it free and let it be—it will naturally accord with principle. To impose laws and regulate things disturbs the human heart.” The discussion of the human heart follows below.

【Exegesis】*Cuī Qū*: Xiang’s edition writes it as *臞*. *Qū*: read as *qiúzhū*. Cui Qu is a person’s name. *Lǎo Dān*: read as *tǔlán*. *Nǚ shèn*: read as *rǔ shèn*. *Yīng*: read as *yúyíng*, also *yúyìng*. Sima explains: to pull. Cui explains: to entangle.

【II】
◎ Commentary: Push it and it sinks; urge it and it rises—so easily swayed.

◎ Subcommentary: The human heart pushes others down and elevates itself—this is common sentiment.

【Exegesis】*Pái*: read as *píjiē*. Cui’s edition writes it as *俳*. *Jìn shàng*: read as *shízhǎng*. Same in the commentary below. *Qí yì*: read as *yǐchǐ*.

【III】
◎ Commentary: Without pushing or urging, it remains secure.

◎ Subcommentary: The heart, drowned in up and down, is led by circumstances like a prisoner in bonds, tormented by vexation.

【Exegesis】*Qiú shā*: read as written, or *xú suǒlì*. Meaning it imprisons and destroys the ten thousand things. ◎ Jia Shifu states: “Up and down, imprisoned and killed”—this means deceivingly high and deceivingly low, constraining the heart so it is bound and slain, unable to find its own ease. *Nào yuē* is forced compliance, so the hard may be made soft; *lián guì* is directness, yet cold and heat shift endlessly, water and fire both applied—disturb it and it becomes uncontrollable. Guo Xiang’s commentary may be in error.

【IV】
◎ Commentary: To be soft and yielding is to make the hard and strong compliant.

◎ Subcommentary: *Nào yuē* means soft and weak. Forcing one’s nature to act with softness and weakness aims to subdue the hard and strong.

【Exegesis】*Nào*: read as *chānglüè*, also *zhíjué*.

【V】
◎ Commentary: Scorching fire and congealing ice arise from the accumulation of joy and anger. If one does not carve or polish, preserving one’s original simplicity, where would there be ice or embers?

◎ Subcommentary: *Lián* means pursuing fame. *Guì* means harm. Carving and polishing one’s reputation and conduct seeks to surpass others. If one acts against nature in anger, the cold becomes as severe as congealing ice; if one follows desire in joy, the heat surpasses scorching fire.

【Exegesis】*Liánguì*: read as *jūwèi*. Sima [Biao] says: harm. *Guǎngyǎ* says: sharp. *Zhuó*: read as *dīngjué*.

【VI】
◎ Commentary: What custom stirs.

◎ Subcommentary: The mind that chases external realms traverses the ten directions in a single thought—how much more in the span of a bow and a glance, does it not repeatedly overlook the four seas!

【VII】
◎ Commentary: Stillness may be made like an abyss; movement then binds to heaven and leaps.

◎ Subcommentary: The desiring mind has no fixed standard for departure. When it happens to be still, it is like flowing water encountering a deep pool; when it touches the external and stirs, it resembles the high heavens suspended—unceasing in its movement, it binds to heaven and leaps.

【Exegesis】*Xuán ér tiān*: read as *xuán*. The *Xiàng* edition lacks the character *ér*, explaining: aspiring to the lofty and admiring the distant, hence called "binding to heaven."

【VIII】
◎ Commentary: The transformations of the human mind know no bounds. If one follows and releases it, it becomes still and naturally penetrates; if one governs and restrains it, it becomes strained and haughty. Haughtiness is an uncontrollable force.

◎ Subcommentary: Driving down and elevating up, beauty and ugliness, joy and anger—haughty eruptions and arrogant pride cannot be restrained: does this not lie in the human mind?

【Exegesis】*Fèn*: read as *fěnwèn* in the *Xiàng* edition. *Guǎngyǎ* says: stiff. Guo [Pu] reads it as *bēn*. *Jiāo*: as written, or read as *jūbiǎo*. Guo [Pu] says: haughtiness is an uncontrollable force.

【Collation】(1) The *Shìdétáng* edition writes *zàng* as *cáng*. (2) The *Shìdétáng* edition lacks the character *zì*.

In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor first used benevolence and righteousness to disturb the human mind.【1】Thereupon, Yao and Shun’s thighs grew no flesh, and their shins no hair, as they nurtured the forms of the world. They wearied their five viscera for benevolence and righteousness, strained their blood and qi to model laws and standards. Yet there were still those they could not overcome.【2】Thus, Yao banished Huān Dōu to Mount Chong, exiled the Three Miao to Sanwei, and sent Gong Gong to Youdu—these were the ones who could not be overcome by the world.【3】By the time this extended to the Three Kings, the world was greatly alarmed.【4】Below were Jie and Robber Zhi; above were Zeng [Can] and Shi [Qiu];【5】and the Confucians and Mohists all arose.【6】Thereupon, joy and anger suspected one another;【7】the foolish and the wise deceived one another;【8】the good and the bad condemned one another;【9】the extravagant and the truthful mocked one another.【10】And the world declined.【11】Great virtue diverged, and the nature and mandate dissolved into chaos.【12】The world delighted in knowledge, and the common people exhausted themselves in pursuit.【13】Thereupon, axes and saws were fashioned, inked cords were used to kill, and hammers and chisels decided matters.【14】The world was sharply and utterly disordered; the fault lay in disturbing the human mind. Thus, the worthy concealed themselves beneath the cliffs of great mountains, while the lords of ten thousand chariots trembled with anxiety in their ancestral halls.【15】

【1】
◎ Commentary: The Yellow Emperor did not act for benevolence and righteousness; he simply merged with things, and the traces of benevolence and righteousness appeared of themselves. Once these traces appeared, the minds of later ages necessarily followed them—this was also the Yellow Emperor’s traces disturbing things.

◎ Subcommentary: The Yellow Emperor established standards in accord with what was fitting, lovingly nurturing the people. In truth, this differed from the partiality of benevolence and the restraint of righteousness. Later kings adhered to his tracks, and the common people named him a sage. The disturbance of the human mind began here. The corruption arose with later kings; the blame does not lie with the Yellow Emperor.

【Exegesis】*Zìxiàn*: read as *xiànbiàn*. The same below.

【2】◎ Subcommentary: *Bá* refers to the white flesh. Yao and Shun followed the traces of the Yellow Emperor, their minds and bodies emaciated and worn. Their thighs were gaunt, devoid of white flesh; their shins were bare, stripped of fine hair. They nurtured the world’s appearance and pacified the dispositions of the myriad things. Their five viscera were consumed with sorrow within, while their blood and qi maintained dignity without. They practiced benevolence and righteousness as their compass, established laws and measures as their models—yet still could not avoid banishing the wicked clans, for there were matters they could not overcome.

◎ *Exegesis*: *Gǔ* is pronounced *gǔ*. The base of the shin is called the thigh. *Bá*: *pànmò* or *xiàngfùmò* in fanqie. Li [Yi] reads it as *fúgài*, explaining it as "white flesh." Some say the character should be *fú* (蔽膝, apron). Cui [Yuan] says: *bá* means □. *Jìng*: *xíngdìng* in fanqie. ◎ Qing Fan’s note: "To dignify their blood and qi" is akin to Mencius’ "toil their minds." *Jīn* means "toil," as glossed in the *Erya*’s *Shi Yan* chapter.

【3】◎ Subcommentary: Formerly, the Lord of Grand Swelling had an unworthy son, whom the world called Hundun—this was Huan Dou. He allied with Gonggong and was banished to the southern wilds. The Lord of Red Cloud had an unworthy son, whom the world called Taotie—this was San Miao. He was a vassal of Yao and enfeoffed with the state of San Miao, located to the left of Dongting Lake and the right of Poyang Lake, in Yuzhang, near Mount Heng. The Three Peaks were mountain names in the western wilds, in the land of the Qiang tribes west of Qinzhou. The Shaohao clan had an unworthy son, whom the world called Qiongqi—this was Gonggong. He served as Yao’s minister of waterworks. Youdu lay in the north—this was the land of Youzhou. The *Book of Documents* records the execution of Gun, but this text does not elaborate. These four men all harbored malice and defied Yao’s transformation, so they were exiled to the four wilds. This shows that Yao could not overcome the affairs of the world. Though the banishment of the Four Fiends was carried out by Shun, it is attributed to Yao here because Shun was then acting as Yao’s regent.

◎ *Exegesis*: *Huān*: pronounced *huān*. *Dōu*: *dīnghóu* in fanqie. *Chongshan*: in the southern wilds. In the sixtieth year of Yao’s reign, Huan Dou was exiled to Mount Chong. *Banishing San Miao*: In Cui’s edition, *banish* is written as *kill*; the *Book of Documents* has *exile*. San Miao was the son of the Lord of Red Cloud, i.e., Taotie. *Three Peaks*: pronounced *wēi*; also written as 危. The Three Peaks were mountains in the western wilds, now part of Tianshui. In the sixty-sixth year of Yao’s reign, San Miao was exiled to the Three Peaks. *Gonggong*: pronounced *gōng*. Gonggong was an official title, i.e., Qiongqi. *Youdu*: Li [Yi] says this was Youzhou, in the northern wilds. The *Book of Documents* has Youzhou. In the sixty-fourth year of Yao’s reign, Gonggong was banished to Youzhou.

【4】◎ Commentary: The names of Yao and Shun as emperors and kings are but their traces. I lodge in these traces, yet the traces are not me—thus the world is startled of itself. The more startled the world grows, the coarser the traces become. Coarseness and subtlety are but the levelness or ruggedness of the path; does the traveler ever change his feet? Thus the sage is one, yet there are differences among Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu. To clarify these differences: they are but names of the times, insufficient to name the sage’s reality. Therefore, Yao and Shun—were they merely one Yao and one Shun? Though they bore the appearance of toil and sorrow and the traces of benevolence and righteousness, what underlay those traces remained whole.

◎ Subcommentary: *Shī* means "to extend." From the Yellow Emperor to Yao and Shun, the sagely traces stagnated, and things grew disordered. This disorder extended to the Three Kings, and the alarm grew even greater.

◎ *Exegesis*: *Shī jí*: *yǐzhì* in fanqie. Cui [Yuan] says it means "to extend." *Dà hài*: *hài* means "alarm." *Yù cū*: pronounced *cū*; same below.

【5】◎ Subcommentary: Jie and Zhi practiced the conduct of petty men as their lowest standard, while Zeng and Shi practiced the conduct of gentlemen as their highest.

【6】◎ Subcommentary: The Ru and Mohists clung to traces, and from this, disputes over right and wrong arose.

【7】◎ Subcommentary: What one loves, another hates; their doubts and divisions multiply.

【8】◎ Subcommentary: They adorn their wisdom to startle the foolish, deceiving and humiliating one another.

◎ *Exegesis*: *Yú zhì*: pronounced *zhì*; same in the commentary below.

【9】◎ Subcommentary: Good and not good, each side condemns the other.

【10】◎ Subcommentary: They fabricate falsehoods and trust in truth, mocking and ridiculing one another.

【11】◎ Commentary: None could equal the self-sufficiency of the inner.

◎ Subcommentary: The entanglements persisted, and the cosmos declined.

【12】◎ Commentary: They established minor distinctions and did not rest in division.

◎ Subcommentary: Joy and anger, right and wrong flared up in great tumult. Thus the heavenly years were cut short, and natures and lives scattered in chaos. *Lànmàn* means "dispersed and disordered."

【13】◎ Commentary: Knowledge is boundless, yet they delighted in it—thus they had nothing to meet its demands.

◎ Subcommentary: The sage exhausted boundless knowledge; how could the common people not be drained?

◎ *Exegesis*: *Hào zhī*: *hūbào* in fanqie; same in the commentary.

【14】◎ Commentary: They carved and polished natures and lives, thus reaching this state.

◎ Subcommentary: The inked cord levels the crooked and straight of wood; rites and propriety show men degrees of honor and severity. The mallet and chisel bore holes in wood; punishments and laws sever men’s bodies and heads. Craftsmen wield axes and saws to mar timber; sages employ rites and laws to wound the Dao.

◎ *Exegesis*: *Jīn*: pronounced *jīn*, also written as 斤. *Jù*: pronounced *jù*. *Zhì yān*: axes and saws shape, as in mutilating punishments. *Shéngmò shā yān*: both read as written characters. Cui [Yuan] says: referring to execution by flogging. *Zhuī*: pronounced *zhuī*. *Záo*: pronounced *zuò*. *Jué yān*: pronounced *gǔxué* or *kǔxué*. Cui [Yuan] says: corporal punishments, hence the use of mallet and chisel.

【15】◎ Commentary: If one were to follow natural spontaneity and dwell in what is fitting, then worthy and foolish would follow their natures, noble and base would tread their proper stations, ruler and minister, high and low would all attain their ultimate norm—and the world would have no afflictions. Yet this course has entangled the hearts of the world, setting them galloping without cease. Thus, those of middling wisdom and below all outwardly adorn their natures to dazzle and delude the multitude, hating the upright and reviling the correct, drawing throngs of followers in their wake. Thereby, those who uphold authenticity lose their ground, while those who exalt falsity usurp their handle. Thus the lord is beset with cares above, and the people are distressed below.

【Exegesis】"Jiji" means trampling upon one another. Another interpretation holds that chaos arises—cosmic chaos—with blame lying in sagacity and knowledge. The Dao of the noble person wanes, and they conceal their traces in forests and marshes. Though the lord of men resides in the ancestral temple, his heart is ever anxious and trembling. Lacking worthy assistants, he fears the state may topple into peril.

【Pronunciation Notes】"脊脊" is pronounced *jiè* (音藉), with an alternate reading *zài yì* (在亦反), meaning "to trample upon." Originally written as "肴肴." *Guangya* states: "肴 means chaos." "大山" is pronounced *tài* (音泰), or may be read as written. "嵁" is pronounced *kū yán* (苦岩反), with alternate readings *kǔ xián* (苦咸反) or *kū yán* (苦严反). "岩" is pronounced *yán* (音严), with an alternate reading *yǔ xián* (语衔反), or *yán* (音岩), *yǔ xián* (语咸)〔反〕.

◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The current text reads "岩."

◎ Yu Yue states: In the *Pronunciation Notes*, "大山" is glossed as *tài* (音泰) but may also be read as written; the latter is correct. This refers generally to great mountains and is not necessarily Mount Tai of the Eastern Marchmount. "嵁" should be "湛." In the *Fengshan Wen* of the *Wen Xuan*, "湛恩鸿" is glossed by Li as "湛 means deep." "湛岩" thus means "deep crags," and since the context concerns mountains, the water radical was changed to the mountain radical. The text speaks of mountains as vast and crags as deep—these meanings correspond precisely. Scholars who fail to grasp this read "大" as *tài* (泰), which is erroneous. In the *Tian Zifang* chapter, "其神经乎大山而无介，入乎渊泉而不濡," the *Pronunciation Notes* gloss "大" as *tài* (泰), an error identical to this one. In the *Wen Xuan*'s *Feng Fu*, "缘泰山之阿," and the *Gushi* line "孤生竹，结根泰山阿," the wind’s path and the bamboo’s roots need not specifically refer to Mount Tai. The original text should read "大山" in both cases, referring generally to great mountains. Later readers misread it as *tài* (泰) and altered the text accordingly.

The *Yi Xuan* reads *xuán biàn* (玄遍) in reverse. The *Wu Zhi* reads *wū lù* (乌路). The *Fan Tu* is pronounced *fán* (烦).

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The Zhao Jianyi edition writes *dà* (大) as *tài* (太).
(2) The Zhao edition omits the character *hū* (乎).
(3) The character *dīng* (丁) is amended following the Shide Tang edition and the original *Shiwen* text.
(4) The Shide Tang edition writes *ér* (而) as *tiān* (天); the Zhao edition adds *tiān* (天) after *ér* (而).
(5) The Zhao edition writes *shèng* (圣) as *zhì* (至).
(6) The Shide Tang edition writes *ruò* (若) as *gù* (故).
(7) The Shide Tang edition omits the character *suì* (遂).
(8) The character *fǎn* (反) is amended following the Shide Tang edition and the original *Shiwen* text.
(9) The Shide Tang edition writes *yán* (岩); this text follows the *Shiwen* in emending it.

In the present age, those condemned to death lie heaped upon one another; those in cangues and pillories press shoulder to shoulder; and those subjected to punishment and execution stand in full view. Yet the Confucians and Mohists still stretch their legs and wave their arms amidst the fetters and shackles—how extreme is their delusion! How utterly shameless and devoid of shame they are!

I know not whether the wisdom of the sages does not in fact serve as the crossbeams and pegs of cangues and pillories, or whether benevolence and righteousness do not function as the chisels and tenons of fetters and shackles. How can one be certain that Zeng [zi] and Shi [yu] were not the first arrows in the quivers of Jie and Robber Zhi?

Thus it is said: “Cut off sageliness, cast aside wisdom, and the world will be greatly ordered.”

The annotation states: "殊" means to be definitively sentenced to death. "桁杨" refers to restraints—devices that clamp the feet and neck, all called *hengyang*. During the Warring States period and the declining Zhou era, it was precisely the traces of sageliness that led to the branding and mutilation of the Five Punishments, filling the thoroughfares with *hengyang* and causing those sentenced to death to lie heaped upon one another, their mangled remains strewn across the roads. "Press shoulder to shoulder" and "stand in full view" make clear their multitude.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Shusi* (殊死) is read as written. The *Guangya* states: "殊" means "to sever." Sima [Biao] says: "to decide." Another gloss: "to execute." The *Zilin* says: "to die," as does the *Shuowen*. It further notes: The Han ordinance states, "When chieftains of the Man and Yi tribes commit crimes, they are to be *shu*-ed." Cui [Yuan] writes it as "夭死" (premature death). *Xiangzhen* (相枕) is read with the *zhen* rhyme. *Heng* (桁) is read with the *gang* rhyme. Sima [Biao] says: "a long foot restraint." *Yang* (杨) is pronounced *yang* as in "阳." Cui [Yuan] says: "Restraints that clamp the neck and shins are all called *hengyang*."

The commentary states: This calamity arises from the pedantic Confucians clinging to traces. They do not consider abandoning traces to return to the One, but instead wave their arms, employing traces to govern traces—truly, how extreme is their shamelessness and lack of shame!

The annotation explains: *Liqi* (离跂) describes the exertion of force. The traces of sageliness are tools that harm beings, yet the Confucians and Mohists still wave their arms and strain beyond bounds amidst the fetters and shackles, clinging to traces and sealing off teachings to remedy the ills of the age. How could such chaos ever reach its limit? Thus, the sigh is uttered: how utterly benighted and shameless they are!

The *Shiwen* notes: *Li* (离) is read with the *shi* or *zhi* rhyme. *Qi* (跂) is read with the *shi* or *chi* rhyme.

《攘》 is read with the *ryang* rhyme. 《桎》 with the *zhī shí* rhyme. 《梏》 with the *gǔ dú* rhyme.

◎ Qing Fan’s note: *Líqì* corresponds to the meaning in Xunzi’s *Rongru* chapter—“deviating from the norm and straining to criticize”—referring to setting oneself apart from the multitude.

《意》 is read as written, or alternatively with the *yī* sound. 《无愧》 in Cui’s edition appears as a lacuna. 《腐》 is read with the *fǔ* sound. 《方复》 with the *fú yòu* rhyme.

【Three】【Annotation】 The *héngyáng* uses *jiēxí* as its pins, while the *zhìgù* employs chiseled tenons for function. Sagely wisdom and benevolence-righteousness are traces far removed from transgression. When traces distance themselves from transgression, the people then esteem them; when esteemed, deceit and pretense arise. Once deceit and pretense arise, those without the implements to suppress villainy have never existed. Thus, abandoning what is esteemed prevents deceit from emerging; when deceit does not emerge, the *héngyáng* and *zhìgù* are abolished—what need then for chiseled tenons or *jiēxí*?

【Commentary】 *Jiēxí* are the wedges of restraints. *Záo* means “hole.” Inserting an object into a hole is called a *ruì*. Shackles without wedges are not secure; manacles without holes are useless. This is akin to governance: without sagely traces, no standards are established; without benevolence-righteousness, Jie and Zhi would not act. Sagely traces are the source of entanglement, while benevolence-righteousness is the root of harm.

【Pronunciation Notes】 《椄》 Li reads as written; Xiang and Xu read it as *qiè*. Guo and Li read 《槢》 as *xí*; Xiang and Xu read it as *tuó xiè*. Sima explains: *Jiēxí* are the wedges of restraints. Pronounced with the *xī jié* rhyme. Cui’s edition has a lacuna, noting it may be read as *dié* or written as *xí*. *Jiēxí* are the beams of fetters. The *Huainanzi* states: “The large ones are pillars and beams; the small ones are *jiēxí*.”
◎ Qing Fan’s note: The *Wenxuan* commentary on He Yan’s *Jingfu Palace Rhapsody* cites Sima: “*Xí* are the wedges of restraints,” differing from the *Pronunciation Notes*. (The *Pronunciation Notes* include *jiē* before *xí* and omit *yě* after *xiè*.)

《凿》 reads *zào* in the Luoyang pronunciation, and also *zào* in the Baofu pronunciation. 《枘》 reads *ruì* in the Renrui pronunciation. Xiang’s edition writes it as *内*, with the same sound. The *San Cang* states: it is the tenon at the top of a pillar. The mortise at the head of a tenon fits into the wood like the tenon at the top of a pillar.

《远于》 reads *yú* as *yuàn*, with the same pronunciation below. 《而御》 reads *yù* in the Yulü pronunciation. The original text also writes it as *御*, with the same sound.

【Note】 *Hāo shǐ* are the fiercest of arrows, implying that Zeng [Can] and Shi [Qiu] serve as tools for Jie and Zhi.

【Subcommentary】 *Hāo* refers to the roaring sound of an arrowhead. Sagely wisdom is the instrument of usurping the state, while benevolence and righteousness are the resources of the violent. Zeng and Shi serve as the fierce arrows of Jie and Zhi, hence the statement.

【Pronunciation Notes】 《焉知》 reads *yān* as *yú*. 《嚆矢》 reads *hāo shǐ* in the Xujiao pronunciation. The original text also writes it as *嗃*. Xiang explains: *hāo shǐ* are arrows that whistle. Guo states: they are the fiercest of arrows. The *Zilin* says: *hāo* means a great cry. Cui’s edition writes it as *蒿*, explaining: mugwort can be made into arrows. It may also be written as *矫*, where *矫* means *sào* (clamor). Cui’s edition includes an additional twenty-four characters below this: *"If the mutual generation of being and non-being is so extreme, then Zeng and Shi and Jie and Zhi generate being and non-being—how could they not collide?"*

【Note】 Remove what causes entanglement.

【Subcommentary】 Abandon the instruments of usurpation and discard the resources of violence, and the world will be at peace—this is called great governance.

【Pronunciation Notes】 《大治》 reads *dà* as *zhì*. 《去其》 reads *qù* in the Qilü pronunciation.

【Collation Notes】
(1) The Shidetang edition writes *思*; Zhao Jianyi’s edition writes *斯*.
(2) Zhao’s edition writes *矫* as *骄*.
(3) The Shidetang edition writes *奸*.
(4) The character *妾* is amended following the Shidetang edition; the original *Pronunciation Notes* also mistakenly wrote *燮*.

After ruling as the Son of Heaven for nineteen years, the Yellow Emperor’s decrees reached all under heaven. Hearing that Guangchengzi dwelled on Mount Kongtong, he went to see him and said: “I have heard that you, Master, have attained the ultimate Dao. I venture to ask: what is the essence of the ultimate Dao? I wish to gather the essence of heaven and earth to aid the five grains and nourish the people. I also wish to regulate yin and yang to nurture all living things. How should this be done?”

【Collation Notes】
(1) The character *山* is amended following the *Quewu* edition’s citation of Zhang Junfang’s text and the *Chengshu* commentary.

【Commentary】
(1) The virtue of his transformation and decrees spread widely throughout the realm.
(2) Mount Kongtong lies on the northern border of Liangzhou. Guangcheng is another name for Laozi.
【Pronunciation Notes】
*Guangchengzi*: Some say this is Laozi.
*Kongtong*: Sima [Biao] says: the mountain beneath the Northern Dipper. The *Erya* states: "That which bears the Dipper’s pole is called Kongtong." Another account places it thirty *li* east of Yucheng in Liangguo.
(3) The five grains are millet, glutinous millet, beans, hemp, and wheat. He wished to draw upon the profound principles of the Way, the essential qi of heaven and earth and yin and yang, to aid the growth of the five grains and nourish the people.
(4) *Suì* means "to accord." He wished to model the regulation of yin and yang by establishing offices and dividing duties, thereby harmonizing with the natures of all living things, and asked how this might be achieved.

Guangchengzi said: “What you wish to inquire about concerns the substance of things; what you wish to regulate concerns the ruin of things. Since you began to govern all under heaven, clouds have rained without gathering, grasses and trees have withered before turning yellow, and the light of the sun and moon has grown ever more dim.
