With a mind as narrow as that of a flatterer, how could you be fit to speak of the ultimate Dao?”

(1) *Annotation:* To inquire into the essence of the ultimate Dao may indeed be called "substance."
*Commentary:* 而 (*er*) means "you." Your wish to sow and cultivate the five grains and establish offices to regulate the two modes [of yin and yang]—what you ask is coarse and shallow, no more than physical form, far removed from the profound and mysterious. This is a rebuke.
*Exegesis:* 《質也》 (*Zhì yě*) The *Guangya* states: *zhi* means "correct."

(2) *Annotation:* To not allow things to be as they are of themselves but instead seek to regulate them is to ruin them.
*Commentary:* If you insist on establishing offices and dividing duties, compelling things to follow your will, you will violate the workings of creation and inevitably bring about harm and destruction.

(3) *Commentary:* 族 (*zú*) means "to gather." To appoint officials to manage yin and yang and govern all things with intent will surely invite calamity. Wind and rain will fall out of harmony, heat and cold lose their proper season; clouds will rain before gathering, leaves will fall while the trees are still green. Comets and eclipses will dim the three luminaries, human hearts will be disturbed, and the celestial patterns will grow desolate and perilous.
*Exegesis:* 《云氣不待族而雨》 Sima [Biao] says: *zú* means "to gather." Rain falls before clouds gather, indicating a scarcity of moisture.
《草木不待黃而落》 Sima [Biao] says: This indicates an excess of killing *qi*.
The *Erya* states: *luò* means "to die."
《益以》 Cui [Zhuan] writes this as *gài yǐ*.

(4) *Commentary:* 翦翦 (*jiǎnjiǎn*) describes a narrow and inferior state. You are a flattering and obsequious man, your mind petty and shallow—how could you be fit to speak of the ultimate Dao!
*Exegesis:* 《佞人》 Read as written. Guo [Xiang] reads this as *níng*.
《翦翦》 Read as written. Guo [Xiang] and Sima [Biao] say: "skilled in debate." Another says: "the appearance of obsequiousness." Li [Yi] says: "a shallow and limited appearance." Another says: "a cramped and small appearance."

The Yellow Emperor withdrew, relinquished the world, built a solitary chamber, spread a mat of white cogon grass, and dwelled in seclusion for three months before returning to seek him out.

*Commentary:* The Yellow Emperor withdrew, purified his mind, relinquished the throne of the Nine-Five, built a solitary chamber to escape the clamor, spread white cogon grass to maintain purity, and dwelled in seclusion for a time before returning once more to seek the Dao. 邀 (*yāo*) means "to encounter."
*Exegesis:* 《捐》 Read as *yuàn*.
《閒居》 Read as *xián*. The annotation below is the same.
《復往》 Read as *fù wǎng*.
《邀之》 Read as *yāo zhī*, meaning "to seek."

Guangchengzi lay with his head to the south. The Yellow Emperor approached from downwind, crawling forward on his knees, bowed twice, touched his forehead to the ground, and asked: “I have heard that you, Master, have attained the ultimate Dao. I venture to ask: how should one cultivate the body so as to achieve longevity?”

Guangchengzi sprang to his feet and said: “An excellent question! Come!”

“I shall speak to you of the ultimate Dao. The essence of the ultimate Dao is profound and obscure; its utmost reaches are dim and silent. See nothing, hear nothing, embrace the spirit in stillness, and the body will naturally align itself. You must be still, you must be pure; do not weary your form, do not disturb your qi, and only then can you attain longevity. Let your eyes see nothing, your ears hear nothing, your heart know nothing, and your spirit will guard your form—thus your form will endure. Guard your inner self, seal off the outer, for excessive knowledge brings ruin.

I shall lead you to the heights of great brightness, to the source of utmost yang; I shall guide you through the gate of profound obscurity, to the source of utmost yin. Heaven and Earth have their offices, yin and yang their repositories; guard your body with care, and all things will naturally flourish. I preserve the One and dwell in harmony, and so I have cultivated my body for one thousand two hundred years, yet my form has never declined.”

“[2] *Commentary*: ‘Profound obscurity’ and ‘silent darkness’ both signify utter nothingness. Why do Zhuangzi and Laozi repeatedly extol *wu* (non-being)? To clarify that what gives rise to things is no-thing, and things arise of themselves. They arise of themselves—not for the sake of arising—so how could there be any further action upon what has already arisen?

*Subcommentary*: The utmost Dao is subtle and imperceptible to the heart-mind; thus it is likened to profound obscurity, deep remoteness, silent darkness, and absolute mystery.

*Philological Notes*: 《吾语》: *yú jù* (rhyme). Below, same. 《女》: *rǔ*. Hereafter the same. 《窈窈》: *wū liǎo* (rhyme).

[3] *Commentary*: Forget seeing yet see of yourself; forget hearing yet hear of yourself—then the spirit will not be disturbed, and the form will not go awry.

*Subcommentary*: When the ears and eyes refrain from outward seeing and hearing, embracing and guarding the spirit, external conditions cannot confuse; heart-mind and form unite, and one naturally merges with the upright Dao.

*Philological Notes*: 《不邪》: *sì jiē* (rhyme).

[4] *Commentary*: Allowing it to move of itself, one remains at ease and still, never cut short.

*Subcommentary*: Purify the spirit and still the thoughts; the body knows no toil. Not clinging to external conditions, the spirit abides in constant stillness. The heart-mind is at leisure, the form at ease—thus one attains longevity and enduring vision.

[5] *Commentary*: All these follow nature in movement, hence longevity.

*Subcommentary*: Engage in seeing and hearing yet perceive nothing; the sense faculties and their objects are empty, the heart-mind likewise at peace. Illumination is free of knowing and deliberation; response to the moment remains ever still. The spirit, serene, guards the form—thus one may attain longevity and enduring vision.

[6] *Commentary*: Preserving one’s true nature.

*Subcommentary*: Forgetting the heart-mind preserves the true.

[7] *Commentary*: Guarding one’s allotted portion.

*Subcommentary*: Cutting off seeing and hearing, one guards one’s portion.

[8] *Commentary*: Knowledge without bounds brings ruin.

*Subcommentary*: Without caution in wisdom and thought, the heart-spirit is exhausted; ears and eyes are spent on externals—how could this not lead to ruin?

[9] *Commentary*: To reach the source of yin and yang is to emerge upon the heights of great brightness and enter the gate of profound obscurity.

*Subcommentary*: Yang is movement; yin is stillness. *Suì* means ‘to emerge.’ When the perfected one responds to movement, wisdom shines like the sun and moon—this is called ‘great brightness.’ The source of utmost yang traces the descent of manifestations from their origin, hence it is said to ‘emerge.’ When there is no stimulus, the root is profoundly still, congealed in tranquility—this is the source of utmost yin. It demonstrates the return of manifestations to their origin, hence it is called ‘entering the gate of profound obscurity.’ Guangcheng revealed to the Yellow Emperor both the principles of movement and stillness, thus employing the two gates of yin and yang.

*Philological Notes*: 《我为》: *yú wěi* (rhyme). Below, same.”

**Annotations and Text:**

[10] *Commentary*: Simply allow things to follow their course.

[11] *Subcommentary*: The "offices of Heaven" refer to the sun, moon, and stars, which illuminate the four directions and govern the myriad things—hence they are called "offices." The "offices of Earth" refer to metal, wood, water, fire, and earth, which sustain the movements of plants and animals and bear the multitude of beings—thus they too are called "offices." The two qi of yin and yang, along with the four seasons of spring, summer, autumn, and winter, each have their appointed functions, like the viscera and bowels. All things follow their nature without hindrance, perfectly attuned—why defy the transformations of creation by establishing further offices and bureaus? Woman, simply practice non-action, guard your body with care, and all the myriad things will naturally flourish. Why trouble your heart and bring sorrow upon yourself?

*Philological Notes*: 《物将自壮》 *cè liàng* (rhyme). This means that if one does not govern the world, all things will follow their own course and grow strong thereby.

[12] *Commentary*: It is a matter of fully realizing the utmost of one’s nature and destiny, attaining the ultimate of long life. Only when the body does not meet an untimely end can one extend care to others.

*Subcommentary*: Preserve tranquility and a unified mind, abide in the wondrous Dao of central harmony, cultivate and protect the body—though one may enjoy a long lifespan, there will never come a day of decline.

*Textual Note*: (1) The character *zhēn* (真) is amended according to the commentary.

The Yellow Emperor bowed twice, touching his head to the ground, and said, "Guangchengzi is indeed like Heaven!"

[1] *Commentary*: Heaven is non-action.

*Subcommentary*: He praised the lofty purity of the sagely Dao, which may unite in virtue with the mysterious Heaven.

Guangchengzi said, "Come! I will tell you."

Those beings are without end, yet all people deem them finite;
Those beings are unfathomable, yet all people deem them bounded.

One who attains my Dao,
above becomes a sovereign, below a king.
One who loses my Dao,
above sees light, below becomes earth.

Now, the hundred flourishing things all arise from earth and return to earth.
Thus I shall leave you,
enter the gate of the boundless,
and wander the wilds of the infinite.

I share radiance with the sun and moon,
I am constant with Heaven and Earth.
Approach me—luminous!
Distance yourself—obscured!
All people will perish entirely,
yet I alone endure!"

Returning to the profound stillness of the root, entering the gate of the boundless;
responding to transformations between Heaven and Earth, wandering the wilds of the infinite.

Utterly yielding to them.

To partake is to be one—
sharing radiance with the three luminaries,
abiding as long as the two poles.
How could it be a mere twelve hundred years!

Things come and go,
yet none perceive it.

The sage, empty of mind as a mirror,
when the moment calls forth a response, answers in perfect accord;
if no stimulus comes, remains dim and obscure.

"Approach me—luminous!
Distance yourself—obscured!"
Whether turning toward or away,
all is met with the same unburdened heart.

Seeing life and death as one body,
there is nowhere that is not presence.

To unite life and death is to illuminate transformation—
nothing was ever not the self.
No going, no coming,
I alone endure.

People cling to life and death,
and so suffer distress.

Cloud General was traveling east,
passed the branch of the Whirlwind Tree,
and there by chance encountered Vast Vagueness.
Vast Vagueness was just then slapping his thigh and leaping about in play.
Cloud General saw him,
startled, halted,
and stood in astonishment, saying:
"Old sir, who are you?
Old sir, what are you doing?"

Li Yun: "Cloud General" means the commander of clouds.
*Fuyao*: *Fu* is also written as *fu*, pronounced *fu*. Li Yun: *Fuyao* is a divine tree, growing in the Eastern Sea. Another says: it is the wind.
◎ Qingfan’s note: *Chuxue Ji* 1 and *Taiping Yulan* 8 cite Sima [Biao] as saying: "Cloud General is the commander of clouds." *Shiwen* omits this.
*Hongmeng*: read as written. Sima [Biao] says: it is the primordial qi of nature. Another says: it is the qi above the sea.
*Fu*: *fufu* (反切), one reading *fu*. *Pi*: in some editions written as *bi* (髀), pronounced *bi*. Xu [Shen] reads *fubi* (反切), also *fudi* (反切).
*Que*: in some editions written as *jue* (爵), same meaning. Pronounced *jianglüe* (反切).
*Yue*: Sima [Biao] says: "sparrow-leaping," like a sparrow bathing. Another says: like a sparrow’s hopping.

[Annotation 2] The commentary explains: [Cloud General] marveled at [Vast Vagueness’s] appearance and bearing, so unlike the common, and his movements so extraordinary, that he asked the reason for his journey, hoping to learn the Way of governing things.

[Annotation 3] The commentary explains: *tang* is an expression of startled doubt. *Zhi* means unmoving. *Sou* is the name for an elder.
*Shiwen*: *Tang*: *chizhang* (反切), one reading *tulang* (反切), Li [Zhouhan] reads *tudang* (反切). Sima [Biao] says: it is the appearance of wanting to stop.

Li [Zhouhan] says: the appearance of being lost in oneself.
*Zhi*: *zhi’er* (反切), also *zhuli* (反切), or *yulie* (反切). Li [Zhouhan] says: the appearance of immobility.
*Sou*: in some editions written as □, *sukou* (反切), Guo [Xiang] reads *suzou* (反切). Sima [Biao] says: a term for elders.

[Collation] (1) Zhao the Remonstrator’s edition writes *pi que* as *bi jue*, the same below. (2) *Shenmu* follows the *Shiwen* emendation.

Hong Meng clapped his thigh and sparrow-leaped without ceasing, then turned to Cloud General and said, “Roam!”

[Annotation 1] To roam is to wander freely through the transformations of nature.

[Shiwen] *Bu chuo*: *dielie* (反切). Li [Zhouhan] says: to stop.

Cloud General said, “I wish to ask you something.”

Hong Meng looked up at Cloud General and said, “Hmph!”

Cloud General said, “The qi of Heaven is disharmonious, the qi of Earth is pent-up, the Six Qi are unbalanced, and the Four Seasons are out of order. Now I wish to blend the essence of the Six Qi to nurture all living things—how might I do this?”

[Annotation 1] The two qi neither descend nor ascend, thus pent-up.
[Shiwen] *Yue xu*: *kuangyu* (反切). Also written as *hu*. ◎ Qingfan notes: In the *Shiwen*, *xu* is also written as *hu*. *Hu xu* are interchangeable in ancient texts. The *Shuowen* says: *xu* is an exclamation of surprise. In the *Zuozhuan* of the first year of Duke Wen, “calling the laborers,” Du [Yu]’s commentary says: *hu* is an utterance. In the *Canon of Yao*, “the Emperor said *xu*,” the commentary says: *xu* is an expression of doubt and astonishment. An exclamation of surprise or doubt is also an utterance. In the *Tan Gong*, “startled, he said *hu*,” the *Shiwen* writes *hu* as *xu*. In the *Monthly Ordinances*, “the great *yu* sacrifice to the Emperor,” Zheng [Xuan]’s commentary says: *yu* is the sacrifice of sighing and calling for rain. In the *Rites of Zhou*, the *Subcommentary on Female Shamans* cites Dong Zhongshu: “*Yu* is the art of seeking rain, a song of sighing and calling.” All are examples of this.
*Yu jie*: read as written. Cui [Yuan]’s edition writes *wan*, pronounced *jie*.

[Annotation 2] Yin-yang, wind-rain, darkness-brightness—these are the Six Qi.
[Annotation 3] Spring, summer, autumn, winter—their seasonal order is disrupted and delayed.
[Annotation 4] I wish to blend the essence of the Six Qi to nourish the myriad beings, hence the question.

[Collation] (1) The character *yu* is supplied from the *Shuowen*.

Hong Meng clapped his thigh, sparrow-leaped, and shook his head, saying, “I do not know! I do not know!”

[Annotation 1]

[Annotation 1] All things receive their nature from the spontaneous; if one were to impose intention to govern them, it would surely contravene the workings of creation—hence his shaking of the head and refusal to answer.

*Shiwen*: *Diao* (掉) is read *tiao* (徒吊反).

Cloud General could obtain no answer. Three years later, he traveled east, passing through the wilds of Song, where he chanced upon Hong Meng. Cloud General rejoiced greatly, hastening forward and saying, “Has Heaven forgotten me? Has Heaven forgotten me?” He bowed twice, touching his head to the ground, and entreated Hong Meng for instruction.

[Annotation 1] He revered him as he would Heaven; repeating “forgotten me” expressed his hope to recall their former encounter.

*Shiwen*: *You Song* (有宋) is read as written, the name of a state. The variant *zong* (宗) is incorrect.

Hong Meng said, “Wandering aimlessly, I know not what I seek; roaming wildly, I know not where I go. The traveler moves with restless urgency, observing what is without delusion. What do I know?”

The *Subcommentary* states: "Floating and wandering through the world entails no grasping or seizing."

[Annotation 2] *Zhu* notes: "And thus naturally attains what it seeks."
The *Subcommentary* states: "Moving without intent is aimless wandering, without fixed direction."

[Annotation 3] *Zhu* notes: "One who is inwardly sufficient finds all things self-correcting upon a mere glance."
The *Subcommentary* states: "Hong Meng’s roaming heart dwells in vastness; the things it encounters are manifold. The wisdom of observation knows that the realm it perceives is without delusion. *Yangzhang* means abundance."
*Shiwen*: *Yangzhang* is read *yu zhang* (于丈反). The *Mao Poetry Tradition* states: "*Yangzhang* means loss of composure." Here, however, it signifies self-attainment and correctness.

[Annotation 4] *Zhu* notes: "It is merely this."
The *Subcommentary* states: "Floating and wandering, unburdened in heart and yielding to things—each thing corrects itself, so what do I know?"

Cloud General said, "I myself believed I was acting wildly, yet the people follow wherever I go. I cannot escape the people, and now they imitate me. I wish to hear a single word."

[Annotation 1] *Zhu* notes: "Riding the natural course of things is not for the sake of leaving traces, yet traces manifest of themselves. Wildness is not for the sake of summoning the people, yet the people follow of themselves. Thus, one is compelled by the people’s imitation and cannot escape."
The *Subcommentary* states: "Like Hong Meng, I govern the world without intent. Unable to avoid overseeing the people, they follow my traces and are thus led by things to imitate me."
*Shiwen*: *Zhi fang* (之放) is read *fang wang* (方往反), meaning "imitation." The *Zhu* concurs.

[Annotation 2] The *Subcommentary* states: "I wish to hear the essential teaching, that my profound doubts may be resolved."

Hong Meng said, "To disorder the constant principles of Heaven and contravene the nature of things is to fail in the mysterious work of Heaven. To scatter the herds of beasts and cause birds to cry out at night; to bring calamity upon grasses and trees and disaster upon insects—this is the fault of governing people!"

[Annotation 1] *Zhu* notes: "If one follows the nature of things without governing, then natures are not contravened and principles are not disordered. The mysterious and silent work is accomplished, and the natural is attained."
The *Subcommentary* states: "To disorder the constant Dao of Heaven and contravene the true nature of things is to invite deceit and cunning, so that the transformations of the natural are not fulfilled."

[Annotation 2] *Zhu* notes: "Separated from their source of stillness."
The *Subcommentary* states: "When traces are imitated and manifest, harm to things arises: beasts are startled into scattering, and birds are frightened into crying out at night."

[Annotation 3] *Zhu* notes: "All sit and receive harm."
The *Subcommentary* states: "Grasses and trees wither before frost, and calamity befalls insects. *Kun* means brightness, referring to those that emerge toward the sun."
*Shiwen*: *Zhi chong* (止虫) is read as written. Some versions write *kun chong* (昆虫). Cui’s version writes *zheng chong* (正虫). *Jie zuo* (皆坐) is read *cai wo* (才卧反).

[Annotation 4] *Zhu* notes: "The traces of governance are the very source of disorder."
The *Subcommentary* states: "Where Heaven governs, things perish—this is the fault of governing people."
*Shiwen*: *Yi* (意) is read *yi* (医). Some versions write *yi* (噫). The same applies below.

The *Collation Notes* state:
(1) The Zhao Jianyi edition writes *kun* (昆) in place of *zhi* (止).
(2) The Zhao edition writes *yi* (噫) for *yi* (意), and the same applies below.

Cloud General said, "In that case, what am I to do?"
[Annotation 1] *Subcommentary*: He wishes to request the art of non-governance.

Hong Meng replied, "*Yi*! How poisonous indeed!
[Annotation 1] *Zhu* notes: The fault of governing people runs deep.
*Subcommentary*:

「*Duo* (咄) is interchangeable with *chu* (黜). (In the *Xu Wugui* chapter, *chu qi yu* [黜耆欲] appears as *duo* in Sima Biao’s edition.) Wei Zhao’s commentary on the *Zhouyu* states: *Chu* means to dismiss. *Chu* and *duo* (堕) share similar meanings. In the *Great Master* chapter, *duo zhi ti, chu cong ming* (堕枝体，黜聪明) serves as evidence. In clerical script, the character *chu* (出) is sometimes abbreviated as *shi* (士) (as in *ao* [敖] abbreviated as *mai* [卖], or *kuan* [款] abbreviated as *mai* [卖]). Thus, *duo* (咄) may appear as □, and due to its resemblance to *tu* (吐), it was mistakenly written as such. (The corruption of *duo* into *tu* mirrors the corruption of *tu* into *duo*. In the *Book of Han*, *Bi wei e tu qi wo* [必畏恶吐弃我] appears in the *Han Ji* as *duo* instead of *tu*.) Yu Yue said: *Tu* should be *du* (杜), meaning to block or suppress one’s intelligence.

[Annotation 4] *Commentary*: Unbounded by things.
*Subcommentary*: *Mingxing* is the qi of spontaneity. When body and mind merge into vastness, they unite with the natural whole.
*Exegetical Notes*: *Xing* (涬) is pronounced *huding* or *xing*. *Ming* (溟) is pronounced *muding*. Sima Biao says: *Xingming* is the qi of spontaneity.

[Annotation 5] *Commentary*: Sitting in forgetfulness, embracing solitude.
*Subcommentary*: *Hun* refers to the pursuit of knowledge. *Jieshi* means to release and dissolve. *Moran* signifies ignorance; cleansing the mind until it resembles dead ashes or withered wood, devoid of conscious *hun*.

[Annotation 6] *Commentary*: Only by forgetting knowledge can one truly return.
*Subcommentary*: *Yunyun* denotes multiplicity. Amid the ceaseless flux of arising and ceasing, all remains rooted in spontaneity. How could one rely on knowledge to return to the root?

[Annotation 7] *Commentary*: Abiding in primordial chaos without knowledge, allowing spontaneous return, one remains forever united with the source.
*Subcommentary*: Dwelling in chaos without knowledge, embracing solitude, one traverses myriad transformations without departing from spontaneity.
*Exegetical Notes*: *Hunhun* (浑浑) is pronounced *hubun*. *Dundun* (沌沌) is pronounced *tubun*. *Buli* (不离) is pronounced *lizhi*. The same applies to the commentary below.

[Annotation 8] *Commentary*: To know and then return is to deviate from true return.
*Subcommentary*: Seeking the root through knowledge is to stray from the nature of spontaneity.

[Annotation 9] *Commentary*: Inquiry disrupts the spontaneity of life.
*Subcommentary*: The Dao transcends names and words; principle eludes thought and emotion. To question the Dao with names or peer into principle with emotions—how far removed is this! Only by relinquishing emotions and forgetting names, surrendering to spontaneous transformation, can things attain their natural vitality.
*Collation Notes*: The Shidetang edition writes *zhi* (知) in place of *zhi* (之).

Cloud General said, "Heaven has bestowed virtue upon me and shown me the Way of silence. Through personal cultivation, I have now attained it." He bowed twice, touched his forehead to the ground, rose, and departed.

[Annotation 1] *Commentary*: To know without silence is to perpetually lose oneself.

*Subcommentary*: Heaven has sent down words of virtue and demonstrated the practice of profound silence. From the moment I stood in this body, only now have I awakened.

Ordinary people delight in those who resemble themselves and despise those who differ.
[Annotation 1] *Subcommentary*: Those mired in habit and delusion grow accustomed to favoring the like-minded and resenting the unlike.
*Exegetical Notes*: *Er wu* (而恶) is pronounced *wulu*.

They desire conformity and reject difference because they seek to stand out from the crowd.
[Annotation 2] *Commentary*: Their heart aspires to rise above the multitude as an outstanding figure.
*Subcommentary*: To affirm oneself and negate others, to favor the like and despise the unlike, is to crave distinction and renown, striving to surpass the masses.
◎ Jia Shifu says: To stand out from the crowd is to surpass others in talent and wisdom, compelling all to submit. Yet how can one know whether it is oneself who stands out from the crowd or the crowd that stands out from oneself? Aligning with the crowd’s preferences—conforming where they conform, differing where they differ—one remains one of them. Thus, delighting in conformity and despising difference is merely another form of aligning with the crowd. Joy and anger arise not from oneself but from the crowd, yet one clings to them as one’s own—this is the root of confusion.

[Annotation 3] *Commentary*: Since all desire to stand out, they remain ordinary. If I, too, sought to stand out, I would differ from them in no way and could never surpass them. Only by never opposing the multitude in any regard can one truly transcend them and become their master.
*Subcommentary*: People’s hearts are set on competition and distinction, a base and common impulse. How can one rise above the crowd? Only by harmonizing with their dust and radiance can one truly stand apart as their paragon.

[Annotation 4] *Commentary*: My own knowledge is no match for the multitude’s skills; thus, relying on them brings peace. Without such reliance, the countless masses become my adversaries.
*Subcommentary*: Employing the skills of the multitude and deferring to their insights eliminates contention. This is what is meant by "the wise see for them, the clever plan for them."
*Exegetical Notes*: *Yin zhong yi ning suo wen* (因众以宁所闻) means to entrust oneself to the multitude’s knowledge and perceptions, thereby attaining tranquility.

The *bu ru zhong ji* (不如众技) reads *qǐ* in the *qǐ* rhyme. *Zhong yi* (众矣): If I rely on my own knowledge to surpass the multitude, the multitude’s skills will outnumber mine—how can I avoid self-imposed distress?

*[Annotation 5] Commentary*: Those who seek to govern others’ states yet refuse to rely on the multitude’s self-governance, imposing their own will instead, merely chase the profit of the Three Kings’ dominion while blind to the peril of their own doing. Yet how did the Three Kings secure their profit? By entrusting themselves to the self-governance of all under heaven.

*Subcommentary*: Those who govern a state through their own partiality and obstinacy merely chase the profit of the Three Kings’ dominion, unaware that it spells their own ruin.

*Exegetical Notes*: *Ci lan* (此揽) is pronounced *lǎn*; the original text also writes it as *lan* (览).

*[Annotation 6] Subcommentary*: To seek illicit gain for a royal state through coercion and presumption—such fortune for a single person—inevitably leads to ruin. Not one in ten thousand survives; how fleeting is such a fate!

*Exegetical Notes*: *Jiao* (侥) is read as *gǔ yáo* in the *Gu Yao* rhyme; Xu Shen reads it as *gǔ liǎo*, and the character may also be written as *jiao* (徼). *Xing* (幸) is pronounced *xìng*. One interpretation: *jiao xing* (侥幸) describes an insatiable pursuit of profit. ◎Qing Fan’s note: *Jiao* means coercion or seeking. The *Exegetical Notes* sometimes write it as *jiao* (徼), which also means seeking (see Gao You’s commentary on the *Lüshi Chunqiu*, "Ode to the People"). *Ji he* (几何) is read as *jū qǐ*; Guo Pu reads it as *jù jī*. *Bu sang* (不丧) is read as *xī làng*, and the same applies below and in the commentary.

*[Annotation 7] Commentary*: The self and all under heaven arise through mutual reliance. If one insists on monopolizing all under heaven with a single self, all under heaven becomes obstructed—how can the self remain unobstructed? Thus, the self fails to achieve completion, and the myriad regions suffer ruin beyond measure.

*Subcommentary*: To rule as a sovereign with a presumptuous heart is to ensure no success in preservation and excess in ruin.

*Exegetical Notes*: *Wan fen* (万分) is read as written, or alternatively as *fú wèn*.

*[Annotation 8] Subcommentary*: This line laments that rulers fail to recognize the harm of presumption.

*Collation Notes*:
(1) The Jiangnan ancient manuscript reads *ci yi* (此以) as *yi ci yin* (以此因).
(2) The Shide Hall edition omits this line.
(3) The Shide Hall edition omits the character *zhong* (众).

Those who possess land possess great dominion. Those who possess great dominion cannot be possessed by it. To be possessed yet not possessed—only thus can one master all things. Understanding that the master of all things is not a thing itself—how could this apply merely to governing the people of all under heaven? Moving in and out of the six directions, roaming the nine provinces, coming and going alone—this is called "possessing singularity." Those who possess singularity are called "most noble."

*[Annotation 1] Subcommentary*: The ninth and fifth hexagrams, lofty and revered, vast as the four seas—these are called great dominion.

*[Annotation 2] Commentary*: Those who cannot use things but are used by them are merely things themselves—how can they master all things? Unable to master all things, they are unfit to possess great dominion.

*Subcommentary*: Those who pursue the dominion of the Three Kings yet fail to let things govern themselves are instead governed by things. If the self is but a thing, how can it master all things? It is utterly impossible.

*[Annotation 3] Commentary*: Those who use things are not used by them. Not being used by things, they are not things. Not being things, they can govern the things of all under heaven, allowing each to attain its proper place.

*Subcommentary*: Not being used by things but using them. ◎Jia Shifu says: When a thing exists and one perceives it as a thing to be mastered, one remains bound to it for life. The greater the thing one perceives, the smaller one’s self becomes. Yet when one perceives no thing at all, all things submit of their own accord. If one does not even perceive a thing, how can one be concerned with its size? ◎Yu Yue says: Guo Xiang’s division of the phrase *bu ke yi wu wu* (不可以物物) into five characters as a single clause misreads the text. It should be read as *bu ke yi wu* (不可以物) for the first clause and *wu er bu wu* (物而不物) for the second.

*[Annotation 4] Commentary*: Relying on the self-governance of all under heaven, one roams boundlessly among the myriad things.

*Subcommentary*: The sage, attuned to nature and penetrating the workings of creation, employs the knowledge of the people and the senses of all beings—thus understanding that the master of all things is not a thing itself. How could this apply merely to wearing the imperial yellow, sitting in the Fenyang Palace, holding the jade seal, and governing all under heaven? One must instead transcend the six directions, soar beyond the heavens, traverse the nine provinces, and wander the slopes of Mount Guye.

*[Annotation 5] Commentary*: While others distinguish themselves, one alone roams in harmony with the multitude—this is what it means to come and go alone. To possess this singularity is to truly possess singularity.

*Subcommentary*: As per the commentary.

*[Annotation 6] Commentary*: Those who merge with the multitude in profound unity do not seek nobility from others, yet others cannot but revere them—this is the highest nobility. If, however, one clings to partial views and takes singular distinction as one’s aim, even if aligned with a single purpose, one remains but a thing among the common—no true singularity. Without singularity, to covet rank and titles, seizing what is not rightfully one’s own—how could the multitude submit? Thus, one is not most noble.

*Subcommentary*: While others seek to stand out, one alone roams in harmony with the multitude—a feat no other can achieve, hence called "possessing singularity." Those who possess singularity are joyfully embraced by the people, borne aloft by the masses. To be their sovereign is to be most exalted and noble.

*Exegetical Notes*: *Tao* (饕) is read as *tǔ dāo*. *Mao* (冒) is read as *wáng bèi* or *wáng bào*.

*Collation Notes*:
(1) The Shide Hall edition adds *ye* (也) after *zhi* (之).
(2) The twenty-seven characters from *ren jie zi yi* (人皆自异) to *ke wei du you yi* (可谓独有矣) are mistakenly inserted into the commentary and should be deleted.

The great person’s teaching is like form to shadow, sound to echo. When questioned, they respond, exhausting what lies in the questioner’s heart, serving as a counterpart to all under heaven. Abiding in no-echo, moving in no-direction, they grasp and guide you through the tumult of going and returning, roaming without end. Emerging and entering without side, with the sun having no beginning, they extol and discourse on the bodily form, harmonizing with the Great Unity—unified in the Great Unity yet without self. Without self, how could there be anything possessed? Those who perceive possession are the gentlemen of former times; those who perceive nothingness are friends of heaven and earth.

*Subcommentary*:
The hearts of the common people are form and sound; the great person’s teaching is shadow and echo. What intent does the great person hold toward all under heaven? Merely following form and sound like shadow and echo.

*Exegesis*:
The great person is the sage. Without intent, they respond—not by intent—thus the hearts of the common people are form and sound, and the great person’s teaching is shadow and echo.

*Annotation*:
- *To shadow/echo* (于向): pronounced *xǔ zhàng*. The original also writes *响* (echo).
- *Exhausting what lies in the questioner’s heart*: allowing each to fully express what they hold within.
- *Serving as a counterpart*: the questioner is the host; the response thus serves as counterpart.
- *Abiding in no-echo*: dwelling in stillness to await things.
- *Moving in no-direction*: transforming in accord with things.
- *Grasp and guide you through the tumult of going and returning*: *tumult* (挠挠) means self-movement. Lifting and guiding the myriad things, they restore their self-moving nature—this is the perfection of non-action.
- *Roaming without end*: moving in unison with transformation, hence without end.
- *Emerging and entering without side*: mystically identical, without outward mark.
- *With the sun having no beginning*: moving in unison with daily renewal, hence without beginning.
- *Harmonizing with the Great Unity*: their form and appearance differ not from heaven and earth.
- *Unified in the Great Unity yet without self*: possessing a self precludes Great Unity.
- *Without self, how could there be anything possessed?*: The difficulty in all under heaven lies in the self. Once the self is absent, the multitude of things need no longer be possessed.
- *Those who perceive possession*: merely those who beautify names.
- *Those who perceive nothingness*: allowing things to live in their singularity.

*Collation Notes*:
(1) The Zhao Jianyi edition writes *响* (echo); the Shide Hall edition writes *向* (toward). Following the *Exegesis*, it should be *向*.
(2) The character *也* is amended according to the Shide Hall edition.

What is base yet cannot be left unengaged is *things*;
what is lowly yet cannot be left unaccommodated is *the people*;
what is hidden yet cannot be left undone is *affairs*;
what is coarse yet cannot be left unarticulated is *law*;
what is distant yet cannot be left unoccupied is *righteousness*;
what is intimate yet cannot be left unexpanded is *benevolence*;
what is measured yet cannot be left unaccumulated is *ritual*;
what is centered yet cannot be left unexalted is *virtue*;
what is singular yet cannot be left unchanged is *the Dao*;
what is numinous yet cannot be left unenacted is *Heaven*.

Thus the sage observes Heaven yet does not assist,
accomplishes virtue yet is not encumbered,
emerges from the Dao yet does not scheme,
converges in benevolence yet does not rely,
approaches righteousness yet does not accumulate,
responds to ritual yet does not avoid,
engages with affairs yet does not decline,
orders by law yet does not disorder,
depends on the people yet does not belittle,
follows things yet does not abandon.
Things are not worth acting upon, yet they cannot be left unacted upon.

One who is not enlightened by Heaven is not pure in virtue;
one who does not penetrate the Dao has no means of proceeding;
one who is not enlightened by the Dao—how lamentable!

---
*Annotations*:
- **The people**: Accommodating their nature and engaging them leads to order; opposing their nature and oppressing them leads to chaos. That the people and things are lowly and base arises from the failure to accommodate and engage. Thus, engaging the base brings honor; accommodating the lowly brings esteem—this is the inevitable correspondence.
- *Though the people dwell below, each possesses abilities; though things are light and base, all bear useful qualities. No material is to be discarded; no person is to be left unused—thus all may flourish.*
- **Affairs**: Affairs are concealed in that place, hence "hidden." Each has its own course, hence they cannot be left undone—only appropriately engaged.
- *Affairs may be hidden or manifest, natures skilled or unskilled; some are manifest here, hidden there; skilled here, unskilled there. One must only engage them, and all affairs will be settled.*
- **Law**: Law is the trace of wondrous affairs—how can one fail to articulate wondrous affairs because their trace is coarse?
- *Law refers to teachings. Using teachings to seek principle, principle is wondrous while law is coarse—like the fish-trap and rabbit-snare, one follows and articulates the traces.*
- **Righteousness**: Only by occupying it does one perceive its distance.
- *Though righteousness is distant from the Dao, if it accords with principle, one must still make judgments.*
- **Benevolence**: Intimacy suffers from partiality; only by expanding it does one achieve benevolence.
- *Intimacy, though partial and narrow, when universally and broadly extended, becomes great benevolence.*
- **Ritual**: Ritual’s measures risk being bound to singularity; thus, when embodied in each thing, they accumulate and become all-encompassing.
- *Accumulation means thickness. Measures refer to patterns. Ritual values reciprocity, yet human sentiment is shallow and thin. Thus, one outwardly displays refined conduct while inwardly fostering deep accumulation—this is true ritual.*
- **Virtue**: What is below in affairs, though centered, is not virtue.
- *Centered means compliant. Those who cultivate the Dao harmonize their light with the world, remaining humble and compliant toward things while maintaining lofty aspirations and pure conduct—though dyed, their virtue remains unstained.*
- *Centered: compliant. Compliant with their nature yet exalted.*
- **The Dao**: What is difficult in affairs, though singular, is not the Dao—how much less when not singular!
- *The wondrous root is singular qi, which pervades and generates the myriad things. How simple and easy—surely this is the Dao!*
- *Unchanged: as in "unchanging." The annotation below is the same.*
- **Heaven**: Insisting on non-action, though numinous, is not Heaven—how much less when not numinous!
- *Heaven’s numinous workings are unfathomable, manifesting and concealing without fixed pattern, flowing with opportunity without obstruction—this is its natural accord.*
- **Observes Heaven yet does not assist**: Merely following its self-so.
- *The sage observes the wondrous principle of nature, fully complying with the myriad things without assisting their inherent dispositions. The following explains the preceding text.*
- **Accomplishes virtue yet is not encumbered**: Naturally converges with the exalted.
- *Able to merge environment and wisdom, once exalted virtue is accomplished, one is naturally free from blemishes and burdens.*
- **Emerges from the Dao yet does not scheme**: Unscheming unity is what makes it easy.
- *Manifesting the wondrous singular Dao—how could one wait for schemes before speaking!*
- **Converges in benevolence yet does not rely**: Relying precludes expansiveness.
- *The Laozi says, "Acting without relying." Benevolent and compassionate love values appropriateness, hence there is no reliance.*
- **Approaches righteousness yet does not accumulate**: Following one’s nature and dwelling in the distant is not accumulation.
- *The sage’s thatched hut is not to be treasured; once the straw dogs are displayed, why accumulate and retain them!*
- **Responds to ritual yet does not avoid**: Naturally responds to ritual, not through avoidance or taboo.
- *The wondrous root is profoundly still; its traces respond to ritual—how could one be bound by avoidance or taboo!*
- *Yu Yue says: "Avoid" should be read as "oppose." "Avoid" and "oppose" share the phonetic element *wei*, hence the *Guangya*’s *Exegesis* says: "Avoid means to shun." Wei Zhao’s annotations to the *Zhouyu* and *Jinyu* both say: "Oppose means to shun." Thus, the two words are phonetically close and semantically connected. "Responds to ritual yet does not avoid" means "does not oppose."*

Guo’s commentary states: "Naturally responds to ritual, not through avoidance or taboo"—this is overly circuitous.

**Responds to affairs with principle, taking success or failure upon oneself; moves when movement is called for, without refusal or deference.**

In blending with the俗 while riding its waves, one engages with affairs as they arise, responding to the moment without grasping, without refusal or deference.

*Yingsheng* (for *应动*): *yìshēng* (rising tone).

**Guides the coarse with the wondrous, thus avoiding disorder.**

Following the nature of things, one governs them with the Dao, thus avoiding disorder.

**Relies on their self-soing, not lightly employing them.**

The people are the root of the state; when the root is firm, the state is at peace. Thus, one relies on and does not dare to employ them lightly.

**Thereby taking them on, not abandoning their root.**

Following the hearts of the black-haired people and the natures of the myriad things, though laws and teachings are applied, they are not made to depart from their original nature.

**Now, as for doing—how could one do for the sake of feet? One embodies this doing, thus it cannot be stopped.**

The endowments of things differ in their functions. Like the dung beetle rolling its ball or the spider weaving its web, these arise from nature, not from acquired learning. Thus, what is not inherent cannot be forcibly done, while what lies within one’s nature cannot but be done.

*Mò zú wéi* (nothing to be done) lies beyond one’s nature; *ér bùkě bù wéi* (cannot but be done) lies within it.

**Not understanding the natural leads to contrivance; contrivance renders virtue impure.**

Obscuring the principle of the natural results in the impurity of shallow and insubstantial virtue.

**Unable to empty oneself and await things, one loses harmony in every affair.**

Clinging to the empty and mysterious Dao-nature, one collides with things like a wall—truly, there is no path by which this may succeed.

**Ignorant of the principle of Heaven and man, confused about the meaning of ruler and minister, their actions stumble and falter—deeply lamentable.**

What is the Dao?
There is the Dao of Heaven, and the Dao of Man.

That which is revered through non-action (*wuwei*) is the Dao of Heaven; that which is burdened through action is the Dao of Man.

The ruler embodies the Dao of Heaven; the minister embodies the Dao of Man. The Dao of Heaven and the Dao of Man are vastly distant from one another—this must not go unexamined.

To be above and entrust all things to their own spontaneity is the Dao of Heaven. Non-interference and non-action, revered and exalted above, accord with the natural Dao of Heaven.

To be burdened by action is to fail to follow one’s inherent attainment. Those who hold office and act are entangled in worldly affairs—this is the Dao of human relations.

To be one with Heaven’s entrustment of things is to naturally preside over them. The lord, above and entrusting things, accords with the non-action of the Dao of Heaven.

Each fulfills their appointed role.

When the ruler’s position is one of non-action, delegating to the hundred officials, and the officials each attend to their duties while the ruler does not intervene, both achieve self-attainment through non-doing. Thus, the ruler’s path is one of ease, while the minister’s path is one of toil—the disparity between labor and leisure cannot be spoken of in the same breath.

The ruler’s position is exalted, entrusted to stewards; the minister’s path is humble, exhausting sincerity in service to the ruler. Thus, the ruler’s path is ease, the minister’s path is toil—they cannot be spoken of in the same breath.

If this is not examined, the positions of ruler and minister will fall into chaos.

The Dao of Heaven is for the ruler and non-action; the Dao of Man is for the minister and affairs. With distinction in rank and difference in labor and leisure, each maintaining their proper place, both ruler and minister achieve non-action. If one fails to discern this principle, labor and leisure will be misaligned, and ruler and minister will fall into disorder.

---

Though Heaven and Earth are vast, their transformation is uniform; though the myriad things are numerous, their governance is one; though the people are many, their lord is the ruler.

The ruler originates in virtue and is perfected by Heaven. Thus it is said: The ancient rulers of the world practiced non-action—nothing but the virtue of Heaven.

Their transformation is uniform through non-action and self-transformation.

Heaven and Earth give birth and nurture, covering and sustaining without end. Among all forms and substances, they are the most vast; yet their ceaseless transformation remains unchanging, their moment-to-moment renewal truly equal—this is what is meant by "nurturing them."

The myriad things, though numerous, are governed by their inherent attainment—this is what is meant by "poisoning them."

Though the common people are many, their lord is the ruler. Without self-interest, he presides over all.

The ruler takes virtue as his origin, and all things attain their proper state. What is attained is self-attainment, and thus, though attained, it is not owed gratitude—this is how Heaven is perfected.

Observing through the Dao, the rulers of the world are rectified; observing through the Dao, the duties of ruler and minister are clarified; observing through the Dao, the officials of the world are well-governed; observing through the Dao in all directions, the responses of the myriad things are complete.

Thus, that which pervades Heaven and Earth is virtue; that which flows through the myriad things is the Dao; that which governs the people above is affairs; that which enables skillful execution is technique.

Technique is encompassed by affairs, affairs by duty, duty by virtue, virtue by the Dao, and the Dao by Heaven.

Thus it is said: The ancients who nurtured the world had no desires, and the world was sufficient; they practiced non-action, and the myriad things were transformed; they were profound and still, and the hundred clans were settled.

It is recorded: "Mastering the One, all affairs are complete. Without intent, one gains, and ghosts and spirits submit."

**Annotation [1]:** "Non-action" means that the ruler acts naturally, not perversely.
**Subcommentary:** Observing the principle of emptiness and penetration, one examines the patterns of responding to things. The ruler who practices non-action and follows the natural course does not employ perverse words, thus aligning with the correct Dao.

**Jia Shifu says:** "Words" are names. Rectifying the ruler’s name, the world naturally obeys his commands. Thus it is said: Naming must be expressible, and it is simply a matter of aligning with the Dao.

**Exegetical Note:** *Fei xie ye* (非邪也) is read as *sì jiē fǎn* (似嗟反). Some versions read *zuò* (作) instead of *wéi* (為).

**Annotation [2]:** Each fulfilling its proper role, non-action belongs to the superior position, and action to the inferior.
**Subcommentary:** The ruler’s Dao is non-action, while the minister’s Dao involves affairs. The distinction between honor and baseness, labor and ease, is inherently different. For example, the head naturally resides above, and the feet below. Observing through the Dao, the divisions of duty are clear.

**Annotation [3]:** When officials each fulfill their capacities, there is good governance.
**Subcommentary:** Offices have ranks, and abilities vary in excellence. When each receives their proper office, things are impartially achieved. Thus, the officials of the world are well-governed.

**Annotation [4]:** Through non-action, the world responds with its own non-action.
**Subcommentary:** The great Dao generates things, whose natures and dispositions differ. Following their own principles, all are complete. Some run, some fly, each serving its function without deliberate intent. How could one impose a design? Thus, observing through principle, the responses of the myriad things are complete.

The Master said: "The Dao covers and sustains the myriad things—how vast and great it is! The noble person cannot but hollow out their heart. Non-action as action is called Heaven; non-action in speech is called virtue; loving people and benefiting things is called benevolence; making the unlike alike is called greatness; acting without eccentricity is called magnanimity; possessing myriad differences is called richness. Thus, holding to virtue is called discipline; virtue’s completion is called establishment; following the Dao is called fulfillment; not allowing things to thwart one’s will is called wholeness. The noble person who understands these ten is vast in the greatness of their intent, abundant in their passage through the myriad things. Such a one hides gold in the mountains, conceals pearls in the depths, does not prize goods or wealth, does not draw near to nobility or riches; does not delight in long life, does not grieve over early death; is not honored by success, is not shamed by poverty; does not claim the world’s benefits as private gain, does not regard ruling the world as personal eminence. Eminence is clarity. The myriad things are one storehouse; death and life share the same form."

**Annotation [1]:** Having intent burdens one’s naturalness, so it must be hollowed out and removed.
**Subcommentary:** The Master is Laozi. Zhuangzi studied under Lao Jun, hence he is called the Master. *Kū* (刳) means to remove or cleanse. The Dao of emptiness and penetration encompasses all without exception. The Two Modes depend on it for covering and sustaining; the myriad things obtain it for transformation and generation. What does not proceed from this? It is the root of things. Marveling at its vast greatness, he exhorts the rulers of the age: Should they not model themselves on the Dao’s non-action and wash away the burdens of having intent?

**Exegetical Note:** *Fūzǐ* (夫子): Sima [Biao] says it is Zhuangzi. Another version says it is Laozi.

These two Masters state that the Yuanjia edition treats them as separate chapters, and the Cui edition does likewise.

**Annotations:**
- *Fùzài* (覆載): *fāngfù* (芳富) rhyme.
- *Yángyáng* (洋洋): pronounced *yáng*, also *xiáng*.
- *Bù kū* (不刳): *kǒuwú* (口吴) rhyme, also *kǒuhóu* (口侯). The Cui edition writes *xuān* (轩), glossed as "a countenance of ease and joy."
- *Ér qù* (而去): *qǐlǚ* (起吕) rhyme.

**[2]**
**Annotation:** Not acting for the sake of acting, yet this acting arises of itself—this is the Dao of Heaven.
**Subcommentary:** Acting through non-action, moving in accord with one’s nature. The heavenly mechanism unfolds spontaneously, hence it is called "Heaven." This is acting without acting for the sake of acting.

**[3]**
**Annotation:** Not speaking for the sake of speaking, yet these words arise of themselves—this is true virtue.
**Subcommentary:** Silent and without discourse, yet responding without limit, like a mirror hung high in a hall: when things come, it reflects them. Speech and silence are not distinct, hence it is called "virtue." This is speaking without speaking for the sake of speaking.

**[4]**
**Annotation:** This is to follow the natural tendencies of one’s nature and destiny.
**Subcommentary:** Compassion flows like clouds, love spreads like rain. Without partiality in the heart, virtue and grace extend universally. Entrusting to one’s nature and destiny, this is called "benevolence."

**[5]**
**Annotation:** The myriad things and myriad forms each abide in their proper place. Not drawing others to be the same as oneself—this is how greatness is achieved.
**Subcommentary:** Carving and sculpting the multitude of forms, each with its distinct nature. Following their inherent allotment, all harmonize with the natural. Acting without cutting or dividing, this is called "greatness."

**[6]**
**Annotation:** Mysteriously identifying self and other, the myriad things naturally find accommodation—hence there is surplus.
**Subcommentary:** Concealing one’s brilliance and obscuring one’s traces, blending with the world and riding its waves. If one’s cultivated virtue does not differ from others, and one’s established conduct is no different from things, yet the heart has no bounds—like waves stretching a thousand *li*, forests and marshes teeming with life—this may be called "magnanimity."

**[7]**
**Annotation:** I do not differ from anything, hence I alone possess these ten thousand.
**Subcommentary:** Occupying the position of the nine-fifth, wielding the might of ten thousand chariots, accommodating the myriad things’ differences, following the multitudes’ diversities—yet all natures attain fulfillment. Thus one may abundantly possess all under Heaven.

**[8]**
**Annotation:** Virtue is the guiding principle of humanity.
**Subcommentary:** One who can uphold the virtue cultivated beforehand may be called the guiding thread of the multitude of things.

**[9]**
**Annotation:** That which is accomplished without virtue cannot be called establishment.
**Subcommentary:** Only when virtue is fully realized can one establish merit and aid the world.

**[10]**
**Annotation:** The Dao does not favor any particular thing.
**Subcommentary:** *Xún* (循) means to follow. Only by following the empty and penetrating can one’s virtue be complete.

**Exegetical Note:**
- *Xún* (循): pronounced *xún*, sometimes written *xiū* (修).

**[11]**
**Annotation:** Inner self-possession.
**Subcommentary:** *Cuò* (挫) means to bend. Indifferent to praise or blame, blending honor and disgrace, not allowing worldly things to bend one’s integrity—this is the perfection of virtue.

**Exegetical Note:**
- *Cuò* (挫): *zuòwò* (作卧) rhyme.

**[12]**
**Annotation:** A great heart, thus no affair is unaccommodated.
**Subcommentary:** *Tāo* (韬) means to encompass. If the ten matters of the noble and worthy unfold before one, one can embrace all affairs, for the heart’s nature is magnanimous.

**Exegetical Note:**
- *Tāo* (韬): *tǔdāo* (吐刀) rhyme. The *Guǎngyǎ* states: "to conceal."
◎ **Yu Yue’s Note:** Guo’s annotation fails to grasp the meaning of *shì* (事).

To set the heart is akin to establishing the heart, speaking of the greatness of its establishment. The *Zheng* commentary on the *Liji*’s "Jiao Te Sheng" chapter states: "事 (*shì*) means 立 (*lì*), to establish." The *Shiming* says: "事 (*shì*) is 倳 (*zì*); 倳 (*zì*) is 立 (*lì*), to stand." Both serve as evidence. If we follow Guo’s annotation, then the heart suffices to accommodate affairs, rather than affairs setting the heart. The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s "Lun Ren" chapter reads: "事心乎自然之涂 (*shì xīn hū zìrán zhī tú*)," where *shì xīn* are conjoined in the text, its meaning identical to this passage—sufficient proof of Guo’s annotation being in error.

**[13]**
**Annotation:** Virtue and grace overflow abundantly, allowing the myriad things to go their own way.
**Subcommentary:** *Shì* (逝) means to go. With a heart of magnanimous ease and virtue overflowing like a flood, all living beings naturally turn toward it.
**Exegetical Note:**
- *Pèi* (沛): *pǔbèi* (普贝) rhyme. The *Zilin* states: "to flow."
- *Shì* (逝) in the *Cui* edition is written *qǐ* (启), meaning "to open."
- *Pāngpèi* (滂沛): *pǔpáng* (普旁) rhyme.

**[14]**
**Annotation:** Does not prize rare and precious things.
**Subcommentary:** If one proceeds as before, this is non-action. Having no longing for glory, one does not value treasures. Thus, pearls born in water are not sought and so remain hidden in the depths; gold issuing from mountains is not pursued and so stays concealed in the peaks.

**[15]**
**Annotation:** Thus one can forget the self—how much more wealth and property!
**Subcommentary:** Though one may obtain pearls and jade, one does not covet them for personal gain; how then could one use goods and riches for profit!

**[16]**
**Annotation:** They come and go as mere lodging; the heart ever distances itself from them.
**Subcommentary:** Whether coming or going as a guest, one feels neither sorrow nor joy. Thus, one remains outwardly aloof from high office and inwardly distant from wealth and honor.
**Exegetical Note:**
- *Bù jìn* (不近): the *jìn* of *fùjìn* (附近), "to be near."

**[17]**
**Annotation:** What is called "suspended release."
**Subcommentary:** Even if one’s years are long, one does not rejoice; if life is cut short, one does not grieve.
**Exegetical Note:**
- *Bù lè* (不乐): pronounced *luò*.
- *Xuánjiě* (县解): *xuán* (上音玄), *jiě* (下音蟹).

**[18]**
**Annotation:** Forgets life and death in the breast—how much more the vicissitudes of success and failure!
**Subcommentary:** Wealth, honor, and prosperity are not taken as glory; poverty, lowliness, and obstruction are not taken as shame. If even life and death are not set in the mind, how could the feelings of glory and disgrace find a place!

**[19]**
**Annotation:** All are entrusted to the myriad things.
**Subcommentary:** Illuminating the cosmos, ruling all under Heaven, the treasures of the four seas are all at one’s command—yet one does not value wealth and property, entrusting them to the myriad states. How could one restrict them for personal use!

**[20]**
**Annotation:** Suddenly, one is unaware of glory residing in the self.
**Subcommentary:** Nurturing the black-haired people, ruling all under Heaven, one ascribes merit to things and forgets one’s own wealth and honor, thus not taking one’s greatness as glory.
**Exegetical Note:**
- *Bù yǐ wáng* (不以王): *wáng* pronounced *yù*; the same for *wáng dé* (王德) below.

**[21]**
**Annotation:** If not manifest, then silence alone.
**Subcommentary:** *Míng* (明) means to reveal. Though seated at Fenyang, having lost the world, if one must display wisdom, how can this be called concealing one’s light!

**[22]**
**Annotation:** Shedding like a cicada, nowhere to be found.
**Subcommentary:** Forgetting self and others, the myriad things may be as one’s storehouse; oblivious to change, life and death share the same form. If life and death bring no change to the self, how much less the vicissitudes of success, failure, life, and death!
**Exegetical Note:**
- *Tuìrán* (蜕然): *shìruì* (始锐) rhyme, also pronounced *yuè*.
**Collation Notes:**
(1) *Quēwù* cites the *Zhang Junfang* edition, where *cáng* (藏) is written as *shěn* (沈).
(2) The *Zhao Jianyi* edition writes *yǐ* (已) as *zhǐ* (止).

The Master said: "The Dao—how abysmal its dwelling, how limpid its clarity! Metals and stones cannot attain it, and thus have no means to resound. Therefore, metals and stones possess sound, yet without being struck, they do not ring. Who among the myriad things can determine this?

The person of royal virtue moves in purity and feels shame at becoming entangled in affairs. They establish the root and origin, and their knowledge flows into the numinous. Thus their virtue is vast. When their heart issues forth, things gather to it. Therefore, form does not arise without the Dao, and life does not become luminous without virtue. To preserve form and exhaust life, to establish virtue and illuminate the Dao—is this not the person of royal virtue?

How boundless! Suddenly emerging, suddenly stirring, and the myriad things follow—this is called the person of royal virtue. Gazing into the darkness, listening to the soundless: within the darkness, they alone perceive the dawn; within the soundless, they alone hear the harmony. Thus, profound beyond profundity, they are able to embody things; numinous beyond numinosity, they are able to embody essence. Therefore, in their encounter with the myriad things, they reach the utmost void and yet supply what is sought. They gallop through time, seizing the lodging of things—great and small, long and short, far and near."

---
**Annotation [1]**
**Subcommentary:** The ultimate principle is profoundly mysterious, like an abyssal sea. Limpid and pure, it illumines even the finest details. "Abysmal" expresses its dwelling in stillness and depth; "limpid" expresses its constancy in purity despite movement. Some editions write *jūn* (君, "lord") instead.

**Exegetical Note:**
- *Liáo* (漻): Li reads *liángyóu*; Xu reads *lìxiāo*; the *Guang Ya* reads *xiàqiǎo*, glossing it as "appearance of clarity."

**Annotation [2]**
**Commentary:** Sound emerges from silence.

**Subcommentary:** Resonance arises from silence, response from truth. Metals and stones inherently contain the five notes, yet without being struck, they remain silent. This is like the heart of the perfected person, which truly holds sagely virtue—if things do not stir it, no response is manifest. Earlier, the abyssal waters were invoked to clarify the ultimate Dao; here, metals and stones are used to reveal the sagely heart.

**Annotation [4]**
**Commentary:** Response and stimulus are without fixed direction.

**Subcommentary:** This is like a bright mirror or an empty valley: things arrive, and it responds, yet without intent. Since things vary endlessly in length and brevity, the response likewise has no fixed shape or measure.
◎ Jia Shifu says: Within the abysmal stillness and limpid clarity, the heavenly mechanism moves of itself. The mechanism’s movement has that which moves it, yet its movement is without constancy. Metals and stones are likewise without constancy, yet the music of *Shao*, *Xia*, *Hu*, and *Wu* arises from what moves them. That which moves them cannot be determined by things.

**Annotation [5]**
**Commentary:** They follow their purity and go forth—it is not that they delight in becoming entangled in affairs.

**Subcommentary:** *Sù* means "true"; *shì* means "to go." The person of royal virtue is neither arrogant nor self-important. They follow their true nature and proceed, embracing simplicity in lofty purity, thus feeling shame at becoming entangled in worldly affairs.

**Exegetical Note:**
- *Fēi hào* (非好): Read *hūbào*.

**Annotation [6]**
**Commentary:** The root is established, and knowledge does not run counter.

**Subcommentary:**
The "spirit" refers to its unfathomable function. It ever abides in principle, proceeding to respond to things. The unfathomable spirit, in its knowing, pervades all things—this wondrous function necessarily relies upon the root. To show that the root can give rise to function, and that function does not deviate from the root’s meaning.

**Exegetical Note:**
- *Ér zhī* (而知): Pronounced *zhì*. The annotation is the same.

**Annotation [7]**
**Commentary:** Following simplicity, one communicates with the spirit, and thereafter it becomes ever more vast.

**Subcommentary:**
To be pure and without contrivance, to follow one’s true nature and proceed—thus the spirit’s knowing pervades all things while ever establishing the root. Function does not deviate from substance; movement does not harm stillness. When virtue and conduct are thus, is this not the great central Dao?

**Annotation [8]**
**Commentary:** Things seek it, and only then does it emerge—it does not precede things in initiating.

**Subcommentary:**
To seek. The utmost sage, empty of self, responds to things and self as one. Were it not for things seeking the sage’s virtue, the sage’s mind would have no means to manifest. The emergence of the sage’s mind truly arises from things seeking it. This shows harmony without initiating, not preceding things.

**Annotation [9]**
**Subcommentary:**
"Form" refers to the seven-foot body; "life" to the hundred-year span; "virtue" to the power of clarity and wisdom; "Dao" to the realm that can be traversed. The Dao can give life to the myriad things, thus without the Dao there is no life. Virtue can illumine the root of principle, thus without virtue there is no clarity. As the *Laozi* says: "The Dao gives birth to them; virtue nurtures them."

**Annotation [10]**
**Subcommentary:**
"Preserve" means to follow; "exhaust" means to fully realize. To follow the beauty or ugliness of form and appearance, to fully realize the brevity or longevity of life, to establish great virtue in order to rectify the age, to employ the utmost Dao in order to pervade all things—one who can do this is none other than the royal virtue!

**Annotation [11]**
**Commentary:**
*Hū* and *bó* both describe the appearance of responding without intention. Movement arises without intention, thus the myriad things follow it—this is called "vast and level." Therefore, one can preserve form and exhaust life, establish virtue and illumine the Dao, thereby perfecting royal virtue.

**Subcommentary:**
"Vast and level" is the name for broad and even. *Hū* and *bó* describe the appearance of being without intention. Things move it, and it emerges in accord with the trigger, following and yielding to things—thus things follow it. Since it possesses all excellences, it is royal virtue.

**Annotation [12]**
**Subcommentary:**
The utmost Dao is profoundly mysterious; the sage’s mind is concentrated and still. It cannot be seen with the eyes, for it is without color; it cannot be heard with the ears, for it is without sound.

**Annotation [13]**
**Commentary:** If one sees and hears without entrusting them to stillness, then there is obscurity and disharmony.

**Subcommentary:**
Though it is dark and without color, it can shape and transform the myriad images. Though it is silent and without sound, it can harmonize the tones of the eight winds. This shows that function arises from substance, and its efficacy is thus.

**Annotation [14]**
**Commentary:** Only by exhausting its source can one then act upon things.

**Subcommentary:**
It is both being and non-being, both stillness and response. Having dispensed with it again and again, it is profound beyond profundity. Having thus exhausted principle and fully realized nature, one can then act upon the multitude of things.

**Annotation [15]**
**Commentary:** Only by reaching the utmost in compliance can one then fully realize its wondrousness.

**Subcommentary:**
"Spirit" is the name for the unfathomable. Response and stillness are non-dual; being and non-being are thoroughly dispensed with. Thus, it is neither fathomable nor unfathomable, nor is it neither unfathomable—this is the essence and wondrousness of spirit.

**Annotation [16]**
**Commentary:** If I am steadfast in this and wholly entrust it to that, then that which seeks will be spontaneously supplied.

**Subcommentary:**
Having dispensed with it again and again, it is called "utmost non-being." Yet in engaging with things, it is without fixed method, adapting to the trigger as fitting. The thousand differences and ten thousand kinds—whatever seeks is supplied, like a mirror hung high in the hall, reflecting whatever comes before it.

**Exegetical Note:**
- *Ér gōng* (而供): Pronounced *gōng*; the original also writes it as *gōng*.
- *Què* (确): Pronounced *kùxué*.
- *Sī* (斯): Pronounced *sì* or read as written.

**Annotation [17]**
**Commentary:** All are indulged and entrusted to it, meeting only at their utmost.

**Subcommentary:**
To gallop; to meet. If one embodies the utmost non-being, one can thus respond to what is sought in a fitting manner. Therefore, one can comply with the times and follow what is entrusted, responding to things in manifold ways, ultimately converging without being fixed to one. Thus, it may be great or small, now short, now long, even to the farthest reaches. Whatever comes is indulged, adapting to the affairs of the trigger, supplying all that is sought, administering medicine according to the illness—there is nothing that is not fitting.

The Yellow Emperor roamed north of the Red Waters, ascended the Kunlun peaks and gazed southward. Upon returning, he lost his dark pearl. He sent Knowledge to seek it, but it was not found. He sent Li Zhu to seek it, but it was not found. He sent Chi Gou to seek it, but it was not found. Then he sent Imageless, and Imageless found it. The Yellow Emperor said: "How strange! Could it be that only Imageless could obtain it?"

**Annotation [1]**
**Commentary:** This illustrates the means by which the true is obtained.

**Exegesis:** Red is the color of the southern direction, and the heart is the organ of the southern direction. Water’s nature is flowing and mobile, its position in the north. This is like a deluded mind mistaking a mirror—dark and without illumination—hence it speaks of “north of the Red Waters.” Kunlun peaks are the body. South is the direction of clarity and brightness; *wang* (望) means “to observe and perceive.” *Xuan* (玄) denotes what is distant and subtle; the pearl is a treasure of precious value. This illustrates that all beings in the world, without exception, are deluded in body and mind, galloping in attachment, without awareness or understanding—dark as the northern direction, moving like flowing water, losing the true and forfeiting the Dao, all arising from this cause. Now, if one wishes to return to the root and revert to the source, to seek the true and inquire after the Dao, one must gaze southward to demonstrate illumination and insight, and “return” to signify the restoration of the mandate. Thus, it first clarifies where the true is lost, then reveals the method of attaining the Dao. The method revealed is set forth in the text below.

**Explanatory Notes:**
*Red Waters*: Li [Yun] says: “The waters issue from beneath Mount Kunlun.”
*Return*: Pronounced *xuan*.
*Dark Pearl*: Sima [Biao] says: “The true of the Dao.”
◎ Qingfan’s note: The *Wen Xuan* commentary on Liu Xiaobiao’s *Guang Juejiao Lun* cites Sima [Biao] as saying: “The Red Waters are a figurative name; the dark pearl is a metaphor for the Dao.” This differs from the *Explanatory Notes*.

**Commentary [2]:** This says that the use of knowledge is insufficient to attain the true.

**Commentary [3]:** "Seek" means to inquire. Thus, one cannot attain it by severing thoughts and seeking with the heart.

**Explanatory Notes:**
*Shi zhi* (使知): Pronounced *zhi* (智). The pronunciation applies to the annotation and all instances below.
*Suo zhi* (索之): Pronounced *suo* (所), with the falling tone (白反). The same applies below.

**Commentary [4]:** It is not form, so one cannot grasp it with the eyes.

**Annotation [4]:** Cleverness and sharpness lead to contention, losing the true ever further.

**Commentary [4]:** "Contention" means disputation. One cannot seek it through verbal debate.

**Explanatory Notes:**
*Chi* (吃): Pronounced *kouxie* (口懈反).
*Gou* (诟): Pronounced *koudou* (口豆反).
Sima [Biao] says: "Contention means exerting force."
◎ Jia Shifu notes: The *Guangyun* states: *Chi* (吃) is the same as *qi* (□). *Qi* means "sound"; *gou* (诟) means "anger," which is also a kind of sound. The *Jiyun* says this refers to forceful disputation. The wise seek it with spirit, Li Zhu seeks it in form and shadow, and the contentious seek it in sound and reputation—thus, the more they seek, the further they stray. "Vague semblance" (*xiangwang*) is as if present, as if absent, so it is said: "One obtains it with the pupil." Seeking it in form fails; seeking it beyond form also fails. The *Explanatory Notes* cite Sima [Biao]’s annotation—"contention means exerting force"—as erroneous.

**Commentary [5]:** "Vague semblance" means "without heart-mind." By departing from sound and form, severing thoughts and deliberations, knowledge and Li Zhu turn back at their limits, while contention in disputation, exerting force, loses the true. Only "vague semblance," free of heart-mind, uniquely attains the Dark Pearl.

**Annotation [6]:** To attain the true, one does not employ the heart-mind; "vague semblance" is itself the true.

**Commentary [6]:** Li Lou loses his nature by relying on keen sight and forfeiting the Dao, while the Yellow Emperor awakens to the principle, sighing that "vague semblance" obtains the pearl. He exhorts all students: thus, one need not depart from form or abandon wisdom, but may dismiss cleverness and break the body.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The Zhao Jianyi edition writes *huan* (还) as *xuan* (旋).
(2) The character *shui* (水) follows the Hu Ke edition of the *Wen Xuan* annotation.

Yao’s teacher was Xu You, Xu You’s teacher was Nie Que, Nie Que’s teacher was Wang Ni, and Wang Ni’s teacher was Pi Yi.

**Annotation [1]:** The four men above were all recluses of Yao’s time, who loathed the filth of the world and embraced the Dao while holding fast to virtue. Pure and incorrupt, they kept apart from human society. Yao, knowing their worth, wished to yield the throne to them. Zhuangzi shows the transmission of lineage, thus listing their succession of master and disciple.

**Exegetical Notes:**
*Wang Ni*: Xu reads *wu xi* (五兮).
*Pi Yi*: Pronounced *pi*.

Yao asked Xu You, “Could Nie Que be fit to match Heaven? I would rely on Wang Ni to summon him.”

**Annotation [1]:** That is, to serve as the Son of Heaven.
**Annotation [2]:** To use his teacher as a means to summon and employ him.

**Commentary:** *Pei* means “to join.” *Jie* means “to rely upon.” Yao said, “Nie Que is a worthy man, possessing the virtue to join with Heaven’s position. Perhaps by relying on Wang Ni, I might from afar bend him to my will.” Yet uncertain of the matter, he asked Xu You.

**Exegetical Notes:**
*Yao zhi* (要之): Read *yao* (一遥反). The annotation is the same.

Xu You said, “How perilous it is—this bringing the world to the brink! Nie Que’s nature is such that his intelligence and wisdom are keen, his wit and agility swift; his nature surpasses others. Yet he would take what belongs to man and claim it as Heaven’s. He is precise in forbidding transgressions yet does not know whence transgressions arise. Could one such as he match Heaven?

He would ride upon men yet cast off Heaven, root himself in the body yet estrange its form, exalt knowledge yet blaze like wildfire, be driven by threads of affairs, be ensnared by things, turn his gaze in all directions and have things respond, adapt to every circumstance, transform with things yet never attain constancy. How could such a one suffice to match Heaven?

Nevertheless, he has kin, he has ancestors; he may serve as father to the multitude, yet cannot serve as the father of fathers. Governance is the harbinger of chaos, the calamity of facing north, the bane of facing south.”

**Annotation [1]:** *Ji* means “peril.”
**Commentary:** *Dai* means “imminent.” *Ji* means “peril.” To employ Nie Que and relinquish the throne of ten thousand chariots—signs of peril and ruin would not be far off.
**Exegetical Notes:**
*Ji*: Also written as *ji* (岌), pronounced *wu ji* (五急反) or *wu he* (五合反). Guo and Li say: “peril.”

**Annotation [2]:** One so surpassingly keen and swift would lead others to strain after him, repeatedly harming the people.
**Commentary:** *Rui* means “sagely.” *Gei* means “nimble.” *Min* means “swift.” The sage who governs the world lets his crown tassels hang before his eyes and fills his ears with silk floss, thereby blocking keen perception, desiring neither to hear nor see too much. Yet Nie Que inwardly harbors sagely wisdom, outwardly dazzles with keen intelligence, wields a swift and sharp tongue, and devises far-reaching plans. His virtue, conduct, nature, and understanding surpass others; once his traces become manifest, they will surely become a source of harm. The signs of peril and ruin are enumerated below.

**Annotation [Yishu]:** *Gei shu* reads as *shuo*.

**[3] [Annotation]:** Employing knowledge to seek the restoration of one’s natural state.

**[Commentary]:** Things have lost their true nature for a long time; now, by means of the arts of the heart and intellect, one compels them to return to their origin—thus, the natural essence is lost all the more.

**[4] [Annotation]:** Excess arises from keen intelligence, yet if one further employs knowledge to restrain it, the excess only grows worse. Thus it is said: there is no excess in eliminating knowledge, not in forcibly restraining it.

**[Commentary]:** The source from which excess arises is knowledge. Nie Que merely knows how to scrutinize and restrain the excesses of the common people, yet does not understand that the source of calamity lies in wisdom itself.

**Annotation [Yishu]:** *Zai qu* reads as *qǐ lǚ* in reverse. *Yu qiang* reads as *qí zhàng* in reverse.

**[5] [Annotation]:** If one were to grant him the world, he would thereby cause later generations to rely on knowledge and lose their true nature.

**[Commentary]:** If he were given the throne and allowed to govern the multitudes, he would surely deploy his heart and intellect, assaulting Heaven’s principles—thus, all things would lose themselves and never recover their natural essence.

**[6] [Annotation]:** To take the myriad things as one’s foundation is to unify the diverse transformations and harmonize the varied forms. Yet this course will lead later generations to take themselves as the measure for controlling things, causing the myriad things to fall into disorder.

**[Commentary]:** *Fang* means “about to.” The sage has no mind of his own and follows things as they are. Now Nie Que takes himself as the foundation, drawing things to himself and compelling the world’s diverse forms to submit to his transformation. The loss of things’ natures stems precisely from this; the calamities of later ages begin here.

**Annotation [Yishu]:** *Fang qie* is read as written. Whenever the phrase *fang qie* appears, it means “about to act.”

**[7] [Annotation]:** When the worthy occupy positions of precedence, knowledge and perception are revered in their wake, and the world races and dashes about like wildfire.

**[Commentary]:** Unable to forget knowledge and entrust things to their own course, yet exalting knowledge to govern the age, one will inevitably follow after traces, abandoning oneself to imitate others, galloping and chasing with the speed of fire.

**[8] [Annotation]:** This will initiate the beginnings of later generations’ toil and servitude.

**[Commentary]:** *Xu* means “beginning.” *Shi* means “servitude.” Unable to practice non-action, yet relying on knowledge to govern things, the labor and servitude of later ages begin here.

**[9] [Annotation]:** This will lead later generations to constrain and control things.

**[Commentary]:** *Gai* means “obstruction.” Unable to employ the Dao to connect with people, one instead relies on knowledge to obstruct things.

**Annotation [Yishu]:** *Wu gai*: Xu reads *hù gé* in reverse; *Guangya* reads *gōng cái* in reverse, glossing it as “to bind.” This aligns with Guo’s interpretation. Here, the *Guangya* pronunciation is adopted.
◎ Jia Shifu says: The *Yishu* cites *Guangya*, which glosses *gai* as “to bind.” I suspect *gai* should be *gāi*.
