The *Guangyun* defines *gāi* as “to encompass” or “to embrace.” The *Hanshu: Lüli zhi* states, “*Gāi* contains the myriad things”; the *Taixuanjing* says, “The myriad things are *gāi*-embraced.” *Xu shi* means its remnants suffice to *shi* (employ) the multitudes. *Wu gai* means its mechanisms suffice to encompass the myriad things.

**[10] [Annotation]:** This will lead later generations to point and command, moving things to respond to the ruler’s affairs.

**[Commentary]:** About to survey the four directions and pacify the myriad states, compelling the common people to respond to his transformative laws.

**Annotation [Yishu]:** *Ling ying* reads as *lì chéng* in reverse.

**[11] [Annotation]:** This will lead later generations to be unable to forget goodness, instead using benevolence to respond to what is fitting.

**[Commentary]:** Employing one’s own knowledge to respond to the fittingness of the myriad things, one is not without a mind—and thus not without peril.

**[12] [Annotation]:** This will lead later generations to chase after things and be unable to attain self-realization within.

**[Commentary]:** Imposing one’s own knowledge upon the multitudes, compelling the myriad things to follow transformation—once things lose themselves, the self also fails to attain realization.

**[13] [Annotation]:** All these are expedients suited to the times, yet today one receives their virtue, while tomorrow one bears their harm. Thus it is said: “There has never yet been constancy.”

**[Commentary]:** Governing things with knowledge results in policies issuing from many sources: one reaps their virtue in the present but suffers their harm later. Having departed from the purity of antiquity, there is no constancy.

**[14] [Annotation]:** Their affairs and methods can be traced and emulated.

**[Commentary]:** *Zu* means “gathering place.” Nie Que dwells in seclusion among mountains and marshes, elevating his aspirations, yet cannot blend with the world and is unfit to match Heaven. Among the mingled masses, his kind is rare—thus, his lofty and pure aspirations are indeed worthy of emulation.
◎ Jia Shifu says: *Zu* refers to the traces of comparison. *Zu* (ancestor) refers to the origin of living things. Following the traces of comparison to unite them, the myriad things are governed as one, and the ruler of things becomes the refuge of the multitudes. Tracing the origin of living things, the myriad things arise from nothingness, and the generator of things is the branching outflow. Without plumbing the origin of living things, yet busily comparing to seek unity, order and chaos arise from this, and the calamities of ruler and minister begin here.

**[15] [Annotation]:** “Father of the many fathers” is but a trace.

**[Commentary]:** *Fu* means “ruler.” Nie Que’s lofty non-action does not level him with the common world. Though his Dao may be transmitted, he is fit only to be the father of the many, not the father of fathers. The “father of fathers” is Yao. Yao sits enthroned above the myriad things, yet his heart roams to Mount Guye, where he visits the Four Masters in the land of Fenyang. Thus, from quiescence he moves, from movement he returns to quiescence; non-action becomes action, action becomes non-action—being and non-being occur simultaneously, movement and quiescence are one. Therefore, he may be the ruler among rulers, the father among fathers.

To exhaust the principles and fulfill one’s nature, delving into the ever more profound—this is how one becomes the father of the many fathers, and thus it is fitting.

Thus, Guo’s commentary states: “The father of the many fathers is but a trace.”

**[16] [Annotation]:** This speaks not only of governing lords but also of leading chaos.

**[Commentary]:** *Shuai* means “lord.” If one employs wisdom to govern things, though order may prevail at the time, disorder will surely follow. Both paths take wisdom as their lord.

**[16] [Textual Notes]:** *Zhi-luan* (治乱): *zhi* as in “govern,” *luan* as in “chaos.” *Zhi shuai* (之率): *shuai* as in *se-lei* (色类); also read *se-lü* (色律).

**[17] [Annotation]:** Jie and Zhou did not kill worthy ministers by their own power but relied on the traces of sagely wisdom to bring them to ruin.

**[Commentary]:** Jie and Zhou relied on sagely wisdom to kill worthy ministers, thus sagely wisdom is the calamity of those who face north.

**[18] [Annotation]:** Tian Huan did not kill his lord by his own power but drew upon benevolence and righteousness to harm him.

**[Commentary]:** Tian Huan drew upon benevolence and righteousness to kill his lord, thus benevolence and righteousness are the thieves of those who face south. The annotation states: “Tian Huan did not kill his lord by his own power but drew upon benevolence and righteousness to harm him.”

**[Textual Notes]:** *Sha jun* (杀君): read *shi* (试); alternate character *shi* (弒), same pronunciation.

**[Collation]:** The preceding character follows the Song edition.

Yao gazed upon Hua. The border guard of Hua said: “Ah! A sage! I beg to offer a blessing to the sage.”

**[1] [Commentary]:** *Hua* is a place name, today’s Huazhou. A *feng ren* is one who guards the borders of Hua. *Xi* is an exclamation. Seeing Yao’s sagely virtue illuminating the world, the border guard asked to bless him with longevity, wealth, and many sons.

**[Textual Notes]:** *Hua* (华): read *hu-hua* (胡化) or *hu-hua* (胡花). Sima: “A place name.” *Feng ren* (封人): Sima: “One who guards the borders.” *Yue xi* (曰嘻): read *xi* (熙). *Qing zhu* (请祝): read *zhi-you* (之又) or *zhou-liu* (州六).

“May the sage live long.” Yao said: “I decline.”
“May the sage be wealthy.” Yao said: “I decline.”
“May the sage have many sons.” Yao said: “I decline.”

**[1] [Commentary]:** Wealth, longevity, and many sons are indeed burdensome, yet one who embodies the Way does not reject non-action. Thus, through these two figures, the three afflictions are made clear. The meaning of his refusal is explained below.

The border guard said: “Longevity, wealth, and many sons—these are what all people desire. Why do you alone not desire them?”

**[1] [Commentary]:** The three things mentioned earlier are the greatest desires of people. Why do you alone refuse them?

**[Textual Notes]:** *Nü du* (女独): read *ru* (汝); same below.

Yao said: “Many sons bring many fears; wealth brings many affairs; long life brings many humiliations. These three are not what nurture virtue, and so I decline.”

**[1] [Commentary]:** When descendants flourish, anxieties multiply; when wealth abounds, affairs grow burdensome; when lifespan extends, disgrace accumulates. These three do not nourish the virtue of non-action but only add to the encumbrances of striving—hence his refusal of all.

The border guard said: “At first, I took you for a sage—now I see you are but a gentleman. Heaven generates the myriad people and must assign them duties. If you have many sons and assign them duties, what fear remains? If you are wealthy and distribute it among others, what affairs remain? The sage dwells like the quail, eats like the fledgling, moves like the bird without leaving a trace. When the world follows the Way, all things flourish with him; when the world loses the Way, he cultivates virtue in seclusion. After a thousand years, weary of the world, he departs to become an immortal above, riding the white clouds to the realm of the Emperor. With the three afflictions kept at bay and his person ever free from harm—what humiliation remains?”

**Commentary:**
At first, I declared you possessed unparalleled illumination and thus embodied the sagely one who has realized the Dao—yet now, having abandoned all attachment to existence and non-existence, you are but a worthy gentleman.

**Annotation:** All things attain their proper place, and the will is settled.

**Commentary:** Heaven and Earth, in their transformative workings, endow the myriad beings with distinct capacities; measuring their talents to assign offices—what cause for fear remains?

**Annotation:** Entrusting it to the world, thus no affairs remain.

**Commentary:** When the hundred clans abound in prosperity and the four seas teem with abundance, entrusting it to the multitude of beings without claiming it as private—such is the absence of affairs through non-action.

**Annotation:** Without intention, yet naturally attaining tranquility.

**Exegetical Note:** *Chun* (鹑) is pronounced as *chún*. *Ju* (居): "quail-dwelling," denoting no fixed abode. Alternately: dwelling like the quail, akin to living in the wild.

**Annotation:** Depending on things to be sufficient.

**Commentary:** The quail, a wild bird, dwells without fixed abode. The fledgling, a young bird, must depend on its mother to be fed. The sage’s resting and dwelling are frugal, like the quail; his provisions are barely adequate, like the fledgling. Having no inclination toward extravagance, how could he harbor desire for rich flavors?

**Exegetical Note:** *Kòu* (鷇) is pronounced as *kòu*. The *Erya* states: "A hatchling that is fed is called *kòu*." *Kòu shí* (鷇食) means depending on things to be sufficient. ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The character *shēng* (生) was formerly miswritten as *zhǔ* (主); now corrected.

**Annotation:** Following one’s nature in movement, leaving no extraordinary traces.

**Commentary:** *Zhāng* (彰) means patterned traces. The sage, having extinguished the heart-mind and obliterated knowledge, merges with things in obscurity—like a bird in flight, leaving no visible tracks.

**Annotation:** Recklessly and wantonly acting, yet naturally treading the great path.

**Commentary:** When the age is governed by clarity and peace, he governs the multitudes; when things come to move him, he responds with timely flourishing. Guo’s annotation of "recklessly and wantonly acting" seems contrary to the text’s intent.

**Annotation:** Even the deeds of Tang and Wu, if they accord with Heaven and respond to the people, are not without leisure. Thus, "non-action yet nothing left undone" is not the absence of leisure.

**Commentary:** When the times are turbulent, he conceals his brilliance and blends with the vulgar, cultivating virtue and withdrawing his traces to preserve the Dao of life, delighting in reclusion and dwelling in leisure, carefree and withdrawn from the world. This is what is meant by "concealment and emergence at will, use and disuse following the times."

**Exegetical Note:** *Jiù xián* (就闲) is pronounced as *jiù xián*. The annotation is the same.

**Annotation:** The perfected person attains the utmost longevity, mastering the transformations of thoroughgoing penetration. In life, they follow Heaven’s course; in death, they merge with the transformations of things. Thus it is said: "Weary of the world, they ascend as immortals."

**Commentary:** The sage comprehends the non-duality of life and death, the unity of change and transformation. Therefore, they fulfill the span of their allotted years, whether long or short, and weary of the clamor of the vulgar, dissolve and ascend. Why must there be the ascent of the Yellow Emperor at Mount Dinghu alone to be called an immortal? Why must the longevity of Anqi alone be deemed a thousand years?

**Phonetic Note:** *Shàng xiān* (上仙) is pronounced *xiān*.

**Annotation:** When qi disperses, there is nowhere it does not go.

**Commentary:** The essence-spirit ascends, merging obscurely with the Great Unity. Riding the clouds and commanding qi, it arrives at the realm of Heaven and Earth.

**Commentary:** The "three afflictions" refer to wealth, longevity, and many sons. One who harnesses the Creator and comes and goes, who rides transformation and roams freely—these three afflictions are fundamentally empty and null, and this seven-foot frame arises from non-being. What weight do calamity and disgrace carry?

**Textual Note:** The character *qióng* (穷) is emended to *tōng* (通) following Wang Shumin’s suggestion.

The border guard departed. Yao followed him and said, "May I ask—"

**Commentary:** After the border guard had finished speaking, he departed. Yao, having awakened to his error, thus sought to question him.

The border guard said, "Withdraw now!"

**Commentary:** Once his doubts were resolved, Yao should swiftly withdraw.

**Textual Note:** The lacuna is here supplied as *jǐ* (己) following the Jiangnan ancient manuscript.

When Yao ruled the world, Bo Cheng Zi Gao was enfeoffed as a lord. When Yao abdicated to Shun, and Shun to Yu, Bo Cheng Zi Gao resigned his lordship and took up plowing.

Yu went to see him and found him plowing in the fields. Yu hastened to the lower position, stood, and asked, "In the past, when Yao ruled the world, you, sir, were enfeoffed as a lord. When Yao abdicated to Shun, and Shun to me, you, sir, resigned your lordship and took up plowing. May I ask the reason?"

**Commentary:** Bo Cheng Zi Gao—it is not known from whence he came; he was likely a man of the Dao.

**Phonetic Note:** *Bó Chéng Zǐ Gāo* (伯成子高): The *Tongbian Jing* states, "Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, my body has undergone one thousand two hundred transformations. In later ages, those who attained the Dao included Bo Cheng Zi Gao."

**Commentary:** In the age of Yao and Shun, he faced south and was called "the solitary one." Yet in the Xia dynasty, he retired to plow in the wilds. His appearances and withdrawals were suddenly different—what meaning did this hold?

Bo Cheng Zi Gao said, "In the past, when Yao ruled the world, he did not reward, yet the people were encouraged; he did not punish, yet the people stood in awe. Now you reward and punish, yet the people grow ever less humane. Virtue has declined from this point, punishments have been established from this point, and the disorders of later ages will begin from this point. Why do you tarry? Do not interfere with my work!"

He plowed with single-minded devotion, paying no heed.

**Commentary [1]:** Rewards and punishments exist to make encouragement and awe manifest. Yet Yao governed through non-action, and all things followed his transformation. Thus, the people did not wait for his commendations to exert themselves in goodness, nor did they require punishments to fear evil and refrain from it. This reveals Yao’s sagely illumination—such was his virtue.

**Commentary [2]:** Though rewards and punishments were vigorously enforced, the people still lacked benevolence. Once the highest virtue had declined, penal codes proliferated. Thus, we know the disorders of later ages began from this point.

**Annotation [3]:** During the time of Yu, three sages succeeded one another, their governance perfected and virtue complete. Yet as their achievements and excellence gradually faded, historical records had little to record, and even Confucius could not find leisure to discuss them. Thus, though they possessed the world, they did not engage with it—this was having yet not having. Examining their eras, Yu was the most outstanding; assessing their persons, though three sages, they were but one Yao. As no sage appeared in that time, the world’s heart suddenly turned to Qi. The most impartial and fitting ruler entrusted the world to the people, for taking and giving were not his own. Thus, he neither sought what was lost nor declined what was gained, departing in an instant and arriving without premeditation. For this, though he was slandered by men of integrity and his name ranked among the Three Kings, it is hardly surprising.

Zhuangzi used this to expose Yao’s flaws—flaws that began with Yao and reached their fullness with Yu. How much worse for later ages without sages! By entrusting distant traces to Bo Cheng, he abandoned governance entirely, seeking to abolish sageliness and return to unity, to discard knowledge and attain perfect tranquility. Yet in truth, this was never heard of.

Zhuangzi’s words cannot be questioned from a single path. Sometimes he shaves the traces of the Yellow Emperor and cuts the shins of Yao and Shun—how could he merely exalt Yao and disparage Yu? Thus, we must set aside his allusions and record only his intent to abolish sageliness and discard knowledge.

**Commentary:** *Hé* means "why not"; *luò* means "abandon." *Yìyì* describes the appearance of plowing. Bo Cheng addressed Yu as "Master." "Master, why do you not depart? Do not disrupt my farming!" Thereupon, he applied himself to plowing without a backward glance.

The three sages succeeded one another, and none was superior or inferior. Yet as the world shifted from simplicity to decadence, their traces differed. Guo’s annotation, "flaws began with Yao and reached their fullness with Yu," aims to show that having sages is not as good as having none, and action is inferior to non-action. Thus, he extols distant traces to illustrate the abolition of sageliness and the discarding of knowledge.

**Exegetical Notes:**
*Hé* is also written as *hé*, pronounced *húlà*. *Wú luò*: *luò* means "abandon." *Yìyì*: Xu pronounces it *yúzhí*, Li as "the appearance of plowing," another as "the bearing of a plowman," also *zhì* or *yúshí*. The *Zilin* defines it as "vigorous and robust." *Zhì chéng*: pronounced *zhílì*. *Néng xián*: *xián* as in "privy." *Bù yǔ*: pronounced *yù*. *Tóng*: pronounced *dòng*, also *tóng*.

**Variant [1]:** The Zhao Jianyi edition reads *biàn* as *shǐ*.

In the Great Beginning, there was nonbeing, without even the name of nonbeing. Where the One arose, there was the One yet no form. When things obtained this to live, it was called virtue. Before form, there were distinctions, yet they were continuous and without gaps—this was called fate. Movement was retained to generate things; when things took form and their principles of life were established, this was called shape. When shapes preserved spirit, each having its own pattern, this was called nature. Cultivating nature to return to virtue, when virtue reached its fullness, it merged with the beginning. This merging was emptiness, and emptiness was vastness. Mouths joined in harmony; when harmony was achieved, it merged with Heaven and Earth. This merging was profound and subtle, appearing foolish and benighted—this was called mysterious virtue, unity with the Great Compliance.

**Annotation [1]:** There was nonbeing, so nothing could be named.

**Commentary:** *Tài* means "great"; *chū* means "beginning." When primal *qi* first sprouted, it was called the Great Beginning, for its *qi* was vast and great, capable of being the origin of all things. Thus, it was named the Great Beginning. At the time of the Great Beginning, there was only this nonbeing, not yet being. Since being had not yet arisen, where could names reside? Hence, there was nonbeing without a name.

**Exegetical Notes:** The *Yi* says: "It is the beginning of *qi*."

**Annotation [2]:** The One is the beginning of being, the most wondrous. Being most wondrous, it had not yet the form of things and their principles. Where the One arises, it arises from the utmost One, not from nothingness. Yet why does Zhuangzi repeatedly speak of nothingness at the beginning? At the beginning, what had not been born obtained birth. Obtaining birth is difficult, yet it still did not rely on nothingness above nor await knowledge below. Suddenly, it spontaneously attained this life—why then seek life in what is already born, losing its self-generated nature?

**Commentary:** The One is the Dao, having the name of the One but not the appearance of the myriad things.

**Annotation [3]:** Nonbeing cannot generate things. Saying "things obtained this to live" clarifies that things generate themselves. Allowing them to generate themselves—this can be called virtue.

**Commentary:** Virtue means "obtaining," referring to obtaining this. When things obtained this to live, they did not rely on things externally nor derive from the self internally. Neither nonbeing nor being, neither self nor other, not knowing how they lived—this was called virtue.

**Commentary [4]:** Though they had not yet physical form, they received *qi* and had inherent distinctions. Yet these distinctions of length and brevity were continuous, without gaps—this was called fate.

**Exegetical Notes:** *Yǒu fèn*: pronounced *fúwèn*. *Wú xián*: read as written.

◎ My late uncle remarked: "The alternation of yin and yang is called the Dao. That which continues it is goodness; that which completes it is nature." When things obtain their life, this is what is meant by "that which continues it is goodness"—yet the name "virtue" does not yet apply. Only when it congeals into fate, with nature contained therein, is this what is meant by "that which completes it is nature." Once fate is established, each takes form in its likeness; by embodying form, one returns to nature, each possessing its own norm—this is the work of fulfilling nature. Zhuangzi, in this regard, also grasped its elusive essence.

**Commentary [5]:** *Liú* means "stillness." Yang moves, yin is still; in their intermingling ascent and descent, they distribute across the Three Powers, transforming and generating the myriad things. When things attain completion, with the principles of life fully present, this is called "form."

**Exegetical Notes:** *Liú dòng*: *Liú* may also be written as *liú*.

**Commentary [6]:** Virtue, form, nature, and fate—these names arise from transformation, yet in their self-so essence, they are one.

**Commentary [7]:** *Tǐ* means "substance"; *bǎo* means "to preserve." Having received bodily substance and preserved spirit, form may be coarse or refined, while spirit may be foolish or wise. Yet each should follow its proper norm, all differing from one another. The original allotment is fixed, never to be altered—this is called "nature."

**Annotation [7]:** Always self-attained without contrivance.

**Commentary [8]:** Following this endowed nature, one cultivates and restores the original virtue of life’s beginning. Thus, when one reaches the state of virtue, one is identical with the Great Beginning.

**Annotation [8]:** Though not identical with the beginning, if one acts with purpose midway, then what one harbors is indeed a "thing." With a "thing" present, the power of nurturing virtue diminishes.

**Commentary [9]:** Identical with the Great Beginning, the mind becomes empty and vast. With the mind thus emptied, it can embrace all expansiveness.

**Annotation [9]:** Speaking without intention yet naturally uttering words—this accords with the cries of birds.

**Commentary [10]:** *Huì* means "a bird’s beak." With the mind emptied and traces obscured, one’s words merge with the cries of birds. Since bird cries are without intention toward right or wrong, how could the sage’s words bear attachment to love or hate?

**Exegetical Notes:** *Huì*: pronounced *dīngdòu*, or alternatively *chōngruì*, *xǐ*, or *huì*.

**Annotation [10]:** Heaven and Earth, too, move without intention.

**Commentary [11]:** Just as words accord with bird cries, virtue accords with Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth have no intention in their covering and supporting, just as the sage has no intention in speech—thus they merge with Heaven and Earth.

**Annotation [11]:** This merging arises from "sitting in forgetfulness," not from deliberate observation to achieve it.

**Commentary [12]:** *Mín* means "to merge." The sage inwardly aligns with the utmost principle and outwardly accords with all beings. Whether in traces or essence, nothing is left unmerged—hence the term *mínmín*. Such a one blends with the world, riding its waves, harmonizing with the dust of the myriad things, appearing foolish and confused, like one lost in darkness. Alternate interpretation: merging with bird cries and with Heaven and Earth—this, too, is *mínmín*.

**Exegetical Notes:** *Mínmín*: pronounced *wǔjīn*.

**Annotation [12]:** Virtue is profound, and that which it accords with is vast.

**Commentary [13]:** Summarizing the foregoing, one extols its excellence. Such a person may be called one of profound virtue, identical with the Great Beginning and in great accord with the world.

Confucius asked Lao Dan: "There is one who practices the Dao as if following a model—what is permissible is permissible, what is not is not; what is so is so, what is not so is not. A debater has said, *'Separating hardness and whiteness is like suspending the universe.'* Can such a one be called a sage?"

Lao Dan replied: "This is but a petty clerk’s skill—one who binds and wearies the form, startling the heart. A dog trained to hold fast grows anxious; the nimbleness of gibbons and apes comes from the mountain forests. Qiu, I tell you what you cannot hear and speak of what you cannot utter. All those with heads and feet yet lacking hearts and ears are many; those with form and those without form or shape, all existing, are utterly nonexistent. Their movement is their stillness; their death is their life; their decay is their rise. Yet this is still not their *thereby*. There is governance in man—one who forgets things, forgets Heaven, is called one who forgets the self. The one who forgets the self is said to enter into Heaven."

The words of "this" and "that" vie to supplant one another, employing these arts to bind the body, thus wearying the form and startling the heart with apprehension. This answers the earlier question. *Ji* (技, "skill")—some texts write it as *zhi* (枝, "branch")—speak of "this" and "that" shifting and seizing, branching and diverging like leaves.

The above all lose their constant nature. "Chengsi" (成思) should be a corruption of "laitian" (来田); "zishanlinlai" (自山林来) ought to be a corruption of "laiji" (来藉). Gibbons and apes, swift monkeys, are hounds trained to seize foxes—often collared and leashed for the hunt, thus bound and not at ease, they grow anxious. Gibbons and apes dwell in mountain forests, roaming freely and unrestrained, their nimbleness in leaping and grasping their natural state; yet when captured and brought forth, they lose their true nature. *Li* (狸)—some texts write it as □—is the bamboo rat.

All those with beginnings and ends yet lacking hearts and ears are many—this speaks of their self-transformation. "Ru" (若) and "er" (而) both mean "you." "Beginnings and ends" refer to the cycle of existence. Reason transcends words and debate, hence they cannot hear speech. Nor can they be known by the heart’s deliberation or the ear’s hearing, so they are said to lack hearts and ears. All sentient beings without true nature are called "beginnings and ends," hence they are many. How can you, with your many displays of the gibbon’s skill or lofty, far-fetched arguments, compel others to imitate you? Is this not a mistake?

Those with form are ever-changing and cannot coexist with the formless and shapeless. Thus, one who governs the Dao does not cling to the old but follows the daily renewal of transformation. "Those with form" are the body; "the formless" is the heart. You say both heart and body exist, but through the lens of principle, I see them as entirely empty.

This speaks of movement and stillness, death and life, flourishing and decay, rise and fall—none of these are constant. All arise naturally, not by any deliberate use, so when released, they find their own harmony. Times have movement and stillness; beings have death and life; affairs have rise and fall—these six are the principles of nature, yet we know not how they come to be. How could they be tied to human thought or imitation? Simply follow and yield to the self-so of things.

Governance lies in man—not in the ruler’s self-will. Each person moves by their inherent nature, the heavenly mechanism unfolding of itself, not by the ruler’s decree.

Heaven and things are all forgotten—what more is there to possess? Not only are worldly affairs empty, but even the principles of Heaven are non-existent. Only when both affairs and principles are forgotten can one reach the ultimate of neither existence nor non-existence.

What man cannot forget is the self; yet if even the self is forgotten, what else remains to be known? This is to be unknowing and unperceiving, merging with the natural.

To enter is to unite. Of all things in the world, the hardest to forget is the self; yet if even the self can be forgotten, what in the world is worth preserving? Thus, one who forgets both self and things merges with the Dao of nature.

All beings share heads and feet; those without hearts cannot deliberate, like birds and beasts; those without ears cannot hear, like insects and fish. Their movement and stillness, their death and life, their decay and rise—all are the transformative mechanisms of Heaven and Earth. The transformative mechanism in Heaven and Earth is not exhausted by things; the formless and shapeless, shifting and surging within Heaven and Earth, are all part of this mechanism. Yet there is governance in man—how meddlesome man is! To force things to conform to governance is not as good as forgetting the self and letting things follow their own course. Only one who forgets the self can unite with Heaven in virtue.

In the *Yin* commentary to the *Bai Xin* chapter of the *Guanzi*: Heaven and Earth are those who forget form. Those who can emulate Heaven and Earth—are they not precisely those who forget the self? This aligns with the same principle.

**Textual Notes:**
(1) The *Zhao Jianyi* edition retains 狸 (*li*); (2) the missing character is emended to 狸 based on the *Shiwen* edition; (3) the *Shide Tang* edition reads 狸, while this follows the original *Shiwen* text; (4) the character 所 is deleted following the *Zhao* edition.

Jiang Lümen visited Ji Che and said: "The Lord of Lu said to me, 'I request to receive your instruction.' Unable to decline his command, I have already told him, but I do not know whether it was appropriate. Allow me to present it again.

I said to the Lord of Lu: 'You must practice reverence and frugality, elevate those of public loyalty, and eliminate partiality and self-interest—then which of the people would dare not be harmonious!'""

**Commentary:**
*Jiang* and *Ji* are surnames; *Lümen* and *Che* are given names. These two worthies are of unknown origin, and no reliable sources clarify their identities. The Lord of Lu refers to the Marquis of Lu, a descendant of Bo Qin, though it is uncertain which duke this was. The Lord of Lu met with Lümen and requested instruction on governing the state. Though Lümen initially declined, he could not refuse the lord’s command and thus explained the Way of governance. As he spoke hastily, he feared his words might not be perfectly apt, so he now dares to present what he said, offering it to the wise. If it is inappropriate, he humbly seeks correction.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Jiang* is also written as 蒋. *Lü* is pronounced with the initial *lì* and the final *yú*. *Miǎn* is also written as [variant], pronounced *miǎn*, or *wǎn*; Guo [Pu] pronounces it *wèn*. Jiang Lümiǎn is the name of a person. One account says: the surname is Jianglü, the given name is [variant]. Another says: the surname is Jiang, the given name is Lǚmiǎn. *Jì Chè* is also the name of a person, likely of the Jì clan. *The Lord of Lu*: some say this was Duke Ding. *Zhī zhòng* is pronounced with the initial *dīng* and the final *zhòng*.

**Commentary:**
*Ē* means "partiality." *Shú* means "who." *Jí* means "harmony." Now, the Way of governance must first require the ruler to personally embody reverence and frugality, simplicity and purity. Only then may he promote those of impartial loyalty and upright integrity, selecting forthright and selfless scholars to recommend the good and reject the flawed, jointly governing the people. Thus, the borders will be secure, the realm will be tranquil, the people will sing and strike the earth in joy—who would dare not be harmonious!

The *Shiwen* notes: *bù jí* is pronounced *jí*. The *Erya* says: "harmony." Another pronunciation is with the initial *cè* and the final *lì*. Guo [Pu] reads it as *sī yú*.

Jì Chè laughed heartily and said: "If one follows your master’s words, then in regard to the virtue of emperors and kings, it would be like the mantis raising its arms in anger to block the wheels of a chariot—it would surely be unequal to the task. Moreover, if one acts thus, one’s own position will be perilous, and the platforms from which one observes will be many. Things will gather, and those who tread in one’s footsteps will be numerous."

The first note states: One must necessarily practice reverence and frugality—not frugality born of forgetting frugality; one must necessarily elevate public-spirited loyalty—not loyalty born of forgetting loyalty. Thus, though free from partiality and self-interest, this is still insufficient to bear the burden of countering deceit and artifice.

The commentary explains: *Jújú* describes bending forward in laughter. That one must necessarily be reverent and frugal, must necessarily elevate public-spirited loyalty—these are all contrived sentiments, not the forgetfulness of the bland. Therefore, to take such words as the virtue of one who faces south [as a ruler]—how is this different from the mantis raising its arms in anger to oppose the chariot’s tracks? Using the small to imitate the great, it cannot bear the task.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Jújú* is pronounced *qíyù*. Another gloss says: the appearance of hearty laughter. *Tángláng* is pronounced *tángláng*. *Chēyì* is pronounced *zhé*. ◎ Qing Fan’s case: The *Shiwen*’s gloss of *yì* as *zhé* is correct. *Zhé* means chariot tracks. The ancient character *zhé* was interchangeable with *yì*. The *Stratagems of the Warring States* reads: "wherever the chariot tracks reach," with the note: *yì* is pronounced *zhé*. (The *Shuowen* has no *zhé* seal; *zhé* is simply *chè*.) The *Records of the Grand Historian*, in the "Annals of Emperor Wen," reads: "tying chariot tracks upon the road," with the note also pronouncing it *zhé*. The *Book of Han*, in the "Annals of Emperor Wen," writes *jiézhé*, which serves as evidence. *Bùshèng* is pronounced *shēng*. The note concurs.

The second note states: All this is to place oneself in a lofty and conspicuous position, as if on a terrace from which one may be observed.

The commentary explains: Reverence, frugality, public-spirited loyalty—these are not true forgetfulness of the bland, but rather a self-display that dazzles the multitude. Since one’s position is already perilously high, collapse and ruin are inevitable, just as a towering terrace, though travelers may gaze upon it, will soon crumble.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Zìwéijù* is pronounced *qíjù*. The original text also writes *chǔ*. ◎ Lu Wenchang says: The present text writes *chǔ*. *Guāntái* is pronounced *gǔluàn*. The note concurs.

The third note states: This will cause things to exceed their inherent allotment of nature, straining and overreaching to attach themselves.

The commentary explains: When a terrace stands high and distant, people vie to gaze upon it, and those who stand and walk multiply; things compete to gather there. ◎ Jia Shifu says: "Many terraces" means that the people, observing the model and receiving the law, find the affairs onerous. Guo Xiang’s punctuation, taking "perilous" with "its terraces," is likely in error.

The fourth note states: Raising one’s feet to tread in others’ tracks is to be unsettled in one’s own proper step.

The commentary explains: When one’s display stirs things, they become unsettled in their allotted nature, and thus those who lift their feet to tread in others’ tracks, stretching on tiptoe, are many.

Jiang Lümen, startled, said: "I am utterly at a loss regarding your master’s words. Nevertheless, I wish to hear the drift of your words."

The annotations state:
*觑觑* (qūqū) describes a startled appearance.
*茫* (máng) means "to see nothing." Upon suddenly hearing lofty discourse, one is startled and alarmed; pondering it, one fails to comprehend, hence the bewilderment.

*Fanqie* glosses:
*《觑觑》* as *xǔnì* (許逆) or *shēngzé* (生責) in alternate readings. Some say it means "the appearance of alarm and fear."
*《茫若》* is sometimes written as *芒* (máng). Guo Xiang reads it as *wǔdàng* (武荡).

The annotations further explain:
*风* (fēng) means "teaching." What I previously said was deeply contrary to principle; I now wish for a single word that might serve as instruction.

◎ Yu Yue says: *风* should be read as *凡* (fán), meaning "to speak of its general outline." *风* originally derives from *凡* phonetically, hence they may be used interchangeably.

Ji Che said: "When the great sage governs the world, he sways and stirs the people’s hearts, causing them to form teachings and change customs. He entirely eradicates their harmful intentions and advances their solitary aspirations, as if their nature acted of itself, and the people remain unaware of how this comes to be. If this is so, how could he be like one who, as a brother to Yao and Shun, teaches the people, treating them as younger siblings in the primordial chaos? Rather, he desires to align with virtue, and the heart abides in stillness."

The commentary explains:
Each aspiration has its own direction and cannot be imitated. Thus, when he follows their natural swaying and sways them, though he sways, it is not an act of doing; when he follows their natural stirring and stirs them, though he stirs, it is not motion. Therefore, their harmful intentions are extinguished of themselves, their solitary aspirations advance of themselves, teachings are established and customs transformed, all without trace. They tread their nature and act of themselves, unaware of how it comes to be, all saying, "It is simply our nature."

The annotations state:
When the sage governs the world, he greatly accords with all beings. He rides their natural swaying to establish the law and follows their natural stirring to form teachings. Thus, teachings are accomplished without visible traces, customs are transformed without the people’s awareness. All eradicate their harmful intentions and cultivate their solitary aspirations. Unmoved by external things, they act as if by nature itself; following their nature in movement, they do not know how it comes to be. *举* (jǔ) means "all."

*Fanqie* glosses:
*《举灭》* *举* means "all."
*《闷然》* is read as *mèn* (门).

The commentary explains:
*溟涬* (míngxìng) means "most noble." He does not deign to defer excessively to Yao and Shun but rather treats them as brothers.

The annotations state:
*溟涬* means "most noble." If one governs the people by the former method, governance returns to ancient purity, and all beings attain their nature. How could one need to uniquely honor Yao and Shun and treat them as elder brothers? This manner of yielding and deference does not yield to Tang and Yu.

*Fanqie* glosses:
*《岂兄》* The Yuanjia edition reads *岂足* ("how could it be worthy").
*《溟》* is read as *míng* (亡顶).
*《涬》* is read as *xìng* (户顶).

The commentary explains:
*居* (jū) means "not to pursue external things." If the heart does not abide, virtue will not be aligned.

The annotations state:
*居* means "to settle and stabilize." When the heart races beyond its proper bounds, it clashes with external things; when it is empty, level, still, and settled, the myriad conditions become one. Thus, the difference or sameness of conditions lies in the stillness or disturbance of the heart. Therefore, if one wishes to align with Yao and Shun in virtue, one must first settle the heart.

The editor notes:
The three characters *举皆也* ("*举* means 'all'") were mistakenly included from the *Shiwen* and have been deleted according to the Zhao Jianyi edition.

Zigong traveled south to Chu and, returning to Jin, passed by Hanyin. He saw an old man preparing garden beds, digging a tunnel to enter the well, holding a jar to draw water and irrigate. He toiled strenuously, yet his achievement was meager.

Zigong said: "There is a device here that can irrigate a hundred beds in a single day, requiring little effort yet yielding great results. Would you not desire it?"

The annotations state:
The south of the water is called *阴* (yīn). A place for growing vegetables is called *圃* (pǔ). The area within the ridges is called *畦* (qí). *隧* (suì) means "underground passage." *搰搰* (húhú) describes the appearance of exertion. *丈人* (zhàngrén) is a term of respect for an elder. Zigong traveled south to the land of Jing and Chu, passing by the south bank of the Han River, where he exchanged words with the old man. The ebb and flow of their dialogue is fully recorded in the text. Zhuangzi used these two worthies to illustrate the praise of primordial chaos.

*Fanqie* glosses:
*《圃》* is read as *bùhù* (布户) or *bù* (布). Li (Yun) says: "A place for vegetables is called *圃*."
*《畦》* is read as *hùguī* (户圭). Li (Yun) says: "The area within the ridges is called *畦*." The *Shuowen* states: "Fifty *mu* is called *畦*."
*《隧》* is read as *suì* (遂). Li (Yun) says: "It means 'path.'"

《瓮》 is read as *wēngsòng* (乌送) *fǎn*. The character is also written as *瓮*.

《搰搰》 is read as *kǔgǔ* (苦骨) *fǎn*; Xu and Li read it as *kǔhuá* (苦滑) *fǎn*; Guo reads it as *hūhuá* (忽滑) *fǎn*. It describes the appearance of exertion. Another pronunciation is *húmò* (胡没) *fǎn*.

[Commentary 2] *械* (xiè) refers to machinery. Upon seeing the elder expend much effort for little result, Zigong sought to instruct him in the use of machinery, hoping to achieve greater results with less labor. Thus, he offered his sincere advice, though he did not know whether the elder would accept it.

[Fanqie glosses]
《有械》 is read as *hùjiè* (户戒) *fǎn*. The *Zilin* writes it as *械*. Li says: "It means 'implements.'"
《浸》 is read as *zǐzhèn* (子鸩) *fǎn*. Sima says: "It means 'to irrigate.'"

[Collation Notes]
(1) *Quēwù* cites the Zhang Junfang edition, which includes the character *机* below.
(2) The character *户* is amended following the Shide Tang edition and the original *Shiwen* text.
(3) *械* is suspected to be a corruption of another character.

The gardener looked up and asked, "What do you mean?"

Zigong replied, "Carve wood into a machine: the rear is heavy, the front is light. When you pull the handle, it draws water as swiftly as boiling over. It is called a *槔* (gāo)."

The gardener flushed with anger, his expression turning to scornful laughter, and said, "I have heard from my teacher that those who possess machinery must engage in mechanical affairs, and those who engage in mechanical affairs must harbor a mechanical mind. When a mechanical mind resides in the breast, purity and whiteness are incomplete; when purity and whiteness are incomplete, the spirit’s vitality is unsettled. One whose spirit’s vitality is unsettled is not borne by the Dao. I am not ignorant of such things—I am ashamed to do them."

【一】**Subcommentary:** *Naihe* means "how" (an inquiry into his method).

**Exegesis:** *Ang* (昂) is read as *yang* (仰).

【二】**Subcommentary:** *Ji* (机) means "pivot." When one lifts and draws the water, irrigating as if pulling, the speed is discussed in terms of its swiftness—like boiling water surging and bubbling. With its front light and rear heavy, it is what is now called a *jiegao* (桔槔, well-sweep).

**Exegesis:** *Qie shui* (挈水) is read as *koujie* (口节) in reverse. *Ruo chou* (若抽) is read as *chiliu* (敕留). Li [Yun] says: "to draw." Sima [Biao] and Cui [Zhuan] write it as *liu* (流). *Shu ru* (数如) is read as *suojiao* (所角) by Xu [Shen] and *suolu* (所录) by others. *Yi tang* (泆汤) is read as *yi* (逸). Some versions write it as *yi* (溢). Li [Yun] says: "as swiftly as boiling water overflowing." Sima [Biao] writes it as *yidang* (佚荡), also describing its rapid back-and-forth motion like unrestrained swaying. *Yidang* (佚荡) means "reckless abandon." *Gao* (槔) is also written as *qiao* (桥) or *gao* (皋), all pronounced *gao* (羔). Xu [Shen] reads it as *juqiao* (居桥). Sima [Biao] and Li [Yun] say: "a *jiegao* (桔槔)."

【三】**Commentary:** What is used in its proper time is indeed pure and complete. This man seeks to cultivate purity and completeness but clings to oneness and upholds antiquity, missing the essential point.

**Subcommentary:** Those who possess mechanical devices must engage in mechanical tasks; those who engage in mechanical tasks must harbor a mechanical mind. When a mechanical mind resides in the breast, purity, whiteness, and simplicity are not fully realized. When purity, whiteness, and simplicity are not fully realized, the spirit hangs in suspense, its arising and ceasing unsettled. When unsettled, it is not borne by the Great Dao, and thus he is ashamed to act. This is one who has not yet embodied true cultivation, merely clinging to oneness and guarding whiteness.

**Exegesis:** *Wu shi* (吾师) refers to Laozi.

**Collation Notes:** (1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition writes *ang* (昂) as *yang* (仰). (2) *Que wu* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, which writes *wei* (为) as *jie* (桔).

Zigong was struck dumb with shame, lowering his head and making no reply.

【一】**Subcommentary:** *Man* (瞒) describes a look of embarrassment. Having misspoken, he did not know how to respond.

**Exegesis:** *Man* (瞒) is read as *wuban* (武版) in reverse, or *mengan* (亡安). The *Zilin* says: "a level gaze." Li [Yun] reads it as *tiandian* (天典), meaning "a look of shame." One pronunciation is *men* (门), or *mogan* (亡干). Sima [Biao] writes it as *wu* (怃), pronounced *wu* (武). Cui [Zhuan] writes it as *fu* (抚).

After a pause, the gardener said, "What are you doing here?"

【一】**Subcommentary:** *You xian* (有闲) means "after a moment." *Xi* (奚) means "what." He asked Zigong: "Whose disciple are you? What do you study?"

Zigong replied, "I am a disciple of Confucius."

【一】**Subcommentary:** He answered: "a disciple of Master Ni."

◎**Qingfan’s Note:** The *Yiqiejing yin yi* (25) cites Sima [Biao] as saying: "a disciple." The *Exegesis* omits this.

The gardener said, "Are you not that one who broadly studies to rival the sages, who struts about to overshadow the masses, who plays the lone zither and sings mournful songs to sell your name throughout the world? You should be forgetting your spirit and qi, casting off your bodily form—then you might approach it! Yet you cannot even govern yourself—how could you have leisure to govern the world? Be gone! Do not hinder my work!"

**【一】Subcommentary:** *Yu yu* (于于) refers to flattery. It means: you, with your vast learning and extensive knowledge, imitate the sages; with fawning flattery, you overshadow all things. Sitting alone, you pluck the zither and sing, modulating your voice in mournful sighs, clinging to these sagely traces to sell your reputation, traveling through the states, traversing the world.

**Exegesis:** *Yu yu* (于于) is read as written. Some versions write it as *yu xu* (唹吁), with the same pronunciation. Sima [Biao] says: "an appearance of boastful exaggeration." Another says: "an appearance of practicing benevolence and kindness." *Yi gai zhong* (以盖众): Sima’s version writes *gai* (盖) as *shan* (善).

◎**Jia Shifu’s Note:** In *Responding to Emperors and Kings*, it says: "In sleep, he is leisurely; when awake, he is *yu yu* (于于)." The *Shuowen* states: "*Yu* (于) means *yu* (于), depicting the unfolding of qi." Thus, *yu yu* (于于) is the same as *yu yu* (于于), meaning "leisurely."

**【二】Commentary:** If one does not forget and does not cast off, then there is no way to approach the nearness of the Dao.

**Subcommentary:** *Ji* (几) means "near." You forget your spirit and qi, cast off your bodily form; only when both body and mind are forgotten can you then nearly approach the Dao.

**Exegesis:** *Duo* (堕) is read as *xu gui* (许规反).

**【三】Subcommentary:** *Er* (而) means "you." *Fa* (乏) means "to neglect." If all things govern themselves, then the world is ordered; if one uses oneself to govern things, then great chaos ensues. With Zigong’s virtue, he is not yet sufficient to govern himself—how could he respond to the world’s summons? It is proper that he depart swiftly and not hinder my work.

**Exegesis:** *Wu fa* (无乏): *fa* (乏) means "to neglect."

Zigong, humbled and discomfited, lost his composure, and only after walking thirty *li* did he recover.

**【一】Subcommentary:** *Bei zou* (卑陬) is an appearance of shame. *Xu xu* (顼顼) is an appearance of self-loss. Having been rebuked, he lost his countenance; after walking thirty *li*, he gradually returned to normal.

**Exegesis:** *Bei zou* (卑陬) is read as *zou hou* (走侯反), or in Xu’s version as *ce liu* (侧留反). Li [Yi] says: "*Bei zou* (卑陬) is an appearance of fear and shame." Another says: "an appearance of lost composure." *Xu xu* (顼顼): some versions write it as *xu xu* (旭旭), read as *xu yu* (许玉反). Li [Yi] says: "an appearance of self-loss."

His disciples said: "Who was that man just now? Why did you, Master, change your expression and lose your composure upon seeing him, remaining unsettled for the rest of the day?"

**【一】Subcommentary:** *Fan* (反) means "to return." Zigong’s disciples called him "Master." "That man we just saw—what arts or learning does he cultivate, that upon a single glance, you lost your usual composure, your spirit and qi unsettled for the entire morning?" His disciples, finding this strange, thus questioned him.

**Exegesis:** *Xiang zhi* (向之) is read as *xu liang* (许亮反). Some versions write it as *xiang* (乡), with the same pronunciation. The same applies hereafter.

He replied: "At first, I believed there was but one such person in the world, unaware there could be another like him.

I have heard from the Master that in affairs, one seeks what is proper; in achievements, one seeks completion. To expend little effort yet attain great results—this is the Way of the sage.

Yet now it is not so. Those who hold to the Dao attain wholeness of virtue; those with wholeness of virtue attain wholeness of form; those with wholeness of form attain wholeness of spirit. Wholeness of spirit—this is the Way of the sage.

Entrusted with life, they move among the people yet remain unaware of their destination, vast and perfectly complete! The pursuit of profit, cunning, and skill must be forgotten from such a one’s heart.

As for this man, if his will does not align, he does not go; if his heart does not consent, he does not act. Though the world praises him and he obtains what he deems right, he remains aloof and unmoved; though the world condemns him and he loses what he deems right, he remains untroubled and unyielding. The world’s praise or blame neither adds to nor detracts from him—such is the person of perfect virtue!

As for me, I am but one tossed by the winds and waves."

[1] [Annotation] This refers to Confucius.

[2] [Exegesis] In the past, when I received instruction, only the Master stood unrivaled throughout the world. Now, having encountered this Venerable One, I find his Dao and virtue even more profound and far-reaching—thus my humility and inability to remain composed. Since I have yet to grasp the true and the false, I truly regard him as wiser than Confucius.

[Phonetic Gloss] *Fuyou* (復有): read as *fúyòu*.
*Furen* (夫人): read as *fú*; same below.

[3] [Annotation] The Way of the sage is simply to employ the hearts of the common people.

[Exegesis] Affairs are deemed proper when they accord with the times, and achievements are deemed complete when they attain their ends. Thus, when little effort yields great results, this is the mechanism of timely success. Zigong recounted what he had heard in the past, taking it to be the Way of the sage.

[4] [Annotation] This is the Way of the sage-king, not the Way of this man. Zigong, hearing his discourse on provisional cultivation, submitted to it, unaware that the one of pure whiteness moves in harmony with the world.

[Exegesis] Now, when the Venerable One questioned me, it was not like this. He said: One who holds fast to the Dao suffers no lack in virtue; one with wholeness of virtue suffers no harm in form; one with wholeness of form attains wholeness of spirit. Wholeness of spirit—this is to dwell among men, entrusting life to the world, moving alongside all things yet remaining unaware of one’s destination, vast and unfathomable, beyond measure. Thus, his conduct is pure and harmonious, his virtue and Dao perfectly complete, such that profit, cunning, and skill cannot enter his heart. This is the Way of the sage, not the art of provisional cultivation. Zigong, failing to awaken, mistakenly offered such words.

[Exegesis]
《茫乎》: *máng hū*, read with *mò gāng* as the fanqie.
《之心》: *xīn* ("heart/mind"), or in some versions *dào* ("Dao/Way").

[Chapter 5]
[Commentary] These are the followers of Song Rongzi, yet they do not suffice for wholeness of virtue. Zigong’s delusion, drowned in this man, is like Liezi’s heart intoxicated by Jixian.

[Exegesis] *Áo* is the bearing of arrogance and boastfulness; *tǎng* is the appearance of nonattachment. The Venerable One’s will and qi are pure and unadorned, unburdened by cunning or skill, his heart holding few desires, unconcerned with action. Though the whole world might praise him, calling him virtuous, he knows it brings no benefit and does not so much as glance at it. Though the whole world might slander him, ruining his reputation, he understands it causes no harm and does not accept it. Unmoved by praise or blame, he may be called a man of whole virtue. Though water’s nature is clear, when wind stirs, waves rise; if my heart is unsettled, it resembles those waves—hence, they are called the people of wind and waves.

Guo’s commentary states: These are the followers of Song Rongzi, yet they do not suffice for wholeness of virtue. Zigong’s delusion, drowned in this man, is like Liezi’s heart intoxicated by Jixian.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*"Yù zhī"* (誉之) is pronounced *yú*; same below.
*"Áorán"* (謷然) is read with the fanqie *wǔ gāo fǎn*.
Sima’s edition has *jǐng* (警).
*"Tǎngrán"* (傥然) is also written as *dǎng* (党) in some editions.
Sima’s edition has a lacuna, but the reading is the same.
*"Chìdàng"* (敕荡) is read with the fanqie *chì dàng fǎn*; Guo [Xiang] reads it as *tù gèng fǎn*.
[The traveler] returned to Lu and reported to Confucius.
Confucius said: "That man was but feigning the arts of the Hun Dun clan.
He knows one thing but not two;
he cultivates his inner self but neglects his outer.
One who is lucid and enters simplicity, who acts without contrivance and returns to uncarved wood, who embodies nature and embraces the spirit, roaming amidst the world of men—would you truly be startled by him?
Moreover, the arts of the Hun Dun clan—how could you or I presume to comprehend them!"

**[1] [Commentary]**
Because he turns his back on the present and faces antiquity, ashamed to engage in worldly affairs, we know he is no true Hun Dun.

**[Exegesis]**
Zigong traveled from Lu to Chu, then returned to Lu and recounted the encounter to Confucius.
Now, *hun dun* means "without distinctions."
Since he turns from the present toward antiquity, we know he does not practice the true arts of the Hun Dun clan.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*"Hún"* (浑) is read with the fanqie *hú běn fǎn*.
*"Dùn"* (沌) is read with the fanqie *tú běn fǎn*.
*"Bèi jīn"* (背今) is pronounced *pèi*.

**[2] [Commentary]**
He merely recognizes the simplicity of ancient cultivation and embracing the unhewn, yet does not understand the ease of adapting to the times and responding to things.

**[Exegesis]**
"Knows one thing" refers to clinging to antiquity without change.
"Not knowing two" means being unable to follow the present and adapt to circumstances.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*"Zhī yì"* (之易) is read with the fanqie *yǐ chǐ fǎn*.

**[3] [Commentary]**
The true Hun Dun does not cultivate at all—how could he treat inner and outer as distinct and cultivate only one side?

**[Exegesis]**
Holding to the Dao and guarding simplicity is cultivating the inner.
Being unable to adapt to the times and respond to change is neglecting the outer.

**[4] [Commentary]**
This is the true Hun Dun: he moves with the world without losing himself, so though he roams amidst the world of men, his traces are obliterated—would he necessarily startle you?

**[Exegesis]**
When the heart’s wisdom is clear and attains the essence of simplicity;
when effortless tranquility returns to the source of uncarved wood;
when one awakens to true nature and embraces pure essence, mingling with the dust of the world—then even rivers and seas, forests and marshes, birds and beasts are not alarmed, so how could men be startled?
Yet it says, "Would you truly be startled?"—this makes clear that one *need not* be startled.

◎ Yu Yue says: *Gù* (固) should be read as *hú* (胡). Since *hú* and *gù* share the same ancient pronunciation, they are interchangeable. *Rǔ jiāng hú jīng yé* (汝将胡惊邪) means "Would you be startled upon encountering the true Hun Dun?" Guo Xiang’s commentary—"He moves with the world without losing himself, so though he roams amidst the world of men, his traces are obliterated—would he necessarily startle you?"—perfectly captures the meaning. In ancient texts, the character *hú* (胡) is sometimes written as *gù* (故). Examples include the *Luxury and Waste* chapter of the *Guanzi*: "The lord was about to depart, so I did not see him off," and the *Exaltation of Worthies* chapter of the *Mozi*: "Thus, he did not examine the root of governing through exalting worthies." Both instances demonstrate *gù* being used for *hú*. The Zheng Xuan commentary on the *Duke Ai’s Questions* chapter of the *Book of Rites* states: "*Gù* means *therefore*." Thus, using *gù* for *hú* is akin to using *gù* for *hú*.

**[5] [Commentary]**
To him, it is "him"; to us, it is "us." The Hun Dun is profoundly identical—who can comprehend it? What is comprehended is merely its traces.

**[Exegesis]**
The Hun Dun is without intention, transcending wisdom and thought. Even if sages and worthies were uniquely perceptive, how could they presume to comprehend it? This reveals its unfathomable depth, pushing it beyond the realm of sentiment and intent.

Zhun Mang was traveling east to the Great Abyss when he encountered Yuan Feng on the shores of the Eastern Sea.
Yuan Feng asked: "Where are you going?"

**[1] [Exegesis]**
*Zhūn* means "pure." *Yuan* is a small wind, or else the great whirlwind *fuyao*. *Bin* means "shore"; the *Great Abyss* is the sea. Zhun Mang and Yuan Feng are both allegorical figures. Zhuangzi uses these two to illustrate the Great Dao, so he feigns them as host and guest, meeting on the sea’s edge.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*"Zhūn"* (谆) is read with the fanqie *zhī lún fǎn*, or else *shù lún fǎn*.
*"Máng"* (芒) is sometimes written as *máng* (茫), pronounced *wǔ gāng fǎn*.
Li [Yi] says: "Gazing at him, he seems earnest; examining him, he seems obscure—hence the name Zhun Mang." Another says: "It is a personal name." Yet another says: "It is mist."
*"Dà hè"* (大壑) is read with the fanqie *huǒ gè fǎn*.
Li [Yi] says: "The *Great Abyss* is the Eastern Sea."
*"Yuàn fēng"* (苑风) is also written as *wǎn* (宛), pronounced *yú ruǎn fǎn* in Xu’s edition.
Li [Yi] says: "It means small, referring to one who roams the world of men." Another says: "Yuan Feng is a personal name." Another says: "It is the great whirlwind *fuyao*."
*"Zhī bīn"* (之滨) is pronounced *bīn*.

◎ Qing Fan’s note: In the *Exegetical Notes*, *yuàn* (苑) is also written as *wǎn* (宛)—*yuàn* and *wǎn* are the same character. The *Stimulating Transformation* chapter of the *Huainanzi* reads: "The form is *yuàn* while the spirit is robust." Gao You’s commentary: "*Yuàn* means withered illness; *yuàn* is read like *wǎn* in Nanyang."

**[2] [Exegesis]**
*Xī* (奚) means "what." *Zhī* (之) means "to go."

"May I ask, Zhun Mang, where do you journey?"
He replied: "I am going to the *Great Abyss*."

**[1] [Exegesis]**
Intending to travel to the Eastern Sea.

"For what purpose?" he asked.

**[1] [Exegesis]**
Further inquiring what he seeks there.

He replied: "As for the *Great Abyss*—such is its nature: pour into it and it is never full; draw from it and it never runs dry. I shall wander there."

**[1] [Exegesis]**
The great sea is vast and boundless, its depths unfathomable. A hundred rivers flow into it yet it does not overflow; the Tail Socket drains it yet it does not run dry. This analogy applies to the supreme principle, and its meaning is likewise so. Thus, though he journeys to the azure deep, in truth he roams the mind in the great Dao.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Draw from it* (酌焉) is also written as *take from it* (取焉).

Yuan Feng said: "Does the Master have no intention toward the *horizontal-eyed people*? I wish to hear of sagely governance."

**[1] [Exegesis]**
Within the Five Phases, only the people have horizontal eyes, hence they are called the *horizontal-eyed people*. Moreover, Zhun Mang’s eastern journey takes him to the edge of the *Great Abyss*, where he observes its depth and distance to discern the methods of governance. Yuan Feng, having perceived this intent, thus posed the question: "Does the Master truly have no concern for the black-headed people?"

"I wish to hear of the methods of sagely transformation."

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Horizontal-eyed people* (横目之民): Li [Yi] says: "They belong to the class of insects, and he desires to govern them."
*Wish to hear* (愿闻): Some versions follow Sima [Biao]’s text, writing *ask* (问) instead; the same applies below.
*Sagely governance* (圣治): Pronounced *zhí lì*; the same applies below.

Zhun Mang said: "Sagely governance? Offices are established and measures implemented without losing their appropriateness; the capable are promoted without misjudging their abilities. **[1]** All circumstances are fully perceived, and actions are taken accordingly; **[2]** words and deeds proceed naturally, and the world is transformed. **[3]** With a wave of the hand or a glance, the people of the four directions all arrive together—this is called sagely governance. **[4]**"

**[1] [Exegesis]**
Commands are issued and offices established, each attaining its proper convenience; the worthy are selected and recommended without misjudging their talents. Thus, the world attains great peace, and the constant norms are ordered—such is the method of sagely governance.

**[Exegetical Notes]**
*Offices established* (官施): Pronounced *shǐ zhī* or *shǐ zhì*. Sima [Biao] says: "Policies are implemented and teachings disseminated, each attaining its proper place."

**[2] [Commentary]**
All are employed according to their nature.

**[Exegesis]**
Divergent paths and multifarious affairs abound, for steps vary with the times, and customs differ across ages. Thus, in governance, nothing precedes allowing things to follow their nature. One must observe their circumstances and discern their actions, then proceed in accordance with them—thus, nothing will be amiss.

**[3] [Commentary]**
If things are made to follow [the ruler], they will not be transformed.

**[Exegesis]**
All matters of implementation and teachings issued are entrusted to things themselves, not imposed by the ruler. Thus, the black-haired people of the world naturally follow transformation.

**[4] [Commentary]**
This means that with a gesture or glance, the people each attain their nature—this is because they are allowed to act of their own accord.

**[Exegesis]**
*Twist* (挠) means *move*. With a motion of the hand or a glance, the four directions submit, and the myriad states pay homage. Such is the efficacy of sagely governance. Some versions write *chin* (颐) instead, meaning that with a movement of the jaw, the four directions all submit. Here, three figures are distinguished: the sagely, the virtuous, and the spirit-like. The above concerns sagely governance; below, the two others—virtuous and spirit-like—are listed in order.

**[Exegesis on Characters]**
*Hand-twist* (手挠): The small *fanqie* reading is *ér*, and another reading is *liǎo*. Sima [Biao] says: it means *to move*. Another explanation: it refers to directing the four directions with a gesture. *Glance-direct* (顾指): read as written. Xiang [Xiu] says: *Glance-direct* means governing through gestures and glances. Some pronounce it as *yí* (颐). The original text also writes *yí*, with the *fanqie* reading *zhī*, meaning to raise the jaw and direct. ◎Qing Fan’s note: *Hand-twist* and *glance-direct* form a parallel structure. The commentary’s *gesture* corresponds to *hand-twist*, while *glance* corresponds to *glance-direct*; thus, the exegesis explains the four characters by separating *moving the hand* and *raising the eyes*. If, as Xiang [Xiu] says, *glance-direct* means *directing with gestures and glances*, the meaning is lost. *Glance-direct* means to glance at someone while directing them. Zuo Si’s *Wu Capital Rhapsody* says, *"Plucking banners as if at a glance-direct,"* and Liu Kui’s annotation: *"It means directing as one wishes."* Here, *glance-direct* shares the same meaning as the *Book of Han*’s *Biography of Gong Yu*: *"Directing with the eyes and commanding with qi"* (Yan Shigu’s annotation: *"Moving the eyes to indicate objects, emitting qi to command people."*).

**[1]**
"I wish to hear of the *virtuous person*."

**[Exegesis]**
The previous discussion of sagely governance has already been amply explained; the meaning of the *virtuous person* is what I deeply wish to hear.

[The Master] said: "The *virtuous person* dwells without thought, moves without deliberation, and harbors no right or wrong, beauty or ugliness. When all within the four seas share in its benefits, this is called *joy*; when all are provided for, this is called *peace*. They are forlorn, like an infant who has lost its mother; disoriented, like a traveler who has lost the Way. Wealth and resources are abundant, yet they know not whence they come; food and drink are sufficient, yet they know not from where they derive—this is called the *bearing of the virtuous person*."

**[Commentary]**
They follow nature alone.

**[Exegesis]**
In profound accord with the Dao’s realm, they attain what is without attainment—thus they are called *virtuous persons*. The *virtuous person* concentrates their spirit and sits in solemn stillness, utterly devoid of thought. Even when responding to things and enacting transformation, they never engage in scheming or deliberation.

**[Commentary]**
They harbor no right or wrong in their hearts but entrust it to the world.

**[Exegesis]**
Embracing the Dao and holding fast to virtue, they forget both self and others—how could they harbor right or wrong, or contain good and evil?

**[Exegesis on Characters]**
*Beauty/ugliness* (美恶): read *wū-lù*.

**[Commentary]**
They have no self-serving inclinations.

**[Exegesis]**
The *virtuous person*’s beneficence is vast and far-reaching, pervading all beings. Thus, when wealth and resources are shared by all within the four seas, and provision is given to the myriad people without distinction, the entire world rejoices, and all under heaven is at peace. ◎Qing Fan’s note: *Called joy* and *as peace* form a parallel structure. *Called* (谓) here means *to be*. In ancient texts, *called* and *to be* were used interchangeably.

**[Exegesis]**
An infant who has lost its mother is forlorn, with no one to rely on; a traveler who has lost the Way is disoriented, with no place to turn. These two analogies illustrate the *virtuous person*.

**[Exegesis on Characters]**
*Forlorn* (怊乎): pronounced *chāo*. The *Character Forest* says: it means *disconsolate*. Xu [Shen] reads it *chí-yáo*; Guo [Pu] reads it *tiáo*. *Disoriented* (傥乎): pronounced *chǎng-dǎng*. Sima’s edition writes it as □.

**[Five] [Commentary]**
Virtue is the trace of the spirit-person, hence it is called *deportment*.

**[Exegesis]**
With few desires and bounded by one’s allotted share, resources and provisions are ever sufficient; not coveting rich flavors, food and drink are taken in moderation; with no demands upon life and fate, one knows not whence they come. These threads gather into the preceding meaning, hence it is called *the deportment of the virtuous person*.

**[Exegesis on Characters]**
*Deportment of the virtuous person* (德人之容): pronounced *yáng-xiōng*. Some say: according to the commentary, it should read *guest* (客).

---

“Would that I might hear of the *spirit-person*.”

**[One] [Commentary]**
Would that I might hear of that by which they leave traces.

**[Exegesis]**
Virtue is but the trace of the spirit-person; would that I might hear of that by which they leave traces.

It is said:
“The supreme spirit rides upon light, and with form perishes and vanishes. This is called *illuminating the vast expanse*. Giving free rein to fate and exhausting one’s nature, heaven and earth rejoice, and the myriad affairs dissolve and vanish. The myriad things return to their nature—this is called *profound obscurity*.”

**[One] [Commentary]**
To *ride upon light* is to be without light.

**[Exegesis]**
*Rides* (乘) means *employs*. *Light* (光) means *wisdom*. The highest spirit-person employs wisdom to illuminate things; though their brilliance may be like that of the sun and moon, it illuminates and then vanishes. Body and senses are cast aside, heart and form both abandoned—thus it is said *with form perishes and vanishes*.

**[Two] [Commentary]**
To be without self and yield to things, empty and void of all attachment, is not darkness or obstruction.

**[Exegesis]**
Their wisdom encompasses the myriad things, their clarity surpassing the Three Luminaries; no hidden thing is not illumined—how could this not be *vast*?

**[Three] [Commentary]**
When nature is exhausted and fate fulfilled, heaven and earth rejoice. When affairs do not obstruct joy, there are no affairs.

**[Exegesis]**
To fathom the utmost of life and fate, to exhaust the nature of generation and transformation—thus they abide between heaven and earth yet are never not carefree and joyful. Having grasped the illusory emptiness of self and things, the myriad affairs dissolve and vanish.

**[Exegesis on Characters]**
*Heaven and earth rejoice* (天地樂): pronounced *luò*. The commentary is the same.
*Dissolve and vanish* (銷亡): Xu pronounces it *xiāo*.

**[Four] [Commentary]**
When nature returns, there is *profound obscurity* without trace.

**[Exegesis]**
To forget illumination yet illuminate—illumination rises with the Three Luminaries in brilliance. To forget life yet live—life rejoices alongside the Two Modes. Thus they perceive the myriad things’ return to their origin, witness the four births’ restoration of fate, and so merge in chaos without division, profoundly one with the Dao.

**[Exegesis on Characters]**
*Profound obscurity* (混冥): pronounced *hú-běn*.

---

Menwu Gui and Chizhang Manji observed the troops of King Wu.

Chizhang Manji said: “Are they not inferior to the Yu clan? Thus they encounter this calamity.”

**[One] [Exegesis]**
Men and Chizhang are surnames. Wu Gui and Manji are given names. Two thousand five hundred men constitute a *troop*; *troop* means *multitude*. When King Wu attacked Zhou, his forces crossed the Meng Ford, and the two men observed together.

**[Exegesis on Characters]**
*Menwu Gui* (門無鬼): Sima’s edition writes *Wuwei* (無畏), stating: *Men* is the surname; *Wuwei* is the style.
*Chizhang Man* (赤張滿): Some editions write *Pu* (蒲).
*Ji* (稽): pronounced *gǔ-xī*. Li says: *Men* and *Chizhang* are surnames; *Wu Gui* and *Manji* are given names.

**[Two] [Exegesis]**
*Encounter* (離) means *suffer*. Yu Shun governed the age with yielding deference; King Wu saved the world with shield and spear. Between yielding deference and shield and spear, the disparity is vast. Judging by this, one arrives at the remark of inferiority. Moreover, arms are inauspicious instruments—hence they suffer the misfortune of slaughter.

Menwu Gui said: “Was the world made orderly by the Yu clan’s governance, or was it disordered and then made orderly?”

**[Exegesis on Characters]**
*Jūnzhì* (均治): pronounced *zhí-lì*. Below and in the commentary, *jūnzhì* is the same.
*Zhī yú* (之与): pronounced *yú*. Some editions write *yé* (邪).
*Fù hé* (复何): pronounced *fú-yòu*. The same in the following chapter’s commentary.
*Yáng* (疡): pronounced *yáng*. Li says: a head wound. The wound is used as a metaphor for disorder, seeking the remedy of the Yu clan to govern it. Sima says: *bǐyáng* (疕疡).
◎ Wang Yinzhi notes: *Yào* (药) was anciently read as *yào* (曜), its sound akin to *liáo* (疗) (see *Tángyùn Zhèng*). *Fāngyán* states: *yáo* (愮) means to cure. The regions of Jiang, Xiang, Jiao, and Hui call medical treatment *yáo* (愮), or *liáo* (疗). The commentary notes: *yáo* (愮) is pronounced *yào* (曜). It shares an ancient graph with *yào* (药). Thus, the *Shènjiàn*’s *Súxián* chapter says: “*Yào* (药) means *liáo* (疗).” The *Zuǒzhuàn* of Duke Xiāng’s thirty-first year reads: “It would be better to hear and *yào* (药) it.” The *Jiāyǔ*’s *Zhènglùn* chapter is the same, with Wang Su’s commentary: “*Yào* (药) means *liáo* (疗).” In the *Shījīng*’s *Dàyǎ* *Bǎn* chapter, “beyond saving by *yào* (药),” the *Hánshī Wàizhuàn* writes *yào* (药) as *liáo* (疗). The graphs for *yào* (药) and *liáo* (疗) were anciently interchangeable in meaning.
*Huànchuāng* (患创): pronounced *chū-liáng*.

**[Exegesis]**
**[1] [Commentary]**
The two sages both governed because of disorder, so yielding deference and the use of arms were merely differences of the times—there was no superiority or inferiority between them.

**[Exegesis]**
*Jūn* (均) means *píng* (平), “level.” If the world were at great peace, with all things in accord with principle, why would there be need for Yu Shun to establish laws and govern it? It was only because Yao’s years were waning and his virtue daily declining that he yielded to Chonghua, entrusting him with the task of ordering it.

**[1] [Commentary]**
When the world is level and governed, the wishes of each are fulfilled—why then calculate the virtue of the Yu clan and elevate him as ruler? Xu Wugui’s words are correct.

**[Exegesis]**
When the realm is clear and harmonious, and the aspirations of all are satisfied, why deliberate on the virtue of the Yu clan and elevate him as ruler? This grasps the meaning of Wugui’s words, affirming their reason.

**[2] [Commentary]**
The world was all afflicted by wounds of disorder, hence it sought the remedy of the Yu clan.

**[Exegesis]**
*Yáng* (疡) means a head sore. When the body suffers wounds, one seeks a physician to treat them—just as when the world encounters turmoil, a sage is needed to govern it. Thus, without illness there is no physician; without disorder, there is no sage.

Chizhang Manji said: “That the world be level and governed is the wish—why then reckon with the Yu clan as ruler! The Yu clan’s remedy for sores: applying medicine to the bald, seeking a physician for the sick. The filial son, holding medicine to cure his compassionate father, his countenance scorched with anxiety—the sage feels shame at this.”

**[3] [Subcommentary]**
With hair thick as clouds, no labor is needed for adornment;
Fortunate to be free of illness, why seek a physician!
Thus, when the world is clear and at peace, there is no need for a great sage.
These two lines summarize the preceding meaning.

**[Exegesis]**
*Tu* (秃): pronounced *tumu* (吐木反).
*Ti* (): pronounced *daxi* (大细反).
Sima [Xiangru] says: it means *bi* (髲, hair).
Also pronounced *tudi* (吐帝反).
Guo [Pu] (2): reads as *mao* (毛).
Li [Xun] says: *mao* (髦) means hair.

**[4] [Annotation]**
Those who govern the world do not do so for glory.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Cao* (操) means to grasp; *xiu* (修), to order.
*Jiaoran* (燋然) describes a withered, haggard appearance.
The filial son, in treating his compassionate father, does not boast of his merit;
The sage, in rescuing the world from calamity and chaos, does not seek honor or distinction!
Such affairs are undertaken out of necessity—hence the shame.

**[Exegesis]**
*Cao yao* (操药): pronounced *qidao* (七刀反).
*Jiaoran* (燋然): pronounced *jiangyao* (将遥反), or *qiao* (樵).

**[Collation]**
(1) *Quewu* (阙误) cites the Zhang Junfang edition, where *xiū zhī* (羞之) is written as *suǒ xiū yě* (所羞也).
(2) Guo [Pu]’s entry likely omits the characters *zuò máo* (作髦).

In an age of utmost virtue, worthies are not exalted, (1)
Abilities are not employed; (2)
The ruler is like the tip of a branch, (3)
The people like wild deer; (4)
Upright yet unaware of righteousness, (5)
Loving yet unaware of benevolence, (6)
Sincere yet unaware of loyalty,
Proper yet unaware of trustworthiness; (7)
Moving in instinctive response, aiding one another without thought of reward. (8)
Thus, their actions leave no trace, (9)
Their affairs leave no record.

**[1] [Annotation]**
The worthy occupy their rightful place—not exalted for it.

**[Subcommentary]**
The unworthy and the worthy each fulfill their station—not exalted to distinguish the worthy.

**[2] [Annotation]**
The capable act of their own accord—not employed for it.

**[Subcommentary]**
The skilled and the clumsy follow their nature, neither boasting nor emulating—without exalting or employing them.

**[3] [Annotation]**
Emerging above things yet not self-elevating.

**[Subcommentary]**
The ruler, dwelling above the people, serene and empty of self, is like the high branch of a tree, without thought of glory or nobility.

**[Exegesis]**
*Ru biao* (如标): pronounced *fangxiao* (方小反), Xu [Shen] reads *fangyao* (方遥反), also *fangmiao* (方妙反).
It means the tip of a tree’s branch, without intent to be above.

**[Collation]**
Hu [Yuan] reads *xiao* (校), Li [Xun] reads *jiao* (较).
One version writes *zhi* (枝).
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The current edition’s *collation* writes *zhi* (枝).

**[4] [Annotation]**
Roaming freely, self-content.

**[Subcommentary]**
With the ruler practicing non-action, the people remain simple and unspoiled—like wild deer, untouched by the rites of kingship.

**[5] [Subcommentary]**
Their hearts are upright, not given to wickedness—how would they know the principle of judging right and wrong!
Following Heaven’s pattern, they naturally draw close to one another—how would they recognize partial affection as benevolence!

**[6] [Annotation]**
Following their nature spontaneously, not through knowledge.

**[Subcommentary]**
Following their nature, they are sincere—unaware that this sincerity is loyalty;
Acting in accord with truth, they are proper—unaware that this propriety is trustworthiness.

**[7] [Annotation]**
Their movements are self-directed, thus they move without gratitude.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Ci* (赐) means to receive favor.
The creatures of instinct—those with spirit and intelligence—drive one another, a principle inherently natural.
Like limbs and trunk, or eyes and ears, they act without intent to create, nor do they feel indebted for favor.
Governing through non-action follows the same principle.

**[Exegesis]**
*Chun* (蠢): Guo [Pu] reads *chuyun* (处允反), meaning movement.

**[8] [Annotation]**
The ruler (2) allows them to act of their own accord—hence no trace remains.

**[Subcommentary]**
With ruler and people simple and unspoiled, above and below at peace, they move by following their nature—thus no trace is left to record.

**[9] [Annotation]**
Each remains in their proper place—hence no teaching is transmitted to others.

**[Subcommentary]**
Like head and feet, each has its office; they remain within their bounds, not transmitting or learning from one another.
With traces already obscured, affairs too vanish.

**[Exegesis]**
*Wu chuan* (无传): pronounced *zhuanzhuan* (丈专反).

**[Collation]**
(1) The character *wei* (为) is emended to *wu* (无) following the Song edition and other versions.
(2) The character *wang* (王) is emended to *zhu* (主) following the Daoist Canon edition.

The filial son does not flatter his parents; the loyal minister does not fawn upon his ruler—this is the height of ministerial and filial virtue. **[1]**
