The method of nurturing life aligns with the mysterious Heaven’s virtue; though the traces are manifest, the mind remains ever tranquil.

**Commentary:**
All these occur naturally, without contrivance.

**Subcommentary:**
*Constancy* means *permanence*. The sun and moon radiate brilliance, illuminating the six directions; cold and heat alternate as the four seasons revolve; day and night follow their course; clouds drift and rain falls—these are the great virtues of Heaven and Earth, the constant Dao of nature. Without partiality in mind, how could there be deliberate nurturing? The Way of emperors and kings is likewise.

**Phonetic Annotation:**
*"Yǔ shī"* (雨施): pronounced *shǐ* (始豉反).

Yao said, "How restless and chaotic! You are the union of Heaven; I am the union of man."

**Commentary:**
He reproached himself for being meddlesome.

**Subcommentary:**
*Jiaojiao* and *raorao* both describe a state of disturbance. Upon grasping these words, he reproached himself for being overly involved, and so they exchanged modest deference.

**Phonetic Annotation:**
*"Jiaojiao"* (胶胶): pronounced *jiao mao* (交卯反). Sima [Biao] says: harmonious.
*"Raorao"* (扰扰): pronounced *er xiao* (而小反). Sima [Biao] says: gentle.
Note: If following the main interpretation, *jiaojiao raorao* describes a state of turmoil.

**Subcommentary:**
Yao humbly deferred, yielding to Shun, saying: "Your great virtue aligns with Heaven above, while my efforts merely accord with human affairs." Now, Yao and Shun were two sages whose virtue was without distinction; thus, this exchange between the two exemplars illustrates the proper way of governance.

Heaven and Earth are what the ancients revered most, and what the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun all celebrated together. Therefore, those who ruled all under Heaven in ancient times—what did they do? They simply followed Heaven and Earth.

**Subcommentary:**
From this point onward, the words are those of Zhuangzi. Heaven covers and Earth bears, giving life to all things; among the Four Great of the world, these two stand supreme. Thus, he invokes the ancients to affirm their virtue in the present.

**Subcommentary:**
Only Heaven is great, and Yao emulated it. Thus, we know that the Yellow Emperor, Zhuanxu, Yao, and Shun all took aligning their virtue with Heaven and Earth as their highest achievement.

**Subcommentary:**
What did the ancient sage-kings who embodied the Dao do? They followed things without contrivance, their virtue uniting with the Two Modes [Heaven and Earth].

**Phonetic Annotation:**
*"Zhi wang"* (之王): pronounced *wang kuang* (往况反).

Confucius went west to deposit his writings in the Zhou archives. Zilu advised, "I have heard that among the Zhou’s *Zhengcang* officials there is one named Lao Dan who has resigned and returned home. If you wish to deposit your writings, you might try visiting him first."

**Subcommentary:**
His surname was Zhong, given name You, courtesy name Zilu, a disciple of Confucius. Seeing that the virtue of Zhou had declined beyond remedy, Confucius could not assist in its restoration. Thus, he wished to deposit his own writings in the Zhou archives, hoping they might serve as a model for future rulers. He consulted his disciples to weigh the matter. Laozi’s surname was Li, given name Dan, and he served as the *Zhengcang* official of Zhou, akin to today’s archivist, responsible for ancient texts. Seeing the Zhou court in turmoil, he resigned his post and retired to a quiet life. Thus, Zilu advised Confucius to visit him and seek his counsel.

**Phonetic Annotation:**
*"Cangshu"* (藏书): Sima [Biao] says: to deposit the books he had written.
*"Zhengcang"* (征藏): pronounced *cai lang* (才浪反). Sima [Biao] says: *Zhengcang* is the name of an archive. Another interpretation: *zheng* means "to oversee."
*"Shi"* (史): the historian of the archives.
*"Lao Dan"* (老聃): pronounced *tu gan* (吐甘反). Some say: Lao Dan was the name of Laozi in Confucius’ time.
*"Mian er gui"* (免而归): Laozi saw that the end of Zhou was beyond repair, so he resigned and departed.

Confucius said, "Very well."

Confucius went to visit Lao Dan, but Lao Dan refused his request. Thereupon, Confucius expounded the Twelve Classics to persuade him.

Laozi, recognizing that the texts Confucius wished to preserve were but the withered straw dogs of former sages—unfit to be long retained lest they mislead later generations—thus refused. Confucius, having edited the *Book of Poetry* and *Book of Documents*, established the rites and music, composed the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, and expounded the *Book of Changes*, these being the Six Classics; adding the Six Wefts, they became the Twelve Classics. He unfolded and expounded them in detail, thus turning and returning to his argument.

Lao Dan, moved by his discourse, said, "This is all too vast and reckless! I would hear its essentials."

Confucius replied, "The essentials lie in benevolence and righteousness."

Laozi asked, "May I ask: are benevolence and righteousness part of human nature?"

Confucius said, "Indeed. The noble person who lacks benevolence cannot achieve completion, and without righteousness cannot live. Benevolence and righteousness are the true nature of humanity—what more is there to say?"

Laozi said, "May I ask: what are benevolence and righteousness?"

Confucius replied, "A heart that delights in all things, universal love without partiality—this is the essence of benevolence and righteousness."

Laozi said, "Ah! These words come perilously close to folly! Is not universal love overly circuitous? And in claiming to be without partiality, one becomes partial. If you, Master, wish the Son of Heaven to lose nothing of his governance, then know this: Heaven and Earth have their constancy, sun and moon their brightness, stars and constellations their order, birds and beasts their flocks, trees and plants their standing. You, Master, should emulate virtue and act, follow the Dao and proceed—this is already perfection. Why then do you clamor for benevolence and righteousness as if beating a drum in search of a lost child? Ah! You, Master, confuse human nature!"

The myriad things are all self-sufficient.

Beasts with awareness and plants without feeling each attain their standing and possess their flocks and ranks—how could this depend on benevolence and righteousness?

This does not require universal love.

To follow one’s virtue and wander freely through the world, to move in step with the Dao of Heaven and tread the paths of men—there is no more wondrous way of conduct in the human realm than this.

If one strains body and mind, bearing the burden of benevolence and righteousness, forcing their practice upon the world to teach all living beings, how is this different from striking a great drum in search of a lost child? The louder the drum’s sound, the farther the lost one flees; the more prominently benevolence and righteousness are displayed, the farther one strays from the Dao—thus there is no way to attain it.

Love as the occasion demands, halt when righteousness calls—this is to forget benevolence and righteousness. To dwell upon them constantly is to disrupt the true.

The lost child is not found, the fault lies in the drum’s clamor; the true nature remains obscured, the error stems from benevolence and righteousness. Thus the sigh is uttered, and the matter concluded.

Shi Chengqi came before Laozi and asked, “I have heard that you, Master, are a sage. I did not hesitate to journey from afar, wishing to meet you, enduring a hundred lodgings with calloused feet, never daring to rest. Yet now I observe you and find you are no sage. There is leftover grain in the rat’s burrow, yet you cast aside those who are ignorant—this is not benevolence. Raw and cooked provisions lie unfinished before you, yet you amass and hoard without end.”

Laozi remained silent and unresponsive.

The next day, Shi Chengqi came again and said, “Yesterday I spoke critically of you, but today my heart is empty and still. Why is this?”

Laozi replied, “The one skilled in wisdom and divine sagacity—I have long since cast off such a name. In the past, when you called me an ox, you called me an ox; when you called me a horse, you called me a horse. If one truly possesses the reality, yet others give a name and one does not accept it, one will suffer harm twice over. I wear my usual garb, always my garb; I do not wear it because it is a garb.”

Laozi said, “As for those skilled in cunning wisdom and divine sagacity—I have long since cast off and moved past such a state. When you called me an ox, I called myself an ox; when you called me a horse, I called myself a horse. If one truly possesses the reality, yet rejects the name others give, one will suffer harm twice over. My bearing is ever my bearing; I do not adopt it because it is a bearing.”

Shi Chengqi, stepping aside like a wild goose in flight and treading cautiously, advanced and asked, “How ought one cultivate the self?”

Laozi replied, “Your countenance is steep and towering, your gaze piercing and sharp, your brow high and exposed, your mouth gaping and fierce, your demeanor stiff and strained—you stand as though tethered like a horse. Your movements are restrained, your reactions swift as a crossbow’s trigger, your scrutiny precise, your knowledge cunning yet tainted by excess. All this betrays a lack of trustworthiness. At the borderlands there dwells one called the Thief.”

◎ Qing Fan notes that *yì* should be read as *é*. *Yìrán* means "lofty," *éran* likewise. For further discussion, see Yu Yue’s *Pingyi* on the "Dasheng Shi" chapter. Both Guo Xiang’s commentary and the subcommentary err in this regard.

**[Six]**
**Commentary:** The mind is set on galloping.
**Subcommentary:** Though his form appears solemn, his heart and nature are restless and agitated, like a swift horse tethered, his mind set on running free.

**[Seven]**
**Commentary:** He cannot relax and let go.
**Subcommentary:** His emotions chase after external things, reacting to every encounter, unable to follow his natural inclinations, constrained in every matter.

**[Eight]**
**Commentary:** His approach and withdrawal are swift.
**Subcommentary:** *Jī* refers to the trigger of a crossbow. His mind clings and climbs, reacting to circumstances with such sudden force that it resembles the release of a crossbow’s trigger.

**[Nine]**
**Commentary:** He discerns right and wrong.
**Subcommentary:** Unable to empty himself and forget both opposition and compliance, he scrutinizes right and wrong, his mind fixed and judgmental.

**[Ten]**
**Commentary:** *Tai* means excess beyond one’s inherent nature. Skill in recognizing excess leads to clumsiness in embracing simplicity.
**Subcommentary:** *Tai* means "excess." Unable to forget cunning and knowledge, to perceive the principle of non-action, he resorts to deceitful wisdom and artifice, seeing only the multiplicity of worldly affairs.

**[Eleven]**
**Commentary:** All these ten traits reveal a lack of trustworthiness in one’s nature and life, leading to recklessness in the face of praise and blame—none of this is the Way of self-cultivation.
**Subcommentary:** *Xin* means "real." These ten traits are all deceptive behaviors, not true virtue.
◎ Jia Shifu remarks: Guo Xiang says, "All these ten traits reveal a lack of trustworthiness in one’s nature and life, leading to recklessness in the face of praise and blame." The phrasing here adds an extra turn. "All reveal a lack of trustworthiness" means that all his actions arise from artificiality, not aligning with the natural Dao, hence called "untrustworthy." His bearing, gaze, brow, mouth, and demeanor—any hint of restraint is like a horse tethered to curb its wildness, unable to trust his own heart. His reactions are swift, his responses mechanical, his knowledge and cunning prevailing—unable to trust the external world. These subtly divide into two meanings and cannot be counted as ten distinct traits.

**[Twelve]**
**Commentary:** This is like your conduct—you are no upright person.
**Subcommentary:** *Qiè* means "thief." At the borderlands, there suddenly appears a man who fears no laws, engaging only in theft. Internally, he corrupts customs; externally, he severs relations with neighboring states. No greater harm to governance and all things exists. Cheng Qi’s behavior is just as base—his every move is as wild and unruly as this thief.
**Exegetical Notes:** *Biān jìng* is pronounced like *jìng* (border). *Yǒu rén yān, qí míng wèi qiè*: A man of the frontier, untouched by the proper rites and music, may speak words that coincidentally align with the classics, but all is stolen knowledge—how can his Way be worth discussing? Sima [Biao] says: This refers to a man once found in distant lands.
**Collation:** (1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition has *jìng* instead of *jìng*. (2) The Shidetang edition has *zhī* instead of *rú*.

The Master said: “The Dao, in its vastness, does not come to an end; in its minuteness, does not omit anything—thus all things are complete within it. Boundless is its capacity to embrace all, unfathomable its depth. Form, virtue, benevolence, and righteousness are but the outermost traces of spirit—who but the perfected person can rightly discern them?

The perfected person engages with the world—is this not grand? Yet it does not burden him. The world stirs in turmoil, but he does not join in its strife. He examines what requires no reliance and does not shift with profit. He attains the truth of things and holds fast to their root. Thus he transcends heaven and earth, leaves behind the ten thousand things, and his spirit is never constrained.

In harmony with the Dao, aligned with virtue, he sets aside benevolence and righteousness, treats rites and music as guests—such is the settled mind of the perfected person.”

**[One]**
**Subcommentary:** Zhuang Zhou studied under Laozi, hence he is called "the Master." *Zhōng* means "to exhaust." Though the two primal forces are vast, they remain within the Dao and cannot exhaust its measure. Though the tip of an autumn hair is small, it relies on the Dao to take form—thus the Dao does not omit even the smallest. Since it can be both vast and minute, we know all things are complete within it.

**[Two]**
**Subcommentary:** So vast it encompasses all, so fine it penetrates all, threading through the ten thousand things, embracing the two primal forces—thus we call it boundless in its breadth, profound in its depth.
◎ Qing Fan notes: *Guǎngguǎng* is akin to *kuàngkuàng*, describing emptiness and absence of people. The *Book of Han*, "Five Elements Treatise," states: "When an army sets out past the proper time, this is called *guǎng*." Li Qi says: *Guǎng* is pronounced *kuàng*. *Kuàng* and *guǎng* share the same meaning in ancient script. The *Book of Han*, "Biographies of the Five Sons of Emperor Wu," records: "How *guǎngguǎng* is the road!" Su Lin says: *Guǎng* is pronounced *kuàng*.

**[Three]**
**Subcommentary:** Form, virtue, benevolence, and righteousness are but the outermost traces of spirit, not its true essence. They are remedies for the world’s ills, employed only when necessary. Who but the most sagely and spiritual person can rightly discern their coarse and refined aspects?

**[Four]**
**Commentary:** Engaging with the world, he does not fear its vastness.
**Subcommentary:** The sage’s power spans the realm, ruling over the world, occupying the throne of the ninefold virtue—is this not grand? Yet like the immortal of Guye or the sage of Fenyang, he forgets things and self, moving yet still, untroubled by the four seas.

**[Five]**
**Commentary:** He remains still and follows along.
**Subcommentary:** *Qì* means "power" or "influence." *Xié* means "to dwell." When the altars of soil and grain collapse and the world falls into chaos, those who rush about in the world stir up power—but the sage remains still and self-possessed, not joining in the tumult.

**[Six]**
**Commentary:** He examines what requires no reliance and does not shift with profit.
**Subcommentary:** He scrutinizes what is without falsehood and does not change for gain.

**[Seven]**
**Subcommentary:** He attains the truth of things and holds fast to their root.

**[Eight]**
**Subcommentary:** Thus he transcends heaven and earth, leaves behind the ten thousand things, and his spirit is never constrained.

**[Nine]**
**Subcommentary:** In harmony with the Dao, aligned with virtue.

**[Ten]**
**Subcommentary:** He sets aside benevolence and righteousness.

**[Eleven]**
**Subcommentary:** He treats rites and music as guests.

**[Twelve]**
**Subcommentary:** Such is the settled mind of the perfected person.

**[Exegesis]**
*Fèn* (奋) is pronounced *bǐng*. Sima [Biao] says: "might and authority." Li [Yi] reads it as *chǒu lún*. One version writes it as *dòng* (栋). ◎ Jia Shifu says: The *Exegesis* cites Sima [Biao]’s gloss—*bǐng* (柄) as "might and authority." The *Shuowen* states: "A *bǐng* is a handle." *Bǐng* (柄) is sometimes written as *bǐng* (棅). The *Guanzi*’s *Shanquan Shu* says: "To grasp the fullness and emptiness of the state’s calculations is called *guóquán* (state authority); this refers to the ruler. To regulate the weight of human affairs is called *jūn* (lordship)." A *bǐng* is that by which affairs are regulated. The great regulate the great; the small regulate the small. All who rise together to act in the world rely on something. The *Shuowen* says: "To *jiǎ* (假) is to borrow." Without something to borrow, there is no action; without action, one drifts like grass in the wind, like waves in the current, shifting with things. Without reliance and without shifting for profit—this is called "non-action yet nothing left undone." Guo Xiang says it means "following one’s nature and proceeding directly," which is incorrect.

**[Six]**
**Commentary:** Following one’s nature and proceeding directly.

**Subcommentary:** His will and nature are tranquil; he entrusts himself to fate and follows his nature. Neither glory nor position touches his heart—how could wealth or profit sway him?

**[Seven]**
**Subcommentary:** The sage’s spirit-mirror is penetrating and clear; he exhausts principle and fulfills his nature, thus attaining the truth of things. Yet his responses are boundless, and his movement does not disrupt stillness—he holds fast to the root.

**[Eight]**
**Subcommentary:** Though he grasps the charts and governs the realm, ruling over all directions, he forgets the two poles [heaven and earth] and abandons the ten thousand things. Thus, with non-action, affairs become non-affairs; his mind is at ease, his spirit sovereign—what exhaustion or constraint could there be?

**[Nine]**
**Subcommentary:** His mind of tranquil indifference communicates with the supreme Dao; his wisdom of empty forgetfulness aligns with the highest virtue. Here, realm and wisdom meet, and ability and object merge in darkness.

**[Ten]**
**Commentary:** He advances the Dao and virtue.

**[Eleven]**
**Commentary:** He takes essence and nature as his master.

**Subcommentary:** He retreats from the shallowness of benevolence and righteousness and advances the purity of Dao and virtue; he casts aside the flamboyance of rites and music and upholds the emptiness of non-action. ◎ Yu Yue says: *Bīn* (宾) should be read as *bìn* (摈), meaning to cast aside rites and music, matching the previous line’s "retreat from benevolence and righteousness." Guo’s commentary—"taking essence and nature as his master"—reads it as the original character, but the meaning becomes circuitous. The *Dá Shēng* chapter says: "Cast aside by his village, pursued by his district"—this is evidence of *bīn* being used for *bìn*. ◎ Qing Fan notes: Yu’s argument is sound. Since *bīn* and *bìn* share the same pronunciation, characters with identical sounds are often borrowed for one another. The *Zhōu Lǐ*’s *Sī Yí* states: "*Bīn* bows and presents gifts," and the *Exegesis* notes: "*Bīn* is pronounced *bìn*." In this book’s *Xú Wúguǐ* chapter, "*Bīn* to my humble self," the Sima edition writes *bīn* as *bìn*—further proof.

**[Twelve]**
**Commentary:** Settled in non-action.

**Subcommentary:** Serene and inactive, yet his use does not deviate from stillness—thus he is settled.

**[Collation]**
(1) The *Quēwù* edition cites the Jiangnan ancient manuscript, which repeats the character *yuān* (渊).

What the world values in the Dao is the *book* **[One]**—yet a book is no more than words, and words have what is valued in them. What is valued in words is *meaning* **[Two]**, and meaning has what it follows. What meaning follows cannot be transmitted in speech **[Three]**—yet the world values speech for transmitting books. Though the world values them **[One]**, I still do not find them sufficient, for what they value is not what is truly valuable **[Four]**. Thus, what can be seen when looking are forms and colors; what can be heard when listening are names and sounds. Alas! The world takes forms, colors, names, and sounds as sufficient to grasp the truth of things! Yet if forms, colors, names, and sounds are truly insufficient to grasp the truth of things **[Five]**, then the knower does not speak, and the speaker does not know—how could the world recognize this **[Six]**?

**[One]**
**Subcommentary:** The *Dao* refers to speech; the *book* refers to writing. The world’s people, with their shallow perceptions, either rely on speech to convey the heart or use writing to express intent, reciting and exchanging them as if they were precious. They do not realize there is nothing sufficient to be spoken.

**[Two]**
**Subcommentary:** The purpose of writing is to convey speech; the purpose of conveying speech is to express meaning.

**[Three]**
**Subcommentary:** *Suí* (随) means "to follow." What meaning arises from follows the Dao. Since the Dao is neither form nor sound, it cannot be transmitted in speech.

**Exegesis:** *Yánchuán* (言传) is pronounced *zhàng zhuān*. The same applies below.

**[Four]**
**Commentary:** What is truly valuable always lies beyond words and speech.
**Subcommentary:** Writing serves to record speech, and speech serves to convey meaning. Yet people of this degenerate age, their minds dull and obstructed, value words and writings excessively, unable to forget language in pursuit of principle. Thus, though they prize them, I still deem them unworthy of esteem—for words and writings are but dregs, not things of true value. Hence Guo’s commentary states: *What is truly valuable always lies beyond words and speech.*

**Exegesis:** *Wéiqí* (为其) is pronounced *yúwěi*.

**[Five]**
**Commentary:** Only those who forget words and abandon writings can grasp the true nature of things.
**Subcommentary:** What the eye perceives does not exceed forms and colors; what the ear hears is confined to names and sounds. Yet the world’s people, failing to comprehend the ultimate principle, mistake names, words, sounds, and appearances for the full reality of the Dao. How could they know that the profound and boundless lies beyond the reach of sight and hearing? Such ignorance is deeply lamentable. Hence Guo’s commentary states: *Only those who forget words and abandon writings can grasp the true nature of things.*

**[Six]**
**Commentary:** This expresses the meaning of *cutting off learning and discarding knowledge.*
**Subcommentary:** Those who know the Dao forget words; those who value virtue forget knowledge. Yet the deaf and deluded masses—how could they awaken? Only those of true understanding can embody this.
**Exegesis:** *Zhīzhě* (知者) is read as *zhī*; the same applies below. Alternatively, both may be read as *zhì*. *Qùshàng* (去尚) is pronounced *qǐlǚ*.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The *Shide Tang* edition includes the character *zāi* (哉) below.
(2) The character *zhī* (之) is supplied following the Song edition and the subcommentary.

Duke Huan was reading in the hall above. Below, Wheelwright Pian was hewing a wheel, and setting aside his mallet and chisel, he ascended and asked Duke Huan: “May I dare ask—what words are those Your Lordship reads?”

**[One]**
**Subcommentary:** Duke Huan was Duke Huan of Qi. *Lún* (轮) means “wheel”; *Piān* (扁) was the name of the craftsman. *Zhuó* (斲) means “to carve.” *Shì* (释) means “to set aside.” The lord of Qi was engrossed in reading, while Wheelwright Pian was crafting a wheel—noble and commoner differed in rank, their tasks in kind. Yet he set aside his tools to pose his question, intending to show that the profoundness of the ultimate Dao cannot be transmitted in speech. Thus, through the figures of Duke Huan and the craftsman, he briefly reveals the attainment of forgetting words.
**Exegesis:** *Huángōng* (桓公): Li [Xian] says: Duke Huan of Qi, named Xiaobai.
*Lúnbiǎn* (轮扁): Pronounced *piān*; alternatively, *fútiǎn*.
Sima [Biao] says: A wheelwright, named Pian.
*Zhuó* (斲): Pronounced *zhíjué*.
*Érshàng* (而上): Pronounced *shízhǎng*.

**Collation Note:**
(1) The *Shide Tang* edition has *zhě* (者) as *zuò* (作).

The Duke said: “The words of the sages.”

**[One]**
**Subcommentary:** These were the canons of Wen and Wu, the teachings handed down from Yao and Shun—words of the sages.

“Are the sages still alive?”

**[One]**
**Subcommentary:** He further asked: “Are the sages still living?”

The Duke said: “They have already died.”

**[One]**
**Subcommentary:** He replied: “Though the sages are dead, their teachings remain.”

“Then what Your Lordship reads are but the dregs and lees of the ancients!”

**[One]**
**Subcommentary:** *Fū* (夫): Wine sediment is called *zāo* (糟); soaked sediment is called *pò* (粕). Fine wine compared to the Dao and virtue is like dregs and lees compared to benevolence and righteousness—stale as straw dogs, what are they worth?
**Exegesis:** *Zāo* (糟): Pronounced *zāo*. Li [Xian] says: The sediment of wine.
*Pò* (魄): Pronounced *pǔgè*. Sima [Biao] says: Rotten food is called *pò*. Another says: *Pò* is what remains when sediment rots. Originally written as *pò* (粕), same pronunciation. Xu Shen says: *Pò* is the coarse sediment left after straining. Alternatively, pronounced *pǔbái*, meaning *húnpò* (魂魄).
*Yǐfū* (已夫): Pronounced *yífú*. A terminal particle. Alternatively, read as written.

◎ Qing Fan’s note on *Shiwen*: *Pò* (魄) is alternatively written as *pò* (粕), which is the version in Sima’s text. *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on Lu Shiheng’s *Wen Fu* cites Sima: “Rotten food is called *pò* (粕).”

Duke Huan said: “When We read books, how dare a wheelwright pass judgment! If you have an explanation, you may live; if not, you shall die.”

**Subcommentary [One]:** Noble and base are separated by ritual; one must not speak lightly. Yet this common craftsman dares to offer his opinion. If his explanation is reasonable, he may be spared guilt; if he has no words, he will surely incur the death penalty.

Wheelwright Pian replied: “Your servant observes it through his own craft. In carving wheels, if done too slowly, the fit is smooth but not firm; if too swiftly, it is rough and does not penetrate. Neither too slow nor too swift—it is grasped by the hand and responds to the heart, yet the mouth cannot express it; there is a method inherent in the process. Your servant cannot make his son understand it, nor can his son receive it from him. Thus, though I am seventy years old, I still carve wheels in my old age.

**Subcommentary [Two]:** The ancients and what they could not transmit have perished. Yet what Your Lordship reads are but the dregs and lees of the ancients!”

**Subcommentary [One]:**
"Gan" means "leisurely"; "ku" means "hurried." "Shu" means "technique." If the wheel-carving misses its proper measure, it will not be secure. But when it is done just right, the mouth cannot express it. How much more is this true of the principles of teaching and learning!

**Explication of Terms:**
"Gan" is read as in the standard pronunciation, or alternatively as *han*. Sima [Biao] says: "Gan" means "leisurely"; "ku" means "hurried." "You shu": Li [Yi] says: *shu* is read with the entering tone (se zhu fan), meaning "technique." ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: Given that the preceding and following instances all read *shu* with the entering tone, this annotation may contain an error.

**Subcommentary [Two]:**
This speaks of how things each possess their own nature, and how teaching and learning are of no avail.

**Subcommentary:**
"Yu" means "to make clear." Wheelwright Pian’s technique cannot be demonstrated to his son, nor can his son receive his instruction. Thus, though he has reached old age, he cannot escape the toil of the axe and adze. From this we know that things each have their own nature and cannot be imitated.

**Commentary [Three]:**
The affairs of antiquity have already perished in antiquity. Even if some part of them has been transmitted, how could it make the ancient present in the present? Since the ancient is not in the present, present affairs have already changed. Thus, one must sever learning and follow one’s nature, adapting to the transformations of the times before attaining the Dao.

**Subcommentary:**
The sages established their methods to benefit the world in accordance with the times. Since time does not stand still, the methods must also change. Thus, the people and laws of antiquity have perished in the past, while the laws and people of the present naturally arise in the present. There is no place for clinging to the traces of the ancient sages in the present age. From this we know that the books one reads are surely the dregs and lees.

**Explication of Terms:**
"Ren yu" is read as in the standard pronunciation, or alternatively as *yu*. "Ke chuan" is read with the retroflex (zhi zhuan fan). The commentary is the same.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The character *bu* ("not") is supplied in accordance with the main text.
(2) The Zhao Jiayi edition reads *gu* ("ancient") as *jin* ("present").
(3) The Zhao edition reads *mie* ("perished") as *jian* ("diminished").

*Outer Chapters, "Heavenly Revolutions," Chapter Fourteen*

**Outer Chapters, "Heavenly Revolutions," Chapter Fourteen**

**[1] Explication of the Title:**
The chapter is named according to its meaning. *Tian yun* ("Heavenly Revolutions") is rendered as *Tian yuan* ("Heavenly Roundness") in Sima’s version.

Does Heaven revolve?
Does Earth abide in stillness?
Do the sun and moon contend for their places?
Who presides over these?
Who maintains their order?
Who, dwelling in inaction, sets them in motion?
Is there some mechanism that compels them, leaving them no choice?
Or do they revolve ceaselessly, unable to halt themselves?
Do clouds give rise to rain?
Or does rain give rise to clouds?
Who bestows this abundance?
Who, dwelling in inaction, indulges in excess and yet urges them on?
Winds arise from the north, now west, now east, drifting upward in restless motion—who exhales and inhales them?
Who, dwelling in inaction, stirs and scatters them?
May I venture to ask the reason?

**[1] Commentary:**
They move not by revolving but by self-propulsion.
**Explication:**
Heaven, endowed with yang qi, is light and floats above; it moves of itself without intent.
**Explication of Terms:**
*Qi yun* ("Does it revolve?"): The *Erya* states: *yun* means "to shift." The *Guangya* states: *yun* means "to turn."
◎Qingfan’s note: *Yun* ("revolve") appears as *yuan* ("round") in Sima’s *Explication*. The characters *yun* and *yuan* were interchangeable in antiquity. The *Yueyu* reads: "A territory of a hundred *li* in breadth," with Wei’s commentary: "East-west is *guang* (breadth); south-north is *yun* (extent)." The *Western Mountains Classic* renders it as "a hundred *li* in *guangyuan* (breadth and roundness)." In the *Mozi*, "Against Fate (Upper)," the phrase "like one who sets the sundial by turning the potter’s wheel" appears as *yun* in the middle chapter, but as *yuan* in the original. *Yun* was also pronounced like *yun* (cloud) in antiquity. *Yun* and *yuan* are interchangeable. In the *Guanzi*, "Admonitions," the line "The four seasons descend as *yun* (clouds), and the myriad things are transformed" uses *yun* for *yun* (revolve). The *Shuowen* defines *zhen* as "also called *yunri* (revolving sun)"; Liu Kui’s commentary on the *Wu Capital Rhapsody* writes *yunri* as *yunri* (cloud sun), where *yun* is *yuan*. In the *Book of Documents*, *Taishi*, the phrase "though it is thus *yunran*" appears in the *Han Shu*, "Biography of Wei Xian," with *yun* written as *yuan*. In the *Book of Songs*, "Emerging from the Eastern Gate," "Let me delight in *yuan* (roundness)"—the *Explication* notes: *yuan* was originally written as *yun*. In the *Odes of Shang*, "Jing yuan," Zheng’s commentary: *yuan* appears as *yun* in the old text. All these serve as evidence.

**[2] Commentary:**
They abide not by stillness but by self-rest.

**[Subcommentary:]**
The earth receives yin qi, its turbidity sinking below, yet it too abides not by stillness but by self-rest.

**[3] Commentary:**
They vie not for place but by self-alternation.

**[Subcommentary:]**
Day and night illumine and overshadow, emerging and vanishing in alternation, naturally thus. Since they bear no sentiment toward alternation, how could they harbor intent in vying for place?

**[4] Subcommentary:]**
*Shu* means "who." *Shi* refers back to the preceding text. The four seasons and eight solar terms, clouds moving and rain descending, nurture the myriad beings, fostering all species—who is the sovereign that governs and enacts this? This line explicates the revolutions of heaven.

**[5] Commentary:**
All is self-so.

**[Subcommentary:]**
Mountains and peaks engender and rear, streams and springs flow and pour, embracing the ten thousand things, bearing them endlessly. Spring’s birth and summer’s growth proceed without error—who upholds this order to achieve such constancy? This line explicates the earth’s abiding.

**[6] Commentary:**
Without it, nothing could be propelled; with it, each has its own affair. Yet who, idle and unoccupied, propels and enacts this? Each moves of itself.

**[Subcommentary:]**
The sun and moon alternate, the stars and constellations shine brightly, each with its own measure, all proceeding from spontaneity. Who, dwelling in idleness, calculates and propels their course? This line explicates the sun and moon’s vying for place. The preceding three instances all pose hypothetical questions to reveal subtle truths. Thus we know all is self-so, with no thing causing it to be thus.

**[Explication of Terms:]**
*Tui er* (propel) is read as written; an alternate pronunciation is *tuī*. Sima’s edition reads *shui* (who).

**[7] Subcommentary:]**
*Ji* means "barrier." *Jian* means "closure." In the dark of winter’s severity and the obscurity of night, one conjectures with intent, supposing there must be a controller barring and sealing, that affairs are thus compelled. Yet by principle’s reckoning, all is self-so. The earth’s immobility follows the same pattern.

**[Explication of Terms:]**
*Jian* is read with the ancient *xian* rhyme, while Xu reads it with the ancient *xian* rhyme. Sima’s edition reads *xian*, glossing it as "drawing forth."

**[8] Commentary:**
Being self-so, it is therefore unknowable.

**[Subcommentary:]**
Consider how, in the height of spring, qi surges forth and the myriad things all come to life; day and night unfold in clarity, and the six directions are bathed in light. The sequence of qi revolves and turns, bringing forth this generation and nurturance. Tracing its principle and purport, no thing causes it to be thus. The revolving of the round heavens follows the same pattern.

**[9] Commentary:**
Neither can act upon the other; each is self-so.

**[Subcommentary:]**
When qi rises and ascends, it becomes clouds; when clouds disperse and descend, they flow and moisten to form rain. Yet tracing their beginning and end, there is no origin to be found. Thus we know neither can act upon the other.

**[Explication of Terms:]**
*Wei yu* is read with the *yu wei* rhyme; the same applies below and in the commentary.

**[10] Subcommentary:**
*Long* means "to arise," *shi* means "to cease." Who causes clouds and rain to arise and pour forth in torrents? Who ceases the sweet rains and brings about this severe drought?

**[Explication of Terms:]**
*Long shi* is read with the *shi* rhyme, *shi shi* rhyme.

◎ Yu Yue notes: This follows the preceding discussion of clouds and rain. *Long* should be *jiang* ("to descend"), meaning "to send down these clouds and rain." In the *Shangshu dazhuan*, Zheng’s commentary on *long gu* reads *long* as *jiang* ("to descend"). Since *long* is derived from the phonetic *jiang*, their ancient pronunciations were the same. In Xunzi’s "Discourse on Heaven," *long li zun xian er wang* appears in the *Han shi waizhuan* as *jiang*. In the *Zhan guo ce*, "In the eighth month, *jiang yu xia*," the *Fengsu tongyi*’s "Sacrificial Canons" chapter reads *jiang* as *long*. This is evidence of their interchangeability in ancient texts.

**[11] Subcommentary:**
Who, dwelling in idleness and at ease, urges and spurs another to create these excessive rains for pleasure? Sima’s edition reads *juan* ("weary").

**[Explication of Terms:]**
*Yin le* is read with the *luo* rhyme, or alternatively the *yue* rhyme. In *er quan* ("and urges"), Sima’s edition reads *quan* as *juan*, glossing it as: read as *sui* ("to follow"), meaning "who, doing nothing, merely follows the heavens in their ceaseless revolving."

**[12] Subcommentary:**
*Panghuang* describes the appearance of turning and revolving. *Xuxi* is like "exhaling and inhaling." *Pifu* is like "fanning and stirring." The north, being the domain of yin qi, is the source of wind. Yet wind blows without intent, drifting east or west as it pleases—now lingering in empty space, now exhaling and inhaling within the mountains, rising and falling in its fanning and stirring, with no fixed pattern. Who, dwelling in idleness, does this? It is simply the natural course.

**[Exegetical Notes:]**
*You shang* is read with the *shizhang* rhyme. *Pang* is read with the *bohuang* rhyme. *Huang* is read with the *huang* rhyme. Sima’s edition reads *panghuang* as *panghuang*, glossing it as: *panghuang* means a whirlwind. *Xu* is read with the *xu* rhyme. *Xi* is read with the *xiji* rhyme. *Pi* is read with the *fangpi* rhyme. *Fu* is read with the *fangfu* rhyme; Guo reads it with the *fufu* rhyme. *Pifu* describes the appearance of wind. Sima’s edition reads it as *fu*.

**[13] Annotation:**
This poses a question about the reason for things being as they are.

**Subcommentary:**
This line broadly questions what prior intent caused this.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) *Que wu* cites Li’s edition, where *shi* ("to apply") is written as *chi* ("to relax").
(2) *Que wu* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, where *you* ("there is") is written as *zai* ("exists").

Wu Xian Shao said: "Come! I will tell you. Heaven has the Six Ultimates and Five Constants. If emperors and kings follow them, there is order; if they oppose them, there is misfortune. The affairs of the Nine Rivers, when governed to completion and virtue perfected, illuminate the earth below. When the world upholds them, this is called the Supreme August."

**[1] Annotation:**
Though the proximate causes of things may be known, tracing their origins to the ultimate reveals no cause—things simply are as they are.

Thus, being as they are, there is no need to inquire further into their causes—one should simply follow them.

**Commentary:**
Wu Xian was a divine shaman and minister to King Zhongzong of the Shang. *Shao* was his name. The Six Ultimates refer to the six directions: the four cardinal points, above, and below. The Five Constants refer to the Five Phases—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth—which are the inherent natures of human relations. This speaks of the natural principle: there are these Six Ultimates and Five Constants, and even the movements of the sun, moon, wind, and clouds follow the same pattern. One should simply allow them to unfold naturally, for they are complete in themselves—why impose intentions upon them?

**Phonetic Glosses:**
*Wu Xian Shao*: *Chi* is read as *yao* in the *fanqie* system; Guo [Pu] reads it as *tiao*, or alternatively as *shao*. Li [Yi] says: Wu Xian was a minister of the Shang. *Shao* is a posthumous name.
*Wu yu*: *Yu* is read as *ju* in the *fanqie* system.
*Nu*: Read as *ru*; the same applies thereafter.
*Liu ji*: Sima [Biao] says: the four directions, above, and below.
◎ Yu Yue says: The Six Ultimates and Five Constants may well be the Five Fortunes and Six Calamities from the *Hongfan*. *Chang* ("constant") and *xiang* ("auspicious") were interchangeable in ancient script. In the *Yili* ("Ceremonies and Rites"), *Shi Sang Li*, it says: "Offer these *chang* matters," and Zheng Xuan’s commentary notes: "In ancient script, *chang* was written as *xiang*." This is evidence. The *Shuowen*’s *shi* section states: *Xiang* means "fortune." Thus, the Five Constants are the Five Fortunes. The text below says: "The affairs of the Nine Rivers, when governed to completion and virtue perfected"—this likely refers to the Nine Categories of the *Luoshu* that Yu received!

**[2] Annotation:**
While acquired learning may be altered, one’s Heaven-endowed nature cannot be opposed.

**Commentary:**
The emperors and kings align above with the Dao of Heaven and follow below the will of the people. Governing with effortless action and allowing things to take their course brings order to the world. But to defy the joy of all under Heaven and disrupt the harmonious *qi* of the Two Modes (Heaven and Earth) is to act perversely, inviting chaos and misfortune.

**[3] Commentary:**
The "affairs of the Nine Rivers" refer to the matters of the Nine Provinces’ settlements. This means that when a ruler responds to Heaven and follows the natural course of things, governing without preconceived intent, the world attains great peace, and the people sing and play *jiqiang*. The lands of the Nine Provinces’ settlements achieve order and completion; the distant barbarian states of the Eight Wastelands perfect their Dao and virtue. Aligning with the Two Modes (Heaven and Earth), they nurture and sustain the myriad things; uniting with the Three Luminaries (sun, moon, and stars), they illuminate the earth below.
◎ Jia Shifu says: This speaks of Heaven’s movements as being spontaneous. When emperors and kings follow this spontaneity and respond with the Dao, Heaven and Earth also receive their shaping influence, and wind and rain are harmonized, the four seasons ordered. The "affairs of the Nine Rivers" are the Nine Categories that Yu received. *Zhuangzi* speaks of the Dao as not deviating from the sages—this is an example of that.

**[4] Annotation:**
This is because they follow what is spontaneously so.

**Commentary:**
When the Dao aligns with spontaneity and virtue equals the transformations of creation, the people willingly uphold it without weariness, and the common folk bear its burden without complaint. This may be called a return to simplicity and the governance of the Supreme August.
The Grand Steward of Song asked Zhuangzi about *ren* (benevolence).
Zhuangzi replied: "Tigers and wolves possess *ren*."
**[1] Commentary:**
The state of Song succeeded the Shang, so "Shang" here refers to Song.

The Grand Steward was an official title; his given name was Ying, and his courtesy name was Dang. Desiring to resolve his doubts, he questioned Zhuangzi about *ren* (benevolence).

**[Textual Note:]**
*Shang da* is read as *Tai*; the same applies to *da xi* below.
*Zai Dang*: Sima Biao states: "Shang refers to Song; *da zai* is the official title; *Dang* is the courtesy name."

**[2] Commentary:**
*Ren* is the manifestation of affection and love. Even fierce beasts like tigers and wolves understand mutual affection, which clearly shows that all beings possess the nature of *ren*.

The Grand Steward asked: "What do you mean by this?"

**[1] Commentary:**
The Grand Steward, not yet grasping the profound meaning, pressed further to inquire what was intended.

Zhuangzi replied: "The affection between father and son—how is this not *ren*?"

**[1] Commentary:**
The love between father and son arises naturally from Heaven; this is true *ren*—why ask again?

The Grand Steward said: "May I ask about perfect *ren*?"

**[1] Commentary:**
The affection of tigers and wolves is limited in scope, so he sought perfect *ren*, hoping to hear its profound principle.

Zhuangzi said: "Perfect *ren* is without partiality."

**[1] Annotation:**
"Without partiality" does not imply a deficiency of virtue. Consider the human body: there is no partiality in its parts. The head naturally resides above, the feet below; the organs dwell within, the skin and hair without. Within the body, outer and inner, above and below, noble and base, each fulfills its utmost function—yet there is no partial affection among them. This is the sufficiency of perfect *ren*. Thus, the five relations and six kinships, the worthy and foolish, near and far, do not lose their proper place in the world. This is the principle of spontaneity—what need is there for partiality?

**[Commentary:]**
Perfect *ren* forgets cares and severs thoughts, uniting with the Great Void as one body, merging the myriad things into singularity. How could partiality or impartiality be discussed? It is utterly without intent, yet accords with the world’s partialities.

**[Textual Note:]**
*Fu zang* is read as *cai lang*.

The Grand Steward said: "I have heard that without partiality, there is no love; without love, there is no filial piety. To call perfect *ren* unfilial—is this acceptable?"

**[1] Commentary:**
Without love or partiality, this is unfilial. To say perfect *ren* is unfilial—does this accord with principle? Shang Dang, failing to grasp the profound meaning, thus fell into shallow confusion. Zhuangzi, for his sake, provided a clear refutation, as elaborated below.

**[Textual Note:]**
In one version, *Dang* is written as *Ying*; the Cui edition follows this. Some say *Ying* is the Grand Steward’s courtesy name.

Zhuangzi said: "Not so. Perfect *ren* is lofty indeed; filial piety is simply insufficient to describe it.

**[1] Annotation:**
It must be spoken of in terms of forgetting *ren* and forgetting filial piety before it can be considered perfect.

**[Commentary:]**
Perfect *ren* forgets rightness and *ren*, esteemed and noble—how could one speak of it in terms of love and respect, mere proximate traces? It is fundamentally insufficient to describe.

**[2] Annotation:**
All names arise from insufficiency. Thus, transcending the names of *ren* and filial piety to enter the realm of namelessness—only then is perfection attained.

**[Commentary:]**
Shang Dang’s question remained mired in conventional bounds, while Zhuangzi’s answer soared beyond all limits. Thus, the principle of affection and love is not an excess of filial piety but a discourse that does not even reach filial piety.

**[3] Annotation:**
Ming Mountain lies in the northernmost reaches; to observe it while traveling south is to see Ying yet grow ever more distant from Ming Mountain. Perfect *ren* resides in impartiality; to speak of it in terms of *ren* and love is to make it ever more distant from the ultimate principle.

**[Commentary:]**
Ying is located in the south, Ming Mountain in the north. As Master Guo notes: "Ming Mountain lies in the northernmost reaches; to observe it while traveling south is to see Ying yet grow ever more distant from Ming Mountain. Perfect *ren* resides in impartiality; to speak of it in terms of *ren* and love is to make it ever more distant from the ultimate Dao." This annotation is quite clear and requires no further explanation.

**[Textual Note:]**
*Ying*: read as *yi jing* or *yi zheng*; the capital of Chu, located north of Jiangling.
*Ming Mountain*: Sima Biao states it is a mountain in the Northern Sea. ◎Qing Fan’s note: The *Su Qin Liezhuan* in the *Shiji*, as cited in the *Suoyin*, refers to Ming Mountain as being north of Shuozhou, differing from the *Shiwen*.

Thus, it is said: "With reverence, filial piety is easy; with love, filial piety is difficult. With love, filial piety is easy; to forget one’s kin is difficult. To forget one’s kin is easy; to make one’s kin forget oneself is difficult. To make one’s kin forget oneself is easy; to forget the world is difficult. To forget the world is easy; to make the world forget oneself is difficult.

The virtue of Yao and Shun was abandoned, yet they did not act for its sake. Their beneficence extended to ten thousand generations, yet the world knew nothing of it. How could this be merely a great sigh over *ren* and filial piety?

Filial piety, brotherly respect, *ren*, rightness, loyalty, trust, integrity, and incorruptibility—these are all self-exertions that enslave one’s virtue. They are not worthy of esteem.

Thus, it is said: The most noble surpasses the state’s ranks; the most wealthy surpasses the state’s wealth; the greatest aspiration surpasses fame and reputation. Therefore, the Dao does not change."

【4】【Commentary】Respect lies in outward traces; love follows the original heart. The heart arises from Heaven’s nature, thus it is difficult; traces are bound to human sentiment, thus they are easy.

【5】【Commentary】Though love and filial piety are difficult, they still linger within the realm of attachment—how much less do they compare to forgetting one’s kin, which is serene and free from entanglement? Since forgetting surpasses love, there is superiority and inferiority; by this measure, the difficulty and ease are made clear.

【6】【Commentary】When gibbons leap and sever their bowels, when old oxen lick their calves, kindness flows downward—this is the constant nature of creatures. Thus, for a child to forget its parents is easy; for parents to forget their child is difficult. Without attaining the Dao, who could practice this?

【7】【Annotation】The utmost *ren* harmonizes every joint, so that one goes through the day without self-awareness. When the sage presides, it is not through deliberate action but by allowing each to find its own fulfillment. When each fulfills itself, all affairs naturally harmonize, all beings naturally suffice—how could the world fail to forget itself? When all have forgotten themselves, where does the ruler reside? This is what is called mutual forgetting.

【Commentary】To mutually forget the world is to cast aside the throne as one would a worn-out sandal. To make the world mutually forget oneself is to have the people act in daily life without awareness. To govern with folded arms at Fenyang while roaming in spirit to Guye, the beauty of yielding and deference—this lies in emptiness and forgetting, and is the mutual forgetting of the world. Compared to what precedes, it is difficult; compared to what follows, it is easy. Yet it does not equal forgetting the Dao and stilling wisdom to merge with the transformations of creation, uniting virtue with Heaven and Earth. Thus, one indulges the natural dispositions of the myriad things, follows the inclinations of the hundred clans, so that great and small all attain their due, flying and sinking none are lost. Beneficence flows unseen, and all things are as they are—above, like branches swaying in the wind; below, like deer in the wild. At such a time, where does the ruler reside? This is to make the world mutually forget oneself, akin to the sovereigns before Xuanyuan, the ancient lords of pristine simplicity. Their virtue was unseen, so the world forgot them. This is to move from inferior to superior, from coarse to subtle, to relinquish and relinquish again, to delve into mystery upon mystery.

【8】【Annotation】Only by relinquishing Yao and Shun does their virtue become complete; if it remains bound in the heart, it is not self-attainment.

【Commentary】To relinquish is to forget and abandon. Yao and Shun, those two sovereigns of profound and far-reaching virtue, also forgot their virtue and acted without contrivance. This explains why mutually forgetting the world is difficult.

【9】【Annotation】Ever at ease, ever harmonious.

【Commentary】Their beneficence and grace nourished the multitude of beings, and ten thousand generations later, their virtue endures. Yet their utmost virtue flows unseen, and in daily use, it goes unnoticed. This explains why making the world mutually forget oneself is difficult.

【10】【Annotation】Lost in rivers and lakes, one then longs for a moistening drop.

【Commentary】*Da xi* means to sigh deeply. If those whose virtue equals Yao and Shun can yet forget and refrain from self-display, how could they sigh over *ren* and filial piety or lament over mere traces?

【11】【Commentary】*Ti* means deference. *De* is true nature. These eight matters above—filial piety, brotherly respect, *ren*, rightness, loyalty, trust, integrity, and incorruptibility—are all contrived emotions that strain one’s nature, forced efforts that abandon the self to imitate others, laboring and enslaving one’s inherent power. Thus, they are not worthy of esteem.

【12】【Annotation】*Bing* means to cast aside. If what is noble lies in oneself, and one forgets even oneself, how much more so titles and ranks! This is the utmost nobility.

【Commentary】*Bing* means to cast aside. Those who value titles and ranks do so for the sake of the self. If one forgets even the self, how much more so titles and ranks! This is the utmost nobility.

【13】【Annotation】The utmost wealth lies in self-sufficiency alone; thus, one casts aside the riches of the world.

【Commentary】The utmost wealth belongs to those who know contentment. For one who knows contentment, non-greed is their treasure—even if the wealth of a kingdom were poured before them, they would cast it aside and make no use of it. Thus, the *Laozi* says, "One who knows contentment is rich." This is what is meant here.

【14】【Annotation】The ultimate fulfillment is attunement; when attunement is attained, the names of *ren* and filial piety all depart.

【Commentary】The ultimate fulfillment is nothing other than attunement to one’s nature. Once one levels praise and blame, merges honor and disgrace, forgets self and other, and dissolves right and wrong, then fame and reputation are seen as mere spittle.

【15】【Annotation】This is because one discards the ornamental and takes the real.

【Commentary】*Yu* means change or diminution. Having forgotten wealth and rank and relinquished fame and reputation, one’s virtue and power become pure and thick, no longer shifting with external things.

【Textual Note】*Qu hua* ("discard the ornamental") is read as *qǐ lǚ* in the *Shiwen*.

【Collation】The *Shide Tang* edition has *yi* ("already") where the received text has *ěr* ("ear").

---

Beimen Cheng asked the Yellow Emperor, saying: "When Your Majesty performed the music of *Xianchi* in the wilds of *Dongting*, at first I heard it and was afraid; upon hearing it again, I grew weary; and when I heard it to the end, I was bewildered. Vacant and silent, I could no longer find myself."

【1】【Commentary】Beimen was his surname, Cheng his given name—he was a minister of the Yellow Emperor. To clarify the Dao of utmost joy, the text introduces these two figures to set forth the exchange. *Xianchi* is the name of the music. *Zhang* means to perform. *Xian* means harmony. *Dongting* refers to the space between Heaven and Earth, not the Dongting Lake of Taihu.

【Textual Note】*Beimen Cheng* is a personal name. *Dongting* is read as *tú sòng*.

【2】【Commentary】*Dai* means to recede. *Zu* means to end. *Fu* means again. *Huo* means darkness. Not yet awakened to the utmost joy, at first hearing, he was startled and fearful; upon hearing the sound a second time, he gradually grasped its purport, and thus his fear receded; when he heard it to the end, he understood that the utmost joy harmonizes with the virtue of the Two Modes, seen but not visible, heard but not audible—thus his mind, devoid of distinctions, became like one in darkness.

【Textual Note】*Zhi ju* is read as written, or as *jù* (alternate pronunciation below). One edition has *jué*, read as *kuàng fù*. According to the *Shuowen*, *ju* is the standard character, *jué* the ancient form. ◎Lu Wenchang notes: The *Shuowen* has *sǒng* as the ancient form of *ju*, and *sǒng* (same as *sǒng*, "to tower") is not a variant of *ju*. There is no *jué* character in the text. It is unclear what edition Master Lu consulted. *Fu wen* is read as *fú yòu*.

【3】【Annotation】"Could no longer find myself" refers to *zuowang* (sitting in forgetfulness).

【Commentary】*Dangdang* describes an even and unobstructed bearing. *Momo* depicts a state of unknowing. Upon the third hearing, he embodied and awakened to the mysterious principle—thus he was *dangdang* without bias, *momo* without knowledge, and in a state of *zuowang*, where self and other were both lost, he could no longer find himself.

The Emperor said: "You were nearly correct! I performed it with human affairs, verified it with Heaven, enacted it with ritual propriety, and established it with Great Purity.

【1】【Annotation】From this we know that the utmost joy is not a matter of sounds and tones. It must first accord with Heaven, respond to humanity, be realized in the heart and attuned to one’s nature, and only then be expressed in sound and performed in melody. Thus, the music of *Xianchi* could only be completed after the transformation wrought by the Yellow Emperor.

【Commentary】*Dai* means "nearly." *Zou* means "to respond."

The utmost joy first responds to human affairs, follows the patterns of Heaven, is enacted through the Five Virtues, and corresponds to spontaneity. Only then does it harmonize the four seasons and bring the myriad things to perfect harmony.

The four seasons arise in succession, the myriad things follow their birth; now flourishing, now declining, the warp of civil and martial order unfolds. Now clear, now turbid, yin and yang harmonize, and their radiance flows forth in sound.

Hibernating creatures begin to stir, and I startle them with thunder. Its end has no tail, its beginning no head. Now dying, now living; now collapsing, now rising. Its constancy is inexhaustible, yet it cannot be awaited. This is why you were afraid."

"‘*Hui*’ means ‘to accord.’ Ritual and righteousness are the Five Virtues. The Great Purity is the Dao of Heaven. After the Yellow Emperor truly heard the third movement of *Beimen Cheng*, he embodied and awakened to the mysterious Dao, forgetting knowledge and stilling thoughts. Thus, I approved of his understanding, saying, ‘You nearly accord with spontaneity.’"

Though one may follow the traces of ritual and righteousness, one forgets the root of spontaneity. This is the first movement.

"To follow is to accord; *lun* is principle; *jing* is constancy. The four seasons arise in succession, and all things follow their ordered birth. Summer flourishes, winter declines; spring is civil, autumn martial—the principles of generation and destruction are the constancy of Heaven’s Dao. Simply abiding by this is the utmost joy."

Spontaneity’s pitch-pipes fill the space between Heaven and Earth. One must only accord without seizing, and the utmost joy is complete.

"Purity is Heaven; turbidity is Earth. Yin ascends, yang descends, and the two qi harmonize. Thus, the myriad things are born, harmonious qi flows forth, and the Three Luminaries illuminate all—this is the utmost joy, the soundless sound."

I further attuned it to the harmony of yin and yang, illumined it with the brightness of sun and moon. Its sound could be short or long, soft or firm; its transformations uniform, unbound by fixed norms. In valleys, it filled valleys; in hollows, it filled hollows. It sealed off and guarded the spirit, taking things as its measure. Its sound soared and resounded, its name lofty and luminous. Thus, ghosts and spirits guarded their hidden realms, while sun, moon, and stars followed their courses. I halted it at the bounded, flowed it into the boundless. I wished to ponder it but could not know it, to gaze upon it but could not see it, to pursue it but could not reach it. Suddenly, I stood on the Way of the fourfold void, leaning against a withered catalpa, chanting. My eyes’ knowledge was exhausted by what they longed to see, my strength spent by what they longed to pursue—I could not attain it! My form filled the emptiness, even to the point of meandering. You meandered, and thus grew weary."

The Way that pervades all living things shines with a brilliance equal to the sun and moon. This is the second performance.

It unifies all in transformation, thus not clinging to fixed constancy.

It follows the long and short of all beings, accords with the soft and hard of the myriad things, and equalizes the principle of change—how could it guard the old and grasp the constant!

The Way of perfect joy leaves nothing untouched.

The Way of perfect joy pervades all without exception, filling valleys and hollows alike. This is what is meant by "the Dao is nowhere absent, yet wherever it is, there is nothing."

Seal off its apertures.

Close the gates of the heart’s knowing, guard the spirit in its serene stillness.

Great regulation does not sever.

In great and small, long and short, it follows the measure of things, never imposing its own divisions.

This is called "unfolding harmony."

It moves like thunder’s quaking, its sound vast and expansive.

Its name matches its reality, thus it is lofty and luminous.

High as the heavens above, bright as the sun and moon, its sound vast and great, its name likewise lofty and luminous.

It does not depart from its place.

Beings dwell in their brightness, ghosts and spirits guard their hidden realms—each attains its proper place without disturbance. Thus the *Laozi* says: "When the Dao benefits all under heaven, ghosts do not act as spirits."

It does not lose its measure.

The Three Luminaries shine forth, following their allotted paths; the net of the highest mystery is never in error.

It ever abides at the utmost.

Though it undergoes a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, it ever dwells at the mysterious summit, never departing from the wondrous root—active yet ever still.

It flows in response to change.

It moves with the ceaseless flux, adapting to each moment without clinging, thus still yet ever in motion.

Thus it darkly lets transformations proceed.

The perfect joy is the true Dao. To clarify that the Dao is not an object of the heart’s knowing, one may ponder it yet never know it; the Dao is not sound or form, thus one may gaze upon it yet never see it; the Dao is not material shape, thus one may pursue it yet never reach it.

This is called "vast and open without partiality."

Suddenly, one stands on the Way of the fourfold void.

Vast and open, impartial in its embrace, the sage, free of self, becomes one with perfect joy. With a mind as boundless as the Dao, they meet all things without bias, encompassing the ten thousand beings and uniting in virtue with the empty void.

Exhausted is the eye’s knowing by what it longs to see, spent the strength by what it longs to pursue—I could not attain it!

The knowing and strength of things each have their limits. The eye’s knowing has its bounds, thus it is exhausted; the strength’s pursuit has its measure, thus it is spent. Perfect joy is not a matter of heart or form, and cannot be bounded by limits. Thus I knew my efforts were in vain and ceased my pursuit. The heart, being limited, knows only its love for the nameless. This repeats the earlier passage on "I wished to ponder it..."

The body fills the empty void, becoming formless—formless, thus it can be supple and yielding. Supple and yielding, following nature, the emotions of dread and fear fade away.

The body fills the void, thus equaling the void in measure; supple and yielding, following nature, it accords with the ten thousand things without attachment—this is what is meant by "dissolving the body, dulling the senses, departing from form, and forsaking knowledge." Only by being supple and yielding, following nature, do the emotions of dread and fear cease. This explains the second hearing of the music.

I then played for him music without weariness, attuned to the mandate of nature. Thus it seemed to blend and surge forth in clusters, a forest of music yet without form; it spread and waved without trailing, deep and obscure yet without sound. It moved without fixed direction, abided in profound darkness. Some called it death, some called it life; some called it substance, some called it glory. Flowing and scattering, shifting without end, it did not adhere to any constant sound. The world doubted it and turned to the sage for inquiry.

The sage is one who penetrates to the truth of things and fulfills the mandate of nature. The celestial mechanism is not set in motion, yet the five senses are all complete—this is called the music of heaven, which speaks no words yet delights the heart. Thus the Divine Flame Clan composed this ode:

*"Hear it yet hear no sound,
See it yet see no form,
Filling heaven and earth,
Enveloping the six directions."*

You wish to hear it yet find no point of contact—thus you remain perplexed.

The mind, already weary, is met with music without weariness—this is its perfection.

Having heard the perfect music, yielding and following nature, the heart’s dread and fear fade away. Though this surpasses the first hearing, it still falls short of what comes after. Thus the music without weariness is played—dispelling weariness with the absence of weariness. As Guo’s commentary states: "The mind, already weary, is met with the absence of weariness—this is its perfection." This is the third playing.

The mandate inherent in all things is not a matter of human artifice—it is all natural. To attune is to harmonize. All living beings take nature as their mandate. Thus, in playing this music of the Pool of Harmony, one seeks to harmonize the spirit of creation and attune to the natural mandate of all things.

Blending without attachment, it arises with the clusters. It moves as one with the stirring of the wind, rising with the sounds of the forest groves.

The perfect music is simply fitting—fitting within the body, thus it has no separate form.

The sounds of the forest groves and the earth’s pipes arise without intention, forming perfect music that merely accords with nature—how could it have form?

It spreads of itself. It stirs the four seasons, disperses the ten thousand things, each finding its place—not by force or trailing.

This is the so-called perfect music. The perfect music is tranquil and transcends sight and sound, thus it is deep, obscure, and silent.

Master Jia Shifu says: *"The* Shuowen *defines clustered trees as a forest. 'Forest of music' means to rejoice together in a multitude. The five notes intermingle, and one cannot discern from whence the sounds arise—thus it is said to be without form. To 'spread and wave' is to shake and raise, like cloth unfurling without end, yet there is no one to trail it. 'Forest of music without form'—its sounds converge; 'spreading and waving without trailing'—its sounds linger; 'deep and obscure without sound'—its sounds are subtle."*

Does that which moves require a fixed direction before it moves?

Though the root of perfect music is soundless, its responses move with the times, truly without fixed direction—this is stillness in motion.

This is the so-called "tranquil extremity." Though it responds to things and adapts to circumstances, transforming endlessly, its deep root remains in tranquil extremity, ever abiding in profound darkness—this is motion in stillness.

It changes with the transformations of things. Spring gives birth, winter brings death; autumn bears fruit, summer flourishes. Clouds move, rain scatters; water flows, winds follow—the principle of nature renews itself daily in change. How could the Way of perfect music adhere to a constant sound?

The world doubts it and turns to the sage for inquiry. The sage, like the echo in a deep valley or the reflection in a bright mirror, responds to things without knowing whence they come, ceases with them without knowing whither they go. Things come, and the sage responds, responding yet forgetting all—how could they preemptively devise methods or fix their minds on responding to the world? Thus, flowing and scattering, shifting without end, not adhering to any constant sound, the world’s people are deluded and perplexed.

The sage is one who penetrates to the truth of things and fulfills the mandate of nature—thus all beings, with their truths and mandates, depend on them.

The virtue of forgetting joy is itself joy’s fulfillment—it is not prepared through deliberate effort.

The celestial mechanism is the pivot of nature. The five officials are the five viscera. Each of the five viscera has its governing office, hence they are called "officials." The eye sees, the ear hears, the hand grasps, the foot walks—spreading nets, rolling pellets, flying through the sky, running on the earth—none of this arises from imitation, but is endowed by the Creator. How could one need to apply the mind before being able to act! Thus, the offices of the five viscera are inherently complete, and the beauty of celestial joy lies precisely here.

Joy resides in harmony, not in words.

Embodying this celestial harmony does not depend on deliberate effort, so the spirit finds delight in a subtlety beyond all description.

This is joy without joy—the ultimate joy.

Yan Shi (Shennong) praised this supreme joy in his hymns. The great sound is soundless, so it cannot be heard when listened for; the great image is formless, so it cannot be seen when looked for. The Dao is present everywhere, filling heaven and earth; the great encompasses all, embracing the six directions. The six directions are the six directions of space. Even if one were to strain to listen, it cannot be grasped by the ear—thus, embodying this supreme joy, its principle is profound and subtle. The mind makes no distinctions, and the matter appears as foolish confusion.

The *Baoguo* is pronounced *bao*. Some versions write it as *bao*.

Joy begins with fear—fear gives rise to misfortune.
Next comes indolence—indolence leads to retreat.
Finally, there is confusion—confusion results in foolishness.
Foolishness gives way to the Dao, which can be borne and journeyed with as one.

**Annotations:**
Fearful listening breeds misfortune, for it is not yet great harmony.
**Commentary:** Below, the meaning of the three performances and three hearings is further expounded, culminating in the Dao of supreme joy. At first, upon hearing the supreme joy, one fails to grasp the great harmony, and the heart is filled with dread, unable to let go—thus inviting misfortune.

**Annotations:**
Retreat marks the fading of traces.
**Commentary:** After hearing it again, the mind begins to awaken, and the fear recedes into indolence, its traces vanishing.

**Annotations:**
Foolishness is ignorance taken to its limit.
**Commentary:** Upon hearing it at last, the spirit becomes pure and harmonious, the heart free of distinctions, akin to darkness and confusion—vast and silent, like one lost in stupidity. Neither indolent nor fearful, it aligns with the true Dao, carried effortlessly and arriving with all things.

Confucius traveled west to Wei. Yan Yuan asked Shi Jin, “What do you make of the Master’s conduct?”

From Lu to Wei is westward, hence called a "western journey." Shi Jin was the Grand Music Master of Lu, named Jin. *Xī* means "what." He asks whether the Master’s practice of the Way of benevolence and righteousness to transform the Lord of Wei will succeed or not.

**Shi Jin said, "Alas! Your Master will meet with misfortune!"**

**Annotations:**
The Master, wise and discerning, is a pity—clinging to the sagely traces of former kings and upholding the ancient Way of Yao and Shun, he repeatedly endures hardship and meets with adversity.

**Yan Yuan said, "Why?"**

**Annotations:**
He asks why he will meet with misfortune.

**Shi Jin said, "Before the straw dog is set out, it is stored in a bamboo box, wrapped in an embroidered cloth, and the invocator fasts and purifies himself to present it. Once it has been set out, passersby trample its head and spine, and gatherers take it to burn for fuel. If one were to take it again, store it in a bamboo box, wrap it in an embroidered cloth, and wander or rest beneath it, even if one did not dream, one would surely suffer from dust in the eyes. Now your Master has taken the already-used straw dogs of former kings, gathered his disciples to wander and rest beneath them. Thus he was barred from felling trees in Song, erased his traces in Wei, met with hardship in Shang and Zhou—was this not like a dream? Besieged between Chen and Cai, seven days without cooked food, life and death as close as neighbors—was this not like dust in the eyes?**

**Annotations:**
The following six analogies are given: first, the straw dog; second, the boat and cart; third, the well-sweep; fourth, the wild pear and plum; fifth, the ape; sixth, beauty and ugliness.
The *chúgǒu* is made of grass, fashioned into a dog for exorcism. *Yǎn* is a bamboo container. The *shīzhù* are shamans. *Jiāng* means "to send off." Before the straw dog is set out, it is stored in a bamboo container, covered with an embroidered cloth, and purified with fasting to show sincerity. It is sent off as if it were present, in hopes of blessing—so highly is it valued.

The *qiè* is pronounced *kǔ dié* (苦牒); some versions write it as *kuāng* (筐). The *yǎn* is pronounced *yán shàn* (延善), or *guō yí* (郭怡) in Guo’s reading. Li says: "A bamboo container, the vessel for holding the straw dog." Sima says: "To join together." ◎Qing Fan notes: The character *jīn* (巾, cloth) is likely a scribal error for *shì* (饰, adornment). The *Taiping Yulan* quotes the *Huainanzi*: "Wrapped in patterned silk as adornment."

**Second Section**
**Annotation:** When discarded things are of no further use, they invite other misfortunes.
**Exegesis:** *Jiàn* means to tread. *Shǒu* is the head. *Jǐ* is the back. *Sū* refers to gathering grass. *Cuàn* means to cook. *Mī* means to be haunted. Before the straw dog is set out, it is treated with solemn reverence. After the ritual, it is cast aside on the road, where passersby trample its head and back, and gatherers take it for kindling. Yet when it is once more esteemed, placed in a bamboo container, covered with embroidered cloth, carried in processions, or kept by one’s side for sleep—even if it does not bring nightmares, it will surely cause repeated hauntings. Thus Guo’s annotation states: "When discarded things are of no further use, they invite other misfortunes."

**Philological Notes:**
*Sū zhě*: Li says: "Sū means grass; those who gather grass use it for cooking." The *Fangyan* states: "In the regions of Jiang, Huai, and southern Chu, it is called *sū*." The *Records of the Grand Historian* says: "They gathered firewood and grass for cooking," with the note: "Sū means to gather grass."
*Cuàn zhī*: Pronounced *qī wán* (七丸).
*Jiāng fù*: Pronounced *fú yòu* (扶又).
*Bì qiě*: Read as written, or *xú* (徐) reads it as *zǐ yú* (子余).
*Shuò*: Pronounced *shuò* (朔).
*Mī*: Li pronounces it *mǐ* (米), or *měi* (美). The *Zilin* says: "An ailment caused by something entering the eye." Sima says: "To be oppressed," pronounced *yì yǎn* (一琰).

**Third Section**
**Exegesis:** This analogy of the straw dog corresponds to Confucius’ hardships. The former kings—Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang—were the ancient sovereigns. Following the models of Wen and Wu, they took Yao and Shun as their ancestors and established teachings. Thus they gathered disciples, roamed in the realm of benevolence and righteousness, and rested in the land of ritual and trust. Yet the ancient ways cannot be clung to; the matter is like the already-used straw dog. The incident of felling the tree in Song: Confucius once traveled to Song, where he discoursed with his disciples beneath a great tree. Sima Huan Tui sought to kill the Master, and after Confucius departed, Huan Tui, resenting the place where he had sat, had the tree cut down. *Xuē* means to erase. The Master also traveled to Wei, where the people despised him and thus erased his traces, leaving him without employment. Shang was the land of Yin, and Zhou was the Eastern Zhou; Confucius journeyed through both and was once besieged there. All this suffering arose from clinging to sagely traces. Such distress—was it not like a nightmare?

◎ Yu Yue states: The first *qu* (取) is to be read as its usual sense, while the second *qu* should be read as *ju* (聚). The *Cui* Hexagram’s *Xiang Zhuan* in the *Zhouyi* says, “Gathering (*ju*) is through rectitude,” and the *Shiwen* notes: “*Ju* is written as *qu* in Xun’s version.” The *Book of Han’s* “Treatise on the Five Phases” reads, “Internally *qu* (*ju*) this,” and Yan Shigu comments: “*Qu* is to be read as *ju* in the *Liji*’s ‘Gathering the Doe.’” Thus, *ju* and *qu* were interchangeable in antiquity.

【Four】【Annotation】This all conveys the meaning of “cutting off sageliness and discarding knowledge,” with no room for hesitation. The rites of the former kings were meant to suit their times. When the time has passed and they are not abandoned, they become portents for the people, giving rise to the beginnings of forced imitation.

【Exegesis】At that time, King Zhao of Chu invited the Master, who led his disciples to lodge in the lands of Chen and Cai. The people of Cai, seeing the great number of followers, took them for bandits and thus raised troops to besiege them. For seven days, their provisions were exhausted, no cooking fires could be lit, and the disciples, starving and ill, could not rise. Distressed and sorrowful, they were nearly brought to death—was this not suffering from clinging to the already-used straw dog, as if trapped in a nightmare?

The best way to travel on water is by boat, and the best way to travel on land is by cart. If, because a boat can traverse water, one seeks to push it on land, then even after a lifetime it will not advance a few feet. 【One】Is not the distinction between past and present like that between water and land? Are not Zhou and Lu like boat and cart? Now, to seek to implement Zhou’s ways in Lu is like pushing a boat on land—【Two】laborious yet fruitless, and one will surely bring calamity upon oneself. They did not understand the transmission of the boundless Dao, which responds to things without exhaustion. 【Three】

【One】【Exegesis】A boat travels on water, a cart on land; even a thousand *li* is not difficult. But if one pushes a boat on land, seeking to transport goods, then even after a lifetime it will not advance a few feet.

【Textual Note】*Tuī zhī* (推之): Guo reads *tu* as *tui* (吐回反), also as the usual pronunciation. The same applies below.

【Two】【Exegesis】This is a metaphor. *Qí* means “to seek.” The past and present differ—is this not like the distinction between water and land? Zhou and Lu are different lands—how are they not like boat and cart?

【Textual Note】*Lù yǔ* (陆与): Pronounced *yú* (余). The same applies below.

《今蕲》: Pronounced *qí*, meaning "to seek."

【Three】【Commentary】As times change and generations differ, rites must also adapt. Thus, one should respond to things without attachment—this is how effort yields success.

【Exegesis】*Fāng* means "constant." *Zhuàn* means "to turn." Confucius clung to the traces of the former kings while living in the declining Zhou era, exhausting his mind and strength to no avail.
