Thus, he was stripped of his position and his tree felled, bringing misfortune upon himself. The wisdom of the sage is boundless, turning and transforming in endless ways to respond to the moment. Not understanding this Dao, he suffered such calamity.

【Textual Note】*Wú fāng zhī zhuàn*: Pronounced *zhí zhuān* (直专反), with the same pronunciation in the commentary below. Sima [Qian] says: *fāng* means "constant." ◎Qingfan’s note: *Zhuàn* should be read as *zhuǎn* (转), meaning "unrestrained turning." *Lǚ shì chūn qiū* ("The Annals of Lü Buwei"), *Bì jǐ* chapter: "As for the nature of the myriad things and the transmission of human relations," Gao’s commentary: *zhuàn* means "to turn." *Hàn shū* ("Book of Han"), *Liú Xiàng zhuàn*: "Yu, Qi, and Gao Yao mutually drew upon one another," meaning they turned to one another for support. *Huái nán zǐ*, *Zhǔ shù* chapter: "In life, one lacks nothing; in death, the corpse does not turn," while the *Yì Zhōu shū*, *Dà jù* chapter writes it as *zhuàn shī* (传尸). *Zuǒ zhuàn* commentary on the 25th year of Duke Xiang: "A copying error," with the *Shì wén* noting: *zhuàn* is written as *zhuǎn* in another version.

Have you not seen the well-sweep? When pulled, it bows; when released, it rises. It is drawn by others, not drawing others—thus, it bows and rises without offending anyone.

【One】Therefore, the rites, righteousness, laws, and institutions of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors were not prized for uniformity but for their efficacy in governance.

【Two】【Commentary】The aim is to suit the times and respond to the needs of governance.

【Exegesis】*Jīn* means "to prize." The Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors lived in different eras, and their rites, music, and ceremonies were not passed down unchanged. Their excellence lay in adapting to the moment, not in rigid adherence. They did not value blindly following the present to match the past.

【Textual Note】*Yú zhì*: Pronounced *zhí* (直吏反), with the same pronunciation in the commentary.

【Three】【Exegesis】The crabapple, pear, orange, and pomelo differ in taste, yet all are pleasing to the mouth. Likewise, the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors governed in eras of varying simplicity and decadence, yet all adapted to the needs of their time.

【Textual Note】*Zhā*: Pronounced *cè jiā* (侧加反). *Yòu*: Pronounced *yóu jiù* (由救反).

Thus, rites, righteousness, laws, and institutions are things that change with the times.

【One】【Commentary】What one deems beautiful, another may deem ugly. Therefore, they must adapt to the times to be universally fitting.

【Exegesis】The standards of the sage-kings are not fixed. They change with the times and cannot be rigidly adhered to. How can one cling to the past while living in the present, like tuning a zither with fixed pegs or carving a mark on a moving boat?

【Two】【Exegesis】*Qiè* means "satisfied." The Duke of Zhou represents a sage of a pure and ancient era, while the cunning ape symbolizes a decadent and competitive age.

If you take an ape and dress it in the robes of the Duke of Zhou, it will gnaw, tear, and rip them off until they are completely removed and it is satisfied. The difference between past and present is like the difference between an ape and the Duke of Zhou.

【Three】When Xishi clutched her chest in pain, the ugly women of her village saw her and admired her. They returned home and also clutched their chests in imitation. The rich people of the village, seeing this, firmly shut their doors and refused to go out, while the poor people took their wives and children and fled.

【Four】They knew that clutching the chest was beautiful but did not understand *why* it was beautiful.

【Five】Alas, how unfortunate that the Master met with such misfortune!

Thus, though ritual robes may be resplendent, apes and monkeys do not deem them beautiful; though the sagely legacy be noble, later ages do not hold it in esteem. Only when ritual robes are cast aside do apes and monkeys find contentment in their hearts; only when the sagely legacy is abandoned do the common people at last suit their nature.

---

【Three】Xishi was a beauty of Yue, her appearance surpassing in loveliness. When stricken with heart pain, she knit her brows in distress. Yet those of refined bearing, their forms naturally graceful, only grew more radiant in their frowns. Thus, when the women of her village saw her, they cherished her all the more. The ugly women of the neighborhood, seeing this, imitated her, forcing frowns though they were not ill, only doubling their ugliness. Therefore, the wealthy shut their doors and refused to emerge, while the poor took their wives and children and fled. To forsake one’s own nature and mimic others—such is the pattern of this folly. The felling of trees and erasure of footprints are all errors born of imitating a frown.

---

【Four】Moreover, with rites and rightness: when applied in their proper time, they are like Xishi; when clung to past their time, they become like the ugly women.

The reason her frown was beautiful lay in Xishi’s innate loveliness. Those ugly women, however, admired only the elegance of the frown, not understanding it arose from Xishi’s natural beauty.

---

【Five】In summary of what follows, this passage completes its meaning. The circumstances of the Master’s misfortune are fully set forth in this chapter.

【Collation】(1) The Zhao Advisor’s edition omits "Moreover" and the two instances of "then."

At fifty-one years of age, Confucius had yet to hear the Dao, so he journeyed south to Pei to visit Lao Dan. (1)
(1) *Subcommentary*: Though Confucius led three thousand disciples and was called the Uncrowned King, his cultivation of the Five Virtues had not yet granted him knowledge of the Great Dao. Thus, he traveled from Lu to Pei, journeying from north to south to meet the Old Master and inquire into the profound mysteries.

*Exegesis*: "To Pei" is pronounced *bei*. Sima [Qian] states: Laozi was a minister of the state of Chen. Chen corresponds to present-day Ku County, which borders Pei.

Lao Dan said: "Have you come? I have heard of you—you are a worthy man of the north. Have you attained the Dao?"
Confucius replied: "I have not."
(1) *Subcommentary*: [Laozi] had heard that Confucius was a worthy of the age but did not know whether he had grasped the ultimate Dao. Confucius answered that he had not. Since he gazed from Chu toward Lu, [Laozi] called him a northerner.

Lao Dan said: "How have you sought it?" (1)
(1) *Subcommentary*: He asked, "Where have you sought the ultimate Dao?"

*Exegesis*: "How" is pronounced *wu*; same below.

Confucius said: "I sought it in measures and calculations, but after five years I had not attained it." (1)
(1) *Subcommentary*: *Calculations* refers to arithmetic. A intercalary month every three years completes the lesser cycle of the celestial Dao; five years with two intercalary months completes the greater cycle. Thus, he spoke of five years. The Dao is not a matter of calculations, so he did not attain it.

Lao Dan said: "How else have you sought it?" (1)
(1) *Subcommentary*: He further asked, "What method have you used to seek the Dao?"

Confucius said: "I sought it in yin and yang, but after twelve years I had not attained it." (1)
(1) *Commentary*: This is all an allegory by which [Zhuangzi] uses Confucius and Laozi to illustrate the meaning of lost learning.
*Subcommentary*: Twelve years constitute one full cycle of yin and yang. That he had not attained it shows that while the Dao may be approached through yin and yang, it is not itself yin and yang. Thus, the text below states: "There is a man in the Central Kingdom who is neither yin nor yang."

Lao Dan said: "Indeed. If the Dao could be presented as an offering, none would fail to offer it to their lord. If the Dao could be advanced, none would fail to advance it to their kin. If the Dao could be told to others, none would fail to tell it to their brothers. If the Dao could be given to others, none would fail to give it to their descendants. Yet it cannot be so—there is no other reason: (1) if there is no host within, it does not abide; (2) if there is no rectitude without, it does not proceed. (3) What issues from within is not received from without—thus the sage does not emerge. (4) What enters from without finds no host within—thus the sage does not conceal. (5) Fame is a public instrument—it cannot be taken in excess. (6) Benevolence and righteousness are the travelers’ lodges of the former kings—(7) one may stay a single night but cannot dwell there long; (8) to encounter them is to incur many reproaches.

(1) *Subcommentary*: The ultimate Dao is profoundly mysterious, transcending speech and form, neither existent nor non-existent, neither self nor other. Thus, it cannot be advanced to lord or kin, nor can it be told to siblings or disciples. The reason lies in nothing else: it is an allegory using the two sages, Confucius and Laozi, to clarify the mystery within the mystery.

(2) *Commentary*: If the heart lacks the capacity to receive the Dao, even hearing it will cause it to pass by.

(3) *Commentary*: Without a host within, external things also lack anything to rectify the self, and thus it never penetrates.
*Subcommentary*: Since there is no heart within to receive the Dao, there is also nothing without to rectify the self, and thus it cannot proceed.
◎ Yu Yue notes: *Rectitude* is a corruption of *match*. In the *Ziyi* chapter of the *Book of Rites*, "Only the gentleman can love his *match*," Zheng Xuan’s commentary states: "*Match* should be *rectitude*—a scribal error." This is a case in point. Here, it should read: "If there is no host within, it does not abide; if there is no match without, it does not proceed." This aligns with the *Gongyang Commentary* on Duke Xuan’s third year: "What issues from within has no match and does not proceed; what arrives from without has no host and does not abide." What arrives from without has no host and does not abide—thus this passage says, "If there is no host within, it does not abide." What issues from within has no match and does not proceed—thus this passage says, "If there is no match without, it does not proceed." Due to *match* being corrupted into *rectitude*, Guo’s commentary explains it as "rectifying the self," which is entirely mistaken. In the "Ze Yang" chapter, "What enters from without has a host and is not grasped; what issues from within has a match and is not resisted"—*match* should also be *rectitude*, the same error as here.

(4) *Commentary*: What issues from within is the Dao of the sage; it emerges only when there is one without capable of receiving it.
*Subcommentary*: *Issues from* means "comes forth from." What comes forth from within refers to the sage’s manifesting traces and teachings. Only when beings are moved by the sage does the sage respond and manifest. If external beings cannot receive it, the sage ultimately does not emerge to teach.

(5) *Commentary*: What enters from without is the cultivation of nature through learning. Though nature may be perfected through learning, it fundamentally requires an inner capacity. Without a host within, there is nothing to contain the sagely Dao.
*Subcommentary*: *Conceal* means "to store." What enters from without refers to the cultivation of nature through learning. Since it is received from without, it should reside in the heart. If there is no heart to receive it, the sagely Dao cannot be stored.
◎ Jia Shifu notes: "What issues from within is to follow one’s settled heart."

Those who learn by taking in from without absorb the words of a single master, delighting privately in their warmth and intimacy. If one follows their settled heart, then what comes from without cannot be received, and the sage cannot emerge to force them to accept it. If one learns the words of a single master and delights in them privately, then there is nothing within to serve as a host, and the sage cannot conceal himself in their heart to become their master.

*Commentary*: Names are what the world shares in common.
*Subcommentary*: *Name* means "to call out." *Public* means "impartial." *Vessel* means "use." There are two kinds of names: one is for designating things, the other for praise and blame. What is spoken of here is the name of praise and blame.
*Exegesis*: The *Explanation of Names* states: *Name* means "to call out." *Public* means "impartial." *Vessel* means "use." The *Master Yinwen* says: Names have three categories: first, names for designating things, such as square and round; second, names of praise and blame, such as good and evil; third, names of comparison and analogy, such as love and hate. What is discussed here is the name of praise and blame.

*Commentary*: To embellish beyond reality is to take excessively, and excessive taking brings chaos to the world.
*Subcommentary*: When fine reputations and good names are shared by the world, if one takes excessively, embellishment surpasses reality, and contention arises.

*Commentary*: Like a travelers’ lodge.
*Exegesis*: *Qū* is pronounced like *qú*. Sima and Guo explain: *Qū-lú* is like a travelers’ lodge.

*Commentary*: Benevolence and righteousness are human nature. Human nature changes, differing between ancient and modern times. Thus, when one wanders and passes through, it remains obscure; if one lingers and clings to one place, it becomes manifest. When it becomes manifest, artifice arises, and with artifice, excessive demands follow.
*Subcommentary*: *Qū-lú* is a travelers’ lodge. *Gòu* means "to see" or "to linger." A travelers’ lodge cannot be stayed in for long; benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and wisdom should be set aside once used. If a guest lingers too long, faults and flaws arise; if sagely traces remain, excessive demands follow.
*Exegesis*: *Gòu* is pronounced *gǔ* in the ancient tone, meaning "to see" or "to encounter."

The perfected ones of antiquity borrowed the Way of benevolence and lodged in righteousness, roaming in the emptiness of carefree wandering, feeding in the fields of simplicity, and standing in the garden of non-transaction. *Carefree wandering* means "non-action"; *simplicity* means "easy to nurture"; *non-transaction* means "nothing to give out." The ancients called this the wandering of gathering authenticity.

*Commentary*: Adapting to the times and changing without fixed traces.
*Subcommentary*: The true persons of antiquity harmonized their light and descended in traces, acting in accord with the moment and practicing universal love, responding to things and employing the multitude—how was this different from borrowing a path or lodging temporarily? Though their sojourn was brief, it was not real. Yet in movement they did not harm stillness, and in response they did not depart from the real. Thus, they ever roamed in the realm of self-contentment, wandering in the realm of non-action.
*Exegesis*: *Zhī xū* is pronounced *xū*. The original text also writes it as *xū* (mound).

Though it be provisional and simple, *gou-jian* means "temporary and unadorned." *Dai* means "to bestow." Knowing when to stop and when one has enough, one feeds from the fields of the provisional and simple; not diminishing one’s own possessions, one stands in the garden of non-transaction. Speaking of fields and gardens is to clarify that these are the grounds where the sages nurture life.

*Exegesis*: *Gou-jian*: Wang [Bi] says: *Gou* means "provisional," *jian* means "simple." The Sima edition writes *jian* as *xian*, glossing it as "to distinguish." ◎ Qingfan’s note: *Jian* in the Sima edition is written as *xian*. Note that *xian* and *jian* are the same. The *Huainanzi*’s *Yaolüe* chapter states: "Thus, moderating wealth and practicing frugal burials, one nurtures life in *xian* service" (*xian-fu* means "simple service"; *xian-fu* refers to the three-month mourning period). The *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on Pan Anren’s "Dirge for Attendant Gentleman Xiahou" and the *Lu Shi*’s *Hou Ji* both quote the *Huainanzi* as *jian-fu*. *Bu dai*: Pronounced *chì-dài*. Sima [Biao] says: "To bestow." *Zhi pu*: Pronounced *bǔ*.

*Commentary*: To act is to depart from humaneness and rightness.

*Commentary*: Since one follows simplicity, it is easy to nurture.

*Subcommentary*: Only because the encumbrances of carefree wandering are exhausted can one be without action and serene. *Gou-jian* means "provisional and simple," contenting oneself with sufficiency—thus, it is easy to nurture.

*Exegesis*: *Yi yang*: Pronounced *yì-chǐ*. The commentary is the same.

**【Six】**
*Commentary*: "Does not bestow" means not diminishing oneself for the sake of others.

*Subcommentary*: Not diminishing oneself to benefit another—thus, nothing is given. These three lines reiterate the preceding meaning.

*Exegesis*: *To make into things*: Pronounced *yú-wěi*.

**【Seven】**
*Commentary*: Wandering freely and following one’s nature—this is true essence. When essence is true, color is not false.

*Subcommentary*: The ancients’ sages practiced provisional simplicity and such methods, for their spirit and essence were genuine and without pretense. They roamed carefree, following their inclinations and wandering with transformation.

*Collation*:
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition has *xū* (虚) as *qū* (墟).
(2) The Shidetang edition has *sī* (斯) as *zé* (则).
(3) *Essence and truth* follows the Shidetang edition’s emendation.

Those who deem wealth right cannot yield emolument;
those who deem prominence right cannot yield fame.
Those who cling to power cannot share authority.

Grasping it, they tremble;
releasing it, they grieve—
yet without a single mirror to perceive
what they never cease pursuing:
these are the people Heaven punishes.

Resentment and gratitude, taking and giving, admonition and instruction, life and death—
these eight are the instruments of rectification.
Only those who follow great change without obstruction can wield them.

Thus it is said: Rectitude is rectification.
If one’s heart holds otherwise,
the Gate of Heaven will not open.

(5)
[Note 1] Never has the world seen one burdened by what they deem wrong—each perishes only for what they deem right. Those who perish for what they deem right do not stand in the garden of inexhaustible bounty.

[Commentary] To esteem wealth and despise poverty, to covet goods and bribes—how could such a one yield emolument to others? To esteem prominence and despise obscurity, to cling to glory and rank—how could such a one yield fame to others? To cherish power and authority, to vaunt oneself over things—how could such a one share authority with others? Only those who loathe the stench of worldly dust, who find glory and profit rank and foul, can cast them aside like refuse.

[Note 2] Those who grieve when releasing it cannot but tremble when grasping it.

[Commentary] Grasping authority, they fear its loss and so tremble; relinquishing power, they mourn its departure and so grieve.

[Textual Note] *Cao zhi* (操之): read *qī dāo* (七刀反). *She zhi* (舍之): read *shě* (舍). The note shares the same reading.

[Note 3] To know advance but not retreat is to forfeit one’s nature and life—hence they are punished.

[Commentary] Those who esteem wealth and crave power are dull of heart and benighted, mired in fame and profit, utterly lacking discernment. How could they perceive the profound Dao and rest their minds, still their wit? Such people, though no executioner’s blade has touched them, are already bound by their own nature—thus they are the people Heaven punishes.

[Textual Note] *Sang* (丧): read *sàng* (息浪反).

[Commentary] Resentment demands vengeance, gratitude repayment; what is due must be taken, what is not due given; ministers admonish their lords, fathers instruct their sons; life follows the verdant spring, death and punishment the withered autumn. These eight are the instruments of rectification—one cannot but wield them.

[Note 5] Clinging to the old without change is to lose rectitude.

[Commentary] *Xún* (循) means to follow; *yīn* (湮), to obstruct. Only those who follow human principle, adapt to change, and penetrate the nature of things without obstruction can wield these eight to govern. Rectitude and change accord with Heaven’s principle—thus it is said: Rectitude is rectification. Those whose hearts cannot do so find the Gate of Heaven barred and shut. *Tianmen* (天门) is the heart.

[Textual Note] *Yīn zhe* (湮者): read *yīn* (因). Li [Yi] says: to obstruct, also to stagnate. Guo [Xiang] reads *yān* (烟) or *wù jié* (乌节反). Sima’s edition has *yīn* (歅), meaning doubt. [Wang] Jianwen’s edition has *zhēn* (甄), meaning to block. *Tianmen* (天门): one says it is the heart; another, the great Dao.

[Emendation] (1) The Zhao Jianyi edition omits the character *ze* (则).

Confucius visited Lao Dan and spoke of benevolence and righteousness. Lao Dan said: “When chaff blinds the eye, heaven and earth and the four directions shift places; when mosquitoes and horseflies bite the skin, one cannot sleep through the night. Benevolence and righteousness, so harsh and bitter, stir the heart—no greater disorder exists! You, sir, would have the world not lose its uncarved simplicity. You, too, should drift with the wind and move, gather your virtue and stand—why then do you strain so mightily, like one bearing a drum in search of a lost child? The swan does not bathe daily to stay white, nor the crow blacken itself daily to stay black. The natural black and white of things are not worth debating; the spectacle of fame and reputation does not enlarge one’s being. When the spring dries, fish find themselves on dry land, where they moisten one another with breath and wet one another with foam—better they forget one another in rivers and lakes!”

[Note 1] Though the external thing be small, the harm to one’s nature is already great.

The Master Kong was mired in the traces of sageliness, and so when he spoke, his words turned to benevolence and righteousness. Now, scattering chaff into the eye blinds it, so that east and west cannot be distinguished; the bite of a mosquito or horsefly stings the skin, so that pain pierces the night and sleep flees. Thus, though external things be slight, the harm they bring is surely great. How much more so with benevolence, which is not Heaven’s principle, and righteousness, which does not follow one’s nature—abandoning the self to imitate others, one loses one’s original nature. What harm they bring—how could it be merely the blinding of the eye or the stinging of the skin?

*[Zām, "to bite."]*

*[Phonetic glosses: 播 (bō/pō),  (kāng), 蚊 (wén), 虻 (méng), 噆 (zǎn/zhá).]*
*[Sīmǎ: "to bite."]*
*[Tōngxī: "through the night."]*
*[Qìngfān’s note: xī means "evening"; tōngxī means "throughout the night." Lüshi Chunqiu’s "Rèn Dì" chapter says, "In the first month of summer’s evening, three leaves are cut to harvest barley." (Huainanzi’s "Tiānwén" chapter writes 夕, "evening," in full.) Shangshu Dàzhuàn says, "The moon’s morning, the moon’s middle, the moon’s evening," with Zheng’s commentary: "The first ten days are morning, the middle ten days are middle, the last ten days are evening." The character is also written 昔.]*

*[To impose them is to add to one’s nature, and so bring disorder.]*

Benevolence and righteousness are more venomous than mosquitoes and horseflies, stirring the heart with indignation and filling it with vexation, disturbing the nature of things—no greater disorder exists! *[Originally written 愦 (vexation), though this is uncertain.]*

*[Phonetic gloss: 憯 (cǎn), 愤 (fèn/fèn). Originally written 愦 (kuì).]*
*[Qìngfān’s note: 愤 in the original text is also written 愦; the latter is correct. The characters 贲 (bēn) and 贵 (guì) are similar in form, so characters using either component are often confused. Qiānfū Lùn’s "Fúchǐ" chapter reads "怀忧愦愦," while the Hànshū’s "Wáng Fú Zhuàn" writes 愤愤—proof of this.]*

*[When one’s substance is whole, benevolence and righteousness become manifest.]*

*[Move with the wind as it stirs, and hold fast to virtue as it stands—this is the Way of easy grasp and easy practice.]*

The *Exegesis* states: *Fang* 放 means "to let go, to follow one's nature." If one wishes to cause the common people to lose their pure and simple nature, nothing is better than severing benevolence and abandoning righteousness—this is to return to the profound extremity of the self.

Confucius, too, should propagate the teaching of non-action, responding to circumstances as they arise and engaging with things, embodying the supreme virtue of emptiness and establishing unfathomable spiritual power.

*[Variant reading: 放 (fàng), "to imitate" (fǎng wǎng fǎn). 放 (fàng) also means "to rely upon."]*

*[Phonetic gloss: 《亦放》 fāng wǎng fǎn. 《风而动》 Sīmǎ (Yì) says: 放 means "to rely upon," to act in accordance with the wind of non-action. 《易持易行》 both read with the sound chǐ.]*

The *Annotation* states: To raise up benevolence and righteousness in pursuit of the realm of the Dao and virtue is like striking a drum to seek a fugitive—there is no way to succeed.

The *Exegesis* states: *Jiàn* 建 means "to strike." *Jiérán* 杰然 describes the exertion of force. To raise up benevolence and righteousness in pursuit of the realm of the Dao and virtue—how is this different from beating a great drum to seek a runaway child? Thus, the louder the drum sounds, the farther the child flees; the more benevolence and righteousness are displayed, the more the Dao and virtue are abandoned.

*[Phonetic gloss: 《杰然》 Guō reads jū jié, also jū yè, jù jié. 《夫揭》 reads qí liè or qí yè.]*

The *Annotation* states: Each is naturally sufficient unto itself.

*[Phonetic gloss: 《鹄》 also written as 鹤, both hú. 《日黔》 reads jù yān, Xú reads qí jīn. Sīmǎ says: "black."]*

The *Annotation* states: Both are natural; there is no partiality.

The *Exegesis* states: *Yù* 浴 means "to bathe." *Rǎn zī yuē qián* 染缁曰黔 means "to dye with black." *Qián* 黔 means "black." *Biàn* 辩 means "to distinguish victory and defeat." The whiteness of the crane and the blackness of the crow are endowed by nature—how could they require daily bathing and dyeing to achieve this? By analogy, the natures of things follow the same principle. Black and white, in their unadorned simplicity, are each sufficient in their allotted portion; where they meet, they are fitting. Thus, it is only when they are insufficient in their portion that one debates victory and defeat.

*[Alternative interpretation: 辩 means "to change." Black and white are fixed in their distinctions; one cannot change white into black.]*

The *Annotation* states: The perfectly sufficient forget fame and reputation; only by forgetting fame and reputation can one be vast.

The *Exegesis* states: To cultivate fame and establish reputation is to attract the gaze of things—how narrow and petty is this, how unworthy of self-aggrandizement! Only by forgetting and relinquishing fame and reputation can one be called great.

*[Phonetic gloss: 《之观》 reads gǔ luàn. Sīmǎ’s version writes 讙.]*

The *Annotation* states: The praise of benevolence and righteousness all arises from insufficiency.

*[Phonetic gloss: 《泉涸》 hú luò. 《相呴》 xiàng xǔ, also xiàng yú. 《相濡》 rú zhǔ, also rú yú. 《以沫》 yǐ mò.]*

The *Annotation* states: This is to forget benevolence and thereby be benevolent.

The *Exegesis* states: This summarizes the preceding text, criticizing the flaws of benevolence and righteousness. When the spring dries up, fish moisten one another with foam; when simplicity scatters and purity disperses, one practices benevolence and righteousness to aid others. Yet when rivers and lakes are vast, each is sufficient and thus they forget one another; when the Dao and virtue are profoundly mysterious, one attains nature and thus becomes empty and tranquil. Since rivers and lakes are comparable to the Dao and virtue, and moistening foam is akin to benevolence and righteousness, measuring them in this way shows they are not to be spoken of on the same day.

*[Phonetic gloss: 《相忘》 both read as written.]*

*[Collation notes: (1) Quēwù cites the Zhāng Jūnfáng edition, which repeats the character 杰; the Zhào Jiànyì edition is the same. (2) 愤愤 follows the Hànshū emendation. (3) The Zhào Jiànyì edition writes 秉 as 乘. (4) 放 is suspected to be a scribal error for 仿.]*

Confucius, having visited Lǎodān, remained silent for three days.

His disciples asked: "Master, when you saw Lǎodān, what advice did you seek?"

The *Exegesis* states: Lǎozǐ was a great sage beyond the world, his transformations unfathomable and unmeasurable—thus, there was nothing to discuss.

*[Phonetic gloss: 《不谈》 also written as 不言.]*

The *Exegesis* states: Without specifying a name, it simply says "disciples," likely referring to those who had entered his hall and jointly raised this doubt. Having seen Lǎozǐ, he should have received instruction—why, then, did he remain silent for three days?

Confucius said: "Only now have I truly seen the dragon! The dragon coalesces into form and scatters into patterns, riding the clouds and qi, nurturing itself in yin and yang. My mouth gapes open and cannot close—what advice could I possibly seek from Lǎodān?"

The *Annotation* states: This refers to Lǎodān’s ability to transform.

The *Exegesis* states: The dragon’s virtue is constant transformation. By analogy, the perfected person’s concealment and manifestation are without fixed form. In essence, they coalesce into a wondrous body, the wondrous body being profound and obscure; in traces, they scatter into patterns, the patterns being radiant and resplendent.

The *Annotation* states: This speaks of their unfettered mastery, their natural sufficiency.

The *Exegesis* states: This means the perfected person rides the clouds and qi without intention, following yin and yang to nurture things.

The *Exegesis* states: *Xié* 嗋 means "to close." His heart trembled in awe, his mouth opened and could not close—how could he have the leisure to hear words of instruction?

*[Phonetic gloss: 《嗋》 xǔ jié, "to close."]*

*[Collation note: Quēwù cites the Jiāngnán ancient manuscript, which adds "his tongue lifted and could not speak" after 嗋.]*

Zǐgòng said: "Then are there indeed those who dwell like corpses yet manifest like dragons, thunder in their voices yet plumb the depths in silence, whose actions move like heaven and earth? Could I, too, observe such a one?" Thereupon, he sought an audience with Lǎodān on Confucius’ behalf.

The *Exegesis* states: This means the perfected person, in their dwelling, is as still as a corpse; in their emergence, they appear like a divine dragon. In speech, they resound like thunder; in silence, they are as profound as the abyss. Thus, when they rouse and act, they move like heaven and earth in generating things.

Having thus dwelt or emerged, spoken or fallen silent—how could there be any difference in their dwelling or emergence, speech or silence that would set them apart? Yet the perfected person must possess the power to emerge or remain, speak or keep silent without words. Thus, when Confucius beheld him, his mouth gaped open and could not close.

*[Phonetic gloss: 《龙见》 xián biàn fǎn.]*

*[Collation note: Quēwù cites the Jiāngnán ancient manuscript, which adds "至" before "人." Another variant in Zhāng Jūnfáng’s edition reads "哉" in place of "乎."]*

Zǐgòng, whose given name was Cì, sought to observe the dragon-like virtue of the perfected person and so went to meet him at Confucius’ behest.

*[Phonetic gloss: 《赐亦》 An alternate reading is "赐也."]*

Lǎodān was then sitting with legs sprawled in the hall when he responded, murmuring: "My years have turned and passed away—what would you teach or warn me of?" *[Annotation: "倨" means to sit with legs apart. "运" means time. Lǎozǐ, self-possessed and at ease, sat sprawled in the hall, carefree and unconstrained. Only when moved by others did he respond, softly voicing his words: "I am old and declining—what would you teach or warn me of?"]*

Zǐgòng said: "The governance of the Three Kings and Five Emperors over the world differed, yet their reputations and renown were as one. Yet you alone deem them not to be sages—how can this be?"

*[Annotation: As customs grew thin or thick, their methods diverged; whether by toil or by arms, whether yielding or resisting, they differed. Yet their fame and good repute remained linked as one. "You dismiss the Three Kings as unworthy of sagehood—what is your meaning? Might I hear it?"]

*[Phonetic gloss: "夫三王" Some versions read "Three Sovereigns" instead of "Three Kings." According to the commentary, "Kings" is correct. The rest read "Three Sovereigns."]

*[Collation note: Quēwù reads "Kings" as "Sovereigns." Another variant in the Jiāngnán ancient manuscript adds "也" after "天下."]

Lǎodān said: "Young man, come closer! Why do you say they differed?"

*[Annotation: "Come closer and explain why you claim they differed."]

Zǐgòng replied: "Yao ceded to Shun, Shun ceded to Yu. Yu governed through labor, while Tang resorted to arms. King Wen submitted to Zhòu without daring to oppose him, while King Wu opposed Zhòu and refused to submit. Thus I say they differed."

*[Annotation: Yao and Shun are counted among the Five Emperors; from Xia Yu onward, they are the Three Kings. Yao yielded to Shun, Shun to Yu. Yu tamed the floods through labor, Tang overthrew Jié with arms. King Wen was imprisoned at Yǒulǐ yet submitted to Shāng Xīn, while King Wu crossed the Mèngjīn Ford to defy Yīn Zhòu. Their differing ways may be briefly described thus.]

*[Collation note: The Dūnhuáng manuscript reads these six characters as "Yao gave and Shun received."]

Lǎodān said: "Young man, come closer! Let me tell you of the governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors over the world.

The Yellow Emperor’s governance made the people’s hearts one: when their parents died, they did not weep, and none among the people found fault with this.

Yao’s governance made the people’s hearts affectionate: when they killed for their parents, none among the people found fault with this.

Shun’s governance made the people’s hearts competitive: pregnant women bore children at ten months, and those children could speak at five months. Before they could even crawl, they began to ask, ‘Who is this?’—and thus people first began to die young.

Yu’s governance made the people’s hearts mutable: each person had their own mind, and weapons followed suit. Killing thieves was not considered killing. People acted as their own kind, and the world was left to itself. Thus the world was greatly alarmed, and the Ru and Mohists arose.

Their beginnings had order, yet now we have women—what more can be said!

I tell you: the governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors was called ‘governance,’ yet no chaos was greater than theirs.

The wisdom of the Three Sovereigns obscured the brightness of sun and moon above, severed the essence of mountains and rivers below, and disrupted the workings of the four seasons in between.

Their knowledge was crueler than the sting of scorpions or centipedes, more savage than the beasts that lurk in the wilds. None could preserve the true nature of their lives, yet they still called themselves sages. Is this not shameful? Truly, they knew no shame!"*

*[Annotation: If the people had found fault, they would have been forced to weep.]

The Three Sovereigns practiced the Dao, and the people’s hearts were pure and unified. They did not exclusively cherish their own kin nor exclusively dote upon their own children, so when kin died, none wept, and the customs of the age did not condemn it. Yet if condemnation arose, those who forced themselves to weep would be many.

The Five Emperors practiced virtue, though not to the extent of the Three Sovereigns. They caused fathers and sons, brothers and kin to cherish one another in turn, establishing graded mourning rites to distinguish closeness from distance. This accorded with the people’s hearts and drew no censure. Yet the distinctions of closeness and distance were already a descent.

Shun, the last of the Five Emperors, saw customs grow increasingly shallow, simplicity scatter, and purity dissolve. The people’s hearts became restless and competitive, so that pregnant women bore children after ten months, and infants could speak at five. In ancient times, pregnant women carried their children for fourteen months before giving birth, and children did not speak until they were two. With simplicity transformed, the present diverged from the ancient ways.

Before they could even smile, infants already distinguished right from wrong, and the mind of discrimination began from this. Unable to harmonize self and other, their hearts competed over closeness and distance, and so they did not live out their Heaven-appointed years. The onset of early death began with the age of Yu.

As the Dao receded, artifice flourished daily, and the foolish people grew fond of calamity. They abandoned the traces of non-action and embraced the impulse to act, rewarding good and punishing evil as their guiding principle. Yet even Yu, moved by compassion, wept for those condemned to death. When the blade fell, it was only in accord with Heaven’s Dao.

Thieves deserved death, and killing them was in accord with principle—thus, though they were killed, it was not truly killing. This was the righteousness inherent in the use of arms.

Yet when the myriad things could not be brought into great harmony and each person distinguished themselves from others, they became as separate species. Carrying forward the currents of a hundred generations to meet the changes of the present age, the corruption reached this point—not through Yu’s doing, but through the world itself. The traces of sagely wisdom did not disrupt the world, yet the world inevitably fell into such disorder.

With artifice flourishing and distinctions growing daily, each person became their own kind and could not bring the myriad things into great unity. This was the consequence of the human mind. The traces of sagely wisdom brought it to this, yet it was not Yu’s fault—it was the world’s doing.

In the time of Zhuangzi, the six states vied for power, and wanton customs spread widely. Taking women as wives violated ritual and defied virtue more than ever before. Thus, we know that when the traces of sages first arose, they established order and principle, but in their decline, all fell into such corruption.

From order, teachings emerged, leading to this. With customs shallow and the age degenerate, what more can be said? The master speaks in grief and lament.

The governance of the Three Sovereigns was truly non-action. Yet the traces of non-action gave rise to corruption, so that in later ages, no chaos was greater than this.

The manifestations of corruption and chaos are enumerated below.

The stars and constellations rebel, comets arise, and the sun and moon lose their brightness. The mountains and rivers fall into discord, the great peaks and rivers collapse and run dry. The four seasons are disrupted, and cold and heat fall out of order.

The wisdom of non-action was employed to establish methods of governance, but later ages clung to its traces, thus giving rise to such corruption.

The harm wrought by the wisdom of the Three Sovereigns upon the people was more venomous than that of scorpions and centipedes. Thus, even the smallest creatures were disturbed, let alone the common folk—how could they find peace? To call this sagely is contrary to reason. The extent of this poisonous harm is deeply shameful.

《憯于》 is pronounced *cǎn yú*. 《蛎》 is pronounced *chì mài*, or alternatively *lì*. Originally also written as 厉. Guo [Pu] reads it as *lài*, or alternatively *chì jiè*. 《虿》 is pronounced *xū yè*, or alternatively *chì mài*. Some say: according to the characters, the upper should be written as 虿, and the lower as 蝎. *Tongsu Wen* states: those with long tails are called 虿, and those with short tails are called 蝎.

◎ Wang Yinzhi says: *Shiwen* states that 蛎 is pronounced *chì mài*, or alternatively *lì*, and originally also written as 厉. Guo [Pu] reads it as *lài*, or alternatively *chì jiè*. 虿 is pronounced *xū yè*, or alternatively *chì mài*. Some say: according to the characters, the upper should be written as 虿, and the lower as 蝎. I note that Lu [Deming] reads 蛎 as 虿 and 虿 as 蝎—both are incorrect. □ is pronounced *lài*, or alternatively *lì*. Lu [Deming] says it was originally written as 厉, which serves as evidence. 虿 is pronounced *chì mài*; 蝎 is pronounced *xū yè*. □ and 虿 are both alternative names for 蝎. *Guang Ya* states: 虿, □, and 蝎 [are the same]. (The current edition of *Guang Ya* omits the □ character. *Yiqiejing Yinyi*, Volume 5, cites *Guang Ya*: "虿, □, 蝎." *Jiyun* cites *Guang Ya*: "□, 虿." The character is now restored accordingly.) □ is pronounced *lú dá*. 虿 and □ are both names for creatures whose venom stings and harms people. The word 虿 is derived from □. (□ is pronounced *zhé*. *Yiqiejing Yinyi*, Volume 10, cites *Zilin*: "□ means to sting." *Zuozhuan Zhengyi* for the 22nd year of Duke Xi cites *Tongsu Wen*: "When a scorpion’s venom harms a person, it is called □.") □ is derived from 瘌. (瘌 is pronounced *lú dá*. Guo Pu’s commentary on *Fangyan* states: "瘌 means a painful sting." The character is sometimes written as 刺. Zuo Si’s *Wei Du Fu* says: "Thorns and brambles sting and pierce; insects and worms poison and bite.") *Guang Ya Shigu* states: "毒, □, 瘌, and 痛 all mean pain"—this is their meaning. □ and □ are homophonous in ancient pronunciation. *Zhuangzi* writes it as □, while *Guang Ya* writes it as □—in fact, they are the same character. (In the *Records of the Grand Historian*, *Annals of Qin*, the name 厉共公 appears in the *Basic Annals of Qin* as 剌龚公. The interchangeability of 剌 and 厉 is analogous to that of □ and □.)

《鲜规之兽》 Li [Yi] says: 鲜规 means "bright in appearance." Another says: it refers to small insects. Yet another says: it refers to small beasts.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The *Shide Tang* edition writes 皇 as 王.
(2) *Quewu* cites the Jiangnan Ancient Collection edition, which includes the character 昔 before 黄.
(3) The Tang manuscript writes 其杀 as 其服.

Zigong stood uneasily, shifting from foot to foot.

**Commentary:** Zigong had originally believed that Laozi alone surpassed the Three Kings, and thus sought to equate the Three Kings with the Five Emperors. Now, seeing Laozi extend his critique to the Five Emperors and even the Three Sovereigns, he lost the basis of his argument.

**Exegesis:** 蹴蹴 describes a startled and fearful appearance. Zigong wished to align the Three Kings with the Five Emperors; now, witnessing Laozi’s lofty and distant discourse—rejecting the Five Emperors and censuring the Three Sovereigns—his mind and form were shaken, and he lost his bearings. Thus, he stood 蹴蹴然, his posture upright but his spirit unsettled.

《蹴蹴》 is pronounced *zǐ liù*.

Confucius said to Lao Dan: "I have studied the Six Classics—*Poetry*, *Documents*, *Rites*, *Music*, *Changes*, and *Spring and Autumn*—and have long considered myself well-versed in their principles. I have advised seventy-two rulers, expounding the Dao of the former kings and clarifying the traces of Zhou and Shao, yet not one ruler has adopted my counsel. How difficult it is to persuade others! How hard it is to make the Dao clear!"

Laozi said: "Fortunate indeed that you have not encountered a ruler of a well-governed age! The Six Classics are but the discarded traces of the former kings—how could they be that by which the traces were made? What you now speak of are still only traces. Traces are what the shoe produces, yet are traces the shoe itself?

The white egrets gaze at one another, their pupils unmoving, and yet the wind effects transformation. The male insects cry from the upwind, the females respond from the downwind, and the wind effects transformation. Like naturally divides into male and female, and thus the wind effects transformation. Nature cannot be altered, fate cannot be changed, time cannot be halted, and the Dao cannot be obstructed. If one attains the Dao, there is nothing that cannot be done; if one loses it, there is nothing that can be done."

The Master of Records states: "They are the young of birds." *Regarding "gaze at one another with their pupils"*: pronounced *mòhóu*. *Regarding "their young are transformed by the wind without movement"*: The Master of Records states: "They await the qi of the wind to transform and give birth." He also says: "They form yin and yang by gazing at one another." *Regarding "the male insects cry from the upwind, the females respond from the downwind, and transform"*: One version reads "and are transformed by the wind." The Master of Records states: "The males belong to the soft-shelled turtle kind; the females, to the hard-shelled turtle kind."

Now, creatures of the same kind, male and female, each possess their own means of mutual resonance. The variations in this resonance are boundless. If they belong to the same kind, transformation is not difficult—thus, there are even those who resonate from afar and are transformed by the wind.

*Annotation*: Some explain that among the categories of things, this is like grasses and trees of different species yet the same kind. The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: "On Danyuan Mountain, there is a beast resembling a leopard but with fur, called the *shilei*; on Dai Mountain, there is a bird resembling a phoenix with five-colored patterns, called the *qilei*—both reproduce through their own males and females." *Regarding "boundless"*: pronounced *shēng*.

Thus, the perfected person follows and flows with these principles.

*Regarding "can be obstructed"*: pronounced *yōng*.

Though transformations have no fixed direction, all are possible.

Wherever one loses the Dao, nothing is possible.

*Textual Note*: (1) The *Quewu* cites the Zhang Junfang edition, which includes the character *gǎn* ("resonance") after *ér* ("and"), and the same applies to the following clause. (2) The *Quewu* cites the Zhang Junfang edition, which includes the character *yuē* ("say") after *gù* ("thus"). (3) Modern texts read *ér huà* ("and transform") as *ér fēng huà* ("and are transformed by the wind").

Confucius did not emerge for three months, then reappeared and said: "I have attained it! Crows and magpies nurture their young, fish coat themselves in foam, creatures with slender waists transform, and the elder brother weeps for his younger brother. How long it has been since I, Qiu, joined with transformation to become human! If one does not join with transformation to become human, how can one transform others?"

*Annotation*: This speaks of the spontaneity of things, each possessing its own nature.

**Annotation and Exegesis:**
Magpies dwell within their nests, mating to manifest yin and yang; fish remain in water, coating themselves in foam to become male and female; bees take mulberry grubs and, through incantation, make them their own offspring. Thus we know that the natures of things differ, each endowed by the great Dao. The spontaneity of things, each possessing its own nature, is so.

**Phonetic Glosses:**
*Fùjiàn* ("reappeared"): *fúyòu* reflex.
Below, *xiánbiàn* ("all-pervading"): also read as the common word.
*Wūquè rú* ("crows and magpies nurture"): *rúyù* reflex. Li [Yun] says: to hatch and give birth.
*Yú fù* ("fish coat"): *fù* sound, also *fù* sound. Originally also written as *zhuàn* ("transmit"), *zhí zhuān* reflex.
*Mò* ("foam"): *mò* sound. Sima [Biao] says: "to transmit foam" means to nurture one another with foam. Another explanation: they coat their mouths with foam and together produce offspring.
*Xìyāo* ("slender-waisted"): *yīyáo* reflex.
*Zhě huà* ("those that transform"): refers to bees and the like. Sima [Biao] says: they take mulberry grubs and incant over them to make them resemble their own offspring. This is what the *Book of Songs* means by "the green caterpillar has young, the sphex carries them away."
◎Qing Fan’s note: The *Liezi* phonetic glosses cite Sima [Biao] as saying: "Young bees with slender waists take mulberry grubs, incant over them, and make them resemble their own offspring." This is more detailed than what the phonetic glosses here record.

**Annotation:**
This speaks of human nature, which abandons the elder to cherish the younger, hence the weeping.

**Exegesis:**
When an elder brother has a younger brother and loses affection, abandoning the elder to cherish the younger, he weeps. Thus we know that one must not cling to past traces but should follow the natural course. Free from entanglements between things and self, [Guo Xiang says:] this speaks of human nature, which abandons the elder to cherish the younger, hence the weeping.

**Phonetic Glosses:**
*Shě* ("abandon"): *shě* sound.
*Zhǎng* ("elder"): *zhāng zhàng* reflex.

**Annotation:**
To align with transformation as a person is to allow oneself to transform naturally. If one were to propagate the Six Classics to persuade others, it would be superficial.

Laozi said: "Good. Qiu has grasped it!"

**Chapter 15: Carving Intent (External Chapters)**
**Chapter 16: Cultivating Nature (External Chapters)**
**Chapter 15: Carving Intent**

**Annotation:**
The chapter is named for its theme.

Those who carve intent and exalt conduct, who depart from the world and differ from common customs, who engage in lofty discourse and resentful slander—do so merely to reach extremity. These are the scholars of mountain valleys, men not of this world, those who favor withering away or plunging into the abyss.

Those who speak of benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, and trust, who practice reverence, frugality, deference, and yielding—do so merely to cultivate themselves. These are the scholars of peaceful eras, men of instruction and edification, those who favor wandering in leisure and learning.

Those who speak of great achievements, establish great reputations, observe the rites between ruler and minister, and rectify the hierarchy—do so merely to govern. These are the scholars of the court, men who honor the sovereign and strengthen the state, those who favor achieving merit and annexing others.

Those who dwell in marshes and wilds, who abide in seclusion and open spaces, who fish and idle—do so merely to be without action. These are the scholars of rivers and seas, men who shun the world, those who favor leisure and tranquility.

Those who practice breathing exercises, exhaling the old and inhaling the new, who emulate the bear’s climbing and the bird’s stretching—do so merely to prolong life. These are the scholars who guide *qi*, men who nurture the body, those who favor the longevity of Peng Zu.

**Exegesis:**
*Ke* means to carve; *yi* means intent. *Kang* means extremity. These partial and stagnant men, unable to grasp the principle, carve and discipline their bodies and minds, exalt their conduct, depart from the world and differ from common customs, standing aloof and apart. They discourse on the winds of the Five Emperors, expound on the teachings of the Three Sovereigns, resent the talented who meet no opportunity, and slander the wayless who indulge in excess. Their lofty intent dwells among the groves and winds, their carved traces lie beneath cliffs and crags. These are the scholars who hide in mountain valleys, men who revile the times. Some wither like Bao Jiao and Jie Zitui, others plunge into the abyss like Shen Tu and Bian Sui—mere one-sided scholars, how could they speak of the supreme Dao? *Yi* means to stop. Their arts stop here.

**Annotation and Exegesis**

*Ke yi* (刻意): Sima [Biao] says: "Ke means to carve; it sharpens the intent." The note explains: to carve the intent and make it acute.
*Guangya* says: "Yi means aspiration."
*Shang xing* (尚行): Read *meng* in the lower tone.
*Li shi* (離世): Read *li* as in "to depart," *zhi* as in "wisdom."
*Gao lun* (高論): Read *li* as in "strength," *kun* as in "exhaustion."
*Yuan fei* (怨誹): Read *fei* as in "slander," Xu [Shen] pronounces it *fei*. Li [Yi] says: "To resent the world’s lack of the Dao is to resent one’s own failure to meet opportunity."
*Wei kang* (為亢): Read *kang* as in "exhaustion." Li [Yi] says: "To be exhausted in loftiness is called *kang*."
*Ku gao* (枯槁): Read *ku* as in "withered," *lao* as in "aged."
*Fu yuan* (赴淵): Sima [Biao] says: "Withered and emaciated, like Bao Jiao and Jie Zitui; plunging into the abyss, like Shen Tu and Bian Sui."

**[Section Two]**
**Exegesis:** When they give voice to their breath, their words turn to benevolence and righteousness, employing these methods as the foundation of self-cultivation. These are the scholars of peaceful and well-ordered times, the men who instruct and enlighten others. Such were Zixia in the West River, Confucius dwelling by the Zhu and Si—some traveling to discourse and debate, others settled to lecture and expound. These are the pursuits beloved by students, but they are not the first concern of Daoists.

**Annotation:**
*Suo hao* (所好): Read *hao* as in "to love." The same applies below and in the commentary.

**[Section Three]**
**Exegesis:** They establish merit throughout the realm, erect great names for all ages, perfect the grand rites of ruler and minister, and uphold the great principles of high and low. They pacify and secure the altars of state, brighten and sustain the constant Dao. Then they exalt the ruler and subdue distant lands, strengthen the homeland and annex rival states. Are these not the scholars of the court, the ministers of the hallowed halls? Such were Gaoyao, Yi Yin, and Lü Wang.

**Annotation:**
*Wei zhi* (為治): Read *zhi* as in "to govern." The same applies below.
*Ci chao* (此朝): Read *chao* as in "court."

**[Section Four]**
**Exegesis:** They dwell in reclusion among mountains and marshes, roam freely through riverbanks and marshes, live in leisure while angling and fishing, withdraw from the world to abide in nonaction. The Son of Heaven cannot make them his subjects, the feudal lords cannot make them their friends. These are the men of ease and leisure—such as Chaofu, Xu You, and Gong Yueren.

**Annotation:**
*Sǒu* (薮): Read *sou* as in "marsh."
*Chu xian* (處閒): Read *xian* as in "leisure." The same applies below.
*Diao yu* (釣魚): The original also writes *diao* (釣). Both are read *diao* as in "to angle." ◎Lu Wenchang notes: The modern text writes *diao* (釣).

**[Section Five]**
**Commentary:** Though these men differ in their pursuits, each indulges his own inclination and follows his own path—this too is a way of attaining freedom. Yet this is merely self-attainment; how can it be universally applied? If one wishes to ensure that the myriad things each attain their proper place without losing themselves, one must entrust it to nonaction and non-attachment.

**Exegesis:** They exhale the old with a cold breath, inhale the new with a warm one—like bears climbing trees to hang themselves, or birds stretching their legs in flight. These are all methods of guiding and refining the spirit and *qi*, nurturing the body and soul, the way to prolong life, the art of preserving form. Thus Peng Zu lived eight hundred years, White Stone three thousand—such are the long-lived. The aforementioned men, though differing in their aspirations, each clung to one corner and failed to achieve perfect harmony. Only from *Ke yi* onward do they begin to grasp the subtleties of the profound Dao.

**Exegesis Notes:**
*Chuixu* (吹呴) is pronounced *kuàng yú fǎn*; the character may also be written as 喣.
*Huxi* (呼吸) is pronounced *xǔ jí fǎn*.
*Tu gu na xin* (吐故纳新): Li [Yun] says: "Exhale the old *qi*, inhale the new *qi*."
*Xiong jing* (熊经) is read as written; Li [Yun] reads it as *gǔ dìng fǎn*. Sima [Biao] says: "Like a bear climbing a tree to guide the *qi*."
*Niao shen* (鸟申) is read as written; Guo [Xiang] pronounces it *xìn*. Sima [Biao] says: "Like a bird stretching and groaning in flight."
*Daoyin* (道引) is pronounced *dǎo*; same below. Li [Yun] says: "Guide the *qi* to harmonize it, stretch the body to soften it."
*Ci shu* (此数) is pronounced *suǒ zhǔ fǎn*.
*Jin* (仅) is pronounced *qí jìn fǎn*.
*Yan neng* (焉能) is pronounced *rú qián fǎn*.

**Textual Note:** (1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition reads *dao* (道) as *dao* (导); same below.

As for one who does not strive with intent yet rises high, who cultivates without relying on benevolence and righteousness, who governs without pursuing merit and fame, who finds leisure without retreating to rivers and seas, who attains longevity without guiding and refining—such a one forgets nothing, yet possesses all. Serene and boundless, all virtues follow in their wake. This is the Way of Heaven and Earth, the virtue of the sage.

**Annotation:** (1) That is, what is called "natural."
(2) **Annotation:** To forget is thus to possess; if one possesses, one cannot truly forget. Thus, to possess is not to possess by possessing, but to possess by forgetting.
**Exegesis:** The scholar who fathoms the profound and embraces change, the one who darkly accords with truth—such a person does not strive with intent yet their Way grows ever higher; they cultivate without relying on benevolence and righteousness; they forget merit and fame yet the world is well-governed; they leave behind rivers and seas yet remain serene and at ease; they do not guide and refine yet their lifespan knows no limit. Thus, they can regard all things and the self as one, forgetting all without exception, while all things return to them—hence, they lack nothing. This is to possess by forgetting, not to possess by possessing.

◎ Jia Shifu says: Benevolence and righteousness are what appear in human interactions. To love is called benevolence; to love others because of them is still to retain the perception of others. To act appropriately is called righteousness; to act appropriately because of others is still to retain the perception of the self. Without the perception of self or others, the names of benevolence and righteousness need not be established, and what one cultivates is true cultivation.

◎ Qingfan notes: *Wang* (忘) is a loan for *wang* (亡), meaning "to cease." The *Guanzi* ("Riding Horse" chapter) says, "Today’s goods are forgotten for tomorrow’s"; the *Records of the Grand Historian* ("Biography of Mengchang Jun") says, "Do not forget what we have agreed upon"—both use *wang* in the sense of *wang*. The *Book of Han* ("Biographies of the Five Sons of Emperor Wu") says, "I have heard that Zixu was loyal yet forgot his title"; Yan Shigu’s commentary: "*Wang* means *wang*." The *Huainanzi* ("Cultivating Effort" chapter) says, "Nanrong Chou was ashamed that the sagely Way had alone ceased in himself"; the *Xunzi* ("Encouraging Learning" chapter) writes *wang* as *wang*—all are examples of this usage.

**Annotation:** (3) If one forces oneself to act, one cannot be boundless, and all evils arise.
**Exegesis:** With the mind not fixed on one corner and traces darkly aligned with the five phases, one remains serene and empty, their Way inexhaustible, and all virtues follow in their wake.

**Exegesis Notes:**
*Dan* (澹) is pronounced *dà zhàn fǎn*; Xu [Shen] reads it as *tán*. *Ran* (然) in one edition reads *dan er* (澹而).

**Annotation:** (4) That which does not act for the sake of the myriad things yet the myriad things arise of themselves is Heaven and Earth; that which does not act for the sake of the hundred practices yet the hundred practices are perfected of themselves is the sage.
**Exegesis:** Heaven and Earth do not intend to nurture yet the myriad things are born; the sage does not intend to transform yet the hundred practices are perfected. Thus, Heaven and Earth use non-production to produce, and the sage uses non-action to act as virtue. Hence, the *Laozi* says, "Heaven and Earth are not benevolent; the sage is not benevolent."

**Exegesis Notes:**
*Bai xing* (百行) is pronounced *xià mèng fǎn*; same below and at the end of the chapter.

Thus it is said: Serenity, tranquility, stillness, silence, emptiness, nothingness, non-action—these are the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth and the essence of the Way and virtue.

Thus it is said: When the sage rests in this, they are at peace and ease. At peace and at ease, they are serene and tranquil. Serene and tranquil, then cares and troubles cannot enter, and perverse *qi* cannot invade. Thus, their virtue is whole and their spirit is not diminished.

**Annotation:** (1) If it were not for stillness, silence, and non-action, their equilibrium would be endangered and their essence lost.
**Exegesis:** Serenity and tranquility are the mind of concentrated stillness; emptiness, nothingness, and non-action are the wisdom of quiescent function. Heaven and Earth take this as the source of their equilibrium; the Way and virtue take this as the foundation of their essence.

**Exegesis Notes:**
*Tian dan* (恬惔) is pronounced *dà zhàn fǎn*; Xu [Shen] reads it as *tán*. Same below.
*Zhi ye* (质也): *Zhi* means "correct."
*Er sang* (而丧) is pronounced *xī làng fǎn*; same below.

**Annotation:** (2) To rest in serenity, tranquility, stillness, and silence, to repose in emptiness, nothingness, and non-action—then, though one may traverse perilous changes, one remains ever at peace and free from difficulty.
**Exegesis:** Resting the mind in the realm of serenity and tranquility, reposing the intellect in the state of emptiness and nothingness—then one treads through hardship with ease and traverses danger with equanimity.

**Exegesis Notes:**
*Ren xiu* (人休) is pronounced *xū qiú fǎn*, meaning "to rest." Same below and in the annotation.
*Ping yi* (平易) is pronounced *yǐ chǐ fǎn*; same below and in the annotation.
◎ Yu Yue says: The characters *xiu yan* (休焉) are mistakenly reversed in transmission. The original text reads: "Thus it is said: The sage rests in this; at rest, they are at peace and at ease." The *Tian Dao* chapter says, "Thus, the emperors, kings, and sages rest in this; at rest, they are empty"—the structure is similar and can be used to correct this passage.
*Wu nan* (无难) is pronounced *nǎi dàn fǎn*; same below.

**Annotation:** (3) Troubles arise from action; action also arises from troubles. Thus, peace, ease, serenity, and tranquility mutually complete one another.

The *Exegesis* states: Is it only that a tranquil and serene heart leads to peace and ease? Indeed, peace and ease also engender serenity and tranquility—thus it is known that peace, ease, serenity, and tranquility mutually complete one another.

**Annotation (4):** Merging imperceptibly with the right principle as it proceeds.

**Exegesis:** With the heart serene and the conduct at ease, both mind and action embody a single non-action. Thus, profound worries and worldly burdens cannot enter their sacred chamber, nor can perverse *qi* or malevolent vapors invade their viscera. "Invade" means to enter, a variation in phrasing.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Xie qi* (邪氣) is pronounced *sì jiē fǎn*; same below.

**Annotation (5):** Those who are neither at peace nor tranquil—do they merely harm their physical form? Their spiritual *power* and inner *virtue* are also lost within.

**Exegesis:** As for those who are tranquil and non-active, do they merely remain unharmed in outward form? Their inner *virtue* is also complete and whole. With both form and *virtue* at peace, their spirit and essence suffer no depletion.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The *Quewu* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, where *xiuxiu yan* (休休焉) appears as *xiu yan xiu* (休焉休).
(2) The Tang manuscript includes the character *ye* (也) after both *ru* (入) and *xi* (袭).
(3) The Tang manuscript includes the character *yi* (矣) after *kui* (亏).
(4) The *Shidetang* edition reads *xianzu* (险阻).

Thus it is said: In life, the sage moves as the heavens move; in death, they transform as things transform. At rest, they share the *power* of *yin*; in motion, they flow with the waves of *yang*. They do not precede fortune, nor do they initiate misfortune. They respond only after being stirred, act only when pressed, and rise only when unavoidable. They discard knowledge and contrivance, following the principle of heaven. Thus, they suffer no heavenly disasters, no burdens from things, no human reproach, and no blame from spirits. Their life is like floating; their death, like resting. They do not ponder, nor do they plan ahead. Radiant yet not dazzling, trustworthy yet not bound by expectation. In sleep, they dream not; awake, they know no sorrow. Their spirit is pure and unadulterated; their soul does not weary. Empty, tranquil, and serene—they accord with the *virtue* of heaven.

**Annotation (1):** Moving in accordance with nature.

**Annotation (2):** Shedding their form without attachment.

**Exegesis:** The sage embodies the unity of labor and rest, comprehending the oneness of departure and return. Thus, in life, they move like the heavens’ course; in death, they transform like the myriad things, submitting to the molding of the forge without the slightest obstruction in their heart.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Tui ran* (蜕然) is pronounced *shuì*, or alternatively *shǐ ruì fǎn*.

**Annotation (3):** In stillness and motion, they are without intent, entrusting themselves to *yin* and *yang*.

**Exegesis:** With spirit concentrated and thoughts stilled, they share the abundant *power* of great *yin*; when stirred to action, they move with the waves of *yang*’s *qi*. In stillness and motion, they follow the seasons, acting without intent.

**Annotation (4):** They initiate nothing.

**Exegesis:** To precede fortune with goodness or initiate misfortune with evil—having abandoned both good and evil, they have also forgotten fortune and misfortune. They respond only after being stirred; how could they be the first to act?

**Annotation (5):** They act only upon encounter.

**Exegesis:** *Po* (迫) means arrival or compulsion. *Dong* (动) means response. Harmonious yet not initiating, they respond to the moment as it arises.

**Annotation (6):** Rising in accordance with principle, they cannot but act.

**Exegesis:** *Yi* (已) means cessation. When the moment’s stimulus compels, and the matter admits no delay, they rise in response—not by premeditation.

**Annotation (7):** The principle of heaven is natural; knowledge and contrivance have no place in it.

**Exegesis:** *Xun* (循) means to follow. Within, they discard the mind’s knowledge; without, they forget contrived affairs. Like the undifferentiated state of primordial chaos, they follow the wondrous principle of nature.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Qu zhi* (去知) is pronounced *qǐ lǚ fǎn*.
◎ Qingfan’s note: *Gu* (故) means deception. The *Guoyu* states: "Many contrivances are made to alter one’s resolve." Wei’s commentary says: "This refers to devising many schemes to change one’s intent." The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Lun Ren* chapter says: "Discard craft and deception." Gao’s commentary: "Craft and deception mean falsity." The *Huainanzi*’s *Zhu Shu* chapter states: "Where contrivance is many, deception below is also many." Gao’s commentary: "*Gu* means craft." All are examples of this. The *Guanzi*’s *Xin Shu* chapter says: "Discard knowledge and contrivance." Yin Zhizhang’s commentary: "*Gu* means affairs"—this is incorrect.

**Annotation (8):** Disasters arise from opposing heaven.

**Exegesis:** Accordant with heaven, they suffer no disasters.

**Annotation (9):** Burdens arise from opposing things.

**Exegesis:** Harmonious with things, they bear no burdens.

**Annotation (10):** Those who are the same as others are surely affirmed by the multitude.

**Exegesis:** Identical to others, they incur no reproach.

**Annotation (11):** Identical to self-possession, they incur no blame.

**Annotation (12):** Floating without attachment.

**Exegesis:** The sage, without intent in action or stillness, unifies life and death. Thus, in life, they are like a fleeting bubble’s rise, transforming in an instant; in death, they rest as if weary, without lingering attachment.

**Annotation (13):** Entrusting it to the principle of heaven.

**Exegesis:** Their heart is like dead ashes, cut off from all entanglements.

**Annotation (14):** Responding as principle arrives.

**Exegesis:** Like a mirror hung high in a hall, it reflects whatever comes before it, never premeditating or anticipating affairs.

**Annotation (15):** Using the world’s own radiance, not their own brilliance.

**Exegesis:** The light of their wisdom shines brighter than the sun and moon, yet they conceal their brilliance and obscure their traces, never dazzling others.

**Annotation (16):** Using the world’s own trustworthiness, not their own expectation.

**Exegesis:** Responding to the moment’s stimulus, they are like a shadow following form—trustworthy as the four seasons, without error or deviation. They respond only when the moment arrives, never anticipating it.

**Annotation (17):** In sleep, they do not dream; awake, they know no sorrow.

**Exegesis:** Their spirit is pure and undefiled; their soul does not weary. Empty, tranquil, and serene—they accord with the *virtue* of heaven.

**Annotation (17):**
Accordant with the true, they are thus serene and dreamless; their encumbrances exhausted, they are ever content and free from sorrow.

**Textual Note:** 《其觉》 pronounced as *gǔ xiào* in ancient rhyme.

**Annotation (18):**
Desiring nothing.

**Exegesis:**
"Pure" means undefiled. Having no dreams, no sorrows, and accordant with the true and the Dao, their mind and spirit are thus pure and free from杂念.

**Textual Note:** 《粹》 pronounced as *suì* in ancient rhyme.

**Annotation (19):**
Fatigue arises only from desire.

**Exegesis:**
Tranquil and inactive, their mind and spirit are at ease, so their essence and soul remain ever responsive, never weary.

**Textual Note:** 《不罢》 pronounced as *pí*.

**Annotation (20):**
Thus do they unite with heaven and earth in their *virtue* of tranquility.

**Exegesis:**
In praising this emptiness and nothingness, they unite their *virtue* with heaven and earth.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The character *逼* is amended based on the preceding exegesis. The original text reads *迫而后动* ("moved only under compulsion"), where the exegesis explains *迫* as *至* ("arrival") or *逼* ("compulsion"). *逼* and *通* are graphically similar and likely miswritten.
(2) The *Shide Tang* edition omits the character *其*.

Thus it is said:
Joy and sorrow are the aberrations of *virtue*;
Anger and delight are the transgressions of the Dao;
Likes and dislikes are the failings of *virtue*.

Therefore:
A mind free from joy and sorrow is the perfection of *virtue*;
Unchanging unity is the perfection of stillness;
No resistance to anything is the perfection of emptiness;
No engagement with things is the perfection of tranquility;
No opposition to anything is the perfection of purity.

Thus it is said:
When the body labors without rest, it becomes worn;
When the essence is employed without cease, it becomes weary;
Weary, it is exhausted.

**Annotation (1):**
Grief arises from defiance of the heart; joy from compliance with it. Failing to comprehend this defiance and compliance is the perversion of *virtue*.

**Textual Note:** 《悲乐》 pronounced as *bēi luò*. The same below.

**Annotation (2):**
Delight arises from gratification of the heart; anger from frustration of the emotions. To harbor delight and anger without forgetting them is the transgression of the Dao.

**Annotation (3):**
To mistake non-preference for preference, non-aversion for aversion—this deluded heart is the fault of *virtue*.

**Textual Note:** 《好恶》 pronounced as *hào wù*.

**Annotation (4):**
The perfection of *virtue* is ever content, so the emotions have nothing to seize upon.

**Exegesis:**
Neither delight nor anger, neither sorrow nor joy—tranquil, empty, and equanimous—such is the person of perfect *virtue*.

**Annotation (5):**
Stillness and unity cannot be altered.

**Exegesis:**
Embracing the mysterious Dao of true unity, they merge with the dust of the world without change. Who but one of perfect stillness could achieve this?

**Annotation (6):**
Their mind is vast and utterly empty, leaving no trace of resistance.

**Exegesis:**
*忤* means opposition. In perfect accord with all beings, they harbor no resistance. Who but one of perfect emptiness could achieve this?

**Textual Note:** 《于忤》 pronounced as *wǔ gù*. 《确》 pronounced as *kǔ jiǎo*. 《纤介》 pronounced as *xiān jiè*.

**Annotation (7):**
Things come of themselves; the perfectly tranquil have no inclination to engage with them.

**Exegesis:**
Abiding in their nature, their spirit soars, unentangled with things. Without need or expectation, this is the perfection of tranquility.

**Annotation (8):**
If tainted by turbid desires, there will be resistance.

**Exegesis:**
Their wisdom shines with clarity, perfectly pure and undefiled. Thus they harmonize with the myriad things and accord with all beings. This discussion of *忤* ("resistance") and *逆* ("opposition") reveals the same principle, illustrating the two aspects of emptiness and purity—hence the repetition.

**Annotation (9):**
All things have their proper measure; it must not be lost.

**Exegesis:**
The body and spirit are endowed with limits, yet their employment knows no bounds—this must lead to death. To labor the body beyond its measure without rest is to invite exhaustion. To pursue things with the spirit without cessation is to invite weariness; weary, the essence and *qi* wither and perish.

**Collation Note:**
(1) The Tang manuscript includes the character *也* after *邪*, *过*, and *失*.

The nature of water is such that, undefiled, it is clear; undisturbed, it is level. Obstructed and confined, it cannot flow, nor can it remain clear. This is the image of heaven’s *virtue*.

**Annotation (1):**
This is the image of heaven’s *virtue*—unintentional yet perfectly attuned.

**Exegesis:**
*象* means to emulate. Water’s nature is clarity and levelness, reflecting all things. If it is mixed and defiled, obstructed and confined, it strays from its constant nature, unable to ripple or flow, nor to reflect things. Only when undisturbed and unobstructed can it remain clear and level, illuminating all impartially as a standard for things. This is the image of heaven’s *virtue*. By analogy, the sage’s mind is luminous and pure, reflecting all without partiality, emulating the natural and uniting in *virtue* with the mysterious heavens. Thus the *Laozi* says, "The highest good is like water."

Thus it is said:
Pure and undefiled,
Still and unchanging,
Tranquil and inactive,
Moving in accord with heaven’s course—
This is the Dao of nurturing the spirit.

The sword of Gan and Yue is treasured in a case, never dared to be used—such is its supreme value.

The spirit flows in all four directions, reaching everywhere without limit. Above, it touches heaven; below, it coils upon the earth. Transforming and nurturing the myriad things, it cannot be represented in form—its name is "united with the Emperor."

**Annotation (1):**
To emulate heaven’s *virtue* is to be without intention yet perfectly attuned.

**Annotation (2):**
Nothing is not in perfect accord.

**Exegesis:**
Though they harmonize their light with the dust, their spirit remains concentrated and profound. This further explains the earlier statement, "their spirit is pure."

**Annotation (3):**
Ever abiding in what is proper.

Though a thousand transformations unfold,
the heart remains ever still and one.
This further explains "one and unchanging."

**Annotation (4):**
It is simply to be in perfect accord with all things.

Though they mingle with the world and stir its waves,
they do not hinder their emptiness and tranquility.
In their dealings with things,
they do not abandon non-action.
This explains the earlier "perfect tranquility."

**Annotation (5):**
To move in pursuit of desire is the way of men.

Moved by things yet responding without intention,
they align with heaven’s course—
spontaneously generating the myriad things without intention.

**Exegesis (6):**
To summarize the preceding:
the movement of heaven and such principles
are the arts of governing the body,
the Dao of nurturing the spirit.

**Annotation (7):**
How much less would one dare to lightly use their spirit!

**Exegesis:**
*Gan* is the name of a stream;
*Yue*, the name of a mountain.
Both Gan Stream and Yue Mountain produce fine swords.
Another account states:
*Gan* refers to Wu.
Thus, the two states of Wu and Yue both produced famous swords,
and so they are named after them.
Now, if one possesses such a treasure sword from Wu and Yue,
it is kept in a case and stored away.
Only in the gravest matters of state would one dare to use it.
Such is the reverence with which it is treasured—
how much more so for one who treasures and cherishes their spirit!

**Textual Note:**
*Gan-Yue Swords*—Sima Biao: *Gan* refers to Wu. Wu and Yue produce fine swords.
Li Yi: Gan Stream and Yue Mountain yield famous swords.
Note: Wu has a stream called Gan Stream; Yue has a mountain called Ruoye,
both of which produce fine iron used to forge renowned swords.
◎Qingfan’s note—Wang Niansun: *Gan-Yue* is equivalent to *Wu-Yue*.
In the *Book of Han*, *Bi-Rong* and *Rong-Di* are said to be as distinct from *Yu-Yue* as can be.
*Yu* is a corruption of *Gan*.
*Gan* and *Yue* are both state names, hence the phrase *Rong-Di* and *Gan-Yue*.
Yan Shigu took *Yu-Yue* as the *Yu-Yue* of the Spring and Autumn period,
further corrupting *Yu* into *Yu*.
The correct interpretation follows Sima Biao.
(*Huainanzi*’s *Yuan Dao* chapter: *Gan-Yue* produce *ge-chi* cloth.
Gao You’s commentary: *Gan* refers to Wu.
Liu’s edition emends *Gan* to *Yu*, stating: *Yu-Yue*, also written as *Yu-Yue*—incorrect.)
*In a case*—*xia*, pronounced *hu* (户) *jia* (甲).

**Annotation (8):**
One who embodies the ultimate of heaven and earth,
responding to the measures of the myriad things with their spirit,
is thus.
If one achieves such merit as to surpass heaven and earth,
it is simply by following heaven’s course—
not by lightly using it.

**Exegesis:**
*Flows*—pervades.
One who cherishes and nurtures their spirit
can thus reach the four directions, flowing without obstruction.
Below, it coils upon the thick earth;
above, it extends to the dark heavens.
In the four directions and above and below,
there is nowhere it does not reach.
Though it moves, it remains ever still—
not one who lightly uses it.

**Textual Note:**
*Coils below*—*pan*, pronounced *pan* (盘); Guo: *fan* (烦).

**Annotation (9):**
What it nurtures has no fixed direction.

**Exegesis:**
Transforming and guiding the people,
embracing and nurturing the myriad things,
it responds to circumstances without clinging to one direction—
thus, it cannot be confined by form or image.

**Annotation (10):**
In accord with the Heavenly Emperor’s non-action.

**Exegesis:**
*Emperor*—to examine.
To summarize the preceding:
this is the Dao of examining reality.
Also: in accord with the Heavenly Emperor’s non-action.

The Dao of pure simplicity guards only the spirit.
Guard it and do not lose it, and you become one with the spirit.
The essence of this oneness penetrates, aligning with heaven’s order.

A rustic saying goes:
“The common people value profit,
the upright value reputation,
the worthy esteem aspiration,
the sages treasure essence.”
Thus, *simplicity* means having nothing mixed with it;
*purity* means not diminishing one’s spirit.

One who embodies pure simplicity is called a *true person*.

**Annotation (1):**
Always guarding the utmost stillness with pure simplicity,
never swayed by externals—this is darkness.

**Exegesis:**
The Dao of pure essence and simple substance lies solely in guarding the spirit.
Guard the spirit without losing it,
and the spirit congeals in stillness—
the body becomes like withered wood,
the heart like dead ashes,
