**Exegesis:** Gain is the name for not losing. Yet the one who attains the ultimate, equal in gain and loss, having nothing to lose, also has nothing to gain. Thus the *Laozi* says: *"The highest virtue does not act as virtue."*

**[18]**
**Commentary:** Simply entrusting things to themselves.
**Exegesis:** The great sage responds to stimuli, adapting to things as square or round—thus having no self.
**Exegesis on the Text:** *"Wuji"* (no self) reads as *ji*.

**[19]**
**Commentary:** Binding them to reach their proper limits, thus they are obscure. Only that which is utterly formless and cannot be encompassed is so.
**Exegesis:** *Yue* means to rely upon; *fen* means boundary. The great person benefits things, which may take many paths, but in essence, nothing precedes relying on their proper limits. If one sees only what the eye can see, hears only what the ear can hear, knows only what the mind can know, and restricts oneself to these boundaries—this is the perfection of virtue.
**Collation Notes:**
(1) The missing text cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, which adds *"zhi tu ye"* (of these paths) after *"ren"* (person).
(2) Zhao Jianyi’s edition omits *"er"* (and) and *"ye"* (also).
(3) The character *"wei"* (act) is amended following the original text of the *Laozi*.
(4) The Shidetang edition reads *"xi"* (rest) instead of *"jie"* (touch); Zhao’s edition omits this sentence.

The River Lord said: *"Beyond things, within things—where do the distinctions of noble and base arise? Where do the boundaries of small and great emerge?"*
**[1]**
**Exegesis:** *"Beyond things, within things"* refers to the inner and outer of things’ natures. *"Wu"* (where) means *"he"* (what). The distinctions of noble and base, the boundaries of small and great—do they lie within the nature of things, or beyond it? To what place do they extend? The River Lord, not yet comprehending their source, thus makes this inquiry.
**Exegesis on the Text:** *"Wu zhi"* (where to) reads as *wu zhi*. The same below.

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: "Observed through the Dao, things have no noble or base.
**[1]**
Observed through things themselves, each deems itself noble and others base.
**[2]**
Observed through custom, noble and base lie not within oneself.
**[3]**
Observed through distinctions: if you magnify what each thing considers great, then nothing in the world is not great; if you diminish what each thing considers small, then nothing in the world is not small. Knowing that heaven and earth are but a grain of millet, that the tip of a hair is as a mountain—then the gradations of difference become clear.
**[4]**
Observed through function: if you affirm what each thing possesses, then nothing in the world is without; if you negate what each thing lacks, then nothing in the world is not lacking. Knowing that east and west, though opposite, cannot do without each other—then the divisions of function are settled.
**[5]**
Observed through inclination: if you affirm what each thing affirms, then nothing in the world is not affirmed; if you negate what each thing negates, then nothing in the world is not negated. Knowing that Yao and Jie each affirmed their own ways and negated the other—then the tendencies of conduct become clear.
**[6]**

**[1]**
**Commentary:** Each is self-sufficient.
**Exegesis:** The Dao is the wondrous principle of emptiness and penetration; things are coarse matters of form and obstruction. To view the wondrous through the coarse is to perceive great and small; to observe the coarse through the wondrous is to find no noble or base.

**[2]**
**Commentary:** These petty distinctions are what the Dao interweaves and equalizes.
**Exegesis:** When the sentiments of things are inverted and their judgments confused, each desires to esteem itself and belittle others. Others, too, esteem themselves and belittle the rest—thus, all harbor delusion, and so it is called "mutual."

**[3]**
**Commentary:** This is what is meant by inversion.
**Exegesis:** Glory and shame arise by chance, yet the vulgar mind mistakenly feels joy or sorrow. Thus, what comes by chance is deemed noble, and its attainment is called honor; what departs by chance is deemed base, and its loss is called disgrace. Such honor and disgrace depend on external things—how can noble and base lie within oneself?

**[4]**
**Commentary:** What is great is sufficient; what is small leaves no remainder.

Thus, by following its inherent nature to be called great, the tip of a hair and a mountain peak cannot differ in name; by following its lack of remainder to be called small, heaven-and-earth and a grain of millet share no distinction in designation. If, however, one observes differences without relying on this Way, then gradations accumulate, infinitesimal disparities tilt against one another, and they cannot be exhaustively examined.

**Exegesis:** *Difference* means distinction. If one takes self-sufficiency as greatness, then the tip of a hair and a mountain peak are equal in greatness; if one takes lack of remainder as smallness, then heaven-and-earth and a grain of millet are equal in smallness. Therefore, if one takes the tip of a hair as the basis for greatness, then the myriad things are all great; if one takes heaven-and-earth as the basis for smallness, then the myriad things are all small. Thus, though there be a thousand distinctions and ten thousand boundaries, with differing measures and quantities, when viewed through this principle, the pattern becomes evident.

◎**Jia Shifu says:** The Dao is what unites self and other; *things* are what the mind relies upon to weigh others; *custom* is what follows convention to determine noble and base; *difference* is the gradation of the myriad things; *merit* is the achievement required by both self and other; *inclination* is the aim of the single mind. Though tangled and chaotic, each is upheld by the Dao, and thus each has its root when spoken of. Noble and base, great and small—debated, contested, and overturned—are why the world is so rife with complications.

**[Exegesis]**
*《其称》* reads *chǐ zhèng* in reverse rhyme.
*《可胜》* is pronounced *shēng*.

**[Chapter Five]**
**[Annotation]**
In the world, none do not mutually constitute "other" and "self," yet both "other" and "self" seek to act for themselves—hence the opposition of east and west. Nevertheless, "other" and "self" are as interdependent as lips and teeth. Though lips and teeth do not act for each other, when the lips perish, the teeth grow cold. Thus, the self-serving actions of the "other" vastly benefit the "self"—this is their opposition, yet they cannot do without one another. Therefore, if one disregards their self-serving actions and denies their merit, then the merits of the world will all be nullified; if one acknowledges their indispensability and affirms their merit, then the merits of the world will all be established. Yet if one forgets the merit of self-serving actions and instead dwells on the favors of mutual aid, the more diligently such favors are pursued, the more hypocrisy and shallowness proliferate. The world loses its proper work, and human nature becomes dissolute—thus, the apportionment of merit can never be fixed.

**[Subcommentary]**
East and west are opposite directions, yet without east, west cannot stand—this is their indispensability. Taking the body as a closer example: the eye sees, the ear hears, the hand grasps, the foot walks; the five viscera, six bowels, four limbs, and hundred parts each possess their own functions, all endowed with fixed roles. How could the eye see for the ear, or the foot walk for the hand? The merit of mutual aid is extinguished here. This is to negate what is not inherently theirs, and thus the myriad things are all negated. Yet if the feet do not walk, the four limbs grow weary; if the eyes do not see, the hundred parts become obstructed. Each part fulfills its own office without consciously aiding the other, yet the benefit to the other naturally arises. This is to affirm what is inherently theirs, and thus the myriad things all possess merit. Viewed thus, functions exist, and roles are each fixed. But if one forgets the merit of self-serving actions and instead dwells on the favors of mutual aid, then "self" and "other" lose their nature, and right and wrong become confused—how could this be the intent of Master Zhuang!

As for the character 然, it is to be read in its usual sense.

All things are natural, thus none are unnatural; all things mutually negate, thus none are without negation. Where none are without negation, there is no affirmation; where none are unnatural, there is no negation. He who embodies neither affirmation nor negation is Yao; he who embodies both affirmation and negation is Jie. Yet these two rulers each received their innate endowment from Heaven and could not transform one into the other. Thus, by observing Yao and Jie, one may perceive the tendencies and dispositions of the world—how they cannot be made to interchange is evident.

Now, all things deem themselves right, thus none are not right; all things mutually negate, thus none are without negation. Where none are without negation, the world has no right; where none are not right, the world has no wrong. Therefore, observing the inclinations of things: if one follows their self-affirmation, then the myriad things are all right; if one follows their mutual negation, then the myriad things are all wrong. The most extreme opposites in the world are Yao and Jie, and so these two rulers are cited to illustrate the duality of right and wrong. Yao regarded non-action as right and desire as wrong; Jie regarded non-action as wrong and desire as right. Thus it is said that Yao and Jie naturally negate one another. From this, the inclinations, dispositions, and aspirations of the myriad things in the world may be discerned.

Of old, Yao and Shun abdicated and became emperors, while Zihuai abdicated and perished; Tang and Wu contended and became kings, while the Duke of Bai contended and was destroyed. Viewed thus, the rites of contention and abdication, the conduct of Yao and Jie, the esteem and baseness of the times—these are not constant.

A roof beam may breach a city wall but cannot plug a rat hole: this speaks of differing implements. The swift steeds Qi Ji and Hua Liu may gallop a thousand li in a day, yet they are no match for a wildcat in catching mice: this speaks of differing skills. The owl snatches fleas at night, discerning the finest hairs, yet by day it emerges, glaring, and cannot see a hill or mountain: this speaks of differing natures.

Thus it is said: Should one follow right and reject wrong, follow order and reject chaos? This is to fail to comprehend the principles of Heaven and Earth and the conditions of the myriad things. It is like following Heaven while rejecting Earth, or following yin while rejecting yang—its impossibility is clear. Yet still one prattles on without ceasing: if not foolish, then deceitful.

The abdications of emperors and kings differ; the successions of the Three Dynasties differ. Those who miss their time and defy custom are called usurpers; those who meet their time and accord with custom are called righteous followers.

O silent River Spirit! How could you know the gate of esteem and baseness, the house of small and great?

Yao, knowing that the Mandate of Heaven had its destined recipient, abdicated to Shun; Shun, knowing that the dynastic succession was to change, yielded to Yu. Tang and Yu belong to the count of the Five Emperors, hence it is said that they became emperors through abdication.

Zi Zhi was the prime minister of Yan. Kuai was the name of the king of Yan. Zi Zhi was the son-in-law of Su Qin. Su Qin’s younger brother, Su Dai, came from Qi as an envoy to Yan and, citing the precedent of Yao’s abdication to Xu You, persuaded King Kuai of Yan to yield the throne to Zi Zhi. Zi Zhi then accepted. The people of the state resented his acceptance of the abdication and refused to submit to him, plunging the state into three years of chaos. King Xuan of Qi, following Su Dai’s plan, raised an army to attack Yan, whereupon King Kuai was killed in the suburbs and Zi Zhi was beheaded in the court, thus extinguishing the state of Yan. Was this not the result of imitating the old traces of Yao and Shun and bringing disaster to such an extent!

Tang of Yin overthrew Jie, and Wu of Zhou conquered Zhou; these two rulers both received the Mandate of Heaven, bringing about the purification of the Six Directions and the submission of the myriad states. Thus they succeeded the Three Kings of their time, hence it is said that they became kings through contention. When the times demand the use of weapons, one responds with Tang and Wu; when the times demand yielding and deference, one responds with Yao and Shun. Thus, in the myriad transformations and the encounter with things, one adapts to the moment—neither the traces of abdication nor those of contention can be rigidly adhered to.

White Duke was named Sheng, grandson of King Ping of Chu and son of Crown Prince Jian. King Ping heeded the words of Fei Wuji, took a daughter of Qin as consort, and estranged the crown prince. The crown prince fled to Zheng, where he married a woman of Zheng and fathered Sheng. After Grand Tutor Wu She was killed, Wu Zixu fled to Wu, and Sheng followed him there, tilling the fields together. The Chu minister Zixi welcomed Sheng back to the state and enfeoffed him at Bai County, where he usurped the title of duke. Sheng, holding the people of Zheng responsible for his father’s death, requested troops to avenge him. When his repeated requests were denied, he raised troops in rebellion. Chu dispatched the Viscount of Ye, Zigao, to suppress and destroy him—hence it is said that White Duke contended and perished.

Contention and yielding are the ways of Wen and Wu; Yao and Jie represent right and wrong. If one weaves the warp and woof of Heaven and Earth, then the martial is debased and the civil exalted; if one must quell calamity and disorder, then the civil is debased and the martial exalted. Thus the Way of Wen and Wu has its times of honor and disgrace, and the conduct of right and wrong likewise has its moments of use and disuse. Therefore, the rites of contention and yielding were prized in the times of Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu, but debased in the times of Zihuai and White Duke—they cannot be fixed as constants.

A *liang* is a roof beam, and *li* is a ridgepole. *Chong* means to strike, and *zhi* means to block. A large beam and ridgepole may be used to strike city walls, but cannot be used to block a mousehole—this shows that implements differ in their uses according to size.

The *qi*, *ji*, *hua*, and *liu* were all fine horses of antiquity. *Bu* means to seize, and *li* and *sheng* are wildcats. A fine steed with swift hooves can gallop a thousand *li* in a day, yet when it comes to seizing a small mouse, it is no match for a wildcat. This shows that skills differ, and one cannot apply a single standard to all.

To employ each according to its particular capacity is to ensure that nothing is misused.

The *chi* is an owl, also called a *zhi-hu*, a kind of earthen owl. By day its eyes are dim, but by night they are bright. Thus at night it can snatch fleas and lice, discerning the tip of an autumn hair, yet when it emerges by day, its eyes bulge wide and it cannot see the shape of a hill. This shows that the natures of things differ—how could this be true only of owls? Therefore, if one follows their natures and settles them accordingly, nothing will be misused.

The *chi* (尺夷反). Cui [Yuan] states: "The *chi* is the *xiu-liu*; it is the same as the *wei-xiao*." *Ye cuo* (七括反). Cui’s edition writes *zui* (最), with the same pronunciation. *Zao* (蚤), pronounced *zao*. The *Shuowen* says: "A jumping insect that bites people." The *Huainanzi* states: "The *chi* gathers fleas at night, discerning the tip of a hair’s end." Xu Shen says: "The *chi* gathers and feeds on fleas and lice at night without fail." Sima’s edition writes *wen* (文), stating: "The *chi* is the *xiu-liu*, which hunts for food at night." The present Guo edition also has an author’s note. Cui’s edition writes *zhua* (爪), stating: "The *xiu-liu* gathers people’s nails in its nest at night." ◎Wang Yinzhi says: "The character *xiu* (鸺) is a superfluous interpolation, influenced by the *chi xiu liu* in the *Shiwen*." (The *Pei Ya* already cites this in error.) He notes: "The *Shiwen* states, '*chi* (尺夷反), Cui says *chi xiu liu*,' but does not provide a pronunciation for *xiu*, which clearly indicates that the original text did not contain the character *xiu*. The *Huainanzi*’s *Zhu Shu* chapter also says: '*chi* gathers fleas at night.'" ◎Qing Fan notes: "*Zhua* (爪) and *zao* (蚤) are interchangeable, hence Cui’s edition writes *zhua*. The characters are graphically similar, so Sima’s edition writes *wen* (文)." The *Huainanzi*’s *Zhu Shu* chapter, in Gao You’s commentary, states: "The *chi* is the *chi xiu*, also called the *lao-tu*, which cries on people’s rooftops at night. Its eyes are bright at night, and it gathers people’s nails to place in its nest, hence the saying 'discerning the tip of an autumn hair.' By day, it sees nothing, hence the saying 'its nature and form are perverse.'" Xu Shen’s commentary says: "The *chi* gathers and feeds on fleas and lice at night without fail." The accounts of gathering fleas differ between Xu and Gao. Wang Yinzhi says: "Judging by reason, Xu Shen’s commentary is more refined." *Chen* (瞋), *chi yi* (尺夷反); Xiang [Xiu] reads *chu chen* (处辰反). Sima states: "To open wide." Cui reads *xuan* (眩), also *shi shen* (师慎反). Some editions write *ming* (瞑). ◎Qing Fan notes: "The *Shiwen* states that *chen* may also be written as *ming*. It is likely that *ming* is correct. The *Shuowen* says: '*Chen* means to glare angrily.' '*Ming* means to close the eyes.' With eyes closed, one sees nothing." In clerical script, *zhen* (真) may be written as *mian* (冥), or *ming* (冥) as *zhen* (□), leading to graphical confusion. The *Guanzi*’s *Xiao Wen* chapter says: "Duke Huan glared angrily," while the *Hanzi*’s *Shou Dao* chapter says: "Glaring angrily, gnashing teeth, straining ears." The *Huainanzi*’s *Dao Ying* chapter says: "Glaring angrily, rolling up sleeves, drawing swords." In all these cases, modern editions mistakenly write *ming* (瞑) for *chen* (瞋), which are further examples of this error.

【七】
**Commentary:** The principle of Heaven and Earth and the nature of the myriad things regard obtaining the self as right and losing the self as wrong, aligning with nature as order and losing harmony as chaos. Yet things have no fixed limit, and the self has no constant suitability. With differing natures and varying advantages, right and wrong have no fixed standard.

If one deems what is right by one’s own standards, then others cannot be deemed wrong—this is merely knowing the self while failing to see others. Thus, when viewed through the Dao, right and wrong have no fixed correspondence. Entrusting them to the equilibrium of Heaven and allowing both to proceed freely, then differing directions and distinct kinds all find their place.

**Subcommentary:** *Gai* (盖) is a term of inexhaustibility. *Shi* (师) here means following one’s own mind. Each thing follows its own *cheng*-heart, deludedly clinging to partiality: deeming oneself right while unaware that others deem one wrong, deeming oneself ordered while unaware that things deem one chaotic. Thus, following the mind to assert rightness, one fails to see that one’s own position may be wrong; following the mind to assert order, one claims one’s person is without chaos. How can one know that order and chaos share a single source, that right and wrong have no fixed ground? That order and chaos share a source is the principle of Heaven and Earth; that right and wrong have no fixed ground is the nature of the myriad things. Being blind to this truth, one’s words remain unclear.

**Exegesis:** *Shi shi* (师是): Some say *shi* means "to follow." *Shi zhi* (师治): Read as *zhì* (吏), with the same pronunciation in the commentary.

**【Eight】**
**Subcommentary:** Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, exist in mutual opposition. If there were Heaven without Earth, the myriad things would not take form; if there were yin without yang, living beings would not arise. Thus, it is clear that to assert rightness without acknowledging wrong, or order without acknowledging chaos, is impossible to uphold.

**【Nine】**
**Commentary:** Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, arise in mutual opposition; right and wrong, order and chaos, exist in mutual dependence. What, then, could one discard?

**Subcommentary:** To insist upon rightness without wrong, or Heaven without Earth, and to persist in such speech without ceasing—such a one is either utterly foolish or deliberately deceitful.

**Exegesis:** *Bù shě* (不舍): Pronounced *shě* (舍). The same below.

**[Ten]**
**Subcommentary:** The *Di* are the Five Emperors; the *Wang* are the Three Kings. The Three Dynasties are Xia, Yin, and Zhou. *Shàn* means "to transmit"; *jì* means "to continue." Some succeeded through lineage, while others yielded to different clans—hence the term "diverse transmissions." Some passed rule from father to son, while others seized power through rebellion—hence the term "diverse continuations." Some acted too hastily or too slowly, failing to align with Heaven’s timing; others lost the allegiance of the people, defying human affairs. Thus, Zihuai emulated Yao and Shun but lost his line, while the Duke of Bai imitated Tang and Wu yet perished—such cases are called "usurpations."

**Exegesis:** *Cuàn fū* (篡夫): Pronounced *chuàn* (初患反), meaning "to seize." Below, read as written.

**[Eleven]**
**Subcommentary:** Though warfare and yielding differ in form, their application varies with the times and cannot be rigidly held. For instance, Tang and Wu rose by force, while Yao and Shun yielded with courtesy—both accorded with Heaven’s Dao above and the people’s hearts below. Such acts are called "righteous."

**[Twelve]**
**Commentary:** What the world esteems may later be despised; what is deemed great in one age may be diminished in another.

Thus, following the traces of things, one cannot but diverge—this is why the Five Emperors and Three Kings differed. **Subcommentary:** The River Lord could not yet grasp the principle, so the Ocean Spirit rebuked him, urging silence and wordlessness, lest he waste breath in vain. For in matters of small and great, there is no fixed standard; in matters of noble and base, no set gate. The sentiments of things are inverted, and judgments are made recklessly. How then could you, woman, discern the gates of noble or base, great or small? The meaning is that she does not know.

**Exegesis:** *Nǚ è* (女恶) pronounced as *rǔ*; below, read as *wū*. **Collation:** (1) The missing text cites the Zhang Junfang edition, which adds *zhī* (之) beneath *cuàn* (篡). (2) The character *zhī* (之) is supplied from the Shidetang edition. (3) The two characters *chóng lèi* (重累) are amended following the *Wenxuan* commentary. (4) The character *bì* (痹) is amended following the *Guanzi*.

The River Lord said: "If so, then what should I do? What should I not do? How am I to decide in matters of speech and acceptance, pursuit and abandonment? What am I to do in the end?"

**[One]**
**[One] Subcommentary:** *Nài hé* (奈何) means "how" or "what to do." Though the River Lord comprehends the lofty principle, he has not yet grasped its ultimate purport, so he further seeks resolution of his doubts, hoping to hear an explanation. I wish to dwell in the world of men, safeguard my person, and cultivate the Dao—what should I do, and what should I not do? In matters of yielding and accepting, advancing and withdrawing, and the myriad affairs of things, how should I proceed? I beg your instruction, that I may follow it all my life.

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: "From the perspective of the Dao, what is noble and what is base? This is called *fǎn yǎn*—reversal and recurrence. To constrain the will and cling to it is to greatly obstruct the Dao.

What is few and what is many? This is called *xiè shī*—alternation and application. To act with singular purpose is to be at odds with the Dao.

Solemn as a state with its ruler, yet without private virtue; reverent as a sacrifice with its altar, yet without private blessing; boundless as the four directions without end, without demarcation or boundary.

Embracing all things, who bears them up? This is called *wú fāng*—without fixed direction. All things are equal; what is short and what is long? The Dao has no end or beginning, while things have death and life, yet it does not rely on their completion. Now empty, now full, they do not abide in their forms.

Years cannot be lifted; time cannot be halted. Dissolution and growth, fullness and emptiness—when one ends, another begins. This is how we speak of the great principle’s direction and discuss the pattern of the myriad things.

The arising of things is like galloping, like racing—no movement without change, no moment without shift. What is to be done? What is not to be done? They will naturally transform of themselves."

**[One] Subcommentary:** *Fǎn yǎn* means "reversal and recurrence." Nobility and baseness arise from delusive attachment. When viewed through the principle of emptiness and penetration, the noble revert to baseness, and the base revert to nobility—hence it is called *fǎn yǎn*.

**[Two] Subcommentary:** *Ér* means "you." One who cultivates the Dao should act with spontaneity. Yet you constrain and cling to your will, holding fast with pride—thus you obstruct and fail to harmonize with the Dao of emptiness and penetration.

**[Three] Subcommentary:** *Xiè* means "to replace"; *shī* means "to apply." Things may gather the few to become many or scatter the many to become few, so their application alternates without constancy.

**[Four] Subcommentary:** Alternation and application, few and many, adapt to the moment, changing with the occasion—thus they equalize things. To act with singular purpose is to fail to merge with the principle.

**[Five] Subcommentary:** One who embodies the Dao appears majestic, guiding the myriad realms as a ruler guides a state. Nurturing the people, they bestow no private virtue.

**[Six] Subcommentary:** *Yóu yóu* describes their towering presence. Like the people’s sacrifices to the altar, the altar bestows no private blessing.

**[Seven] Subcommentary:** *Fàn fàn* describes their boundless reach. The sage’s resolve is impartial, aiding all beings with universal love. Like the four directions, vast and endless, how could there be boundaries or limits?

**[Eight] Subcommentary:** *Huái* means "to embrace"; *shú* means "who." The great sage’s compassion embraces all beings, yet their response is impartial—who would presume to support or uplift them?

**[Nine] Subcommentary:** Like a bright mirror or a deep valley, they adapt to every circumstance without fixed direction.

**[Ten] Subcommentary:** All things, though varied, are equally nurtured. The duck and the crane differ in length, yet each is sufficient in its nature.

**[Eleven] Subcommentary:** Death and life are but endless transformations, not true endings or beginnings. The Dao of emptiness and penetration has no end or beginning, while clinging things falsely calculate death and life. As the *Laozi* says: "Going ahead, one does not see its head; following behind, one does not see its tail."

**[Twelve] Subcommentary:** Responding to things without fixed direction, transcending and transforming alone—how could they rely on opposition to achieve completion?

**[Thirteen] Subcommentary:** They do not take form as their position and cling to it without change.

**[Fourteen] Subcommentary:** It is like yin and yang—spring gives life, autumn brings death; fullness and emptiness transform, flourishing and withering follow the seasons. How could one cling to form and skeleton, rigidly adhering to names and positions!

**[Fifteen] Annotation:** One wishes to lift it and make it depart, yet cannot.

**Explication:** *Lìng qù* (令去): *lìng* as in "command," *qù* rhyming with 呈 (*chéng*).

**[Sixteen] Annotation:** One wishes to halt it and make it stay, yet cannot.

**[Seventeen] Subcommentary:** Whether years are cut short or prolonged, whether time is fleeting or drawn out, all emerges from Heaven’s principle—it is not up to man. Thus, its coming cannot be lifted to make it depart, nor its going halted to make it stay; both must be entrusted to their course, for it has never been other than the self.

**[Eighteen] Annotation:** Transformation renews daily, never clinging to the old.

**[Nineteen] Subcommentary:** Yin wanes as yang waxes, summer’s fullness yields to winter’s emptiness; the qi’s sequence cycles endlessly, returning to its beginning. The Way of undifferentiated completion renews daily through transformation, proceeding straight ahead in accord with principle—no need for deliberate effort.

**[Twenty] Subcommentary:** The preceding discourse of Hai Ruo precisely expounds the meaning of the great Dao and elucidates the profound principle of the myriad things.

**[Twenty-One] Annotation:** One should simply follow its function.

**[Twenty-Two] Subcommentary:** Arising and perishing, flowing and fading—all ceaselessly in motion, swift as a gallop. Even a hundred years pass in a flash; why fixate on such things!

**[Twenty-Three] Annotation:** Thus, it cannot be grasped or clung to.

**[Twenty-Four] Subcommentary:** Flowing movement and transformation, the shifting of eras—swift as an arm’s turn, fleeting as a crack’s passage. Never has there been speech that moves without transformation, or words that mark time without change.

**[Twenty-Five] Annotation:** If one acts or refrains from acting amid these intervals, one disrupts their spontaneous transformation.

**[Twenty-Six] Subcommentary:** The myriad things, though tangled, all receive their nature from Heaven. At peace and entrusted to their course, they must transform of themselves—why trouble over acting or not acting!

**Textual Note:**
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition reads *fàn* (泛).
(2) Zhao’s edition includes one additional character below.

River Lord said, "If so, then why value the Dao?"

**Annotation:** Because it transforms of itself.

**Subcommentary:** If acting and not acting were indistinguishable, then the principles of the common and the sage would be equal. Since one entrusts oneself to the spontaneity of transformation, why value the supreme Dao? The River Lord raises this question again, lingering over his doubt.

North Sea Lord said, "One who knows the Dao must penetrate principle; one who penetrates principle must be clear about adaptability; one who is clear about adaptability does not allow things to harm oneself.

The one of utmost virtue—fire cannot burn, water cannot drown, cold and heat cannot harm, birds and beasts cannot injure.

This does not mean one treats them lightly. It means discerning safety and danger, finding peace amid fortune and misfortune, being cautious in approach and retreat, so that nothing can harm one.

Thus it is said: Heaven is within, humanity without; virtue resides in Heaven.

Knowing the conduct of Heaven and humanity, rooted in Heaven, positioned in attainment—advancing and retreating, bending and extending, returning to the essential and speaking of the ultimate."

**Annotation:** One who knows the Dao knows its inability to act. If it cannot act, how could it generate me? I am born naturally, and my four limbs, hundred parts, five viscera, and spirit are already complete without acting—what further intention could there be after their formation?

One who penetrates this principle must be able to relinquish excessive knowledge, abandon the sentiment of preserving life, and ride transformation to respond with adaptability. Thus, one does not allow externals to injure the internal, nor things to harm oneself, and so remains constantly whole.

**Subcommentary:** One who can know the Dao of emptiness and penetration must penetrate the profound and mysterious principle of reality. One who penetrates this principle must be clear about the adaptability in responding to things. Having grasped the boundless nature of adaptability and reality, one can thus rest in transformation, untroubled by life and death. How could external things cause harm?

This answers the River Lord’s doubt and next clarifies the value of the supreme Dao.

**Annotation:** Where the mind finds peace, danger cannot endanger; where intention is without obstruction, suffering cannot afflict.

**Subcommentary:** The one of utmost virtue is one who has attained the supreme Dao. Though blending light with the world and dwelling in the dust of the vulgar, they are not assailed by the four seasons nor harmed by the three disasters. Having attained this internally, externals cannot injure them. This clarifies the value of understanding the Dao.

**Annotation:** Though the mind finds peace, one does not allow it to be violated.

**Subcommentary:** *Bó* means "to treat lightly." That water and fire do not invade, and birds and beasts do not harm, arises from the mind’s peace—what could injure cannot injure. Not only does one not avoid them, but one also does not treat them lightly.

**Annotation:** Knowing it cannot be escaped.

**Subcommentary:** That what could injure cannot injure is precisely because one discerns safety and danger, follows them without escape, and abides in constant accord.

**Annotation:** Finding peace in what fate encounters.

**Subcommentary:** *Nìng* means "peace." Misfortune is blockage and obstruction; fortune is passage and attainment. The one of utmost virtue follows whatever arises, embodying the mandate of fortune and misfortune, penetrating the gatelessness of fortune and misfortune. Thus, what they delight in is not fortune or misfortune, and what they encounter is always peace.

**Annotation:** Discerning what to approach and retreat from as not one’s own.

**Subcommentary:** Cautious in the indeterminacy of approach and retreat, discerning the timeliness of taking and abandoning—though following things in their changes, one always dwells in the most fitting.

**Annotation:** Not taking harm as harm, thus nothing can harm one.

**Subcommentary:** Unified in safety and danger, obscure in fortune and misfortune, moving with transformation—thus, nothing can injure. This summarizes the preceding meaning of being unharmed.

**Annotation:** The natural is within, and what the natural follows is without. Thus, the *Great Master* says, "One who knows what Heaven and humanity do attains the utmost." This clarifies that the division of internal and external is not a matter of acting.

**Subcommentary:** The natural nature is concealed within the heart; what human affairs follow lies in external traces—neither is a matter of acting. Entrusting oneself to spontaneity, thus nothing can harm one.

**Annotation:** Indulging human knowledge leads to dissipation and loss of the original.

**Subcommentary:** The beauty of utmost virtue lies in the natural. If one indulges human knowledge, the natural nature is dissipated.

**Annotation:** This is the knowledge of the natural, acting without exceeding its bounds. Thus, though acting externally, it is always rooted in Heaven and positioned in attainment.

**Subcommentary:** This is true knowledge. *Wèi* means "to dwell." Acting in the world with true knowledge, though encountering the myriad changes of things, one always takes the natural as the root, dwelling in emptiness and extremity without losing one’s nature—active yet tranquil.

**Annotation:** Responding to opportunities brings about these changes.

**Subcommentary:** *Zhí* describes the appearance of indecision in advance and retreat. The perfected one responds to the world, following the turbidity and clarity of things, now bending, now extending, without fixed attachment, meeting and parting in dark accord to suit the moment.

Though mingling among the common folk, the heart remains ever serene and still, ever abiding in the pivotal essence and returning to the root to restore the source. All speech arises from the utmost emptiness, movement never departing from stillness, words never departing from silence.

**Subcommentary:** *Fǎn yào* is pronounced *yú miào*.

**Collation:** A variant from the Jiangnan ancient repository reads *tiān* as *hū*.

He asked: "What is meant by Heaven? What is meant by man?"

**Subcommentary:** As the River Lord has not yet grasped the profound mystery, he raises this doubt, inquiring about the Way of Heaven and man, hoping for an answer to follow.

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: "That oxen and horses have four legs is called Heaven; to bridle a horse’s head or pierce an ox’s nose is called man. Thus it is said: Do not let man obliterate Heaven, do not let the artificial obliterate fate, do not let attainment be sacrificed for fame. Guard this carefully and do not lose it—this is called returning to one’s true nature."

**Annotation:** In life, can one do without yoking oxen or riding horses? And in yoking oxen or riding horses, can one do without piercing or bridling them? Oxen and horses do not refuse to be pierced or bridled, for this is the natural course of their fate. If it accords with fate, then though entrusted to human affairs, the root still lies in Heaven.

**Subcommentary:** Oxen and horses receive their four legs from Heaven, naturally, without relation to human affairs—thus this is called Heaven. To rein a horse’s head or pierce an ox’s nose arises from human intention—thus this is called man. Yet that an ox’s nose may be pierced or a horse’s head bridled, though they know not why, nor discern the cause, though the matter is entrusted to human sentiment, the principle ultimately returns to the Creator. To illustrate the unity of the Way of Heaven and man, he thus takes the two beasts, ox and horse, as examples.

**Annotation:** Piercing and bridling are permissible, but if one overworks them, driving them beyond measure or causing their steps to lose rhythm, then the heavenly principle is obliterated.

**Subcommentary:** To apply human affairs in accordance with nature is permissible for bridling and yoking. But if one pierces horses or bridles oxen contrary to creation, this may be called pursuing the falsity of human sentiment and obliterating the natural principle of Heaven.

**Annotation:** If one does not follow what arises spontaneously but instead acts with deliberate contrivance, where then is fate?

**Subcommentary:** To act in accord with one’s nature, without exceeding measure, is to reach a thousand miles while preserving fate. But if one spurs a nag to urge a steed, driving it beyond rhythm, this is to destroy the heavenly principle with human sentiment and artificial affairs, endangering life to the point of imminent ruin—where then is fate? Not only horses and oxen, but all things are thus.

**Annotation:** What one attains has its proper measure; to sacrifice it for fame is excess.

**Subcommentary:** Fame that may be sacrificed is boundless, while what one attains by nature is limited. If one sacrifices limited attainment for boundless fame, then the heavenly principle is obliterated and one’s nature and life are lost.

**Annotation:** The true lies within one’s inherent nature.

**Subcommentary:** Whether foolish or wise, short-lived or long-lived, impoverished or prosperous, honored or disgraced—all are received from nature, each having its proper measure. Only by carefully guarding and holding fast, not pursuing external things, attaining what lies within one’s measure without losing the Way, may one be said to return to the root and restore the source, recovering one’s true nature. This sentence summarizes the preceding profound principle.

Kui pities the centipede, the centipede pities the snake, the snake pities the wind, the wind pities the eye, the eye pities the heart.

**Subcommentary:** *Lián* means "to cherish" or "to esteem." Kui is a one-footed beast, its form like a drum, its foot resembling a human foot but with its heel turned forward. The *Shanhai Jing* states: "Within the Eastern Sea, there is Mount Liubo. On this mountain is a beast resembling an ox, dark in color, without horns, with one foot, that moves swiftly. Its voice is like thunder, and it is called Kui. Formerly, the Yellow Emperor, in his campaign against Chiyou, used Kui’s hide to cover a drum, and its sound carried five hundred miles." The centipede has many feet, and Kui, with few, envies its many—thus it pities the centipede. The centipede, having more than it lacks, pities the snake. The snake, small, envies the great—thus it pities the wind. The wind, dark, admires the bright—thus it pities the eye. The eye, external, admires the internal—thus it pities the heart. This illustrates that all things under Heaven receive their nature from the natural, and whether bright or dark, existent or nonexistent, there is no need for envy. Released and allowed to follow their course, they naturally accord with the mysterious Dao. Those who invert priorities, vainly admiring with deluded hearts, are thus presented with the coarse examples of Kui and the others to clarify the subtle principle of the heavenly mechanism.

Another interpretation: *lián* means "to pity." Kui, with one foot, leaps and bounds, and pities the centipede’s many feet as burdensome. The centipede, with feet, moves easily, and pities the snake’s footlessness as laborious. The snake, having form, enjoys comfort, and pities the wind’s formlessness as obscure. The wind, drifting freely, pities the eye’s confinement to form as stagnant. The eye, external and bright, pities the heart’s internal obscurity. This illustrates the inversion of things’ natures, vainly arising in pity, and thus takes Kui and the centipede as examples to cure such afflictions.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Kuí* is pronounced *qiú guī*, a one-footed beast. Li says: During the Yellow Emperor’s reign, the feudal lords on Mount Liubo in the Eastern Sea obtained a strange beast resembling an ox, dark in color, without horns, with one foot, that could run swiftly. Entering or exiting water brought wind and rain, its eyes shone like the sun and moon, and its voice was like thunder. It was called Kui. The Yellow Emperor killed it and took its hide to cover a drum, and its sound carried five hundred miles.
*Lián* is pronounced *lián*.
*Xiàn* is pronounced *xián*, or *xuán*. Sima says: It is the centipede. The *Guangya* says: *qū qú mǎ xiàn* (a kind of centipede).
*Sima says:* Kui has one foot; the centipede, many feet; the snake, no feet; the wind, no form.

The eye’s form is fixed here, yet its brightness flows there; the heart’s essence is subtle, its spirit roaming beyond. Kui said to the centipede: "With my single foot I stride and leap—nothing compares to me. Now you deploy ten thousand feet—how do you manage it?"

**[Note 1]**
**[Annotation 1]** *Striding and leaping* means bounding and prancing. I bound and prance with one foot, moving with joy, for the world is simple—none compare to me. Yet you drive ten thousand feet—are you not wearied by toil? How is your birth so unlike other creatures? This question is posed to reveal the workings of heaven’s mechanism.

**[Phonetic Gloss]**
*Chěn* (踸): *chì shèn* (敕甚) in Fanqie, Guo reads *tú jiǎn* (菟减), another reading *chū bǐn* (初禀).
*Zhuó* (踔): The base text also writes it as *zhuó* (踔), identical.
*Chì* (敕): *chì jué* (敕角).
Li says: *□zhuó* (□卓) is the manner of walking.
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The modern text writes *zhuó* (踔) for *zhuó* (卓).
◎ Qingfan observes: *Zhuó* (卓) means standing alone, sharing sound and sense with *zhuó* (踔).
The *Book of Han*’s "Biography of King Xian of Hejian" reads *zhuó ěr bù qún* (卓尔不群), and the *Shuo Yuan*’s "Jun Dao" chapter has *zhuó rán dú lì* (踔然独立).
(*Zhuó* (踔): *chì jué* (敕角).)
The *Shuowen* says: *□* (*zhú jué* (竹角)).

") denotes standing alone. Xu Kai’s *Xizhuan* states: “Standing alone” means standing tall and erect. It is also written as *zhuō* (踔) or *chuō* (逴). The *Guangya* says: *Zhuō* (踔) means “to transcend.” Li Shan’s commentary on the *Xidu Fu* notes: *Chuō* (逴) (*jiù jué* cut) and *lì* (跞) both mean “to surpass” or “to excel.” Their meanings are identical.

The millipede said: “Not so. Have you not seen one who spits? When ejected, the large droplets are like pearls, the small like mist, and those scattered in between are too numerous to count. Now, when I set my natural mechanism in motion, I do not know how it comes to be so.”

**[Annotation]**
**[1]** **[Exegesis]** When one spits, there is no deliberate intention regarding size, yet the sizes of the droplets naturally differentiate. Thus, the large are like pearls, the small like drifting mist, and the scattered fall in countless numbers. Now, the millipede’s multitude of feet are but the natural mechanism of heaven, moving and advancing without conscious effort—unintentional yet fully extended, much like the act of spitting. Kui posed the question from a human perspective, while the millipede answered directly from the workings of nature. The inherent principle is thus self-evident.

**[Phonetic Gloss]**
*Tuò* (唾): *tǔ wò* cut.
*Pēn* (喷): *pǔ mèn* cut, also *fāng bēn* cut, or *fú wèn* cut.
*Rú wù* (如雾): *wù* (务), Guo reads *wǔ gòng* cut.
*Kě shèng* (可胜): *shēng* (升).
◎ Qingfan notes: Li Shan’s commentary on Lu Ji’s *Wen Fu* cites Sima’s gloss: “Natural mechanism” means “spontaneous.” The *Shiwen* omits this.
**[Collation]**
**[1]** The Zhao Jianyi edition omits the character *yě* (也).

The millipede said to the snake, “I move with many feet, yet I do not match you who have no feet—why is this?”

**[Annotation]**
The millipede, with its many feet, is slow, while the snake, with no feet, is swift. Yet slowness and speed, presence and absence, are bestowed by creation. To clarify this principle, the question is thus raised.

The snake replied, “How can one alter the movement of the celestial mechanism? What need have I for feet?”

**[Commentary]**
When things come into being, they do not know they are being born. Likewise, when they move, do they know they are moving? Thus, the feet do not know how to walk, the eyes do not know how to see, and the mind does not know how to know—yet all proceed effortlessly of their own accord. The rhythm of slowness and speed, the clarity of perception, whether one excels or falls short—none of this belongs to me. Those who are deluded seek to claim their bodies and boast of their abilities, thereby resisting the celestial mechanism and harming their spiritual vessel. The perfected person knows the celestial mechanism cannot be altered, so they discard cleverness, abandon cunning, and, in utter oblivion, forget their actions and entrust themselves to spontaneous movement. Thus, in all things, there is no movement that is not free and unbound.

**[Annotation]**
The natural mechanism possesses this inherent function; slowness and speed, presence and absence, cannot be changed. Moving without intent, what need is there for feet?

**[Phonetic Gloss]**
*Miǎnrán* (俛然): *máng běn* cut.

**[Collation]**
**[1]** The Zhao Jianyi edition omits the character *yě* (也).
**[2]** The Zhao edition omits the characters *zāi gù* (哉故).
**[3]** The Zhao edition omits the character *yě* (也).

The snake said to the wind, “When I move my spine and ribs to advance, there is something to it. Yet you arise in a great rush from the Northern Sea and rush into the Southern Sea, appearing as though nothing exists—why is this?”

The **Annotation** states: *Xié* (胁) means "ribs." *Péngpéng* (蓬蓬) denotes the sound of wind, or the appearance of dust stirred into motion. Since the snake has no feet, it must rely on the movement of its spine and ribs to advance. *Sì* (似) means "resemblance." Though the snake lacks feet, it possesses form and likeness, whereas the wind, formless and boundless, stirs without direction—from the Northern Sea to the Southern Sea, lashing the vast ocean, invisible yet forceful. The snake harbors this doubt and thus poses the question, hoping to hear the wind’s reply.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*Péngpéng* (蓬蓬): *bù dōng* (步东) *fǎn*, *xú fú gōng* (徐扶公) *fǎn*. Li [Yun] says: the appearance of wind.
◎ Jia Shifu notes: In the *Yùpiān*, *sì* (似) means "to resemble." That by which one moves is the feet; to move by means of the spine and ribs is to lack feet yet still resemble feet. What has form has resemblance; what is formless has nothing to resemble.

The wind replied: "Indeed. I arise *péngpéng* from the Northern Sea and enter the Southern Sea. Yet if you point at me, you overpower me; if I contend with myself, I too am overpowered. Nevertheless, only I can snap great trees and topple vast halls—thus, my many small defeats are my great victory. To achieve such great victory is the sole province of the sage."

**Commentary:**
To follow the natural mechanism without contention is to be defeated in small things. Yet to harness the myriad things and govern the multitude of talents, allowing each talent to fulfill itself and each thing to act according to its nature, is to render all under heaven carefree—this is how the sage achieves great victory.

**Annotation:**
Though the wind travels from north to south, lashing the vast seas, if a person points a finger at it, the wind cannot break the finger; if one stamps a foot upon it, the wind cannot break the foot—these are its small defeats. Yet when a sudden whirlwind rises, twisting like a ram’s horn, it can send great halls flying and shatter sacred oaks—this is its great victory. It is like the enlightened sage who, though mingling with the foolish and stirring up dust amid the clamor of right and wrong, suffers small defeats. Yet in nurturing all living things and shaping the cosmos, matching the encompassing embrace of heaven and earth and the illuminating radiance of sun, moon, and stars, the sage achieves great victory. This is beyond the comprehension of ordinary minds; only the sage can attain it.
◻︎ Some texts write this character as *jiè* (藉), meaning "to trample." This interpretation is not adopted here.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
◻︎ *Qiū* (□) *yǐn*. Li [Yun] says: "to trample," which implies "to cut down." Another version writes it as *cù* (□), *zǐ liù* (子六) *fǎn*, or *qī liù* (七六) *fǎn*, meaning "to press."
◎ Jia Shifu notes: Li Gui says, "to trample," which implies "to cut down." Another version writes it as *cù* (□).
*Zhǐ* (指) means "to point with the hand"; *cù* (□) means "to stamp with the foot."

The *Xunzi*’s "Strengthening the State" states: "The mighty Chu hangs before me, the great Yan presses behind me, the formidable Wei hooks to my right." Yang Liang’s commentary: "踧 means 'to trample,' speaking of being trodden upon from behind." *Zhe* (折) is pronounced with the *she* (舌) initial reversed. *Fei* (蜚) is read as *fei* (飞), or alternatively as *fu gui* (扶贵) reversed.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The Zhao Jianyi edition omits the characters *zhe ye* (者也).
(2) The Zhao edition omits *mo bu* (莫不).
(3) The Zhao edition omits *nai* (乃).
(4) The character *gai* (盖) is deleted following the *Shiwen*.

Confucius traveled to Kuang, where men of Song besieged him repeatedly, yet he continued his zither-playing and singing without pause.
Zilu entered to see him and asked, "Why does the Master remain so joyful?"

**Commentary:**
*Chuò* (辍) means "to cease." *Song* should be *Wei*, a scribal error. Kuang was a town in Wei. Confucius, traveling from Lu to Wei, passed through Kuang. Earlier, Yang Hu had raided and oppressed the people of Kuang, and Confucius resembled him in appearance. Moreover, Confucius’ disciple Yan Ke had once joined Yang Hu in oppressing Kuang and was now serving as Confucius’ charioteer. The people of Kuang, seeing Confucius’ resemblance to Yang Hu and Yan Ke driving his chariot, mistook him for Yang Hu’s return and thus mobilized troops to surround him. Confucius, understanding the inevitability of fate’s vicissitudes, continued his zither-playing and singing without interruption.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*Confucius traveled to Kuang, where men of Song besieged him repeatedly*: *sè zhǔ* (色主) reversed.
*Chuò* (辍): *zǐ hé* (子合) reversed.
Sima [Biao] says: *Song* should be *Wei*. Kuang was a town in Wei. The people of Wei mistakenly besieged Confucius, taking him for Yang Hu. Hu had once oppressed the people of Kuang, and Confucius’ disciple Yan Ke had been with him at the time. Later, Ke served as Confucius’ charioteer. Upon arriving in Kuang, the people recognized Ke, and seeing Confucius’ resemblance to Hu, they surrounded him.
*Bù chuò* (不惙): Another version writes *chuò* (辍), same pronunciation: *dīng liè* (丁劣) reversed.

[II] [Subcommentary] *Yú* (娱) means "joy." Since the people of Kuang had already surrounded him, by reason he should have been anxious and fearful—yet he continued his zither-playing and singing without cease. Why was this so? Not comprehending the Sage’s state of mind, they thus raised this question. Some versions also write *yú* (虞), meaning "anxiety." They wondered why the Master, though beset by cares, still did not cease his zither-playing and singing.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*Rù jiàn* (入見): *xián biàn* (賢遍) reversed.

**Textual Note:**
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s version writes *chuò* (辍).

Confucius said: "Come! Let me tell you. I have long avoided adversity, yet cannot escape it—this is fate. I have long sought success, yet cannot attain it—this is timing. (1) In the age of Yao and Shun, there were no men of adversity in the world, not because of their wisdom in gaining; in the age of Jie and Zhou, there were no men of success in the world, not because of their wisdom in losing. The circumstances of the times made it so. (2) He who travels by water without avoiding dragons and serpents is the courage of the fisherman; he who travels by land without avoiding rhinoceroses and tigers is the courage of the hunter; (3) he who faces crossed blades before him and regards death as life is the courage of the hero; (4) he who knows adversity is governed by fate, knows success comes with timing, and faces great peril without fear—this is the courage of the Sage. (5) You may rest now, for my fate is determined by what governs it."

[I] [Commentary] To clarify the inevitability of timing and fate, he thus speaks of seeking and avoiding.

[Subcommentary] *Huì* (讳) means "to shun" or "to resist." *Qióng* (穷) means "obstruction" or "adversity." *Tōng* (通) means "prosperity" or "success."

The Master summoned Zhong You and spoke to him of the ultimate principle, saying: "I have shunned adversity yet cannot escape it—is this not Heaven’s decree? I have long sought success yet cannot attain it—is this not due to the absence of an enlightened era? As for timing and fate, their coming cannot be resisted, their going cannot be detained. Thus, to be at ease and yield to them is to find harmony in all circumstances."

The Master wished to make this principle clear, so he framed it in terms of adversity and avoidance, though in truth there is no adversity to avoid.

[II] [Commentary] Do not weary the mind over adversity and success.

[Subcommentary] When one lives in the time of Yao and Shun, the world is at great peace, and people are like vessels, free within their allotted bounds—thus there is no obstruction. When one lives in the time of Jie and Zhou, the world is in violent chaos, and all things lose their nature—thus there are no successful men. Yet whether the times are level or perilous is determined by circumstances, not by the wisdom or folly of one’s fate, which brings such gains and losses.

[III] [Commentary] Each disposition finds its own peace.

[Subcommentary] When one’s disposition finds peace, fear is forgotten. This begins the analogy.

[IV] [Commentary] The Sage finds peace in all things.

[Subcommentary] The Sage understands timing and fate, grasps adversity and success, and thus remains courageous amid peril without ever being unsettled. This concludes the analogy.

[V] [Commentary] Fate is not self-determined, so there is no need to exert the mind. One who is at peace with fate finds freedom wherever they go; thus, even in Kuang, Chen, or Youli, it is no different from resting in the Purple Ultimate’s tranquil hall.

[Subcommentary] *Chǔ* (处) means "to rest" or "to dwell in peace." *Zhì* (制) means "allotted bounds" or "predetermined limits." He admonished Zilu, instructing him to set his mind at ease: "I am endowed with Heaven’s mandate, which has its own limits—how could human effort alter it?"

[Glossary Notes]
*Xián táng* (闲堂): pronounced *xián*. [Variant Readings] (1) The *Quewu* cites the Jiangnan ancient manuscript as reading *yù* (遇). (2) The *Quewu* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition as adding *zhī shí* (之时) after "Yao and Shun" and likewise after "Jie and Zhou."

After no great while, armored soldiers advanced and declared: "We mistook you for Yang Hu, and so we surrounded you. Now that we see it is not so, we beg leave to withdraw." [Subcommentary] *Wú jǐhé* (无几何) means "a brief moment." Once they realized it was Master Xuan Ni rather than Yang Hu, the commanders and their armored troops came forward, bowed in apology, acknowledged their error, and lifted the siege.

[Glossary Notes]
*Wú jǐ* (无几): pronounced *jū qǐ*. *Jiāng jiǎ* (将甲): read as written; some editions read *chí jiǎ* (持甲).

Gongsun Long questioned Wei Mou, saying: "In my youth I studied the Dao of the former kings; in maturity I clarified the practice of benevolence and righteousness. I unite sameness and difference, separate hardness and whiteness; I affirm the un-affirmed, approve the un-approved..."

"I have confounded the wisdom of the Hundred Schools and exhausted the debates of all disputants—I once believed myself to have attained ultimate comprehension. Yet now, hearing the words of Master Zhuang, I am bewildered and struck with wonder. Do I fall short in discourse, or does my understanding pale in comparison? Now I find myself at a loss for words; I venture to ask: what is the Way?"

[Subcommentary 1] *Gongsun* is his clan name, *Long* his given name; he was a native of Zhao. *Wei Mou* was a prince of Wei, one who embraced the Dao and held fast to virtue, disdaining the filth of the world. "Former kings" refers to the legacies of Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang. "Benevolence and righteousness" are the practices of the Five Virtues. Gongsun Long, endowed with keen intelligence and a talent for grand disputation, composed the *Discourse on Guarding the White* and gained renown for his dialectical skill. Thus he could unite difference as sameness and separate sameness as difference; affirm the un-affirmed and approve the un-approved. He challenged the writings of all schools, overpowering them, and silenced every debater, leaving none unvanquished. Born in the declining Zhou, he stood peerless in his time. Disciples such as Kong Chuan revered and followed him, and his name resounded through the age—none dared contest him. Thus he boasted of his learning, believing it to have reached the utmost subtlety. Yet upon encountering Zhuangzi, he was like a frog at the bottom of a well.

[Phonetic Gloss] *Gongsun Long wen yu Wei Mou*: Sima [Biao] says: Long was a man of Zhao; Mou was a prince of Wei. *Shao xue* (少学): *shi* as in *shizhao* (诗照). *Zhang er* (长而): *zhang* as in *zhangzhang* (张丈). *Zhi xing* (之行): *xing* as in *xiameng* (下孟). *Zhi zhi* (之知): *zhi* pronounced *zhi* (智).

[Subcommentary 2] *Hui* means "mouth." *Fang* means "Dao/Way." Though Gongsun Long excelled in rhetoric, he had not yet grasped the profound emptiness of the Dao. Thus, upon hearing Zhuangzi’s words, he was stunned by their strangeness and suddenly realized the shallowness of his own learning, awakening to the depth of Zhuangzi’s speech. Was it merely that his arguments were inferior, or did his intellect and capacity also fall short? Hence he sealed his lips and humbly sought further instruction from Wei Mou.

【Pronunciation Notes】*Mang yan* (茫焉): *mang* as in *mogang* (莫刚), Guo [Xiang] reads *mang* (莽). *Lun zhi* (论之): *lun* as in *likun* (力困). *Ji yu* (及与): pronounced *yu* (余). The following auxiliary phrases follow this pattern. *Suo kai* (所开): read as written; also written as *guan* (关), both acceptable. Alternatively written as *he* (阂). *Wu hui* (吾喙): *hui* as in *xuhui* (许秽), or *changrui* (昌锐).

Prince Mou leaned against his desk, sighed deeply, looked up to the sky, and laughed, saying: "Have you alone not heard of the frog in the shallow well? It said to the turtle of the Eastern Sea: 'How joyful I am! I leap and bound upon the well’s ledge, then rest at the edge of its broken bricks. When I enter the water, it supports my armpits and cradles my chin; when I trample the mud, it buries my feet and covers my insteps. I turn to the shrimp, crabs, and tadpoles—none can compare to me. Moreover, to monopolize the water of a single ravine and straddle the joy of this shallow well—this is perfection itself! Why do you not come in from time to time to see for yourself?'

The turtle of the Eastern Sea had not yet placed its left foot inside when its right knee was already stuck. Thereupon it retreated and withdrew, then told the well-frog of the sea: 'A distance of a thousand *li* is insufficient to convey its vastness; a height of a thousand *ren* is insufficient to measure its depth. In the time of Yu, floods came nine years out of ten, yet the waters did not increase; in the time of Tang, drought struck seven years out of eight, yet the shores did not diminish. Unchanged by the passage of moments or ages, unmoved by abundance or scarcity—this is the great joy of the Eastern Sea.'

Upon hearing this, the frog in the shallow well was startled and dumbfounded, utterly at a loss."

The noble scion embodied the Dao in purity and loftiness, transcending the mundane world. He discerned the shallow sophistry of Sun Long and perceived the profound words of Zhuangzi. Thus, he sighed toward heaven and scoffed in amusement, citing the two parables of the frog and the turtle to clarify the victory and defeat of the two.

The "shallow well" refers to a shallow pit. The "frog" is a toad. The *gan* is the well’s railing. The *zhou* are the bricks layered within the well. The *fu* is the instep of the foot. The *huan* means to glance back. The *han* is a red worm in the well, also said to be a cocooned grub. The *xie* is a small crab. The *kedou* are tadpoles. The *ye* is beneath the arm. The *yi* is beneath the mouth.

The turtle of the Eastern Sea, vast and immense in form, roams and plays upon the waves, dwelling briefly upon the flatlands. Yet the toad and the tiny creatures, confined to the shallow well—both inferior in form and cramped in dwelling—believed themselves content within the well. Unafraid even upon seeing the great turtle, they declared:

"When I emerge, I leap and prance upon the well’s railing; when I enter, I rest beside the broken bricks. Swimming, I touch my armpits and support my chin; wading through mud, I sink my insteps and submerge my feet. Glancing around at creatures like shrimp and crabs, gazing down at the tadpoles below—carefree and joyous, none compare to me."

**Phonetic and Lexical Notes:**
*Yinji* (《隐机》): pronounced *yú jìn* (于靳反).
*Daxi* (《大息》): pronounced *tài* (音泰).
*Kanjing* (《埳井》): pronounced *kǎn* (音坎); Guo [Pu] reads it as *xiàn* (郭音陷).
*[Zhi]* (《之》): an alternate version writes it as *wa* (蛙), pronounced *huò wō* (户蜗反).
Sima [Biao] says: *Kanjing* means a ruined well. *[Zhi]* is an aquatic creature resembling a toad.
◎ Qing Fan’s note: The *Xunzi Zhenglun* commentary cites Sima [Biao] as saying: *[Zhi]* is a kind of toad, differing slightly from the *Shiwen*.
*Zhi bie* (《之鳖》): pronounced *bì miè* (必灭反). The character is also written as *biē* (鳖).
*Wu le* (《吾乐》): pronounced *luò* (音洛). The *le* in the following *zhi le* (之乐) and *da le* (大乐) is pronounced the same.
*Tiao* (《跳》): pronounced *tiáo* (音条).
*Jinggan* (《井干》): pronounced *gǔ dàn* (古旦反).
Sima [Biao] says: It means the well railing.
Chu Quanzhi reads it as in the *Xijing Fu*, where it is pronounced *hán* (as in the *Xijing Fu*).
◎ Qing Fan’s note: The *Wen Xuan* commentary on Ban Mengjian’s *Xidu Fu* cites Sima [Biao] as saying: *Jinggan* is the well railing, constructed by stacking wood like a fence. The *Xie Yuanyui Tong Que Tai* poem commentary by Xie Hui cites Sima [Biao] as saying: *Gan* is the well railing; however, *jinggan* is also a general term for towers. The explanations differ, but the *Shiwen* citations are the most detailed.
◎ Further note: *Gan* should be written with the wood radical as *gàn* (干). The *Shuowen* standard seal script writes it as □, meaning the well enclosure. The *Hanshu* *Mei Cheng Zhuan* mentions "the breaking of the *shanji*’s *duàn gàn*," where Jin Zhuo says: *Gàn* refers to the four intersecting beams above the well.
*Zhou* (《甃》): pronounced *zè jiù* (侧救反).
Li [Yi] says: It resembles a railing, made of bricks, placed at the bottom of the well as a barrier. The *Zilin* reads it as *zhuàng miù* (壮缪反), meaning the well wall.
*Fushui* (《赴水》): read as written.
Sima’s version writes it as *bó* (踣), meaning "to rush."
◎ Lu Wenchang says: *Fu* (赴) is likely a miswriting of *pu* (仆).
*Jue* (《蹶》): pronounced *jù yuè* (其月反), also *jué* (音厥).
*Nize mozu mie fu* (《泥则没足灭跗》): *fu* is pronounced *fāng yú* (方于反); Guo [Pu] reads it as *fù* (音附).
Sima [Biao] says: *Mie* means "to submerge." *Fu* is the instep.
Li [Yi] says: It describes leaping and bounding in the mud.
*Huan* (《还》): pronounced *xuán* (音旋).
Sima [Biao] says: It means "to glance back."
*Han* (《虷》): pronounced *hán* (音寒), a red worm in wells, also called *yuān* (蜎). The *Erya* says: *Yuān* is *xuān* (蠉). Guo [Pu]’s commentary says: It is a small red worm in wells. *Yuān* is pronounced *qiú yǎn* (求兖反); *xuān* is pronounced *kuàng yǎn* (况兖反). *Ji* is pronounced *jí jué* (吉厥).
*Xie* (《蟹》): pronounced *hù mǎi* (户买反).
*Kedou* (《科斗》): pronounced *kē hé* (苦禾反). *Kedou* are tadpoles.

**Section Two**
**Commentary:** This is like a small bird contenting itself among the reeds.
**Exegesis:** *Shan* means "to monopolize." *Zhi* means "to rest." The frog addresses the turtle as "Master," saying: "I alone monopolize the water of this gully and rest content in the joy of this shallow well—nothing in the world is more satisfying than this. Though my dwelling is humble, it allows for swimming and wading. Why not step down for a moment, Master, and visit this lowly abode?" Thus it boasts and vaunts itself before the turtle.

**Phonetic and Lexical Notes:**
*Fu shan* (《夫擅》): pronounced *shì zhàn* (市战反), meaning "to monopolize."
*Yi he* (《一壑》): pronounced *huǒ gè* (火各反).

**Section Three**
**Commentary:** This illustrates that the great does not roam in the small—not out of delight in doing so.
**Exegesis:** *Zhi* means "to restrain." The shallow well is narrow, while the sea turtle is immense. To embrace the vast within the small is impossible in principle, so no sooner had its right knee descended than it was already constrained. Thus:

**Phonetic and Lexical Notes:**
*Yi zhi* (《已絷》): pronounced *zhū lì* (猪立反).
Sima [Biao] says: It means "to restrain." The *Sancang* says: It means "to fetter."
*Fei le* (《非乐》): pronounced *yuè* (音岳), also *wǔ jiào* (五教反).

**Section Four**
**Exegesis:** *Qunxun* means "leisurely." Seven *chi* make one *ren*. With its left foot not yet entered and its right knee already restrained, the turtle retreated in hesitation and described to the frog the vastness of the sea. Those who consider a thousand *li* distant have not yet grasped the breadth of the sea; those who deem a thousand *ren* high have not yet fathomed its depths.

The vastness and depth of the sea are beyond human measurement—yet you take this pitiful well as the ultimate limit. How inferior this is!

**Phonetic and Lexical Notes:**
*Qun* (《逡》): pronounced *qī xún* (七旬反).

**Section Five**
**Exegesis:** *Qǐng* means "a brief moment," while *jiǔ* means "a long time." *Tuīyí* means "to change and transform." When Yao faced the great flood, he commanded Yu to govern it with success, hence the reference to the age of Yu. Yet in Yao’s ten years, nine were plagued by floods; in Tang’s eight years, seven suffered drought. Though drought came, the cliffs did not diminish; though floods rose, the waters did not increase. This makes clear that the boundless expanse of the sea, its fathomless depths, are not altered by moments or ages, nor do they advance or recede with quantity. Is not the joy of the Eastern Sea found here?

**Phonetic and Lexical Notes:**
*Jiǔ lǎo* (《九潦》): pronounced *lǎo* (音老).
*Fú wéi* (《弗为》): pronounced *yú wěi* (于伪反). The same below.
*Qǐng jiǔ* (《顷久》): Sima [Biao] says: "It means 'early or late.'"

**Section Six**
**Commentary:** To admire the great from the small is to lose oneself.

**Exegesis:** *Shìshì* describes a look of alarm; *guīguī*, a demeanor of self-loss. The frog, boasting of the well’s beauty, claimed nothing in the world surpassed it. But upon hearing the sea turtle’s words, it was stunned, bereft of its former certainty—hence its *shìshì* and *guīguī* demeanor, alarmed and self-lost. Now, Master Gongsun Long studied the Way of the former kings, upheld the practice of benevolence and righteousness, confounded the wisdom of the hundred schools, and exhausted the eloquence of all debaters. Yet upon hearing Zhuangzi’s words, he was like the well-frog encountering the sea turtle.

**Phonetic and Lexical Notes:**
*Shìshì* (《适适》): pronounced *shǐ chì* (始赤反), also *zhàng gé* (丈革反); Guo [Xiang] reads *yú dí* (郭菟狄反).
*Guīguī* (《规规》): read as written, or *xū yì* (虚役反); Li [Yi] and Xu [Kai] read *jì shuì* (徐纪睡反). *Shìshì* and *guīguī* both describe a startled gaze and self-loss.

**Textual Variants:**
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition reads *frog* (蛙).
(2) The Shide Tang edition omits *chū* (出) in "jump up," matching the lacuna; the Jiangnan ancient manuscript reads *chū tiào* (出跳), omitting *liáng* (梁).

Moreover, if one does not even know the limits of right and wrong yet still wishes to examine Zhuangzi’s words, it is like making a mosquito bear a mountain or a centipede race across a river—surely beyond its strength.

Furthermore, if one does not comprehend the ultimate subtlety of discourse yet seeks only momentary advantage, is this not the same as the well-frog?

For the Dao strides across the Yellow Springs and ascends the Great Emperor, unbound by south or north, utterly liberated in all four directions, merging into the unfathomable. Unconfined by east or west, it begins in profound obscurity and returns to great penetration. Yet you seek to measure it with narrow scrutiny and probe it with debate—is this not like using a tube to view the sky or a awl to point at the earth? How petty!

Go now! Have you not heard of the young men of Shouling who went to Handan to learn its walk? Before mastering the state’s skill, they lost their own way and could only crawl home. If you do not leave now, you will forget your original path and lose your former learning.

**Commentary:** All things have their proper measure; one cannot forcibly emulate what is beyond them.

The *shangju* is the centipede, also called *shangju*, or *juqu*. Though Sun Long possessed keen intelligence and natural discernment, his was but worldly knowledge, not true understanding. Thus, to one who has not yet exhausted the realm of right and wrong yet seeks to scrutinize the profound words of Zhuangzi—how does this differ from making a mosquito bear a mountain or a *shangju* race across rivers and seas? Their strength is too feeble for their burden, their wisdom too slight for their ambition; they are surely unequal to the task.

**Exegetical Note:** Sun Long’s learning was narrow and shallow of mind—how could he presume to discuss Zhuangzi’s words, which plumb the subtlest depths? He could only parse right and wrong to chase fleeting fame and profit. To take this as the Dao—is this not like the frog in the shallow well? This concludes the analogy.

**Commentary:** It speaks of that which reaches everywhere.

**Exegetical Note:** *Ci* means to transcend, or to reach the utmost. *Taihuang* is Heaven. *Xuanming* is the wondrous root. *Datong* is the responsive trace. Zhuangzi’s words exhaust the subtleties of principle, ascending to the heights of the azure vault and descending to the depths of the Yellow Springs, traversing the four directions and eight limits with boundless freedom. This wisdom is hidden and unfathomable, beginning in the profoundest obscurity and returning to great penetration, its Dao darkly merging with all things.

**Phonetic Glosses:** *Fangci*: read *ci*; Guo reads *shizi*, also *zemai*. *Guangya* says: to tread, to step, to trample. Sima says: to fathom. *Taihuang*: read *tai*. *Shiran*: read *shi*. *Sijie*: read *humai*. ◎ Qingfan notes: "Unbound by east or west" loses the rhyme; the present text is a later corruption. Wang Niansun says: It should read "Unbound by west or east," rhyming with *tong*. (For example, in the *Da Ya*’s *Huang Yi* ode, "with your brothers" originally rhymed with "king," but now reads "brothers." In the *Yi Zhou Shu*’s *Zhou Zhu* chapter, "harsh and yielding, firm and soft" originally rhymed with "bright and dark, long and short," but now reads "firm and yielding." In the *Guanzi*’s *Nei Ye* chapter, "Can one know good and ill fortune without divination?" originally rhymed with "one," but now reads "ill fortune." In the *Fu Niao Fu*, "some rush east and west" originally rhymed with "same," but now reads "west and east." In the *Da Ke Nan*, "granaries without" originally rhymed with "offering," but now reads "granaries." All these are later corruptions by those who failed to grasp ancient rhymes and altered them at will.)

[4] **Annotation:** Those who roam the boundless cannot be grasped by discernment or debate.
**Exegesis:** *Suo* in *suozhi* is pronounced with the entering tone *bai*.

[5] **Annotation:** If a task is not one’s own, it may be abandoned.
**Subcommentary:** *Guigui* describes the appearance of scheming. To seek the Dao through observation, or to approach it with eloquent discourse and unadulterated sincerity—even if one applies the most meticulous care, one remains far from it. It is like gazing at the heavens through a tube: how could one know their vastness? Or probing the earth with an awl: how could one fathom its depths? Zhuangzi’s Dao harmonizes with the Two Modes; Sun Long’s virtue is no greater than an awl or tube. The disparity in wisdom and capacity is so vast that, since one cannot match him, it is best to depart swiftly.

[6] **Annotation:** To model oneself on another is to lose both.
**Subcommentary:** Shouling was a town in Yan; Handan, the capital of Zhao. *Yuzǐ* refers to youths not yet of age. The customs of Handan were renowned for their walking style, so young men from Yan traveled far to learn it. Yet, having forsaken their nature, they failed to master Zhao’s skill; in imitating others, they lost even their own way. Thus, they ended up crawling home on hands and knees.
**Exegesis:** Sima Biao says: *Shouling* is a town name. *Yuzǐ* refers to those not yet of age for corvée. *Han* is pronounced *han*; *Dan*, *dan*. Handan was the capital of Zhao. ◎ Qing Fan notes: *Yuzǐ* are the younger sons of the people. The *Rites of Zhou*’s *Minor Controller of the Multitude* states: for major state affairs, all citizens are summoned; for great emergencies, even *yuzǐ* are called. Zheng Sinong explains: *Yuzǐ* are surplus troops, so named because they are extra soldiers. In major affairs, the regular troops are summoned; in emergencies, even the surplus are called. The *Lost Books of Zhou*’s *Tiao Kuang* chapter says: in years of plenty, *yuzǐ* practice the arts; in lean years, *yuzǐ* cultivate the fields; in famine years, *yuzǐ* assist in transport. The *Book of Han*’s *Treatise on Food and Goods* also mentions *yuzǐ* in the sequence of studies. Su Lin says: those not yet liable for service are *yuzǐ*—this aligns with Sima’s “not yet of age for corvée.” *Pu* is pronounced *pu*, or *fu*; *fu*, *pubei*, or *fu*.

[7] **Subcommentary:** Zhuangzi’s Dao crowns the profound mystery, transcending all bounds; though Sun Long’s discourse is vast and eloquent, it remains within the world’s confines. Thus, to study Zhuangzi through Sun Long’s words is to grasp nothing of principle. If one’s heart stirs with longing and hesitation, never returning, one will surely lose one’s own learning and forget one’s original steps. This is the fitting analogy.
**Collation:** (1) The Zhao Jianyi edition includes the character *ye* (also).

[The text continues:]
Gongsun Long’s mouth gaped without closing, his tongue lifted without lowering—then he fled in haste.
**Subcommentary:** *Qū* means “to open.” *Yì* means “to flee.” Having heard Zhuangzi’s discourse, which surpassed all hearing and sight, and then encountering Wei Mou’s teachings, which transcended words and forms—

Within, distinctions arose; without, barriers stood—matters beyond Sun Long’s ken. Thus his mouth gaped without closing, his tongue lifted without lowering, and so his spirit wandered in disarray while his body fled in haste.

**Explication of Terms:**
*Kou qu* (口呿): *qu* rhymes with *ju* (據). Sima [Biao] says: “to open.” Li [Yi] reads it as *qu* (袪), also pronounced *jue* (巨劫).

Zhuangzi was angling at Pu River when the King of Chu dispatched two grandees to approach him first, saying: “I wish to burden you with the cares of my realm!”

**Subcommentary:**
Pu is the name of a river, belonging to Dong Commandery; present-day Puyang County in Pu Prefecture. The King of Chu was King Wei of Chu. Zhuangzi’s heart dwelt in nonaction, yet he lodged his traces in angling. The King of Chu, knowing Zhuangzi’s worth and wisdom, sought to bend him to serve as minister and counselor. Thus he dispatched envoys bearing jades and silks, sending them to Pu River to first declare his intent: he wished to entrust the realm’s borders to a worthy man, for the king’s affairs were many and not without their burdens and cares.

**Explication of Terms:**
*Pu River* (濮水): pronounced *bo* (卜), a river in Chen territory.
*King of Chu* (楚王): Sima [Biao] says: King Wei.
*First* (先焉): to declare one’s words beforehand.

Zhuangzi held his rod and did not turn, saying: “I have heard that in Chu there is a divine tortoise, dead now three thousand years, which the king keeps wrapped in silk and stored in a casket upon the ancestral altar. This tortoise—would it rather have died to leave its bones honored, or lived to drag its tail through the mud?”

**Subcommentary:**
The tortoise possesses numinous power, so it is hollowed out for divination, able to decide fortune and misfortune. It is placed in a casket, covered with silk, and stored in the ancestral temple to divine state affairs—thus is it treasured and honored. The question is: “Would this tortoise rather preserve its life and flee harm, dragging its tail through the mire, or would it prefer to be hollowed of its bones to gain renown, honored in the ancestral temple?” Thus did Zhuangzi deeply grasp this truth, and so he haughtily paid no heed.

«**Exegetical Notes**»
*《巾笥》* Xīsì, variant reading Sī.
*《而藏之》* Li [Yun] says: “Stored in a casket, covered with silk.”

Two grandees said: “Better to live and drag one’s tail through the mire.”
**Subcommentary:**
