“《可乐》 is pronounced as *luò*. [12] **Commentary:** What is called "leaving the state and abandoning custom" refers to purging one’s heart. **Subcommentary:** *捐* means to discard. To abandon custom is to walk in mutual support with the Dao of effortless action.

The ruler said, “That Way is distant and perilous, and there are rivers and mountains in between. I have no boats or carriages—what is to be done?” [1] **Commentary:** Truly, this is to urge him to go south to Yue. **Subcommentary:** Delusion and awakening differ in nature, hence the separation between Lu and Yue.

Master Shinan said, “Let Your Lordship not be haughty in form or linger in residence, and I shall make a carriage for you.” [1] **Commentary:** *形倨* means to stumble and be hindered. **Subcommentary:** Do not rely on lofty status or display arrogance in bearing. **Philological Notes:** *无形倨* is pronounced *wú xíng jù*. Sima [Biao] says: “Do not be haughty in form.” *踬* is pronounced *zhì* (also *zhǐ*). *碍* is pronounced *ài*. [2] **Commentary:** *留居* means to stagnate and cling. **Subcommentary:** Follow things as they move, without attachment to glory. **Philological Notes:** *无留居*: Sima [Biao] says: “Do not linger in comfort at one’s residence.” [3] **Commentary:** When form is level with things and the heart transforms with them, one may entrust oneself to things for conveyance.

The ruler said, “That Way is secluded and distant, with no people—with whom shall I be neighbors? I have no provisions, no food—how can I reach it?” [1] **Subcommentary:** Not yet having grasped solitary transformation, he cannot forget things. **Philological Notes:** *我无食*: One version reads *饿* instead of *我*.

Master Shinan said, “Reduce your Lordship’s expenses and diminish your desires, and though you have no provisions, you will yet have enough. [1] **Commentary:** This is what is meant by ‘knowing contentment, there is nothing that is not sufficient.’ **Subcommentary:** The Dao does not rely on things to be complete but is simply serene and indifferent. Let Your Lordship cross the river and float upon the sea. [2] **Subcommentary:** The *river* refers to wisdom; the *sea*, to the Dao. Cross the river of supreme goodness and wander the sea of the Great Dao. Gaze upon it, and you will not see its shores; the farther you go, the more you will not know its end. [3] **Commentary:** This is the remoteness of cutting off passions and desires. **Subcommentary:** How could one know its limit? Those who see you off will all turn back from the shore, and from this point, Your Lordship will be far away. [4] **Commentary:** When the ruler desires to depart, the people each return to guard their proper places. **Subcommentary:** As they see the ruler off on his journey to the realm of the Dao, the people return to their true nature and guard their original roles. *崖* means *boundary*. [5] **Commentary:** To stand transcendent and independent above the myriad things. **Subcommentary:** *自* means *from*. From this, the ruler’s feelings will be lofty, and his Dao and virtue profoundly distant.

Those who possess others become encumbered; those who are possessed by others become anxious. [6] **Commentary:** *有人者* means to possess them as one’s private property. **Subcommentary:** Ruling the state of Lu, with its abundant wealth and people, and claiming them as one’s own, deeply becomes a burden. [7] **Commentary:** *见有于人者* means to be employed and used by others. **Subcommentary:** Not yet having forgotten Lu, being possessed by others, he reveres ghosts, honors the worthy, pities the people, and toils for them—is this not anxiety? Thus, Yao neither possessed others nor was possessed by them. [8] **Commentary:** Though he had the world, he entrusted it to the hundred officials and committed it to the myriad things without partaking in it—this is not possessing others. Following the people and entrusting things without being employed by them—this is not being possessed by others. **Subcommentary:** As Guo’s commentary says: “Though he had the world, he entrusted it to the hundred officials and committed it to the myriad things without partaking in it—this is not possessing others. Following the people and entrusting things without being employed by them—this is not being possessed by others.” **Philological Notes:** *不与* is pronounced *bù yǔ*.

I wish to remove Your Lordship’s encumbrances and dispel your anxieties, that you may wander alone with the Dao in the land of the Great Vastness. [9] **Commentary:** This is to urge him to be utterly free of attachment to his state. **Subcommentary:** *大莫* means *great nothingness*—no one in the world can disturb it. **Philological Notes:** *大莫*: *莫* means *nothingness*.

When two boats are lashed together to cross the river, [10] **Subcommentary:** Two boats joined side by side are called *方舟*. **Philological Notes:** *方舟*: Sima [Biao] says: “*方* means *joined*.” if an empty boat comes and strikes them, even a man of narrow temper will not grow angry. [11] **Subcommentary:** *褊* means *narrow and impatient*. He does not grow angry because the boat is empty. **Philological Notes:** *惼心* is pronounced *biǎn xīn*. The *Erya* says: “impatient.” But if there is a man aboard, he will shout to make him open and close [his course]. If he shouts once and is not heard, and shouts again and is still not heard, then on the third shout, he will surely follow with angry words. [12] **Subcommentary:** *恶声* means *abusive language*. **Philological Notes:** *则呼* is pronounced *zé hū* (and similarly below). *张歙*: *xū* is pronounced *xū jí* (Xu says *xǔ zhé*; Guo’s subcommentary says *shè*). *张* means *to open*; *歙* means *to close*. Formerly he did not grow angry, but now he does; formerly the boat was empty, but now it is full. If a man can empty himself and wander through the world, who can harm him?” [13] **Commentary:** Though the world changes, in emptying oneself to avoid harm, it is one and the same.

The *Subcommentary* states: "Emptying oneself" means having no mind.

**Textual Note:** (1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition has *biān* (褊) for *biǎn* (惼).

Now, Beigong She [1] levied taxes for Duke Ling of Wei to cast bells. He built an altar outside the outer gate of the capital, [2] and in three months completed the upper and lower chimes. [3]

[1] *Subcommentary:* His surname was Beigong, his given name She. He lived in the Northern Palace, hence his surname. He was a grandee of Wei.
*Philological Notes:* Beigong She—Li [Yi] says: a grandee of Wei who lived in the Northern Palace, hence his designation. *She* was his given name.

[2] *Subcommentary:* Bells are the name of a musical instrument. To cast bells, one must first perform a sacrifice, hence the altar.
*Philological Notes:* "For Wei"—pronounced *yú wěi*. "Levied taxes"—pronounced *lì yàn*. "Built an altar"—pronounced *wéi tán*. Li [Yi] says: a sacrifice; one prays, hence the altar.

[3] *Subcommentary:* When the upper and lower tones are tuned, the eight sounds are complete, hence "chimes."
*Philological Notes:* "Upper and lower chimes"—pronounced *shàng xià zhī xuán*. Sima [Biao] says: the eight sounds are complete, forming chimes with high and low pitches.

Prince Qingji of Wang saw this and asked, “What method have you employed?” [1]

[1] *Subcommentary:* Qingji was a son of the Zhou king and a grandee of Zhou. Seeing the exquisite bell-altar, he marveled and asked.
*Philological Notes:* Prince Qingji of Wang—Li [Yi] says: a royal clansman. Qingji was a grandee of Zhou. Marveling at the swift simplicity, he asked.
◎ Yu Yue says: The *Commentary on the Lunyu* states that Wangsun Jia was a grandson of King Ling of Zhou, named Jia, and served as a grandee in Wei at that time. Thus, this Prince Qingji of Wang was likely also a prince of Zhou who served in Wei. Qi also had Prince Chengfu, as seen in the *Zuozhuan* under the eleventh year of Duke Wen.

She replied, “In the interval of unity, I dared not employ any method. [1] I have heard: ‘Once carved, once polished, return to simplicity.’ [2] Vast and without knowledge, [3] carefree and hesitant; [4] gathering in boundless obscurity, sending off the departing and welcoming the arriving; [5] those who come are not forbidden, those who go are not stopped; [6] follow their strength, [7] comply with their crookedness, [8] rely on their self-exhaustion, [9] thus morning and evening levying taxes yet not the slightest harm is done. [10] How much more so for those on the great path!” [11]

[1] *Commentary:* He simply embraced unity, not daring to impose methods to complicate matters.
*Subcommentary:* Guo’s commentary states: He simply embraced unity, not daring to impose methods to complicate matters.
*Philological Notes:* "Simply"—pronounced *bó rán*.

[2] *Commentary:* Return to one’s original nature.
*Subcommentary:* Guo’s commentary states: Return to one’s original nature.

[3] *Commentary:* Let it be in its pure simplicity.
*Subcommentary:* "Vast"—the appearance of having no feelings. Let it be in its pure simplicity.
*Philological Notes:* "Vast"—pronounced *tóng hū* (alternate readings: *tǔ gōng*, *chì dòng*; appearance of ignorance). The *Zilin* says: appearance of greatness. Also pronounced *tòng*.

[4] *Commentary:* Without direction.
*Subcommentary:* "Carefree"—without concern. "Hesitant"—retreating. All matters of doubtful deliberation have departed.
*Philological Notes:* "Carefree"—pronounced *tǎng*.

[5] *Commentary:* Without delight.
*Subcommentary:* "Gathering"—to assemble. Things assemble in boundless obscurity; their coming and going are neither welcomed nor sent off—this is letting things be. Alternatively: in dim confusion, the mind has no certainty, following their welcoming and sending, letting things come and go.
*Philological Notes:* "Gathering"—pronounced *cuì hū*. "Boundless"—pronounced *máng hū*. "Delight"—pronounced *xīn yuè*.

[6] *Commentary:* Let them be.
*Subcommentary:* The people welcome those who come without prohibition and do not detain those who depart.

[7] *Commentary:* Comply with the multitude.
*Philological Notes:* "Strength"—great power.

[8] *Commentary:* Without attachment.
*Subcommentary:* *Zhuàn*—pronounced *zhāng liàn*. Those who are strong and difficult to tax are followed and allowed; those who are crooked in human feelings are complied with and followed.
*Philological Notes:* "Crooked"—pronounced *qū fù*. Sima [Biao] says: those who crookedly attach to oneself are followed. Originally written as *zhuàn*, pronounced *zhāng liàn*.

[9] *Commentary:* Use their inevitability.
*Subcommentary:* Let the people each exhaust their own circumstances.
◎ Jia Shifu says: Levying taxes to cast bells is like the *Zuozhuan* under the twenty-ninth year of Duke Zhao, where the state of Jin was taxed one drum of iron to cast penal tripods—it was called levying taxes but allowed the people to contribute of their own accord, hence "rely on their self-exhaustion." The *Shuowen* says: "Exhaustion" means extremity. It means exhausting all they possess to contribute. Only by not daring to employ methods to seek but purely following nature did the people respond naturally. Today’s levies employ many methods, yet none can prevent the people’s clever evasion of them! Hence it is said: "Once carved, once polished, return to simplicity."

[10] *Commentary:* As before, without harm.
*Subcommentary:* Though taxes were levied, there was no coercion; each followed their nature, hence no harm was done.
*Philological Notes:* "Not harmed"—pronounced *bù cuò*.

[11] *Commentary:* Being at ease without attachment, using the world’s self-direction—this is the great path of thoroughfare. Hence it is said: "Plan it, manage it, and it is accomplished without a day’s effort."

The *Subcommentary* states: "Thoroughfare" means the Dao. Directly allowing things to take their course, without harm to oneself—how much more so when drawing upon the great Dao, where spiritual transformation operates through non-action! It is accomplished in three months—what is strange about this?

*Collation Notes:*
(1) The character *fu* (傅) is amended following the *Shiwen* and the *Shide Tang* edition.
(2) In the Zhao Jianyi edition, *hao* (毫) is written as *hao* (豪).
(3) The character *zhong* (众) is amended following the *Shide Tang* edition.
(4) The character *qing* (情) is suspected to be a miswriting for *qiong* (穷).

Confucius was besieged between Chen and Cai, going seven days without cooked food.

*[1]* *Subcommentary:* King Zhao of Chu summoned Confucius, who traveled from Lu to Chu, passing between the states of Chen and Cai. As the Master’s retinue was large, the people of Chen and Cai mistook him for Yang Hu and thus raised troops to surround him. His disciples suffered from hunger, going seven days without cooked food, pressed to the point of extreme hardship.

Taigong Ren went to offer his condolences, saying: "Were you near death?"
Confucius replied: "Yes."
"Did you detest death?"
Confucius replied: "Yes."

*[1]* *Commentary:* He merely aligned himself with common likes and dislikes; the sage has no likes or dislikes.

*Subcommentary:* *Taigong* is an honorific for elders. *Ren* is his given name. *Ji* means "near." *Ran* means "thus." After Confucius was besieged, Taigong came to offer condolences and asked: "Were you near death?" He answered: "Thus." Taigong then asked: "Did you detest it?" He answered: "Thus."

**Phonetic Glosses:**
*"Da"* is read as *Tai*. *"Gong Ren"* is read as written. Li [Yun] says: *"Da gong"* is a title for high officials; *Ren* is his given name. ◎ Yu Yue notes: The *Guangyun* (1: dong) glosses the character *gong*: *"The* Shiben *records a* Da Gong □ Shu." *Thus, "Da gong" is a compound surname, not a title for officials.* *"Zi ji"* is read as *qi*, also as *ji*. *"Zi wu"* is read with the *wu* in *wulu* (反切: *wu-lu*). The same applies to the annotation below. *"Yu hao"* is read with the *hao* in *huba* (反切: *hu-bao*). The same applies throughout the chapter.

**Textual Note:**
The Zhao Jianyi edition omits the six characters *"Zi wu si hu? Yue: Ran."*

Taigong Ren said: "I have spoken before of the Way of not dying. In the Eastern Sea there is a bird—its name is *Yidai*. As a bird, it is *fenfen-zhizhi*, appearing incapable. It takes flight only with support, and roosts only when pressed close to others. It dares not advance to the front nor retreat to the rear. It dares not eat first but must take the remnants. Thus, it is never singled out in formation, and outsiders never succeed in harming it, so it escapes calamity. The straightest trees are felled first; the sweetest wells run dry first. You, I suspect, adorn your wisdom to startle the foolish, cultivate your person to expose filth, and stride forth as conspicuously as if bearing the sun and moon—how could you escape harm? Long ago, I heard the Perfect One say: *'Those who boast of themselves achieve no merit; those who complete merit collapse; those who achieve fame suffer loss.'* Who can relinquish merit and fame and return to the common fold? The Dao flows but does not shine; it dwells in attainment yet does not claim a place. Pure and constant, it resembles madness. Erasing traces and relinquishing power, it does not pursue merit or fame. Thus, it bears no blame from others, and others bear none from it. The Utmost Person remains unknown—why do you delight in this?"

**Annotations:**
1. *Both expansive and unhurried, yet its mind is free of fixed attachments.*
2. *Always at ease, abiding in the mean.*
3. *It merely follows things as they are.*
4. *Its ranks are never expelled.*
5. *It is thus spared from misfortune.*
6. *Straight trees are felled first; sweet wells are drained first.*
7. *You, I suspect, adorn your wisdom to startle the foolish, cultivate your person to expose filth, and stride forth as conspicuously as if bearing the sun and moon—how could you escape harm?*
8. *'Those who boast of themselves achieve no merit; those who complete merit collapse; those who achieve fame suffer loss.'*
9. *Who can relinquish merit and fame and return to the common fold?*
10. *The Dao flows but does not shine.*
11. *It dwells in attainment yet does not claim a place.*
12. *Pure and constant, it resembles madness.*
13. *Erasing traces and relinquishing power, it does not pursue merit or fame.*
14. *Thus, it bears no blame from others, and others bear none from it.*
15. *The Utmost Person remains unknown—why do you delight in this?*

**Subcommentary:**
To illustrate the Way of longevity, he cites the sea bird as an analogy. *Fenfen-zhizhi* describes its slow, unsteady flight, incapable of soaring high. When flying, it must rely on companions and dares not take the lead; when roosting, it folds its wings tightly, pressed among the flock. ◎ *Fenfen* is read as *fen*; the character may also be written as *□*. *Zhizhi* is read as *zhi* (Xu reads *zu*); the character may also be written as *□*. Sima [Biao] says: *Fenfen-zhizhi* means leisurely and unhurried; another says: it describes low flight. Li [Yi] says: it refers to the sound of wings. *Pressed close to roost*: It dares not roost alone but huddles among the flock, barely finding space to perch—such is its extreme avoidance of harm. ◎ *Advancing not to the front, retreating not to the rear*: Always at ease, abiding in the mean. ◎ *Food not dared to be tasted first*: It merely follows things as they are. ◎ *Advancing and retreating in moderation* is the height of harm-avoidance; *eating and pecking in order* means it must follow the sequence. ◎ *Its remnants*: *Xu* means sequence. ◎ Wang Niansun says: The *Shiwen* states: *Xu* means sequence. This is incorrect. *Xu* means remainder—it dares not eat first but takes only what is left. The *Rangwang* chapter says: *"Its remnants are used for the state."* Sima Biao says: *Xu* means residue, i.e., what remains. The *Jiuzhang* of the *Chuci* says: *"The lingering winds of autumn and winter."* Wang Yi’s annotation: *Xu* means remainder. The *Dizi Zhi* chapter of the *Guanzi* says: *"Offer it as remnants."* Yin Zhichang says: *Xu* refers to candle stubs—stubs are also remnants. (See *Fangyan* and *Guangya*.)

◎ **4** ◎ *Annotation*: It moves with the flock.
◎ *Shiwen*: *Xinglie* (行列): *hùgāng* (户刚) *fǎn* (反). Below, *luanxing* (乱行) is the same. ◎ *Bùchì* (不斥): *chǐ* (尺).

◎ **5** ◎ *Annotation*: Harm and danger arise from employing knowledge in restless striving.
◎ *Exegesis*: By its humility and gentleness, it does not contend with things, so the flock of birds keeps to its ranks, and none is singled out or cast aside. Outsiders, in their haste, cannot harm it—thus it escapes the calamities of the human world.
◎ *Shiwen*: *Zúbù* (卒不): *zǐxù* (子恤) *fǎn* (反), meaning "in the end." ◎ Also *qīhū* (七忽) *fǎn* (反).

◎ **6** ◎ *Annotation*: This is the harm of talent.
◎ *Exegesis*: The straightest trees, being useful, are the first felled; the sweetest wells, being drawn from, are the first to run dry. Those who flaunt talent and wit meet the same fate.

◎ **7** ◎ *Annotation*: To scrutinize minor differences is to set oneself against the multitude; to merge in great sameness is to have no singularity in the world. Thus, what shines brightly is but the trace of what is profoundly obscure. Seeking to convey meaning through words and leave traces behind, he therefore took refuge in Chen and Cai to express his *intent*.
◎ *Exegesis*: This refers to Confucius, whose intent lay in adorning talent and wit to astonish the vulgar, polishing his person and mind to outshine others’ defilement, and displaying his brilliance to dazzle with his abilities.

Just as one who marches bearing the sun and moon aloft cannot escape calamity.

◎ *Exegesis*: Those who, like the great Sages, possess vast virtue and boundless power, giving life to all things, are called "greatly perfected." To fell is to take; to cast down is to ruin. Those who take credit for their abilities achieve no merit, while those who do not withdraw after success are sure to fall. Those whose fame shines brightly, unless they conceal their brilliance, will meet with disgrace.

◎ **9** ◎ *Annotation*: Merit is achieved through the many, so it is returned to them.
◎ *Exegesis*: Who can establish great merit, build towering renown, yet not claim it as their own, but instead attribute it to others? Only the Sage!

◎ **10** ◎ *Annotation*: It moves of itself, dimly and without ostentation.
◎ *Exegesis*: The Dao and virtue flow and fill the world, yet they conceal their brilliance, hence they are called "unilluminated."

◎ **11** ◎ *Annotation*: They all naturally attain this conduct, not by seeking fame before embracing it.
◎ *Exegesis*: Though one’s person is imbued with the Dao and virtue, flourishing in the world, they hide their name and obscure their traces, hence they do not dwell in fame.

◎ **12** ◎ *Annotation*: It moves without intention.
◎ *Exegesis*: "Pure and plain" refers to unadorned nature; "constant and unchanging" refers to blending with things. Without self-aggrandizement, one resembles a madman.

◎ **13** ◎ *Annotation*: Merit is achieved by others, so power does not reside in oneself, and name and traces vanish.
◎ *Exegesis*: Erasing sagely traces, relinquishing authority—how could one cling to merit or dwell on reputation?

◎ **14** ◎ *Annotation*: Following one’s nature and yielding to others, each bears their own responsibility.
◎ *Exegesis*: For this reason, one has no reputation. Since I do not reproach others, they in turn bear no blame toward me.

◎ **15** ◎ *Annotation*: Serene and without attachment, such is the perfected person.
◎ *Exegesis*: The person of utmost virtue does not display themselves in the world. You are sagely and wise—why then delight in fame?

Confucius said, "Excellent!" He then severed ties with his acquaintances, parted from his disciples, and fled to the great marsh. Clad in coarse cloth and deerskin, he ate wild fruits and acorns. Entering among beasts, he did not disrupt their herds; entering among birds, he did not disturb their flocks. Birds and beasts felt no aversion—how much less would humans!

◎ **1** ◎ *Annotation*: He adopted what others had discarded.
◎ *Exegesis*: Having received this admonition, Confucius found it excellent. He then withdrew from his social circles, left his disciples, dissolved his followers, and fled alone into the mountains and marshes. He exchanged his scholar’s robes for coarse cloth and deerskin, and forsook rich foods to eat wild fruits and acorns.

◎ **2** ◎ *Annotation*: Like plants and trees, without intention, they were not feared by birds and beasts.
◎ **3** ◎ *Annotation*: This is an allegory to illustrate the utmost sincerity and trust, moving with things yet remaining beyond harm.

◎ *Exegesis*: Like dead ashes, serene and still; like plants and trees, without emotion—birds and beasts were not startled, so how could humans feel aversion?

Confucius asked Zisang Hu, "I was twice banished from Lu, had a tree felled over me in Song, was forced to erase my traces in Wei, was impoverished in Shang and Zhou, and was besieged between Chen and Cai. I have endured these many hardships, yet my close associates have grown more distant, and my disciples and friends have scattered. Why is this?"

Confucius served as Minister of Justice in Lu. When the people of Qi heard of this, they selected female musicians and fine horses adorned with patterned trappings to gift to the Lord of Lu, sowing discord between him and Confucius, who was thus banished. Song was a successor state to Yin. Confucius, having been in Song and Zhou, was not employed, hence the term "impoverished." Facing these trials, his kinsmen and close associates grew ever more distant, while his disciples and friends became ever more scattered. Why should this be so?

*Annotation*: In *Zisang Hu*, *Hu* is pronounced *hù*. An alternate character is □, pronounced *yú*. Li [Yun] says: *Sang* is the surname; □ is his given name; he was a recluse. Some say: his surname was *Zisang Hu*, and his given name was *Yin*. Yu Yue remarks: This may be the *Zisang Hu* from *The Great and Venerable Teacher*. Since *Hu* is pronounced *hù*, it is identical to *Zisang Hu*. The alternate character □ is *yu*, the same as *雩* in *Shuowen*, which notes that *雩* may also be written as □. I believe that *Caisang Yu* in *The Table of Ancient and Modern Personages* is *Zisang Hu*, as discussed in the *Great and Venerable Teacher* chapter. *Yu* may be a corrupted form of □. In *Had a Tree Felled Over Me in Song*, one version reads *had a tree felled over me in Song, was forced to erase my traces in Wei*. Lu Wenchang says: The current text has *Wei* as *Song*; Lu [Deming] states that the following sentence’s *Song* and *Wei* should be transposed. In *These Many*, the emphasis is inverted. *Why Is This* is pronounced *yú*; the same applies below.

*Collation*: (1) The *Zhaojiangyi* edition has *Hu* as *Yu*; the *Shidetang* edition has it as *Hū*.

Zisang Hu said: "Have you alone not heard of the escape of the man on loan? Lin Hui abandoned a jade disc worth a thousand gold pieces, carried a child on his back, and fled. Someone asked: 'Was it for the sake of wealth? The child’s wealth is meager. Was it for the sake of burden? The child’s burden is great. Why abandon a jade disc worth a thousand gold pieces to carry a child and flee?' Lin Hui replied: 'That was bound by profit; this is joined by Heaven. Those bound by profit abandon one another when pressed by poverty, misfortune, and harm; those joined by Heaven gather together when pressed by poverty, misfortune, and harm. The distance between gathering and abandoning is vast. Moreover, the friendship of the noble person is bland as water; the friendship of the petty person is sweet as sweet wine. The noble person’s blandness draws close; the petty person’s sweetness severs. Those who unite without cause will part without cause.'"

The annotations clarify: "布" refers to wealth and silk. *Jie* (《假》) is pronounced *jiǎ* (古雅反). Li [Yi] says: it is a state’s name. ◎Qing Fan notes: *Wen Xuan*’s annotation to Wang Zhongbao’s "Chu Yuan Stele Inscription" cites Sima [Biao]’s commentary: "Jie is the name of a state." The *Shiwen* omits this. *Lin Hui* (《林回》): Sima [Biao] says: he was a fugitive from Yin. ◎Qing Fan notes: *Wen Xuan*’s annotation to Liu Xiaobiao’s "Guang Juejiao Lun" cites Sima [Biao]’s commentary: "Lin Hui is a person’s name." This differs slightly from the *Shiwen*. ◎Yu Yue says: In the preceding text, "the people of Jie fled," and Li’s annotation states: "Jie is the name of a state." Thus, Lin Hui must have been a fugitive from Jie. When Jie fell, its people fled, so Lin Hui carried the child and fled. "Yin" (殷) is an error for "Jie" (假). *Wei qi* (《为其》) is read as written; the same applies below. It may also be read *wèi* (于伪反). *Bu yu* (《布与》): "布" refers to goods and wealth.

The exegesis states: Jie is the name of a state, a fiefdom under Jin. Lin, by surname, Hui by given name, was a worthy man of Jie. "布" refers to wealth and goods. When Jie was destroyed by Jin, its people fled, and Lin Hui cast aside his precious jade disc, carried the child, and ran. Someone questioned him, suggesting it was for the sake of wealth. Yet if it were for wealth, the child had little; if for burden, the child was heavy. Abandoning something light and valuable to carry something heavy and worthless—why? The exegesis further clarifies: The jade disc represents profit-bound ties; the child represents kinship by Heaven. Kinship endures in hardship; profit-bound ties are abandoned in misfortune. The difference between abandonment and endurance is vast. ◎Qing Fan notes: *Wen Xuan*’s annotation to Wang Zhongbao’s "Chu Yuan Stele Inscription" cites Sima [Biao]’s commentary: "属 means connection." The *Shiwen* omits this.

The annotation explains: Without profit, the bond is bland; with shared Dao, it draws close. The exegesis states: Without profit, the bond is bland; with shared Dao, it draws close. With profit, the bond is sweet; when profit is exhausted, it severs. The annotation further clarifies: Those who unite without cause are joined by Heaven. If union is not based on cause, then cause cannot sever it. Yet those who unite for a cause will part for a cause. The exegesis explains: Those who unite without cause—such as the Heaven-joined bond of father and child—cannot be severed without cause. Confucius, when speaking of the traces of the former kings, said that closeness with friends is not a Heaven-joined bond but arises from the pursuit of fame and profit. This is union for a cause. When the traces are erased and the trees are felled, they depart—this is parting for a cause. It is not a Heaven-joined bond, which unites and parts without cause. Confucius said: "I respectfully heed your instruction!" He walked slowly, feigning leisure, and returned home. He abandoned learning, discarded his books, and his disciples no longer bowed before him, yet his affection for them grew ever deeper. The annotation explains: He cast aside adornment and embraced simplicity. The exegesis states: Having heard this lofty instruction, he walked slowly home, soaring and roaming at ease, free and self-content. He abandoned the learning of deliberate action, cast aside the books of sagely traces, and ceased the teachings of ornate refinement. Thus, he no longer observed the rites of bowing, yet his reverence and affection deepened daily. The *Shiwen* notes: *Wu yi* (《无挹》) is pronounced *yī* (音揖). Li [Yi] says: it means "nothing to grasp." *Qu shi* (《去饰》) is pronounced *qǔ* (起吕反). ◎Collation note: The Dunhuang manuscript reads "受" instead of "爱."

Later, Sang Hu said: "When Shun was about to die, he truly instructed Yu, saying: ‘Be vigilant! In form, nothing surpasses following; in feeling, nothing surpasses spontaneity. Following ensures no separation; spontaneity ensures no toil. Without separation or toil, there is no need to adorn form. Without adorning form, there is certainly no reliance on external things.’" The annotation explains: Follow form and act spontaneously, without distorting for profit. The exegesis states: "缘" means to follow; form must follow things, and feeling must be spontaneous. When the Great Shun was about to pass, he used this true teaching to instruct Yu, urging him to be cautious and follow these words. Thus, Sang [Hu] cited it to admonish Confucius. Some versions use "泠" (lìng), meaning "to enlighten." When Shun was about to pass, he truly enlightened Yu with these words. The *Shiwen* notes: *Zhen* (《真》): Sima [Biao]’s version reads "直" (straight). *Ling* (《泠》) is pronounced *líng* (音零). Sima [Biao] says: "泠" means "to enlighten," referring to instructing Yu with the true Dao. "泠" may also be written as "命" (command) or "令" (order), both meaning "teaching." ◎Wang Yinzhi says: The *Shiwen* states that "真" in Sima’s version is "直," and "泠" is pronounced *líng*. Sima explains: "泠" means "to enlighten," referring to instructing Yu with the straight Dao. "泠" may also be written as "命" or "令," both meaning "teaching." I contend that "直" should be "□" (nǎi). "□" is the seal-script form of "乃" (nǎi), which in clerical script appears as "乃." The character "□" resembles "直," so it was mistakenly written as "直," and later as "真." "命" and "令" are interchangeable in ancient script (e.g., *Zhou Li*’s "司仪" uses "令" for "坛三成," and the *Jin Li* annotation cites "令" as "命"; the *Zuozhuan*’s "令不及鲁" has a variant "命"; *Zhuangzi*’s "田子方" chapter’s "先君之令" has a variant "命"; *Zhou Li*’s "大卜" annotation’s "以命龟也" also appears as "令"). Thus, "令" and "命" are correct. "□令禹" means "乃命禹" (he commanded Yu).

The annotation explains: Form is not artificial, so it remains whole; feeling is not forced, so it remains at ease.

The exegesis states: When form follows its nature, it constantly harmonizes with things; when one acts according to one’s inherent disposition, one’s actions remain free from corruption.

The annotation explains: Proceeding with simplicity and forthrightness.

The exegesis continues: Acting in accordance with one’s inherent nature, proceeding with simplicity and forthrightness—how could one then seek artificial embellishments or rely on external adornments to refine one’s form and nature?

The annotation explains: Simple and sufficient in itself.

The exegesis states: Since one does not seek artificial embellishments to adorn form, it is evident that each part is self-sufficient and does not depend on external things.

*Textual Note:* (1) The character 峄 is emended following *Dushu Zazhi*. (2) The character 籍 is emended to 迹 following the preceding text.

In the *Zhuangzi*, Zhuangzi wore coarse cloth patched with hemp and tied his shoes with strings when he passed by King Wei. King Wei said, “Why is the Master so distressed?”

The exegesis explains: “Coarse cloth” refers to rough cloth. Zhuangzi, being poor, wore garments of rough cloth that he had mended. 緳 refers to the straps of his shoes, or alternatively, his belt. His shoes were worn through, so he tied them with string. King Wei was King Hui of Wei. 惫 means “afflicted.” Wearing coarse cloth and tattered shoes, with his belt properly fastened, he appeared before King Wei. Seeing him, the king asked, “Why is the Master so impoverished and afflicted?”

*Phonetic Gloss:* In *Zhuangzi*, 衣 is pronounced *yù* (于既反).

The *Great Cloth* (《大布》): Sima [Biao] states: "coarse cloth."
《正緳》: pronounced *xiánjié* (贤节反), also *kǔjié* (苦结反). Sima [Biao] states: "a belt."
《系履》: Li [Yi] states: "the shoes were worn through, so they were tied."
◎My late father remarks: The *Shiwen* cites Sima [Biao] as saying, "緳 means a belt." Yet there is no other evidence that a belt is called *緳*, nor can merely tying one’s shoes be called *惫*. The *Shuowen* states: *絜* is "one end of hemp." *絜* and *緳* are interchangeable characters, meaning one arranges and binds the end of the hemp to fasten the shoes. With no silk straps, one ties them with hemp—hence the term *惫*.
《而过》: pronounced *gǔhé* (古禾反).
《魏王》: Sima [Biao] states: "King Hui."
《惫》: pronounced *píbài* (皮拜反), also *bójì* (薄计反). Sima’s text reads *病* ("affliction").

Zhuangzi said: "This is poverty, not affliction. A scholar who possesses the Dao and virtue yet cannot put them into practice—that is affliction. Wearing tattered clothes and worn-out shoes is poverty, not affliction. This is what is meant by ‘not encountering the right time.’ Have you alone not seen the soaring (*téng*) ape? When it finds itself among *nán*, *zǐ*, *yù*, and *zhāng* trees, it grasps the vines, swings among the branches, and reigns supreme—even Yi or Peng Meng would not dare cast a sidelong glance. Yet when it finds itself among *zhè*, *jí*, *zhǐ*, and *gǒu* thorns, it treads warily, glances about in fear, and trembles with dread. This is not because its sinews and bones have suddenly stiffened, but because its circumstances are unfavorable, and it cannot fully display its abilities. Now, dwelling among benighted rulers and chaotic ministers, how could one not be afflicted? This is like the fate of Bi Gan, whose heart was carved out as proof!"

【一】*Annotation*: When one encounters the right time and place, one may extend one’s finest skills, so that even the archers of old could do no harm.
【疏】*Nán*, *zǐ*, *yù*, and *zhāng* are all straight, fine trees. *Lǎnmàn* means "to grasp." *Wángzhǎng* means "to be at ease." Yi was a skilled archer of old; Peng Meng was Yi’s disciple. *Pìnì* means "to glance sideways." The character is also written as *miǎn*; one reads it according to the written form. This says that when a worthy or sage encounters the right time and place, it is like an ape among straight trees—leaping and bounding freely. Even a skilled archer would not dare cast a sidelong glance, much less draw a bow!
【释文】《螣》: pronounced *téng* (腾). Also written as *腾*.

◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The current text writes *téng* (腾). *Nán* is pronounced *nán* and is the name of a tree. *Lǎn* was formerly read as *lìgǎn*. *Màn* is pronounced *wàn*. Guo [Xiang] reads *wǔbàn*. *Ér wáng* is read *wǎngkuàng*; Sima [Biao]’s version writes *wǎng*. *Zhǎng* is read *dīngliàng*; another version writes *zhāng*, with the same pronunciation. Sima [Biao] reads *zhíliáng*, explaining: "The distance between two branches is great." ◎ Yu Yue says: Guo’s annotation states, "When one encounters the right time and place, one may extend one’s finest skills," reading *zhǎng* as "length" (long/short), yet this hardly accords with the original text’s meaning. Sima [Biao] says, "The distance between two branches is great," which refers to the tree itself—even less fitting. This should refer to the ape: when the ape obtains *nán*, *zǐ*, or *yùzhāng*, it leads its troop to dwell among them and acts as their lord, hence "reigns as king among them" (*wángzhǎng qíjiān*). The *Shiwen*’s readings—*wáng* as *wǎngkuàng* and *zhǎng* as *dīngliàng*—are quite apt. *Yì* is pronounced *yì*, or sometimes *hùxì*. *Péng Méng* is read *fúgōng*; Xu [Shen] reads *fúgōng*. Sima [Biao] says: "Yi was a skilled archer of old; Peng Meng was Yi’s disciple." *Miǎn* is read *mòliàn*; formerly *mòxiǎn*. Another version writes *pì*, read *pǔjì*. *Nì* is pronounced *yì*; Guo [Xiang] reads *wǔmǐ*. Li [Yi] says: "To look askance." *Chángjì* is read *qíqǐ*.

【二】【疏】*Zhè*, *jí*, *gǒu*, and *zhǐ* are all thorny, noxious trees. When an ape obtains such trees, it cannot display its agility and cunning. Thus, its heart grieves and trembles, its bearing becomes perilous and sidelong—not because its sinews and bones differ from before, but because the circumstances are unfavorable. A scholar encountering a chaotic age must act likewise.

【释文】*Zhèjí* is read *zhāngyè*. *Zhǐ* is read *jíshì*, or alternatively *zhǐ*. *Gǒu* is pronounced *jǔ*. *Dào* is read as written, or alternatively *zhídiào*. ◎ Qingfan notes: The *Shuowen* says: *Dào* means "fear"; in Chen and Chu, fear is called *dào*. The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s "Lun Wei" chapter says, "The enemy is fearful, trembling, and terrified," which aligns with the sense of "quivering and trembling in fear" here. *Bùbiàn* is read *bìmiàn*; the annotation is the same. ◎ Wang Niansun says: In antiquity, the place one occupied was called *chùshì* ("position of power"). The *Records of the Grand Historian*’s "Biography of Cai Ze" states: "Kingfishers, rhinoceroses, and elephants do not necessarily die young in their habitats." Some say *shìjū* ("powerful position"). The *Yi Zhou Shu*’s "Zhou Zhu" chapter says: "One in a lowly position cannot act as a great one." Jia Yi’s "Guo Qin Lun" says: "Among the Qin kings, over twenty generations were lords of the feudal lords—such was their power." The *Huainanzi*’s "Yuan Dao" chapter says: "Inherent nature cannot be altered; one’s position cannot be shifted." Whether it is called *chùshì* or *shìjū*, the meaning is the same. The *Book of Han*’s "Biography of Chen Tang" says: "Thus, [Li] Ling relied on his natural endowments, occupied true soil, and dwelt in a high, open position."

【三】【注】If one forces action despite unfavorable circumstances, one will suffer execution. 【疏】This is the concluding analogy.

At that time, the Zhou royal house had grown weak, while the six states flourished. Thus, rulers were benighted above, and ministers chaotic below. Master Zhuang, though holding the Dao and embracing virtue, could not be employed; he concealed his traces to avoid harm, and so spoke these words. In former times, King Zhou of Yin was without the Way, and Bi Gan, though loyal in remonstrance, was disemboweled and died—was this not proof? Citing the past to verify the present, it serves as a mirror for later days.

When Confucius was stranded between Chen and Cai, he went seven days without cooked food. Leaning left against a withered tree, striking its withered branches with his right hand, he sang the wind of Yan Shi, possessing its form but not its measure, its sound but not its modes. The sound of wood and the sound of man, plowed clear and fitting to the human heart.

【Annotation】Yan Shi refers to Shennong.
The sage Confucius, at peace with poverty and success alike, though beset by hardship in Chen and Cai, did not abandon nonaction. Thus, with his left hand striking the withered wood and his right resting on the dead branch, he remained serene and content, singing the pure wind of Yan Shi. Wood is one of the eight timbres, yet though struck, it produces no melody; without voice, only the beating of wood—how could there be gong or shang? Yet the song’s sound and the wood’s sound, plowed clear and simple, were joyous and upright, resonating and fitting to the human heart.

"The *Biāo* of *Biāo Shì* must be read with a distant retroflex: *yáo fǎn*. It refers to the nonactive sovereigns of antiquity. *Lí rán* is read *lì xī fǎn*, or alternatively *lì zhī fǎn*. Sima [Biao] says: *lí rán* means the same as *lì rán*. *Yǒu dàng* is read *dīng làng fǎn*. Yan Hui straightened his posture, turned his gaze, and observed.

Confucius, fearing that [Yan Hui] might overestimate him and aspire to greatness, or cherish himself and fall into sorrow, said: 'Hui, to accept the decrements of Heaven is easy; to accept the increments of man is difficult. There is no beginning that is not also an end—man and Heaven are one. Who, then, is the singer of this song now?'

[Annotation] Having seen Confucius strike the wood and sing, Yan Hui straightened his body and turned his eyes to watch. Confucius, fearing he had not yet awakened and might mistakenly speculate—thinking that Confucius was magnifying his own virtue and power to aspire to great office, or pitying himself for his hardship and composing a lament—summoned him to instruct him.

[Annotation] Only by accepting it can one find it easy.

[Annotation] What comes fortuitously from external things cannot be controlled.

[Annotation] The principle of spontaneity entails that when one encounters the decrements of hardship and aligns with fate, acceptance comes easily. In human affairs, when increments such as rank and emolument arrive unexpectedly, relinquishing them is difficult. This shows that though Confucius struck the wood and sang, he harbored no sorrow or resentment.

[Annotation] What is called a beginning now was an end yesterday; thus, what is called a beginning is already an end. This speaks to the boundlessness of transformation.

[Annotation] *Zú* means "end." What is a beginning now was an end yesterday. This is meant to show that there is no beginning and no end, no birth and no death. If there is no death and no birth, how can there be sorrow over hardship?

[Annotation] All is spontaneous.

[Annotation] The so-called decrements of Heaven and increments of man are but traces of teaching. When one reaches the state of congealed principle, all is spontaneous—thus, they are not two.

[Annotation] If one allows things to be as they are, then the singer is not I.

[Annotation] The great sage is empty and forgetful, having lost both things and self. If I am not I, then who is the singer? If I have no self, where can the song reside?

[Correction] The character *jué* ("rank") is supplied here based on the subsequent pairing of "rank and emolument."

Yan Hui said: 'May I ask why accepting the decrements of Heaven is easy?'"

Confucius said: "Hunger and thirst, cold and heat, obstruction and stagnation—these are the movements of Heaven and Earth, the unfolding of the turning of things. This is what is meant by 'moving together with them.'

As a minister, one does not dare to depart from them. If even the Way of the minister is thus, how much more so the manner in which one awaits Heaven!"

[Annotation] One cannot escape them.
[Annotation] The preceding briefly states the name; what follows explains the meaning. *Zhi* means blockage. When fate reaches its end in obstruction, and the Dao and virtue cannot proceed—this is like Heaven and Earth’s emptiness and fullness, the turning of the four seasons, the movement of the myriad things, and the release of qi and climate.

[Explanation of Characters] *Qiong zhi* (穷桎): *zhi* rhymes with 實.
◎ Jia Shifu says: "Obstruction and stagnation mean that hunger, thirst, cold, and heat are sufficient to shackle a person, preventing self-contentment. Yet hunger and thirst drive them, cold and heat move them—one cannot resist and not receive them, but can only pass away together with them."
*Yun wu* (运物): Sima [Biao] says: *Yun* means movement.
*Zhi xie* (之泄): *Xie* rhymes with 列. Sima [Biao] says: it means release. Xu [Shen] reads it as 世.

[Annotation] This is what is meant by "not knowing or recognizing yet following the pattern of the Lord."
[Annotation] *Xie* means together; *shi* means to go. Having embodied the impermanence of the turning of things, one moves together with transformation and goes along with it, without joy or aversion in between.

[Explanation of Characters] *Yan yu zhi* (言与之): *Yan* means "I."

[Annotation] Wherever one is, there is peace. Not taking loss as loss—this is awaiting Heaven without receiving its decrements.
[Annotation] As a minister, one does not dare to flee the ruler’s commands. If even holding to the minister’s Way is like this, how much more so when it comes to awaiting the transformations of obstruction and passage, which must accord with the principle of spontaneity—how could one resist or refuse it!

[Correction] (1) The missing character in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript reads *wu* (物) as *hua* (化).

"What is meant by 'not receiving the increments of man is difficult'?"

Confucius said: “At the beginning, when one’s influence extends in all four directions, ranks and emoluments arrive together without end. What things find beneficial is not for oneself—my mandate lies in what is external. The noble man does not act as a thief, the worthy does not act as a pilferer. If I were to take these, what would it be for?

Thus it is said: Among birds, none is wiser than the swallow. Where its eyes find no suitable place, it does not linger to look, and though its food should fall, it abandons it and flees. Though it fears humans, it nests among them—such is the preservation of the altars of soil and grain.”

[Annotation] *Ganying pangtong* (感应旁通) means “resonance extending in all directions.”
[Annotation] Extending in all directions, one may thereby respond to what is lofty and great.
[Annotation] Not sought by oneself but received.
[Exegesis] *Shi* (始) means “root.” *Nai* (乃) means “fitting.” The wondrous root is empty and tranquil; its traces respond to the moment. Extending in all four directions, its concentrated illumination reaches the nine limits. Having no fondness for noble rank, its wealth and virtue are inexhaustible. That the myriad things seek benefit is fitting.
[Annotation] In human life, there must be the mandate of engaging with external things—unlike tiles and stones, which are limited to form and substance alone.
[Exegesis] Confucius, a sage, was endowed by Heaven’s mandate. Exercising this external virtue, he saved the black-haired people—not like tiles or stones in mere form and substance.
[Annotation] “Theft” and “pilfering” refer to taking for oneself. Now, when worthy men and noble men attain ranks and emoluments, it is not by taking for themselves but by receiving them.
[Exegesis] If worthy men and noble men do not act as thieves or pilferers, how much less would the great sage Confucius violate Heaven or go against principle to take ranks and emoluments for himself? If they come by chance and lodge with him, he receives them—that is all. It is without intent.
[Annotation] Swiftness in avoiding harm.
[Exegesis] *Yiyi* (鷾鸸) is the swallow. *Shi* (实) means “food.” In wisdom for avoiding harm and preserving its life, no bird surpasses the swallow. Flying into human dwellings to build its nest, if its eyes find the place unsuitable, it does not wait to look carefully but flies far away. Even if it drops food to the ground, it swiftly abandons it and flees, never turning back to retrieve it—such is its swiftness in avoiding harm.
[Phonetic Gloss] *Mozhi* (莫知) is read as *zhi* (智). *Yi* (鷾) is read as *yi* (意).

"The *er* (鸸) is pronounced as *er* (而). Some say: *yiyi* (鷾鸸) is the swallow. *‘Where the eye finds unsuitable’* is read *changlü* (昌吕) in reverse. It means that where it cannot stay, the eye has already perceived it through its network of vision, and so it abandons it.

[Annotation] There has never been one who distanced themselves from others yet was preserved by them. Fearing humans and entering human dwellings—this is why the bird is called wise.

[Exegesis] *Xi* (袭) means “to enter.” The swallow, fearing humans, attaches itself to them and dwells in their houses, lodging there to build its nest. Thus, people cherish and grow familiar with it, and so it escapes harm. This is just as the sage harmonizes their light while in the world, blending their traces among people, guarding against danger with caution, and not sinking into worldly realms. The common people gladly support them without tiring, and so they attain long life.

[Annotation] As for the perfected person, they are profoundly one with all under Heaven. Thus, all under Heaven gladly support them without tiring, joining together to establish them as the foundation of the altars of soil and grain. This is why it is difficult to receive the benefits of others.

[Exegesis] The sage’s virtue extends far, and all beings gladly support them. The preservation of the altars of soil and grain is thus fitting. This is what is meant by “the benefits of others.”

◎ *Jia Shifu* says: Where there is land, there is the altar of soil; where there is farmland, there is the altar of grain. The altar of soil is for dwelling; the altar of grain is for sustenance. Birds, too, have their dwellings; birds, too, have their sustenance. The swallow’s entering human dwellings does not rely on humans for shelter but rather establishes its own dwelling; it does not rely on humans for sustenance but rather provides its own nourishment.

[Collation] The character *sheng* (生) follows the *Laozi*.

“What is meant by ‘nothing has a beginning that is not also an end’?”
Confucius said: “Transforming the myriad things without perceiving what succeeds them—how could one know their end? How could one know their beginning? One simply remains upright and awaits it—that is all.”

[Annotation] Unaware of its changes.

[Exegesis] *Shan* (禅) means “to succeed.” The Dao universally gives life to the myriad things, transforming and changing all directions, revolving without cease, renewing itself daily, yet in daily use, one remains unaware. Thus, no one perceives its succession. Since it is renewed daily without change, how can there be a beginning or end?

[Phonetic Gloss] *Qishan* (其禅) is read *shizhan* (市战). Sima [Biao] says: “to bestow.”

[Annotation] Day and night succeed one another without end. Thus, one remains upright and awaits it, without harboring any concerns.

[Exegesis] For the end is the beginning, and the beginning is the end—how can one determine beginning and end? Since there is no end or beginning, there is no death or life. Thus, one follows change and submits to transformation, finding all encounters fitting. Holding fast to the true and upright, one awaits the Creator alone.

[Phonetic Gloss] *Yanzhi* (焉知) is read *yuqian* (于虔). The same below."

“What does it mean for man and Heaven to be one?” Confucius said: “Where there is man, there is Heaven; where there is Heaven, there is also Heaven. That man cannot possess Heaven is his nature. The sage, at ease, embodies passing and comes to an end.”

[Annotation] All that is called Heaven makes clear what is not done but is spontaneous.

[Exegesis] Among human relations and the myriad things, none is not spontaneous. Extending even to spontaneity itself, thus man and Heaven are not two, and the myriad things merge as one.

[Annotation] To speak of spontaneity is to speak of spontaneity—how could man deliberately possess this spontaneity? It is spontaneous, and thus is called nature.

[Exegesis] Spontaneity is that which is so without knowing why it is so—it is spontaneous, not made. How could it be something one possesses? If one claims to possess it, then it is not spontaneity. Thus, we know spontaneity is nature, not something man possesses. This explains the earlier meaning of “possessing Heaven.”

[Annotation] At ease and without affectation, the body moves with change.

[Exegesis] *Yanran* means at ease. *Shi* means to pass. The sage, understanding the non-duality of beginning and end, realizing the oneness of death and life, can thus calmly dissolve the body, follow transformation, and pass away—floating without beginning, submitting to change and coming to an end.

◎ Jia Shifu says: Mencius spoke of the mouth’s delight in flavors, the eye’s delight in colors, the ear’s delight in sounds, the nose’s delight in scents, and the four limbs’ delight in ease and comfort as nature, yet subject to fate. What Zhuangzi calls “man’s inability to possess Heaven” is precisely what Mencius meant by “nature being subject to fate.” Zhuangzi takes what is bound by things and desires as man, and spontaneity as Heaven, thus severing sounds and colors, abandoning scents and flavors, and dividing Heaven and man into two. When he speaks of man and Heaven as one, it is still a matter of abandoning man to align with Heaven. The sage exhausts nature to know Heaven, and this work does not go beyond daily eating and drinking. What is nature is subject to fate, yet it is not called nature; what is fate contains nature, yet it is not called fate—this is what is meant by Heaven and man being one.

Zhuang Zhou wandered within the fence of *Diaoling*, a chestnut grove, when he saw an unusual magpie coming from the south. Its wings spanned seven feet, and its eyes measured a full inch across. It brushed against Zhuang Zhou’s forehead and settled in the chestnut grove. Zhuang Zhou said: “What bird is this? Its wings are vast yet it does not fly, its eyes are large yet it does not see?” He tucked up his robes, strode forward, took up his sling, and waited. He saw a cicada, having found a fine shade, forget its body; a mantis, seizing the cover, struck at it, seeing only its gain and forgetting its form; the strange magpie, following after, took advantage of it, seeing only profit and forgetting its true nature. Zhuang Zhou, startled, said: “Alas! Things indeed entangle one another, and the two kinds summon each other!” He cast aside his sling and turned to flee, but the gamekeeper pursued and berated him.

[Exegesis] *Diaoling* is the name of a chestnut grove. *Fan* means fence, referring to wandering within the chestnut grove’s wicker enclosure. *Yun* means round. *Gan* means to touch. *Sang* means forehead. An extraordinary magpie came from the south, its wings seven feet long, its eyes a full inch round. It struck Zhuang Zhou’s forehead and then perched in the chestnut grove.

[Phonetic Gloss] *Diao* is read *diao* in Xu’s pronunciation. Originally also written as *diao*.

《Ling’s Fan》 is pronounced *fán*. Sima Biao states: *Diao Ling* is the name of a mound; *fan* means fence, referring to wandering within the chestnut grove’s wicker enclosure. *Fan* is sometimes written as *ye* (wild), the ancient form of *ye*. *Yi Guang* is pronounced *guāng làng* in *Guangyun*. *Yun Cun*: Sima Biao states: “capable of turning one *cun*.” ◎Wang Niansun says: Sima Biao explains *yun cun* as “capable of turning one *cun*.” However, Sima takes *yun* to mean “turning,” which is incorrect. *Yun cun* parallels *guang qi chi* (seven feet wide) in structure—*guang* being horizontal, *yun* thus vertical. “Eyes large *yun cun*” simply means “eyes a full *cun* in diameter.” In the *Yue Yu*, it says, “Goujian’s land spans a hundred *li* in *guang yun*”; Wei’s commentary states: “East-west is *guang*, south-north is *yun*.” Thus *yun* means vertical. The *Western Mountains Classic* says, “This mountain spans a hundred *li* in *guang yuan*.” *Yuan* is synonymous with *yun*. The *Zhou Officials’ Great Controller of Land* records the *guang lun* (breadth and length) of the Nine Provinces’ territories; the *Rites of the Officer of Earth* states, “one *chi* wide, two *chi* in *lun*”; Zheng’s commentary explains both: “*lun* means vertical.” *Lun* and *yun* are phonetically close and share the same meaning—*guang lun* is thus *guang yun*.

《Gan Zhou zhi Sang》 is pronounced *xī dàng*. Li Yi states: *gan* means to touch. 【二】【Exegesis】 *Yin* means great; *shi* means to depart; *jué bù* means swift movement; *liú* means to lie in wait. With wings too large to fly far and eyes too large to see clearly, Zhuang Zhou marveled at the magpie’s condition. He then conceived the idea of pursuing it, striding swiftly forward with sling in hand to lie in wait. 【Phonetic Gloss】《Wings vast, not departing; eyes large, not seeing》: Sima Biao states: *yin* means vast; *shi* means winding. Li Yi states: with wings too vast to depart and eyes too large to see clearly, it failed to notice the man. 《Jian》 is pronounced *qǐ qián*. 《Jué》: Li pronounces it *qū bì*, Xu as *jiǔ fù*. Sima Biao states: swift movement. This aligns with the *Analects*: “feet moving *jué* as if...” 《Zhi Dan》 is pronounced *tú dàn*. 《Liu zhi》: Li Jiu states: *liú* means to linger and await the opportunity. 【三】【Annotation】 Holding a leaf to conceal himself from the cicada, he forgot his own form was visible to the strange magpie. 【Phonetic Gloss】《Tang》 is pronounced *táng*. 《Lang》 is pronounced *láng*. 《Zhi Yi》 is pronounced *yú jì*. Sima Biao states: holding grass to conceal oneself. 《Bo zhi》: Guo pronounces it *bó*, Xu as *fù*. 《Zhi jian hu》 is pronounced *xián biàn*. 【四】【Annotation】 Eyes that can see, wings that can fly—these are the bird’s true nature. Now, seeing profit, it forgets them. 【Exegesis】 *Bo* means to capture; *zhen* means nature and life. Zhuang Zhou, sling in hand but not yet released, suddenly saw a cicada concealed among the leaves, delighting in the shade and oblivious to its body. A mantis, holding a leaf to conceal itself, intent on capturing the cicada, failed to notice its form was visible to the strange magpie. The magpie, following the mantis, seized the opportunity to capture the cicada, intent on profit and unaware of the danger to its life—this is what is meant by “forgetting the true.” 【Phonetic Gloss】《Qi zhen》: Sima Biao states: *zhen* means body. 【五】【Annotation】 Those who seek profit from one another are ever entangled. 【Exegesis】 Having witnessed the cicada and magpie forsaking their lives for profit, he was startled and alarmed, uttering a sigh. Thus he knew that those who seek profit from things must suffer entanglement. 【Phonetic Gloss】《Chu ran》 is pronounced *zhào lǜ*. 【六】【Annotation】 One who desires something from things will likewise be desired by them. 【Exegesis】 One who desires something from things will likewise be desired by them. Thus the cicada and magpie, both creatures of the world, summon harm through their pursuit of profit—this must be so. 【七】【Annotation】 *Sui* means to question. 【Exegesis】 *Juan* means to discard. The *yuren* was the warden of the chestnut grove. *Sui* means to question. Realizing that harm follows profit, he cast aside his sling and turned to flee. The warden, suspecting him of stealing chestnuts, pursued and questioned him. 【Phonetic Gloss】《Sui zhi》 is also written as *xun*, pronounced *xìn*, meaning to question. Sima Biao states: he took Zhou for a chestnut thief. 【Collation】 (1) *Quē wù* is written as *qiān*; Zhang’s edition has *jiǎn*. (2) Zhao Jianyi’s edition has *cháng* instead of *xiāng*.

Zhuang Zhou returned home and did not step into the courtyard for three months. Lin Qie followed and asked him: “Master, why have you not come to the courtyard at all of late?” 【一】【Exegesis】 Zhuang Zhou, having seen the magpie forget its life and been suspected of stealing chestnuts, returned home in shame and did not leave his courtyard. Lin, whose given name was Qie, was a disciple of Zhuangzi. Wondering why his master had shut himself indoors of late, he followed and asked him. 【Phonetic Gloss】《San yue bu ting》: one edition has “three days.” Sima Biao states: he did not leave his seat in the courtyard for three months. ◎Wang Niansun says: The *Phonetic Gloss* states, “three months not *ting*—one edition has three days.” Sima Biao explains: “he did not leave his seat in the courtyard for three months.” If Sima’s interpretation were correct, *ting* would require the addition of *chu* (to leave) for clarity. The following line reads, “Master, why have you been so *bu ting* of late?” If *bu ting* meant “not leaving the courtyard,” the phrasing would be even more awkward. I propose that *ting* should be read as *chěng* (content). *Bu chěng* means discontent; *shen bu chěng* means deeply discontent. Having forgotten his body and his true nature, he was humiliated by the warden—hence his discontent. The *Fangyan* states: *chěng* means clear, content. East of the Pass, it is called *xiǎo* or *chěng*; in the regions of Jiang, Huai, Chen, and Chu, it is called *chěng*. The *Zuozhuan* of Duke Huan’s sixth year states, “Now the people are starving, yet the lord indulges his desires”; the *Zhou Language* states, “Duke Guo of Guo exhausted the people to indulge his transgressions”; Wei and Du’s commentaries both explain: *chěng* means content.

The character *chěng* was anciently pronounced like *chéng* (呈), its sound close to *tíng* (庭), hence interchangeable with it. (Zhang Heng’s *Sikong Thoughts Rhapsody* rhymes *bù chěng* with *qíng*, *míng*, *shēng*, *yíng*, *píng*, *zhēng*, *zhēn*, *míng*, *róng*, and *níng*. The *Shuowen* states: *chěng* is composed of 辶 with *chéng* as phonetic. The *Zuozhuan* of Duke Xi’s twenty-third year reads “excessive punishments to *chěng* [his desires],” where the *Shiwen* notes *chěng* as *chéng*. The *Fangyan* states: *chěng* means to release. The *Guangya* writes it as *chéng*.) “Three months of *bu ting*”—one version reads “three days,” which is correct. Below it says, “Master, why have you been so *bu ting* of late?” If it had been three months, it could not be called “of late.” *Lìn* (蔺) is read with the entering tone as *lì xìn*. One version writes it as *lìn* (). *Qiě* (且) is read as *zǐ yú*. Sima [Biao] says: Lin Qie was a disciple of Zhuangzi. ◎ Qing Fan’s note: The *Wenxuan*’s commentary on Guo Jingchun’s *Jiang Fu* cites Sima: “*Qǐng* means long duration.” Xie Lingyun’s poem *Entering Huazi Cave, the Third Valley of Mamasource* and its commentary cite Sima: “*Qǐng* means constant duration.” The *Shiwen* omits this. 【Collation】 (1) *Quewulun* cites the Jiangnan old manuscript, adding the character *gōng* below.

Zhuang Zhou said: “I preserved my form yet forgot my person. I observed the turbid waters and became lost in the clear abyss. Moreover, I have heard from the Master: ‘Enter their customs, follow their commands.’ Now I wandered in Carved Mound and forgot myself; a strange magpie struck my forehead. I roamed in the chestnut grove and forgot my true nature; the warden of the chestnut grove took me for a criminal—this is why I have been so *bu ting*.”

◎ **Annotation (1):** When one’s person dwells in the human world, where the world holds both safety and peril, to extend the form of safety and ease into this world without measuring what is fitting for this world—this is to preserve one’s form yet forget one’s person.
**Explication:** *Yí yì* (夷易) is pronounced *yǐ chǐ* (以豉反). *Bù duó* (不度) is pronounced *zhí luò* (直落反).

◎ **Annotation (2):** To see another yet remain unclear, thus using the other to see oneself, is nearly to forget the Way of turning the mirror back.
**Exegesis:** I, seeing profit and pursuing things, clung to preserving my form, yet profit and harm summoned one another—this is to forget one’s person. Having witnessed the magpie and cicada, I returned home and did not step beyond the gate, doubting and reproaching myself. This is what is meant by observing the turbid waters and so becoming lost in the clear spring. Though it does not accord with one’s original nature and the true, it still retains the Way of turning the light back.
**Explication:** *Zì jiàn* (自見) is pronounced *xiàn biàn* (賢遍反).

◎ **Annotation (3):** It means not violating their prohibitions and commands.

The Exegesis states: Zhuang Zhou studied under Lao Dan, hence he referred to Laozi as "the Master." The enlightened move with the dust and enter the world, and where the world has prohibitions and commands, they follow and act accordingly. Yet now, having wandered into that carved mound, he was suspected of stealing chestnuts and lightly violated the legal statutes—words of regret and self-reproach.

◎ **Annotation (4):** To treat being questioned as execution. Zhuangzi extended impartiality to the world, thus often conveying meaning through words, even to the point of slandering Confucius, disparaging Lao Dan, striking above at the Three Sovereigns, and lamenting the afflictions of his own person below.

The Exegesis states: His intent fixed on the strange magpie, he forgot the prohibitions of the chestnut grove—this is to forget oneself. The character is also written as *zhen* (真), to be read as such. The gamekeeper called me a chestnut thief, thus bringing such shame and humiliation upon myself—this is why he did not remain in the court. Zhuangzi was a great man, yet he concealed himself in a lowly position, roaming the state of Song and nurturing his nature in the lacquer garden. How could he be one who lost himself in the clear abyss or fixated on profit and harm? Rather, he sought to evaluate and critique the natures of all beings, even at the cost of harming himself.

◎ **Philological Notes:** 《上掊》 pronounced *pǔ kǒu* (普口反).
◎ **Collation:** (1) The character *lìng* (令) follows the emendation in *Quēwù* citing Cheng Xuanying’s edition; Guo’s commentary also writes *lìng*. (2) *Quēwù* cites *Rúhǎi* and Zhang Junfang’s editions, where "chestnut grove" is written as □□. (3) Zhao Jianyi’s edition omits the three characters *yán yǐ chū* (言以出).

When Master Yang traveled to Song, he lodged at an inn. The innkeeper had two concubines: one beautiful, the other ugly. The ugly one was honored, while the beautiful one was slighted. Master Yang asked the reason, and the innkeeper’s servant replied, “The beautiful one is self-aware of her beauty, so I do not recognize her as beautiful. The ugly one is self-aware of her ugliness, so I do not recognize her as ugly.”

◎ **Annotation (1):** His surname was Yang, given name Zhu, courtesy name Ziju, a native of Qin. *Nìlǚ* (逆旅) means an inn. Traveling to the state of Song, he lodged at an inn in the region. The beautiful one, relying on her beauty, caused others to forget her beauty and not acknowledge it. The ugly one, humble and self-deprecating, caused others to forget her ugliness and not acknowledge it.

◎ **Philological Notes:** 《阳子》 Sima [Biao] states: Yang Zhu.
◎ **Collation:** (1) *Quēwù* cites Liu Deyi’s edition, where *rén* (人) is written as *zhī* (之).

Master Yang said, “Disciples, take note! Act with virtue yet discard the conduct of self-regard—where could you go and not be beloved?”

◎ **Annotation (1):** The Way of self-regard is never admissible.

The Exegesis states: To cultivate virtue and establish conduct while discarding the heart of self-regard and disdain for others—where could one go and not be cherished? Thus, he commanded his disciples to remember this.

◎ **Philological Notes:** 《而去》 pronounced *qǐ lǚ* (起吕反). 《之行》 pronounced *xià mèng* (下孟反).
◎ **Collation:** (1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition includes the character *yě* (也) after *kě* (可).

**Scroll 7 (Part 2) – Outer Chapters**
**Chapter 21: Tian Zifang**
**Chapter 22: Outer Chapters: "Knowledge Wanders North"**
**Chapter 21: Tian Zifang**

◎ **Philological Notes:** The chapter is named after the person.

Tian Zifang sat in attendance upon Marquis Wen of Wei and repeatedly praised Xi Gong.

◎ **Exegesis:** His surname was Tian, given name Wuze, courtesy name Zifang, a worthy of Wei and the teacher of Marquis Wen. Marquis Wen was the seventh-generation descendant of Bi Wan and the father of Marquis Wu. Xi was his surname, Gong his given name, also a worthy of Wei.

◎ **Philological Notes:** 《田子方》 Li [Xi] states: Tian Zifang was the teacher of Marquis Wen of Wei, given name Wuze.
◎ **Qingfan’s Note:** The *Philological Notes* cites Li [Xi], stating Tian Zifang’s given name was Wuze. *Wuze* should be *Wu*. *Dù* (斁) and *zé* (择) both derive from *gāo* (睪), and were interchangeable in ancient script. In the *Book of Songs*, *Great Odes: "Si Qi"* (思齐), "the ancients were without *dù*" (无斁), Zheng’s commentary writes *wúzé* (无择). The *Shuowen* states: *Dù* means weariness, or alternatively, completion. Without weariness, there is constancy, hence his courtesy name was Zifang. (Zheng’s commentary on the *Rites: Tan Gong* states: *Fāng* means constancy.)

《数称》 pronounced *shuāng jué* (双角反), or *suǒ zhǔ* (所主反). The same below.
《溪》 pronounced *xī* (溪), or *xī* (兮). Sima’s edition writes *jī* (鸡).
《工》 Li [Xi] states: Xi Gong was a worthy.

Marquis Wen said, “Is Xi Gong your teacher?”
Zifang replied, “No, he is a fellow villager of mine. His praises of the Way often accord with principle, so I extol him.”

◎ **Exegesis:** Xi Gong was a villager of Zifang. When he spoke of the Way, his words frequently aligned with reason, so Wuze praised him—he was not his teacher.

Marquis Wen said, “In that case, do you have no teacher?”

Zifang said, “I do.”

Marquis Wen asked, “Who is your teacher?”

Zifang replied, “Dongguo Shunzi.”

Marquis Wen said, “Then why have you never spoken of him?”

◎ **Exegesis:** He lived east of the outer wall, hence his surname; his given name was Shunzi, and he was Zifang’s teacher. Since he was the Master’s teacher, why did Wuze never speak of him?

Zifang said, “His person is true—human in form yet celestial in nature, empty yet attuned to things while preserving the real, pure yet embracing all. When things lack the Way, he rectifies his bearing to awaken them, dissolving their intentions. How could one such as Wuze be worthy to speak of him?”

◎ **Annotation:** Without artifice.
◎ **Exegesis:** He is what is called a true Daoist.
◎ **Annotation:** Though his form is like that of others, he alone follows nature.
◎ **Exegesis:** Though his appearance accords with human principles, his mind harmonizes with nature.
◎ **Annotation:** Empty and in accord with things, thus his reality is never lost.
◎ **Exegesis:** *Yuan* means to follow. With an empty mind, he follows things while ever guarding the true source, moving yet ever tranquil.
◎ **Exegesis (Sound Gloss):** *Baozhen* (葆真) is pronounced *bao* (保). The original also writes *bao* (保).
◎ **Annotation:** The pure risk excessive fastidiousness; now pure yet embracing all, he is one with Heaven.
◎ **Exegesis:** As Guo’s annotation states: “The pure risk excessive fastidiousness; now pure yet embracing all, he is one with Heaven.”
◎ **Exegesis (Sound Gloss):** *Da jie* (大絜) is pronounced *tai* (泰).
◎ **Yu Yue’s Note:** Guo’s annotation takes “human in form yet celestial” (*ren mao er tian*) as a single phrase, but this misreads the passage. It should be punctuated as “human in form, celestial in emptiness” (*ren mao er tian xu*). “Human form, celestial emptiness” form a parallel construction, just as “attuned yet preserving the real” (*yuan er bao zhen*) parallels “pure yet embracing all” (*qing er rong wu*). *Xu* (虚) means aperture or cavity. The *Huainanzi*’s “Fanlun” chapter states: “If one follows the empty to go in and out,” with Gao You’s note: “*Xu* means aperture or cavity.” Since it denotes apertures, it also denotes the mind. The “Chuzhen” chapter says, “An empty room generates brightness,” with the note: “*Xu* means the mind.” The *Tai Xuan Jing*’s “Duan” section, first hexagram, says, “Cut off the mind, destroy the axe,” while the “Shi” section, first hexagram, says, “Pierce the empty, destroy the blade.” “Destroy the blade” is the same as “destroy the axe,” and “pierce the empty” is the same as “cut off the mind.” Thus, the “Yi” section, first hexagram, says, “Cherish awe, fill the empty,” which means to fill the mind. For further discussion, see the *Tai Xuan Jing*. Here, “human in form, celestial in emptiness” (*ren mao er tian xu*) is equivalent to “human in form, celestial in mind” (*ren mao er tian xin*), meaning that in form he is human, but in mind he is celestial. Scholars who fail to grasp the meaning of *xu* mistakenly attach it to the following phrase, leaving “human in form yet celestial” incomplete in sense. The two subsequent parallel phrases thus become uneven. The *Yangsheng Zhu* chapter’s “Follow the supervisor as the constant” (*yuan du yi wei jing*) has a gloss by Li (Xun) stating: “*Yuan* means to follow.” “Attuned yet preserving the real” (*yuan er bao zhen*) means “following yet preserving the real.” Prefixing *xu* here would render it meaningless.
◎ **Annotation:** Vast and clear, empty and upright, he rectifies himself alone, and the perversity of things naturally dissolves.
◎ **Exegesis:** When worldly things lack the Way, or when people are devious, Dongguo simply corrects his bearing to enlighten them, causing their deluded and disordered intentions to dissolve naturally.
◎ **Exegesis (Sound Gloss):** *Wu xie* (物邪) is pronounced *si jie* (似嗟反).
◎ **Exegesis:** The teacher’s profound virtue is so abstruse that Wuze, in his mediocrity, is unworthy to extol it!

Zifang departed. Marquis Wen, lost in thought, remained silent for the rest of the day. He summoned his ministers who stood before him and said, “How distant is the gentleman of perfect virtue! At first, I took the words of the sagely and wise, the conduct of benevolence and righteousness, to be the ultimate. But now that I have heard of Zifang’s teacher, my body feels unstrung and unwilling to move, my mouth clamped shut and unwilling to speak. What I have learned is but a clod of earth—truly, Wei has become a burden to me!”

◎ **Exegesis:** *Tangran* (傥然) describes a state of self-loss. Upon hearing of Shunzi’s virtue, Marquis Wen was left adrift, bereft of grounding, and naturally forgot his own words—hence his silence for the rest of the day. Then, summoning the ministers who stood before him, he spoke with them, sighing over Dongguo’s Dao, so profound and distant as to be unfathomable. Truly, the man of perfect virtue could govern the myriad things as a true lord.

◎ **Sound Gloss:** *Tangran* (傥然) is pronounced *chi dang* (敕荡反). Sima [Biao] says: it denotes a loss of resolve. *Er yu* (而语) is pronounced *yu ju* (鱼据反).

◎ **Annotation:** He realized his own limitations.

◎ **Sound Gloss:** *Sheng zhi* (圣知) is pronounced *zhi* (智). *Zhi xing* (之行) is pronounced *xia meng* (下孟反). *Xing jie* (形解) is pronounced *hu mai* (户买反). *Kou qian* (口钳) is pronounced *qi yan* (其炎反); [Xu] (徐) reads it *qi yan* (其严反).

◎ **Annotation:** Not a true thing.

◎ **Exegesis:** At first, I pursued learning, taking the words of the sagely wisdom of the former kings and the conduct of benevolence and righteousness of Zhou and Kong as the ultimate principle.

Now, having heard the teachings of Master Zi Fang’s master, I find his Dao vast and expansive. It has caused my form to dissolve and scatter, leaving me unable to move or rest, my mouth and tongue bound and exhausted, with nothing to say. I realize that what I have studied is but the work of a clay man—crumbling at the first touch of rain, not a true thing at all.

A *clay puppet* is a clay man.

◎ **Sound Gloss:** *Zhi* (直) is read as written. Originally also written as *zhen* (真), and the following sentence is the same. The Yuanjia edition writes *zhen* (真) here, and *zhi* (直) in the next sentence.
◎ Lu Wenchang says: The current text reads *zhen* (真).
◎ *Tu geng* (土梗) is pronounced *geng meng* (更猛反). Sima [Biao] says: *Tu geng* refers to a clay man, which crumbles when exposed to rain.
◎ Qing Fan notes: The *Wen Xuan* commentary on Liu Xiaobiao’s *Guang Juejiao Lun* cites Sima [Biao] as saying: *Geng* means the stubble of earth; a clod. The *Yiqie Jing Yinyi* (vol. 20) cites Sima [Biao] as saying: *Tu geng* is a wooden puppet of earth, or a wooden man; earth and wood paired together, referring to figures shaped like humans, all called *ou* (偶, puppets). This differs from the *Shiwen*.

◎ **Annotation:** To know what is most noble is to see human rank as a burden.

◎ **Exegesis:** Having heard the true Dao, I have collapsed in body and forgotten all, thus recognizing that official rank is but a mound of earth—nothing more than a source of worry and encumbrance.

◎ **Textual Note:** (一) The character *Xu* (徐) follows the *Shi De Tang* edition.

When Wen Bo Xuezi traveled to Qi, he lodged in Lu. A man of Lu requested an audience with him. Wen Bo Xuezi said, “It cannot be. I have heard that the *junzi* of the Central States are enlightened in ritual and righteousness but crude in understanding the human heart. I do not wish to meet them.”

◎ **Exegesis:** His surname was Wen, his given name Bo, and his courtesy name Xuezi. He was a man of Chu who embodied the Dao. *Zhongguo* refers to the state of Lu. *Lou* (陋) means clumsy.

From Chu to Qi, he passed through Lu and stayed at his host’s lodging. The people of Lu were disciples of Confucius, and having heard that Wen Bo Xue was a worthy man, they requested to meet him. Wen Bo refused, saying, “I have heard that the people of the Central States are enlightened in ritual and righteousness and the sagely traces, yet clumsy in understanding the human heart—this is why I do not wish to meet them.”

**Exegesis:** *Wen Bo Xuezi*—Li [Yun] says: a worthy man of the southern lands.

Upon reaching Qi, he returned and stayed again in Lu, where the same man once more requested an audience.

Wen Bo Xuezi said, “In the past, you sought to meet me; now, you seek to meet me again—you must have some reason to move me.”

**Exegesis:** *Qi* means to seek. *Zhen* means to stir. When I traveled to Qi before, you sought to meet me; now that I have returned to Lu, you come again to seek an audience—you must have some other purpose, wishing to move me with it.

**Exegesis:** *Qi* is pronounced *qi* (祈).

He went out to meet the guest, then returned and sighed. The next day, he met the guest again, and upon returning, sighed once more. His servant asked, “Each time you meet a guest, you return and sigh—why is this?”

**Exegesis:** After meeting guests both times, he repeatedly sighed to himself. Wen Bo’s servant, finding this strange, questioned him.

Wen Bo Xuezi said, “I have already told you: ‘The people of the Central States are enlightened in ritual propriety yet crude in understanding the human heart.’ In the past, those who came to see me advanced and withdrew as if following a compass, as if adhering to a square; their demeanor was at once dragon-like and tiger-like. When they admonished me, it was as a son to a father; when they guided me, it was as a father to a son—this is why I sighed.”

**Exegesis:** Their steps were winding, their footprints serpentine.
**Exegesis:** Their bowing and yielding, their advancing and retreating—all conformed to square and circle; their movements were sinuous as a dragon, their bearing majestic as a tiger.
**Pronunciation Notes:** *Congrong* (從容) is read as *qī róng*; *panpi* (盤辟) as *bì yì*; *yi* (遺) as in the standard reading, though some texts write it as *wei* (逶), read *yú wēi*; *she* (蛇) as *yǐ zhī*.
**Exegesis:** The corruption of ritual propriety gives rise to such affectations.
**Pronunciation Notes:** *Qi dao* (其道) is read as *qí dǎo*.
