**Exegesis:** They corrected me as a son admonishes a father; they instructed me as a father teaches a son. Though distance and proximity, honor and humility each have their proper sentiments, these are not of Heaven’s nature—why then such earnest pretense? Thus do we know that the corruption of the sage’s path leads to such artifice, and this is why I sighed.

Confucius met him and said nothing.
Zilu said, “Master, you have long wished to meet Wen Bo Xuezi. Now that you have met him and said nothing, why is this?”
**Exegesis:** He already understood his heart.

The two were in perfect accord, thus forgetting speech. Zilu found this strange and so raised his question.

Confucius said, “In the case of such a man, the Dao is present the moment one’s gaze meets his—no room remains for words.”

**Exegesis:** The instant the eyes move, understanding is already complete; there is no place for the resonance of virtue’s voice.
**Pronunciation Notes:** *Fu ren* (夫人) is read as *fú rén*.
**Exegesis:** For one who embodies awakened insight, the principle is grasped without words. The moment the eyes move, the profound Dao is already present—no need for further expenditure of speech or accommodation of his voice.
**Pronunciation Notes:** *Mu ji er Dao cun yi* (目击而道存矣): Sima Biao says, “One sees his eyes move, and the spirit is already manifest.” *Ji* means “to move.” Guo Xiang says, “The moment the eyes move, understanding is already complete.”

Yan Yuan asked Confucius, “When you walk, I walk; when you hasten, I hasten; when you run, I run. Yet when you race ahead, leaving all dust behind, I can only stare blankly from behind!”

Confucius said, “Hui, what do you mean?”

Yan Yuan replied, “When you walk, I walk; when you speak, I speak; when you hasten, I hasten; when you debate, I debate; when you run, I run; when you discourse on the Dao, I too discourse on the Dao. But when you race ahead, leaving all dust behind, and I can only stare blankly from behind—it is because you are trusted without speaking, you are in harmony without attachment, and though you hold no vessel of office, the people gather before you as water flows downward. I simply do not know how this comes to be.”

**Exegesis:** “Racing ahead, leaving all dust behind” means running swiftly. *Cheng* (瞠) describes the appearance of staring straight ahead. When one’s speed outstrips all traces, it cannot be matched, so one can only stare blankly from behind. *Qi* (器) refers to rank or office. The Master is trusted without speaking, moves in harmony with all things without attachment, and though he holds no position of lordship, the people tread before him as if drawn by a current. Not knowing how this comes to be, one can only accept it as it is—this is what is meant by “racing ahead, leaving all dust behind.”

**Pronunciation Notes:** *Ben yi* (奔逸): Sima Biao’s edition also writes it as *che* (彻). *Cheng* (瞠): *Chi geng* (敕庚) *fan* (反), also *chou lang* (丑郎) *fan* (反). The *Zilin* says: “the appearance of staring straight ahead.” Another pronunciation: *du geng* (杜哽) *fan* (反), also *chi meng* (敕孟) *fan* (反). ◎ Qing Fan’s note: The *Hou Hanshu* “Biography of Recluses” commentary and the *Wen Xuan* “Fan Weizong’s ‘Discourse on Recluses’” commentary both cite Sima Biao: “It means one cannot keep pace.” This is omitted in the *Pronunciation Notes*. *Bu bi er zhou* (不比而周): *pi zhi* (毗志) *fan* (反). *Tao hu qian* (滔乎前): *tu dao* (吐刀) *fan* (反), meaning without the vessel of lordship, the people gather before him like a surging current. Another pronunciation: *du gao* (杜高) *fan* (反).

**Textual Note:** (1) The character *you* (又) and *chou* (丑) are amended following the *Shi De Tang* edition.

Confucius said, “Alas! How can one fail to examine this?”

Alas! No sorrow is greater than the death of the heart, while the death of the person is secondary to it.

The sun rises in the eastern quarter and sets in the western extreme—all things without exception follow its course. Those with eyes and feet depend on it to accomplish their ends: when it rises, they exist; when it sets, they perish. All things are likewise: some await it to die, some await it to live.

Once I received my completed form, I did not transform but waited for its end. I moved in imitation of things, day and night without pause, yet knew not where it would conclude. My form was thus completed, yet I knew my fate could not be foreseen before me—with this, I daily declined.

**Note (1):** When the heart takes death as death, it only hastens its own demise. The swiftness of its death arises from sorrow’s self-destruction. Without sorrow, it would be nothing; with sorrow, the death of the heart is the greatest sorrow of all.

**Exegesis:** To be all-encompassing without comparison, to be trustworthy without speech—this arises from an empty heart in accord with things. How could it be otherwise? How could one fail to forget concerns and reflect, to still the heart and examine closely? Of all the burdens of emotion, none surpasses the heart’s transformations. These transformations of arising and ceasing are deeply lamentable, while the sorrow of life and death is secondary.

**Pronunciation Notes:** *Wu ke* (恶可) is read as *wu*. *Cha yu* (察与) is read as *yu*. Below, *ai yu* (哀与) is the same. *Zi sang* (自丧) is read as *xi lang*; the same applies in the next chapter.

**Note (2):** All is visible.

**Exegesis:** Night’s darkness and day’s brightness, the sun’s rising in the east and setting in the west—these are like a person entering obscurity and emerging into clarity, dying and being born, departing and returning. Thus we know that human life and death are like heaven’s day and night. Using this analogy, what is there to lament?

◎ Jia Shifu says: When the sun rises, all things move with it; when it sets, all things rest. It is its light that governs this. No being that depends on light for movement can exist outside this principle. To move with the light, to live with the qi—this is simply to follow the natural order. If one cannot harness qi to sustain life, one likewise cannot forcibly summon light to initiate movement. The light of yesterday is the same as the light of today, yet one cannot grasp today’s light and use it to measure yesterday’s in every detail. To cling to today’s light in order to measure yesterday’s is to let it slip through one’s fingers. Each has its own pace and rhythm. Resemblance lies in the rhythm, but what makes them resemble is not the rhythm itself. Only when both are forgotten within the rhythm does one fully accord with the Dao. Only by forgetting can what should not be forgotten then abide. To be indifferent to human rhythms is to ride the sun’s light without knowing movement—this is called human death. To forcibly impose a rhythm in pursuit of alignment is to forget today’s light and seek it in the past—this is called the death of the heart. Death is that which clings rigidly without transformation, holds fast without yielding.

Zhuangzi’s words are sublime; they must be grasped with spiritual insight.

**[3] Note:** The eyes achieve the work of seeing, the feet achieve the work of walking.

**Exegesis:** The toes are part of the feet. All the body’s limbs are endowed by yin and yang; the eyes see and the feet walk by virtue of creation’s power. Without these, how could their functions be achieved? Thus we know that life and death are not within human control.

**[4] Note:** It is merely that one does not see it as existing, yet it never ceases to exist.

**Exegesis:** To see the sun rise is to call it existence; to watch it set is to call it extinction—this is the reckless attachment of ordinary sentiment, not the penetrating vision of the sage.

**[5] Note:** To await concealment is called death; to await manifestation is called life—yet in truth, there is no death or life.

**Exegesis:** The concealment and manifestation of things all depend on creation. Concealment is called death; manifestation is called life. Since the sun’s rising and setting entail no true existence or extinction, how can the concealment and manifestation of things involve life and death?

**[6] Note:** For that which cannot change from being into non-being, once a form is received, transformation continues without end.

**Exegesis:** Our forms and natures are bestowed by creation. Bright or dim, fair or foul—the boundaries are already set. Once fixed, there is no further change, only an enduring constancy awaiting exhaustion. Thus the years come to an end. Since beauty and ugliness are not subject to free will, the principle of life and death must likewise be entrusted to fate.

**[7] Note:** This arises from having no mind of one’s own.

**Exegesis:** The utmost sage is empty and still; when stimuli come, responses arise. Things move, and movement follows—this is the nature of having no mind of one’s own.

**[8] Note:** Ever transforming, ever new.

**Exegesis:** Change and renewal occur daily, vanishing without a trace.

**[9] Note:** Not taking death as death.

**Exegesis:** Following it, one does not see what comes after.

**[10] Note:** Fuming forth of itself—what else could bring it about?

**Exegesis:** *Xunran* describes the appearance of self-motion. Fuming forth, endowed with qi to form a body—nothing makes it so.

**Pronunciation Notes:** *Xunran* (熏然) is read as *xuyun*.

**[11] Note:** Not bound to what came before, it moves forward with change—hence it is called "departing."

**Exegesis:** *Cu*, meaning "to go." One who comprehends the changes of time cannot prearrange a pattern; embodying daily renewal, one thus moves forward with transformation.

**Pronunciation Notes:** *Ri cu* (日徂) is read as written. Sima’s edition writes it as *ju*, glossing it as "illness."

All my life, I have clasped your arm and lost you—how could this not be lamentable? You are perilously attached to what I am attached to. That has already ended, yet you seek it as if it still exists—this is like searching for a horse in a market where pottery is sold.

I have worn you so thoroughly that I forget you; you have worn me so thoroughly that you forget me. Even so, what cause for concern do you have? Though you forget what was before, I have what cannot be forgotten abiding within.

**[1] Note:** Transformation cannot be grasped and held in place.

Thus, though you clasp arms and guard one another, you cannot make it halt—if you mourn the dead, then this too is cause for mourning. Yet people have never taken this as cause for grief; why then mourn death alone?

**Commentary:** Confucius and Yan Hui, two sages of worth, cultivated the same body as if clasping arms; yet with daily renewal and swift transformation, firm grasping and steadfast holding cannot pause even for a moment. In the space between clasped arms, one is suddenly gone, the new already proceeding—thus is it lost. If one grieves over such loss, this is deeply lamentable.

**Pronunciation Notes:** *Neng ling* (能令) is read *li cheng*. The same applies in the following chapter’s annotation.

**Annotation:** A pottery market is no place to halt a horse—this speaks of seeking what once existed but can no longer be obtained. Human life is like a horse passing through a market, never pausing even for an instant; the succession of old and new continues unceasing, day and night. *Zhuo* (着) means "to see"—it says you are perilously close to what I see. What I see is daily renewal, and thus it has already ended; how can you still possess it?

**Commentary:** *Dai* (殆) means "near." *Zhuo* (着) means "to see." *Tang* (唐) means "road"; *si* (肆) means "market." What I see is the daily renewal of the old. Yan Hui and Confucius, speaking face-to-face in pure conversation, were not far from the principles of the past—thus it is said they were perilously close. Those past affairs have already vanished; yet you still seek what once existed, believing it remains in the present—this is what is meant by seeking a horse in a pottery market. A pottery market is no place to halt a horse; the horse you saw before has already passed through the road and market, and now, when you search again, it is gone. It is just like the traces of the past, which have vanished ahead, and when sought in the present, the thing has already transformed. Thus we know that the new never abides, and movement ceaselessly shifts.

**Pronunciation Notes:** *Nü* (女) is read *ru*. *Dai zhuo hu wu suo yi zhuo ye* (殆着乎吾所以着也): Guo reads *zhuo* as *zhang lü*; the annotation is the same. Another reading is *zhang lüe*. Sima says: What I am attached to is external transformation, and you are perilously close to this. What I alone do not transform is beyond your reach. *Shi qiu ma yu Tang si ye* (是求马于唐肆也): Guo says: A pottery market is no place to halt a horse. Li concurs. Another says: *Tang* means "inn." Sima writes it as *guang si* (广肆), glossing it as "broad courtyard"—to seek a horse in a market’s broad courtyard is not its proper place. *Ma chu* (马处) is read *chang lü*. *Ke fu* (可复) is read *fu you*. *Bu she* (不舍) is read *she*.

**Annotation:** *Fu* (服) means "to dwell in thought." *Shen wang* (甚忘) refers to the speed of passing—it says you depart suddenly, and in thinking of you, I am always left behind.

**Commentary:** *Fu* (复) means "to reflect and think." The you of before has already passed, and when I reflect on it again, I too have utterly forgotten.

**Annotation:** It is the same for all—whether worthy or sage, none can make it halt.

**Commentary:** Daily renewal does not distinguish between worthy and sage. Not only in you, but in me as well: when you think of me, the past affair has already vanished.

**Annotation:** What cannot be forgotten abides—this refers to succession through daily renewal. Though you forget the old me, the new me has already arrived; it has never ceased to be me, so why should I be concerned? Thus one can leave the vulgar world and transcend dust, merging with all things without obstruction.

**Commentary:** The Dao of transformation never pauses even for a moment. Though the old me is lost, the new me still remains—this is what cannot be forgotten abiding within. Thus it has never ceased to be me; why should you be concerned?

**Pronunciation Notes:** *Li su* (离俗) is read *li zhi*. The same applies in the following chapter’s text.

The collation notes:
(1) The Tang manuscript omits the character *gu* (故).
(2) Wang Shumin states: *Zhi bi* (执臂) should read *jiao bi* (交臂).
(3) Liu Wendian states: *Fu* (复) should follow the main text and read *fu* (服).

Confucius visited Lao Dan. Lao Dan had just washed his hair and was letting it loose to dry. He stood so still and serene that he seemed no longer human. Confucius withdrew and waited. After a while, he saw Lao Dan again and said: “Was I deluded, or was it truly so? Just now, Master, your form stood as if a withered tree, as though you had left all things and departed from humanity, standing alone in solitude.”

**Annotation:** The utmost stillness and tranquility.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Bei fa* (被发) is read *pi ji* (皮寄).
*Er gan* (而干) in some versions reads *gan* (干).
*Zhi* (慹) is read *nai die* (乃牒) or *ding li* (丁立). Sima Biao says: “the appearance of immobility.” The *Shuowen* says: “fear.”
*Bo* (泊) is read *bu ge* (步各).

**Annotation:** Only when body and mind are absent do external things depart.

**Commentary:** Having just washed his hair, he let it loose to dry, gathering his spirit in profound stillness. Motionless as a withered tree, he seemed no longer human. Seeing this, Confucius dared not approach but withdrew to a distance and waited quietly.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Bian er dai* (便而待) in some versions reads *shi* (侍).

**Commentary:** In that brief moment, Confucius entered and saw Laozi, saying: “When I saw you, Master, my eyes were dazzled, and I forgot both form and intellect—truly a sage! Yet now you stand apart from humanity, having abandoned all things, vanished into the unfathomable, and merged with solitary transformation.”

**Pronunciation Notes:**
*Jian yue* (见曰) is read *xian bian* (贤遍).

《眩》*Xuàn*, read *xuánbiàn*. 《与》pronounced *yú*. Same below. 《掘若》*Xū*, read *qū*. 《槁木》*gǎo mù*, read *kǔlǎo*. **Textual Note:** (1) The character *jué* (掘) is amended according to the main text.

Laozi said: “I roam my mind in the origin of things.”

**Commentary:** The origin is that which was not and then suddenly is. Thus, to roam in the origin of things is to clarify that things do not act to bring themselves into being but arise spontaneously.

**Subcommentary:** The origin is the root. The Dao pervades and gives life to the myriad things, hence it is called the origin of things. To roam the mind in the origin of things is to concentrate the spirit in the wondrous root, so that the form becomes like withered wood and the mind like dead ashes.

**Pronunciation Notes:**
《而欻》*ér xū*, read *xùnfú*.

Confucius said: “What does this mean?”

**Subcommentary:** Though he had heard the sage’s words, he did not yet grasp their meaning.

Laozi said: “The mind is exhausted and cannot know; the mouth is shut and cannot speak. I have tried to discuss it for you in terms of its manifestations. Supreme yin is solemn and still; supreme yang blazes and flourishes. Solemn stillness emerges from heaven; blazing flourishing arises from earth. The two intermingle and harmonize, and things are born. Some structure governs this, yet none see its form. It waxes and wanes, fills and empties, now dark, now bright, changing day by day and month by month. Daily it acts, yet none see its work. Life has that from which it sprouts; death has that to which it returns. Beginning and end revolve without end, yet none know where it ceases. If not this, then what else could be its source?”

The desire was to compel Confucius to seek beyond words and meaning. "Shut" means the mouth opens but does not close. The sage’s mind is not incapable of knowing, but there is no method by which it may be known; the mouth is not incapable of speech, but there is no method by which it may be spoken. To speak of it is to depart from its essence; to know it is to lose its truth. Thus we know the supreme Dao is profoundly mysterious, transcending words and meaning—hence his perplexity and silence.

I have merely attempted to discuss yin and yang as an analogy for what has no form, though I dare not claim certainty. The ultimate principle is wondrously subtle, beyond the reach of words or thought. I have tried to discuss yin and yang for you, sketching an image of the great Dao, yet though it resembles the truth, it is not the truth itself.

It speaks of their intermingling. Solemn stillness is the cold of yin qi; blazing flourishing is the heat of yang qi. They draw near to yang within yin and yin within yang, speaking of their harmonious union. Though some structure governs this, none see the form of that structure—it is simply so of itself. Yin wanes and yang waxes, summer fills and winter empties, night darkens and day brightens, changing day by day and month by month, ever renewing without cease—thus it acts daily. Yet it acts of itself, and none see its work. It sprouts from what is not yet gathered. It returns to dispersion. It returns to what is not yet born. Beginning and end revolve without end, as what meets it does not see its head, and what follows it does not see its tail. If not this, then what else could be its source? If not this vast, unobstructed, life-generating Dao, what else could be the root and origin of the ten thousand things? All things, in their multiplicity, depend upon the Dao.

Confucius said: “May I ask about wandering in this?”

He asked: “If one wanders the mind in the Dao, what is its method? If one attains this wandering, what power does it yield?”

Laozi said: “To attain this is the utmost beauty and utmost joy. To attain the utmost beauty and wander in the utmost joy is called the perfected person.”

The utmost beauty is without beauty; the utmost joy is without joy. To realize the Dao, to find beauty and delight in it, and to wander the mind in joy without joy—this is the perfected person.

Confucius said: “I would hear of its method.”

The method is this: beasts that feed on grass do not resent changing marshes, nor do creatures born in water resent changing waters. They undergo small changes yet do not lose their great constancy. Joy and anger, sorrow and delight do not enter their breasts.

The world is that in which the ten thousand things are one. If one attains this oneness and becomes identical with it, then the four limbs and hundred parts of the body will be but dust and grime, and death and life, end and beginning will be as day and night—none can disturb them. How much less could gain and loss, fortune and misfortune intrude!

To cast off what is servile is like casting off mud and mire, for one knows the body is nobler than what is servile. What is noble resides within me and is not lost amid change.

Moreover, the ten thousand transformations have never yet reached their limit—what is there to trouble the heart? Those who have become the Dao are released from this.

Confucius said: “The Master’s virtue matched Heaven and Earth, yet he still relied on profound words to cultivate the heart—among the noble men of antiquity, who could escape this?”

Laozi said: “Not so. Water in its stillness requires no effort, for its nature is spontaneous. The perfected person in their virtue needs no cultivation, yet things cannot depart from them—just as Heaven is naturally high, Earth naturally thick, and the sun and moon naturally bright. What cultivation is there to speak of?”

The virtue of the perfected person is not cultivated or contrived, yet it is spontaneously realized. Stillness in water is its inherent nature; drawing from it for benefit does not come from study or practice. The profound virtue of the perfected person is likewise: they remain serene in lofty seclusion, yet things cannot depart from them, their blessings extending to all beings without conscious effort. Like Heaven’s height, Earth’s depth, and the luminosity of the sun and moon—what cultivation is there? It is simply the natural state.

Confucius went out and told Yan Hui, “In my relation to the Dao, am I not like a vinegar gnat? Had the Master not lifted my covering, I would never have known the great wholeness of Heaven and Earth.”

*[Annotation: A vinegar gnat is a midge in a jar.]*
*[Exegesis: "Xī-jī" (酰鸡), pronounced "xǔ-xī" in the *Shuōwén*; Guo Xiang says it is a midge in a jar. Sima Biao says it is like the midges that fly above wine. Yu Yue’s note in the *Taiping Yulan* (395) cites Sima Biao: "Xī-jī are flying gnats above wine," slightly differing from the *Exegesis*. "Jar" (瓮) is pronounced "wēng-lòng"; "mèi" (蠛) is pronounced "míng-jié"; "měng" (蠓) is pronounced "wú-kǒng."]*

*[Annotation: Comparing my wholeness to that of Lao Dan is like comparing a jar to Heaven and Earth.]*
*[Exegesis: Vinegar gnats are midges in a vinegar jar, always hidden beneath the jar’s cover, thus unable to see the two poles of Heaven and Earth. Just so, Confucius was obscured by the traces of the sages, unable to perceive the principles of things. Had Laozi not lifted the covering, he would have remained ignorant of the great wholeness of Heaven and Earth and the wondrous Dao of emptiness and penetration.]*

---

Zhuangzi had an audience with Duke Ai of Lu.
The Duke said, “In Lu, there are many Confucians, but few who follow your Way.”

*[Exegesis: "Way" (方) means method. Zhuangzi lived during the Warring States period, contemporaneous with King Hui of Wei and King Wei of Qi, 120 years after Duke Ai of Lu. That he is said to have met Duke Ai is merely a parable. However, Lu was the successor state of the Duke of Zhou and should have been a land of ritual and refinement. Moreover, Confucius, who was born in Lu, vigorously promoted the teaching of the Five Virtues, so that his disciples numbered three thousand, all clad in Confucian robes with long hems and wide sleeves. Thus, Lu must have had many such men, while those who practiced the effortless Way were rare.]*

*[Exegesis: "Zhuangzi had an audience" is pronounced "xián-biàn" or read as written. "Duke Ai of Lu": Sima Biao says Zhuangzi was contemporaneous with King Hui of Wei and King Wei of Qi, 120 years after Duke Ai.]*

Zhuangzi said, “In Lu, there are few Confucians.”

*[Exegesis: Robes symbolize virtue; one should not change them lightly. Zhuangzi, with his profound understanding, thus mocked the scarcity of true Confucians.]*

The Duke said, “Yet the whole state of Lu wears Confucian robes—how can you say there are few?”

*[Exegesis: Duke Ai, being mediocre and dull, failed to examine their Way and merely judged by their attire, mistakenly claiming there were many Confucians.]*

Zhuangzi said, “I have heard that Confucians wear round caps to know the seasons of Heaven, square shoes to know the forms of Earth, and jade pendants with loose girdles to decide matters as they arise. A noble person who possesses the Way may not wear such robes, while one who wears such robes may not know the Way. If you truly do not believe this, why not issue a decree throughout the state: ‘Those who wear these robes without possessing the Way shall be put to death!’”

*[Exegesis: "Square" (句) means angular.]*

The term "缓" refers to multicolored silk cords used to thread jade *jue* pendants as ornamental girdle decorations. *Jue* means "to decide." Some texts also write this as "绶." Now, Heaven is round and Earth is square, and attire is worn to emulate their virtue. Thus, wearing a round cap to emulate Heaven enables one to know the auspicious and inauspicious signs of the Three Luminaries; wearing square shoes to model Earth enables one to know the water and land of the Nine Provinces; and trailing silk cords with *jue* pendants allows one to make decisions when matters arise. Therefore, those who embody the Way need not don such robes, while those who wear such robes need not embody the Way. Such individuals—both past and present—have always existed, which is why Master Zhuang employed parables and dialectical discourse.

*[Phonetic Glosses:]*
《冠》: *guan* (ancient reading: *gwan*)
《圜冠》: *yuan guan* (pronounced *yuan*)
《履句》: *ju ju* (pronounced *ju*; Xu reads *qi ju*)
Li [Yun] says: "square."
《屦》: Xu reads *ju* (as in *ju bei*)
《缓》: *huan* (read *hwan*)
Sima’s version writes *shou* (silk sash).
《佩玦》: *pei jue* (ancient reading: *gwat*)
◎Qingfan’s note: The *Shuowen* defines *xuan* and *jue* interchangeably; *huan* conveys a sense of spaciousness. The *Book of Jin* states, "loose sashes and light furs," where "loose sashes" means broad sashes. *Huan pei jue* describes the *jue* as the ornament worn, suspended from the belt with ample slack. The *Shiwen*’s citation of Sima’s version as *shou* is erroneous.
《而断》: *er duan* (read *dwan*)

Thus, Duke Ai issued a decree for five days, and no one in the state of Lu dared don Confucian garb. Only one man, clad in Confucian robes, stood at the palace gate. The Duke summoned him and questioned him on state affairs; his responses were inexhaustible, shifting a thousandfold yet never at a loss.

*[Annotation:]*
To wear the robes without embodying the Dao is a crime deserving the harshest penalty. With the law so severe, none dared violate it. After five days of decrees, not a single Confucian remained.

*[Phonetic Gloss:]*
《号于国》: *hao* (to issue decrees)

Zhuangzi said: "With the whole state of Lu, only one man is a Confucian—can this be called many?"

*[Annotation:]*
One whose virtue is full within does not adorn himself without.

*[Annotation:]*
This "one man" refers to Confucius. As a sage, Confucius responded to circumstances with wisdom, like a mirror reflecting all—his transformations were boundless. That the entire state had but one such man cannot be called many.

Baili Xi took no heed of rank or emolument, which is why, though he fed cattle, the cattle grew fat. This made Duke Mu of Qin forget his lowly status and entrust him with governance.

*[Annotation:]*
Surnamed Meng, styled Baili Xi, he was a worthy of Qin. Originally a man of Yu, when Yu was destroyed by Jin, he entered Qin. Initially unrecognized, he lived in poverty, feeding cattle. Content with his lot, he remained robust and joyful, unmoved by wealth or nobility, so rank and emolument never entered his heart. Later, Duke Mu, recognizing his worth, entrusted him with state affairs without suspicion, hence "forgot his lowly status."

*[Phonetic Gloss:]*
《故饭》: *fan* (read *fwan*)
《忘其贱与之政也》: refers to forgetting his lowly status as a cattle-feeder.

The Lord of Yu took no heed of life or death, which is why he could move others.

*[Annotation:]*
One who is self-sufficient within keeps external affairs whole.

*[Annotation:]*
The Lord of Yu was Shun, surnamed Gui, styled Chonghua. Though beset by his stepmother’s trials and repeatedly thwarted, he never let life or death weigh on his heart. His filial piety was renowned, moving even Heaven and Earth. Thus, Yao wed him to his two daughters and entrusted him with the realm—hence he could move others.

When the Lord of Song was about to commission a painting, all the scribes arrived, received his bow, and stood in attendance. They licked their brushes and mixed ink, but half remained outside.

*[Annotation:]*
The Lord of Song wished to have maps of his state’s mountains and lands painted. The scribes all arrived, received his command, bowed, and stood ready. They prepared their pigments and ink, vying to display their skill. Excluding those who had bowed, half remained outside—so many were eager to compete.

*[Phonetic Gloss:]*
《受揖而立》: Sima [Biao] says: they received his command, bowed, and stood.
《舐》: Some versions write *shi* (read *shih*).

One scribe arrived late, strolling leisurely without haste. He received the bow but did not stand, then went straight to his quarters. The Duke sent someone to observe him, and he was found sitting with his robes undone, bare-chested. The Duke said: "This is the one—he is a true painter."

*[Annotation:]*
One who is sufficient within is at ease in spirit and settled in mind.

*[Annotation:]*
*Chanchran* describes his unhurried demeanor. Self-sufficient within, he showed no outward restraint. He walked slowly without haste, received the command but did not stand, entered his quarters directly, sat with his robes undone, and bared his body without fear. Seeing his spirit and bearing, the Lord of Song declared him a true painter.

*[Phonetic Gloss:]*
《儃儃》: *chantran* (read *thran*); Xu reads *dan*. Li [Yun] says: it describes a relaxed, unhurried appearance.
《般》: The character is also written as *pan*.
《礡》: *bok* (read *pok*); Xu reads *fok*. Sima [Biao] says: *banbok* means sitting with legs spread.
《裸》: Also written as *lei* (same pronunciation). Sima [Biao] says: he undid his robes to reveal his form for painting.
《神闲》: *shen xian* (read *shyen*)

*[Textual Note:]*
(1) Zhao’s remonstrance edition writes *ban* as *pan*.
(2) The original *Shiwen* text had a corrupted character, which should be *shi*.

The *Shuowen* writes: "𠵁, meaning 'to take food with the tongue.'" It is composed of "tongue" (舌) with *yi* (易) as phonetic. Pronounced *shen zhi* (神旨). Some versions write it with *ye* (也).

King Wen observed at Zang and saw a man fishing, yet his fishing was no fishing. It was not that he held his rod with intent to fish, but that he fished habitually.

*[Note 1]* Merely to pass the years.
*[Exegesis]* Zang is a place name near the Wei River. The "man" is an allegory for the Grand Duke. Before Lü Wang encountered King Wen, he angled at Zang, casting his line without bait, idly passing his days in carefree ease.

*[Phonetic Gloss:]*
《文王观于臧》 Li [Yun] says: Zang is a place name. Sima [Biao] writes: "King Wen, in plain clothes, observed at Zang."
《丈夫》 Some versions write it as *zhangren* (old man).

*[Note 2]* Ultimately seeking nothing.
*[Note 3]* Unconcerned with gain or loss, merely feigning to fish.
*[Exegesis]* He did not grasp his rod with the intent to covet fish, but roamed the banks of the Wei, merely passing the years. King Wen wished to raise him and entrust him with governance, yet feared the ministers, fathers, and elder brothers would not accept it. He wished to abandon the idea and release him, yet could not bear the people’s lack of a lord.

At dawn, he gathered his ministers and said: "Last night, I dreamt of a worthy man—his complexion dark, his beard full—riding a dappled horse with one crimson hoof. He commanded: *'Entrust your governance to the old man of Zang, and the people’s afflictions may yet be healed!'*"

*[Exegesis 1]* King Wen, having encountered the worthy man and wishing to entrust him with state affairs, feared that the royal kin and chief ministers would grow suspicious and envious. Yet if he were to abandon the idea and release him, he could not bear the thought of the common folk left without shelter.

*[Exegesis 2]* Desiring to employ the worthy, he thus ascribed it to a dream, addressing his assembled ministers: "Last night, I dreamt of a man of virtue—his complexion dark, his beard full—riding a dappled horse with one crimson hoof. He commanded me: *'Entrust your governance to the old man of Zang. By honoring the worthy and advancing the reclusive, the people’s desolation and disorder shall surely be cured.'*" *Dappled* is also written as *xing*; read according to the character.

*[Phonetic Gloss]*
《旦而属》 Pronounced *zhú*.
《之夫夫》 Both read *fú* (as in *fǔyú*).
Sima [Biao] says: *Fufu* means "ministers." Another version: *Fufu* was read as "ministers" in antiquity.
◎ Qingfan’s note: *Xizhe* means "night." In ancient times, night was called *xi*. Some versions write *xi zhe* (e.g., *Yanzi Chunqiu: Za Xia* has "the owl *xi zhe* cried"; *Shuo Yuan: Bian Wu* also writes *xi zhe*), others *ye zhe* (e.g., *Yanzi Chunqiu: Wai Pian*: "I *ye zhe* heard a man weeping in the west"; since night is called *ye zhe*, day is likewise called *zhou zhe*, as in *Yanzi Chunqiu: Za Shang*: "*Zhou zhe* the meal was served"), and still others *xi zhe* (e.g., *Yanzi Chunqiu: Xia Pian*: "*Xi zhe* Meng fought with the two suns").
《》 Pronounced *ér zhān*; Guo [Xiang] and Li [Yi] read *ér jiān*; also *ér xián*.
《驳马》 Pronounced *bāng jué*.
《偏朱蹄》 Li [Yi] says: "One hoof was crimson."
《瘳乎》 Pronounced *chì liú*.

*[Textual Note]* *Fufu* in modern texts is written as "ministers."

The ministers, startled, exclaimed: "It was the late king!"

The father of King Wen, Jili, in his lifetime had a dark complexion and abundant whiskers, and favored riding piebald horses—horses whose hooves were crimson on one side. What the king dreamed was none other than his late father’s instruction to him, which is why the ministers were so startled and fearful.

*[Pronunciation Note]*
《蹴然》 *zǐ liù* (反切); some versions write *愀*, pronounced *qǐ* (七小二反).
《先君王也》 Sima [Biao] says: "This refers to the spiritual influence of the late king."

◎ Yu Yue says: Below *先君* ("late ruler"), the character *命* ("command") is likely missing. The original text should read *先君命王也* ("the late ruler commanded the king"), which aligns with the following line: "the late ruler’s command to the king—let there be no other."

King Wen said: "Then let us divine it."
The ministers replied: "The late ruler’s command leaves no room for doubt—why divine at all?"

*[Annotation]* This was the late ruler’s decree, decisive and unquestionable. Divination is for resolving doubts; where there is no doubt, why divine?

*[Pronunciation Note]*
《之令》 Some versions write *命* ("command").
◎ Lu Wenchang says: The modern text writes *命*.
《王其无它》 Sima [Biao] says: "Do not disobey the command."

Thereupon, they welcomed the Elder of Zang and entrusted him with governance. No laws were altered, and no partial decrees were issued.

After three years, King Wen surveyed the state and found that the ranks of scholars had abandoned factionalism and dispersed their cliques; high officials no longer cultivated personal virtue; and grain measures dared not enter the four borders. When the ranks of scholars abandoned factionalism and dispersed their cliques, it showed unity of purpose. When high officials no longer cultivated personal virtue, it showed shared endeavor. When grain measures dared not enter the four borders, it showed that the feudal lords harbored no divided loyalties.

*[Annotation]* In harmonious accord between ruler and ministers, they welcomed the Elder and appointed him as chief minister, entrusting him with state affairs. Thus, the statutes and penal codes were uniformly applied without change, and no partial or biased decrees were issued.

The term *zhi* (植) denotes ranks or formations; it also refers to border stations arranged in rows to receive memorials of remonstrance, or to lodgings for remonstrance officials. *Yu* (庾) measures six *dou* and four *sheng*. After three years of governance, customs were transformed and mores altered; ruler and ministers trod the Way, leaving no room for admonition or correction. Thus, the ranks of scholars’ titles were abolished, the lodgings for memorials of remonstrance dismantled, and all between high and low prospered. High officials no longer displayed their virtue, while near and far followed the same track, and measures of grain dared not enter the four borders.

*[Pronunciation Notes]*
*Lie shi huai* (列士坏) is read as *guài*.
*Zhi* (植) is read as *zhí*.
*Sǎn qún* (散群): Sima [Biao] explains: *zhi* means ranks; *sǎn qún* means they no longer maintained followers. Another interpretation: *zhi* refers to border stations where lodgings were constructed in clusters to await remonstrators.
◎ Yu Yue remarks: Neither of Sima’s explanations captures the meaning of *zhi*. In the *Zuozhuan* (Year 2 of Duke Xuan), when Hua Yuan served as *zhi*, Du Yu’s commentary states: *zhi* means the commanding leader. The ranks of scholars must first have a leader before they can gather followers; thus, to disperse their followers, one must first dismantle their leader.
*Cháng* (长) is read as *zhàng*. The same applies below.

The *Officials Fail to Perfect Virtue*: Sima [Biao] explains: "They do not benefit from merit or fame."
*Yǔ hú* (斔斛) is read as *yǔ*. Li [Xun] states: Six *hu* and four *dou* are called *yǔ*. Sima’s text reads *yǔ yǔ*, explaining: *Yǔ* is read as *zhōng*, and *yǔ* is read as *yú*.
*Four Borders* (四竟) is read as *jìng*. The same applies below.

**[3]** *[Annotation]* This refers to harmonizing one’s light and blending with the dust.
**[4]** *[Annotation]* Maintaining purity and self-completion sets one apart from worldly affairs.
**[5]** *[Annotation]* The world places its trust in him, thus he unifies the standards of weights and measures.

*[Exegesis]* When the world achieves great unity, loyalty and remonstrance cease to compete; affairs know no division, and thus virtue remains unmanifest. When the five ranks observe their duties, the four directions enjoy tranquility. King Wen thereupon appointed him Grand Preceptor, faced north, and inquired: "Can governance extend to all under heaven?" Master Zang remained silent and unresponsive, then vaguely declined. By morning’s decree, he fled by night, and for the rest of his life, no word of him was heard.

**[1]** *[Annotation]* One who acts for the sake of achievement is not the self; thus, when the task is accomplished, the person must withdraw. When affairs are settled, the name must depart. Only when name departs and self withdraws can one extend influence to all under heaven.

*[Exegesis]* In an instant, [King Wen] bowed to him as teacher and mentor, facing north to serve him and inquire about governance. [Master Zang], unmoved by honor or favor, thus vaguely declined; his hidden intent dissolved all clamor, so he remained silent and unresponsive. Having achieved fame, he withdrew, attributing success to others. Unwilling to extend his influence to all under heaven, he fled and vanished without trace. Yet Lü [Shang], who aided the Zhou house and was enfeoffed in Qi, appears in historical records with no sign of flight—this claim of nocturnal escape is but Zhuangzi’s allegory.

*[Pronunciation Notes]*
*Grand Preceptor* (大师) is read as *tàishī*.
*Silent* (昧然) is read as *mèirán*.

《泛然》 reads *xūfūjiànfǎn*.
*Night flight* (夜遁) reads *túkùnfǎn*.
*[Collation]* Zhao Jianyì’s edition omits the character *也*.

Yan Yuan asked Confucius, “Was King Wen perhaps still not [fully realized]? Why then did he dream?”
*[Exegesis]* Yanzi doubted whether King Wen had attained the ultimate virtue of the perfected person. The true person does not dream—why then did he dream?

Confucius said, “Silence! Say no more! King Wen fulfilled it—what criticism could there be? He merely followed the momentary [needs of the people].”
*[Commentary]* Entrusting all to his ministers without claiming authority for himself—this was fulfillment.
*[Commentary]* *The momentary* refers to the people’s feelings, the interval between awakening and unawareness. Thus King Wen followed and aroused them to align with their great nature.
*[Exegesis]* *The momentary* means a brief instant. *Followed* means to comply. King Wen, a sage, fully embodied the subtle principle. You should remain silent and not trouble yourself with criticism. He simply accorded with the nature of things, aligning with the people’s hopes. In the fleeting interval between their awakening and unawareness, in the instant of advance or retreat, he used dreams to stir their nature—nothing strange in that.

*[Pronunciation Notes]*
*Criticism* (刺焉) reads *qìyān*.

Lie Yukou shot for Bohun Wuren, drawing the bow to full draw,
*[Commentary]* *Full draw* means the arrowhead reaches the bow’s limit.
placing a cup of water on his elbow.
The arrows flew in succession,
*[Commentary]* *Succession* means one arrow follows another.
and as each was loosed, another took its place.
*[Commentary]* *Took its place* means the next arrow was nocked.
At that moment, he was like a wooden figure.
*[Pronunciation Notes]*
*For Bohun* (为伯昏) reads *wéibóhūn*.
*Full draw* (盈贯) reads *yíngguàn*.
Sima [Biao] says: *the arrowhead*.
*Arrowhead* (镝) reads *dílì*.

The left hand was as if pushing against stone, the right hand as if clinging to a branch. The right hand released the shot while the left hand remained unaware—thus the cup of water could be placed there.

*[Commentary]*
Lie Yukou and Bohun Wuren are fully explained in the Inner Chapters. *Full draw* means the arrowhead is fully nocked. *Placed* means set down. Lie Yukou, an immortal of the wind and a master archer of Zheng, drew the bow with his right hand as if clinging to a branch, the arrowhead fully drawn, while his left hand stood firm as if pushing against stone. The cup of water was set upon his elbow, demonstrating the utmost steadiness and swiftness.

*[Pronunciation Notes]*
*Placed* (措) reads *qìgù*. *His elbow* (其肘) reads *zhújiǔ*. *Like pushing* (如拒) sounds *jù*; some texts write it as 矩.

The arrow flew away. As one arrow departed, another followed in succession.

*[Pronunciation Notes]*
*Arrow flew* (适矢) reads *dílì*. *Followed in succession* (复沓) reads *fúyòu*; the same applies below. *Succession* (歃) reads *sèqià* or *chūqià*.

The arrow had just been loosed and not yet reached the target when the cup was again placed upon the elbow, demonstrating the marvel of his swiftness.

*[Commentary]*
*Departed* (适) means went forth. *Succession* (沓) means repeated. *Placed* (寓) means set down. The bowstring was loosed, the arrow flew forth, and another followed in rapid succession—this is what is meant by "splitting the nock and entering." The arrow had just been shot and not yet reached the target when the cup of water was again placed upon the elbow, showing his swiftness. The character *寓* may also be written as *隅*, referring to the round arrowhead repeatedly striking the square nock, fully entering the slot and lodging in the corner.

He was utterly motionless.

*[Commentary]*
*Utterly motionless* means the pinnacle of stillness. *Wooden figure* refers to a wooden or clay puppet. This says that when Lie Yukou shot, he was so still that he resembled a figure of earth or wood.

◎ Jia Shifu says: *The arrow flew away, followed in succession* describes the release of the arrows; *the arrow had just been loosed, again placed* describes the drawing of the bow.

The *Shuowen* states: "Much speech flows *tàtà*, like water in its course." This describes one arrow just loosed as another surges forth. *寓* means "to lodge," signifying that as one arrow is released, another is already drawn in the bow.

*象人* is akin to Zheng Kangcheng’s term *xiangren’ou* (wooden figurine).

Bo Hun Wu Ren said: "This is the shooting of one who shoots—it is not the shooting of one who does not shoot. Have I not once ascended a high mountain with you, trodden upon perilous rocks, and stood at the edge of a ravine a hundred *ren* deep? Could you shoot then?"

*[Commentary]*
This means that though your skill is refined, it remains the shooting of intention—it is not the effortless, unintentional shooting of one who does not shoot.

*[Commentary]*
A *ren* is seven *chi*; seven hundred *chi* is the depth. *若* means "you." This is the shooting of one who does not shoot.

Thereupon Wu Ren ascended the high mountain, trod upon the perilous rocks, and stood at the edge of the ravine a hundred *ren* deep. Turning his back to the abyss, he retreated step by step, with two parts of his feet hanging over the void. He bowed to Lie Yukou and beckoned him forward. Lie Yukou prostrated himself upon the ground, sweat streaming down to his heels.

*[Commentary]*
Earlier, he briefly expounded the meaning of shooting; here, he directly prepares to draw the bow. *逡巡* means to step backward. *进* means to yield. Having climbed the towering mountain, trodden upon the precarious rocks, and stood at the brink of the sheer abyss, he turns his back to the chasm and retreats, with two parts of his feet suspended in empty space. Yet he draws the bowstring as if at ease, bows to Lie Yukou, and yields to him. Overcome with terror, Lie Yukou cannot lift his head; he shuts his eyes, prostrates himself upon the ground, and sweats until it flows down to his feet.

*[Phonetic Gloss]*
*《逡巡》* is read *qūnxún* (seven-*xún* tone).
*《汗流》* is read *hànliú* (house-*dàn* tone).

Bohun Wuren said: "The perfected person peers upward into the azure heavens, plunges downward into the Yellow Springs, roams and ranges to the eight limits, yet his spirit and qi remain unaltered. Now you tremble with the intent to dazzle the eyes—how perilous this is for your shot!"

---

Shoulder Wu asked Sunshu Ao: "You have thrice served as Prime Minister without vaunting glory, thrice been dismissed without a troubled countenance. At first I doubted you, but now I see the radiant ease between your brows—how do you alone cultivate your mind thus?"

Sunshu Ao replied: "How do I surpass others? I know that what comes cannot be refused, what departs cannot be halted. I regard gain and loss as no concern of mine, and so remain free of troubled countenance. How do I surpass others? Moreover, how can I know whether it lies in them or in me? If it lies in them, it is lost to me; if it lies in me, it is lost to them. I am just now lingering in hesitation, just now casting my gaze all around—how could I find leisure to attend to whether men are noble or base?"

Confucius, having heard this, said: "The true persons of antiquity—sages could not sway them with eloquence, beauties could not seduce them with excess, bandits could not plunder them by force, and even Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor could not befriend them. Death and life are indeed momentous, yet they wrought no change within themselves—how much less could rank and emolument! Such as these: their spirit threaded through the great mountains without obstruction, plunged into the abyssal springs without wetting, dwelt in lowliness and obscurity without weariness, filled heaven and earth, and even after bestowing all upon others, themselves possessed still more."

Fu Xi, pronounced as Xi.

Though people daily renew themselves, death and life are indeed momentous, yet they wrought no change within themselves—how much less could rank and emolument engage their hearts! To carve one’s flesh for the sake of the world is for both self and others to lose; to enable each person to find their own fulfillment is to give to others without diminishing oneself. Their spirit and luminosity filled heaven and earth, thus wherever they dwelt was fitting; wherever they dwelt was fitting, thus they did not diminish themselves for things but abided in the realm of self-fulfillment.

Obstruction means hindrance. *Ji* means exhaustion. The true person enters fire without burning, enters water without wetting, traverses the great mountains with spirit unobstructed, dwells in lowliness and obscurity without weariness, their virtue harmonizing with the two poles, thus filling heaven and earth. Not diminishing themselves for things, they possessed still more.

The King of Chu sat with the Lord of Fan. After a short while, those beside the King of Chu said three times that Fan was perishing. The Lord of Fan said: "That Fan is perishing does not suffice to lose what I possess. If 'Fan’s perishing does not suffice to lose what I possess,' then Chu’s existence does not suffice to preserve existence. From this perspective, Fan has never truly perished, and Chu has never truly existed."

This refers to three signs of perishing.

King Wen of Chu sat together with the Marquis of Fan to discuss alliances and covenants. Fan was the name of a state, descended from the Duke of Zhou, located within the borders of Ji Commandery; the present-day Fan City remains. The three referred to disrespect for spirits, failure to honor the worthy, and neglect of the people. Since Chu was large and Fan small, Chu harbored intentions of annexation, prompting its attendants to speak thus.

Yu Yue said: The attendants of the King of Chu spoke of three people from Fan perishing. Guo Xiang’s note, "This refers to three signs of perishing," is incorrect.

The self-attains the transformations of creation, content and unafraid—truly the descendants of the Duke of Zhou, whose generations never lack the worthy.

What abandons them does not take perishing as perishing, so existence also does not suffice to be taken as existence. Only in vastness without self-importance does one abide in constant presence.

Existence and perishing lie solely in where the heart places its concern; in the world, there is ultimately no existence or perishing.

Existence and perishing are but the heart’s gains and losses. Once obscured to gains and losses, the perished are not necessarily perished and may instead abide, while the existent do not alone exist and may instead perish.

---

**Outer Chapters: "Knowledge Wanders North" (Chapter Twenty-Two)**

Knowledge wandered north to the banks of the Dark Waters, ascended the Hidden Mound, and there by chance encountered Non-Action Spoken. Knowledge said to Non-Action Spoken: “I wish to ask you: What thoughts, what reflections lead to knowing the Dao? What dwelling, what practice lead to resting in the Dao? What following, what path lead to attaining the Dao?” Three questions, yet Non-Action Spoken gave no answer—not that he refused to answer, but that he did not know how to answer.

Knowledge, receiving no answer, returned to the south of the White Waters, ascended Fox Terrace, and there beheld Mad Qu. Knowledge repeated his questions to Mad Qu. Mad Qu said: “Ah! I know it—I was about to tell you, but midway I forgot what I wished to say.”

Knowledge, receiving no answer, returned to the Celestial Palace, saw the Yellow Emperor, and asked him. The Yellow Emperor said: “With no thoughts, no reflections, one begins to know the Dao. With no dwelling, no practice, one begins to rest in the Dao. With no following, no path, one begins to attain the Dao.”

Knowledge asked the Yellow Emperor: “You and I know it, yet those two do not—who is right?” The Yellow Emperor said: “Non-Action Spoken is truly right; Mad Qu resembles him. You and I will never come close. For the knower does not speak, and the speaker does not know—thus the sage enacts the teaching without words. The Dao cannot be attained; virtue cannot be reached. Benevolence may be enacted, righteousness may be diminished, and ritual is mutual pretense. Thus it is said: ‘Lose the Dao and then virtue follows; lose virtue and then benevolence follows; lose benevolence and then righteousness follows; lose righteousness and then ritual follows. Ritual is the flower of the Dao and the beginning of disorder.’ Thus it is said: ‘One who practices the Dao daily diminishes, diminishes again and again until reaching non-action—with non-action, there is nothing not done.’”

"'Now that one has already become a thing, to seek again to return to the root—is this not difficult! How easy it is—only for the great person!'

[1] To follow its natural course is the teaching without words.
[The commentary:] The true knows not; the semblance forgets the mean. That we do not draw near is because of knowing. Practicing the teaching without words, one cites the *Laozi* as proof.

[2] The Dao abides in spontaneity; it cannot be attained through words.
[The commentary:] To attain is to obtain. The mysterious Dao cannot be obtained through words; to speak of obtaining it is not the Dao.

[3] Not losing virtue is called 'virtue,' yet to name virtue is not to reach it.
[The commentary:] The highest virtue does not act as virtue; to act as virtue is not the ultimate virtue.

[4] The ultimate benevolence has no partiality; what is now practiced as partial benevolence is merely something that can be enacted.

[5] To cut and sever is merely to diminish; it is not the great wholeness. The great wholeness is simply to give life.

[6] Ritual values reciprocity, yet it is mutual pretense—ornamentation that disorders virtue, not truth.

[7] Ritual has fixed norms, and thus arises artificial imitation.
[The commentary:] Abandoning the root to pursue the branches, scattering simplicity for refinement, the Dao is lost and purity dissipated, until one resorts to ritual. Thus, the *Laozi* is cited to confirm this meaning.

[8] To diminish is to shed artificial ornamentation.

[9] When ornamentation is gone and simplicity is whole, then though one acts, it is as if one does not act.
[The commentary:] Those who cultivate the Dao daily diminish artificial ornamentation. First, they diminish what exists; then, they diminish what does not exist. Both existence and non-existence are relinquished, reaching the non-action of neither existence nor non-existence. Serene and unmoving, with non-action, there is nothing not done. This again cites the *Laozi* to clarify the point.

[10] Things lose their proper place, and thus become things.
[The commentary:] Only the great person finds it easy to return to the root. The great person embodies transformation, and thus transforming things is not difficult.
[The commentary:] Inverted beings, with falsity in their hearts, pursue the branches and forget the root, taking the Dao as a thing. If they indulge their desires to return to the root and recover their mandate, how could they succeed? Yet to reverse course and return to the root is not difficult—only for the great sage.

◎ Jia Shifu says: What humans receive to live is qi. Once obtained to form life, qi flows daily within the great transformation, and we, as mere clods, receive its completed form, with no way to return qi and merge with the vast. The flower of the Dao as ritual, and qi’s flowing to become human—neither is what is originally so. To regard life and death as the same, to let qi’s gathering and dispersing proceed without our involvement, is non-action. When the Dao reaches non-action, the names of benevolence, righteousness, and ritual may be set aside—this is called returning to the root."

The living are the companions of death, and death is the beginning of life—who knows their order! Man’s life is the gathering of qi; when it gathers, there is life, and when it scatters, there is death. If death and life are companions, what cause have I for sorrow?

Thus the myriad things are one. What they deem beautiful is called wondrous and divine, while what they despise is called foul and rotten. Yet the foul and rotten transform again into the wondrous and divine, and the wondrous and divine transform again into the foul and rotten. Therefore it is said, “The world through-and-through is but a single qi.” Hence the sage values oneness.

---
**Annotations from the text:**
**[1]** Those who understand the Dao of transformation do not regard death and life as different.
**[2]** Each alternately becomes the beginning, so who can know which is death and which is life?
**[3]** Both are but gathering, both are but scattering.
**[4]** Sorrow arises from seeing them as different.
**[5]** Since death and life are not two, the principle of the myriad things must return to oneness.
**[6]** Each calls what it deems beautiful “wondrous and divine,” and what it despises “foul and rotten.” Yet what one deems beautiful, another may despise, and what one despises, another may deem beautiful. Thus all share in the wondrous and divine, all share in the foul and rotten—how could death and life, self and other, be truly distinct?
**[7]** Things themselves have no beauty or ugliness; it is human sentiment that turns toward or away. What sentiment deems beautiful is called wondrous and divine, while what it deems repulsive is called foul and rotten—thus inverting root and branch to such an extent. Yet natures differ, and preferences vary: what one finds beautiful, another may despise, and what one despises, another may find beautiful. Xi Shi and Mao Qiang are deemed beautiful by humans, yet fish dive deep at the sight of them, and birds take flight. Thus the foul and rotten become wondrous and divine, and the wondrous and divine become foul and rotten—how can there be any fixed standard of right and wrong, beauty and ugliness? Know then that the world’s myriad things are but a single harmonious qi.

**[Fu Hua]**

The sage who embodies the Dao encompasses all transformations with wisdom, thus prizing this true unity and merging indistinguishably with the ten thousand conditions.

Huangdi questioned Know, saying: “I asked Wuweiwei, but Wuweiwei did not respond to me—not that he refused to respond, but that he did not know how to respond. I asked Kuang Qu, and Kuang Qu wished to tell me yet did not tell me—not that he refused to tell me, but that in wishing to tell, he forgot. Now I ask you: you know, so why do you not come near?”

Huangdi replied: “He is truly so because he does not know; this one resembles it because he forgets. You and I will never come near because we know.”

Kuang Qu heard this and took Huangdi to have spoken truly.

Heaven and Earth possess great beauty yet do not speak; the four seasons follow clear patterns yet do not debate; the myriad things fulfill their principles yet do not explain. The sage traces the beauty of Heaven and Earth and penetrates the principles of the myriad things—thus the perfected person does nothing, the great sage takes no action, for this is to contemplate Heaven and Earth.

The *Great Beauty* refers to the beauty of covering and bearing.

**[2]**
**[Annotation]** Simply allowing things to be as they are.
**[Subcommentary]** The sage aligns with the covering and bearing of the Two Modes and harmonizes with the generation and completion of the myriad things—thus his mouth utters no words, his heart takes no action.

**[3]**
**[Annotation]** Only following and yielding.
**[4]**
**[Annotation]** Observing its forms, emulating its proper manifestations, no different from Heaven and Earth.

**[Subcommentary]** The great sage and perfected person, doing nothing and taking no action, contemplate the covering and bearing of Heaven and Earth, model themselves on the generation and completion of the supreme Dao—this is what it means to do nothing and say nothing.

Now, that numinous clarity and utmost essence, together with the hundred transformations,
though things die and live, are square and round, none know their root.
Yet all things have existed from of old, naturally so.
The Six Directions are vast, yet never leave its bounds;
the tip of an autumn hair is minute, yet depends on it to complete its form.
Nothing in the world does not sink and float, never remaining the same throughout life;
yin and yang, the four seasons, move in their courses, each keeping to its proper order.
Obscurely, as if absent yet present;
effortlessly, without form yet spirit—
the myriad things are nurtured yet do not know.
This is called the *root*;
by this one may observe Heaven.

**[1]**
**[Annotation]** The hundred transformations transform themselves, and the numinous clarity does not interfere.
**[Subcommentary]** That divine and sagely luminosity, of utmost essence and subtlety, blends with things and flows with transformations—now gathering, now scattering—without joy or sorrow. When speaking of "hundreds" or "thousands," it is merely to indicate the general scope.

**[2]**
**[Annotation]** The dead have already died of themselves, the living have already lived of themselves; the round have already been round of themselves, the square have already been square of themselves. There is no maker of their root, hence none know it.
**[Subcommentary]** Things now live, now die, now square, now round—transforming naturally, none know their root or thread.

**[3]**
**[Annotation]** Do they wait to be made before existing?
**[Subcommentary]** *Pianran* describes the appearance of universal generation. All things arise in their time, flourishing and multiplying; from ancient times they have existed of themselves—how could they depend on deliberate effort to come into being?
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Pian* is read as *pian*, also as *fan*.

**[4]**
**[Annotation]** To consider the Six Directions as contained within the boundless is to belittle them.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Wei li* is read as *li zhi*; *qi nei* means unable to depart from self-transformation.

**[5]**
**[Annotation]** Though the tip of an autumn hair is minute, it is not nothing—yet there is no place to contain its substance.
**[Subcommentary]** The Six Directions are Heaven, Earth, and the four quarters. When beasts encounter autumn’s scenery, fine hairs grow at the tips of their fur—this is the *qiu hao*, the tip of an autumn hair. *Ju* means great. Though the Six Directions are vast, they still reside within the supreme Dao; though the hair-tip is minute, it relies on the Dao to complete its form.

**[6]**
**[Annotation]** Ever renewing.
**[Subcommentary]** All things in the world sink and float, rising and falling, living and dying, coming and going without cease. Their movement never stops, ever renewing in succession, never clinging to the old.

**[7]**
**[Annotation]** No need to make them so.
**[Subcommentary]** The two qi intermingle, the four seasons revolve—spring and autumn, cold and heat follow their natural sequence. Do they wait to be made before moving?

**[8]**
**[Annotation]** If it were clearly present as if existing, it would be absent.
**[Subcommentary]** Dimly, as if obscured, seeming absent yet present.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Hunran* is read as *hun*, also as *min*.

**[9]**
**[Annotation]** If it were bound to form, it would not be spirit.
**[Subcommentary]** *Shen* refers to that which subtly pervades all things. Effortlessly unbound, without visible form, its spiritual function is without limit.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Youran* is read as *you*, meaning without attachment or reluctance.

**[10]**
**[Annotation]** Though things are nurtured, their root in original nature is not grasped—hence they do not know how they are nurtured.
**[Subcommentary]** Nurturing and fostering all beings, sustaining the myriad things, its mysterious power works in hidden ways, yet in daily use it goes unnoticed. This true power is the root of the supreme Dao.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Wu xu* is also written as *chu*, both read as *chi liu fan*. The annotation is the same.

**[11]**
**[Annotation]** Observing together with Heaven.
**[Subcommentary]** *Guan* means to see; *tian* means nature. One who penetrates principle and comprehends the mysterious, who knows the root and recognizes the origin, may be said to observe the supreme Dao of nature.

**[Textual Note]** (1) The missing character in *Liu Deyi’s* edition is here supplied as *he* following the version of *Liu Deyi*. (2) The *Zhao Jianyi* edition includes the character *ye* after *zhi*. (3) The character *zhao* follows the *Shi De Tang* edition.

Nie Que asked the Way of Pi Yi.
Pi Yi said: “Correct your form, unify your gaze, and the harmony of Heaven will come to you.
Collect your knowledge, unify your measures, and spirit will come to dwell.
Virtue will become your beauty, the Dao will become your dwelling.
You will gaze in wonder like a newborn calf, seeking no reason for things!”

**[1]**
**[Subcommentary]** Nie Que was a disciple of Wang Ni; Pi Yi was Wang Ni’s teacher. Make your form upright and refined, do not incline toward the perverse; let your seeing and hearing be pure and single, do not take in many objects. Naturally, harmony and principle will come to you.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Pi Yi* is read as *pi*, also written as *pi*.

**[2]**
**[Subcommentary]** Gather and restrain your private thoughts, making them balanced and equal; focus your mind and measures, allowing no dissipation. Then your spirit will naturally come to dwell.
◎ Yu Yue says: *Yi ru du* should be *zheng ru du*. These four lines vary the phrasing but express the same meaning.

Gather in your knowing—this is the intent of unifying your seeing. What you see is singular, thus what you know is gathered in. Make your measures upright—this is the intent of making your form upright. *Du* means "form." The *Daoying* chapter of the *Huainanzi* and the *Daoyuan* chapter of the *Wenzi* both read *zheng ru du*, which may be taken as authoritative for correction.

**[3]**
**[Subcommentary]** Profound and mysterious, the highest virtue flourishes in you; the boundless Dao dwells within your heart.

**[4]**
**[Subcommentary]** *Tongyan* describes the appearance of gazing directly with no knowing. *Gu* means "matter." When the heart is empty and level, seeing too becomes even and straight, thus like a newborn calf, it seeks nothing in matters.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Tong* is read as *chihong*; Guo reads it as *tu*; Li says: "the appearance of having no knowing." Before the words were finished, Nie Que fell asleep. Pi Yi was greatly pleased, and departed singing, saying:

**[1]**
"Form like withered bones,
heart like dead ashes,
true in its actual knowing,
not clinging to the old to sustain itself.

**[2]**
Vague and dim,
without mind, unfit for plotting—
what manner of man is he!"

**[3]**

**[1]**
**[Subcommentary]** Before the discourse on the mysterious had concluded, this man had already awakened—sitting in forgetfulness, he merged with the Dao, his state no different from sleep. Thereupon, Pi Yi leapt with joy, praising his swift comprehension. Proceeding upon the great Way, he departed singing.

**[Phonetic Gloss]**
*"Nie Que sleeping"*—his body inclined toward what was said, feigning sleep to avoid seeing or hearing. Having received the Dao so swiftly, Pi Yi rejoiced.
*"Greatly pleased"*—pronounced *yue*.

**[2]**
**[Commentary]** He moves with all transformations.
**[Subcommentary]** His form is like the bones of withered wood; his heart resembles the soil of dead ashes. Devoid of emotion, he directly embodies the true knowing of pure actuality, not relying on past affairs to sustain himself.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Like withered"*—pronounced *kulao*.

**[3]**
**[Commentary]** He is one who transforms alone.
**[Subcommentary]** Vague and dim, he stills illumination and dispels clarity, forgetting both heart and knowing, unfit for plotting. Not one whom the common can recognize—thus, "what manner of man is he!" All from *"form like withered bones"* onward are Pi Yi’s song lyrics.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Vague"*—pronounced *mei* (also *wupeng*); *"dim"*—pronounced *hui*. Li says: *"Vague and dim"* describes the appearance of obscurity.

Shun asked Cheng, "Can the Dao be possessed and held?"
**[1]**
**[Subcommentary]** Cheng was an ancient realized one, Shun’s teacher. The supreme Dao is empty and all-pervading, giving rise to the movement and stillness of all beings. Shun wondered whether this Dao could be found within his own body. Having encountered his master, he thus posed his question.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Cheng"*—pronounced as written. Li says: Shun’s teacher. Another opinion: In ancient times, there were four assistants—front as *yi*, rear as *cheng*, likely official titles.

Cheng replied, "Your body is not your own—how could you possess the Dao?"
**[1]**
**[Commentary]** The body is not something you can possess; it arises spontaneously, a mere clod of earth. If the body is not yours to own, how much less the Dao!
**[Subcommentary]** The Dao transcends the four propositions and eludes the hundred negations. If you cannot even possess your own body, how could you possess the Dao?
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Possess the"*—pronounced *fu*; *"clod-like"*—pronounced *kuiran*.

Shun said, "If my body is not my own, then who possesses it?"
**[1]**
**[Subcommentary]** Not yet awakened to the fact that life arises from spontaneity and form from creation, he asked, "If my body is not mine, then whose is it?"

Cheng replied, "It is the form entrusted to you by Heaven and Earth. Life is not yours to possess—it is the harmony entrusted by Heaven and Earth. Nature and destiny are not yours to possess—they are the compliance entrusted by Heaven and Earth. Even your descendants are not yours to possess—they are the shedding entrusted by Heaven and Earth. Thus, in walking, you know not where you go; in dwelling, you know not what sustains you; in eating, you know not the taste. You are but the strong yang qi of Heaven and Earth—how could you possess it?"
**[1]**
**[Commentary]** If the body were yours to possess, then beauty and ugliness, life and death would be for you to control. Yet when qi gathers, you cannot prevent birth; when qi scatters, you cannot halt death. Clearly, it is a spontaneous coalescence—not yours to possess.
**[Subcommentary]** *Commission* means coalescence. Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang coalesce the qi of hardness, softness, harmony, and compliance to form your body, nature, and destiny. Thus, coalescence brings life; dispersion brings death. Since life and death, coalescence and dispersion do not depend on you, how can you claim your body as your own?
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Entrusted form"*—Sima says: *Commission* means accumulation. ◎Yu Yue says: Sima’s explanation does not fit the meaning. In the *Strategies of Qi*, "I wish to entrust it to you," Gao’s commentary says: *Entrust* means to consign. In the *Zuo Tradition*, second year of Duke Cheng, "The king sent to entrust to the three officials," Du’s commentary says: *Entrust* means to assign. Thus, "the form entrusted by Heaven and Earth" means the form consigned and assigned by Heaven and Earth. The same applies to the three subsequent instances of *entrust*.

**[2]**
**[Commentary]** Qi coalesces and sheds like a cicada’s molting.
**[Subcommentary]** Yin and yang coalesce, giving rise to descendants, spontaneously transforming like a cicada’s shedding.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Entrusted shedding"*—pronounced *tuowo* (also *yue*, *chaiwai*, *shirui*, *shilie*).

**[3]**
**[Commentary]** All arise spontaneously within you—thus, you know not.
**[Subcommentary]** Walking, dwelling, eating, and tasting all follow spontaneity. Tracing their origins, none knows whence they come. Who walks? Who dwells? Who eats? Who tastes? None knows the source—all arise spontaneously. ◎Jia Shifu says: Daily, one sees walking but never knows the destination; daily, one sees dwelling but never knows what sustains it; daily, one sees eating but never knows the taste. Thus, one’s going is not self-directed; one’s dwelling for decades is not self-sustained; one’s eating and tasting are not self-discerned. The qi of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang moves and turns it—none can be possessed.

**[4]**
**[Commentary]** *Strong yang* is but movement. This clarifies that the Dao may be used to relinquish the body and forget life.
**[Subcommentary]** *Strong yang* means movement. How could this body, formed by the coalescence of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang’s moving qi, be possessed?
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Strong yang qi of Heaven and Earth"*—Guo says: *Strong yang* is but movement. The text states that even Heaven and Earth move—how much less can the life born of qi’s coalescence be grasped and retained!

**[Collation]** (1) The missing or erroneous text cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, where "Sunzi" appears as "descendants."

Confucius asked Lao Dan: “Today, with leisure and ease, I venture to inquire about the supreme Dao.”

**[1]** **[Subcommentary]** *Yan* means "at peace." Confucius studied under Laozi, thus taking advantage of this tranquil, unoccupied moment to inquire about the profound Dao.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Yan"* (晏): Yu Jian’s reading; Xu’s reading: Yu Xian; another reading: Yu Jian. *"Xian"* (闲): pronounced *xian*.

Lao Dan replied: “Purify and fast, dredge your heart, cleanse and refine your spirit, shatter and strike your knowledge! The Dao—how abstruse and difficult to speak of! Let me tell you its broad outlines.”

**[1]** **[Subcommentary]** *Shu* means "to wash away." *Zaoxue* means "pure and bright." *Er* refers to "you." *Pouji* means "to break apart." *Yai* means "division." If you wish to inquire about the Dao, you must first purify your heart’s traces, fast with reverent sincerity, wash and rinse body and mind, clarify and settle the spirit, shatter sagely wisdom, and sweep away all emptiness. Yet the profound Dao is dark and obscure, difficult to articulate—let me present its divisions and speak of it in rough outline.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Zhai jie"* (齊戒): *ce jie* (side-by-side reading). *"Yao"* (窅): *yao*. Some say: "to soak." *"Pou"* (掊): *pu kou*; Xu’s reading: *fang gou*. *"Er zhi"* (而知): pronounced *zhi* (wisdom). *"Yaoran"* (窅然): *wu liao*. *"Jiang wei"* (將為): *yu wei*.
**[Collation]** (1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition reads *zhai* (斋).

“Brightness arises from obscurity; pattern emerges from formlessness; spirit arises from the Dao; form originates from essence. Yet the myriad things beget one another through form. Thus, those with nine orifices are born from the womb, while those with eight orifices hatch from eggs. Their coming leaves no trace; their going has no boundary. No gate, no chamber—vast and unbounded, they reach in all four directions. Those who attain this are strong in limb, clear in thought, keen of ear and eye. Their minds do not toil; their responses have no fixed form. Heaven cannot but be high; Earth cannot but be vast; sun and moon cannot but move; the myriad things cannot but flourish—such is the Dao!”

**[1]** **[Commentary]** All these illustrate its solitary arising, needing no external aid.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Wu xing"* (無形): refers to the Great Beginning.

**[2]** **[Commentary]** All proceed from essence to the coarse.
**[Subcommentary]** *Lun* means "pattern." Bright and manifest things arise from the abstruse and obscure; human patterns and affairs emerge from formlessness; the heart of spirit and wisdom arises from the profound Dao; the categories of form, substance, and qi take root in the subtle and refined.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Xing ben sheng yu jing"* (形本生於精): refers to the constant Dao.

**[3]** **[Commentary]** Though the myriad things beget one another through form, all is spontaneous. Thus, womb-born and egg-born creatures cannot exchange their kinds—this clarifies that spirit and qi cannot be fabricated.
**[Subcommentary]** The formless Dao gives rise to things with form; things with form, in turn, beget one another through form, substance, and qi. Thus, humans and beasts, with nine orifices, are womb-born, while birds and fish, with eight orifices, hatch from eggs—all received naturally and cannot be interchanged.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Jiu qiao"* (九竅): *ku diao*. *"Luan sheng"* (卵生): *li guan*. *"Yi zhong"* (易種): *zhang yong*.

**[4]** **[Commentary]** Those who follow their natural disposition and wander the path without trace cast their forms amid Heaven and Earth, entrust their spirits beyond the eight directions. Thus, without gate or chamber, they reach boundlessly in all four directions, roaming the six directions in harmony with transformation.
**[Subcommentary]** To take non-arrival as arrival is to arrive without trace; to take non-departure as departure is to depart without boundary. Thus, they enter and exit without doors, come and go without edges, and so can expand to the four directions, pervading all things.
**[5]** **[Commentary]** Those born and encountering this Dao preserve their Heaven-endowed nature and settle their spirit.
**[Subcommentary]** *Yao* means "to encounter." *Xun* means "to penetrate." Those who encounter the Dao and meet the true principle find their bodies at peace, their limbs strong, their thoughts penetrating, their hearing and sight keen. The mind without mind is used without toil; the response without response answers without fixed form.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Yao yu"* (邀於): *gu yao*. ◎ Yu Yue says: The *Shuowen* has no *yao* character. Under the *chi* radical: *jiao* (徼), meaning "to follow." This is today’s *yao* character. It also says: *xun* (循), meaning "to follow in sequence." Thus, *yao* also means "to follow," and *yao yu ci* means "those who follow this." Guo’s commentary, "those born and encountering this Dao," takes *yao* as "to encounter," which is circuitous and lacks ancient authority—likely an error. *"Si lü"* (思慮): *xi si*. *"Xun da"* (恂達): *xun*.

**[6]** **[Commentary]** All these cannot but be so naturally—not that the Dao compels them.
**[Subcommentary]** The Two Modes rely on emptiness to be high and vast; the Three Luminaries depend on the profound Dao to move; the myriad things attain it to flourish—such is the Dao’s efficacy. Thus, the *Laozi* says: "Heaven attains the One and becomes clear; Earth attains the One and becomes stable; the myriad things attain the One and live." This is the meaning.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Tian bu de bu gao"* (天不得不高): means that without the One Dao, it cannot be high. *"Dao yu"* (道與): *yu*. The same below.

**[Collation]** (1) The *Shide Tang* edition reads *zhi* (枝).

Moreover, extensive study does not necessarily yield true knowledge; eloquent debate does not necessarily bring wisdom—this the sage has decisively settled. (1)

As for that which, when augmented, gains no increase, and when diminished, suffers no loss—this the sage preserves. (2) Abyssal, it resembles the sea; (3) lofty, it cycles from end to beginning, (4) measuring and sustaining the myriad things without exhaustion. (5) Then is the Dao of the noble one external to these? (6) All things turn to it for sustenance yet it is never exhausted—this is its Dao! (7)

**[1]** **[Commentary]** To cast aside knowledge and wisdom and entrust all to spontaneity.

**[Subcommentary]** Vast reading of the classics does not necessarily yield true knowledge; grand eloquence and ornate words do not necessarily bring luminous wisdom.
