Thus, the *Laozi* says: "The good do not debate; the debaters are not good. The knowing are not learned; the learned do not know." This is what the sage has decisively cast aside.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Bo zhi bu bi zhi"* (博之不必知): to observe variant texts is called "extensive study." *"Yi duan"* (以断): *duan* (端管反). The commentary is the same.

**[2]** **[Commentary]** To let each preserve its proper measure alone, thus rendering knowledge and wisdom unnecessary.

**[Subcommentary]** Extensive knowledge and eloquent wisdom do not enhance clarity; silence and facing the wall do not diminish it. This is what is called "neither increasing nor decreasing, neither harming nor benefiting." The sage’s wondrous embodiment is thus preserved and cherished.

**[3]** **[Commentary]** Its bearing is measureless.

**[Subcommentary]** The Tail Hole drains it yet it is not depleted; the hundred rivers pour into it yet it does not swell. Profound and vast, it serves as a metaphor for the mysterious Dao.

**[4]** **[Commentary]** One who moves with transformation accumulates boundless cycles—this may be called "lofty."

**[Subcommentary]** *Weiwei*: a term denoting great height. The Dao transcends the Great One and surpasses the Two Modes, encompassing the infinite—hence the exclamation of its loftiness. Ending then beginning anew, this clarifies its lack of beginning or end, its ceaseless renewal, its elusive following.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Weiwei"* (魏魏): *yu wei* (鱼威反). *"Ze fu"* (则复): *fu you* (扶又反).

**[5]** **[Commentary]** Employing things without being enslaved by them—thus it is never exhausted.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Yun liang"* (运量): *yin liang* (音亮).
*"Wan wu er bu kui"* (万物而不匮): *qiu wei fan* (求位反).
This means allowing things to move by their own nature, each fulfilling its measure.

**[6]** **[Commentary]** Each draws from itself and is sufficient.
**[Subcommentary]** To bear and sustain the ten thousand things, to contain and nourish all beings—pervading the boundless without exhaustion—this is the Way of the sage and the noble person. This is not distant; it lies near, within the heart. Since it does not rely on external provision, how could it be other than internal?

**[7]** **[Commentary]** Returning to employ the myriad things, thus I am never exhausted. This clarifies that the Dao’s provision for things lies in its non-provision; through non-provision, things attain sufficiency—hence the saying, "This is its Way." It speaks of the supreme Dao’s non-action; only non-action is truly worthy of the name "Dao."
**[Subcommentary]** All that has awareness, all that is without emotion, receives this mysterious Dao. Yet its mysterious power operates in hidden pervasion, never exhausted. Now, Dao and things are neither one nor distinct, yet apart from the Dao there are no things—hence the saying, "This is its Way."
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Zhi shan"* (之赡): *she yan fan* (涉艳反). The same below.

**[Collation Notes]**
(1) *Weiwei* (魏魏) follows the Shide Tang edition; the commentary and phonetic gloss also read *Wei*.
(2) The *Quewu* text cites Liu Deyi’s edition, where all instances of *kui* (匮) appear as *yi* (遗).
(3) The character *wan* (万) is supplied following Liu Wendian’s proposal.

There exists in the Middle Kingdom one who is neither yin nor yang, abiding between Heaven and Earth, simply and only human—who will return to the Origin.

Viewed from its root, life is but a congeries of qi. Though there be long life and early death, how far apart are they? A mere moment’s discourse. How could it suffice to distinguish Yao from Jie?

Fruits and melons have their principles; human relationships, though difficult, are ordered by mutual ranking. The sage encounters them without resistance, passes beyond them without attachment. Harmonizing and responding—this is virtue; coinciding and responding—this is the Dao. Herein lies the rise of emperors and the founding of kings.

**[1] [Commentary]** Without partial designation.
**[2] [Commentary]** Aloof and self-reliant, content with whatever is encountered, utterly devoid of merit or fame.
**[Subcommentary]** The Middle Kingdom refers to the Nine Provinces. The Dao that humans receive is neither yin nor yang, neither soft nor hard, neither short nor long—thus transcending the four propositions and departing from the hundred negations. Abiding between Heaven and Earth, one is simply and only human, without bias. Some texts write *zhi* (值, "encounter") instead of *zhi* (直, "simply"), meaning that within the cosmos, one encounters being human without attachment.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Zhi qie"* (直且): read as written. Formerly *zi yu* (子余) *fan* (反).
**[3] [Commentary]** Not pursuing the branch.
**[Subcommentary]** Without bias, one is simply human—thus able to return to the root and revert to the Origin.
**[4] [Commentary]** Merely an aggregation of qi.
**[Subcommentary]** The root is the Dao. *Yin-yi* (喑醷) denotes the gathering of qi. Observing from the perspective of the Dao, one knows that life is but a thing of aggregated qi—how could it be worth cherishing?
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Yin"* (喑): *yin* (音荫); Guo: *an* (音暗); Li: *yin* (音饮); alternate reading: *yu gan* (于感) *fan* (反). *"Yi"* (醷): *yu jie* (于界) *fan* (反); Guo: *yu gan* (于感) *fan* (反); Li: *yi* (音意); alternate reading: *ta gan* (他感) *fan* (反). Li and Guo both state: *an-yi* (暗醷) is the appearance of aggregated qi.
**[5] [Commentary]** Even life and death are not sufficiently distinct—how much less the interval between long life and early death!
**[Subcommentary]** Within a single lifetime, amid a hundred years, even if one lives long or dies young, how great is the difference? A fleeting moment’s discourse—how could it suffice to affirm Yao or negate Jie and make distinctions between them?
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Ji he"* (几何): *ju qi* (居岂) *fan* (反).
**[6] [Commentary]** All things have their principles; one need only follow them.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Guo luo"* (果蓏): Xu: *li guo* (力果) *fan* (反).
**[7] [Commentary]** Human relationships involve the vicissitudes of wisdom—thus they are difficult. Yet their wisdom merely orders them by mutual ranking; one need only follow and accord with them.
**[Subcommentary]** Those on trees are called *guo* (fruits); those on the ground are called *luo* (melons). Peaches, plums, and the like, gourds and calabashes—whether tree-born or vine-born—all have their principles. Human existence in the world is fraught with peril and difficulty, yet nobility and baseness, honor and humility, are mutually ranked. One need only follow them, and they naturally accord with the Dao—just as fruits and melons have their inherent principles.
**[8] [Commentary]** Following whatever is encountered.
**[9] [Commentary]** Rightly passing beyond what should be passed.
**[Subcommentary]** Encountering eminence and rank, one follows without resistance; having passed beyond them, one does not linger.
**[10] [Commentary]** *Tiao* (调) and *ou* (偶) mean harmonizing and coinciding.
**[Subcommentary]** Harmonizing the myriad things and responding accordingly—this is supreme virtue. Coinciding with circumstances and responding to stimuli—this is the sagely Dao.
**[11] [Commentary]** It is thus and no more.
**[Subcommentary]** The rise of emperors and kings, their response to the multitudes—nothing surpasses harmonizing and coinciding with the times, responding to stimuli and engaging with things.

One who lives between Heaven and Earth is like a white colt passing through a gap—suddenly, it is gone. Bursting forth, none fails to emerge; flowing smoothly, none fails to enter. Having transformed and been born, one transforms again and dies. The living things mourn it; humankind grieves for it. Unfastening Heaven’s quiver, casting off Heaven’s [bonds], in a whirl of confusion, the hun and po depart, and the body follows—thus the great return!

The formless takes form; the formed becomes formless. This is what all people know, yet it is not what the perfected strive for. This is what the multitude commonly discuss. Those who have attained do not discuss; those who discuss have not attained. Manifest insight encounters no value; disputation is inferior to silence. The Dao cannot be heard; hearing is inferior to blocking [the ears]. This is called the great attainment.

---

The *Shiwen* notes: 《勃然》 *boran* (stepped swiftly), 《油然》 *youran* (smoothly flowing), 《漻然》 *liuran* (Lí: *liran*). [3] The commentary states: All are transformations. [4] The commentary states: The dead do not mourn. [5] The commentary states: The dead kind do not grieve. The *Shu* explains: Life and death, coming and going—all are but transformations. Entrusting them to the Creator, why cling to them? Thus, in death, living things and humankind share in the duty of grief, but those not of their kind or life do not grieve or mourn.

◎ Jia Shifu remarks: Living things mourn it, and thus we know mourning—only because they live, yet they do not know that life, too, will ultimately perish. Humankind grieves for it, and thus we know grief—only because humans possess awareness, yet they do not know that human awareness, too, will ultimately perish.

[6] The commentary states: To be uniquely freed. The *Shu* explains: *Tāo* is the quiver’s casing; *shù* is to bind the casing. People cling to right and wrong, delight in life and abhor death, thus binding themselves to life and death. Now, having unified right and wrong and forgotten life and death, they cast off Heaven’s natural quiver. The *Shiwen* notes: 《天弢》 *tiāntāo* (chìdāo), the *Zilin* states: the covering of a bow. 《堕其》 *duòqí* (xǔguī), 《天》 *tiān* (chénbǐ).

[7] The commentary states: Transformations are misty and obscure. The *Shiwen* notes: 《宛乎》 *wǎnhū* (yǔruǎn), 《絪》 *yīn* (yīn), also written as 烟 *yān* (yīn). 《缊》 *yùn* (yúyún), also written as 煴 *yūn* (same sound). ◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The current text reads *yānyūn* (misty and obscure).

[8] The commentary states: Do not apply the mind to their midst. The *Shu* explains: In the tangled, winding dispersal, all things follow their own course. The *hun* and *po* ascend to Heaven, bones and flesh return to earth, spirit and *qi* scatter and drift—freely they go from being to non-being. This is the great return.

[9] The commentary states: The formless takes form; if one forces form upon it, one ruins that form. The *Shu* explains: Before a person is born, they fundamentally lack form; thus, they arise from the formless. When *qi* gathers, form comes to be; when *qi* disperses, it returns to the formless. The *Shiwen* notes: 《则败》 *zébài* (bǔmài).

[10] The commentary states: Though they know this, they cannot allow it to take form naturally but instead impose form upon it, thus often ruining it. [11] The commentary states: Striving prevents attainment. The *Shu* explains: From the formless arising form, from form returning to the formless—this is what all people know. Yet these are but common matters of the world, not the profound concerns of the perfected.

[12] The commentary states: Though they discuss it, they still cannot help but strive, and thus they do not attain. The *Shu* explains: The coming and going of form and substance, of life and death—this is what the multitude commonly discusses. [13] The commentary states: Unawares, one attains. The *Shiwen* notes: 《悗然》 *mǎnrán* (wángběn).

[14] The *Shu* explains: Those sagely persons, having forgotten words and grasped the principle, have nothing to discuss. If they were to discuss it, they would not attain the Dao. [15] The commentary states: Obscurely attaining, one encounters it. The *Shu* explains: *Zhí* means to meet. Only by closing off wisdom and blocking the senses can one obscurely unite with the profound principle. If one relies on clear hearing and seeing, one will not encounter the real.

[16] The commentary states: By silencing and blocking them, one has nothing to pursue, and thus attains greatly. The *Shu* explains: Grand eloquence adorns words, distancing one from the real; forgetting words and abiding in stillness, one draws near to the profound Dao. Thus, the Dao cannot be sought through much hearing; seeking through much hearing is inferior to obscuring and blocking. If one can subtly grasp this meaning, one may be said to have deeply attained the great principle.

◎ Jia Shifu remarks: The Dao is formless. To see it and take it as the Dao is as if one had skillfully encountered it, yet fundamentally, there is no encounter. The *Shuowen* states: *Zhí* means to place. If one cannot lift and place it, then what one sees as the Dao here, another sees as a different Dao there, and there will be no end to disputation. Thus, disputation is inferior to silence.

The text collates: (1) The character 形 *xíng* is deleted following the Shidetang edition.

Dongguo Zi asked Zhuangzi: “Where does the so-called Dao reside?” [1] The *Shu* explains: Dwelling in Dongguo, he was called Dongguo Zi—Master Dongguo, the teacher of Wuze. He asked Zhuangzi: “This so-called empty, penetrating Dao—where does it reside?” The *Shiwen* notes: 《东郭子》 *Dōngguō Zǐ* (Lǐ: He dwelled in Dongguo).

Zhuangzi said: “It resides nowhere and yet everywhere.” [1]
[1] *Subcommentary*: The Dao is all-pervading; it is present in every place.

Dongguo Zi said: “Name a place, then I will accept it.”
[1] *Commentary*: He wished Zhuangzi to specify where it resides.
*Subcommentary*: As Guo’s commentary states: He wished Zhuangzi to specify where it resides.
*Phonetic Gloss*: *Desire to make* (欲令): pronounced *lì*.

Zhuangzi said: “It is in the ants.”
Dongguo Zi asked: “Why so lowly?”
Zhuangzi said: “It is in the weeds and millet.”
Dongguo Zi asked: “Why even lower?”
Zhuangzi said: “It is in the tiles and bricks.”
Dongguo Zi asked: “Why still lower?”
Zhuangzi said: “It is in excrement and urine.”
Dongguo Zi did not respond.

[1] Zhuangzi said: “Your question, Master, fundamentally misses the essence. [2] When the inspector of the market’s swine-treader was asked about judging a pig’s fatness, the more he probed the lower parts, the clearer the condition became. [3] You must not insist on a single place, for nothing escapes the Dao. [4] The supreme Dao is like this, and so too are grand words. [5] The three—pervasiveness, universality, and completeness—are different names for the same reality; their meaning is one. [6]
[1] *Subcommentary*: The great Dao is nowhere absent, yet wherever it is, it is not confined. Thus, it is present everywhere, without rejecting the foul or base. Dongguo Zi failed to grasp this truth and believed the Dao to be lofty and pure. When told it was in tiles and bricks, he already found it too lowly; upon hearing of excrement and urine, he grew indignant and did not respond.
*Phonetic Gloss*: *Ants* (蝼蚁): *lóu*, *yǐ*. *In* (在): *dài*. *Weeds* (稊): also written 稊. *Millet* (稗): *bài*; Li explains: *tí* and *bài* are two types of grass. ◎Lu Wenzhao notes: The current text reads *tí-bài*. *Tiles and bricks* (瓦甓): also written 甓, *bì*. *Excrement* (屎): *shǐ*; in older texts, *shī*. Sometimes written 矢. *Urine* (溺): *niào*.

[2] *Commentary*: To point to its manifestations and say it is nowhere absent, yet then to find fault with this, is to miss the essence.
*Subcommentary*: The Dao is nowhere absent—how could it be only in weeds and millet? Your question, Master, still falls short of the truth.

[3] *Commentary*: *Shǐ* means a large pig. When the market inspector treads on a pig to judge its fatness, the more he presses the harder-to-fatten parts, the better he understands the pig’s true condition. Now, when asked where the Dao resides, and one illustrates it by descending to ever baser things, it becomes certain that the Dao does not escape anything.
*Subcommentary*: *Zheng* is an official title, equivalent to today’s market magistrate. *Huo* is a personal name. *Jian* refers to the market overseer, equivalent to today’s butcher. *Shǐ* means pig. The method of judging a pig’s fatness, as asked of the butcher, is this: tread on the pig’s legs and haunches—the harder-to-fatten parts—to gauge its condition. Why? If even the lower, harder-to-fatten parts have flesh, then the easier-to-fatten parts must be rich with fat. Likewise, if the Dao is present in excrement and urine, the lowliest places, then it must pervade even the purest and most refined.
*Phonetic Gloss*: *Zheng Huo’s question to the market overseer* (正获之问于监): *gǔ*. *Treading on the pig* (市履狶): *xī*.

The *Every Descent Further Clarifies* (《每下愈况》), Li [Yun] says: *Zheng* is a pavilion guard; *Huo* is his name. *Jian-shi* (market overseer) is the chief of the market. *Xi* is a large pig. *Lü* means to tread. The market chief treads on the pig, pressing its thighs and legs—the parts where the pig is hardest to fatten—thus knowing whether the pig is fat. Inquiring into the Dao is likewise: by examining the lowly and base, one comes to know the Dao.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Shòu* (瘦): *sè* (色救反). *Zhī chù* (之处): *chāng lǜ* (昌虑反).

**[4]**
*Commentary*: If one must insist that there is something from which the Dao escapes, then the Dao is not all-encompassing. A Dao that is not all-encompassing is insufficient to be called the Dao.
*Subcommentary*: *Wu* (无) refers to the Dao of non-action. The great Dao is vast and boundless, governing all without exception. You must not say that the supreme Dao escapes or abandons things. If it truly escaped things, how could it be all-pervading?

**[5]**
*Commentary*: This clarifies that the Dao does not escape things.
*Subcommentary*: The supreme Dao is principle; the great teaching is instruction. Since principle does not escape things, the teaching likewise pervades all without bias.

**[6]**
*Subcommentary*: All-encompassing and universally pervasive, the Dao is present in all things. This further clarifies that the supreme Dao does not escape things. Though it may have three different names, in essence, its principle and purport converge as one.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Zhōu biàn* (周遍): *biàn* (音遍).
*Collation*: (1) The *Quewu* edition, citing Zhang Junfang and Cheng Xuanying, includes *wei* (谓) after *bi* (必).

---

We have wandered together in the Palace of Nothing-Whatsoever, merging in discussion without end or limit! We have dwelled together in non-action—serene and still, vast and clear, harmonious and at ease! My aspiration is emptied; I go forth yet do not know where I arrive. I depart and return yet do not know where I rest. I have come and gone yet do not know where it ends. I wander in boundless expanse, where great wisdom enters yet does not know its limit.

The one who gives things their thingness is without boundary with things, yet things have boundaries—what is called the boundary of things. The boundary of the boundless is the boundary that is not a boundary. It is said: fullness and emptiness, decline and decay—what is full and empty is not full and empty; what declines and decays is not decline and decay. What is root and branch is not root and branch; what accumulates and disperses is not accumulation and dispersal.

**[1]**
*Commentary*: If one wanders in what *is*, one cannot be universally all-encompassing. Only by merging in discussion does one realize the Dao is present in all things. Once one knows the Dao is present in all things, one can then be unbounded and without attachment, wandering in the infinite.
*Subcommentary*: The Palace of Nothing-Whatsoever refers to the abode of the mysterious Dao—where not a single thing exists, hence "nothing-whatsoever." The three terms—all-encompassing, universally pervasive, and present in all—describe wandering together in the realm of the supreme Dao. Since their essential purport is one, they merge in discussion, darkly aligning with the mysterious principle, thus without beginning, end, or limit.

**[2]**
*Commentary*: All this arises from non-action.
*Subcommentary*: This collectively extols the abundant power and virtue of the three—all-encompassing, universally pervasive, and present in all. Having wandered in the realm of the supreme Dao and dwelled in the domain of non-action, one can thus be tranquil and still, silent and clear, yielding and harmonious, at ease and unhurried.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Dàn ér* (澹而): *tú zhàn* (徒暂反).
◎ Qingfan’s note: *Mò ér qīng* (漠而清): *mò* also means clear; ancient texts often use such reduplicative expressions. The *Erya* states: *mò* (漠) means to examine, to be clear. Fan’s commentary: *mòrán* (漠然) is the appearance of clarity. *Mò* can also be written as *mò* (莫). In the *Zuozhuan*, twenty-eighth year, De Zheng responds in harmony, saying *mò* (莫); Du’s commentary: *mòrán* (莫然) means clear and still.
*Ér xián* (而闲): *xián* (音闲).

**[3]**
*Commentary*: Empty and vast.
*Subcommentary*: The sage who attains the Dao aligns with principle and the mysterious truth; their nature and aspiration are empty and open, silent and vast.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Liáo* (寥): *liáo* (音辽).

**[4]**
*Commentary*: If the aspiration is empty and vast, then there is nowhere to go; having nowhere to go, one goes yet does not know where one arrives. If there *were* somewhere to go, principle would not yet stir, yet the aspiration would already be *wù* (骛).
*Phonetic Gloss*: *Yǐ jīng* (已惊): as written. Also written as *wù* (骛), *wù* (音务).
◎ Qingfan’s note: Guo’s commentary—"if there were somewhere to go, principle would not yet stir, yet the aspiration would already be *jīng* (惊)"—*jīng* is difficult to understand; the meaning should follow the *Shiwen*’s *wù* (骛), which is correct. *Wù* and *chí* (驰) share the same meaning; the commentary means "not yet stirred, yet the aspiration has already raced ahead." Aspiration cannot be said to be *jīng* (惊). *Jīng* and *wù* are similar in form, hence the error. (In the *Huainanzi*, *chí* (驰) is written as *chěng* (聘), and *jīng* is further corrupted to *wù*.)

**[5]**
*Commentary*: This is following the natural course.

**[Subcommentary]**
The aspiration, being already still and silent, thus accords with the absence of going and returning. Even if one were to "go without going" or "come without coming," there would ultimately be no place of arrival, nor any abiding.

**[6]**
*Commentary*: It is merely that going and coming do not proceed from knowledge; they are not the absence of going and coming. Going and coming are the constant principle of the natural course—can they ever reach an end?

**[Subcommentary]**
Even if one were to go and return in accordance with the Creator, or follow the transformations of life and death, drifting with change and yielding to transformation, one would still not know beginning or end.

**[7]**
*Commentary*: *Fenghong* refers to the vast and empty. The person of great wisdom roams in the boundless expanse, freely following the course of transformations—hence, they do not know.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Panghuang* is the name for unrestrained wandering; *fenghong* describes the appearance of emptiness and vastness, referring to the state of attunement. It speaks of the person of great sagely wisdom who can accord with the principle of stillness, silence, emptiness, and vastness—thus, they wander freely and at ease, unrestrained and without limit.

*Phonetic Gloss*: *Pang* (彷): pronounced *páng*. Also written as *páng* (彷).

**[Phonetic Gloss]**
*Huang* (徨): pronounced *huáng*.
*Feng* (冯): *pí bīng* (皮冰) *fǎn*, also *pǔ gēng* (普耕) *fǎn*, or *bù gēng* (步耕) *fǎn*.
*Hong* (闳): pronounced *hóng*.
Li [Yun] says: *Fenghong* (冯闳) both mean "great."
Guo [Xiang] says: It refers to emptiness and vastness.

**[8]**
*Commentary*: To "thing" things means there are no things, yet things spontaneously become things. Since things spontaneously become things, they are thus obscure.

*Subcommentary*: *Ji* (际) means edge or boundary. The one who can "thing" things is the sage. The sage is obscurely one with the myriad conditions, thus sharing no boundary of self and other with things.

**[9]**
*Commentary*: Things have boundaries, so they constantly interact yet cannot be obscurely one—this is what is truly called a boundary.

*Subcommentary*: The emotions of things discriminate, accepting and rejecting in endless ways, hence there are boundaries of interaction between self and other.

**[10]**
*Commentary*: The one without boundaries, though bearing the name of "thinging" things, simply clarifies that things spontaneously become things. The one who "things" things ultimately has no thing—where then is the boundary?

*Subcommentary*: The boundary that is no-boundary is the sage’s penetrating insight; the no-boundary that is a boundary is the deluded attachment of the vulgar.

**[11]**
*Commentary*: Having clarified that the one who "things" things has no thing, and that things cannot spontaneously become things, then who is the maker? All is suddenly and spontaneously so.

*Subcommentary*: Wealth and honor are fullness; poverty and lowliness are emptiness. Aging and illness are decline and decay; beginning and end are root and branch. Birth is accumulation; death is dispersal. The one who "things" things is not a thing—then who gives life to things? This clarifies that what can "thing" and what is "thinged" are both not things. Since things are not things, how can one speak of fullness and emptiness, decline and decay? Thus, what is called fullness and emptiness is truly not fullness and emptiness. As the *Scripture of Western Ascension* says: "If you can illuminate this, what is taken as right is actually wrong."

**[Phonetic Gloss]**
*Shuaisha* (衰杀): *sè jiè* (色界) *fǎn*, Xu [Shen] reads *suǒ lì* (所例) *fǎn*. The same below.

**[Textual Note]**
The character *jīng* (惊) follows the *Phonetic Gloss*, the *Shide Tang* edition, and Guo Qingfan’s annotation; only the *Fusong* edition has *zhì* (至).

(2) The character *zhì* follows the main text for emendation. (3) The character *yóu* follows the *Shide Tang* edition for emendation.

He Gandan and Shennong studied together under Lao Longji. One day, Shennong leaned on his armrest with the door closed, dozing at midday. At noon, He Gandan flung open the door and entered, saying: "Old Long is dead!" Shennong, still leaning on his armrest, rose with his staff, then suddenly cast it aside and laughed, saying: "Heaven knew my stubbornness, rudeness, and arrogance, so it abandoned me and let him die. Alas, Master! He died without having unleashed my wild words!"

**[Annotation 1]**
[Commentary] His surname was He, his courtesy name Gandan. This Shennong was not the Shennong of the Three Sovereigns but a later figure. The two studied together under Lao Longji, which was also a sobriquet.
[Phonetic Gloss] *Yú Hé* (于河): pronounced *yú hé*. *Hé Gān* (荷甘): pronounced *hé gān*. Some versions write it as *Kē* (苛). *Lǎo Lóngjí* (老龙吉): Li [Yi] says: "A man who embodied the Dao."

**[Annotation 2]**
[Commentary] *Yǐn* (隐) means "to lean." *Hé* (阖) means "to close." *Zhā* (奓) means "to open" or "to push aside." Those who study the Dao concentrate their spirit and settle their minds, closing their doors to lean on their armrests, preserving silence in meditation. When He Gandan heard of his teacher’s death, he pushed open the door to announce it.
[Phonetic Gloss] *Yǐn jī* (隐机): pronounced *yú jìn*. The same below.

◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The present text reads *jī* (几, "armrest"). *Hé hù* (阖户): pronounced *hù là*. *Zhòu míng* (昼瞑): pronounced *mián*. *Zhā* (奓): Guo reads *chǔ yě*, also *shē*; Xu reads *dū jià*, also *chǔ yè*. Sima says: "to open."

**[Annotation 3]**
**[Commentary]** He rose, awakening to the fact that death is not worth alarm, and so returned to lay down his staff and laugh.
**[Exegesis]** *Bō rán* (嚗然) is the sound of setting down the staff. When Shennong heard of Ji’s death, he clutched his staff in shock; reflecting again that death is not worth mourning, he then laid it down and laughed.
◎ Yu Yue says: Having already said he "clutched his staff and rose," it is inconsistent to say he "leaned on the armrest." The phrase *yǐn jī* (隐几) may be a scribal interpolation from the earlier passage about Shennong leaning on the armrest, closing the door, and meditating by day.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Bō rán* (嚗然): pronounced *bō*, also *fú miǎo*, also *fú mào*. Li says: "the sound of setting down the staff." *Tóu zhàng* (投杖): some versions read *fàng zhàng* (放杖, "lay down the staff").
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: The present text reads *fàng zhàng* (放杖).

**[Annotation 4]**
**[Commentary]** From Jianwu downward, all took the ultimate words as madness and did not believe them. Thus, apart from Lao Long, Lian Shu, and their like, none were fit to speak with.
**[Exegesis]** *Fūzǐ* (夫子, "Master") refers to Lao Longji. His virtue was natural, so he was called *tiān* (天, "Heaven"). *Kuáng yán* (狂言, "mad words") are the ultimate words, which the world cannot comprehend, hence the ultimate words are called "mad." The Master knew I was eccentric and coarse, negligent and inattentive, so he abandoned our company, ceased, and died. With the wise man gone, the ultimate words are cut off; no one remains to discourse on the profound or instruct, to open and enlighten my heart.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Pì lòu* (僻陋): pronounced *pǐ yì*. *Màn* (慢): Wu reads *wǔ bàn*, Xu reads *wú jiàn*, Guo reads as written. *Dà* (訑): Tu reads *tú dàn*, Xu reads *tú jiàn*, Guo reads *dàn*. *Yǐ yǐ fū* (已矣夫): pronounced *yǐ fú*.

Yan Gangdiao, upon hearing this, said: "Those who embody the Dao are the ones to whom the noble persons of the world turn. Now, in Lao Long’s relation to the Dao, he had not attained even one ten-thousandth of the tip of an autumn hair, yet he still knew to conceal his mad words and die—how much more so for those who embody the Dao! Seen, it has no form; heard, it has no sound. In the discourse of men, it is called *míng míng* (冥冥, "obscure"), yet this is but a discourse on the Dao, not the Dao itself."

**[Annotation 1]**
**[Commentary]** Those who embody the Dao are the lords and masters of men.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Yǎn* (弇): pronounced *yǎn*. *Gāng* (缸): pronounced *gāng*. *Diào* (吊): Li says: "Yan Gang was a man who embodied the Dao; *Diao* was his given name." *Xì yān* (系焉): means "to be the refuge of all things."

**[Annotation 2]**
**[Commentary]** The tip of an autumn hair is minute, yet he had not attained even one ten-thousandth of it.

**[Annotation 3]**
**[Commentary]** This makes clear that the ultimate Dao cannot be attained by words but only by personal realization.

**[Exegesis]** His surname was Yan, his given name Gang, a recluse. *Xì* (系) means "to attach" or "to belong." Hearing of Longji’s death, he offered this discourse: "Those who embody the Dao are revered by the world; the worthy and the noble turn to them in devotion. Now, Lao Long’s relation to the profound Dao was not even one ten-thousandth of the tip of a hair, yet he still knew to conceal his unbridled words and die in accord with the Way—how much more so for those who have awakened to the mystery! Thus, those who deeply embody the Dao and forget words to grasp the principle are exceedingly rare."

**[Annotation 4]**
**[Commentary]** Though called *míng míng* ("obscure"), it is still not the Dao, which shows that the Dao is nameless.

**[Exegesis]** The profound Dao is empty and vast, its wondrous essence beyond form and sound, neither visible nor audible. Thus, when scholars discuss it, they call it *míng míng* ("obscure"), yet this is still not the true Dao.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Yóu fù* (犹复): pronounced *fú yòu*.

Thereupon Tai Qing asked Wu Qiong: "Do you know the Dao?"
Wu Qiong said: "I do not know."

**[Annotation 1]**
**[Exegesis]** *Tài* (泰) means "great." The ultimate Dao is vast and boundless, tranquil and empty, embracing the infinite, hence the names Tai Qing ("Great Clarity") and Wu Qiong ("Without Limit"). Tai Qing asked about knowing the Dao, and Wu Qiong answered that he did not know, intending to show that the Dao transcends form and sound and cannot be sought through verbal knowledge.

He then asked Wu Wei.
Wu Wei said: "I know the Dao."
Tai Qing said: "In your knowing the Dao, are there also numerical principles?"
Wu Wei said: "There are."

Tai Qing said: "What are its numerical principles?"
**[Annotation 1]**
**[Exegesis]** Since you claim to know the Dao, do you have names and numbers for it? What are these numerical principles? Please give a brief account.

Wu Wei said: "I know that the Dao can be noble, can be base, can be gathered, can be dispersed—these are the numerical principles by which I know the Dao."
**[Annotation 1]**
**[Exegesis]** Noble as an emperor, base as a servant; gathered as life, dispersed as death—its numbers are boundless. This is but a rough sketch, meant to show that it is not a name yet has names, not a number yet has numbers.

Thereupon Tai Qing, having heard these words, asked Wu Shi: "If this is so, then between Wu Qiong’s not-knowing and Wu Wei’s knowing, which is right and which is wrong?"
**[Annotation 1]**
**[Exegesis]** The ultimate Dao is mysterious and all-pervading, tranquil and without action, unfathomable in its response, without end or beginning—hence the names Wu Qiong ("Without Limit") and Wu Shi ("Without Beginning"). Between Wu Qiong’s not-knowing and Wu Wei’s knowing, who is right and who is wrong? Please determine which is correct.

Wu Shi said: "Not-knowing is profound; knowing is shallow. Not-knowing is internal; knowing is external."
**[Annotation 1]**
**[Exegesis]** Not-knowing accords with principle, hence it is profound and abides within. Knowing deviates from the Dao, hence it is coarse and external.

Thereupon Tai Qing, struck to the center, sighed and said: "Is not-knowing then knowing? Is knowing then not-knowing? Who knows the knowing of not-knowing?"
**[Annotation 1]**
**[Commentary]** That which is attained not through knowing is called *ming* (dark enlightenment).
**[Exegesis]** Tai Qing, having grasped the central Way, sighed in realization that not-knowing is true knowing. Who knows the knowing of not-knowing? This shows how rare true knowing is.

Wu Shi said: "The Dao cannot be heard; to hear it is not it. The Dao cannot be seen; to see it is not it. The Dao cannot be spoken; to speak it is not it. Do you know that which gives form to forms yet itself is formless? The Dao should not be named."
**[Annotation 1]**
**[Commentary]** Thus, it is perfected in the realm of not-hearing and not-seeing, and only then is it attained.
**[Exegesis]** The Dao has no sound, so it cannot be heard with the ears—what is heard is not the Dao. The Dao has no color, so it cannot be seen with the eyes—what is seen is not the Dao. The Dao has no name, so it cannot be spoken—what is spoken is not the Dao.
**[Annotation 2]**
**[Commentary]** Forms form themselves; that which forms forms is ultimately no-thing.
**[Exegesis]** That which gives form and color to the myriad things is itself not form or color—hence it is said to give form to forms yet itself is formless.
**[Annotation 3]**
**[Commentary]** There is the name "Dao," yet ultimately no-thing—thus, the name does not fit.
**[Exegesis]** Names have no power to attain the Dao; the Dao has no reality that corresponds to names—hence, to name the Dao is inappropriate.

Wu Shi said: "One who answers when asked about the Dao does not know the Dao. Even the one who asks about the Dao has not heard the Dao. The Dao admits no questions; questions admit no answers. To question what admits no questions is to question emptiness. To answer what admits no answers is to lack inwardness. Responding to the emptiness of questions with what lacks inwardness—such a one outwardly does not observe the cosmos, inwardly does not know the Great Beginning. Thus, they do not pass beyond Kunlun, nor do they wander in the Great Void."
**[Annotation 1]**
**[Commentary]** To ask out of not-knowing, and to answer such a question, is not the Dao. Not to answer is not what the questioner can attain—thus, though they ask, they ultimately do not hear.
**[Exegesis]** The Dao transcends names and words, so it cannot be questioned or answered. Thus, both asking and answering about the Dao show ignorance.
**[Annotation 2]**
**[Commentary]** This is the meaning of abandoning learning and teaching to return to naturalness.
**[Exegesis]** To embody the Dao is to leave words behind—what questions or answers could there be? These words reiterate the preceding text.
**[Annotation 3]**
**[Commentary]** This is called demanding emptiness.
**[Exegesis]** *Qiong* means "emptiness." To insist on questioning what admits no questions is to demand emptiness.
**[Annotation 4]**
**[Commentary]** To feign existence where there is none is to be external.
**[Exegesis]** To insist on answering what admits no answers is to become externally divided.
**[Note]** Jia Shifu said: The Dao admits no questions—if one conjectures about the Dao and questions it, one first impoverishes oneself, hence "questioning emptiness." The Dao admits no answers—if one conjectures about the Dao and answers it, one follows externals, hence "lacking inwardness."
**[Annotation 5]**
**[Exegesis]** *Yu* refers to the four directions and heaven and earth; *zhou* refers to past and present. The Great Beginning is the root of the Dao. One who meets the emptiness of inner wisdom with a mind external to principle may be said to outwardly not recognize the cosmos of the six directions, and inwardly not know the wondrous root of their own body.
**[Annotation 6]**
**[Commentary]** As for those who ramble through heaven and earth, wander afar, and enter into darkness—this is simply not answering.
**[Exegesis]** Kunlun is a lofty and distant mountain; the Great Void is a profound and mysterious principle. If one remains attached to names and words, still clinging to questions and answers, one has not yet traversed the distant or wandered the profound.

Guang Yao asked Wu You: "Do you, Master, exist? Or do you not exist?"

**[1]**
**[Exegesis]** *Guang Yao* ("Radiance") denotes the faculty of vision—wisdom itself. *Wu You* ("Nonbeing") is the realm it observes. Wisdom possesses the power of illumination, hence the provisional name *Guang Yao*; the realm is empty and quiescent, hence the provisional name *Wu You*. Yet wisdom may be bright or dim, while the realm has no depth or shallowness. Thus, when wisdom questions the realm—does it exist or not?—*Guang Yao* finds no ground for inquiry. Who could discern its form? It is profound and void, seen all day yet unseen, heard yet unheard, grasped yet unattainable.

**[Exegesis]** The wondrous realm is beyond sound and form, where seeing and hearing cease. Thus, when examining its appearance, one finds only stillness and emptiness.
◎ Yu Yue notes: The *Huainanzi*’s "Dao and Its Applications" chapter includes the phrase *"Wu You did not respond"* above *"Guang Yao could not question it."* These five characters should be restored here, for only with *Wu You*’s silence does *Guang Yao*’s inability to question arise. Without them, the meaning is incomplete.

**[Phonetic Gloss]**
*Yaoran* (窅然): read *wū liǎo*.
*Bozhi* (搏之): read *bó*.

*Guang Yao* said: "Perfect! Who could attain this!"

"Now I can possess nothingness, yet I cannot attain non-nothingness; when one reaches the state of non-existence, how could one arrive at this!"

**[Annotation]** This expresses the meaning of cutting off learning. When one severs it from the Dao, then the learner returns to the root. Thus, the excellence of learning lies precisely in non-learning!

**[Exegesis]** Guang Yao’s luminous wisdom is still shallow—he can only grasp nothingness and lose being, yet cannot transcend both being and non-being. Thus, he sighs that non-existence is profoundly deep; who could attain such mystery! Yet this "non-existence" does not merely mean the absence of being, but also the absence of absence itself—all four propositions and a hundred negations are entirely void. The word "non-" in "non-existence" negates all things without exception; its expression is concise, yet its principle vast—hence it is called "non-existence." As for "how could one arrive at this," the realm of non-existence exhausts principle and fulfills nature, and unless one is a sage of profound virtue, who could embody it? Thus, those of shallow learning and petty wisdom have no way to reach it.

A smith under Da Ma, who forged hooks, was eighty years old yet never missed a hair’s breadth.

Da Ma said: "Is it skill? Or is there a Dao?"

**Annotations and Text:**

① **Annotation:** (Weighing) the lightness or heaviness of the forged hooks without the slightest deviation in hair’s breadth.
**Commentary:** "Da Ma" is an official title, the Grand Marshal of Chu. *Chui* (捶) means "to forge by hammering." *Gou* (钩) refers to a belt hook. The Grand Marshal had a craftsman who, from a young age, excelled at forging hooks. Though he had reached eighty years of age, his skill in forging hooks grew ever more refined. With concentrated mind and focused attention, he made no error even as fine as a hair’s breadth. The hook here refers to a steelyard hook, meaning he could precisely gauge the weight of the hook, knowing its exact heft without the slightest deviation.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*"Da Ma’s forger of hooks was eighty years old yet never missed a hair’s breadth."*
*Chui* (捶): Guo reads as *ding guo* (丁果), Xu as *zhi lei* (之累), Li as *zhi shui* (之睡).
*Da Ma*: The Grand Marshal.
*(Weighing)*: Guo says, "Weighing the lightness or heaviness of the forged hooks without missing a hair’s breadth." An alternate explanation holds that in the region between the three Wei rivers of Jiangdong, people commonly called forging *chui* (捶), with the same pronunciation and character. Guo’s interpretation is incorrect, and this explanation is not followed here.
◎ Lu Wenchong notes: "Forging hooks" was originally written as "forging iron" in older editions; corrected here according to the Song edition. Other editions concur.
*Dian* (玷): Read as *ding tian* (丁恬).
*Chui* (捶): Read as *ding guo* (丁果).

② **Commentary:** The Grand Marshal marveled that, though the craftsman was advanced in years, his forging grew ever more precise. He suspected the craftsman’s skill arose from some special Daoist technique.
**Phonetic Gloss:**
*"Skill?"* Read as *yu* (余). The same below.

① **Collation Notes:**
(1) The Tang manuscript writes *hao* (豪) as *gou* (钩).
(2) The character *dian* (玷) is amended here following the *Shiwen* and the Shide Hall edition.
(3) The Shide Hall edition writes *gou* (钩).

The craftsman said: "Your servant has his *shou*. From the age of twenty, I have delighted in forging hooks. To other things, I pay no heed; apart from hooks, I observe nothing. This is how the user relies on the non-user to prolong its use—how much more so for one who employs nothing yet lacks nothing! What thing does not draw sustenance from this?"

① **Commentary:** He possessed no other technique but held fast to his *shou*. From youth, he had devoted himself single-mindedly to this craft. Beyond forging hooks, he observed nothing, and through long practice, it became his nature, thus attaining such mastery.

◎ Wang Niansun notes: *Shou* (守) is the character *Dao* (道). In the *Da Sheng* chapter, Confucius asks: "Is your skill the result of the Dao?" The craftsman replies: "I have the Dao." This is evidence. The character *Dao* was anciently pronounced like *shou*, hence the interchange. (In the rhymed passages of the Nine Classics, *Dao* is always read as *shou*; the *Chu Ci* and the works of Laozi and Zhuangzi follow this pattern. In the Qin Stele Inscription of Kuaiji, "pursuing the lofty and bright" is written with *Dao* in the *Records of the Grand Historian*'s "Annals of Qin Shi Huang," where *Dao* is replaced by *shou*, sharing the same pronunciation. The *Shuowen* states: *Dao* is written with *chu* (辶) and *shou* (首) as phonetic. The modern edition omits the phonetic component because the two Xu brothers did not understand the ancient pronunciation and excised it.)

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*"Delighted in"* Read as *hu bao* (呼報反).

② **Commentary:** Utterly without distraction, all things respond to his call.

**Exegesis:** That he maintained his skill in forging hooks into old age was due to his reliance on not directing his mind to observe other things. If even borrowing non-use as use allows one to sustain it for a lifetime, how much more so for the sage who embodies the Dao—neither using nor not-using, yet capable of great use! Is it not fitting that all things draw sustenance from him?

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*"To prolong"* Read as *ding zhang* (丁丈反).

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The character *zhi* (之) is supplied here following *Dushu Zazhi*.

Ran Qiu asked Confucius, “Could one know what existed before Heaven and Earth?”

Confucius replied, “Yes. The past is like the present.”¹

¹ **Commentary:** Heaven and Earth endure eternally; there was never a time when they did not exist.

**Exegesis:** Ran, surname Ran, personal name Qiu, was a disciple of Confucius. Here, master and disciple engage in dialogue, inquiring whether the state before the existence of the Two Modes could be known. Since transformation renews itself daily, there is no present and no past—the past is like the present. Thus, Confucius answered that it could be known.

Ran Qiu, having posed his question poorly, withdrew. The next day, he returned and said, “Yesterday, I asked, ‘Could one know what existed before Heaven and Earth?’ You replied, ‘Yes. The past is like the present.’² At the time, I understood clearly, but today I am confused. May I ask what this means?”

² **Exegesis:** He failed to grasp the intent of his own question and thus withdrew. Yet upon reflection, he returned to seek clarification.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*"The next day"* Read as *fu you* (扶又反).
*"Returned"* Read as *xian* (贤遍反).

**Exegesis:** When he first posed the question, his mind was bright and clear. Later, in quiet reflection, his thoughts grew dim and obscure. He dares to ask: why was he once enlightened and now benighted?

Confucius said, “Your former clarity came because the spirit first received it.³ Your present confusion arises because you now seek it with what is not spirit.⁴ There is no past, no present, no beginning, no end.⁵ Could there be descendants before there were descendants? Is this possible?”⁶

³ **Commentary:** To empty the mind and await its mandate is to receive it with the spirit.

⁴ **Commentary:** To think and seek further only leads to greater confusion.

**Exegesis:** Initially, he had not yet awakened; he sharpened his spirit and applied his mind to seek understanding, so he was bright and clear. Later, having grasped the meaning, he no longer exerted his spirit but simply let things be as they are, making no further inquiries—thus, he became dim and obstructed. “Seeking” here means not seeking.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*"Now seek"* Read as *you wei* (于伪反).

⁵ **Commentary:** Not only can the nonexistent not transform into existence, but the existent also cannot transform into nonexistence. Thus, that which exists as a thing, though it undergoes a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, cannot become nothing even once. Since it cannot become nothing even once, there has never been a time when Heaven and Earth did not exist.

**Exegesis:** Since things renew themselves daily through transformation, there is no beginning and no end, no past and no present. Thus, we know there was never a time before Heaven and Earth.

⁶ **Commentary:** This speaks of the endless succession of generations.

**Exegesis:** Descendants beget descendants in an unbroken line, generation after generation without end. Heaven and Earth, and all things within them, have no origin, no time when they did not exist. “Is this possible?” means it is not possible.

**Phonetic Gloss:**
*"Descendants before there were descendants"* This refers to the necessity of cause; things cannot arise without reason. Generations succeed one another, so there cannot be descendants without ancestors. Likewise, Heaven and Earth cannot have come into existence after having once been nonexistent.

◎ Lu Wenchang notes: Modern editions read “descendants” as “descendants and ancestors.”
◎ Jia Shifu comments: Heaven and Earth revolve without ceasing; descendants succeed one another without end. If one supposes there were descendants, then to seek what came before descendants is to confuse oneself from the outset. The revolutions of the great transformations of Heaven and Earth have no beginning and no end. How could one seek what came before Heaven and Earth? Thus, it is said, “The past is like the present”—together, they form an expression of boundless continuity.

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The character *fu* (夫) is amended following the *Shide Tang* edition.

Ran Qiu did not respond.

Confucius said, “Enough! No answer is needed. Do not use life to give rise to death,⁷ nor use death to give rise to life.⁸ Do life and death depend on one another?⁹ Each has its own integral form.¹⁰ Was there something that existed before Heaven and Earth?¹¹ That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing. A thing cannot emerge before that which gives rise to it, just as there are things. Just as there are things,¹² there is no end.¹³ The sage’s love for others never ends, for he takes this as his model.”¹⁴

⁷ **Commentary:** Death is simply the solitary transformation of the dead; it is not that life gives rise to this death.

⁸ **Commentary:** Life, too, is simply the solitary transformation of the living.

**Exegesis:** “Enough” means to stop; “no answer” means there is none. Gathering and scattering, death and life—all are solitary transformations, renewed daily, never relying on anything else. How could they depend on one another? Thus, one does not use life to give rise to death, nor death to give rise to life. Since Ran Qiu had no response, Confucius stopped him from answering further, for the principle was exhausted here—what more was there to say?

⁹ **Commentary:** It is self-sufficient in its solitary transformation.

¹⁰ **Commentary:** Death and life each form their own integral whole.

**Exegesis:** Death is a solitary transformation—how could it become something else? Since death does not depend on life, we know that life does not depend on death. Death and life, gathering and scattering—each forms its own integral whole, so there is no mutual dependence.

¹¹ **Commentary:** Who could exist before things? If I take yin and yang as prior to things, yin and yang are themselves things. Who, then, existed before yin and yang? If I take spontaneity as prior, spontaneity is simply the self-so of things. If I take the supreme Dao as prior, the supreme Dao is ultimately nothingness. Since it is nothingness, what could precede it? Then who existed before things? Yet there are things, and there is no end—this makes clear that the spontaneity of things is not caused by anything else.

**Exegesis:** That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing.

Thus, that which is not a thing has no before or after. When a thing emerges, it is a thing, and there can be nothing prior to this thing. How do we know this is so? Because it remains a thing. Extending this reasoning, there is ultimately nothing prior to things. Then who existed before things? It is clear that things arise spontaneously, and spontaneity has no end. Thus we know that heaven, earth, and the myriad things have always existed since antiquity, with no time before their existence.

**Exegesis by Shi Shifu:** That which precedes heaven and earth is the Dao. Yet if we call it "generative," then the Dao is also a thing. If we call it a thing, then what gave rise to that which precedes things? Things succeed one another endlessly, and if we trace the origin of things to find what preceded and gave rise to them, how could things ever cease? If they ceased, something would have initiated them; if they do not cease, what could initiate them? Therefore, when a thing emerges, it cannot precede other things.

**Commentary:** Taking spontaneity as the source, its grace flows through a hundred generations without end.

**Exegesis:** The sage who attains the Dao, with compassionate love and nurturing care, extends grace through a hundred generations without limit. This is because their virtue harmonizes with heaven and earth, and their wondrous embodiment is spontaneous. Thus they empty themselves toward others, forgetful of all concerns, neither cherishing the myriad things nor treating the people as straw dogs. They act in accordance with this principle.

**Textual Notes:**
(1) The Tang manuscript omits "thing" after "者."
(2) In the phrase "犹其有物也," the Liu Deyi edition does not repeat the character.

Yan Yuan asked Confucius, "I once heard the Master say, 'Do not send off, do not welcome.' May I ask about their wandering?"

**Exegesis:** Yan Yuan requests the Master’s teaching. To "send off" means to see off. The sage is like a mirror, neither sending off nor welcoming. Having heard this, Yan Yuan did not yet understand the principle, so he inquired of Confucius about its meaning.

Confucius said, "The people of antiquity transformed externally but remained untransformed internally. The people of today transform internally but remain untransformed externally. Those who transform with things are one with the untransforming. At peace with transformation and non-transformation, at peace with blending with them, they must blend without excess. The hunting parks of Xiwei, the gardens of the Yellow Emperor, the palaces of Youyu, the halls of Tang and Wu—these were the masters of the Confucians and Mohists, who used them to engage in mutual disputation. How much more so the people of today! The sage dwells among things without harming them. One who does not harm things cannot be harmed by things. Only one who harms nothing can join others in sending off and welcoming. The mountain forests! The marshes and wilds!"

Let me bring forth joy that fills me with delight! Yet before the joy is complete, sorrow follows in its wake. Joy and sorrow come unbidden—I cannot resist their arrival, nor can I halt their departure. How lamentable! The people of this world are but transient lodgers in the realm of things.

They know what they encounter but not what they do not; they know what they can do but not what they cannot. Yet ignorance and inability are inescapable for all. To strive to avoid what no one can escape—is this not also cause for sorrow?

Ultimate words transcend words; ultimate actions transcend action. To equal the knowledge of what knowledge knows is but shallow indeed.

---

Harmony is the state of accord. The masters of Confucianism and Mohism, who are the most difficult in the world to harmonize, can still be harmonized by those who are without intent—how much more so the ordinary! Harmony is the state of accord. The masters of Confucianism and Mohism, who endlessly dispute right and wrong, are the most difficult in the world to harmonize, yet the sage and the noble person can still follow and harmonize them. How much more so the people of this age, who are not masters of Confucianism or Mohism! To adapt and transform with them is only fitting.

Shih-wei, the Yellow Emperor, the sage-kings of Yu, Tang, and Wu, and the masters of Confucianism and Mohism—none fully embodied the Dao of inner transformation without change, and thus they arrived at disputes of right and wrong, showing that they still contended over such matters. Only when the five flavors blend and contend can harmony arise; thus it is called "accord."

Utmost compliance. Abiding in the worldly while blending one’s light, benefiting without harming—thus one does not injure. It rests with me alone. The empty boat and drifting tile, in perfect accord with all beings, are joyfully embraced by them, and so one dwells without harm.

Without intent, one attains utmost compliance; with utmost compliance, one can be without anticipation or reception, yet surpass those who anticipate and receive. Only by peacefully accepting all things, so that self and other remain unharmed, can one interact with the world and illuminate the truth that there is no reception, yet reception occurs.

Mountains, forests, riverbanks, and wilds are not inherently superior to me, yet I delight in them—this is joy without cause. Joy without cause is also sorrow without cause. Thus, all that brings joy is not truly joy, and all that brings sorrow is not truly sorrow. Ordinary emotions cling and fixate, falsely generating delight and aversion. Suddenly beholding towering mountains and lush forests, sacred riverbanks and secluded wilds, one feels joyful admiration, deeming it bliss. Yet before long, sorrow follows, for emotions shift with circumstances, and joy and sorrow transform. This is joy without cause, sorrow without cause—thus the world’s joys and sorrows are not worth reckoning.

One cannot sit in forgetfulness and attain self-realization, yet remains bound to joy and sorrow. An inn is a lodging for travelers. The coming of poverty and success cannot be warded off, nor can the departure of joy and sorrow be halted. Yet the common people, unversed in this truth, are like guests at an inn, detained by things, mistaking the illusory for the real—how deeply lamentable!

What knowledge encounters, it knows; what it does not encounter, it does not know. What one cannot do, one cannot force oneself to do. From this, we see that knowing and not knowing, being able and not being able, are not determined by me—they should be entrusted to nature.

Wisdom has its brightness and dimness, ability its skill and clumsiness; each is endowed with its inherent portion, which cannot be forced. Thus, what one’s portion encounters, one knows; what it does not, one cannot know. What one’s nature can do, one can do; what it cannot, one cannot. Like birds flying and fish swimming, spiders weaving webs and dung beetles rolling balls—following nature, is this not their inherent disposition?

My late uncle said: Each has what it knows, each has what it can do—there is no forcing one another; each has what it does not know, each has what it cannot do—there is no surpassing one another. To force what one knows to comprehend what one does not, to force what one can do to accomplish what one cannot, and then to claim this as knowledge or ability, to impose it upon the world and make all equal—this breeds contention over right and wrong and multiplies joy and sorrow. Therefore, forget what you know, and knowledge will naturally align; forget what you can do, and ability will naturally align. Ultimate words transcend words; ultimate actions transcend action. Having already forgotten oneself, how could one have leisure to equalize the world? Those who equalize the knowledge of what knowledge knows are those who, based on what they know, forcibly impose it upon the world.

Receiving life, each has its allotted portion. Since one is not a sage, one’s wisdom cannot encompass all things. Thus, knowing and not knowing, being able and not being able, are endowed differently, with each having its own mechanism. Yet the common people stubbornly resist what they cannot escape.

What humans cannot escape are matters beyond their allotted wisdom and ability. Yet the vulgar and base cannot accept their portion, so they strive with deluded clarity, seeking to uniquely escape—how profoundly foolish and deeply lamentable!

All is self-realization. The words of ultimate principle transcend words, so they are abandoned. The actions of ultimate principle transcend action, so they are abandoned.

Those who attain through knowledge are merely learners, thus their understanding is shallow. Seeing the worthy and thinking to equal them, abandoning oneself to emulate others, seeking principle through learning, employing knowledge to inquire into the Dao—this is superficial, not profound understanding.

**Chapter 23 of Miscellaneous Writings, Volume 8 (Part 1): "Gengsang Chu"**

This chapter is named after a person. Some versions title it *Gengsang Chu*.

Among the disciples of Lao Dan was one named Gengsang Chu, who had uniquely attained the Dao of Lao Dan. He went north to dwell in the mountains of Weilei. Those among his retainers who were cunningly clever departed from him, and those among his concubines who were ostentatiously benevolent kept their distance. Only the dull-witted remained with him, and the restless were employed as his servants.

After three years, Weilei flourished abundantly. The people of Weilei said to one another: "When Master Gengsang first arrived, we regarded him with surprise. Now, when we reckon our daily gains, they seem insufficient, but when we tally our yearly harvest, there is surplus. He must be a sage! Why do we not together honor him as our ancestral spirit, worship him as our earth deity, and revere him as our grain god?"

---

[2] [Annotation] *Huaran* refers to ostentatious cleverness; *qieran* refers to affected benevolence.
[Exegesis] Weilei is the name of a mountain, located in the state of Lu. "Retainers" are servants and slaves; "concubines" are attendants. This means that people regard benevolence and wisdom as servants and concubines, but Gengsang Chu entirely discarded benevolence and wisdom in his dealings with the noble-minded.

Having become a recluse, Chu dwelt in the mountains and marshes, his nature honest and unadorned, his heart disdaining superficial splendor. The men and women of the mountainside vied to serve him as retainers and concubines. Thus, those who were *huaran*—flaunting their cleverness to dazzle—he expelled and sent away; those who were *qieran*—affecting benevolence to set themselves apart—he caused to keep their distance.

[Philological Notes] *Wei* (畏) is sometimes written as *wei* (猥), both pronounced *wěi*. *Lei* (垒), in Cui’s edition, is written as *lei* (累), both pronounced *lěi*. Li Yi says: Weilei is the name of a mountain. Some say it is in Lu, others in Liangzhou. *Huaran* is pronounced *huò*. *Zhi* (知, "cleverness") is pronounced *zhì*, as in the annotation. *Qieran* is sometimes written as *qieran* (契), both pronounced *qiè*. Xiang Xiu says: It means "cleverness." Also pronounced *qiè*. The *Guangya* says: It means "to lift." *Yuanzhi* ("kept their distance") is pronounced *yuǎnzhī*. Sima Biao says: This means that people regard benevolence and wisdom as servants and concubines, but Gengsang discarded them entirely.

[3] [Annotation] *Yongzhong* means "uncarved simplicity."
[Philological Notes] *Yong* (拥) is pronounced *yǒng*. *Zhong* (肿) is pronounced *zhǒng*. In some editions, it is written as *zhǒng* (踵).

[4] [Annotation] *Yangzhang* means "self-contentment."
[Exegesis] *Yongzhong* and *yangzhang* both describe the appearance of unadorned self-contentment. Having discarded benevolence and wisdom, he returned to plainness, and so the simple and unrefined *shi* dwelt with him, while those of unbridled nature were employed as his servants.

[Philological Notes] *Yangzhang* is pronounced *yǎngzhǎng*. Guo Xiang says: *Yongzhong* means "uncarved simplicity"; *yangzhang* means "self-contentment." Cui Zhuan says: *Yongzhong* describes ignorance; *yangzhang* conveys an unfeeling manner. Xiang Xiu says: Both phrases describe rustic clumsiness. Sima Biao says: Both describe an ugly appearance.

[5] [Annotation] This is because he discarded wisdom and relied on foolishness.
[Philological Notes] *Darǎng* is pronounced *érzhǎng*. In some editions, it is written as *ráng* (穰). Cui’s edition is the same, also pronounced *ráng* or *rǎng*. The *Guangya* says: It means "abundance." Lu Wenchang notes: In the *Liezi*’s "Heaven’s Blessings" chapter, *rǎng* is also used for *ráng* (穰). *Sǎrán* is pronounced *sùtiǎn* or *xǐlǐ*. Cui and Li say: It describes a startled appearance. Xiang Xiu pronounces it *sūhěn*.

[6] [Annotation] One who moves in harmony with the four seasons seeks no immediate gains.
[Exegesis] *Darǎng* means "abundance." *Sǎ* describes a slight startle. After three years of dwelling there, the mountains flourished greatly. The people of Weilei said to one another in private: "When Gengsang Chu first arrived, we were slightly startled. Now, when we reckon our daily gains, they seem insufficient, but when we tally the year’s harvest, there is surplus. He must be a sage! For he moves in harmony with the four seasons, seeking no immediate gains—thus daily reckoning seems insufficient—but his distant virtue ensures that yearly reckoning yields surplus. The heavens complete a minor cycle every three years with an intercalary month, and so after three years, Weilei flourished abundantly."

[Philological Notes] *Rì jì zhī ér bùzú* ("daily reckoning seems insufficient"): Xiang Xiu says: There is no small profit from day to day. *Suì jì zhī ér yǒuyú* ("yearly reckoning yields surplus"): Xiang Xiu says: Following the seasons, there is great abundance.

[7] [Exegesis] *Shù* means "to admire"; *jī* means "near." *Shī* means "to preside over."

Gengsang, a man of great worth, admired and drew near to the virtue of the sage. Why not together honor him as lord, preside over the affairs of the southern throne, establish altars of soil and grain, build ancestral temples, and offer prayers and sacrifices according to ritual—would this not be excellent?

[Textual Notes]
(1) The character *shì* (飾) is amended following the commentary.
(2) The character *shì* (士) is restored following Liu Wendian’s corrected edition.
(3) The character *hěn* (很) is amended following the *Yunhui*; the Shidetang edition mistakenly omits it.

When Gengsangzi heard this, he faced south yet remained unsettled. His disciples found this strange.

[1] [Exegesis] Suddenly hearing that the people of Weilei would make him lord of the southern throne—this contravened the Way of non-action, so he was displeased. His disciples, not understanding this intent, were thus puzzled and found it strange.

Gengsangzi said: “Disciples, why do you find me strange? When the qi of spring stirs, the hundred grasses grow; when autumn arrives in due season, the ten thousand treasures ripen. Do spring and autumn achieve this by deliberate effort? The Dao of Heaven has already unfolded.”

[2] [Commentary] Spring’s generation and autumn’s fruition both accord with the natural Way, so no action is taken.
[Exegesis] Spring’s growth and autumn’s harvest are the constant workings of yin and yang; summer’s flourishing and winter’s storage are the regular patterns of things. Thus spring and autumn do not intentionally bestow upon the myriad beings—yet the natural Dao has already operated of itself, so one forgets the virtue of their arising and possessing.
[Philological Notes] *Zhèng dé qiū ér wàn bǎo chéng* (“when autumn arrives in due season, the ten thousand treasures ripen”): Heaven and Earth regard the myriad things as treasure, and by autumn they come to fruition. The Yuanjia edition reads *wàn shí* (“ten thousand fruits”). ◎ Yu Yue says: The character *dé* (得) is likely superfluous; the original text probably read *zhèng qiū ér wàn bǎo chéng* (“when autumn arrives in due season, the ten thousand treasures ripen”). The *Yi*’s *Shuogua* states: *Duì zhèng qiū yě* (“Dui corresponds to the proper autumn”), and “the myriad things rejoice in their completion.” The subcommentary says: “In proper autumn, the myriad things all rejoice in their completion.” This passage is evidence. The character *dé* (得) was likely mistakenly added due to the following sentence: *Fū chūn yǔ qiū qǐ wú dé ér rán zāi* (“Do spring and autumn achieve this by deliberate effort?”). The meaning of *chūn qì fā ér bǎi cǎo shēng, zhèng qiū ér wàn bǎo chéng* (“When the qi of spring stirs, the hundred grasses grow; when autumn arrives in due season, the ten thousand treasures ripen”) is already complete; there is no need to add *dé* (得) to create parallelism with the preceding line. *Dà dào yǐ xíng yǐ* (“The great Dao has already unfolded”): Some editions read *tiān dào* (“the Dao of Heaven”).

[3] [Commentary] They simply proceed of themselves, not through knowledge.
[Exegesis] Four walls, each one *du* (堵) in length, form an *huán dǔ* (環堵), what is called a “square-zhang chamber.” As still as a corpse, hence “dwelling like a corpse.”
[Philological Notes] *Huán* (環): Read as written. The *Guangya* says: “round.” *Dǔ* (堵): Pronounced *dīng lǔ*. Sima Biao says: “One *zhang* is called a *du* (堵).” *Huán dǔ* (環堵): Each side is one *zhang*, indicating its smallness.

[4] [Commentary] He did not wish to be a measuring mark for things.
[Exegesis] *Qièqiè* (竊竊): Whispering in pairs. *Zǔ* (俎): A stand for cutting meat; *dòu* (豆): A vessel for holding dried meat—both are ritual implements. The flock of dragons has no head: the sage’s guiding words.

Gengsangzi said: “Now, with the humble folk of Weilei whispering among themselves to place me among the worthies with ritual vessels—am I one to be measured? This is why I remain unsettled by the words of Lao Dan.”

[5] [No additional exegesis provided in the original.]

The cultivation of obscurity nurtures tranquility, leaving a path for later worthies to follow. Now, the petty folk of Weilei whisper in pairs, seeking to honor me as a worthy and revere me as their master—this is to make me a measuring mark for things. How could this be the way of one who dwells in reclusion!

[Philological Notes] *Zǔ dòu* (俎豆): Pronounced *cè lǚ*. Cui says: “*Zǔ dòu* means to set me among the common folk.” *Biāo* (杓): Guo reads as *dí*, also *pǐ yāo*, or *diào*. The *Guangya* says: “the tip of a tree.” Guo says: “to be a measuring mark for things.” Wang says: “This is to make oneself a target for others.” Xiang says: “Ma’s edition writes *diào*, pronounced *dí*.” *Biāo* (标): Pronounced *bì yáo*, also *bì xiǎo*.

[5] [Commentary] Lao Dan said: “When merit is accomplished and affairs are settled, the people all say, ‘We did this ourselves.’ Now, the folk of Weilei reverse this, which is why I am unsettled.”
[Exegesis] The Old Master said: “Achieve success without claiming it, lead without dominating.” Chu, having reverently received his teacher’s instruction, finds the people of Weilei acting contrary to this, and so remains unsettled.

[Textual Variants] (1) The character *chéng* (成) follows the *Shi De Tang* edition. (2) The modern edition reads *tiān dào* (天道).

The disciple said: “It is not so. In a ditch of ordinary size, great fish have no room to turn their bodies, and so the *ni* rule there; on a hillock of a few paces, mighty beasts have no place to conceal themselves, and so the fox becomes its omen. Moreover, to honor the worthy and empower the capable, to put goodness and benefit first—this has been so since the time of Yao and Shun, how much more should it apply to the people of Weilei! Master, you should listen to them!”

The disciple’s note states: “This means that great persons must possess abundant emolument.”

The subcommentary explains: A length of eight *chi* is called a *xun*; twice that is a *chang*. A distance of six *chi* is called a *bu*; seven *chi* make a *ren*. The *ni* is a small fish with legs—this is not the great fish *kun*. *Zhi* means “to dominate.” How could a ditch of mere *xun* and *chang* accommodate the circling of *kun* and *jing*? Yet the tiny *ni* fish is deemed fine there. A hillock of only *bu* and *ren* cannot conceal a mighty beast, yet the ominous fox is taken as an auspicious sign. Thus we know that great beasts must hide in deep mountains, and great persons require generous emolument.

The *Shiwen* glosses:
- *“Xun-chang ditch”*: Eight *chi* make a *xun*; twice a *xun* is a *chang*. A *xun-chang* ditch corresponds to the breadth and depth of the *xu* and *kuai* in the *Zhou Ritual*. The *xu* is eight *chi* wide and deep; the *kuai* is two *xun* wide and two *ren* deep.
- *“To turn its body”*: Pronounced *xuan*, meaning “to revolve.” Cui’s edition reads *dai*.
- *“Ni”*: Pronounced *wu-xi*. The character *qiu* is pronounced *qiu*.
- *“Dominates it”*: The *Guang Ya* states: *Zhi* means “to bend.” That is, the small fish can twist and turn. Wang comments: *Zhi* means “to dominate,” as the *ni* monopolizes the small ditch.
◎ Qingfan notes: The *Shiwen* says *zhi* means “to bend,” meaning the small fish can twist and turn. *Zhe* (“to break”) and *zhi* (“to control”) were originally interchangeable characters. The *Book of Lü*’s “*zhi* with punishment” is cited in the *Mozi* as “*zhe* then punish”; in the *Analects*’ “Yan Yuan” chapter, “a word can *zhe* a lawsuit” appears in the Lu *Analects* as “can *zhi* a lawsuit”—this is evidence.
- *“A hillock of bu and ren”*: Six *chi* make a *bu*; seven *chi* make a *ren*. It is one *bu* wide and one *ren* tall. Kong Anguo says: eight *chi* make a *ren*. The *Xiao Er Ya* states: four *chi* make a *ren*.
◎ Jia Shifu says: Water is where fish gather; hills and mounds are where beasts gather. Even a *xun-chang* ditch or a *bu-ren* hillock must have something that gathers there, for there is something to take refuge in. The greater the virtue, the more gather to it. Guo Xiang’s use of the great fish and beast as metaphors, saying that great persons must have abundant emolument, is mistaken.
- *“Qiu”*: Pronounced *yu-jie*.
- *“The fox becomes its omen”*: Li comments: *Xiang* means “portent.” Foxes and raccoon dogs are inauspicious. Each has its proper place; if the proper place is not lost, then great persons possess abundant emolument. Wang comments: Wild foxes rely on it to create omens. Cui comments: The *gu* fox takes the small hill as good fortune. *Xiang* means “good.”

The subcommentary to the second note explains: To honor the worthy and elevate the capable, to put goodness first and bestow its benefits—even the sage-kings Yao and Shun acted thus. How much more should the people of Weilei! Master, as one who comprehends all things, should deign to listen!

Master Gengsangzi said: “Come, my disciple! The beast that can hold a carriage in its mouth, once it leaves the mountain in its solitude, cannot escape the disaster of nets and snares. The fish that can swallow a boat, once it drifts and loses the water, is tormented by ants. Thus birds and beasts do not disdain the heights, and fish and turtles do not disdain the depths.

The note states: To avoid harm and distance oneself from profit is to be whole.

The subcommentary explains: That beast is so vast its mouth can hold a carriage; once it stands alone and leaves the mountain, it cannot escape the disaster of nets and snares. The fish that can swallow a boat is no small creature; once it drifts and loses the water, ants can harm it. Thus birds and beasts seek high mountains, and fish and turtles seek deep waters—is this love of the unusual? It is to preserve their bodies and avoid harm. If even birds and fish act thus, how much more should humans!

The *Shiwen* glosses:
- *“Han”*: Pronounced *han*.
- *“The beast that holds a carriage”*: Li comments: A beast as large as a carriage. Another says: large enough to hold a carriage.
- *“Stands alone”*: Pronounced *jie*. The *Guang Ya* says: “alone.” Also pronounced *gu-xia*. One edition reads *fen*, meaning “to separate.” The Yuangjia edition is the same.
◎ Yu Yue says: The *Fangyan* states: a beast without a mate is called *jie*. One edition reads *fen*—incorrect.
◎ Qingfan notes: *Jie* in the *Shiwen* appears in one edition as *fen*. *Fen* and *li* (“to leave”) form a coherent meaning, so the edition reading *fen* is correct. In ancient texts, *jie* was written as *fen*; *fen* was later corrupted to *jie* (介), and the two shapes being similar, transcription errors are common. The *Guliang Zhuan* for the 30th year of Duke Zhuang reads: “Yan Zhouzi *fen*zi”; the *Shiwen* notes: *fen* appears in one edition as *jie*. The *Zhou Ritual*’s *Da Zongbo* commentary on “pheasants take their heads *jie* and die” notes: *jie* appears in one edition as *fen*. The *Chunqiu Fanlu*’s “Establishing the Origin and Spirit” chapter has *jie* blocking perilous terrain, where *jie* is a corruption of *fen*. The *Huainanzi*’s “Miu Cheng” chapter says: “Disasters arise *fen-fen*,” which Wang Niansun emends to *jie-jie*—this is evidence.
- *“Leaves the mountain”*: Pronounced *li-zhi*. Below and in the note, the same.
- *“Swallow a boat”*: Pronounced *chi-en*, also *tian*.
- *“Drifts and loses the water”*: Pronounced *tu-lang*, meaning to drift and lose the water. Cui’s edition reads “leaves the water and dwells on land.”
- *“Then ants”*: Pronounced *yu-qi*.
- *“Torment it”*: Read as written. Xiang comments: Ma’s edition reads *zui* (“most”), also *qiong* (“exhaust”).

The note to the second passage states: If one entangles oneself in emolument and salary, one is coarse and shallow.

The subcommentary explains: *Miao* means “distant.” Those who retire to preserve their lives must distance themselves from the dust of the world and deeply enter mountains and springs. If one entangles oneself in emolument and salary, one is coarse and shallow.

The *Shiwen* glosses:
- *“Deep and distant”*: Pronounced *mi-xiao*.
- *“Coarse”*: Pronounced *qi-nu*.

All subsequent instances follow the same pattern.

Moreover, how could these two men ever be worthy of praise! In their disputations, they are like those who recklessly breach walls only to plant thistles and weeds. Combing their hair strand by strand, measuring rice grain by grain—how could such petty fastidiousness ever serve the world! Promote the worthy, and the people will contend; entrust the rapacious, and the people will steal. These few measures are not enough to enrich the people. The people’s pursuit of profit is so relentless that fathers are murdered by sons, rulers by ministers; in broad daylight they commit robbery, and at noon they bore through walls. I tell you: the root of great disorder must have arisen in the age of Yao and Shun, and its branches will endure for a thousand generations. A thousand generations hence, there will surely be men who devour one another!

---

**Note to the first passage:**
The two men refer to Yao and Shun.

**Subcommentary:**
The two men refer to Yao and Shun. The sagely traces of Tang and Yu are the root of disorder among men—how could they be worthy of praise!

**Shiwen Gloss:**
*“The two men”*: Xiang, Cui, and Guo all say: Yao and Shun.

---

**Note to the second passage:**
This will cause later generations to recklessly engage in breaches and plant defilement and chaos.

**Subcommentary:**
This will cause later generations to recklessly engage in breaches and plant defilement and chaos. *Bian* means “to distinguish.” To establish the ways of Yao and Shun outside the nature of things and teach later men to imitate their traces is like breaching a fine wall only to plant thistles and weeds as a barrier.

**Shiwen Gloss:**
*“Thistles”*: Pronounced *pu-kong*.
*“Will cause”*: Pronounced *li-cheng*.

---

**Note to the third passage:**
This is like managing the tip of an awl.

**Subcommentary:**
It is like carefully selecting and combing each hair or measuring each grain of rice for cooking—such trivial benefits are far outweighed by the harm.

**Shiwen Gloss:**
*“And comb”*: Pronounced *zhuang-bi*. Also written as *栉* or *楖*, all equivalent. Guo reads *jie*; Xu reads *ce-ji*.
◎ Lu Wenchang notes: Modern texts write *栉*.
◎ Wang Yinzhi notes: The *Shiwen* reads *扻* as *zhuang-bi*, also written as *栉* or *楖*, all equivalent. Guo reads *jie*; Xu reads *ce-ji*. According to the *Yupian*, *扻* is pronounced *ku-gan*, meaning “to strike.” It cannot be read *zhuang-bi* or *jie*. *扻* should be *□*, the same as the *□* in the *Yupian*. In clerical script, the hand radical was mistakenly moved to the left.
