The *Yupian* reads *□* as *qi-zi*, meaning “to grasp.” Here it is borrowed for *栉* (“to comb”), hence the pronunciations *zhuang-bi* and *jie*. Characters with the *ci* phonetic may be read as *ji* or *jie*. The *Shuowen* states: *Ci* (堲), to enlarge a road with earth, from *tu* (土) and *ci* (次) as phonetic. The ancient form *{堲}* (一) is from *tu* (土) and *ji* (即) as phonetic, citing the *Book of Yu*: “My *ji* (堲) slanderous words and perverse conduct.” The *Yupian* reads *cai-zi* or *cai-ji*. The *Shuowen* states: *Zi* (咨), a bracket, from *mu* (木) and *zi* (咨) as phonetic. *Zi* (咨) is from *kou* (口) and *ci* (次) as phonetic, as in “mountain *jie* (节) and painted beams.” The *Kang Gao* reads: “Do not employ *ci* (次) to enfeoff your daughter.” The *Xunzi*’s *Zhi Shi* chapter cites this, writing *ci* as *ji*. These are all examples.

「□ is the *comb* in "to comb one's hair," and should be read with the *rù* (入) tone. However, since its character uses *cì* (次) as the phonetic component, it may also be read with the *qù* (去) tone, hence Xu Mì’s pronunciation as *cè-jì* (侧冀反).

*《Shùmǐ》* (数米) reads *sè-zhǔ* (色主反).
*《Érchuī》* (而炊) reads *chāng-chuí* (昌垂反).
Xiàng (向) says: "This is but minor profit-seeking." **[IV] [Annotation]**: "Mixed and unified, without restraint, this is no way to bring about salvation."

**[Cushí] (疏)**: "Following the traditions of Yao and Shun, yet indulging in private scheming—this is but a petty Dao, how can it suffice to save the world!"
**[Shìwén] (释文)**: "*《Qièqiè》* (窃窃) as the character reads."

Sīmǎ (司马) says: "Whispered speech."
Another interpretation: "The appearance of calculating and measuring."
Cuī (崔) reads it as *chá-chá* (察察).

**[V] [Annotation]**: "When one suppresses and frustrates their nature to await what they truly cherish."
**[Shìwén] (释文)**: "*《Yà》* (轧) reads *wū-qiè* (乌黠反), Xiàng (向) pronounces it *yǐ* (乙).
*《Lì-fú》* (戾拂) reads *fú-fú* (符弗反).

**[VI] [Annotation]**: "If truth is insufficient and one relies on knowledge to follow, then it becomes falsehood. Falsehood in pursuit of life—what else is this but theft?"
**[Cushí] (疏)**: "Yà (轧) means harm. When one promotes the worthy and assigns tasks based on ability, prioritizing knowledge over virtue, then deception and rivalry flourish, and a hundred schemes of theft and trickery arise. The paths of competition open wide, and thus mutual harm ensues."

**[Shìwén] (释文)**: "*《Rènzhī》* (任知) is pronounced *zhì* (智). The annotation is the same."

**[VII] [Annotation]**: "Nothing left to look back upon."
**[Cushí] (疏)**: "Counting things" refers to promoting the worthy and assigning tasks based on knowledge. This teaching fosters superficiality and cannot cultivate the sincerity and virtue of the common people. Yet the people’s greedy hearts are ever eager for gain, and private resentments and grievances give rise to regicide and treason, endangering the state. They commit theft in broad daylight, assaulting cities and breaching walls at noon.

**[Shìwén] (释文)**: "*Yǒushā* (有杀) pronounced *shì* (试). The original also reads *shì* (弒). The same below. *Xuèhuài* (穴坏) pronounced *pǔhuí* (普回反). Xiàng (向) pronounced *péi* (裴), saying: *huài* (坏) means "wall." This speaks of having nothing to fear or restrain. ◎Qìng Fān’s annotation: □ is the same as *péi*. In *Huáinánzǐ*’s *Qísú* (齐俗) chapter, "凿培而遁之" (high walls breached to flee), Gāo Yù’s annotation says: *péi* (培) is the rear wall. (*Qísú* chapter must include acts of burrowing, scaling, and leaping over □—deliberate transgressions.) □ is also the same as *péi*, hence Gāo’s annotation: □ is the rear wall. *Lǚshì Chūnqiū*’s *Tīngyán* (听言) chapter also uses *péi*, while *Hànshū*’s *Yáng Xiōng* biography uses *huài*, with slight phonetic variation but identical meaning.

**[VIII] [Annotation]**: "Emperor Yáo and Shùn left their traces, yet false adornments spread afterward, leading to these calamities."
**[Cushí] (疏)**: The refined deference of the Tang and Yù dynasties gave way to treasonous chaos. The roots of this disorder trace back to Yáo and Shùn, and their ill effects persist for a thousand years—Yellow Turbans and Red Eyebrows, devouring one another.

**[Shìwén] (释文)**: "*Wúyǔ* (吾语) pronounced *yújù* (鱼据反). *Nǚ* (女) pronounced *rǔ* (汝). The same below.

**[Jiào] (校)**:
**(1)** The character *qí* (堲) is supplemented according to *Shuōwén Jiězì*.
**(2)** The character *jiān* (奸) is corrected according to the original *Huáinánzǐ* text.

Nán Róng *zhì* (趎), sitting upright with a solemn demeanor, said: "If one of my age has already grown old, where then shall I entrust my Dao to reach such words as these?" **[1]**

**[1] [Cushí] (疏)**: Nán Róng, given name *Zhì* (趎), was a disciple of Gēngsāng.

「Shùrán—an expression of startled awe—betokened Nán Róng’s demeanor. Upon hearing this teaching, his heart filled with reverence and admiration. Thus, with solemn composure and earnest sincerity, he humbly sought further instruction:

*"Zhì is old, his spirit dimmed by age—upon what learning may I rely to grasp such words as these?"*

**[Shìwén]**: *Nán Róng Zhì* is pronounced *Chāngyú* (昌于反), *xiàng* (向) as *chóu* (畴), *yī* (一) as *shàojù* (绍俱反) or *xúzhí* (徐直俱反), and also *chùjù* (敕俱反) or *chǔyóu* (处由反). Lǐ [Xingzhong] notes: "A disciple of Gēngsāng." The *Hànshū* *Gǔjīn Rénbiǎo* records him as *Nán Róng Chóu*. Some texts render his name as *tóu* (俦) or *shòu* (寿). The *Huáinánzǐ* writes *Nán Róng shuì* (帱), describing him as *"kèluó bùxī"* (欶蹻趹步), ceaselessly marching a hundred *shè* without rest. Others also use *chóu* (畴). ◎ Lú Wénpiàn remarks: *"The current text of Huáinán Xiūwù Xùn reads chóu (畴). The earlier 'kèluó' (欶蹻) was corrupted as 'chùmiǎn' (敕蟜); now corrected according to the original text."* Gāo Yù’s annotation explains: *"Kè (欶), like zhù (箸); luó (蹻), footwear; bù (步), to hasten. Kè is pronounced 'jiǎo' (角); luó as 'qiè' (略); bù as 'jué' (决). Zhù is 'zhuó' (着), pronounced 'zhí' (直略); bù (趋), to stride. Some versions omit 'bù' (步), a missing character."*

Gēngsāngzǐ replied:
*"Preserve your form intact **[1]**, cherish your life **[2]**, and let no restless scheming cloud your mind. If you abide thus for three years, then you may attain these words **[3]."**

「**[1]** **[Annotation]** *Guard your allotted portion.* **[Reading]** *Its portion* is pronounced *fú-wèn* (扶问).
Later interpretations sought meaning beyond the text.

**[2]** **[Annotation]** *Do not grasp at anything beyond your life.* ◎ **Yú Yì** remarks: *The Shīmíng* (释名) under *Shì Zīróng* (释姿容) states: *"Bào (抱), to preserve; xiàng qīn bǎo (相亲保), to protect what is close."* This shows that *bào* (抱) and *bǎo* (保) share the same meaning. *Bào rǔ shēng* (抱汝生) is equivalent to *bǎo rǔ shēng* (保汝生). Gāo Yù’s annotation—*"Do not grasp at anything beyond your life"*—takes *bào* (抱) literally, failing to grasp its figurative usage through *fǎjiè* (假借).

**[3]** **[Exegesis]** When the mind ceases to chase external phenomena, it attains *quánjué* (全角, "preservation of the whole"). To *guard one’s allotted portion* (守其分内) and *preserve one’s life* (抱生者) is to cultivate stillness. Once the division is rectified and life preserved whole, the spirit concentrates and the body relaxes, so no further exertion of thought or worry is needed. Only after three years of *xūjìng* (虚静, "emptiness and tranquility") can one truly reach these words. This is the teaching of **Gēngsāngzǐ** to **Nán Róng**.

**[Reading]** *Thinking* is pronounced *xī-lì* (息吏). Same as below. **Nán Róng** replied:
*"The eye and its form—I do not know their difference, yet the blind cannot see themselves;
The ear and its form—I do not know their difference, yet the deaf cannot hear themselves;
The heart and its form—I do not know their difference, yet the mad cannot find themselves.
**[1]** The form and its form are also divided**[2]**, yet external things may interfere with this, making it so that one seeks the other but cannot attain**[3]**.
Now you tell me, **tréng**[4]: *'Preserve your form, cherish your life, and let no restless scheming cloud your mind.'*
**Tréng**, I strive to hear the **Dao/Way** and understand its depths!"**[5]**»

---

**[1] [Annotation]** The eye with the eye, the ear with the ear, the heart with the heart—though their forms resemble one another, their capacities differ. If they differ, then one cannot imitate or emulate the other.
**[Commentary]** The blind and the deaf do not differ in outward form from ordinary people with sight and hearing, yet the blind cannot perceive colors, and the deaf cannot hear sounds. The mad and the sane may appear alike in appearance, yet the mad lose their nature and cannot find themselves. **Nán Róng** cited these three instances to illustrate the unity of the body—how one may fail to grasp the **Dao/Way**’s deepest truths just as the blind and deaf fail to perceive the world. Hence, the *Inner Chapters* state: *"It is not only the physical form that is blind and deaf—even wisdom may be so."*

**[Textual Notes]** *可* (kě) is pronounced *qì-zhàng* (其丈反). The same applies below.

**[2] [Annotation]** [The forms] have not yet been closed off.
**[Textual Notes]** *亦辟* (yì pì) is pronounced *bì-yì* (婢亦反), meaning "open." **Cuī** (崔) says: "It means *relative*." Pronounced *bì-yì* (必亦反).
◎ **Jiāshì Fù** (家世父) says: **Guó Xiàng**’s annotation—*"The form and its form are also divided"*—means *"have not yet been closed off."* The *Textual Notes* explain: *辟* (pì), pronounced *bì-yì* (婢亦反), means "open." This is a homophonic substitution. **Zhèng Kāngchéng**’s annotation on the *Great Learning* states: *辟* (pì) means *"to illustrate."* The *Shuōwén Jiezi* (说文解字) under the *Speech* radical says: *"Pì (譬), to illustrate."* The *Fāng Jì* (坊记) uses *pì* (辟) for *"prevent"* and *"compare,"* while the *Zhōng Yōng* (中庸) uses it as *"like walking far"* and *"like ascending high."* *Pì* (辟) and *pì* (譬) are interchangeable, both meaning *"to illustrate."* **Guó Xiàng**’s annotation is incorrect. The *Han Shū* (汉书) *Bào Yǒng Zhuan* (鲍永传) says: *"Those who speak are a warning; those who hear are not yet enlightened."* **Cháng Huái Tàizǐ**’s annotation says: *"Pì (譬), to make clear."* To be clear about the similarity between forms is also to illustrate.

**[3] [Annotation]** Though the two forms are open, they cannot attain one another—there is an obstruction between them.
**[Commentary]** *Pì* (辟) means "open." *Jiàn* (间) means "distinction." The blind and the sighted both have open orifices, yet sight and blindness create a distinction in perception. The blind and deaf seek hearing and seeing, yet they cannot attain them—just as **Nán Róng** seeks enlightenment but finds no path to it.
**[Textual Notes]** *或间* (huò jiàn) is pronounced *jiàn-chè* (厕之间). The annotation is the same.

**[4] [Annotation]** Early separation by form makes transformation difficult.
**[Commentary]** *"Preserve your form, cherish your life"* has been explained as before. The repeated emphasis on *"hearing"* clarifies the question’s intent.
**[Textual Notes]** *勉闻道* (miǎn wén dào): **Cuī Xiàng** (崔向) says: *"Miǎn (勉), ‘also.’"* The original text may have a missing character. *达耳矣* (dá ěr yǐ): **Cuī Xiàng** says: *"Only reaching the ears, not penetrating the heart."*

**Gēngsāngzǐ** said:
*"My words are exhausted. The bumblebee cannot transform into a cicada, the wild chicken cannot brood over a duck’s egg, but the domestic chicken can. The chicken and the chicken—though their *virtue/power* is not inherently different, some can and some cannot, for their innate capacities differ in magnitude. My capacity is small, insufficient to transform you. Why not go south to see **Lǎozǐ**?"* **[2]**

「**[1] [Exegesis]**
The *bumblebee* (奔蜂) refers to the slender-waisted ground wasp. *Breast* (藿) means *bean*. *Shuǎi* (蠋) is the large green grub found in beans. *Yue chicken* (越鸡) is the *Jing chicken* (荆鸡). *Lu chicken* (鲁鸡) is what we now call the *Sichuan chicken* (蜀鸡). The slender-waisted wasp can transform silkworm larvae into its own offspring but cannot transform *bean grubs*. The *Jing chicken* is small and cannot brood over a *wild goose’s egg*; the *Sichuan chicken*, being larger, can. This illustrates that my capacity is inferior and cannot yet transform you—my words have exhausted their meaning.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Delun* (奔蜂): Pronounced *fù-gōng* (孚恭). Sima [commentary] says: "A small wasp." Another reading: "Ground wasp."
*Huǎi shuǎi* (藿蠋): Pronounced *shù* (蜀). Sima [commentary] says: "The large green grub in beans."
*Yueji* (越鸡): Sima Xiang says: "A small chicken." Another reading: "Jing chicken."
*Neng fú* (能伏): Pronounced *fú-yòu* (扶又).
*Hú* (鹄): Also written as *hè* (鹤), same meaning. Pronounced *hù* (户各) or *hù* (户沃).
*Luán* (卵): Pronounced *lì-guǎn* (力管).
*Luji* (鲁鸡): Sima Xiang says: "A large chicken, the Sichuan chicken of today."
**[Regulatory Note]** *Tai Ping Yu Lan* (太平御览) 918 cites Sima [commentary]: "Yue chicken: small chicken. Lu chicken: large chicken, the Sichuan chicken of today." Slightly different from the *Release Text* citation.

**[2] [Exegesis]**
The chicken possesses five virtues: wearing a crest (礼), having spurs (义), calling one another when feeding (仁), knowing the seasons (智), and facing enemies with courage (勇). Though the *Jing* and *Lu* chickens differ in size, their five virtues are the same. Their ability or inability lies in their innate capacities—some large, some small. I am like the *Jing chicken*, my capacity insufficient to transform you. Why not journey south to seek **Lǎozǐ** as your teacher?

**[Collation Note]**
**[1]** The text is missing a character in the *Jiangnan Ancient Cang* and *Li-Zhang* editions, reading: *"Nánróng Zī yíngliáng"* (南荣趎赢粮), arriving at **Lǎozǐ**’s place in seven days and seven nights.
**[1] [Exegesis]**
*Yíng* (赢): To wrap or carry. With ardent reverence for the Sage, he traveled without rest, day and night, for seven days before seeing **Lǎozǐ**.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Yíngliáng* (赢粮): Pronounced *yíng* (盈). According to *Fāngyán* (方言), *yíng* means *dàn* (儋), used in Qi, Chu, Chen, and Song regions. Another reading: *guǒ* (果).
**[Annotation]** Lu Wénpiàn notes that the pronunciation *guǒ* may also be written as *luǒ* (裸).

**Lǎozǐ** said: *"Are you from the place of Sanchu?"*
Nánróng Zī said: *"Yes."* **[1]**

**[1] [Exegesis]**
*Zì* (自): "From." Asking: "Are you coming from the land of Sanchu?"
Nánróng Zī replied with *"Wéi"* (唯), a respectful affirmative sound.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Yuē wéi* (曰唯): Pronounced *wéi* (惟癸).

**Lǎozǐ** said: *"Why did you come with so many others?"*
Nánróng Zī, startled, looked behind him. **[2]**

**[1] [Annotation]**
He came with three companions, hence the rebuke.

**[Exegesis]**
*Xiè* (偕): Together. **Lǎozǐ**, the Sage, discerned his motives like a mirror. Though he had not yet abandoned *ren* (仁) and *yì* (义), he reproached him for bringing others. The logic was that he had come with three companions, so he mocked him for claiming a larger group.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Xiè sān* (挟三): Pronounced *xié* (协).

**[2] [Exegesis]**
*Jùrán* (惧然): A startled expression. Not yet understanding **Lǎozǐ**’s words, he was suddenly told of the others behind him, glancing back in fear of many people.

**[Textual Notes]**
*Jùrán* (惧然): Pronounced *jù-jì* (向纪俱). Also written as *jié* (戄), same sound, or *qiú* (况缚).
**[Regulatory Note]** *Jùrán* is the same as *qǔrán* (瞿然), an expression of surprise. The original character is missing. *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字): *"Qǔ"* (九遇切), lifting one’s eyes in startled surprise. *Qǔ* and *jù* are both borrowed characters. *Lǐ Dàn Gōng* (礼檀弓) uses *qǔ* for *"incidentally startled."* *Shǐjì Mèngzǐ Zhuan* (史记孟子传) and *Hànshū Huì Jì Zhǎn* (汉书惠纪赞) also use *qǔ* in similar contexts.

**Lǎozǐ** said: *"Do you not understand what I mean?"* **[1]**

**[1] [Exegesis]**
*Wèi* (谓): Speech or intent.

I spoke together with you, yet you mock me for arriving with these three precepts. You looked behind you—this shows you did not grasp my meaning.

Nánróng Zǐshì bowed his head in shame, then raised his gaze and sighed, saying:
*"Just now, I forgot my response and lost my question."*

**[1]**
**[1] [Exegesis]**
*Bowing*: lowering the head in shame. Recognizing his own ignorance and failing to comprehend the Sage’s words, he thus lowered his head in humiliation, raised his eyes to the sky in sighing, his spirit dazed, his emotions in disarray. Was it merely that he lost his composure? He had also lost his inquiry.

**[Textual Notes]**
*"Factor lost my question"* (因失吾问): The *Yuánjiā* edition reads *"hear"* (闻) instead of *"question"* (问). **Qìngfān’s Note**: *"Question"* (问) is synonymous with *"hear"* (闻). In ancient usage, they were interchangeable. In *Lúnyǔ—Gōngyě Cháng* (论语公冶长), *"Hearing one thing, knowing ten"* (闻一知十), the *Shìwén* (释文) notes: *"Hear"* (闻) was originally written as *"question"* (问). In *Xuánzǐ—Yáo Wèn* (荀子尧问), *"Not hearing the things"* (不闻即物), *Yáng Shè* (杨倞) comments: *"Hear"* (闻) was sometimes written as *"question"* (问).

**[Correction]**
**[1]** The two characters were supplemented based on context.

**Lǎozǐ** said:
*"What do you mean by this?"* **[1]**

**[1] [Exegesis]**
Asking what meaning lies in his words.

Nánróng Zǐshì replied:
*"Do I not know? People call me *zhūyú*—a fool.
Do I know? Yet practicing virtue brings me sorrow upon my body. **[1]**
To act without *rén* harms others; to act with *rén* brings sorrow to myself.
To act without *yì* injures others; to act with *yì* brings sorrow to myself.
How can I escape this? These three precepts are my afflictions—I wish to ask about them through Sāng Chǔ."* **[2]**

**[1] [Exegesis]**
*Zhūyú*: like being utterly foolish, without knowledge. If one remains mired in ignorance and worldly confusion, one earns the name of foolishness. If one applies wisdom in human affairs, one risks bodily harm. Since the harm falls upon oneself, it is said to bring sorrow to the body.
**Family Tradition Note**: In the *Zuǒzhuàn—Shuānggōng Sìnián* (左传襄公四年), *Dù Yú* (杜预) annotates *"zhūrú"* (朱儒) as *"short and stunted."* *Zhūyú* thus refers to one whose wisdom is stunted and small.

**[2] [Exegesis]**
*Rén*: the practice of universal love.
*Yì*: the function of fulfilling proper order.
Both are the teachings of the ancient sages, yet they are not means to preserve the self or avoid harm. Thus, acting without *rén* or *yì* harms others; practicing them risks betraying true nature and the Dao. I do not yet know how to reconcile this within my heart to avoid such afflictions. I entrust these three precepts to Sāng Chǔ as an intermediary, hoping you will grant me an answer below.

**[Correction]**
**[1]** The character *"make"* (使) was altered to match the preceding clause.

**Lǎozǐ** said:
*"Earlier, I observed you within the space of my eyebrows and eyelashes, and thus I came to know you. Now you speak, and your words confirm it. **[1]**
You are so meticulously troubled, as if you had lost your parents, and now you raise a pole to seek the sea. Alas, you are a lost soul! How bewildered you are! **[2]**
You wish to return to your true nature and innate endowment, yet you have no path to enter—how pitiful!"* **[3]**

**[1] [Exegesis]**
Earlier, I observed your form and demeanor, and thus I discerned your heart. Now your spoken words align with the three precepts you hold. Your speech thus verifies my understanding.

**[Textual Notes]**
*"Toward me"* (向吾): Also written as *"toward"* (向) in some editions, same meaning.
*"Eyebrows and eyelashes"* (眉睫): Pronounced *jié* (接). *Shìmíng* (释名) states: *"The hairs of the eyes."* **[2] [Exegesis]**
*Guīguī*: finely fragmented, as in overanalyzing. You apply your mind in such fragmented ways to these three precepts, like a child who has lost its parents. You are like someone in *Dàn* (儋) raising a pole to seek the sea, attempting to measure its depths—how could this succeed? You are a person who has lost the true self and the Dao, a drowning child adrift, with no clear path to return.

**[3] [Exegesis]**
You seek to restore your original nature and innate endowment, yet you lack the means to do so—this is truly lamentable.

「[Textual Notes]
*Guīguī*: Li Yun: "Loses the divine appearance." Another reading: "Fine and minute appearance."
*Ruò sàng*: Pronounced *xīlàng* (息浪). Gloss same as above.
*Jiē*: Pronounced *qílì* (其列) or *qíyè* (其谒).
*Gān*: Pronounced *gān* (干).
*Er qiú zhū hǎi yě*: Xiàng Yun: "Speaking of using a small, limited thing to measure the vast depths of the sea."
*Nǚ wáng rén zāi*: Cuī Yun: "A person lost in nature and innate disposition."

**[3] [Exegesis]**
Though you cling to the traces of the sages, drowning in the virtues of *rényì* (仁义), even if you strive to return to your original nature and innate endowment, your afflictions have already taken root—there is no way to enter (the Dao). The great sage’s compassion is profound, and this is truly lamentable.

South *Róngzhuó* (荣趎) sought to enter and take refuge in the dwelling, called forth what you love, and removed what you hate. After ten days, he grew troubled and again saw the Old Master.

**[1] [Exegesis]**
Having lost the object of inquiry, his understanding and awareness became dim. Thus, he withdrew to his home, reflecting for a decade, searching for the Dao’s virtues he favored, and eliminating the virtues of *rényì* (仁义) he despised. Unable to grasp the Dao, he fell into sorrow, hoping to seek further instruction, and thus again saw the Old Master.

[Textual Notes]
*Suǒhǎo*: Pronounced *hūbào* (呼报).
*Qù qí*: Pronounced *qǐlǜ* (起吕).
*Suǒwù*: Pronounced *wūlù* (乌路).
*Fù yòu*: Pronounced *fúyòu* (扶又).

The Old Master said:
“You have washed yourself, but your *yùyù* (郁郁) still lingers—how could it be so? Yet within you, there remains a *jīnjīn* (津津) still—there is still evil there **[1]**.
Those whose *wéi* (外) is bound cannot be seized with urgency; instead, they must be closed within **[2]**.
Those whose *nèi* (内) is bound cannot be seized with earnestness; instead, they must be closed without **[2]**.
Those whose both *wéi* (外) and *nèi* (内) are bound—even the Dao’s *virtue/power* (德) cannot sustain them, let alone those who abandon the Dao and act recklessly **[3]!”**

**[1] [Exegesis]**
Returning home for a decade, he discarded the Five Virtues (五德), cleansed and purified his defilements and accumulated merits. From my observation of your *qi* (气), it is *yùyù* (郁郁) yet calm—though you exert effort, the *jīnjīn* (津津) still leaks through. Thus, I verify that evil remains.

[Textual Notes]
*Sǎzhuó*: Pronounced *dàjiǎo* (大角).
*Yùyù*: Cuī Yun: "How could it be so?" (孰洒貌).
*Jīnjīn*: As the character. Cuī Yun: "Lǜlǜ" (律律), meaning "evil appearance" (恶貌).
*Yóu yǒu wù yě*: Lǐ Yun: "Evil schemes still linger" (恶计未尽也).

**[2] [Gloss]**
*Bàn*: "To close" (关闭).
Ears and eyes are the *external* (外); the mind and methods are the *internal* (内).
To fully embrace life and preserve it, nothing is better than forgetting your internal methods and abandoning your external senses.
If one’s external senses are bound by sounds and colors, then one’s internal mind is clogged within.
If one’s internal mind is bound by cravings and aversion, then one’s external senses are lost without.
Only when there is neither gain nor loss can one be said to be in harmony.

**[Exegesis]**
*Wéi* (韄) means "to bind or constrain."
*Bàn* (揵) means "to close."
*Fán* (繁) means "urgency."
*Miù* (缪) means "earnestness."
It is said that if a person’s external senses (ears and eyes) are bound by sounds and colors, then their internal spirit is closed off within.
If one’s internal mind and wisdom are bound by cravings and aversion, then their external senses are closed off without.
This mutual binding is a natural consequence.
Even if one tries to restrain with the mind, seize with urgency, or earnestly weave nets, there is no way to achieve harmony.
Only when the spirit is settled within and the senses are still without can one align with the Dao’s way of preserving life.

[Textual Notes]
*Wài wéi*: Xiàng Yun: Pronounced *huò* (霍). Cuī Yun: "Vast and expansive" (恢廓也). Also as the character.
This word is also written as *wéi* (韄), pronounced *huò* (获), *yǐhuó* (乙虢), *wūmiào* (乌邈), or *jī* (羁). Lǐ Yun: "To bind" (缚也).
*Shū* (三苍): "To adorn with a sword and bow" (佩刀靶韦也).
◎Lú Wénfǎn: "Now written as *wéi* (韄)."
*Ér zhuō*: Xu Yun: Pronounced *zéjiǎo* (侧角).»

「崔作促，云：迫促也。
*[Inner] Wéi*: Pronounced *jìniàn* (郭其辇反), *qíyǎn* (徐其偃反).
*Guan*: "To close" (关也).
*Xiàng*: Also pronounced *jiǎn* (蹇), same below.
*Miào*: Pronounced *mòhóu* (莫侯反), also *chóu* (稠), meaning "to bind" (结也).
*Cuī Xiàng*: "To weave and bind" (绸缪也).

◎Yú Yì said: "Guo provides no annotation here, yet annotates the following text: *Even if one uses both hands to seize it, weaving nets to hold it, one cannot stop it.* Thus, interpreting *fán* (繁) as *fánshǒu* (繁手) is surely untenable. *Fán* is likely a corruption of [□]. □, colloquially written as *jiǎo* (缴). In the *Han Shu* biography of Sima Xiangru, *míngjiā kēchá jiǎo rào*, Xu Sheng says: *Jiǎo rào* means *to entangle*. Here, [□] and *miào* (缪) are used together—[□] refers to *jiǎo rào* (entangling), *miào* refers to *chóu miào* (weaving and binding). The *Guang Ya* explains that [□] and *chóu miào* both mean *to entangle*—their meanings are identical. □ and *fán* resemble each other in form, leading to the error."

◎Jiāshì Fù said: "The *Shuowen Jiezi* states: *Wéi* (韄) is the silk cord for a sword belt. Xu Shí said: *Silk* refers to its binding threads. The *San Cang* states: *Péi dāo bǎi wéi* (佩刀靶韦). Thus, *wéi* conveys the meaning of binding and tying. *Wài wéi* (外韄) means to restrain the ears and eyes;"

「The governance of the ears and eyes grows chaotic and convoluted, shifting and multiplying beyond grasp—then one must internally restrain the heart to still the restless movements of the ears and eyes. *Internal wéi* (韄) means to restrain the heart; yet when the heart is entangled and erratic in a hundred ways, it too cannot be grasped—then one must externally restrain the ears and eyes to sever the heart’s connections. When both internal and external are restrained, one enters a state of profound oblivion, forgetting both self and Dao/Way, with no reliance or attachment; then even virtue/power cannot penetrate and take root—how much more so can the lingering of malevolent desires persist!

Guo Xiang said: "When sounds and sights are restrained externally, the heart’s faculties grow clogged internally; when desires and evils are restrained internally, the ears and eyes are lost externally. Even partial restraint is not possible—how much less so when both internal and external are restrained!" This seems not to be Zhuangzi’s original intent.

【Three】【Annotation】 Partial restraint is not possible; how much less so when external and internal are both restrained! If the ears and eyes are dazzled and confused externally while the heart’s faculties wander unrestrained internally, even if one uses both hands to seize them and weaves and binds them tightly, one cannot stop it.

【Exegesis】 Partial fixation at the edges already contradicts natural spontaneity; how much more so when internal and external are both drowned in restraint, deepening the confusion. Even if there are scholars who cherish Dao/Way and virtue/power, they still cannot uphold it—how much less so for those who abandon the lofty Dao/Way and solely pursue this confusion, hoping to achieve restraint?

The *Laozi* says: "The *Sutras of Vitality* (衛生之經) —can one embrace the *One* (一)?
Can one refrain from losing it?
Can one know auspicious and inauspicious without divination?
Can one cease (action)?
Can one stop (desire)?
Can one abandon others and seek within oneself?
Can one be effortlessly light?
Can one be unstrained and at ease?
Can one be like a child?
A child all day cries yet its throat never grows hoarse—this is the ultimate harmony.
All day grasping yet its hands never tire—this is the fulfillment of virtue/power.
All day gazing yet its eyes never blink—its focus is not external.
It moves without knowing where it goes,
It acts without knowing what it does,
It flows with things in harmony,
Yet remains aligned with their Dao/Way.
This is the *Sutras of Vitality* already.

【Annotations】
【One】 Do not depart from its nature.」

**Commentary:**

The *True* is guarded without division. **[2]**
**[Annotation]** Returning to self-acquisition. **[2]**

**Commentary:**
Self-acquisition of its nature. **[3]**
**[Annotation]** When aligned, it is auspicious; when excessive, it is inauspicious—no need for divination.
**Commentary:**
Treading the Dao/Way brings auspiciousness; yielding to things brings inauspiciousness. This is the natural order—why consult divination?
◎ Wang Yansun remarks: *"Auspicious and inauspicious"* should read *"inauspicious and auspicious."* The rhyme demands *"lost auspicious"* (失吉), and *"cease"* (止) rhymes with *"self"* (己).

In *The Heart-Methods* of *Guanzi*, it asks: *"Can one focus entirely? Can one embrace the One? Can one know auspicious and inauspicious without divination?"* This confirms it.
(*In the Inner Cultivation Chapter, "auspicious and inauspicious" is also mistakenly reversed, but not in The Heart-Methods.*)

Cui agrees. The *Zìlín* says: *"Great."* ◎ Lu Wēnpán notes: Now written as *tóng*. *"Obstruction"* (碍) — *Wǔdài* rhyme. **[8]**

Like a child. **[9]**

**Commentary:**
*Sē* (嗌) — throat constriction. *Shā* (嗄) — voice breaking. Qi flows freely, the heart untouched by joy or anger, so all day it cries yet the throat neither constricts nor breaks. Pure harmony preserved, reaching this state. **[10]**
**Textual Notes:**
*"Cries"* (嗥) — *Hùgāo* rhyme. Also written *háo* (same sound). **[10]**

「《而嗌》—*Yì* (益). Cui says: *"throat."* Sima says: *"throat."* Li reads it as *è* (厄), meaning *"choked."* One version reads *"while not choked"* (而不嗌). Case: As Li’s reading, it includes *"not"* (不). *《不嗄》—Yú-Mài* (于迈) rhyme. Also written *yōu* (嚘), with Xu pronouncing it *yōu* (忧). Sima says: *"The Chu people call utter silence ‘sé’ (嗄)."* Cui’s version reads *hè* (喝), meaning *"mute."* ◎Yu Yì says: The *Shìwén Jié* (释文) states that *sé* (嗄) was originally *yōu* (嚘), with Xu pronouncing it *yōu* (忧)—this should be followed. Laozi’s *"all day cries yet not choked"* (终日号而不嗄) was written as *□* (嚘) in Fu Yi’s version, another variant of *yōu*. In *Yáng Zhī Tàixuān Jīng* (扬子太玄经), *"Three days of softness"* (夷次三日柔), *"the infant cries"* (婴儿于号), *"three days without yōu"* (三日不嚘)—both Song-era editions by Lu and Wang follow this. Clearly, *yōu* rhymes with *rǒu* (柔), proving that *Yáng Zhī*’s Lao-Zhuang texts used *yōu* (嚘).

**[11] [注]** *Rèn shǒu zhī zì wò, fēi dú dé yě.* **[11]**
**[疏]** *Jū jì* (拘寄), *[while not]* laboring or wearying—this is because their pure harmony and Daoist virtue align with the utmost Dao.

**[释文]** *《终日握》—Lǐ yùn:* *"To curl the hands"* (卷手曰握). *《不》—Wǔlǐ* (五礼) rhyme, *xiàng* (向) pronounced *yì* (艺). Cui says: *"to hold."* *Guǎng Yǎ* says: *"to grasp."* ◎Yu Yì says: *Shuōwén* has no such character. Under the *jiǎo* (角) radical: *bì* (觬), meaning *"to curve."* Likely this character. If speaking of the horn, it uses *jiǎo*; if speaking of the hand, it uses *shǒu*—thus *bì* (觬) transforms into *wò* (握), showing how characters multiply over time. *"All day the hands grasp yet do not [curl]"*—meaning the hands do not clench into fists. Cui says: *"to hold"*—this is incorrect.

◎Jiāshì Fù says: The *Shìwén Jié* cites Cui as saying *"to hold"* (寄), and *Guǎng Yǎ* says *"to grasp"* (捉). Now, examining *Yáng Xióng Tàixuān*’s *"Xuan"* (玄), it says: *"The praises of the Dao sometimes use qi, sometimes use likeness, sometimes use completed things."* *"Wò"* (握), meaning *"to imitate."* Xióng’s intent is to use *"wò"* as *"nǐ"* (拟). *Shuōwén* says: *"Nǐ"* means *"to measure."* Meaning there is no standard to measure or infer. *Shuōwén* says: *"Gòng"* (共) means *"same."* Whether seizing things or taking things, it is done without measuring—its virtue is the same. *"Gòng qí"* (共其) follows the character. Cui says: *"One"* (壹)—incorrect.

**[12] [注]** *Rèn mù zhī zì jiàn, fēi xì yú sè yě.* **[12]**
**[疏]** *Shùn* (瞬), meaning *"to move."* The eyes move naturally, yet the gaze does not flicker—it does not linger on external dust.

**[释文]** *《不瞬》—Also written *shùn* (瞬), same meaning. Pronounced *shùn* (舜), meaning *"to move."* Sometimes written *míng* (瞑), pronounced *mò* (莫). *《偏不》—Xu* pronounces it *piān* (篇).

**[13] [注]** *Rèn zú zhī zì xíng, wú suǒ qù.* **[13]**
**[疏]** *Zhī* (之), meaning *"to go."* Like a boat drifting without tether, thus though it moves, it has no fixed destination.

**[14] [注]** *Zòng tǐ ér zì rèn yě.* **[14]**

**[15] [注]** *Sī shùn zhī yě.* **[15]**

**[释文]** *《委》—Yú-Wēi* (于危) rhyme. *《蛇》—Yǐ-Zhī* (以支) rhyme.

**[疏]** As previously discussed in the *Yángshēng Jīng* (卫生之经), following it aligns with the Dao. Is this the virtue of the Perfect One?

*"No! This is what is called ‘ice melting, frost thawing’—can it be done? [1]*
**[1]**
The Perfect One—*xiāng yǔ jiāoshí hù dì ér jiāolè hù tiān* (相与交食乎地而交乐乎天), not clashing over profit or harm among people and things, not regarding each other as strange, not plotting against each other, not scheming together—*qiáorán ér wǎng, tóngrán ér lái.* This is called the *Yángshēng Jīng* (卫生之经) already. [4]"

**[1] [注]** *Néng hū* (能乎), clarifying it is not natural. **[1]**
**[疏]** Nán Róng was constrained by Confucian *rén yì* (仁义), his days long bound. Now hearing the Sage’s teachings, he finally understands *yángshēng* (卫生). Like winter ice encountering spring sun—his rigid heart now melts and disperses. This is enlightenment through learning, not innate nature. *"Néng hū"* (能乎) clarifies it is not true. This is Laozi’s reply to Zhì.

**[释文]** *《冰解》—Pronounced *xiè* (蟹).*
**[2] [注]** *Zì wú qí xīn, jiē yǔ wù gòng.* **[2]**
**[疏]** The Perfect One has no emotions, responding to things as they arise—thus able to share the people’s nourishment from the earth and commune with all beings in Heaven’s joy. *"Jiāo"* (交) means *"to share."*

**[释文]** *《交食》—Cui says: "Jiāo"* means *"together."* Li says: *"shared."* *《交乐》—Pronounced *luò* (洛).*
◎Yu Yì says: Guo’s annotation says, *"Selflessly, all things are shared."* The *Shìwén Jié* cites Cui as saying *"jiāo"* means *"together,"* and Li says *"shared."* None truly grasp the meaning of *"jiāo."* In *Xú Wúguǐ Piān* (徐无鬼篇), it says: *"I share joy with them in Heaven, I share nourishment with them on Earth."* Though the meaning differs, the intent is the same. *"Jiāo"* means *"to invite"*—anciently written as *"jiào"* (徼). In the *Lùn Yú* (论语), *"Wén Èr"* (文二年), *"The Duke of Lu wishes to invite blessings from Duke Zhou and Duke Lu."* Here, *"jiào fú"* (徼福) is akin to *"jiào shí hù dì"* (邀食乎地) and *"jiào lè hù tiān"* (邀乐乎天)—the phrasing is identical in meaning.

「作邀者后出字，作交者假借字。 *Shī* *Sāng Hù Piān* (《桑扈》) says: *"彼交匪傲"* (彼交匪傲), the *Hàn Shū* *Wǔ Xíng Zhì* (《汉书·五行志》) renders it as *"匪儌匪傲"* (匪儌匪傲)—this is the precedent.

**[三]**
◎ **[Cù]** says: *"Rǎn"* means *"to disturb."* The **至人** (Perfect Person) maintains a **虚心** (empty heart), aligning with the **世** (World), and rides the waves with all things. Thus, they can pacify the strange and unnatural among the masses, and cut off schemes and plots from the common folk. If they do not treat external affairs as their own concerns, how could **利害** (gain and loss) ever disturb them!

**[Shìwén]** *《Xiàng Rǎn》* (《相撄》) is read *"yú yíng"* (于营), Xu also pronounces it *"yīng"* (婴).
The *Guǎng Yǎ* (《广雅》) states: *"to disturb."* Cui says: *"akin to **贯** (pierce/penetrate)."*

**[四]**
◎ **[Cù]** says: Repeating the earlier passage to conclude its meaning.
**[Jiào]** (校) The second *"无"* (without) is removed according to the correct text.
It says: *"Then is this the **至** (Perfect) **Dao/Way**?"*
**[一]【注】** *"Does this mean that by merely hearing this, one can attain the Perfect Dao/Way?"*
**[Cù]** says: *"Hearing this, one can attain the utmost heights."* Nán Róng (南荣) being unlearned, repeats the question to Lǎo Jūn (老君).
Lǎo Jūn says: *"Not yet. I have already told you: 'Can you **养子乎** (nourish your own children)?"*

「【一】'When one's **children** (子) move, they act without purpose; when they walk, they go without direction. Their body is like a withered tree's branch, and their mind is like extinguished ashes【二】.
If such is their state, calamity will not come, and fortune will not arrive. Calamity and fortune are absent, yet who would dare to speak of human disasters! 【三】”

【一】【注】This does not mean that calamity is absent because of these words, but rather that those who merely hear them without practice cannot attain the Perfect Dao/Way by themselves.
If it does not come from oneself, then even hearing the Perfect words, one can only use them as scripture—how could one truly attain the Perfect Dao/Way?
Thus, the learned do not attain it, and those who attain it do not rely on learning. 【疏】The words *"能"* (able) are an encouraging exhortation.
Though these words are profound, they are still like **fishing nets and traps** (筌蹄), for once it is said *"吾固告汝"* (I have already told you), one must then **absorb and cultivate** (因禀学) them.
Yet the learned do not attain it, and those who attain it do not rely on learning—this is because the **nature of the Perfect Dao/Way** (筌) is beyond ordinary understanding, hence *"未也"* (not yet).
This is **Lǎo Jūn**’s repeated answer to **Nán Róng**.

【二】【疏】In **emptiness, stillness, and repose** (虚冲凝淡), utterly **serene and without attachment** (寂寞无情), their being aligns with a withered tree that does not flourish, and their mind resembles extinguished ashes that forget warmth.
With **body and mind thus forsaken** (身心既其双遣), how could their actions and movements be known?
This is the **essence of longevity** (卫生之要).

【释文】*《若槁》* pronounced *"kǔ lǎo"* (苦老).

【三】【注】Calamity and fortune arise from **gain and loss** (得丧), while human disasters stem from **affection and aversion** (爱恶).
Now, if one’s body is like a withered tree and mind like extinguished ashes, reaching the utmost **detachment** (无情), then affection and aversion, gain and loss, come of their own accord.

【疏】Indeed, calamity and fortune spring from **gain and loss** (得丧), and human disasters arise from **beauty and ugliness** (美恶).
Now, if one’s form is like a withered tree and mind like extinguished ashes, forgetting both gain and loss, forsaking beauty and ugliness,
they are still without **obscurity and confusion** (冥昧), so how could human disasters exist?

【释文】*《恶有》* pronounced *"wū"* (乌).
*《爱恶》* pronounced *"wū lù"* (乌路).
Same below.

**Those whose virtue and bearing are serene and steadfast** (宇泰定) emanate from **the luminous Dao/Way of Heaven** (天光)【一】.
Those who emanate from **the luminous Dao/Way of Heaven** (天光) are seen by others as **the luminous Dao/Way of Heaven** (人见其人)【二】,
and **objects see their own nature** (物见其物).
【一】People who **cultivate the Dao/Way** (修) have **constancy** (恒)【三】;
those with **constancy** (恒) are **abandoned by others** (人舍), yet **assisted by Heaven** (天助)【四】.
What others abandon is called **Heaven’s people** (天民);
what Heaven assists is called **Heaven’s child** (天子)【五】.

【一】【注】When one’s **virtue and bearing are serene and steadfast** (德宇泰定), their emanation is **the luminous Dao/Way of Heaven** (天光), not human brilliance.

【疏】The body is the dwelling of the spirit, so the Perfect Sage is likened to a vessel of **virtue and bearing** (道德).
Moreover, when **virtue and bearing are serene and steadfast** (德宇安泰) and **quietly settled** (静定), their emanation of **spiritual illumination** (发心) and **perception of things** (照物) comes from **natural wisdom** (自然之智光).

【释文】*《宇泰定》* **Jiāshìfù** says: *"器宇"* (instrumental bearing) refers to the **calm and expansive bearing** (器宇闲泰) that leads to stillness and steadfastness.
**Wáng** says: *"器宇"* (instrumental bearing) refers to the **calm and expansive bearing** (器宇闲泰), meaning that when one’s bearing is calm and expansive, it is settled and steadfast.
◎ **Jiāshìfù** (家世父) says: *"In an empty chamber, white purity is born; in stillness, auspiciousness abides.
The human heart naturally reveals its inclinations, and **the luminous Dao/Way of Heaven** (天光) shines forth—this is natural and cannot be concealed.
Cultivate what is natural, and the responses will come.
Each person cultivates themselves, and each person perceives themselves, hence *"人见其人"* (people see their own nature).*

【二】【注】When **the luminous Dao/Way of Heaven** (天光) naturally emanates, others see **their own nature** (人见其人), and objects see **their own nature** (物见其物).
Each perceives their own nature without seeing others’, hence their **serene and steadfast bearing** (泰然而定).

【疏】Ordinary people cannot fathom the Sage’s perfection; they only see them among the masses, unaware of **the luminous Dao/Way of Heaven** (天光) extending far.

【三】【注】When one **cultivates the Dao/Way in others** (修人), they attain it themselves—this is why they maintain **serene and steadfast bearing** (常泰).

【疏】**Constancy** (恒) means **permanence** (常).
Though **the Dao/Way transcends learning** (绝学), its cultivation still requires **seeking** (资求).
Thus, those who truly **cultivate the Dao/Way** (真修) can converge on the **permanent and settled Dao/Way** (凝常之道).

【四】【注】Because they maintain **permanence** (常泰), they can **return to their dwelling** (反居我宅) while naturally **receiving Heaven’s assistance** (获助)【二】.

【疏】Those who embody **permanence** (体常), in all their actions meet with **auspicious harmony** (吉会),
are **abandoned by the common folk** (苍生之所舍止) and **assisted by Heaven** (皇天之所福助)—is this not fitting?

【五】【注】When they **act in the world**, they are **Heaven’s child** (天子); when they **remain in seclusion**, they are **Heaven’s people** (天民).
These two states both arise from **serene and steadfast bearing** (泰然而自得), not from **effort** (为).

【疏】When they **act in the world**, they become **rulers and sovereigns** (君后); when they **remain in seclusion**, they are **free and virtuous individuals** (逸人).
All achieve this through **embodying the Dao/Way and maintaining permanence** (临道体常), hence their **attainment of such merit** (致斯功).

【校】（一）The four characters *"物见其物"* (objects see their own nature) are added based on the missing text and **Zhāng Jūnfáng**’s (张君房) version and commentary.
（二）**Zhào Jiànyì**’s (赵谏议) version lacks the two characters *"自然"* (natural).

**The learned** (学者) are those who **learn what they cannot learn** (学其所不能学);
**those who act** (行者) are those who **practice what they cannot practice** (行其所不能行).

The **discerner** discerns what he cannot discern.
To know and stop at what he cannot know—this is the utmost attainment;
If there is anything that does not conform to this, the **Heavenly Balance** will undermine it.

---
**【One】** *Commentary*: Whatever one is capable of, even if one acts, it is not *forcing*; even if one practices, it is not *learning*; even if one speaks, it is not *discerning*.

**Exegesis**: When one acts within one’s proper sphere, though one acts, it is not *forcing*—thus, though one learns, it is not *learning*; though one practices, it is not *practicing*; though one discerns, it is not *discerning*. How much less would one *force* beyond one’s sphere to learn what one cannot?

**Textual Note**: *"The learned learn what they cannot learn"*—this speaks of how all people desire to know what they cannot know. Whatever they are capable of, they are thus capable of what they are capable of. Those who are capable of what they are capable of—even if they practice, it is not *practicing*.

---
**【Two】** *Commentary*: What one cannot know, one cannot force oneself to know; thus, stopping here is the utmost (achievement).

**Exegesis**: Following what one is capable of and stopping within one’s proper sphere, one does not force oneself to know what one cannot. This is the most refined state of approaching learning.

---
**【Three】** *Commentary*: Though the mind may wish to *force*, the act will inevitably fail, and reason will ultimately prevent it.

**Exegesis**: If one’s heart strays beyond one’s sphere and does not regard what is within one’s sphere as correct, this is to undermine one’s innate nature.

**Textual Note**: *"Undermine it"*—read as *méi* (迈), or alternatively as *zé* (则). The *Yuán Jiā* edition reads *zé*.

---
**Collation**: (One) The *Shì Dé Táng* edition includes the character *yě* (也).

---
To **provide all things to shape form**,
To **store the unforeseen to nurture the mind**,
To **hold reverence centrally to reach the other**—
If this is so, yet all evils arrive,
They are all **Heaven’s doing**, not **human doing**,
Unworthy of **corrupting completion**,
Unfit to be **internalized in the Spirit Hall**.

The **Spirit Hall** has what it holds,
Yet it does not know what it holds,
And what cannot be held—it cannot hold.

---
**【One】** *Commentary*: Following one’s own preparedness and aligning with the shaping of form.

**Exegesis**: *Jiāng* (将) means *to align*. The vast furnace of creation and transformation is complete in all things; one need only align with their formed nature and inquire into the principles of learning.

**Textual Note**: *"Provide all things"*—*bèi* (备) means *complete*. *Jiāng* (将) means *to align*.

「【Two】 *Commentary*: The mind naturally generates intention—it is not premeditated but arises spontaneously.
*Exegesis*: The sage of perfect attainment has no fixed emotions; when things stimulate him, he responds in kind. He encompasses holy wisdom, and when encountering things, his mind arises naturally—never premeditating or scheming beforehand.

*Textual Note*: *"Intention"*—*亿度* (yìdù), pronounced as *yì-luò* (待洛反).

【Three】 *Commentary*: The Dao/Way naturally illuminates all—it is not a matter of inner arrogance while outwardly revering.
*Exegesis*: The *"central"* (中) refers to inner wisdom, the *"other"* (彼) to external circumstances. Holding one’s divine intelligence in reverence, one dare not trifle with it. When wisdom is concentrated and tranquil, and circumstances are clear and open, the Dao/Way is naturally understood.

【Four】 *Commentary*: Heaven’s principles inherently possess their own limits and depths.

【Five】 *Commentary*: When one acts and brings about evil, that is the doing of humans.
*Exegesis*: Take the case of King Wen’s imprisonment in the *Yǒu Lì* (羑里), or Confucius’困困 at the hands of the people of *Kuāng* (匡). Their wisdom was not lacking, nor were they unworthy sages—yet they encountered such boundless misfortunes and adversities, for it was due to the *Heavenly timing* (天时) and *destiny* (运命). How could such evil be their own doing?

【Six】 *Commentary*: Accepting it as one’s fate, thus their completion is not corrupted.
*Exegesis*: *"Corrupt"* (滑) means *disorder* (乱). Those who embody the Dao/Way and grasp truth are at peace with their times and understand destiny. Even if they face boundless evils, they cannot disorder the mind of great completion.

*Textual Note*: *"滑"* (húan) is pronounced as *"骨"* (gǔ).

【Seven】 *Commentary*: The *Spirit Hall* (灵台) is the mind—clear and unobstructed, so that worries and troubles cannot penetrate it.
*Exegesis*: *"Internalize"* (内) means *enter*. The *Spirit Hall* is the mind. Its subtle essence is empty and tranquil, so that worldly affairs cannot enter its *Spirit Hall*.

*Textual Note*: *Guō Yún* (郭云) says: *"The Spirit Hall is the mind."* It is said that the mind has *spiritual wisdom* (灵智) capable of holding and maintaining. *Xǔ Shèn* (许慎) says: *"Above the human heart, where the *qi* travels."* ◎ *Yú Yì* (俞樾) says: *"The phrase ‘万恶不可内于灵台’ (millions of evils cannot be internalized in the Spirit Hall) should not be deleted, as the text above reads: ‘If this is so, yet all evils arrive, they are all Heaven’s doing, not human doing, unworthy of corrupting completion,’ which already suffices. The evils that cannot be internalized in the Spirit Hall are then further explained below. The passage below reads: ‘The Spirit Hall has what it holds, yet it does not know what it holds, and what cannot be held—it cannot hold.’ All of this follows from the previous statement. Readers who do not carefully examine the meaning mistake that ‘万恶不可内于灵台’ (millions of evils cannot be internalized in the Spirit Hall) belongs with ‘不足以滑成’ (unworthy of corrupting completion), thus deleting ‘万恶’ (millions of evils). The *Wén Xuǎn* (文选) *Guǎng Jué Jiāo Lùn* (广绝交论) by *Lǐ Shàn* (李善) quotes this text correctly, reading ‘万恶不可内于灵台’ (millions of evils cannot be internalized in the Spirit Hall)." *Gāo Shān Sì* (高山寺) manuscript reads *冥* (míng) instead of *闲* (xián).

【Eight】 *Commentary*: The *"has what it holds"* (有持) refers to the mind’s immobility toward things—yet in truth, it does not hold.
*Exegesis*: Only the noble mind that can hold is said to hold, yet it does not know the reason for this.

【Nine】 *Commentary*: If one knows what the mind holds, then it holds.
*Commentary*: To hold is to lose.

*Exegesis*: If there is a mind that clings and holds, it will lose it far away. Thus, it is not possible.

When one does not see his sincerity in action—
Every action is misguided,
Every deed is taken on without abandon—
Every (misguided) action further leads to loss.

Evil done in the light of day—humans can punish it;
Evil done in secret—ghosts can punish it.

Only when one understands both humans and ghosts can he walk alone.

*Textual Note*: *"不见其诚己而发"* (Not seeing his sincerity in action) refers to not reflecting inward while outwardly rushing.

【One】 *Commentary*: This is the false action of reckless intention.
*Textual Note*: *"Every action is misguided"*—*丁浪反* (dīng-làng fǎn). The *Ěr Yǎ* (尔雅) says: *"Every"* (每) means *"even though"* (虽). It refers to even though there is action, it does not hit the mark.

【Two】 *Commentary*: Intention arises not from one’s own sincerity—how can it be correct?
*Exegesis*: Earlier, those who openly obtained the Dao/Way had their wisdom illuminated and clear. Below, those who lose their true understanding have their minds confused and contrary to reason. *"Sincerity"* (诚) means *"reality"* (实). Without first reflecting on the reality of wisdom, one recklessly gives rise to false intentions. Since the mind is not true, every intention is contrary to reality and thus misguided.

*Textual Note*: *"幽闲"* (yōu-xián) is pronounced as *"闲"* (xián).

【Three】 *Commentary*: Affairs do not stay within their proper place.

*Exegesis*: *"Deed"* (业) means *"affair"* (事). Worldly affairs disturb and agitate—each time they enter the mind, one does not grasp their violation or compliance, so they cannot be abandoned.

【Four】 *Commentary*: Intention arising from one’s own sincerity is what is called *obtaining*.

*Exegesis*: Every time one recklessly gives rise to false intentions, following previous circumstances, one thinks it is obtaining—yet it further loses truth.

【Five】 *Exegesis*: Humans and ghosts, secret and open, are said to be different paths. Yet when one pushes sincerity and fulfills truth, there is no separation between Dao/Way and reason. If one goes against their proper place and loses truth, they will inevitably invite retribution and response. Enmity and resentment are felt in kind—this is why they are punished, as in the case of *Dù Bó* (杜伯) and *Péng Shēng* (彭生).

*Textual Note*: *"镆"* (yú) is pronounced as *"金耶"* (jīn-yē).

Those who dwell within the *Spirit Hall* (券内者) walk in the *Nameless* (无名);
Those who dwell outside the *Spirit Hall* (券外者) aspire to *periodic profit* (期费).

Walking in the *Nameless*—only the *Yong* (庸) can shine;
Aspiring to *periodic profit*—only the merchant can do so,
But when people see his *foot* (跂), they regard him as *proud and arrogant* (魁然).

Those who exhaust themselves with things—things enter them;
Those who exhaust themselves with *moderation* (且)—their own bodies cannot contain them, how much more could they contain others?

Those who cannot contain others have no kin;
Those with no kin abandon all humans,
For *war is not more cruel than ambition*,
And *no place to escape in Heaven and Earth*.

*Textual Note*: *"券"* (quàn) here refers to the *Spirit Hall* (灵台). *"无名"* (wúmíng) is the *Nameless* (无名). *"期费"* (qīfèi) refers to *periodic profit* (期费). *"跂"* (qì) means *foot*. *"魁然"* (kuírán) means *proud and arrogant*. *"且"* (qiě) means *moderation*. *"尽"* (jìn) means *abandon*. *"镆"* (yú) is pronounced as *"金耶"* (jīn-yē). *"阴阳"* (yīnyáng) refers to *Heaven and Earth* (天地).

The inner self, dwelling within its proper bounds, acts in accordance with the *Nameless* **[1]**.
Those who stray beyond their allotted measure, their ambitions lie in *periodic profit* **[2]**.
To dwell within bounds and act in the *Way* is to move without leaving a trace **[3]**.
To fix one’s resolve on *periodic profit* is the way of the merchant **[4]**.
When others see their *foot* **[5]**, they appear *proud and arrogant* **[6]**.

The one who exhausts himself with things—things enter him;
The one who exhausts himself with *moderation* **[7]**—his own body cannot contain him, how much more could he contain others?

Those who cannot contain others have no kin;
Those with no kin abandon all humans,
For *war is not more cruel than ambition*,
And *no place to escape in Heaven and Earth* **[8]**.

It is not *Heaven and Earth* that harm them—
Their own hearts are what drive them to ruin **[9]**.

---
**[1]** *Textual Note*: **"券"** (quàn) means *bound/allotted measure*. The inner self, confined to its proper domain, acts without regard for reputation.
**[2]** *Textual Note*: **"期费"** (qīfèi) refers to *extreme expenditure*—the relentless pursuit of profit, akin to *gluttonous extremes* (綦).
**[3]** *Textual Note*: **"庸"** (yòng) means *utilize*; those aligned with the *Way* act without leaving a name or trace.
**[4]** *Textual Note*: **"贾人"** (gǔrén) refers to *merchants*—those who fix their resolve on profit, trading in what they do not inherently possess.
**[5]** *Textual Note*: **"跂"** (qì) means *to tiptoe or strain*—here, the outward display of ambition.
**[6]** *Textual Note*: **"魁然"** (kuírán) means *arrogant and self-assured*, though others perceive their precariousness.
**[7]** *Textual Note*: **"且"** (qiě) retains its prior meaning of *moderation*—here, the futile attempt to restrain excess.
**[8]** *Textual Note*: **"镆(金耶)"** (yú/jīn-yē) as *war*; **"阴阳"** (yīnyáng) as *Heaven and Earth*—the ultimate bounds of existence.
**[9]** *Textual Note*: The harm stems not from external forces but from the self’s corrupting desires.

「The impoverished truly manifest their sincerity through their actions, yet the merely *moderate* [且] only align with one another in their shallowness.

To *aspire* [志] to *appointments* [期会] is to *moderate* [且], while to act in *namelessness* [无名] is to exhaust their intentions. Thus, they can fully realize their purpose.

**[6]** *Textual Note*: **"穷"** (qióng) means *completion*—the beginning and end.
*Explication*: It refers to *abiding* [舍止].

Those who align with the *Dharma* [物] and *Self* [我] in profound resonance and exhaust the *principles* [理] to their *essence* [性] are thus dependent on external things.

**[7]** *Textual Note*: **"且"** (qiě) refers to *those who strain outward* [□外而跂者].
*Explication*: The *tiptoeing* [跂] cannot stand firm—how can they then *comport themselves* [自容]?
If they cannot *comport themselves*, how can they *comport others* [容人]?
When one fails to be *comported*, they depart.

*Explication*: They merely *dally* [涉] with others in superficiality, *moderating* [苟且] in vain pursuits of fleeting fame and profit. Though their bodies remain *proud and haughty* [矜企], their minds are restless in *competition* [躁竞], unable to *comport themselves*—how then can they *comport external things* [容物]?

*Suggested Reading*: In *"The Treatise on Things"* [《物且》], **"且"** (qiě) is pronounced with the *initial* [始]. ◎ *Yu Yue* [俞樾] notes: **"且"** (qiě) is the same as *merely moderate* [苟且].
In the *Ode* [《诗》] *"Dongmen"* [《东门之枌》] passage *"Gudan"* [谷旦] at *"Chai"* [差]*,* the *Han Commentary* [《韩诗》] reads *"Jian"* [旦] as **"且"** (qiě)**,** saying: *merely moderate* [苟且].
This is a *repetition* [重言] for *merely moderate*, while the *single term* [单言] is **"且"** (qiě)**.
The preceding text, where *things* [物] and *exhaustion* [穷] are discussed, *Guo Xiang* [郭象] notes that **"穷"** (qióng)** means *completion*—the beginning and end. Thus, **"穷"** (qióng)** carries the meaning of *exhaustion* [穷极].
*Merely moderate* [苟且] and *exhaustion* [穷极] are diametrically opposed in meaning.
*Suggested Reading* states: **"且"** (qiě) is *initial*—this is incorrect.
*"Firm"* [《焉》] is pronounced *Yan* [于虔]. The *note* [注] is the same.

**[8]** *Textual Note*: If one’s body cannot even *comport itself*, then though they are not *themselves* [己], much less can they have *affection* [亲]!
Thus, they are entirely *others* [他人].

*Explication*: Narrow-mindedness and *inability to comport* [不容] mean no *affection* [亲爱]; lacking *affection*, they are entirely *others*.
With *hostility* [逆忤] so frequent, *enemies* [雠敌] are not few. Seeking *safety* [安泰], how can it be attained?

**[9]** *Textual Note*: The *mind’s* [志] attachments are like *congealed ice* [凝冰], thus their harm as *war* [镆(金耶)] surpasses even *swords and spears* [剑戟].
*Explication*: *Weapons* [兵戈] are mere instruments of sharpness. *镆(金耶)* (yú/jīn-yē) is a *fine sword* [良剑].
Yet, *bitterness* [憯毒] and *injury* [伤害] are nothing compared to the *mind*—
when the *mind’s* [心] attachments arise, they are swift yet not hasty, thus their *harm* [损害] surpasses even *镆(金耶)*.
By this measure, *swords and spears* [剑戟] are inferior.

*Suggested Reading*: **"憯"** (cǎn) is pronounced *Qi Kan* [七坎]. *Guang Ya* [《广雅》] states: *pain* [痛].
The *Yuanjia* [《元嘉》] version reads *Qian* [潜].
◎ *Qing Fan* [庆藩] concludes: **"憯"** (cǎn) and *cruelty* [惨] are the same.
*The Sayings of the Classics*: *cruelty* [惨] means *poison* [毒]. The character may also be written as **"憯"** (cǎn).
*Regional Speech*: *cruelty* [惨] means *to kill* [杀], aligning closely with the meaning of *poison*.
**"镆"** (yú) is pronounced *Mo* [莫].
**(金耶)** is pronounced *Ya Jie* [也嗟]. *镆(金耶)* is the name of a *fine sword* [良剑].

**[10]** *Explication*: *Raid* [寇] means *enemy* [敌]. The *mind’s* [域心] gains and losses, its *joy* and *anger* waging *war* within the chest—this is the *enemy* of *Heaven and Earth* [阴阳].
Even *mighty foes* [勍敌] and *great raiders* [巨寇] may be escaped, yet when *war* [兵] arises from within the *mind*, how can one evade *evil* [邪]!

**[11]** *Textual Note*: When the *mind* [心] governs *qi* [气], *Heaven and Earth* [阴阳] are *constrained* [征结] in the *Five Organs* [五藏], and wherever *qi* resides, it is all *Heaven and Earth*—thus, it cannot be escaped.
*Explication*: This *harm* [贼害] does not stem from *Heaven and Earth* [阴阳] themselves, but arises from the *mind’s* [心] *restlessness* [躁竞] and *competition* [竞], causing such effects.

*Suggested Reading*: **"五藏"** (wǔzàng) is pronounced *Cai Lang* [才浪]. The following all follow this pronunciation.

**[Corrected Text]**

**[Collation Note]** (1) The characters *凝冰* follow the Song edition and the subsequent *Explication*.

The **Dao/Way** is complete—its division is but its **partition** (1).
Its **formation** and its **ruination** (1) are one.
What one **abhors** in its **partition**, is its **partition** to be **complete** (2);
What one **abhors** in **completeness**, is that it **has** what makes it **complete** (3).
Thus, to **exit** without **returning**, one **beholds its specter** (4);
To **exit** and **obtain**, this is called **"obtaining death"** (5).
To **extinguish** yet **retain substance**, this is the **one** of **ghosts** (6).
With **form** to **embody** the **formless**, it is **settled** (7).

---
**(1) [Note]** Formation and ruination are **unconstant** in their **partition**, yet the **Dao/Way** flows through all.
**[Explication]** Things receiving *qi*, each have their **limits**—beauty and ugliness, goodness and evil, **partitioned** into formation and ruination.
Yet what one calls **formation**, another calls **ruination**; the **Dao/Way** unifies them, **complete** in all.

---
**(2) [Note]** To **not uphold** one’s **partition** yet **seek completeness**, this is why one **abhors partition**.
**[Explication]** Honor and disgrace, life and death—**naturally** bestowed by **Heaven**—within one’s **inherent partition**, **sufficiency** lies in **self-return**.
To **transgress** one’s **partition** and **seek sufficiency** elsewhere is to **wander** in the realm of **right and wrong**, **abhorring** the **partition** one has received.

---
**(3) [Note]** If one’s **inherent partition** is **already complete**, why would one **abhor completeness**?
**[Explication]** If **Nature** has already **endowed sufficiency**, yet one **complains** of it—how could one know that **sufficiency** was **already complete** from the start?

---
**(4) [Note]** To **not return** and **guard** within one’s **partition**, then death comes soon.
**[Explication]** To **exit** in **folly**, **chasing** the realm of **right and wrong**, unable to **return** to one’s **origin**—this is to **court death**, hence one **beholds the specter**.

---
**(5) [Note]** To **not exit** is to **not obtain**; this is to **obtain life**.
**[Explication]** When the **mind** **chases** after **things**, **indulging desires**, and **gains** from it—this is called **"obtaining death’s root."**

---
**(6) [Note]** One has **extinguished** one’s **nature**; though **substance** remains, what **differs** from **ghosts**?
**[Explication]** To **obliterate** one’s **true nature**, to **claim** that **life and death** are **indistinguishable**—thus, one is **one** with **ghosts**.

---
**(7) [Note]** Though **substance** exists, if one is **vast** and **without attachment**, then **life is preserved** and **form is settled**.
**[Explication]** *Xiàng* means **"to resemble."**
Though **form** appears, it **resembles** the **formless**—for **form** is **not truly present**.
In **vastness**, **forgetting self**, the **mind** becomes **serene and luminous**, **still and settled**.

---
**[Collation Note]** (1) The Gao Shan Temple edition includes the characters *成也毁也* after *其分也*.

**Exit** without **origin** (1),
**Enter** without **orifice** (2).
To **have substance** yet **no place** to reside,
To **have length** yet **no root** to **plunder** (3),
To **have emergence** yet **no orifice**—this is **substance** (4).
To **have substance** yet **no place** to reside is **Space** (5).
To **have length** yet **no root** to **plunder** is **Time** (6).
There is **birth**, there is **death**, there is **emergence**, there is **entry**—
**Entry and exit** (1) yet **no sight of form** (7),
This is called the **Heavenly Gate** (8).
The **Heavenly Gate** is **non-being**—
All things **emerge from non-being** (9).
What **cannot** be **held as being** by **being**,
Must **exit from non-being** (10),
Yet **non-being** is **neither being nor non-being** (11).
The **Sage** **conceals** within this (12).

---
**(1) [Note]** **Sudden** and **self-arising**, yet **no origin**.
**(2) [Note]** **Sudden** and **self-perishing**, yet **no root**.
**[Explication]** *Exit* is **birth**; *entry* is **death**.
From **non-being** arises **being**—**being** has **no root or source**.
From **being** returns to **non-being**—**non-being** is **without orifice or cavity**.

---
**[Explication]** *Plunder* means **end** or also **origin**.
*Root* is also written as *piāo* (摽); here, it follows the character’s reading.
It speaks of **emerging from non-being** into **being**—though **substance** exists,
**Tracing** its **cause**, there is **no place** to **reside**;
From **ancient times to now**, it is **vastly long**—
**Searching** from **past to present**, yet **no beginning or end** can be found.
