**[Release Text Notes]**
*出无本入无窍* (chū wú běn rù wú qiào): *Chū* (exit/generate) is **birth**; *rù* (enter) is **death**; *běn* is **origin**; *qiào* is **orifice**.
Thus, it is known that **form** is **burdened by the formless**—
Because **emergence and entry** have **no origin or orifice**.

**◎ Family Tradition (Father’s Commentary):**
Guo Xiang took *exit* and *entry* as **life and death**.
But *exit* and *entry* are **not** life and death—
They are **analogous** to life and death.
**Form** is **substance**; if **form** has **no place** to reside, then there is **emergence**.
The **formless** is what **sustains**—yet it has **no beginning, end, root, or extremity**—thus, there is **entry**.
**Emergence and entry** have **no orifice**, yet **substance** is **fixed**.
**Heaven and Earth**, the six directions—this is **Space**, spoken of in terms of **vastness**.
**Ancient times to the present**—this is **Time**, spoken of in terms of **duration**.
To **enter and exit** within **Space and Time** yet **see no form**—
This is called **settlement**.
*"Oùrán"* (欻然) is read as *wù* (勿).

**Exegesis and Commentary:**

**【Textual Notes】**
*"Húchǔ"*—read as *Chāngjù* (昌据反).
*Below* follows the same reading.
*"Yǒu zhǎng"*—read as *Dīngzhàng* (丁丈反), meaning "increase."
*Also* as the character itself.
*Below* follows the same reading.
*"Běn piāo"*—*běn* also written as *piāo* (摽), same.
*Fǔ* (甫) read as *xiǎo* (小反).
*Cui* says: "end."
*Lì* read as *bùyáo* (怖遥反), *Xú* again as *fúyáo* (敷遥反).
*Below* follows the same.
◎ *Lú Wénpiàn* says: *"Piāo"* should be *"biāo"* (标).

**【Commentary】**
It speaks of the *emergence* having its own *substance*—yet its *emergence* lacks an orifice or root from which it issues.

**【Exegesis】**
Though it *emerges*, there is no orifice—
For the common observer, it seems to have *substance*, yet truly it does not.
If there were an orifice, it would require *substance*;
But *substance* is unattainable, so the orifice is nonexistent.

**【Textual Notes】**
*"Yǒu suǒ chū"*—"All that emerges must have a source."
*"Ér wú"*—This clarifies that the source is *nonexistent*.
If it is *nonexistent*, how could there be emergence?

*"Kǒu zhě yǒu shí"*—If there is an orifice, it must have *substance*;
Seeking *substance* yields nothing, so the orifice is also nonexistent.

**【Commentary】**
*Space* (*yǔ*) has four directions—up, down, and the four cardinal points—yet these directions are without limit.

**【Exegesis】**
*Space* refers to the four directions and above/below.
Though things arise, they seem to have *substance*, yet searching *Space* reveals no origin.
If *Space* is nonexistent, how could there be a place?

**【Textual Notes】**
*"Yǒu shí ér wú húchǔ zhě yǔ yě"*—The *Three Ancient Readings* (*Sānpáng*) say: "The four directions and above/below constitute *Space*."
Though *Space* may seem to have *substance*, no fixed place can be found.

**【Commentary】**
*Time* (*zhòu*) has the length of ancient and modern eras, yet this length is boundless.

**【Exegesis】**
*Time* refers to past antiquity and the present.
The seasons stretch long, called *ancient and modern*;
Examining successive ages reveals no beginning or end.
If *Time* is nonexistent, how could there be an origin?

**【Textual Notes】**
*"Yǒu zhǎng ér wú běn piāo zhě zhòu yě"*—The *Three Ancient Readings* say: "Past antiquity to the present is *Time*."
The *Shuōwén Jiězì* says: "The covering of a boat or carriage is called *Time*."
*Zhǎng* means "increase."
*Běn* means "beginning."
Though *Time* may increase, its beginning and end remain unknown.

**【Commentary】**
Death, life, emergence, and entry—
All occur *wùrán* (欻然), spontaneously, without cause, thus no form is seen.

**【Exegesis】**
*Emergence* and *entry* are like *life* and *death*.
Though they bear these names, probing their nature reveals no visible form of their emergence or entry.

**【Commentary】**
*The Heavenly Gate* is the collective name for all things.
It is called *Heavenly Gate*, akin to the *Gate of All Marvels*.

**【Exegesis】**
*Heaven* refers to the natural order—
The natural order is defined by having no origin.
All existence arises from nowhere, its source unfathomable;
Thus, *Heaven* is the gateway of creation.

**【Commentary】**
Death, life, emergence, and entry—
All occur *wùrán*, spontaneously, with no agent behind them.
Yet there is gathering and dispersal, concealment and revelation—
Thus they bear the names *emergence* and *entry*.
Only in name do they exist; truly, there is no emergence or entry.
Where then is the *Gate*?
Thus, the *Gate* is *nonbeing*.

If the *Gate* is *nonbeing*, then there is no *Gate*.

**【Exegesis】**
The natural order’s principle, the gateway of transformation—
Only in name does it exist; in reality, it is nonexistent.
Yet all things arise from this *Gate*, hence Guo’s note: "The *Gate* is *nonbeing*."
If the *Gate* is *nonbeing*, then there is no *Gate*.

**【Commentary】**
Before *being* emerged, what gave rise to it?
Thus, it must arise from *itself*—how could *being* itself be its cause?

**【Exegesis】**
If *being* exists, how could it give rise to *being*?
Before *being* emerged, who gave rise to it?
Seeking this *being* reveals nothingness.

**【Commentary】**
This clarifies that *being* cannot create *being*—it arises from *itself*.
If *nonbeing* could create *being*, what would *nonbeing* be?

**【Exegesis】**
Both *being* and *nonbeing* are nonexistent;
This *being* emerges from *nonbeing*—not that *nonbeing* can generate *being*.
If *nonbeing* could generate *being*, what would *nonbeing* be?

**【Commentary】**
If *nonbeing* is absolute, then *being* is nonexistent.
If *nonbeing* is nonexistent, then *being* spontaneously emerges.

**【Exegesis】**
Not examining the four negations—
All is *nonbeing*, hence "one *nonbeing*."
*(Note: Original text appears truncated; "四句" likely refers to the four negations in Buddhist logic—*abhāva*, *śūnyatā*, etc.)*

**【Commentary】**
The Sage of ancient times, attuned to the Dao, harmonized with reality—
Concealing the spirit, hiding wisdom—
This is their state.

**Textual Corrections:**
(1) Omitted text from *Zhāng Jūnfáng*’s edition: *"Chū rù"* (出入) corrected to *"chūrù"* (出入).
(2) *"Jìng"* (竟) corrected based on the following sentence.

---
**Ancient Masters’ Insight Reached Its Peak.**
How did they attain it?
Some say: *"Before anything existed, they reached the peak, exhausted it—nothing more could be added."*
The next level: *"Things exist,"*
Yet they see *birth* as *loss*,
And *death* as *return*—
Thus, they are divided.

The next says: *"At first, there was *nonbeing*;*
Then *being* arose, *being* swiftly perished.
Taking *nonbeing* as the head,
*Being* as the body,
*Death* as the tail—
Who knows the unity of *being* and *nonbeing*, *life* and *death*?
I would count them as my friends.

---
**These three, though differing, are kin—**
Like *Zhāo* and *Jìng* (昭景),
Like *Zhuó* and *Dài* (着戴),
Like *Jiǎ* and *Fēng* (甲氏, 着封)—
They are not one.

**【Exegesis】**
The ancient Sage, attuned to the Dao, merged with reality—
Thus called *"attained."*

**【Exegesis】**
Asking how they attained it—
*(Original text truncated; likely refers to the method of their attainment.)*

**【Exegesis of Terms】**
*"Éhū"* is pronounced *Wū*.

**【Exegesis】**
This reveals the true nature of the *attained*—
Once knowledge reaches its peak, all within is void,
Thus all phenomena are used without attachment—
Not a single thing remains.
This is the utmost subtlety, exhausting principle and perfecting nature,
A boundless, wondrous emptiness beyond further refinement.

**【Exegesis】**
In the next stage, they have not yet grasped true emptiness,
Yet perceive all myriad things as substantial.

**【Annotation】**
*"Sāng"* means to lose and turn toward aggregation.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*"Wéisāng"* is pronounced *xīlàng*.

**Annotation:** Same as above.

**【Annotation】**
*"Róngyè"* means to return and dissolve.

**【Exegesis】**
*Sāng* means *loss*.
Common folk regard *life* as gain and *death* as loss.
Now, to reverse their deluded perception,
*Life* is called *loss*—for it is *nonbeing*;
*Death* is called *return*—returning to emptiness and stillness.
Though not yet attaining the utmost subtlety,
They equalize *life* and *death*.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*"Róngyè"* is pronounced *yì*.

**【Annotation】**
Though they seek equality, distinction remains.

**【Exegesis】**
Though *life* and *death* are equalized,
They still perceive their difference,
Thus arising from *nonbeing* to make distinctions.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*"Yǐ fēn"* is pronounced *fāngyún*.

**【Exegesis】**
In the next stage, their understanding dims slightly—
At first, there was *nonbeing*;
Then *being* arose, swiftly perishing.
Thus, they take *nonbeing* as the head,
*Being* as the form,
*Death* as the tail.
Who knows the unity of *being* and *nonbeing*, *life* and *death*,
And cultivates it thus?
Zhuangzi would befriend such a person—
Such individuals are rare indeed.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*"Wéi shāo"* is pronounced *kǔgāo*.

**【Annotation】**
Some take *being* and *nonbeing* as one,
Some take them as singular,
Some equalize them through division—
Thus, three categories.
Though these three differ in completeness,
All refrain from judgment within,
Hence called *public kin*.

**【Exegesis】**
The three refer to:
Taking *nonbeing* as the head,
*Being* as the body,
*Death* as the tail.
Within one unity, these three distinctions arise—
Like the three clans of the Chu lineage under one surname.

**【Annotation】**
Though these four are *public kin*,
They are not one—
Thus, the previous three already differ.

**【Exegesis】**
*Zhāo* and *Jǐng* are the three public clans of Chu.
Long ago, Qu Yuan was the Grand Tutor of the Three Gates,
Overseeing the three clans and three surnames—
This is the case.
The text is abbreviated, thus simply stating *Zhāo* and *Jǐng*.
Royal princes, upon coming of age, wore robes and crowns—
Each held ranks, fulfilling their duties,
And received surnames through their offices,
Thus *Jiǎ* (甲) as a clan—
Their merits recorded, they were granted fiefs,
Branches spreading—
Hence, they are not one.

Like the Dao itself,
Divided into *being* and *nonbeing*, *life* and *death*,
Each with distinct names and realities—
Thus, their clans are cited as analogy.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*"Zhāojǐng yě zhuó"* is pronounced *dīnglüè* or *zhānglǜ*.
*"Dài"* is also written as *zǎi*.
*"Yě jiǎ shì yě zhuó"* is pronounced *zhānglǜ* (long) or *dīnglüè*.
*"Fēng yě fēi yī yě"*—
One interpretation says:
*Zhāo*, *Jǐng*, and *Jiǎ* are all of Chu’s same lineage.
*Zhuó* and *Dài* refer to wearing crowns,
Generations serving in Chu’s court, revered by all.
*Zhuó* and *Fēng* refer to holding fiefs,
Their glory enduring.
Though *Zhāo*, *Jǐng*, and *Jiǎ* are three surnames,
Their origins are the same.
Cui (崔) says:
*Zhāo* and *Jǐng* are two surnames honored by Chu,
All of the *Jiǎ* lineage, granted illustrious fiefs—
Though not one surname, they share the same public kin,
Illustrating the unity of *life* and *death*.
These two interpretations differ from the annotation.

◎ *Jiāshì Fù* says:
Gu’s annotation calls the four *public kin*,
Seemingly treating *Zhāo*, *Jǐng*, and *Jiǎ* as clans.
The *Exegesis of Terms* says:
*Zhāo*, *Jǐng*, and *Jiǎ* are all of Chu’s same lineage.
It also cites Cui, saying:
*Zhāo* and *Jǐng* are two surnames honored by Chu,
All of the *Jiǎ* lineage, granted illustrious fiefs.
Doubtless, Cui’s interpretation is correct.
Wang Yi’s *Annotations on Chu Ci* states:
The Three Gates oversaw the royal clans’ three surnames:
*Zhāo*, *Qu*, and *Jǐng*.
There is no *Jiǎ* as a surname.
*The Book of Characters* says:
*Shǒu* (首) means *to wear*.
*The Yà* says:
*Dài* (戴) refers to the road’s beginning, facing the mound.
*Zhuó* and *Dài* refer to *Zhāo* and *Jǐng* succeeding as surnames;
*Jiǎ* is the beginning of the day—
Speaking of first receiving a surname to be granted a fief,
Then succeeding as a surname.
Though of the same public kin,
Their origins are not one.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*"Yǐ fù"* is pronounced *fúyòu*.

**Collation:**
(1) The text is missing; as in the *Hǎi* edition, *zhōu* (守) is mistakenly cited as *zōng* (宗).
*"Yǒu shēng"* (有生) is pronounced *hēixiàn*.
*Bìrán* (披然) is pronounced *yíshì*.
It was said: *"Yíshì"*—this is not what was spoken.
(3) Nevertheless, it is unknowable.
The *là* (腊) of *làzhě* has *fēngtí* (膍胲)—
It can be dispersed, yet cannot be dispersed.
(5) Observing a hall, they circle the ancestral temple,
Then suddenly stop—
This is called *"Yíshì."*

**【Annotation】**
This is merely the gathering of *qi*.

**【Exegesis】**
*Hēixiàn* means *blemish*.
To call this formless *being* merely a gathering of *qi* into a blemish—
This is not what is honored.
**Exegesis of Terms:**
*"Yǒu shēng (hēixiàn)"* is pronounced *xúyújiǎn*.
Sima (司马) says: *Hēi* (黡) means *blemished*,
Blemished—desiring to peel away.
Li (李) is pronounced *wūgǎn*.
*Zìlín* says: *Hēi* is the black at the pot’s bottom.

「(2) **【Annotation】**
Once the *qi* has dispersed (*bìrán*), yet distinctions arise,
Then each becomes what it is called (二).
This is impermanent, hence it is said to be *"moved"* (*yí*).

**【Exegesis】**
*Bì* (披) means *dispersed*.
The Dao does not disperse me, yet things have their distinctions (*shìfēi* 是非),
These distinctions are not fixed, hence they disperse and move (*yíxǐ* 移徙) without permanence.
The state of their movement (*yí*) is detailed below.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*Bì* (披) is pronounced *pǔpí*.
*"Yíshì"* (移是)—some say: □*Rán* (然) gathered while alive, *bìrán* (披然) dispersed while dead.

(3) **【Annotation】**
The movement (*yí*) of what is called (*suǒshì* 所是) has already been spoken of.

**【Exegesis】**
It tests the distinctions of form and substance (*lǐxíng shìfēi* 理形是非),
Hence the words are merely spoken.
Yet the movement of distinctions (*shìfēi* 是非) is not what is spoken of.

(4) **【Annotation】**
If one does not speak of its movement (*yí*),
Then its movement cannot be known—
Hence one tests it through speech.

**【Exegesis】**
Though distinctions (*shìfēi* 是非) do not depend on speech,
Without speech, one cannot know distinctions.
Hence one speaks of distinctions (*shìfēi* 是非) to dispel them.
Names do not rely on speech—
Only then does one know that distinctions are without distinctions (*shìfēi wú shìfēi* 是非無是非).

(5) **【Annotation】**
Things each have their use (*yòng* 用).

**【Exegesis】**
*Là* (腊) refers to the grand sacrifice.
*Fēngtí* (膍胲): *Fēng* (膍) is the cow’s hundred leaves (i.e., its hide),
*Tí* (胲) means *complete*—also referring to its hooves.
At the time of the grand sacrifice (*là*),
The sacrificial animals are fully prepared—
Even their limbs and five viscera are displayed.
Once the sacrificial rites are concluded,
They are then dispersed—
This is called *proper* (*shì* 是).
If the sacrifice is not yet finished,
They should not be dispersed—
This is called *improper* (*bùshì* 不是).
Thus one knows that *proper* and *improper* are without permanence (*yíshì wúcháng* 移是無常).

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*Là* (腊) is pronounced *lìhé*.
*"Zhě zhī yǒu fēngtí"* (者之有膍胲) is pronounced *pī* (毗).」

「Sīmǎ yún: The cow’s hundred leaves (*fēng* 膍) are indeed its hide.
Originally, *fēng* (膍) was sometimes written as □, pronounced *pī* (毗), meaning *roe deer*.
*Tí* (胲), pronounced *gǔlái* (古来反), refers to the great toe.
Cuī yún: *Tí* (胲) means *complete*.
In the grand sacrifice (*là* 腊), all sacrificial animals are fully prepared, and the feast includes *fēngtí* (膍胲). Though these may be dispersed, the ritual demands that nothing essential should be discarded—this is the proper order.

**【Sixth Annotation】**
*Yǎn* (偃) refers to the screened privy (*píngzhè* 屏厕).

**【Exegesis】**
*Yǎn* (偃) is the screened privy (*píngzhè* 屏厕).
When the sacrificial rites are complete, the *zhāi gōng* (斋宫) and the feasting are done,
And the remaining sacrificial meat (*yúzhì* 胙) is placed within the halls and chambers.
The participants observe and move about within the *qǐn miào* (寝庙).
After prolonged feasting, they must retire to a private place,
Thus they go to the screened privy (*yǎn* 偃) to relieve themselves.
Feasting is deemed proper within the *qǐn miào* (寝庙),
While relieving oneself is deemed proper within the screened privy (*yǎn* 偃).
Thus *proper* and *improper* are without constancy—
How can anything be definitively fixed?

The grand sacrifice (*là* 腊) illustrates that gathering and dispersing are without permanence,
And that the designated chambers and places are not fixed—
All are without *proper* or *improper*.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*Yǎn* (其偃) is pronounced *yúwǎn* (于晚反).
Both Sīmǎ (司马) and Guō (郭) state: It is the screened privy (*píngzhè* 屏厕).
It is also pronounced *yújàn* (于建反).
◎ Qìngfān (庆藩) notes: Guō (郭) and Sīmǎ (司马) both say *yǎn* (偃) is the screened privy (*píngzhè* 屏厕).
Guìfú (桂馥) states: *Píng* (屏) should be *yǎn* (庰), and *yǎn* (偃) should be *yàn* (晏).
In *Jíjiù Piān* (急就篇), *yǎn* (庰) is described as a name for a private, screened place (*bìyǎn* 僻偃).
Now, I consider *yǎn* (偃) should be *yīn* (匽).
The *Zhōu Lǐ* (周礼) mentions that attendants (*gōngrén* 宫人) serve at the privy (*yīn* 匽), which I suspect may be a miswritten character for *yǎn* (庰).
*Zhōu Lǐ* (周礼) further states: *Yīn* (匽) is a roadside privy (*lùyǎn* 路厕).
The *Yàn Cè* (燕策) records that the *Sòngwáng Zhòu* (宋王铸) sent attendants to serve at the *píng* (屏), which is also a miswritten character for *yǎn* (庰).
Thus, *yǎn yīn* (庰匽) refers to the screened privy (*yǎn* 庰).
The *Kāiyuán Zhànjīng* (开元占经) quotes Gān Shì (甘氏) as saying:
The seven stars of *Tiān yǎn* (天溷) are outside the *píng* (屏).
The *Huáinán Zhù* (淮南注) states: *Tiān yǎn* (天溷) is the privy (*yǎn* 厕),
And *píng* (屏) is what shields the sky’s shadow (*yǐn* 翳).
*Píngyǎn* (屏厕) is pronounced *bùdìng* (步定反) or *bìlǐng* (必领反).
The same applies below.

**【Seventh Annotation】**
The *qǐn miào* (寝庙) is where the feast and reception (*xiǎngyàn* 飨燕) take place,
While the screened privy (*yǎn* 偃) is where one relieves oneself (*sǎoshuō* 溲).
When one relieves oneself in the screened privy (*yǎn* 偃),
The *proper* (*shì* 是) of the *qǐn miào* (寝庙) shifts to the screened privy (*yǎn* 偃).
Thus, the shifting of *proper* and *improper* alternates between one and the other—
Who could maintain constancy in this?

Hence, the *Perfect Sage* (*Zhìrén* 至人) follows this principle and rides upon it,
And thereby achieves balance (*jūn* 均).

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*Wéi shì* (为是) is pronounced *yúwěi* (于伪反).
◎ Jiāshìfù (家世父) says:
*Yǒushēng* (有生) is *chén* (尘, dust).
□ (*yǒu* 有, here referring to *yǎn* 偃) is the accumulation and retention of dust (*chén* 尘).
Thus, it is said that one exchanges life (*shēng* 生) for death (*sǐ* 死),
And the transformation is called *shifting proper* (*yǐshì* 移是).

Although there is life (*shēng* 生),
Like *fēngtí* (膍胲) clinging to one another,
Dispersal leads to death (*sǐ* 死),
Yet it cannot be permanently dispersed.
Those with life must also face death,
Just as the *qǐn miào* (寝庙) requires the *yǎn* (偃, privy act).
These are interdependent and thus arise together.

The phrase *shifting proper* (*yǐshì* 移是) signifies
That life is seen as a burden (*lèi* 累),
Death as return (*guī* 归),
And self-perception as a hindrance (*lèi* 累).
To equalize life and death (*qíngshēngsǐ* 齐生死),
One transcends the labels of *proper* and *improper*, name and reality (*shìngmíngshí* 是非名实).
If one regards life as a burden,
Then one must inevitably hold onto a fixed perception (*jǐ* 己),
And thereby create distinctions of *proper* and *improper*, name and reality (*shìngmíngshí* 是非名实),
Which give rise to the contentions of foolishness, pride, and shame (*yúróngrù* 愚荣辱).

The shifting of *proper* (*yǐshì* 移是) has its limits—
There are things that cannot be shifted.
This is the reason life (*shēng* 生) is called □ (*yǎn* 偃).

*Sǎoshuō* (溲) is pronounced *suǒliú* (所留反).

**Corrections:**
(1) The text from *Jiāngnán Gǔzàng* (江南古藏本) and *Lǐzhāng* (李张二本) omits the character *shuō* (溲) after *yǎn* (偃).
(2) The *Shìdétáng* (世德堂本) has *yě* (也) instead of *yǐ* (矣).
Please use the term *shifting proper* (*yǐshì* 移是) consistently in speech.»

Thus, life (*shēng* 生) is taken as the root **[1]**, and knowledge (*zhī* 知) as the teacher **[2]**, yet one rides upon distinctions of *proper* and *improper* **[3]**. Names and realities (*míngshí* 名实) are indeed produced **[4]**, and one thereby takes oneself as the standard **[5]**. This makes others regard it as one’s principle (*jié* 节), and one thereby repays with death for one’s principle **[7]**.

If such is the case, then to act is seen as wisdom, inaction as foolishness, clarity as honorable name (*míng* 名), and adversity as shame (*rǔ* 辱) **[8]**. Those who engage in *shifting proper* (*yǐshì* 移是) are the people of today **[9]**, just as the cicada and the *xuān* bird (*xiāo jiū* 蜩鸠) share the same delusion **[10]**.

---
**[1] Annotation:** The transformations of things—there is no moment without life (*shēng*), and wherever life is, that is the root (*běn* 本).
**Exegesis:** Those who can forget life and death have no *proper* or *improper*. It is only because they are entangled in life that they cling to *proper* distinctions. If one must abandon life, where else would one rest? Thus, it is said that *shifting proper* takes life as the root.

**[2] Annotation:** Though the known may differ, each takes their own knowledge as teacher.

**[3] Annotation:** To ride upon distinctions of *proper* and *improper* is to have no *proper* or *improper* at all.
**Exegesis:** Because of the heart’s attachment to its teacher’s knowledge, the heart rides upon the function of *proper* and *improper*—how could one who takes their teacher’s knowledge as inverted *proper* and *improper* truly have no *proper* or *improper*?

**[4] Annotation:** The names and realities of things indeed each have their own.
**Exegesis:** All things, spoken of thus, are but empty illusions—straw dogs and myriad phenomena. Where do names and realities apply? Those who invert [truth] assert that these names and realities are definitively real.

**[5] Annotation:** *Quality* (*zhì* 质) means *master* (*zhǔ* 主). Each thing claims itself as *proper*, sufficient to be the master of *proper* and *improper*.
**Exegesis:** *Quality* means *master*. Blindly grasping names and realities, one thereby takes oneself as the master of names and realities, contending over *proper* and *improper*.

**[6] Annotation:** All claim themselves as *proper*, so none understand.
**Exegesis:** *Principle* (*jié* 节) is ultimate integrity (*zhì* 操). Having lost sight of names and realities and become entangled in *proper* and *improper*, one makes the unenlightened firmly cling to empty names as their integrity.

**[7] Annotation:** What one upholds is not true liberation.
**Exegesis:** Upholding *proper* and *improper* to form resolve—unyielding and steadfast—one dies clinging to it.
**Phonetic Explanation:** *"Repay with death for one’s principle"* (*yǐ sǐ cháng jié* 以死偿节) is pronounced with *cháng* as in *liàng* (亮). The *Guangya* states: *cháng* means "to repay," "to reciprocate." It is said that one kills oneself to establish a name, and when the principle is fulfilled, the body dies—thus, "to repay with death for one’s principle."

**[8] Annotation:** Unable to adapt to circumstances as they arise.
**Exegesis:** To flaunt as wisdom, to conceal as foolishness, to clarity as honorable name, and to adversity as shame—if such is the case, how could one harmonize with adversity, prosperity, honor, or shame?

**[9] Annotation:** The ancient and pure had no *proper* or *improper*—what shifting could there be?
**Exegesis:** Those who rigidly cling to names and realities, who are entangled in *proper* and *improper*, who are superficial and deceitful—these are the people of today. How could they be the pure and unadorned scholars of antiquity?

**[10] Annotation:** *Shared* (*tóng* 同) is what they share.
**Exegesis:** The cicada and the *xuān* bird (*xiāo jiū* 蜩鸠) take reeds and weeds as *proper*. Though these two creatures share the same *proper*, it is not true enlightenment. Those who engage in *shifting proper* are of this kind. The cicada is like the *xuān* bird, and the *xuān* bird is like the cicada—thus, "shared in the same delusion."
**Phonetic Explanation:** *"Cicada"* (*xiāo* 蜩) is pronounced *tiáo* (条). *"Xuān bird"* (*jiū* 鸠) is sometimes written as *xuān* (*jiū* 鸴), with the same pronunciation.

---
**Collation Notes:**
(1) The *Jiāngnán Gǔzàng* (江南古藏本) and *Lǐzhāng* (李张二本) manuscripts omit the character *fēi* (非) after *jīn* (今) above.
(2) The *Zhào Jiànyì* (赵谏议本) has *shì* (是) instead of *zú* (足).

When one treads upon a stranger’s foot in the marketplace, one excuses oneself by claiming arrogance (*fàngmiǎo* 放骜) **[1]**, upon a brother’s by feigning maternal tenderness (*yūxǔ* 妪诩) **[2]**, and upon a parent’s, one remains silent **[3]**. Thus it is said: the utmost *ritual* (*lǐ* 礼) does not apply to others **[4]**, the utmost *rightness* (*yì* 义) does not apply to things **[5]**, the utmost *wisdom* (*zhī* 知) does not deliberate **[6]**, the utmost *benevolence* (*rén* 仁) has no kin **[7]**, and the utmost *trustworthiness* (*xìn* 信) rejects gold **[8]**.

**[1] Annotation:** One falsely claims detachment to apologize.
**Exegesis:** *Tread* (*diàn* 蹍) means to step or trample. Trampling upon the foot of a stranger in the marketplace—one excuses oneself, saying, "I was arrogant and reckless in my mistake," not doing it intentionally.

**[2] Annotation:** One feigns maternal tenderness without apology.
**Exegesis:** Trampling upon a brother’s foot, one acts with maternal tenderness and pity, not shamed by words.

**[3] Annotation:** One acknowledges natural humility.
**Exegesis:** If a father tramples upon a child’s foot, one remains silent without further excuse. Thus, it is known that words of apology are hollow and insincere.

**[4] Annotation:** *Ritual* that does not apply to others is to regard others as oneself. To regard others as oneself means no apology is needed—this is the utmost *ritual*.
**Exegesis:** Both sides forgotten, one regards others as oneself. Not distinguishing between self and others, how could there be apologies? This is the utmost *ritual*.

**[5] Annotation:** Each attains its proper place, so all things are oneself.
**Exegesis:** Having transcended the duality of self and other, one perfectly attains harmony. Not knowing that there is anything outside oneself, how could there be distinctions of *proper* and *improper*?

This is the utmost *righteousness* **[1]**.

**[6] Annotation:** One knows only after deliberation—this is not innate knowledge.
**Exegesis:** To illuminate nature spontaneously is not to know through scheming. This is the utmost *wisdom*.

**[7] Annotation:** By analogy with the five *zàng* organs—though they have never met, *ren* (benevolence) has already reached its fullness.
**Exegesis:** Like hands and feet, they naturally assist one another without conscious effort, yet their harmonizing function is complete. How could there be affection between them?

**[8] Annotation:** Gold and jade are merely the substance of petty *faith*—true *faith* transcends them.
**Exegesis:** *Bì* means "to discard." Gold and jade are but the substance of petty *faith*; true *faith* casts them aside.

---
To pierce through *zhi* (arrogance), to dissolve *miù* (delusion of the heart), to remove the burdens of *virtue*, to unblock the obstructions of the *Dao* **[1]**.

Wealth, honor, eminence, prestige, reputation, and profit—these agitate the *zhi* **[2]**.
Appearance, movement, expression, speech, *qi*, and intention—these ensnare the mind **[3]**.
Aversion, desire, joy, anger, sorrow, and delight—these encumber *virtue* **[4]**.
Departure, approach, taking, giving, knowing, and ability—these obstruct the *Dao* **[5]**.
If these twelve categories do not disturb the chest, one attains rectitude; rectitude brings stillness; stillness brings clarity; clarity brings emptiness; emptiness allows *wuwei* yet accomplishes all **[6]**.

The *Dao* is the revered manifestation of *virtue* **[7]**.
Life is the radiance of *virtue* **[8]**.
Nature is the essence of life **[9]**.
When nature moves, it is called *wei* **[10]**.
When *wei* is artificial, it is called *loss* **[11]**.
Knowledge is *jie* (reception);
Knowledge is *mó* (deliberation) **[12]**.
What the knowing does not know is like *nì* (glancing) **[13]**.
To move only when unavoidable is *virtue* **[14]**.
To move without ever opposing oneself is *zhì* (governance) **[15]**.
Names may be contrary, yet their reality aligns **[16]**.

**[1] Exegesis:** *Chè* means "to destroy." *Bó* means "to disrupt." *Miù* means "to bind." This section briefly names the categories; their detailed explanations follow below.
**Annotations:** *Zhī-bó* originally also written as *bèi*, same meaning. *Zhī-miù* as written. One version reads *miù*, pronounced *wúng-hóu* (same as *miù*).
*Zhī-dé* pronounced *qǐ-lù*.

**[2] Exegesis:** Honor, wealth, abundance, elevation, dignity, fame, and gain—these six are the instruments that disrupt emotions and will.

**[3] Exegesis:** Mien, movement, complexion, discourse, *qi*, and sentiment—these six bind and ensnare the spirit. Some texts also use *miù* (delusion), clarifying the heart’s falsehoods.

**[4] Exegesis:** Hatred, love, joy, anger, grief, and pleasure—these six are the afflictions burdening *virtue*.
**Annotations:** *È-yù* pronounced *wū-lù*. *Āi-lè* pronounced *luò*. *Lèi-dé* pronounced *liè-wěi*. Later annotations match this.

**[5] Exegesis:** Departure and dwelling, acquisition and bestowal, cognition and deliberation, skill and ability—these six obstruct the True Dao.

**[6] Annotation:** *Dàng* means "movement."
**Exegesis:** The afflictions of the fourth and sixth [sections]—if they do not agitate within the chest, then the mind and spirit remain balanced. Balance brings tranquility, tranquility brings clarity, clarity brings openness, openness brings serenity and non-action. Responding to things without exhaustion.

**[7] Exegesis:** Dao is the method of cultivation; virtue is the conduct toward others. To revere people over method, hence one honors the Dao.
**Annotation:** *Yú Yù* says: In *Shuō Wén* (Explanations of Script): *chǎn* (陳) means to array offerings and garments in the courtyard. In *Xiǎo Éryá* (Minor Commentary on Words): *chǎn* means "to array." Here, *qīn* (欽) is a borrowed character for *chǎn*. What sustains life is virtue, and when arrayed, it becomes Dao—thus, it is called the *chǎn* of virtue. The *Hàn Shū* (Book of Han) annotation on Emperor Aidi cites *Lǐ Fěi* as saying: "Arrayed" means Dao. This is its meaning.

**[8] Exegesis:** The great virtue of Heaven and Earth is *shēng* (生, "generation"), thus the generation and transformation of all things is the radiant manifestation of supreme virtue.
**Annotation:** *Dé zhī guāng* (德之光) – One version reads *xiān* (先) instead of *guāng*.

**[9] Exegesis:** *Zhì* (質) means "root." Natural disposition is the root of what is received at birth.

**[10] Annotation:** Movement arising from nature is thus called *ěr* (耳, "ear"); this is true action, not contrived action.
**Exegesis:** Moving in accordance with nature, acting within one’s proper role—acting without contrivance is true action, not contrived action.

**[11] Exegesis:** Responding to things and moving—this is the desire of nature. To distort nature and feign emotions is to act beyond one’s role; this is called losing the Dao.

**[12] Exegesis:** Engaging with things before them, deliberating and attending to affairs—this is called *zhī* (知, "knowing").

**[13] Annotation:** The eye’s ability to see is not knowing how to see while seeing; it sees without knowing it sees—this is natural. If one knows before acting, then knowing is false.
**Exegesis:** *Nì* (睨) means "to glance." The eye opens to see without knowing how it sees, yet vision has clarity and darkness. The mind knows without knowing how it knows, yet knowledge has depth and shallowness. The eye cannot force vision, nor can the mind force knowing. If there were limits, it would be like glancing. If one forces it, it is false.

**[14] Annotation:** If movement arises from compulsion, it is forced movement—this is where loss lies.
**Exegesis:** When movement comes from necessity, harmonious yet not forced, using it without constraint—this is supreme virtue.
**Annotation:** *Jiāshì Fù* says: When interacting with things, knowledge arises naturally. Deliberating accordingly, one earns a name. What one does not know is still grasped through intuition, like glancing. Knowledge arises this way, yet the Dao is corrupted by it. Moving only when unavoidable and fully trusting nature—why speak of knowing at all?

**[15] Annotation:** Moving to imitate others brings disorder.
**Exegesis:** Moving in accordance with nature, without abandoning oneself to conform to things, aligns with proper principle—thus, there is no disorder.

**[16] Annotation:** There are names of "self" and "other," hence opposition; when each attains its reality, it follows naturally.
**Exegesis:** There are names of "self," "other," "right," and "wrong," hence opposition in names. Without the reality of "self," "other," "right," or "wrong," their essences align naturally.

**Text:**
Yì was skilled in hitting minute targets but clumsy in avoiding self-praise.
The Sage was skilled in Heaven but clumsy in human affairs.
He who is skilled in Heaven and clumsy in human affairs—only the *quán rén* (全人, "complete person") can do this.
Only insects can understand insects; only insects can understand Heaven.
Does the complete person hate Heaven? Does he hate the human aspect of Heaven?
And yet, what of my Heaven and my humanity?

**[1] Annotation:** Skill in hitting brings praise naturally.
**Exegesis:** Yì was an ancient archer. *Gōng* (工) means "skillful." Yì bent his bow and shot arrows, mastering the subtleties of archery. With such skill, he earned his name, yet avoiding self-praise was impossible.

**[2] Annotation:** Following nature is Heaven; deliberate action is human.
**Exegesis:** The earlier passage used analogy; this is its application. The Sage harmonizes with nature, his achievements matching creation. He makes all things function without revealing his traces—this is truly difficult. Hence, the earlier passage says, "Making the world forget me is difficult."

**[3] Annotation:** Skill in Heaven means clumsiness in human affairs—this is the *quán rén* (complete person), the Sage.
**Exegesis:** *Lǎng* (俍) means "good." The *quán rén* is the *shén rén* (神人, "divine person").

**[4] Only insects can understand insects; only insects can understand Heaven.**
**[5] Does the complete person hate Heaven? Does he hate the human aspect of Heaven?**
**[6] And yet, what of my Heaven and my humanity?**

「》This is the sound of *yú* (余, "excess"). The later chapters are the same.

**[3] Annotation:** The Sage who skillfully harmonizes with nature is clumsy in human affairs—this is the *quán rén* (complete person), the Sage.
**Exegesis:** *Lǎng* (俍, "good/adept") means "good." The *quán rén* (complete person) is the *shén rén* (神人, "divine person").

**[4] Annotation:** To return and guard over insects is to be skilled in Heaven—this is the *quán rén*.
**Exegesis:** Birds fly, beasts run, yet they are skilled in insects; spiders weave webs, dung beetles roll balls—these are skilled in Heaven. All are endowed by the Creator, yet how could they achieve this through mere imitation?

**[5] Exegesis:** The complete person’s virtue is boundless, his divine power unfathomable. Would he scorn his own innate nature and hate what others are endowed with? No! He simply follows his natural inclination.

**[6] Annotation:** To act without knowing, yet still in accordance—this is what is meant by "skillful in Heaven."
**Exegesis:** Whether Heaven or humanity, he sees no distinction between them, acting in total alignment. The earlier passages spoke of Heaven and humanity as separate, yet here they are merged—no distinction is seen between them. *Wú* (吾, "my") is the author’s self-referential term.

A single sparrow alights where the archer stands, and the archer will surely capture it—this is *wēi* (威, "awe/force") **[1]**. But if one uses the whole world as a cage, then the sparrow has no place to flee **[2]**. Thus, King Tang of Shang enclosed Yi Yin within the kitchen **[1]**, and Duke Mu of Qin ransomed Bai Li Xi with five-colored sheep pelts **[2]**.

**[3] Exegesis:** Thus, those who cannot be captured by what they love are nonexistent **[4]**. **[1] Annotation:** Force is used to seize things, and things will surely flee it. **[2] Annotation:** All things in the world have their own inclinations; if their inclinations are satisfied, where would they flee to? **[3] Exegesis:** The Great Dao is vast and boundless, encompassing all without exception. Hence, using Heaven and Earth as a cage means the sparrow has no escape. To know that force alone can seize things is fundamentally contrary to the Creator’s intent.

**[4] Exegesis:** To follow their inclinations is to make all things in the world effortless to obtain; to constrain their nature and forcefully capture them is never possible.

**[5] Annotation:** The Sage’s Way is to act without knowing, yet still in accordance—this is what is meant by "skillful in Heaven."
**Exegesis:** Whether Heaven or humanity, he sees no distinction between them, acting in total alignment. The earlier passages spoke of Heaven and humanity as separate, yet here they are merged—no distinction is seen between them. *Wú* (吾, "my") is the author’s self-referential term.

**[6] Exegesis:** To act with awe and seize things is contrary to virtue and wisdom, so few are captured while many flee. To rule the world with awe is the same in principle.

A single sparrow alights where the archer stands, and the archer will surely capture it—this is *wēi* (威, "awe/force") **[1]**. But if one uses the whole world as a cage, then the sparrow has no place to flee **[2]**. Thus, King Tang of Shang enclosed Yi Yin within the kitchen **[1]**, and Duke Mu of Qin ransomed Bai Li Xi with five-colored sheep pelts **[2]**.

**[3] Exegesis:** Yi Yin was a lowly servant of the Shī clan, skilled in cooking, and carried a jade tripod to serve King Tang. Tang knew of his virtue and also followed his nature, so he appointed him as a kitchen official to contain him. Bai Li Xi was exiled to Di, where the people valued sheep pelts, so Duke Mu of Qin redeemed him with five-colored sheep pelts from Chu. It was also said that Bai Li Xi favored wearing a five-colored sheep pelt robe and was called "Five-Zhu Duke." Both Tang and Mu were sages and virtuous rulers, able to attract worthy men, so they obtained these two individuals, using them as able ministers. They did so by following their natural inclinations.

**[4] Exegesis:** To follow their inclinations is to make all things in the world effortless to obtain; to constrain their nature and forcefully capture them is never possible.

**[5] Annotation:** The Sage’s Way is to act without knowing, yet still in accordance—this is what is meant by "skillful in Heaven."
**Exegesis:** Whether Heaven or humanity, he sees no distinction between them, acting in total alignment. The earlier passages spoke of Heaven and humanity as separate, yet here they are merged—no distinction is seen between them. *Wú* (吾, "my") is the author’s self-referential term.

**[6] Exegesis:** The Sage honors without delight, insults without anger—only those who align with Heaven’s harmony can do this. His anger emerges from non-anger; his action arises from non-action. To seek tranquility, he balances his *qi*; to seek divinity, he follows his heart. When forced to act, he does so out of necessity—this is the Dao of the Sage.

**[Annotations for *wēi* (威):]**
**[1]** *Wēi* (威) as *hū* (或, "perhaps") per the *Lìwén* (释文) variant.
**[2]** *Wēi* (威) as *wú* (无, "none") per the *Lìwén* (释文) variant. *Wú* (无) here means "no possibility of."」

**[7] Exegesis:**

**[1] Annotation:**
*Huà* (画) is what adorns one’s appearance. Since the mutilated man’s form is already impaired and ruined, he no longer cares for praise or blame—thus he *zhuǐ* (拸) and discards it.

**Commentary:**
*Jiè* (介) means "mutilated." *Zhuǐ* (拸) means "to abandon." *Huà* (画) means "adornment." Adornment and fine attire are meant to enhance one’s bearing, but a mutilated man’s appearance is already ruined. Thus, he no longer concerns himself with honor or disgrace—he abandons all such adornment.

**Textual Notes:**
The character *jiè* (介) is pronounced *jiè* (界) in sound. Guo (郭) says: "It means mutilated." Another reading, *qià* (黠), is also attested. The *Guangya* (广雅) defines it as "alone." The Chu (崔) version renders it as *wú* (兀). *Zhuǐhuà* (拸画) is pronounced *chìzhǐ* (敕纸) or *tā* (他), also *zhǐ* (纸). It is also written as *yí* (移). Sima (司马) says: *"Huà* (画) refers to adornments for the body; since he lacks limbs, he no longer cherishes them." Another interpretation: *yí* (移) means "to depart." Chu (崔) says: *"Zhuǐhuà* (拸画) means to disregard conventional standards."

◎Yu Yü (俞樾) notes: Guo’s annotation states that *huà* (画) adorns appearance, and since the mutilated man’s form is ruined, he no longer cares for praise or blame—thus he abandons adornment. However, the phrase *"wài fēiyù"* (外非誉) seems better explained by disregarding conventions rather than mere appearance. Chu’s interpretation—that *zhuǐhuà* (拸画) means to disregard conventional standards—is more fitting. In the *Han Shu* (汉书), Sima Xiangru’s biography mentions *"āi yǐ lùlí"* (痑以陆离), where Zheng Xu (师古) annotates: *"āi* (痑) means self-indulgence." This aligns with the meaning of *zhuǐ* (拸). In the *Guoliang Zhuan* (谷梁传) of the sixth year of Duke Huan, *"yǐ qǐ wǒ"* (以其画我) is rendered *"huà wǒ"* (化我) in the *Gongyang Zhuan* (公羊传), with He Xu (何休) explaining: *"Unseemly conduct is called *huà* (化)."* This too aligns with the meaning of *huà* (画). Truly, once a man’s limbs are mutilated, he no longer cares for his body, and neither praise nor blame affects him—thus he disregards all conventions.

The character *bùfù* (不复) is pronounced *fúyòu* (扶又).

**[2] Annotation:**
He has no reliance on life, so he fears not death.

**Commentary:**
*Xūmǐ* (胥靡) refers to convict laborers. A son of a thousand gold pieces naturally values his life, but a slave or convict does not hold his own life dear. Since he does not cherish it, he ascends heights without fear.

**Textual Notes:**
Sima (司马) says: *"Xūmǐ* (胥靡) are convict laborers." Another interpretation: *"Xūmǐ* (胥靡) refers to those with *liè* (癃, urinary incontinence)."

Cui Yun: *"This refers to castration."* **[3] [Annotation]:** He does not recognize what others hold dear. **[Commentary]:** *"Kui"* (馈), originally also written as *"kui"* (愧), should be read according to the character. Now, returning to one’s innate nature, all things are accomplished through it. Since he does not abandon himself to serve others, he casts aside shame and gratitude, thus forgetting the Dao of human relationships.

Compare it to limbs or clothing—each serves its function in mutual reliance. How could one ever express gratitude for their use?

**[Textual Notes]:** *"Fu"* (夫复) is pronounced *fú* (服), *fúyòu* (扶又).
*"Xu"* (謵) is pronounced *xí* (习).
*"Bùkuì"* (不馈) is pronounced *qìkuì* (其愧).
The *Guangya* states: *"Kui"* (馈) means *"to abandon"* or *"to give away."* Another pronunciation is *"kui"* (愧).
The *Yuanjia* edition reads *"kui"* (愧).
*"While forgetting others"*—*"fu"* (复) here means *"to repay"* or *"to reciprocate."*
*"Xu"* (謵) means *"to indulge"* or *"to play with."*
Now, those who indulge in habits, even in small matters, hold them dear. Yet, if one repays or reciprocates what they have received without returning it in gratitude, this is the utmost foolishness—one who fails to grasp what others cherish. Without reciprocity, there is no human connection, hence *"forgetting others."*

◎ *Jiashishi Fu* says: *"Fei yu"* (非誉) is used interchangeably with *"huǐ yù"* (毁誉, praise and blame). This refers to criticizing his vulgarity. To disregard praise and blame, to abandon life and death, and to forget oneself—this is the case. To repay without gratitude and forget others is to forget propriety.

The *Shuowen Jiezi* states: *"Xu"* (詟) is *"speech that loses its breath."* *"Xu"* (謵) is the same as *"xu"* (詟).
*"Fu xu"* (复謵) means when others speak in submission to coerce one, yet one responds in kind.

Zheng Xuan’s *Shiyi Li* commentary: *"Kui"* (馈) means *"to return"*—whether offering things to deities or humans, it is called *"kui."* To give things to others is *"kui,"* and to speak to comfort others is also *"kui."* *"Fu xu"* (复謵) *"bùkuì"* (不馈) means forgetting distinctions of rank. Forgetting others and oneself, one aligns with the harmony of Heaven.

**[Textual Notes]:** The annotation that *"xu"* (謵) is pronounced *"xí"* (习) and means *"to play with"* is incorrect.

**[4] [Annotation]:** Without human sentiment, one naturally becomes a *"tianren"* (天人, one in harmony with Heaven and humanity).

**[Commentary]:** Following the natural inclinations of Heaven, forgetting human conventions, and thus merging with the principles of nature.

**[5] [Annotation]:** Even those with mutilated bodies and convict laborers align with Heaven’s harmony—how much more so those who naturally embody it!

**[Commentary]:** Aligning with Heaven’s harmony means transcending right and wrong, so one is treated with reverence without delight and with contempt without anger.

**[Textual Notes]:** *"Wu"* (侮) is pronounced *wú* (亡甫).

**[6] [Annotation]:** This expresses the idea that *"wu"* (无, non-being) cannot generate *"you"* (有, being), yet *"you"* cannot act as *"wu."*

**[Commentary]:** Those who act in anger or action are not those who do not act in anger. Thus, one who follows non-action and non-anger is truly aligned. Knowing this, one understands that action originates from non-action, and anger from non-anger. Cultivating this awareness, one remains unperturbed by contempt.

**[7] [Annotation]:** Balancing *qi* (气) brings stillness; sufficiency in principle harmonizes the mind, and divine efficacy manifests. When acting out of necessity, all deeds are just. Thus, the Sage takes this as the Dao—seeking non-action beyond mere emptiness!

**[Commentary]:** *"Yuan"* (缘) means *"to follow"* or *"to conform."* To seek stillness through exertion requires regulating the will and *qi*. Divine transformations begin with surrendering the mind. To harmonize within action yet remain aligned with principle, one must conform to necessity. Necessity means responding naturally to stimuli—what lies within one’s duty. Such examples are why the Sage upholds this as the true Dao.

**[Collation Note]:** The characters *"xu"* (謵) and *"xi"* (詟) were originally reversed; corrected according to the *Shuowen Jiezi*.

**Volume Eight: *Zapian* – *Xu Wu Gui* (徐无鬼) [Twenty-Fourth]**

**[1] [Textual Notes]:** The chapter is named after the person, Xu Wu Gui.

Xu Wu Gui, by way of female official Shang, visited Wei Wu Hou. Wei Wu Hou comforted him: *"Master, you must be weary! Suffering from the toil of mountain forests, you have thus deigned to see me."*

**[1] [Commentary]:** Xu Wu Gui was surnamed Xu, with the courtesy name Wu Gui—a recluse. Female Shang was a minister of Wei. Wei Wu Hou, named Ji, was the son of Wei Wen Hou and the tenth-generation descendant of Bi Wan. Xu Wu Gui wished to admonish Wei Wu Hou, so he used the minister as an intermediary to seek an audience.

**[Textual Notes]:** *"Xu Wu Gui"* (徐无鬼) was a recluse from Mount Mian in Wei. Sima Qian’s text reads *"Mian Mountain recluse Xu Wu Gui."* *"Female Shang"* (女商) was a person’s name. Li [Fan] says: *"Xu Wu Gui and Female Shang were both favored ministers of Wei."*

**[2] [Commentary]:** Having long dwelled in the mountains, enduring hardship, poverty, and illness, he suddenly lowered his aspirations, mingling with the world. His heart was moved, and the ruler sought to console him.

**[Textual Notes]:** *"Wu Hou labored him"* (武侯劳之) is pronounced *lìbào* (力报). The single character *"mountain forests"* (山林) is read as-is; the rest follow the same pronunciation as the next chapter.

Xu Wu Gui replied: *"I am the one wearying you, my lord! What labor could you have for me? If you indulge your desires and prolong your likes and dislikes, your vital essence will falter. If you suppress your desires and restrain your likes and dislikes, your ears and eyes will suffer. I seek to weary you—what labor could you have for me?"*

Wei Wu Hou remained silent in detached composure.

**[1] [Annotation]:** Desires and aversions, internal and external, find no resolution.

**[Commentary]:** *"Pì"* (黜) means *"to dismiss."* *"Zhān"* (掔) means *"to withdraw."* If desires overflow and aversions deepen, the vitality of life weakens. If desires are suppressed and aversions withdrawn, the body becomes unbalanced, causing ears and eyes to suffer. Thus, I seek to console you—how could you have time to weary me?

**[Textual Notes]:** *"Yíng qí"* (盈耆) is pronounced *shízhì* (时志). The same pronunciation applies below and in the annotation.

「《长》 (Dīng zhàng) is pronounced *dīng zhàng* (丁丈).
《好》 (hào) is pronounced *hūbào* (呼报).
The same pronunciation applies below in the annotations and chapters.

《恶》 (wù) is pronounced *wūlù* (乌路).
The same pronunciation applies below in the annotations and chapters.

《黜》 (chù) is pronounced *chùlǜ* (敕律), meaning **"to dismiss"** or **"to retreat."** It is also written as *chù* (出), with the same sound.
司马 (Sīmǎ) reads it as *duō* (咄).

《掔》 (qiān) is pronounced *kǔtián* (苦田) or *kǒuxián* (口闲), meaning **"to fix"** or **"to withdraw."**
《尔雅》 (Ěryǎ) says: **"to hold firm."**
崔 (Cuī) says: **"to draw away."**
司马 (Sīmǎ) says: **"to pull."**

**[二] [Annotation]:** This is a repetition of the previous meaning.

**[三] [Annotation]:** He did not speak to him.

**[Commentary]:** *"Chāorán"* (超然) means **"detached"** or **"lost in thought."** Since his words did not accord with the situation, he remained lost in thought and did not respond.
[释文] 司马 (Sīmǎ) says: *"Chāorán"* (超然) is like **"lost in thought."**

**[Textual Notes]:** *"不说"* (bùshuō) is pronounced *yuè* (悦). The same pronunciation applies below in the larger text.

A little while later, Xu Wu Gui said: **"I once told you that I perceived you as a dog【一】. The lower kind of dog clings to its food until sated, which is the virtue of a weasel【二】; the middle kind gazes at the sun【三】, and the highest kind seems to have lost its body【四】. My perception of you as a dog is still not as favorable as my perception of you as a horse【五】. When I perceive you as a horse, the straight one fits the plumb line【六】, the crooked one fits the hook【七】, the square one fits the compass【八】, the round one fits the circle【九】—this is the finest horse of a feudal state【一０】, yet it is still not as grand as the finest horse in the world【一一】. The finest horse in the world has natural excellence【一一】—it appears anxious, as if it has lost something【一二】, or as if it has forgotten its body【一三】. Such a horse surpasses all others, leaving dust far behind, and its source is unknown【一三】."**

Wei Wu Hou was greatly delighted and laughed【一四】.

**[一] [Commentary]:** Having observed that Wei Wu Hou was lost in thought and not pleased, he spoke of dogs and horses to test his reaction, hoping to cheer his heart.

**[二] [Commentary]:** He holds firm to his emotions and desires, only coveting food, and his nature is as greedy as a weasel—this is the lowest kind of dog.

**[三] [Commentary]:** His spirit and *qi* are lofty and distant, gazing as far as the sun, and his physique is such—this is the middle kind of dog.

**[四] [Commentary]:** The "one" refers to the **body**. His *qi* and spirit are steady and resolute, as if he has forgotten his own body—this is the highest kind of dog.

**[六] [Commentary]:** Refers to the **horse’s front teeth**.

**[七] [Commentary]:** Refers to the **horse’s neck**.

**[八] [Commentary]:** Refers to the **horse’s head**.

**[九] [Commentary]:** Refers to the **horse’s eyes**.

**[一０] [Commentary]:** Combining the above perceptions, this is the finest horse among the feudal states.

**[一一] [Commentary]:** His virtue and talent are naturally complete, requiring no training—this is the finest horse in the world, the kind the sovereign rules over.

**[一二] [Commentary]:** His eyes seem to look back anxiously, as if he is worried; his hooves move slowly, yet he appears to be fleeing—his spirit and appearance suggest he has forgotten himself. Such a horse is the finest under Heaven.

**[一三] [Commentary]:** *"Yì"* (轶) means **"to surpass."** His swift gallop exceeds all other horses, swift as the wind, leaving dust far behind—since this excellence is not taught, its source is unknown.

**[一四] [Annotation]:** The words of a true person are how modest! Only what is pleasing to the senses can delight him.

**[Commentary]:** Xu Wu Gui spoke at the right moment, so Wei Wu Hou laughed and was delighted.

When Xu Wu Gui departed, Nǚ Shāng said: **"Master, why did you alone delight my lord? I delight my lord by speaking of poetry, books, rites, and music when he is at ease, and by discussing military strategies—golden armor and six *zhuó* (弢) of chariots—when I address him formally. Those who serve him well are countless, yet my lord has never opened his mouth to speak【三】."**

Now, Master, how did you alone bring such delight to my lord that he rejoices as he does【四】?

---
**[一] [Commentary]:** Having finished discussing matters, he took his leave. Nǚ Shāng, wondering at the king’s laughter, thus inquired of Xu Wu Gui.

**[二] [Commentary]:** *"Poetry, books, rites, and music"*—these are the Six Classics. *"Golden armor and six zhuó"* refers to the titles of *Zhōu Shū* (周书), or some say, secret prophecies. Originally written as *"six táo"* (六韬), meaning the *Six Táos* of Tàigōng—namely, *Wén*, *Wǔ*, *Hǔbào*, *Lóngquǎn*—and the six *zhuó* (弢). *"Horizontal"* means distant; *"following"* means close. Since Wú Hóu favored martial matters and despised the literary arts, he treated military strategy as the *"following"* and the Six Classics as *"horizontal."*

---
**[三] [Annotation]:** It is only the *Lèyīn* (乐鴳) that delights with bells and drums, so he is troubled. ◎ Qìng Fàn notes in the *Wén Xuǎn* annotation of Guō Jǐngpú’s *"You Xiān"* (游仙) poem that *"start amǐ"* (启齿) means *"to smile."* The *Shìwén* entry is omitted.

**[Release Text]:** *"Yǐ shuō"* (以说) as written, or with the reading *shǐruì* (始锐). All below follow the same.
Sīmǎ (司马) renders it as *"yuè"* (悦).
*"Zòng shuō"* (从说) reads *zǐróng* (子容).
*"Jīnbǎn"* (金版) is also written as *"bǎn"* (板), read as *bóbǎn* (薄版), or as written.

*"Liù zhuó"* (六弢) reads *tǔdāo* (吐刀).
Sīmǎ and Chuǐ (崔) say: *"Jīnbǎn liù zhuó"* (金版六弢) are all titles from *Zhōu Shū*. Some say: secret (*shì*) oracles (*yì*).
Originally also written as *"liù táo"* (六韬), referring to Tàigōng’s *Six Táos*—*Wén*, *Wǔ*, *Hǔbào*, *Lóngquǎn*—and the six *zhuó*.
*"Lè"* (乐) pronounced *luò* (洛).

*"Yàn"* (鴳) is pronounced *jiàn* (谏) with the reading *yì* (谏) reversed.

**[Section Four] [Commentary]**
Serving the martial lord (武侯) with utmost loyalty and integrity, one might offer counsel or dissent—yet even so, one’s merits would stand out. Such devoted ministers are countless, yet my lord has never once opened his mouth to utter even the faintest smile (微笑).

Now, what art (術) do you possess, Master, to bring such joy (欢说) to my lord?

**[Release Text]**
*"Wújūn yuè"* (吾君说) is pronounced *yuè* (悦).

**[Collation]**
The character *yì* (谶) is corrected according to the *Release Text*’s original form.

Xú Wúguǐ (徐无鬼) said: *"I merely told my lord of the dogs and horses."*

**[Commentary]**
Medicine has no rank—what heals the ailment is good. Thus, he simply told the lord of the dogs and horses, with no further embellishment.

Nǚ Shāng (女商) said: *"Is that so?"*

**[Commentary]**
Does he mean to say that he directly told the lord of the dogs and horses? He finds this art too shallow and thus asks in wonder.

He replied: *"Have you not heard of the exiles from Yue?*
After a few days away, they rejoice at seeing those they know;
After a month or two, they rejoice at seeing those they once saw in their homeland;
And when a year has passed, they rejoice at seeing even those who resemble people—
Is it not that the longer they are separated, the deeper their longing grows?

Those who flee into empty voids (虚空), clinging to the narrow paths of *lǐliè* (藜藋) and *qúyòu* (鼪鼬), stumble along in their desolation—yet they delight at hearing the faint footsteps of others, and even more so,
When brothers and kinsmen cough and call beside them!

For long has there been none to speak true words (真人之言) and thus provoke the lord’s laughter (謦欬) at his side!"*

---
**Annotations:**
- *武侯* (Wǔhóu): "Martial Lord" (refers to Zhuge Liang, a historical figure)
- *藜藋* (lǐliè): "Wild plants" (symbolizing harsh, barren conditions)
- *鼪鼬* (qúyòu): "Weasels" (narrow, winding paths)
- *謦欬* (qīngkài): "Coughing and calling" (loud, joyous sounds)

「["One"] **Annotation:** Each reflects on what brings them delight in their own nature.
**Commentary:** Those exiled far from home, whether for crimes against the law or unjust governance, leave their native land. Just a few days after their departure, they suddenly encounter an acquaintance—how could they not feel joy and relief at once! This is the first analogy.

**Textual Notes:** *越* (yuè) means "far." Sima [Zhenru] notes that *流人* (liú rén) refers to those who have been exiled for their crimes. *数日* (shǔ rì) is read with a reversed tone for *日*.

["Two"] **Commentary:** As time passes, homesickness intensifies. Though not familiar, they see someone from their homeland—a former acquaintance—and rejoice at the sight.

["Three"] **Annotation:** If one finds what they desire, they cease longing; without longing, they forget why they rejoiced in the first place.
**Commentary:** A year after their exile, the distance grows greater, so they take delight in seeing someone who resembles a fellow villager. Is it not because the longer they are separated from home, the deeper their longing becomes? The Martial Lord, who loved dogs and horses, had long been detached from affairs of state—like those exiled, he suddenly heard laughter and talk, and his spirits lifted. This is the second analogy.

**Textual Notes:** *及期* (jí qī) is pronounced as *基* (jī).」

「**Exegesis:**
The *Fu Tao* ("Escaping") is rendered *xún* ("to patrol") in the *Shiji* version.
*The Xu Kong zhe* ("The Vacant Space")—the *Shiji* explains: "The ruins of old burial mounds, left desolate."
*Lí* ("prickly chaffvine") is pronounced *lì-xī* (力西).
*Hù* ("mallow") is pronounced *tú-diào* (徒吊).
The original text sometimes uses [□] (homophonous with *hù*).
*Zhù* ("blocking") is pronounced *zhú-jǔ* (诛矩), the *Shiji* glossing it as "to obstruct."
*Shēng* ("weasel") is pronounced *shēng* (生) or *xìng* (姓).
*Hú* ("weasel") is pronounced *yóu-jiù* (由救).
*Zhī jìng* ("the path")—the original also uses *jìng* (径), the *Shiji* explaining: "Path, meaning *dào* (Way)." The original also uses *jì* (迹), while the *Yuán Jiā* version uses *dié* (迭), pronounced *yì* (逸). Chu Hong notes: *Dié* is *jì* (迹).
◎ Qingfan notes: *Lí* (prickly chaffvine) is *hāo* (蒿). *Hù* (mallow) is the modern *huì hù* (灰藋). The *Erya* records *bài-shāng hù* (拜商藋), with Guo Pu’s annotation: "Shang hù resembles *lí* (prickly chaffvine)." Both *lí* and *hù* grow in uncultivated lands, towering above men, forcing passage—hence the *Shiji*’s *Zhongni’s Disciples* transmission: "Sorting through prickly chaffvine and mallow." Here, the "path blocked by weasels and weasels" is likewise described as towering.
*Liáng wèi qí kōng* ("the noble in his vacancy")—the *Shiji* explains: *Liáng* (noble) means *liángrén* (良人, "the virtuous man"), referring to the one who patrols the void. *Wèi qí kōng* means "to dwell amid the emptiness." *Liáng* is sometimes written *liàng* (踉), homophonous.
◎ Lu Wenbian notes: Modern script writes *liáng* as *liàng*.
◎ Jia Shìfù notes: In the *Exegesis*, *liáng wèi qí kōng*, the *Shiji* glosses: "The virtuous man, referring to the one who patrols the void." *Liáng* is sometimes written *liàng*. Referencing the *Qiúshuǐ* chapter’s "leaping *liàng* upon the well’s beam," one version uses *tiàoliàng* (跳踉). Pan Anren’s *Shooting Pheasants* ode describes one who "staggered *liàng* and then came leisurely." The *Yùpiàn* defines *liàng* (踉) as "rapid movement." Here, the path of prickly chaffvine, mallow, weasels, and weasels has gaps—one staggers *liàng* within them. The *Shuōwén* defines *qiāng* (跄) as a motion, while *shū* (舒) speech is *qiāngliàng*, and hurried speech is *liàng*. The *Exegesis* errs.
*Qìrán* ("joyfully") is pronounced *gǒu-jù-gōng* (郭巨恭), *lǐ-qū-gōng* (李曲恭), or *qū-yǒng* (曲勇), meaning "startled," or *xú-gǔ-jiāng* (徐苦江), *qú-héng* (袪扃). The *Shiji* glosses it as "a joyful expression." Chu Hong notes: "The sound of a traveler’s footsteps."
*Ér xǐ yǐ* ("and rejoiced")—Li Feng notes: "This illustrates the Martial Lord’s lack of sovereign virtue, confined to defense—though stern in court, it displeased him. Yet when he heard what he longed for, like an exile hearing human voices, how could he not brighten with joy and smile in relief?"
*Qīng* ("laughing") is pronounced *kǔ-dǐng* (苦顶) or *qìng* (罄).
*Kè* ("coughing") is pronounced *kǔ-ài* (苦爱) or *qì* (器).
Li Feng notes: "*Qīngkè* (laughing and coughing) signifies speech and laughter. Even hearing a familiar voice brings great joy—how much more so with kin and loved ones’ laughter!"

**Fourth Annotation:**
This is why he never spoke.

The True Man’s words, by which he won my lord, are natural.
At first, he was delighted to receive them; but with time, he forgot their worth.

**Exegesis:**
The Martial Lord longed to hear of dogs and horses—his exile had lasted long. Like a fugitive, weary from travel, his homesickness deepened. Now, with the True Man’s teachings from the *Six Classics* and the *Taigong’s Military Methods* beside him—laughter and speech—this was not fitting. This unites the previous analogies.

**Exegesis of Text:**
*Jiǔ yǐ fú* ("Long has it been") is pronounced *fú* (扶). This follows the later placement.
**Collation:**
(1) The *Hǎizhāng* version of Zhang Junfang’s text omits *yú* (于) before *jù* (俱), reading as *hù* (乎).
(2) The *Shìdé Táng* version also uses *ér* (而).

When Xu Wúguǐ visited the Martial Lord, the Martial Lord said:
*"Master, you dwell in the mountains and forests, eating *zhú-lì* (橡栗) and weary of *jiū* (韭). You have honored me for long!
Now, are you old? Do you crave the taste of wine and meat? Or is it that I, your lord, have the blessings of the state’s altars?"*

**First Annotation:**
*Gān* (求) means "to seek."
Long dwelling in the mountains, sustaining oneself on vegetables and fruits, aging and weary—would one not seek nourishment to sustain their declining years? Perhaps to inherit virtue and secure the ancestral temples.

**Exegesis of Text:**
*Zhú-lì* ("acorns") is pronounced *shù* (序) or *shí-rǔ* (食汝). The original also uses *zhú-lì* (橡栗).
◎ Qingfan notes: The *Shuōwén* defines *zhú* (橡) as the fruit of *qiú* (栩), stating: "Qiú is *zāo* (□, same as 芓), its fruit is grass-like. (Modernly borrowed as *cǎo* (草), colloquially *zào* (皂).)" Another entry: "Cǎodǒu (草斗), the fruit of *lì* (栎), also called *yàng* (样)." Gao You annotates *Lǚshì Chūnqiū*: "Zhú (橡), *zàodǒu* (皂斗), resembling chestnuts." The *Shiji*’s *Xiàngrú Zhuan* has Yǐng Shào’s annotation: "Lì (栎) is a timber tree." Observing these, *lì* is also called *qiú*, *zāo*, or *cǎi*; its fruit is called *zào* or *yàng*. Thus, *yàng* is the fruit of *cǎi*. The *Shiji*’s annotation here refers to soft acorns, so *cǎi* is also called *yàng*.
The *Shuōwén*’s *yàng* (样) character is now written *zhú* (橡) in transmitted texts. (Note: In the *Shān Mù Piān*, *zhú-lì* (杼栗) appears as *zhú-lì* (芧栗) in the *Xu Wúguǐ Piān*, showing *zhú* (芧), *zāo* (□), and *zhù* (杼) are interchangeable. The *Huáinán Běn Jīng*’s *líng-zhù-zī-bào* (菱杼紾抱) is annotated by Gao: "Zhù (杼) is the fruit of *cǎi* (采)." Wang Yirang states: "Zhù (杼) is watergrass. *Zhù* read as *zhú* (芧), also written *zhù* (苎)." The *Shiji*’s *Xiàngrú Zhuan*’s *Shànglín Fú* has *Jiǎng Zhú Qīngtán* (蒋芧青薠), with Zhāng Yì’s note: "Zhú (芧) is *sānjiān* (三棱)." In the *Wénxuàn*, *zhú* is written *zhù* (苎). Those writing *zhù* use the character, while *zhú* borrows it.
*Jiū* ("scallions") is pronounced *jiǔ* (久). Some later texts incorrectly place [□] beneath it.
◎ Lu Wenbian notes: [□] is the grass radical; [□] beneath is the vulgar *jiū* (韭) character.

The old character □ was originally written as 廾, which is an error; it has now been corrected.

◎ *Yǐ Bīn* (以宾) must be read as *yǐ-rèn* (必刃反). The original was sometimes written as *bīn* (摈). Sima Qian states: "摈 means to abandon." It was also sometimes read as *yǐ-rén* (必人反). Li (likely Li Fan) says: "It means guest or visitor."

◎ *Yù Gān* (欲干), Li says: "干 means to seek."

◎ *Shè-Jì zhī fú yé* (社稷之福邪), Li says: "This refers to offering good counsel and wise plans that can benefit the state and its people."

【校】(1) The character *zāo* (皂) is amended according to Lü Buwei’s *Chūnqiū* annotations. Xu Wúguǐ states: "Xu Wugui, born in poverty and lowly station, never dared to eat or drink the food and meat offered by his lord, but came to serve him." (2)

【疏】Though living in poverty and obscurity, content in mountains and thickets, how could he desire to glut himself with food and drink for mere sustenance? No! He came to labor for his lord. The lord asked: "What is this? Why would you labor for me, your humble servant?" (3)

【疏】Here, *dá* (奚) means "why." The lord inquires about his intentions. The reply is: "I come to labor for your lordship’s virtue and body." (4)

【疏】Since food cravings are insatiable and physical labor exhausts the spirit, he merely seeks to comfort him.

◎ The Wúhòu of the *Bā* (武) asked: "What does *yé* (邪) mean?" (5)

【疏】The lord asks what his words imply.

Xu Wúguǐ replied: "The nourishment of Heaven and Earth is uniform **[1]**, ascending heights cannot be deemed excessive, nor dwelling in the lowly deemed insufficient. Yet your lordship alone is the sovereign of a great state, causing the people of the land to suffer **[2]** in order to feed your ears, eyes, nose, and mouth **[3]**. The Dao **[4]** does not indulge itself without limit **[5]**.

The Dao loves harmony and abhors deceit **[6]**. Deceit is a malady, hence the labor **[7]**. What malady does your lordship possess that you do not recognize? **[8]**

**[1] [Annotation]** He does not claim it for himself but allows it to proceed without restraint.

**[1] [Commentary]** Heaven and Earth are the two fundamental principles, their blessings pervade all beings. In providing sustenance, they are universally impartial, not indulging in excess or luxury for any single entity. These words are Xu Wúguǐ’s admonition to his lord.

**[2] [Annotation]** This is so, contrary to the balance of Heaven and Earth.

**[2] [Commentary]** Ascending to high station as a noble does not mean one should take pleasure in it as if it were endless; dwelling in lowliness as the common folk does not mean one should burden them as if it were insufferable. Yet your lordship alone boasts the might of a great state, causing the people of this land to endure hardship, indulging in the pleasures of color, sound, fragrance, and taste to satiate your ears, eyes, nose, and mouth. This defies the natural order of Heaven and Earth, and I fear your lordship will not take this path.

**[3] [Annotation]** He merely grants it to others.

**[3] [Commentary]** The sage sovereign and the enlightened person treat all beings with equanimity, never excessively craving flavors and tastes for themselves.

**[4] [Annotation]** Harmony is sharing with all things; indulgence is deceit.

**[4] [Commentary]** The enlightened and virtuous seek to align with all things and abhor private excess.

**[5] [Commentary]** Deceit refers to private gain at the expense of righteousness; this is what is meant by malady. Your lordship alone suffers from this malady—how deep is your affliction?

**[Annotation]** *Ji* (几), near.

**[Annotation]** *Chéng* (成), accomplishment; *féi* (伐), conquest.

**[Annotation]** *Biàn* (变), deviation.

**[9] [Annotation]** *Lì* (丽), beautiful; *qiáo* (谯), watchtower.

**[10] [Annotation]** *Zī* (锱), a fine horse; *bān* (坛), altar.

**[11] [Annotation]** *Nì* (逆), contrary.

**[12] [Annotation]** *Qiǎo* (巧), cleverness.

**[13] [Annotation]** *Móu* (谋), strategy.

**[14] [Annotation]** *Zhàn* (战), warfare.

**[Commentary]** If your lordship persists in this course, cultivate sincerity in your heart to respond to the sentiments of Heaven and Earth without provoking discord **[16]**. For if the people perish, how could your lordship still employ the cessation of warfare? **[17]**

**[Commentary]** The appearance of loving the people will only be a facade, for the people will not truly revere it. The practice of righteousness to halt warfare will only incite competition, for the name of righteousness will provoke rivalry. Even if one wishes to cease warfare, how could it be achieved when father and son, ruler and subject, deceive one another with false affections?

**[Commentary]** If you proceed with this path, you will be close to ruining the foundation of *wuwei* **[18]**. The deeds of benevolence and righteousness, the accomplishments of halting arms and refining culture, though their traces may appear, will only lead others to emulate them in falsehood. The harm to the people and the provocation of warfare begin from here.

**[Commentary]** *Ji* (几), near.

**[Commentary]** Benevolence and righteousness, though they have outward forms, will inevitably give rise to further forms. Once the initial traces are established, subsequent actions must follow.

**[Commentary]** When achievements and reputation are attained, contention and rivalry will inevitably arise, leading to conquest and warfare.

**[Commentary]** When one alters laws and deviates from natural order, it will only bring harm to the people, provoking external enemies and fostering more conflicts and wars.

**[Annotation]** *Wuwei* (无为), non-action.

**[Commentary]** The lord of Wú **[19]** asked: "Is this feasible?"

**[Commentary]** *Ji* (几), near.

**[Commentary]** The traces of benevolence, righteousness, and halting arms are already manifest, and others will follow suit, making them instruments of harm. Though your lordship may profess benevolence and righteousness, you are perilously close to hypocrisy.

**[Commentary]** *Ji* (几), near.

**[Commentary]** The lord of Wú **[19]** said: "I have long wished to meet you, Master. I desire to love my people and uphold righteousness while ceasing warfare—is this possible?"

**[Commentary]** *Ji* (几), near.

**[Commentary]** To cultivate the benevolent virtue of loving the people and the righteous act of halting warfare, to refine culture and cease arms—such governance, though its traces may appear, will only be a means for others to emulate in falsehood. Thus, it becomes the very instrument that harms the people and provokes warfare.

**[Commentary]** *Ji* (几), near.

**[Commentary]** The people will merely follow the outward appearance of benevolence and righteousness, not embracing their true essence.

**[Commentary]** Benevolence and righteousness both have outward forms, and thus the initial traces established will inevitably lead to further actions.
