The people are the root of a state—when the root is firm, the state is at peace. One must attend to their nurturing with care, yet must not treat them lightly with idle disturbance. The boundary-keeper understood this Dao.

Thus, he warned Zǐláo.

---
**[Exegesis]**
*Chángwú* [Long Willow]—a place name.
The boundary-keeper, the guardian of the borderlands.
*Zǐláo*—According to Sima [Bian], this is Qín Láo, a disciple of Confucius by the name of Zhāng. Regrettably, scholars have conflated him with Qín Zhāng, a disciple mentioned in *The Family Sayings of Confucius*—a text falsely attributed to King Zǐyōng—and thus misidentified him. Jiā Qú and Zhèng Qóng, in their annotations on the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, took him to be Zhuan Sūn Shī, but Fú Qiàn refuted this, noting that Zǐzhāng was forty years younger than Confucius, who was forty at the time. Zhào Xī, in his *Mencius* commentary, also equated him with Qín Zhāng, citing *The Records of Ritual*’s mention of Zǐzhāng after mourning rites, though this is speculative. The confusion arises from shallow scholarship. The *Han Book of Ancient and Modern Worthies* lists him as Qín Láo, further evidence of textual corruption.

---
*Lǔmǎng*—pronounced *lǔ* (as in *lǔ* "lukewarm").
*Mǎng*—*mògǔ* rhyme, also read as the character itself.
*Mièliè*—like short grass, as Lǐ [Xún] suggests, meaning "unrefined." Guō [Yǎng] elaborates: recklessness and negligence are frivolity, failing to fulfill one’s duty. Sima [Bian] defines *lǔmǎng* as "roughness," referring to shallow plowing and sparse sowing, while *mièliè* means "severing the grass."

---
**[Annotation]**
*Lǔ*—*chūnqiū* rhyme.
*Mǎng*—*cāigǔ* rhyme; the two characters were often paired in antiquity, as seen in *Spring and Autumn Elucidations* ("beginning with roughness, ending in subtlety") and *Balancing Discourses* ("roughly outlining the main topic"). Some later scholars mistakenly altered *mǎng* to *sū*, but this is incorrect.

---
**[Exegesis]**
*Fù*—to plant grain.
*Yùn*—weeding, removing grass.
Shallow plowing and careless weeding lead to meager harvests—this is the consequence of neglect.

---
**[Annotation]**
Diligence in fulfilling one’s duty, the pinnacle of *wu-wei* [non-action].

---
**[Exegesis]**
*Biàn*—to change, refine.
*Qí*—to regulate, harmonize.
*Sōu*—to hoe, cultivate.
Last year’s reckless farming brought famine; this year, he altered his methods—deep plowing, meticulous weeding—so the grain flourished, filling the granaries by year’s end.

---
*Zhuāngzi* heard this and said:

*"Now, when people govern their bodies and regulate their minds, many fall into the boundary-keeper’s error—
suppressing their nature, severing their essence, extinguishing their feelings, and losing their spirit, all to conform to the crowd.
Thus, those who coarsen their nature—
their desires and aversions become like wild reeds and water plants,
sprouting to prop up their forms,
soon overrunning their true selves;
their boundaries collapse, their leaks unchecked—
boils, abscesses, and festering sores arise from internal heat, as does turbid urine and oily discharges."*

「【一】【Commentary】 In the present age, people are superficial and frivolous, indulging their passions and desires without restraint, until they come to govern their bodies and regulate their minds—just as the boundary-keeper does.

Zhuang Zhou heard this and thus expounded upon it.

【二】【Annotation】 The evasion, abandonment, extinction, and loss are all consequences of conforming to the crowd【一】. If each were taken to its utmost【二】, what would there be to fear?

【Commentary】 Those who evade the natural order, scatter their pure and harmonious nature, extinguish their true and genuine feelings, and forsake the Dao/Way of nurturing their spirit—all do so by yielding to external pressures and clinging too heavily to artificial constraints.

【Variant Readings】 *"離其"* (lì qí) reads as *力智反* (lì zhì fǎn). The same below. *"以眾為"* (yǐ zhòng wéi) reads as *如字* (rú zì). Wang Yi says: "The things that can be done by the crowd." Evasion, abandonment, extinction, and loss all stem from conforming to the crowd. Conforming to the crowd is what we call coarsening one’s nature. The Sima edition mistakenly reads this as *伪* (wěi).

【三】【Annotation】 Wild reeds and water plants harm millet and sorghum; desires and aversions injure one’s true nature.

【Commentary】 Wild reeds and water plants are reeds. The heart of desires and aversions often breeds perversity. Just as wild reeds and water plants harm millet and sorghum, so too do desires and aversions injure one’s true nature—all because of reckless superficiality and falsehood, which lead to such outcomes.

【Variant Readings】 *"欲惡"* (yù è) reads as *乌路反* (wū lù fǎn). The same as the annotation. *"之孽"* (zhī niè) reads as *鱼列反* (yú liè fǎn). *"萑"* (huàn) is pronounced as *丸* (wán), akin to reeds. *"苇"* (wéi) reads as *于鬼反* (yú guǐ fǎn), meaning reeds.

【四】【Annotation】 When the body’s supporting structures grow sparse, the spirit and *qi* are harmed.

【Commentary】 Wild reeds (蒹葭, *jiān jiā*), also reeds, begin as mere weeds and can still be easily removed. But once they spread and flourish, they inevitably harm millet and sorghum. Similarly, when the heart of desire first arises, it can still be easily suppressed. But once it grows rampant and deepens, restraint must be applied at the outset. Hence, Laozi says, *"Before its signs appear, it is easy to plan against it."*【Variant Readings】 *"蒹"* (jiān) reads as *古恬反* (gǔ tián fǎn), meaning *薕* (jiān). *"葭"* (jiā) is pronounced as *加* (jiā), also reeds.

◎Yu Yu notes: *"For nature’s sake, wild reeds and wild reeds"* (為性萑苇蒹葭, *wéi xìng huàn wéi jiān jiā*) is a six-character sentence. Guo Xiang’s annotation under *萑苇* (huàn wéi) states, *"Wild reeds harm the crops, desires and aversions injure one’s true nature."* This is a misreading. *"Begin to sprout to prop up my form"* (始萌以扶吾形, *shǐ méng yǐ fú wú xíng*) and *"soon overrun my true nature"* (尋擢吾性, *xún zhuó wú xìng*)—here, *尋* (xún) and *始* (shǐ) are paired in meaning, *xún* signifying "to proceed and follow through." As in the *Han Book’s* "Idols of the Sacred Mountain" (郊祀志), Jin Zhao says: *"Xún* means to follow through in one’s actions."* *"Begin to sprout to prop up my form"* speaks to how their growth initially seems sufficient to support one’s form; *"soon overrun my true nature"* speaks to how, once they have spread for long, they uproot and dominate one’s true nature. Guo Xiang’s annotation under *"扶吾形"* (fú wú xíng) reads, *"When the body’s supporting structures grow sparse, the spirit and *qi* are harmed,"*—this is also a misreading.

【五】【Annotation】 Using desires and aversions to lure one’s nature does not stop at what is proper.

【Commentary】 *Xún* means "to lure," *zhuó* means "to uproot." When one entices the heart with desires and aversions, it inevitably leads to the uprooting of one’s true nature, which does not remain within what is proper.

【六】【Annotation】 This is the retribution for coarsening one’s nature. Therefore, those who cultivate their nature must harmonize its utmost reaches!

」

「【Commentary】 *Kuì-lòu* refers to **cold sores** (lit. "human cold sores"). *Piāo-jū* is **hot toxin-induced swelling** (lit. "floating carbuncles"). *Jie* is also a type of **carbuncle**. *Sōu-gāo* means **leaking of semen/urine** (lit. "dribbling grease").

Indulging in sensory pleasures and drowning in sounds and colors thus leads to **mental confusion, spiritual disarray, and physical debilitation**—*qi* and form grow weak, and diseases erupt indiscriminately, regardless of time or place.

【Exegesis】 *"Bìng kuì"* reads *hui-nèi-fǎn*. Li [Fan] explains *lòu-fā* as: *"When vital *qi* dissipates and leaks—bursting above, draining below—it flows out without restraint."*

*"Piāo"* is also written as *biāo*. Pronounced *xú-fū-miào-fǎn*, *pǐ-zhāo-fǎn*, or *bì-zhāo-fǎn*. *"Jū"* is pronounced *qī-yú-fǎn*. **Pus-filled sores** (*biāo-jū*) refer to diseases where pus oozes from wounds. *"Jiè"* is pronounced *jiè* (as in *jiè* "boundary").

*"Sōu"* is sometimes written as *sōu* (variant *shāo*). Pronounced *suǒ-qiú-fǎn*. **Sīmǎ** explains *"gāo"* as: *"The frothy, fatty white residue that forms on the urine of those suffering from chronic exhaustion."*

All these ailments stem from **excessive desire and greed disrupting one’s true *qi***, failing to cultivate the depth of **plowing and weeding**—yielding no true substance.

*"Bù qí"* is pronounced *cái-xì-fǎn* or read as-is.

【Collation Notes】 (1) The *Shìdé-táng* edition reads *"zhì"* as *"zhì"* (至). (2) The *Zhào Jiànyì* edition reads *"zhì"* as *"zhì"* (致).

**Bó Jǔ**, a student of **Lǎo Dān**, said: *"May I roam the world?"* **[1]**

**[1] Commentary:** *Bó* is a surname; *Jǔ* is a given name. A **Daoist practitioner** and disciple of **Lǎozi**, he sought to **travel the world, observe governance, and discern human nature**.

**[Exegesis]** *"Bó Jǔ"* refers to **a virtuous, Dao-cultivating individual**. **Lǎo Dān** replied: *"Enough! The world remains as it is."**[1]

**[1] Commentary:** **Lǎozi** restrained him, forbidding his journey, declaring that **human nature and affairs differ not from this place**.

Again, **Bó Jǔ** pleaded, and **Lǎo Dān** asked: *"Where would you begin?"* **[1]**

Bó Jǔ, earnest and insistent in his plea, pressed on: *"Where shall I begin my journey?"*
*"I shall begin in Qi."* **[1]**

**[1] Commentary:** Bó Jǔ was a man of Lu, neighboring Qi. Since Qi’s governance was corrupt, he sought to begin there.

Upon arriving in Qi, he encountered a condemned man, bound for execution. He pushed aside the guards and forced the man to lie still, then removed his own formal robes to drape over the prisoner, and wept to heaven, calling out: *"Alas, my child! Alas, my child! The world has great calamities—you alone are first to suffer them, yet they say, ‘Do not steal! Do not kill!’**[2]

Only when honor and shame are established do people see their afflictions**[3]; only when wealth is amassed do they see what they contend for**[4]. Now you have set in motion the very afflictions of others and the very contests of others, driving people to ruin without respite—how could this not come to pass?"**[5]

**[1] Commentary:** Having traveled to Qi to observe its governance, he suddenly saw a condemned man about to be executed. He pushed aside the guards, forced the prisoner into a proper posture, removed his own formal robes, and covered the man’s body.

**[2] Annotation:** The great calamity of murder begins with what follows. If such calamities exist, how can mere prohibitions—‘Do not steal! Do not kill!’—avert them?

**[3] Commentary:** *Li* (離) means to suffer. *Zāi* (菑) means calamity. He called out to heaven, weeping bitterly, lamenting the injustice, hence the repeated *"Alas, my child!"* The crimes of theft and murder are the world’s greatest afflictions—why should this man alone bear them first? The conditions of these calamities are detailed below.

**[4] Alternative Explanation:** The condemned man refers to the officials of the court. They forcefully push one another to assume formal robes, layering oppressive systems upon the people, hence his lament to heaven, revealing how these calamities arise. The pretexts for these traps are laid out in the following passages.

**[5] Annotation (俞樾):** *"Alas, my child! Alas, my child!"* is an exclamatory sigh. In the *Shī Jīng*, *"Glide, my child! My child!"* (绸缪子兮子兮), the *Máo Zhuan* explains: *"Child!"* is a sigh of lament. In *Guān Zǐ*, *"Ah, this!"* (嗟兹乎) is used in the *Xiǎo Chēng Piān*, and the *Shuō Yuàn*’s *Guì Dé Piān* states: *"Ah, this! My ruin is certain!"* All treat *"Ah, this!"* as an exclamatory sigh. Further discussion is in *Jīng Yì Shù Wén*.

「This is rendered *"Alas, my child! Alas, my child!"* (子乎子乎), which carries the same meaning as *"Glide, my child! My child!"* (子兮子兮). The character **子** should be read as *"wū"* (户刀反).

The **释文** does not provide a pronunciation for **子**, having long lost its original meaning. **"哉"** (大菑之条) is read as *"zāi"* (哉), and **"离"** (离之) means *"to lose"* or *"depart from"* (着).

**[3] Commentary (注):** When each person finds what suits them, there is no distinction between honor and disgrace—gain and loss become entangled. Thus, honor and disgrace arise, and those who boast of their so-called disgrace while disdaining their so-called honor are indeed sick. **[Codicil (疏):** Honor lies in the cap and carriage (轩冕), disgrace in execution and humiliation (戮耻). The pursuit of honor and avoidance of disgrace lead to frantic competition—how can this not be a sickness!]

**[4] Commentary (注):** If one considers contentment as true wealth, what would they still strive for?

**[Codicil (疏):** When treasures pile high, the competition to acquire them begins.]

**[5] Commentary (注):** When those above indulge in certain preferences, those below cannot remain content with their proper station.

**[Codicil (疏):** They are rewarded with cap and carriage (轩冕) and entertained with pearls and jade (珠玑), yet this drives all ranks into frantic competition, leaving them exhausted and unceasing. To make them settle into their rightful stations—is this even possible?

The **释文** for **"所好"** (呼报反) reads *"hūbào."* In ancient times, rulers understood that **gain** (得) lay with the people, and **loss** (失) was their own responsibility **[1]**; **uprightness** (正) came from the people, while **wrongdoing** (枉) was their own fault **[2]**. Hence, when their form (one’s proper station) was lost, they would retreat and blame themselves **[3]**.

But now it is not so. They **hide** (匿) their faults while feigning ignorance **[5]**, making great demands yet daring not to punish **[6]**, burdening excessively while unable to bear the consequences **[7]**, and setting distant paths yet failing to reach them **[8]**. When the people see their strength exhausted, they resort to **deception** (伪) **[9]**, and with deception flourishing daily, how can the common folk (士民) avoid it **[10]!**

When strength is insufficient, deception arises; when knowledge is lacking, fraud follows; when wealth is scarce, theft emerges. The acts of theft and robbery—whom should they blame, and how can this be justified **[11]?**

**[1] Commentary (注):** If the ruler does not fail the people, then the people will naturally find what they need.

**[Codicil (疏):** They ascribe success to external forces (物), so they believe gain lies with the people. They accept the ill fortune of the state as their own responsibility, so they believe loss is their own fault.]

**[2] Commentary (注):** If the ruler does not wrong the people, then the people will naturally be upright.

**[Codicil (疏):** Without imposing burdens on the people, uprightness lies with them. When the ruler takes responsibility for his own mistakes and blames himself, wrongdoing is his own fault.]

**[3] Commentary (注):** How does one’s proper form (形性) come to be lost? It is all because the ruler distorts it, leading to such calamities. Hence, they blame themselves **[1]**.

**[Codicil (疏):** People are born with different endowments (受气不同), and their natural capacities (禀分) vary. If each is assigned tasks according to their abilities, all will find their proper place. But if one thing is mismanaged, and its form or nature is impaired, the ruler should take responsibility, retreat, and blame himself. In ancient times, **Yīn Shāng** (殷汤) cut his own hair in penance, and rain fell for a thousand *lǐ*—this is an example.]

**[Codicil (疏) for [4]:** The steps of governance differ with each age, and the clarity of virtue (浇淳) varies with the times. Thus, today’s rulers do not manage affairs as they once did.]

**[5] Commentary (注):** To **hide** (匿) is to invert its nature; to **reveal** (显) is to use its nature. Hence, when one is exposed by external forces, they will all recognize it.

**[Codicil (疏):** The laws and decrees they enact all invert the natural order (物性), concealing faults while making the people ignorant and unable to discern. Thus, the multitude of crimes arises. The **释文** for **"匿"** (女力反) reads *"nǔlì,"* and **"为物而愚"** (一本作遇) was originally written as *"yù"* (遇).

◎ **俞樾** notes: Below, it says *"great for difficulties while daring not to punish"* (大为难而罪不敢), *"heavy burdens yet unable to bear the consequences"* (重为任而罚不胜), and *"distant paths yet failing to reach them"* (远其涂而诛不至). Here, **"罪"**, **"罚"**, and **"诛"** all refer to **inflicting punishment** (加之以刑). But this passage uses **"愚"** (愚), which does not align with the rest. The **释文** states: **"愚"** (愚) was originally written as **"遇"** (遇). **"遇"** likely stems from a misreading of **"过"** (过). The **Guǎng Yǎ** (广雅) explains **"过"** as **"blame"** (责). They blame the people for their ignorance—this is called **"过不识"** (overblaming ignorance). The **Lǚ Lǜn** (吕览) *Shì Wēi Piān* (适威篇) states: *"To impose burdens as instruction while overblaming ignorance, to issue frequent commands while disapproving of non-compliance, to create grave dangers while daring not to punish—these are the ways of the ruler."* This aligns with the passage’s meaning, but it correctly reads **"过不识"** (overblaming ignorance). **Gāo Yù** (高诱) interprets **"过"** as **"blame"** (责), which supports correcting this text’s error. **"过"** was mistakenly written as **"遇"**, then further altered to **"愚"**.

◎ **Qìng Fān** (庆藩) notes that **"愚"** (愚) and **"遇"** (遇) were interchangeable in ancient times. In the **Yàn Zǐ Chūn Qiū** (晏子春秋), *"Yàn Zǐ"* (晏子) used **"遇"** (遇) in *"to debauch and deceive the people"* (淫愚民), while **Mò Zǐ** (墨子) used **"遇"** (遇) in *"to deceive"* (愚). In the **Hán Zǐ** (韩子) *Nán Miàn Piān* (南面篇), **"遇"** (遇) refers to *"the lazy and indolent people"* (赣寙惰之民), and in the **Sòng Gān Dào Běn** (宋干道本), **"遇"** (遇) was used instead of **"愚"**. In the **Qín Cè** (秦策), *"deceived and confused"* (愚惑) is equated with *"the hearts of criminals"* (与罪人同心), and in the **Mào Běn** (姚本), **"遇"** (遇) was used instead of **"愚"**. Previously, it was thought that following the **释文**’s reading of **"遇"** (遇) was more plausible, but now **俞 Shì** (俞氏) argues that **"过"** (过) was the original character, making his explanation more refined. The characters **"过"** and **"遇"** were often confused in ancient texts due to their similar forms. In this book’s *Yú Fǔ Piān* (渔父篇), *"Today, I have been blamed"* (丘得过也) is recorded, with the **释文** noting that **"过"** (过) could also be written as **"遇"** (遇). In the *Ràng Wáng Piān* (让王篇), *"the ruler’s fault"* (君过) was written as **"遇"** (遇) in the original text. This confirms the mutual misreading of these two characters. **"不识"** (不识) means to **ignore** the natural order while forcing the people to recognize it.**

**[6] Commentary (注):** When one is easily swayed by external forces, they will all dare to act.

**[Codicil (疏):** Since laws are difficult to establish and enforcement is not straightforward, those who firmly violate them are punished. The **释文** for **"大为难而罪不敢"** (王云) reads: *"All that the ruler imposes must conform to what the people can bear; otherwise, they will find it difficult and dare not obey. But if he makes great demands that exceed their capacity, and they cannot fulfill them, then he punishes them for their disobedience."* **"所易"** (以豉反) is read as *"suǒyì"* (所易).**

**[7] Commentary (注):** When one lightens their burdens, they will all be able to bear them.

**[释文 for "不胜" (音升):** The pronunciation is *"shēng"* (升). The commentary remains the same.]**

**[8] Commentary (注):** When one aligns demands with the people’s strength and capacity, they will all reach their goals.**

---

**[Commentary (疏)]** When one’s strength is weak yet the tasks are heavy, demanding what cannot be borne, or when the journey is long yet the deadline is tight, punishing those who arrive late—these are all unjust.

**[9] Commentary (注):** [The people act thus] to avoid execution and punishment.

**[Commentary (疏)]** When wisdom and strength are exhausted, one cannot escape punishment, and fearing punishment, they resort to deceit.

**[释文 for "民知" (音智):** Pronounced *"zhì"* (智). The same below.]

**[10] Commentary (注):** If the ruler daily fosters deceit, how can the common people ever attain truth?

**[Commentary (疏)]** The winds of deceit arise daily, and falsehoods proliferate like weeds—where then can truth be found?

**[11] Commentary (注):** Blame should lie with the ruler.

**[Commentary (疏)]** When one’s knowledge and strength are exhausted, deceit must arise; when taxes and levies grow more urgent, greed and theft inevitably follow—all stemming from the ruler’s lack of **virtue**, whose laws and decrees only multiply. If the ruler could forget personal affection, abandon private gain, and disregard treasures, then blame should rest with the sovereign—why punish the common people?

**[Collation (校)]**
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s annotated text adds *"yě"* (也) after *"zé"* (责).

---

Schu (蘧) Boyu (伯玉), surnamed **Schu** (蘧), named **Yuan** (瑗), styled **Boyu** (伯玉), was a virtuous and eminent minister of **Wei** (卫). His **virtue** was profound and luminous, penetrating the void of principle, so he could renew with the sun and transform with each year.

**[释文 for "蘧" (其居反):** Pronounced *"qú"* (居).]

**[1] Commentary (注):** He could adapt to the world without clinging to rigid distinctions of self and other.

**[Commentary (疏)]** At sixty years of age, he had undergone sixty transformations. Never did he begin by affirming something only to later reject it as false, nor did he know the so-called *"is"* and *"non-is"* of fifty-nine years prior.

**[2] Commentary (注):** He followed the natural flow of things, and their transformations unfolded thus.

**[释文 for "诎" (起勿反):** Pronounced *"qū"* (勿). *Guangya* (广雅) defines it as *"curved."* Guo (郭) pronounces it *"chù"* (黜).]

**[Commentary (疏)]** In the first year of his office, he affirmed something as *"is,"* but by year’s end, he rejected it as *"non-is."* Within a single year, *"is"* became *"non-is,"* so what was initially affirmed was later deemed false.

**[3] Commentary (注):** The transformations of things have no fixed end.

**[Commentary (疏)]** Thus, when change brings renewal, the new is *"is,"* and when the old fades, it becomes *"non-is."* Therefore, last year’s *"non-is"* becomes this year’s *"is,"* and this year’s *"is"* will be next year’s *"non-is."* To cling to *"is"* or *"non-is,"* to fixate on the new while rejecting the old—this is the flow of inversion. Hence, the **Container-Cheng** (容成) School said, *"Without days, there are no years,"* and **Schu Yuan** (蘧瑗) understood this, thus transforming with things.

**[4] Commentary (注):** Things have no roots or origins, no doors or openings—suddenly arising naturally, so none can perceive their source or trace their emergence. Only those who transcend birth and death can glimpse their origins and measure their roots.

**[Commentary (疏)]** Things arise with change, yet their birth has no root; they emerge through transformation, yet their appearance has no gateway. If there are no roots or doors, then there is no birth or emergence. If birth and emergence lack form, how can years be compared to them?

**[5] Commentary (注):** What I do not know, others may know. Thus, relying on the knowledge of things, one knows all; but relying solely on one’s own knowledge, one knows very little. Now, if one does not depend on things to know and instead exalts one’s own [limited] knowledge, then things will not inform you—how can this not be called great doubt?

**[Commentary (疏)]** What one knows is conventional knowledge; what one does not know is true knowledge. Common people revere discriminative knowledge, sharpening their emotions to accept or reject, yet they fail to rely on their [discriminative] *ignorance* to illuminate true principle—truly, they are people of great confusion.

**[6] Commentary (注):** Unable to utilize others, one has nowhere to take refuge.

**[Commentary (疏)]** *"Yǐ"* (已) means *"to stop."* Those who sharpen their emotions to accept or reject, failing to *[know]* rest, will inevitably encounter calamity and have no place to escape.

**[7] Commentary (注):** Those who claim *"this is so"* may not be affirmed by the world.

**[Commentary (疏)]** Each affirms what they affirm, each approves what they approve—self and other stand opposed, yet who is right and who is wrong?

**[释文 for "然与" (音余):** Pronounced *"rán yú"* (余), or as written. *"然乎"* (然乎) means *"is this truly so?"*

**[Collation (校)]**
(1) The *Shide Tang* (世德堂) edition adds *"zé"* (则) after this passage.
(2) The *Shide Tang* edition reads *"qí"* (其) instead of *"shèn"* (甚).
(3) The character *"qí"* (其) is supplemented from the *Shide Tang* edition.
(4) *"Bùzhī"* (不知) is corrected according to the main text.

Confucius inquired of the Grand Historian **Dàshǐ Dàzhuó**, as well as **Bó Chángqiān** and **Xī Wéi** [1], saying:

*"The Duke Ling of Wei indulges in drinking and revelry, yet does not attend to the governance of his state; he hunts with great nets and snares, yet does not respond to the affairs among the feudal lords. How is it that he is called ‘Ling’ [2]?"*

[1]
**[Commentary (疏)]** *Tàishǐ* is an official title. The three names below are those of the historians. The matters he inquires about are listed in the following text.
**[Phonetic Gloss (释文)]** *Dàshǐ* is pronounced *tài*. *Dàzhuó* is pronounced with the sound of "吐刀" (túdiāo, reversed), a personal name. *Bó Chángqiān* is pronounced with the sound of "起虔" (qǐqián, reversed), a personal name. *Xī* is also written as *qí* (同), pronounced *xū* (虚岂) or *xī* (希); Guo pronounces it *jì* (郗), Li pronounces it *xī* (熙). *Wéi* is pronounced as follows: Li says that *Xī Wéi* is the name of the Grand Historian.

[2]
**[Commentary (疏)]** *Bì* refers to a large net; *yì* means to shoot with a bowstring and arrow. A degenerate ruler, lost in licentious music and fond of drink, pursues hunting of birds and beasts, neglects state affairs, and does not attend to alliances and diplomatic exchanges among the feudal lords. You historians must determine his posthumous title—he lacks the Way to such an extent, why is he titled ‘Ling’?
**[Phonetic Gloss (释文)]** *Zhàn* (湛) is pronounced *dīnán* (丁南), meaning prolonged enjoyment. Li pronounces *yín* (淫) as *chángyín* (常淫). *Lè* (乐) is pronounced *luò* (洛). *Bù yìng* (不应) means failing to respond appropriately. *Zhūhóu zhī jiè* (诸侯之际) refers to matters of alliances and diplomacy; Sima says: *"affairs of covenants and assemblies."*

**Dàzhuó** replied: *"This is indeed the reason for it."* [1]

「**[1] [Annotation]** *Líng* is indeed the posthumous title for one who lacks the Way.

**[Commentary]** According to the *Zhōu Gōng* system of posthumous titles: *"To act in chaos without harm is called *líng*."* Thus, *líng* is the title for one who lacks the Way. Here, it is because of his lack of the Way that he is titled *Líng*, hence the saying: *"This is indeed the reason for it."*

Bó Chángqiān remarked: *"The Duke Líng had three wives who bathed together in the same tub. The historian Shǐ, as a minister of virtue, was summoned to attend them, and though offered silk and escorted with deference, he was not allowed to complete the ritual. Such was his arrogance—yet when he saw a virtuous man, he treated him with such reverence! This is why he was called Duke Líng."*

**[1] [Annotation]** Men and women bathing together—this is a violation of propriety.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Tóng lán* (同滥) is pronounced *xú hū zàn* (徐胡暂) or *lì zàn* (力暂), meaning a bathing vessel.

**[2] [Annotation]** Though he honored him as a virtuous man, the labor of attending to him was burdensome, so he seized the silk offerings and escorted him with exaggerated deference, preventing him from completing the ritual. This was how he showed reverence for the virtuous.

*Bì* (币) refers to the silk given to attendants.

**[Commentary]** *Lán* is a bathing vessel. Shǐ (史), with the courtesy name Yú, was a virtuous high minister of Wèi. *Bì* (币) means silk.

Additionally, the system of posthumous titles states: *"The clarity of virtue is called *líng*."* When men and women bathed together and a virtuous minister was summoned to attend, the Duke Líng, upon seeing Shǐ Yú—his loyal minister—felt deep shame and awe. He sent attendants to seize the silk offerings and escort him with exaggerated deference, ensuring he was sent away before completing the ritual. To treat the virtuous with such respect is the mark of an enlightened ruler, hence the title *Líng*—a title of virtue, not degeneracy.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Shǐ* (史) is pronounced *qiū* (秋). Sīmǎ [Zhū] says: *"This refers to Shǐ Yú."*»

「The *So Bó* [is pronounced] *Bó* [博].

The *Bì* [弊]—Guō [郭] renders it as *Bì* [币], meaning silk—was reversed by Xú Fúshì [徐扶世]. Sīmǎ [司马] pronounces it *Bì* [蔽], saying: *"He drew his garments to cover himself."* ◎Lú Wénbiàn [卢文弨] remarks: *"The text now reads *Bì* [币]."*

*"While exulting in virtue"*—Sīmǎ [司马] explains: *"It refers to the Duke Líng and the bathing women supporting each other in mutual concealment."* This interpretation differs markedly from Guō’s [郭].

**[Commentary]** *Líng* [灵] has two meanings: *(1) it signifies* **enlightenment** *(and)* *(2)* **virtue**—it can also be deemed good**, hence Zhòngní [仲尼] inquired about it.

**[Citation]** *"When men and women bathed together, the Duke’s arrogance and negligence reached their peak. Suddenly seeing a virtuous man, he was instantly filled with reverence and solemnity, thus deserving the title of *Líng*—an enlightened ruler."*

**[Correction]** *(1) The* *Zhāng Jūnfáng* [张君房] *copy mistakenly renders* *Lán* [滥] *as* *Jiàn* [槛].
*(2) The character* *Yì* [亦] *is corrected according to* *Fù Sòng* [覆宋] *copy and* *Wáng Shùjìn* [王叔岷] *’s explanation.*

*Wéi* [狶] *yǔ* *Chángqiān* [常骞], *Wéi* [卫] *Zhuānggōng* [庄公], whose name was *Kuō Luò* [蒯瞶], said: *"When Línggōng [灵公] died, we divined his burial at his ancestral tomb—it was unlucky. We divined his burial at Shāqiū [沙丘]—it was lucky. Digging several *rèn* [仞] deep, we uncovered a stone coffin, which we washed and examined. An inscription was found upon it, reading: *'Not relying upon his son, Línggōng seized this place to bury himself.'* Línggōng’s virtue was long established—what need had he of these two men to recognize it!"*

**[Explanation]** *Zǐ* [子] refers to *Kuō Luò* [蒯瞶]. It means Línggōng was not depending on his son to secure this burial site. All things have their predetermined fate, so events can be foreseen. Thus, whatever one does, one **must** do; whatever one does not do, one **cannot** do. Yet fools believe it lies within their own power—is this not delusion!

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Ancestral tomb"*—one copy reads *"great tomb"* [大墓].
*Shāqiū* [沙丘] is a place name.
*"Digging"*—its pronunciation is *qū* [掘之] with *yù* [月] tone, or *wù* [勿] tone.
*"Several"*—its pronunciation is *shù* [数仞] with *zhǔ* [主] tone.
*"Washing"*—its pronunciation is *xǐ* [洗而] with *lǐ* [礼] tone.
*"Not relying"*—pronounced *bù píng* [不凭].
*"His son"*—Guō [郭] reads it as an abrupt sentence. Sīmǎ [司马], taking *zǐ* [子] as an abrupt sentence, says: *"It means his descendants were insufficient to depend upon, so he took this place as his tomb."* ◎Jiāshì Fù [家世父] remarks: *"Guō Xiàng’s [郭象] annotation, that* *zǐ* [子] *refers to* *Kuō Luò* [蒯瞶], *is incorrect. The stone coffin had an inscription, indicating that the ancient burial practice was to say that descendants would be unable to uphold and preserve the tomb, and Línggōng seized it for himself."* The *Shìwén* [释文] also reads *"seized to bury himself"* [夺而埋之], which aligns with this.

*"Seized and buried"*—*ér* [而] means *"you"* (addressing the son). *Lǐ* [里] means *"residence"* or *"burial place."* One copy reads *"seized to bury himself"* [夺而埋之].
*Kuō* [蒯] is pronounced *qǐ* [起] with *guài* [怪] tone.
*Luò* [瞶] is pronounced *wǔ* [五] with *guài* [怪] tone—*Kuō Luò* [蒯瞶] was the name of *Wèi Zhuānggōng* [卫庄公].
*"His burial place"*—pronounced *rǔ* [汝] with *chàng* [昌] tone below.

**[Commentary]** *Shāqiū* [沙丘] is a place name, located north of the *Méngjīn* [盟津] River. *Zǐ* [子] refers to *Kuō Luò* [蒯瞶]. To clarify that all posthumous titles and names are determined before their signs manifest, and not contingent on external circumstances, the stone coffin at *Shāqiū* [沙丘] had its inscription beforehand. Could Línggōng have relied on *Kuō Luò* [蒯瞶] to seize the burial site? *Shǐ* [史] and *Chángqiān* [常骞]—how could they possibly recognize such matters!

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"To recognize"*—pronounced *shí* [识] with *xiàn* [贤] tone.

**[Correction]** *(1) Zhào Jiànyì* [赵谏议] *copy reads* *"seized to bury"* [埋].
*Shǎozhī* [少知] *questioned* *Dà* [大] *Gōng Tiáo* [公调], saying: *"What is meant by* **‘homely burial’** [丘里之言]?"*

**[Explanation]** *Shǎozhī* [少知] was a man of limited wisdom. *Tài* [太] means *great*, and *gōng* [公] means *proper* or *correct*.

The **Dao/Way** is vast and boundless, its **virtue/power** untainted by partiality, yet it harmonizes all things without strain. Hence, it is called **Tài Gōng Tiáo** [太公调].

If two persons were to debate its principles:

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *"Tài Gōng"*—pronounced *tài* [泰].

**[Correction]** *(1) Zhào Jiànyì* [赵谏议] *copy reads* *"Tài"* [太]. Followed below.

**Tài Gōng Tiáo** [太公调] would say: *"‘Homely burial’ refers to the blending of ten lineages and a hundred names to establish custom—uniting differences to create uniformity, yet dispersing uniformity to reveal new distinctions. Just as we point to the hundred parts of a horse yet cannot grasp the horse itself, yet when the horse is tethered before us, we name its hundred forms and call it ‘horse.’ Thus, hills and mountains amass lowly earth and stone to become lofty; rivers and seas converge countless streams to become vast. Great persons unite all to achieve **virtue/power** without partiality.

Therefore, those who teach from without have authority yet do not constrain; those who act from within have correctness yet do not oppose. The four seasons vary in their *qi*, yet since Heaven does not bestow them, the years are fulfilled; the five officials differ in their duties, yet since the ruler does not favor them, the realm is governed. When the **virtue/power** of the sage does not bestow, then **virtue/power** is complete; when all things differ in their *dharma* yet the Dao/Way does not favor, then there is no name. Without name, there is no action; without action, there is no lack of action. Time has its end and beginning, the world its transformations. Misfortune and fortune flow pure and unceasing, yet what seems contrary may also be fitting; self-sacrifice takes varied forms, yet what is corrected may also be misaligned.

Compare it to the great marsh: all materials cross it without hindrance; observe it in the great mountain: wood and stone alike ascend its heights. This is what is meant by **‘homely burial’** [丘里之言]."*

**[Explanation]** *(1) "Blending"*—it takes the ten lineages (each lineage ten persons) and a hundred names (each lineage ten persons), combining them to establish custom. *(2) "Homely burial"*—like the ancient practice of gathering the customs of villages and neighborhoods (ten families as a *qiū* [丘], twenty as a *lǐ* [里]), where local traditions varied, yet through debate, distinctions were clarified. *(3) "Great persons unite all"*—without partiality toward the world, the world’s customs align. *(4) "Reside in authority yet do not constrain"*—the sage’s teachings enter from without yet adapt to circumstances, so authority is held without rigid enforcement. *(5) "Act from within yet do not oppose"*—from within, the nature of all things emerges, each finding its proper place, so there is no resistance. *(6) "Years are fulfilled"*—*suìchéng* [岁成], lit. "yearly completion," meaning the seasons proceed naturally. *(7) "Realm is governed"*—*guózhì* [国治], lit. "state governed," with *zhì* [治] pronounced *lì* [吏]. *(8) "When the **virtue/power** of the sage does not bestow"*—the sage’s **virtue/power** is inherent, not granted; if it were bestowed, it would sometimes fail. *(9) "What is corrected may also be misaligned"*—though some acts align with the Dao/Way, others may diverge. *(10) "All materials cross it"*—*bǎi cái jiē dù* [百材皆度], meaning all things traverse the marsh without obstruction. *(11) "Ascend its heights"*—*mùshí tóng tán* [木石同坛], wood and stone alike reach the same heights.

**(10) [注]** Names halt at reality, hence **non-action**; reality each fulfills itself, hence **nothing is left undone**.
**[疏]** Merit belongs to things themselves, thus it is **non-action**; yet without clinging to this **non-action**, there is **nothing left undone**.

**(11) [注]** Hence, the **heartless** aligns naturally.
**[疏]** *Times* refers to the four seasons in orderly succession. *World* refers to human affairs, ever-shifting and unstable.

**(12) [注]** Flowing and returning in cycles.
**[疏]** *Chúnchún* [淳淳]—the image of flowing motion. Heaven’s seasons of cold and heat ebb and flow without constancy; human fortunes of calamity and blessing—how could they endure long? Hence the ancient text says: *"Calamity, oh calamity! It leans upon fortune; fortune, oh fortune! It harbors calamity within."*

**(13) [注]** What is perverse here may be fitting there.
**[疏]** *Fú* [拂]—*lì* [戾], meaning contrary. Things’ inclinations and aversions have no fixed standard; thus what is perverse here may be fitting there. Hence, those who grasp the Dao/Way do not rigidly adhere to what is逆 or顺.

**(14) [注]** Each follows what it deems true, unable to depart from it.
**[疏]** *Shùn* [殉]—to pursue. *Miàn* [面]—to face. Truth and falsehood clash in stubborn adherence; each pursues its own view, their directions diverging.

**(15) [注]** What is correct here may err there.
**[疏]** What is fixed as correct here may be flawed there—this illustrates how things’ natures invert, differing in their inclinations.

**(16) [注]** No talent is discarded.
**[疏]** *Bǐ* [比]—to liken. *Dù* [度]—to measure. Vast marshes and wetlands teem with life; by measuring each talent’s capacity, none are cast aside. The sage’s way of taking things follows this principle too.

**(17) [注]** Uniting differences to form unity.
**[疏]** *Tán* [坛]—foundation. Stones vary in size, wood in thickness; yet gathered upon the great mountain as a base, differences merge into unity.

**(18) [注]** Speak of villages and hamlets, and the world may be understood.
**[疏]** A summation of prior meanings.

---
**Minor’s Question:** *"Then calling it the Dao/Way—is that sufficient?"*
**[疏]** To name the Dao/Way by its principle—is this naming sufficient? The question arises to clarify that the supreme Dao/Way transcends naming.

**Great Public’s Response:** *"No. Counting all things, they do not stop at ten thousand, yet we say ‘ten thousand things’—we name the most numerous among them. Heaven and Earth are the greatest of forms; yin and yang, the greatest of qi; the Dao/Way is their universal principle. To name it by its grandeur is acceptable, yet having already named it, how could we compare it further? Such reasoning falls far short—like comparing dogs and horses."*

**(1) [注]** Things with numbers do not even stop at ten thousand; how much less the boundless Dao/Way—could it be measured?
**[疏]** *Qī* [期]—limit. *Hào* [号]—speak of. Formed things are infinite; yet people limit them as ‘ten thousand things,’ speaking of the greatest general case. Likewise, the Dao/Way’s subtle principle is nameless in origin, yet by its function, it is forcibly named *Dao*—yet this naming is insufficient to grasp its essence.

**(2) [注]** Things attain harmony through it; it harmonizes all without partiality, yet we forcibly label it *Dao*.
**[疏]** Heaven covers, Earth bears; yin and yang nurture life—these are the greatest among forms and qi. The Dao/Way harmonizes all things, nurtures life without bias, hence it is called *public* [公].

**(3) [注]** This is the *Dao/Way that can be spoken of*.
**[疏]** The great harmony gives rise to all things, generating life in myriad forms. Speaking of its origin, it is truly nameless; yet by its function, we name it *Dao*—and this naming, though inadequate, is acceptable.

**(4) [注]** Having already named it, how could we further compare it to anything?
**[疏]** By its function, the name *Dao* already exists; we cannot compare this named principle to the nameless essence.

「By such comparisons, we stray far from the mark. **[5] [注]** Since there is no debate over its name, it falls short of the distant truth; thus, the *Dao* is said to remain insufficient. Only when it reaches the realm of the *nameless* and *unspeakable* can it attain its fullness—though named, nothing can be compared to it. **[疏]** Even when comparing only to beasts like dogs and horses, there is not only a difference in size but also in rank and worth. Now, to compare the *named Dao* to the *nameless principle*, there is not only a distinction between coarse and subtle, but also between deep and shallow—thus, it falls short of the distant truth.

**[校]** (1) The text is missing; Liu Deyi’s version reads *guang* (广) instead. Minor notes: *“Within the four directions, within the six concourses, from where do all things arise?”* **[1] [注]** Those who ask this may say the *Dao* generates them. **[疏]** Within the six concourses, between Heaven and Earth, how do all living things—both moving and growing—originate? Minor notes asks this to clarify their source. **[释文]** *恶起* (*wùqǐ*) is pronounced *wū* (乌).

The Great Public Harmony responds: *“Yin and yang illuminate, shelter, and regulate each other; the four seasons succeed, generate, and destroy one another **[1]**. Desire, aversion, approach, and avoidance arise from this; mating and union occur naturally **[2]**. Safety and danger transform; calamity and fortune arise; urgency and ease interact; gathering and dispersal take form **[3]**. This is what can be recorded as *name* and *reality*, what can be marked as *subtle* and *refined* **[4]**. Following their sequence, they act in harmony; their operations circulate, exhausting to return, ending to begin anew. This is what things possess **[5]**, what speech can exhaust, what knowledge can reach—the utmost of things **[6]**. Those who perceive the *Dao* do not follow what is discarded, nor trace what arises **[7]**—this is where discussion ceases **[8]**.” **[1] [注]** These are their natural operations, not without origin.**»**

The three luminaries illuminate one another **[1]**, the two *yīng-yáng* [2] alternate in dominance, winds and rains regulate each other, heat and cold succeed one another, spring and summer generate, autumn and winter destroy **[3]**. How could this involve human sentiment or deliberation? It is merely the natural *lǐ* [4] of things.

◎ Yu Yüeh remarked: *"This should be read as ‘harm’."* The *Er Yǎ* ["Explanations of Words"] states: *"‘Swathe’ means to sever."* The *Shìwén* ["Explanations of Texts"] says: *"‘Swathe’—the *Shèrén* [5] version reads ‘harm.’"* Thus, *swathe* and *harm* are anciently interchangeable characters. Sometimes *yīng-yáng* harm each other, sometimes they regulate each other—just as the four seasons succeed, generate, and destroy one another below **[6]**.

**[2]** All these occurrences are what is called *trends and choices* **[7]**, arising from the interplay of *yīng-yáng* and the succession of the four seasons.

**[Citation]** *"Ming"* [8] means to rise; *"yōng"* means constant. When aligned, one approaches and desires; when opposed, one repels and withdraws. It speaks of how things, within the *yīng-yáng* transformations, harbor these emotions and desires, opening and closing in union—this is their constant state.

**[Shìwén Glosses]** *"Desire"* is pronounced *wùlù* [9]. *"Ming"* [10] is pronounced *jūbiǎo* [11]. The same below. Also pronounced *gāo* [12].

「King [Wang Bi] said: *"Gāo"* [17] means lofty; *"jìng"* [18] means forceful, speaking of the swift and vigorous nature of what arises.

**[3]** **[Citation]** The man who encounters *Tài* [19] finds peace; the man who meets *Yōng* [20] faces peril. Peril brings calamity, peace brings blessing; gradualness extends life, haste cuts it short; dispersion leads to death, concentration to life. All these matters stem from the friction of *造化* [21] and are as boundless as the four seasons’ transformations—how could they be confined by human emotions and deliberations?

**[4]** **[Citation]** Beyond this, it reaches the realm of *naturalness*. The workings of naturalness—who can fathom their origins?

**[Citation]** *"Zhì"* [22] means to record. Within the realm of *yīng-yáng*, between heaven and earth, there exists something tangible and named, hence it can be classified and documented. Even if it be subtle and refined, it may still be articulated and recorded; but when it comes to the profound *重玄* [23] Dao, transcending all forms and names, it cannot be sought through words or symbols.

**[5]** **[Citation]** All these phenomena are inherent in things, arising naturally—it is not that there is no power to bring them about.

**[Citation]** The four seasons cycle in turn, regulating and governing one another; the five phases move in succession, driving and restraining each other. When things reach their limits, they turn back; when they conclude, they begin anew. The principles of all things are exhausted here.

**[Shìwén Glosses]** *"Suí xù"* [24] is pronounced *"suìbiǎn"* [25], meaning "to follow and transform in sequence." *Xù* may also be written as *"yuán"* [26] or *"xiǎng"* [27]. *"Qī yùn"* [28] refers to the phases’ sequential transformations, where one phase follows and replaces another in due order, and each phase governs and restrains the next.

**[6]** **[Citation]** Since phenomena have no further limits beyond themselves, it is said that knowledge cannot surpass the study of things.

**[Citation]** The profound Dao is beyond words and comprehension. If one attempts to define it through speech, debate, or thought, one can only reach the limits of tangible things—never attaining the realm of *玄玄* [29].

**[Shìwén Glosses]** *"Suǒ fù"* [30] is pronounced *"fú yòu"* [31].

**[7]** **[Citation]** Both "making" and "not making" arise from this; there is no external cause to follow.

**[8]** **[Citation]** Since all this arises inherently, there is nothing left to debate.

**[Citation]** *"Dǔ"* [32] means to see; *"suí"* [33] means to follow. Those who perceive the Dao, who grasp its profound mystery, focus their essence beyond phenomena, and in stillness, illuminate the cycle. They realize all things are ultimately Dao; the four phases are not fixed. How could they cling to emotions and things, dissecting the origins of "making" and "not making"?

This is what is meant by *"the Dao that cannot be spoken, the arguments that cease."* Shào Zhī asked: *"Does Ji Zhēn’s ‘not making’ or Jiē Zǐ’s ‘sometimes making’ align with true principles? Which view is correct in its essence, which comprehensive in its reasoning?"*

**[1]** **[Citation]** Ji Zhēn said, "The Dao does not act." Jiē Zǐ said, "The Dao sometimes acts." ‘Sometimes acts’ means the Dao has the power to make things arise.

**[Citation]** Ji Zhēn and Jiē Zǐ were both sages of the state of Qí, both studying at the *Jìxià* [34] school. Thus, Shào Zhī invoked the two sages to clarify the Dao. *"Mò"* [35] means ‘nonexistence’; *"huò"* [36] means ‘existence.’ Ji Zhēn held that the Dao is ‘nonexistence,’ while Jiē Zǐ argued that the Dao has the power to make things arise. Each upheld one perspective, yet neither provided a complete explanation. Now Shào Zhī questions this to determine the right and wrong, the correct and the erroneous, in their understanding of the Dao’s true nature and profound principles.

**[Shìwén Glosses]** *"Shì biàn"* [37] is pronounced *"biàn"* [38] or *"biān"* [39] (according to Xú). Dàgōng Diào said: *"The crowing of roosters, the barking of dogs—these are what people know. Even the most enlightened cannot articulate the Dao’s self-so transformation, nor can they grasp what it will bring about. To analyze it thus, the subtleties become boundless, the greatness unfathomable. ‘Sometimes acts’ and ‘does not act’—these are mere speculations, not ultimate truths. The Dao’s essence is boundless and endless; speech cannot capture it, and thought only distances us. What has not yet arisen cannot be avoided; what is already dead cannot be returned. Death and life are not far apart, yet their principles cannot be seen. ‘Sometimes acts’ and ‘does not act’—these are conjectures based on illusion. Observing the Dao’s origin, it extends infinitely; seeking its end, it knows no halt. Infinite and endless, speech cannot grasp it—it aligns with the Dao of things. ‘Sometimes acts’ and ‘does not act’—this is speech about its origin, corresponding with the Dao’s beginning and end. The Dao cannot be possessed, yet to lack possession is impossible. The Dao’s name is a borrowed vessel for its operation."*

「Or it acts, or it does not act—this is but one twist of things, yet how could it suffice for the Great Way?  【一七】
If words alone suffice, then speaking all day would exhaust the Dao;  【一八】
if words alone do not suffice, then speaking all day would exhaust things.  【一九】
At the utmost of Dao and things, words and silence are insufficient to convey it;
neither words nor silence can fully express the principle of its own nature.  【二０】
Non-speech, non-silence—this is where discourse reaches its limit.  【二一」

---
**Annotations (for context, not commentary):**
【一】*[Note]* Things have their own natural course; it is not something that can be willed by action.
Thus, from this perspective, Ji Zhen’s words are correct.

**Exegesis:** The sight of the eyes and the hearing of the ears—chicken crows, dogs bark—these arise from the spontaneous workings of Nature. Both the wise and the foolish recognize them alike.
Thus, even the greatest sage, with all his knowledge, cannot fathom what causes them to crow or bark, nor can he articulate their underlying principles. Their barking and crowing are natural; how could the Dao compel them to do so?
Hence, the view of the *Jiezi* is flawed in reasoning.

**Textual Clarification:** *Brǎi* (吠) is pronounced *fèi* (符废反). *Dàzhī* (大知) is read as *dàzhì* (大智).

---
【二】*[Note]* All things act without being willed, yet they do so of their own accord.

**Exegesis:** Even if we take the subtlest things, which lack discernible order, or the coarsest things, which cannot be measured—applying this reasoning to analyze them, not a single thing exists that does not act naturally on its own.

---
【三】*[Note]* Things have their own natural inclinations, yet all arise without being willed. Thus, "it does not act" is not to say that things do not act.
All things, in this way, are transformed through non-action.

**Exegesis:** If one does not align with the Dao, then one cannot escape the realm of things;
if one clings to one side, then one ultimately falls into error.

---
【四】*[Note]* It is truly self-willed.

**Exegesis:** Clinging to existence is itself the error.

---
【五】*[Note]* There is no willed origin.

**Exegesis:** To drown in non-existence is also an error.

---
【六】*[Note]* Indicating the nature of names and reality.

---
【七】*[Note]* The nature of things is ultimately the utmost emptiness.

**Exegesis:** If one’s mind clings to existence, then everything is seen as things;
if one’s mind clings to non-existence, then everything is seen as emptiness.
Thus, existence and non-existence reside in the mind, not in external reality.

---
【八】*[Note]* Therefore, one must seek it beyond words and thought.

**Exegesis:** That which can be articulated in words or grasped by thought is ever more distant from the Dao.
Thus, one must seek it beyond words and thought.

---
【九】*[Note]* Life suddenly arises; it cannot be controlled by one’s own will, and one cannot prevent it.

【一０】*[Note]* Death suddenly occurs; one cannot defy it.

**Exegesis:** To *prohibit* (忌) is to *restrain* (禁); to *obstruct* (阻) is to *hinder* (碍).
Life suddenly arises—it cannot be restrained or prohibited;
death suddenly occurs—what hindrance or obstruction could there be?
Only by following change and yielding to transformation can one find peace in all circumstances.
Some texts render *阻* as *zhù* (沮), meaning *to lament*.
Death comes in accordance with Nature, so there is no lamentation over loss.

**Textual Clarification:** *Bùkě zǐ* (不可徂) is also written as *bùkě zǔ* (不可阻).」

---

**【校】**
(1) Zhao Jianyi originally translated *徂* (zǐ) as *阻* (zǔ).
(2) The *Shì Dé Táng* edition has "its having" (其有所作) where the original text has "its being" (其有).
(3) Zhao’s edition omits the character *有所* (having).
(4) The character *之* (zhi) is deleted according to the *Shì Dé Táng* edition.

**Volume 9, Upper Section**
*Miscellaneous Chapters on External Things* (外物第二十六)
*Miscellaneous Chapters on Parables* (寓言第二十七)

---

**《外物》第二十六【一】**

**【一】**
**【Text】** The chapter is named by its subject.
External things are not to be trusted **[1]**,**
so Long Feng was executed, Bi Gan was slaughtered, Ji Zi was driven mad, and E Lai died **[2]**.
The sovereign cannot but desire his ministers’ **loyalty**,
yet **loyalty** is not necessarily rewarded **[3]**,**
so Wu Yuan was exiled to the Jiang River,
and Zang Hong died in Shu **[4]**,**
their blood concealed for three years and then transformed into jade **[5]**.

Parents cannot but desire their children’s **filial piety**,
yet **filial piety** is not necessarily loved **[6]**,**
so Xiao Ji died of grief,
and Zeng Shen wept in sorrow **[7]**.

Wood against wood produces friction and heat **[8]**, metal against fire produces melting **[9]**.
When **yin** and **yang** clash in their courses,
the heavens and earth are in great turmoil **[10]**,**
and thus there is thunder and lightning,
fire in the water, and the great huái tree is consumed **[11]**.

There is a sorrow so profound that one is trapped in two disasters and cannot escape **[12]**.
The cicada and the ant cannot reach completion **[13]**.
The heart hangs suspended between heaven and earth **[14]**,**
buried in grief and stagnation **[15]**,**
as **benefit** and **harm** rub against each other,
generating much fire **[16]**.
The common people set the harmonies ablaze **[17]**.
The moon, though constant, cannot withstand fire **[18]**.
Thus, there is a moment of **lamentation** (僓) and the **Dao** is exhausted **[19]**.

**【一】【疏】**
[The heart] is fixed in rigid resolve—this is what is meant by "trust."
Yet between human affairs and things,
there are myriad shifts and threads **[20]**.
Only by aligning with the great **order** (大顺) of Nature
does one attain **emptiness** and **permeation** (虚通) everywhere.
If one opposes things and clings to emotions,
disaster and harm are certain to follow.

**【释文】** In *External Things* (《外物》), Wang Yun says:
*"He who forgets his own self
is naturally without concern for the world,
and thus external things have no need to be trusted.
But if one clings to some fixed view,
then even the **Dao** will never be perfectly attained."*

◎ Lu Wénbián says:
*"The Song edition reads 'trust' (必) instead of 'heart' (心)."*
◎ Qing Fan annotates:
*"The *Wén Xuǎn* commentary on Ji Chūyè’s *Discourse on Nurturing Life* (养生论) quotes Sima [Qian] as saying:
'External things' (物) refers to 'affairs.'
**Loyalty** and **filial piety** are internal [virtues],
yet external affairs are never fully trusted or received."*

*(Translation of 释文 omitted.)*

**【二】【注】**
The consequences of **good** and **evil** are both uncertain.

**【疏】**
Long Feng and Bi Gan are already explained in the *External Things* chapter.
Ji Zi was a younger brother of the Shang tyrant Zhou,
**loyal** in his remonstrance but ignored,
fearing Zhou’s harm, so he feigned madness—
yet he still could not escape execution.
E Lai was Zhou’s flattering minister,
and when Zhou’s fate was sealed,
E Lai shared the same downfall.

**【三】【注】**
[This is the result of] **sincerity** and **devotion** (精诚) to the utmost.

**【疏】**
Jade (碧) is a precious stone.
Wu Yuan and Zang Hong are already explained in the *External Things* chapter.
Yet regarding Wu Yuan’s exile to the Jiang River:
He remonstrated with King Fu Cha of Yue,
but Fu Cha killed him.
Taking horsehide to make a sack,
shaped like an owl (鸱鸟),
he stored Wu Yuan’s body inside,
and floated it upon the Jiang River—
hence, 'exiled to the Jiang River.'
Zang Hong was slandered,
banished and returning to Shu,
where he lamented his **loyalty** leading to slander,
so he slit his abdomen and died.
The people of Shu were moved by his fate,
concealing his blood in a wooden box,
and after three years, it transformed into jade—
this is the **sincerity** and **devotion** to the utmost.

**【释文】**
In *Wu Yuan’s blood concealed for three years* (《藏其血三年》), Lü’s *Spring and Autumn Annals* (《吕氏春秋》) states:
*"His blood was concealed for three years,
and it transformed into jade."*

◎ Qing Fan annotates:
*"The *Taiping Yulan* (八百九) quotes Sima [Qian] as saying:
'Zang Hong was **loyal** yet exiled,
so his blood did not decay and transformed into jade.'"*

*(Translation of 释文 omitted.)*

**【四】【注】**
Thus, the **perfected ones** (至人) have no heart **[21]**,
yet they respond to things **[22]**,**
adapting only to what is fitting.

**【疏】**
Xiao Ji was the son of Shang Gaozong **[23]**.
He suffered from his stepmother’s calamity,
grieving to the point of death.
Yet Zeng Shen was **paragon of filial piety**,
yet his parents hated him,
often beating him to near-death—
hence, his sorrowful weeping.
The bond between father and son is the **order** of Nature,
the tie between ruler and minister is **virtue** of utmost weight,
yet even **loyalty** and **filial piety** of the highest degree
still face rejection and misunderstanding.
How much more so the myriad affairs of the world,
which can truly be trusted or relied upon?
Only by forgetting oneself and things,
adapting to what is fitting,
can one preserve one’s life and avoid harm.

---
**[1] 外物不可必** – External things cannot be relied upon.
**[2] 龙逢诛，比干戮，箕子狂，恶来死，桀纣亡** – Long Feng was executed, Bi Gan was slaughtered, Ji Zi was driven mad, E Lai died, and the tyrants Jie and Zhou perished.
**[3] 忠未必信** – Loyalty is not necessarily rewarded.
**[4] 伍员流于江，苌弘死于蜀** – Wu Yuan was exiled to the Jiang River, and Zang Hong died in Shu.
**[5] 而忠未必信，故伍员流于江，苌弘死于蜀，藏其血三年而化为碧** – Yet loyalty is not necessarily rewarded, so Wu Yuan was exiled to the Jiang River, Zang Hong died in Shu, and their blood was concealed for three years before transforming into jade.
**[6] 孝未必爱** – Filial piety is not necessarily loved.
**[7] 孝己忧而曾参悲** – Xiao Ji died of grief, and Zeng Shen wept in sorrow.
**[8] 木与木相摩则然** – Wood against wood produces friction and heat.
**[9] 金与火相守则流** – Metal against fire produces melting.
**[10] 阴阳错行，则天地大絯** – When yin and yang clash in their courses, the heavens and earth are in great turmoil.
**[11] 于是乎有雷有霆，水中有火，乃焚大槐** – Thus there is thunder and lightning, fire in the water, and the great huái tree is consumed.
**[12] 有甚忧两陷而无所逃** – There is a sorrow so profound that one is trapped in two disasters and cannot escape.
**[13] 螴蜳不得成** – The cicada and the ant cannot reach completion.
**[14] 心若县于天地之间** – The heart hangs suspended between heaven and earth.
**[15] 慰暋（一）沈屯** – Buried in grief and stagnation.
**[16] 利害相摩，生火甚多** – As benefit and harm rub against each other, generating much fire.
**[17] 众人焚和** – The common people set the harmonies ablaze.
**[18] 月固不胜火** – The moon, though constant, cannot withstand fire.
**[19] 于是乎有僓然而道尽** – Thus, there is a moment of lamentation and the Dao is exhausted.
**[20] 参差万绪** – Myriad shifts and threads.
**[21] 至人无心** – The perfected ones have no heart.
**[22] 唯变所适** – Adapting only to what is fitting.
**[23] 孝己，殷高宗之子也** – Xiao Ji was the son of Shang Gaozong.

**[24] 其血不朽而化为碧** – Its blood does not perish but transforms into jade-green.

**[25] 李云：殷高宗之太子** – Master Li says: Xiao Ji was the heir apparent of Shang Gaozong.

**[26] 李云：曾参至孝，为父所憎，尝见绝粮而后苏** – Master Li says: Zeng Can was supremely filial, yet hated by his father, often near starvation before being revived.

**[27] 夫木生火，火克金** – Wood generates fire, and fire conquers metal—this is the natural order of the Five Phases.

**[28] 五行之气，自然之理** – The *qi* of the Five Phases and the inherent principles of nature.

**[29] 故木摩木则火生，火守金则金烁** – Thus, when wood rubs against wood, fire arises; when fire assails metal, it is consumed.

**[30] 是以诚心执固而必于外物者，烁灭之败** – Therefore, those who fix their sincere hearts on external things and rigidly insist upon them will meet ruin through erosion.

**[31] 俞樾曰：淮南子原道篇亦云两木相摩而然** – Master Yu Ye says: The *Huainanzi*’s *Yuan Dao* chapter also states that two pieces of wood rubbed together will ignite.

**[32] 然两木相摩，未见其然** – Yet, when two pieces of wood are rubbed together, their ignition is not observed.

**[33] 下句云金与火相守则流** – The following sentence says that when metal resists fire, it melts.

**[34] 疑此句亦当作木与火** – I suspect this sentence should also read: "wood and fire."

**[35] 下文云，水中有火，乃焚大槐** – Later, it says: "Fire exists within water, which scorches the great huai tree."

**[36] 又云，利害相摩，生火甚多** – It also says: "As benefit and harm rub against each other, generating much fire."

**[37] 众人焚和** – The common people set the harmonies ablaze.

**[38] 月固不胜火** – The moon, though constant, cannot withstand fire.

**[39] 盖木金二物皆畏火** – Indeed, both wood and metal fear fire, hence their mention to illustrate fire’s great harm.

**[40] 故举以为言，见火之为害大也** – Thus, they are cited to show the vast destructive power of fire.

**[41] 所谓错行** – This is what is meant by "errant phases."

**[42] 水中有火，电也** – Fire within water is lightning.

**[43] 乃焚大槐，霹雳也** – It scorches the great huai tree—this is thunder.

**[44] 阴阳错乱，不顺五行** – When yin and yang are disordered, they do not conform to the Five Phases.

**[45] 故雷霆击怒，惊骇万物** – Thus, thunder and lightning strike in wrath, terrifying all things.

**[46] 人乖和气，败损亦然** – When humans defy the *he* of *qi*, their ruin is likewise.

**[47] 《大絯》音骇** – *Dàhuài* is pronounced *huài* (as in "terrify").

**[48] 又音该** – It is also pronounced *gāi*.

**[49] 又胡待反** – And again, *hú dài* (as in "await" but reversed).

**[50] 《水中有火乃焚大槐》司马云，水中有火，谓电也** – Master Sima says of *"Fire exists within water, which scorches the great huai tree"*: "Fire within water" refers to lightning.

**[51] 焚，谓霹雳时烧大树也** – "Scorches" means the burning of great trees during thunder.

**[52] 天地之大用，水火而已矣** – The greatest functions of heaven and earth are water and fire alone.

**[53] 水，阳也，而用阴** – Water is yang in nature, yet its application is yin.

**[54] 火，阴也，而用阳** – Fire is yin in nature, yet its application is yang.

**[55] 人生阴阳之用，喜怒忧乐，爱恶生死** – Humans embody yin and yang in their emotions: joy and anger, sorrow and delight, love and hatred, life and death.

**[56] 相争相靡，犹水火也** – These forces clash and ebb, much like water and fire.

**[57] 两陷者，水火之横溢者也** – "Trapped in two disasters" refers to the overflow of water and fire.

**[58] 螴当作蝀** – *Lú* should be written as *tóng*.

**[59] 尔雅释天：螮蝀，虹也** – The *Er Ya* explains: *"Róng tóng"* is a rainbow.

**[60] 螴蜳，犹言虹蜺** – *Lú tóng* means "rainbow and *niè*."

**[61] 淮南说山训天二气则成虹** – The *Huainanzi*’s *Shuoshān* chapter teaches that two *qi* form a rainbow.

**[62] 二气者，阴阳之相薄者也** – The two *qi* are where yin and yang intermingle.

**[63] 相薄而两相争胜，则虹蜺亦不得成** – When they intermingle and vie for dominance, even rainbows and *niè* cannot manifest.

**[64] 人心水火之争，阳常舒而徐进，阴常惨而暴施** – Human hearts are like the clash of water and fire: yang expands gently and advances slowly, while yin surges violently and erupts abruptly.

**[65] 凡不平于心，皆阴气之发也** – Any imbalance within the heart is the eruption of yin *qi*.

**[66] 故曰生火甚多** – Hence, it is said: "generating much fire."

**[67] 坎为月** – *Kǎn* is the trigram for the moon.

**[68] 月者，水气之精也** – The moon is the refined essence of water *qi*.

**[69] 体阳而用阴也** – Its nature is yang, yet its function is yin.

**[70] 火生而水不能胜之** – When fire arises, water cannot overcome it.

**[71] 所以两陷而无所逃也** – This is why one is trapped in two disasters and cannot escape.

**[72] 苟不能忘形，则随形所遭而陷于忧乐** – If one cannot forget the form, they will fall into sorrow and joy according to what befalls their form.

**[73] 左右无宜也** – No left or right will be fitting.

**[74] 不能虚志而忘形** – Unable to empty their resolve and forget their form.

**[75] 域心执固** – Constrained by the heart, rigidly fixed.

**[76] 是以驰情于荣辱二境** – Thus, they chase their desires through the dual realms of honor and disgrace.

**[77] 陷溺于忧乐二边** – They sink into the dual extremes of sorrow and joy.

**[78] 无处逃形** – With no way to escape their form.

**[79] 心徇有为，高而且远** – The heart submits to worldly striving, lofty and vast.

**[80] 驰情逐物，通乎宇宙** – Chasing desires after things, it permeates the cosmos.

**[81] 遂心则慰喜** – Following the heart brings comfort and delight.

**[82] 乖意则昏闷** – Defying its intent causes confusion and stagnation.

**[83] 遇境则沈溺** – Facing circumstances, one becomes submerged.

**[84] 触物则屯邅** – Encountering things, one is blocked and obstructed.

**[85] 既非清夷，岂是平畅！** – It is neither serene and tranquil nor smooth and unobstructed!

**[86] 夫利者必有害** – For every benefit, there is harm.

**[87] 蝉鹊是也** – As seen with the cicada and the ant.

**[88] 缨缠于利害之间** – Tangled in the web of benefit and harm.

**[89] 内心恒热，故生火多矣** – The inner heart is constantly heated, hence much fire is generated.

**[90] 众人，犹俗人也** – "The common people" are the ordinary folk.

**[91] 不能守分无为** – Unable to uphold their portion and act non-doingly.

**[92] 而每驰心利害** – Yet they always chase their hearts after benefit and harm.

**[93] 内热如火，故烧焰中和之性** – Their inner heat is like fire, thus consuming the harmonious nature of their *qi*.

**[94] 月虽大而光圆** – Though the moon is vast, its light is full and bright.

**[95] 火虽小而明照** – Though fire is small, its light is clear and illuminating.

**[96] 喻志大而多贪，不如小心守分** – It illustrates that a great resolve with many cravings is not as beneficial as a modest heart that upholds its portion.

**[97] 唓然，放任不矜之貌** – *Qióngrán*—the appearance of abandoning all pride and restraint.

**[98] 忘情利害，淡尔不矜** – Forgetting desires for benefit and harm, they are indifferent and without pride.

**[99] 虚玄道理，乃尽于此也** – In the emptiness of profound Dao, it is fully realized here.

「【Exegesis】 *Qióng* is pronounced *tuí* (as in "decay"), or *huái* (as in "embrace"). Guo Xiang says: "It means *to follow* [the natural way]."

【Collation Notes】
(1) The original text mistakenly reads *mì*, corrected according to the *Shìdé Táng* edition. The following exegesis remains consistent.
(2) The *Shìdé Táng* edition reads *zhī* (as in "know") instead of *zhì* (as in "purpose").

Zhuangzi, being impoverished, thus went to borrow grain from the *Jiānhé Hóu* [1].
The *Jiānhé Hóu* said: "Very well. When I receive the tribute from my fiefdom, I will lend you three hundred *jīn* [2]. Will that suffice?"

---
[1] **Exegesis:** *Jiānhé Hóu* refers to *Wéi Wén Hóu*. Zhuangzi, of noble lineage yet indifferent to worldly affairs, his family being destitute, thus came to borrow grain.
**Exegesis of Terms:** *Dài sù* (借粟) is pronounced *tè* (as in "special"), or alternatively *tā dé* (as in "he obtains"). *Jiānhé Hóu* is pronounced *gǔ xián* (as in "ancient official"). The *Shuōyuàn* records this as *Wéi Wén Hóu*.

[2] **Exegesis:** *Nuò* (诺) means "to agree." Copper, iron, and their kinds are all called *jīn* (金), not referring to gold here. He waits until year’s end to receive the taxes, tributes, and fiefs of his people before lending to Zhuangzi.
**Exegesis of Terms:** *Jiāng dài* (将贷) is pronounced *tā dài* (as in "he lends").

Zhuangzi, indignant, flushed with anger, said: "Yesterday, as I came, there was someone calling out from the middle of the road. I looked back and saw a carp in the wheel ruts. I asked it: ‘Carp! What are you doing here?’
It replied: ‘I am a subject of the waves of the Eastern Sea. Do you perhaps have a *dǒu-shēng* (斗升) of water to revive me?’ [1]

Zhuangzi said: ‘Very well. I will travel south to the kings of *Wú* and *Yuè*, divert the waters of the *Xī Jiāng* to welcome you. Will that suffice?’ [2]

The carp, indignant, flushed with anger, said: ‘I have lost my native element, and I have nowhere to be! A *dǒu-shēng* of water would suffice to revive me. Yet you speak thus—it would have been better to seek me early in the dried-fish market!’ [3]"

---
[1] **Exegesis:** A humble servant of the waves, trapped in the wheel ruts—does the lord perhaps have water to save me?
**Exegesis of Terms:** *Ér hū* (而呼) is pronounced *huǒ gù* (as in "fire’s fault"). *Fù* (鲋) is pronounced *fù* (as in "attach"). The *Guǎngyà* says: it is *fèn* (鰿). *Fèn* is pronounced *jì* (as in "track"). *Bō chén* (波臣): Sima Qian says: "It refers to a servant of the surging waves."

[2] **Exegesis:** *Xī Jiāng* is the *Shǔ Jiāng*. Though many rivers flow northward, only the *Shǔ Jiāng* comes from the west, hence called *Xī Jiāng*.
**Exegesis of Terms:** *Jī Xī* (激西) is pronounced *gǔ dí* (as in "ancient enemy").

[3] **Note:** This illustrates that even the most fitting thing, if misapplied, is useless—though grand, it profits nothing.
**Exegesis:** *Suǒ* (索) means "to seek." *Shì* (肆) means "market."

The carp that habitually swims the sea’s waves,
when lost in the surging tides of its usual course,
could be saved by a mere dipper’s worth of water—
yet to rouse the *Xī Jiāng*’s torrent is unseemly.

Since it cannot rescue even for a moment,
better to seek me in the dried-fish market.

This illustrates that in all matters, great or small,
there is a fitting time and opportunity.
If one fails to seize the moment,
even the grandest efforts yield no benefit.

---
**Exegesis of Terms:**
*Ér suǒ* (早索) is pronounced *suǒ bái* (as in "white of the egg").
*Gū yú* (枯鱼) – Li [Fan] says: it means "dried fish."

**Collation Notes:**
(1) The text omits a "say" character after *yóu* (游) in Zhang Junfang’s edition.

---
The Prince of Rèn, fashioning a colossal hook and thick black line,
using five great oxen as bait,
squatted upon Mount Kuàiji,
casting his rod into the Eastern Sea,
fishing daily—yet for a full year, no fish took the hook.

Then a great fish swallowed it, dragging the massive hook downward,
plunging and surging, its scales flashing like white mountains,
the sea roiling, its voice rivaling the gods—
its terror echoed a thousand *lǐ*.

---
When the Prince of Rèn caught this fish,
he cured and salted it, and from the River eastward,
to the northern reaches of Cāngwú,
none could resist its flavor.

Afterward, the clever orators and persuasive scholars
were all astonished and told one another of it.

---
To raise a rod and wait by shallow streams,
to guard a carp—
how difficult to catch a great fish!
To adorn trifling tales before a county magistrate—
how distant from true enlightenment!

Thus, one has never heard of the customs of the Rèn clan,
for their way is far removed from the world’s common path.

---
**Exegesis:**
Rèn – a state’s name; the son of the Rèn lord.
*Jù* (巨) – great.
*Hēi lǘ* (缁) – black line.
*Liè* (犗) – an ox (cf. *jiānniú* 騬牛, *jìniú* 犍牛).
*Wéi èr* (为饵) – bait (lit. "as bait").

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*Rèn gōngzǐ* (任公子) – as characters.
Li [Fan] says: Rèn, a state’s name.
*Dà gōu* (大钩) – originally also written as *diào* (钓).
*Jù hēi* (巨缁) – Sima Qian says: great black line.
*Liè* (犗) – *guǎ qǔ mài* (郭古迈反), meaning "oxen."
Xu [Shen] pronounces it *jiè*.
The *Shuōwén* says: "Oxen of sacrifice."
Sima Qian says: "Oxen of sacrifice."
*Fū* (犍) – *jì yán* (纪言反).

---
*Dūn* (蹲) – *cún* (存).
*Kuài* (会) – *gǔ wài* (古外反).
*Jī* (稽) – *gǔ xī* (古兮反).
Kuàiji – a mountain’s name, now a prefecture.

---
After a year, a great fish took the hook,
dragging it down, plunging with wild haste,
flashing its head and tail, its scales gleaming—
thus the white waves rose like mountains,
the vast waves met the sun.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*Qī nián* (期年) – originally also written as *qī* (期), same pronunciation. *Jī* (基).

「【Cushu】 Named as *Dà gōu* (大钩), yet after a year, no fish was caught.
*Dūn* (蹲) – *jù* (踞), meaning "to sit."
They sat upon the mountain.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*Qī nián* (期年) – originally also written as *qī* (期), same pronunciation. *Jī* (基).

---

When the hook was taken by a great fish,
it dragged the hook down, plunging with wild haste,
flashing its head and tail, its scales gleaming—
thus the white waves rose like mountains,
the vast waves met the sun.

**Exegesis of Terms:**
*Dà yú* (若鱼) – Sima Qian says: a great fish named *Ruò* (若), the sea god.
Others say: *Ruò yú* (若鱼), meaning "this fish."
*Là* (腊) – pronounced *xī* (昔).
*Zhì hé* (制河) – pronounced *shè hé* (设河), should be written as *Zhè hé* (浙河), meaning "to the east of the Zhe River."
The *Han Shu Yìyì* (汉书音义) pronounces it *shì hé* (逝河).
In the north, all waters are called "river" (河), while the Zhe River (浙江) is now in *Yúhàng* (余杭) Commandery,
used by the Later Han as the boundary dividing *Wèihuì* (吴会).
Sima Qian says: the Zhe River (浙江), now in *Kuàijì* (会稽) and *Qiantáng* (钱塘).
◎ *Qìng Fān* (庆藩) notes: The meaning of *zhì* (制) in "to the east of the Zhe River" aligns with the pronunciation *shè* (设),
and the character should be *Zhè* (浙).
Ancient *zhì* (制) shares the same pronunciation as *Zhè* (浙).
In the *Lunyu Yán Yuán* (论语颜渊篇), the *Zheng* (郑) commentary says: "Ru reads *zhé* (折) as *zhì* (制)."
In the *Shu Lü Xíng* (书吕刑), *Mòzǐ Shàng Tóng* (墨子尚同篇), "to make" (制作) is pronounced *zhé* (折).

In the final days of the season’s end,
the people were light and frivolous,
reciting verses and words,
yet neglecting the profound Dao/Way.
When they heard of the great fish,
they were startled and spoke of it among themselves.
The character *qiāng* (轻) is sometimes written as *qiàn* (辁).
*Qiàn* (辁) means "to measure" or "to assess others."
Originally, it was also written as *qú* (軨), meaning "small."
It was also written as *qiāng* (轻).

*Qiàn* (辁) – pronounced *qī quán* (七全) or *zhěn* (砚) *zhuān* (专), also *quán* (权).
Li [Fan] says: *Qiàn* (辁), meaning "to assess others," was originally also written as *qú* (軨).
*Qiàn* (辁) – pronounced *fāng fèng* (方凤), meaning "to recite and explain."

*Lěi* (累) – fine fishing line.
*Niányú* (鲵鲋) – small fish.
With slender poles and fine lines,
hurrying along irrigation ditches,
they might catch *niányú* (鲵鲋),
but never the great fish.

*Jiē* (揭) – pronounced *qí liè* (其列) or *qí yè* (其谒).
*Gān lěi* (竿累) – pronounced *liè bǐ* (劣彼), meaning "unable to match the strength of others."
Originally also written as *lèi* (累).
Sima Qian pronounces it *lún* (纶), meaning "fishing line."
*Zhù* (趣) – originally also written as *qú* (趋), same pronunciation. *Qī shū* (七须).
*Guàn dú* (灌渎) – Sima Qian says: "irrigation ditches."
*Shǒu niányú* (守鲵) – pronounced *wǔ xī* (五兮).
*Fù* (鲋) – pronounced *fù* (附) or *pú* (蒲).
Originally also written as *pú* (蒲).

*Gān* (干) – to seek.
*Xiàn* (县) – to be high or exalted.
Those who adorn minor actions,
boast in speech,
seeking fame and renown—
they shall never grasp the *Dàodé* (至道) of the Dao/Way.

The character *xiàn* (县) is sometimes written as *xuán* (悬).
Ancient *xuán* (悬) often lacked the radical *xīn* (心).

**Zhu** (注):
This speaks of differing aspirations,
thus the suitability for governing the world
varies with the great and the small.

**Cushu:**
Between human affairs in the world,
the Dao/Way is not always smooth or perilous.
Only those with open hearts and boundless understanding
can address chaos and order.
Those who seek fame and adorn their conduct
are far removed from this.

**Jiao** (校):
(1) The character *wù* (骛) follows the *Shì Dé Táng* (世德堂) edition and is corrected.
Zhao (赵) the *Jiàn Yì* (谏议) writes it as *jīng* (惊).
(2) Zhao’s edition writes *zhù* (趣) as *qú* (趋).
