Preyan Child You (颜成子游) said to Dongguo Ziqin (东郭子綦):

*"Since I first heard your words,
**One year** and I became wild **[1]**, **[2]**
**Two years** and I followed **[3]**, **[4]**
**Three years** and I was harmonized **[5]**, **[6]**
**Four years** and I became one with things **[7]**, **[8]**
**Five years** and I returned **[9]**, **[10]**
**Six years** and ghosts entered **[11]**, **[12]**
**Seven years** and Heaven was complete **[13]**, **[14]**
**Eight years** and I knew neither death nor life **[15]**, **[16]**
**Nine years** and I attained Great Mystery **[17]." **[18]**

**[1]** **[Commentary]** Detached from worldly gain. **[19]**
**[2]** **[Explanation]** Dwelling east of the city walls, he was called Dongguo—just as in the *Qíwùpiān* (齐物篇), Southguo Ziqin (南郭子綦). Child You was Ziqin’s disciple. *Wild* means unadorned simplicity. Hearing the Dao in one year, his learning was still raw, yet he began to shed artificiality. **[20]**

**[Annotations]** *Zǐqí* (子綦) pronounced *qí*. **[21]**

**[3]** **[Commentary]** No longer self-possessed. **[22]**
**[4]** **[Explanation]** Aligned with convention. **[23]**

**[5]** **[Commentary]** Unified with self and others. **[24]**
**[6]** **[Explanation]** Unentangled by boundaries. **[25]**

**[7]** **[Commentary]** In harmony with all things. **[26]**
**[8]** **[Explanation]** In harmony with all things. **[27]**

**[9]** **[Commentary]** Self-fulfilled. **[28]**
**[10]** **[Explanation]** Returned to the masses. **[29]**

**[11]** **[Commentary]** Transcended bodily form. **[30]**
**[12]** **[Explanation]** The spirit merges with principle and things. **[31]**

**[13]** **[Commentary]** No further striving. **[32]**
**[14]** **[Explanation]** Naturally complete. **[33]**

**[Annotations]** *Suǒfù* (所复) pronounced *fúyòu*. **[34]**

**[15]** **[Commentary]** All encounters bring ease and rest. **[35]**
**[16]** **[Explanation]** Wisdom fathoms creation, the spirit aligns with nature—thus unaware of life, death, gathering, or scattering. **[36]**

**[17]** **[Commentary]** *Miao* (妙), excellence. Good and evil are one. Thus, nowhere does he fail to penetrate. This speaks of prolonged Dao-hearing, where worldly stains dissolve utterly. **[37]**
**[18]** **[Explanation]** *Miao* (妙), profound subtlety. With time, learning deepens, surpassing the Four Sentences, severing a hundred faults. His understanding reaches the utmost mystery, encompassing all wonders—thus called *Great*. **[38]**

**[Annotations]** *Tiānlài* (天籁) pronounced *lìdài*. **[39]**

Life is artificial; death is natural **[1]**.
I urge the public: though death is natural,
yet life is contrived **[2]**.
And yet—how can this be so?
Where does it find its place?
Where does it not find its place?
Heaven has its cycles; Earth has its occupants.
Where then shall I seek it? **[40]**
Its end is unknown—how then can it lack *ming* (命)? **[41]**

「How can it be said to have *ming* (命) when its beginning is unknown? **[8]**
If there is something to correspond with it, how can it lack *guǐxié* (ghostly evils)? **[9]**
If there is nothing to correspond with it, how can it have *guǐxié* (ghostly evils)? **[10]**

**[1]** **[Annotation]** If life is contrived, it loses its *shēng* (生). **[11]**
**[Exposition]** In the Dao of humans, those immersed in contrivance inevitably return to the path of death and annihilation. **[12]**
**[Pronunciation Note]** *Shēng* (丧) pronounced *xīlàng*. **[13]**

**[2]** **[Annotation]** *Zì* (自), by also. By contrivance, there is death; by clinging to life, there is contrivance. Now, I urge the public because death arises from clinging to life.
**[Exposition]** The public, that is, the common folk. *Zì* (自), by also. What moves people to the brink of death is their private love for life, unable to remain impartial and just. Thus, I exhort them. **[14]**

**[3]** **[Annotation]** Yet life, as the *yáng* (阳) force, abruptly ceases without trace or effort—this is not by any means.
**[Exposition]** Life arises from the *yáng* (阳) qi, yet it comes without origin. Thus, it is not worth clinging to. **[15]**

**[4]** **[Exposition]** *Guǒ* (果), decidedly. The *yáng* (阳) qi gives rise to life—this is decidedly so. **[16]**

**[5]** **[Annotation]** And yet, decidedly so, hence neither finding its place nor not finding its place, and only then is it everywhere fitting.
**[Exposition]** The gathering of qi is life, yet life is not worth delighting in; the scattering of qi is death, yet death is not worth grieving over. If life and death are equal, then sorrow and joy dissolve. Thus, where can one find a fitting place, and where cannot one find a fitting place? It is fitting everywhere. **[17]**
**[Pronunciation Note]** *Wùhū* (恶乎) pronounced *wū*. Same below. **[18]**

**[6]** **[Annotation]** All is already self-sufficient. **[19]**

**[Exposition]**
The stars and their courses, the mysterious patterns arrayed in heaven—
the Nine Regions and Four Quarters, where all beings take their stand.
Within the workings of creation, all is already complete.
Where then must I seek beyond what is already present? **[20]**
**[Pronunciation Note]** *Tian yǒu lì* (天有历) is also written as *tian yǒu lìshù* (天有历数).

**[7] [Annotation]**
The principle must reach its own conclusion; it does not depend on knowledge.
If not by fate, then how?

**[Exposition]**
The rising and setting of heaven and earth, the birth and death of all beings—
trace their origins, and none know their beginning or end.
Fortune comes and fortune goes; if not by fate, then how?
Those who say there is no fate are in truth speaking of fate.

**[8] [Annotation]**
To know not *why* yet accept *that it is so*—this is called fate.
It seems as though there is intent, so the name of fate is discarded
to reveal its self-so nature, and only then is the principle of fate complete.

**[Exposition]**
Death gives way to life, just as spring follows winter and summer follows autumn—
without beginning or end, how could this be fate?
Those who say there is fate are in truth speaking of no fate.
This is again discarding the notion of fate.

**[9] [Annotation]**
The principle must have correspondence, as if some divine agency brings it about.

**[Exposition]**
Ghosts are the lingering *shénzhì* (神识, numinous awareness).
The ears and eyes respond to sound and color;
the mind responds to the world—just as echoes follow their cause,
how could there be no numinous presence?
Those who say there are no ghosts are in truth affirming their existence.

**[10] [Annotation]**
The principle corresponds of its own accord, not due to any external cause—
thus, though there is correspondence, there is no numinous agency.

**[Exposition]**
When a person sleeps, they are unaware of the external world,
though eyes and ears remain—yet they do not respond to color or sound.
If there were a numinous presence, how could they not respond?
Those who say there are ghosts are in truth denying their existence.
This is again discarding the notion of ghosts.

**[Collation Note]**
(1) The text is missing and incorrectly cites Zhang Junfang’s version, which includes the character *sī* (私) below.
The *Wángwàngliǎng* (罔罔两) asks the *Jǐng* (景):
“Why is it that you were once bowed and now stand upright,
that you once bound your hair and now let it loose,
that you once sat and now stand,
that you once walked and now stand still? **[1]**

**[1] [Exposition]**
*Wángwàngliǎng* (罔罔两) is the shadowy *wēiyīn* (微阴, subtle negative force) beyond form.
This is an allegory. *Rú* (若), “you.”
*Fǔ* (俯), to lower one’s head.
*Zhuō* (撮), to bind one’s hair.
Your sitting, rising, walking, and stopping—
your form alone moves as it must.
By measuring this, one sees that form is the sole basis.
It is said that this does not await [external cause],
yet the principle remains unclear.
This question-and-answer is set forth to illuminate *dúhuà* (独化, self-transforming singularity).”

**[Exposition]**
*Jǐng* (景): pronounced as *yǐng* (影), also read as the character itself.
Originally, it may have been written as *yǐng* (影).
◎ **Lu Wénbiàn** (卢文弨) remarks: The character *yǐng* (影) is attributed to Tao Hongjing’s authorship and is not an ancient form.

*Yě kuò* (也括): pronounced *guō* (活反).
Sima [Qian] explains: It means to bind one’s hair.

*Bèifà* (被发): pronounced *jǐ* (皮寄反).

**[Collation]**
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s copy reads *yǐng* (影) for *jǐng* (景), and this is consistent below.
(2) The character *zhuō* (撮) is restored based on Cheng’s commentary and the lacuna-filled citation of Zhang Junfang’s text.

*Jǐng* (景) says:
“Why do you ask further of this *sōusōu* (搜搜) **[1]**
when the movement is of its own accord? **[1]**

I possess what I do not know its source. **[2]**
I am like the cicada’s shed shell, the serpent’s cast skin—
resembling them yet not them. **[3]**

Fire and the sun are my *tún* (屯, stagnation/accumulation);
darkness and night are my *dài* (代, substitution). **[4]**
Is it they that I await? **[5]**
How much more so those who await what is *wú* (無, non-existent)! **[6]**

When they come, I come with them;
when they depart, I depart with them.
When they are strong *yáng* (陽), I am strong *yáng* with them.
What need is there for questioning this strong *yáng*? **[7]”**

**[1] [Annotation]**
Movement occurs naturally; there is no need for further inquiry.

**[Commentary]**
*Sōusōu* (叟叟) is the appearance of motion without intent.
*Deliberate* (奚) means "why."
*Jǐng* replies:
"My motion is without intent, serene and self-sufficient—
I await nothing, spontaneously transforming.
You know nothing; why trouble yourself with questions?"

**[Explanation of Text]**
*Sōusōu* (搜搜) is also written as *sǒu* (叟), same meaning.
*Sōu* (叟) is pronounced *sùkǒu* (素口反), also *sùdāo* (素刀反), or like *xiāo* (萧).
Previously noted: a depiction of motion.

**[2] [Annotation]**
It occurs naturally, so I do not know its source.

**[Commentary]**
*Yú* (予) is "I."
All my actions and stillness follow the natural order—
I know no source, cannot explain their nature.
How could there be anything to await?

**[3] [Annotation]**
A shadow resembles form but is not form itself.

**[Commentary]**
*Tiáojiǎ* (蜩甲) is the cicada’s shed shell.
*Shétuì* (蛇蜕) is the serpent’s cast skin.
The grub transforms into a cicada, the serpent sheds its skin—
neither knows its own change.
The grub perishes before the cicada emerges;
the cicada does not arise *because* of the grub.
The serpent’s skin follows the same principle.
Thus, all things exist without mutual dependence,
each spontaneously arising—all called *zìrán* (自然, "self-so").
Hence, I say: My dependence is like the cicada’s shell and serpent’s skin—
it seems to have form but is not truly dependent on form.

**[Explanation of Text]**
*Tiáojiǎ* (蜩甲) is pronounced *tiáojiá* (条).
Sima Qian says: *Tiáojiǎ* is the cicada’s shed skin.
*Shétuì* (蛇蜕) is pronounced *shuì* (帨), also *tǔwò* (吐卧反), or *shǐruì* (始锐反).

**[4] [Commentary]**
*Tún* (屯) means "accumulation."
*Dài* (代) means "replacement."

The presence of fire and sun, my shadow accumulates;
when night falls or clouds obscure, my shadow fades and rests.
If my shadow depended on form alone,
then it would not require fire or sun.
Yet darkness and night possess form without shadow—
thus it is known that my shadow does not depend on form,
and the principle of spontaneous transformation is made clear.

**[Explanation of Text]**
*Wú tún* (吾屯) is pronounced *túmén* (徒门), meaning "accumulation."
◎Regency Fan annotates from the *Wénxuǎn* commentary on Xie Lingyun’s *Gaming the Southern Pavilion* poem: Sima Qian says:
*Tún* (屯), "accumulation"—when fire and sun shine, shadows appear, hence "my accumulation."
*Dài* (代), "replacement"—when darkness comes, shadows vanish, hence "my replacement."
*Yè dài* (夜代) means "night’s replacement," i.e., allowing rest.

**[5] [Commentary]**
My reason for dependence is fire and sun.
If they lack substance, fire and sun cannot produce shadow,
so shadows do not depend on fire and sun either.

**[6] [Note]**
Pursuing this to its extreme:
Even what is said to be dependent
ultimately reaches the point of no dependence,
and the principle of spontaneous transformation is manifest.

**[Commentary]**
What more is there to say of dependence?
If there is no fire or sun, form cannot produce shadow—
it does not depend on form.
Form arises without fire or sun,
and shadows arise—
how could they depend on form?
Thus, by comparing fire and sun to form,
it is clear that shadows do not depend on form.
Form and shadow do not rely on each other—
how much more so for other things!
Hence, all dharmas
are known to arise spontaneously.

◎My father of the family said:
When fire and sun appear, shadows arise;
when night falls, shadows retreat.
*Tún* (屯) refers to the initial growth of grass and trees;
*Dài* (代) means "change" or "replacement"—
when form changes, my shadow rests accordingly.
Shadows follow form, each mirroring the person’s likeness,
yet they are insubstantial, yielding to form’s every shift.
This is the grand essence of Zhuangzi’s *Responding to the World*.

**[7] [Note]**
They simply follow the strong vitality of movement,
coming and going in attendance—
without intent, beyond questioning.

**[Commentary]**
Form is what moves.
Strong vitality is the appearance of movement.
When shadows move in tandem with form,
they share the same time—
without dependence, all arise from spontaneous transformation.
The principle of spontaneous transformation transcends all names and speech;
names and speech are merely its outward expression.

**[Collation]**
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s edition reads *sǒu* (叟) instead of *wú* (吾).
(2) The missing character "无" is supplemented based on Guo’s annotation and the error in the omitted text, following Zhang Junfang’s edition.
(3) The two characters "所谓" are deleted according to Zhao’s edition.
(4) "卒" (至) is corrected from Zhao’s edition.
(5) "至" (至) and "矣" (矣) are deleted following Zhao’s edition.

Yang Zhu, surnamed Yang, given name Zhu, styled Zǐjū (子居),
traveled south to Pei (彭城, now Xuzhou),
where he encountered Laozi (老子) at the outskirts,
and reached Liang (梁) while meeting him again.
Laozi (老子), midway in his journey, gazed upward and sighed:
“At first I thought you could be taught,
but now I see you cannot.”

**[1] [Commentary]**
Surname Yang, given name Zhu, styled Zǐjū (子居).
*Zhī* (之), "to go."
Pei (沛) is Pengcheng (彭城), now Xuzhou.

**Translation:**

*"邀"* means "to meet" or "to encounter."
Liang (梁) is now Bianzhou (汴州).

Yang Zhu traveled southward,
while Laozi journeyed westward,
and they unexpectedly met in the lands of Liang and Song,
encountering each other in the wilderness and conversing.

**[Commentary]**
*Surname* Yang, *given name* Zhu, styled Zǐjū (子居).
*"Zhī"* (之) in *"zhī Pei"* (之沛) is pronounced *bèi* (贝).
*"Yāo"* (邀) rhymes with *"yáo"* (古尧反), meaning "to seek," "to encounter," or "to intercept."
The *Yùpiàn* (玉篇) states: "to seek," "to gather," or "to obstruct."

**[2] [Commentary]**
Earlier, when I met Yang Zhu, I thought he had a mind for the Dao.
Now, seeing his arrogance, I know he is difficult to teach.
Disliking his unconventional ways, I sigh in disappointment.
Yang Zhu did not respond.

Upon arriving at his dwelling,
he offered water for washing and rinsing,
presented a towel and comb,
removed his shoes outside the door,
and knelt forward to say:

"Earlier, your disciple wished to invite you, Master,
but your journey was not convenient,
so I dared not.
Now that you are at ease,
I humbly request to inquire about my faults."

**[1] [Commentary]**
He felt ashamed of his own shortcomings and remained silent in reverence.

**[2] [Commentary]**
*Swashing* (盥) means to wash or rinse.
*Comb* (栉) means to comb.
Upon arriving at the lodging,
he proceeded to the place of rest,
offered water for rinsing and washing,
held the towel and comb,
moved forward with elbows and knees—
conducting himself with utmost respect and earnestness,
hoping to receive instruction and correction.

**[Release Notes]**
*"Swashing"* (盥) is pronounced *guàn* (管).
The *Xiǎo Éryá* (小尔雅) defines it as "to bathe" or "to rinse."
*"Rinsing"* (漱) is pronounced *shù* (所又反).
*"Towel and comb"* (巾栉) rhymes with *"zhāng yǐ"* (庄乙反).

**[3] [Commentary]**
Previously, though I wished to inquire about my faults after being reproved,
I encountered urgent travel matters and had no leisure to do so.
Now, having arrived at my host’s dwelling and finding myself at ease with no pressing affairs,
I earnestly hope to hear your instructive words,
so that I may benefit from them in the future.

**[Release Notes]**
*"Not at ease"* (不闲) is pronounced *xián* (闲).
Below, it is read the same.
One reading follows the character directly.

Laozi says:
*"With your haughty glare and domineering stare—
who would dwell with you?
Great purity may seem like shame;
abundant virtue may seem insufficient."*

**[1] [Annotation]**
*"Haughty glare and domineering stare"* (睢睢盱盱) depicts arrogance and overbearing demeanor.
People will fear the difficulty and keep their distance.

**[Commentary]**
*"Haughty glare"* (睢睢) and *"dominating stare"* (盱盱) suggest restless, tyrannical authority.
*"You"* (而) refers to yourself.
With your overbearing manner and ostentatious display,
all others recoil in sorrow—
who would choose to dwell with you?

**[Release Notes]**
*"Haughty glare"* (睢睢) is pronounced *guī hū wéi fǎn* (郭呼维反) or *xú xǔ guī fǎn* (徐许圭反).
*"Dominating stare"* (盱盱) is pronounced *xiāng yú fǎn* (香于反), also *xǔ wú fǎn* (许

「**[1]** The sovereignty of the world is the heaviest of burdens—
yet it does not harm one’s life to hold it;
how much less could other trifles concern you! **[2]**
Only those who do not seek the world’s sovereignty
can be entrusted with it. **[3]**

**[1] [Annotation]**
The deeds of Yao and Shun are recorded in the inner chapters.
The surname was **Zi**, the given name **Zhou**, and the courtesy name **Zhi Fu**—
a man who embraced the Dao, a recluse.
Yao recognized his virtue and offered him the imperial throne.
If I were to be Emperor,
I could certainly govern well,
so I say, *"It is indeed acceptable for me."*
**幽** (deep) and **忧** (labor) imply
my heart is immersed in profound reflection,
and I seek to cultivate my self,
striving to align with the Dao,
leaving no leisure to attend to the myriad affairs of state. **[Annotation]**
*"Zi Zhou Zhi Fu"* (子州支父) is pronounced **Fǔ** (甫).
Li Yun notes: *Zhi Fu* is his courtesy name, the same as *Zhi Bo* (支伯).
Wang Yun explains: *"幽忧之病"* (afraid of sorrow's illness) refers to his deep and enduring affliction.

**[Commentary]**
The imperial throne, with its weight of authority,
is the most exalted position among all human stations—
yet even this supreme honor does not cause him to neglect his life.
How much less could other lesser matters occupy his mind!

**[3] [Annotation]**
Only those who forget the world,
who do not seek its sovereignty,
can be entrusted with it.
Shun offered the world to **Zi Zhou Zhi Bo** (子州支伯).
**Zi Zhou Zhi Bo** said:
*"I am afflicted with a deep and laboring illness;
I must first heal myself,
leaving no time to govern the world."* **[1]**
Thus, the sovereignty of the world is a great responsibility,
yet he does not exchange his life for it—
this is how those who follow the Dao differ from the common crowd. **[2]**

**[1] [Annotation]**
Shun’s deeds are recorded in the inner chapters.
**Zhi Bo** is the same as **Zhi Fu**.

**[Annotation]**
Yu Zhi notes: *The Records of the Grand Historian* lists **Zi Zhou Zhi Fu** (子州支父)
but not **Zhi Bo** (支伯),
so **Zhi Fu** and **Zhi Bo** are one person.

**[2] [Annotation]**
The imperial throne is a heavy and great responsibility—
yet he does not barter his life for its honor.
Who but one who follows the Dao could remain so steadfast?
Thus, his conduct stands apart from the vulgar crowd.

Shun offered the world to **Shan Juan** (善卷),
who said:
*"I stand within the cosmos,
wearing animal furs in winter and coarse linen in summer;
spring, I till and sow, my body laboring enough;
autumn, I harvest and store, my body resting with sustenance."*」

The sun rises and I labor; the sun sets and I rest,
drifting freely between Heaven and Earth while my heart finds contentment.
Why should I covet the world? **[1]**
Alas, you do not understand me!
And so he refused.

Then he departed and entered the deep mountains,
where no one knew his whereabouts. **[2]**

**[1]**
Surname **Shan** (善), given name **Juan** (卷), a recluse.
Dwelling within the six directions, harmonizing with the four seasons,
he found fulfillment between Heaven and Earth,
soaring beyond worldly filth—
the Dao was within him, so he did not seek the world.

**[Annotation]**
*Shan Juan* (善卷): *Juan* (卷) reads *quàn* (勉反) or *jù* (居阮反), also *juàn* (眷).
Li (李) notes: Surname **Shan**, given name **Juan**.
Yu Zhi (俞樾) says: *The Treatise on Exalted Worth* (吕览下贤篇) renders it **Shan Zhěn** (善绻).
*Clothing furs* (衣皮): *yú* (于既反). Same below.

**[2]**
The ancients were pure and simple.
They addressed the Emperor as "child."
He lamented that Shun did not grasp the heart of the wild,
thus his sigh of sorrow.

Shun offered the world to his friend, the farmer of **Shíhòu** (石户),
who said:
*"Rolls and toils, this man of later times—
a man of unyielding strength! **[1]**
"*Shun’s virtue has not yet reached its fullness,"*
and so husband bore his wife on his back,
father carried his child in his arms,
and they entered the sea together,
never to return. **[2]**

**[1]**
*Hòu* (户) is also written as *hòu* (后), read as the character demands.
**Shíhòu** (石户) is a place name.
*Agriculturalist* (农) refers to a person—today, in the south, "farmer" (农) is how one addresses another.
This was Shun’s friend.
*Bo* (葆) means steadfast.
He said that Shun’s resolve was unshaken,
his sinews and strength laboring without rest,
his back bent from toil—
because of his ceaseless exertion,
he now offered the world in return,
and so he refused.

**[Annotation]**
*Shíhòu* (石户) is also written as *Shíhòu* (后).
*The farmer* (之农): Li (李) notes: **Shíhòu** (石户) is a place name.

「Agriculturalist, a commoner indeed. **[2]**

*The bent and weary* (卷卷) is pronounced *quán*, with *Guō* reading it as *juàn*—a depiction of exerting effort.
*Steadfast in strength* (葆力) is pronounced *bǎo*, also written as *bǎo*.

**[2]**
Ancient folk bore burdens,
often by head-carrying—
even now, in Koryŏ, this custom remains.
Since Shun’s **virtue/power** and transformation
had not yet reached their ultimate heights,
he took his wife and child,
refusing to set foot on their land,
and entered the vast **sea-island** (海州岛),
never to return.

**[Annotation]**
*Entered the sea* (以入于海): Sima [commentary] states:
Whenever "enter" (入) is mentioned,
it refers to dwelling upon the islands
or in the bays of the sea.

King Dànfù resided in **Mín** (邠) **[1]**
when the **Dì** (狄) people attacked **[1]**.
He offered them **leather and silk** (皮帛) but they refused,
he offered them **dogs and horses** (犬马) but they refused,
he offered them **jewels and jade** (珠玉) but they refused—
for the **Dì** people sought only land.

King Dànfù said:
*“To share a dwelling with a man’s brother
yet slay his younger sibling,
to share a dwelling with a man’s father
yet slay his own child—
I cannot bear it.
All of you, make yourselves at home!
What difference does it make
whether you serve as my subjects
or as the **Dì** people’s subjects?”*

「**[2]** Moreover, I have heard that one should not harm what one cherishes with what one uses to nourish it. **[2]**»
He then took his staff and left.
The people of **Mín** followed him in solidarity,
and thus he established his state beneath **Qí** Mountain.

**[3]** Indeed, King Dànfù **[3]****
could be said to honor life **[3]**.
Those who honor life,
though noble and wealthy, do not let nourishment harm their bodies,
though poor and lowly, do not let gain burden their forms.
Yet people of today who hold high office and noble rank,
all fear losing it and, seeing profit, lightly abandon their lives—
how can they not be deluded? **[4]**

**[4]** **[1]** **[Annotation]**
Dànfù, the father of **Wáng Jì** **[1]**,
the grandfather of King Wén **[1]**.
**Mín**, a place name.
The **Dì** people, the **Róng** **[1]**.
Since his lands bordered the **Róng** barbarians,
they were attacked and ravaged by the **Dì** **[1]**.
**[Annotation]**
*Dàn* is pronounced *tài* (太).
*Fù* is pronounced *fǔ* (父).
*Mín* is pronounced *bǐ qín* (笔贫) and *xú fù jīn* (徐甫巾).

**[2]** **[Annotation]**
*Shì* (事) means to offer.
*Miǎn* (勉) means to encourage.
*Xī* (奚) means what.

The **Dì** people are greedy and cruel, their hearts set on land—
I cannot bear to harm or slay them, so you must strive and dwell there.

**[3]**
**[Annotation]**
*Yòng yǎng* (用养), the land that sustains.
*Suǒ yǎng* (所养), the people sustained.
Originally, the land was used to nourish the people,
but now they kill the people to preserve the land—
thus, it is wrong.
Leaning on his staff, he departed,
and the people followed in procession,
thereby establishing a state at **Qíyáng**.

**[Annotation]**
*《Bù yǐ suǒ yòng yǎng hài suǒ yǎng》*
The land is what sustains the people;
now they contend by killing the people—
this is harming the people with the land.
Since the people are nourished by the land,
one must not harm the people for the sake of the land.

*《Yīn zhàng》* (因杖), *zhì liàng* (直亮) reflex.
*《Cè》* (策), *chū gé* (初革) reflex.
*《Xiāng lián》* (相连), *lì zhǎn* (力展) reflex.
Sima says: *lián* (连) should be read as *niǎn* (辇).
*《Qíshān》* (岐山), *qí yí* (其宜) reflex or *qí zhī* (祁支) reflex.

**[4]**
**[Annotation]**
In chaotic times, falsehoods prevail,
and hearts grow shallow and fickle.
They chase after rank and title and lose their lives,
pursue wealth and profit and perish their fates—
they know not the light from the heavy,
deeply ensnared in delusion.

**[Annotation]**
*《Bù yǐ yǎng shāng shēn, bù yǐ lì lèi xíng》*
The **Wáng** says:
The wealthy have nourishment, yet do not let it harm their bodies,
the poor lack gain, yet do not let pursuit of profit burden their forms.

**[Annotation]**
*(One)* The character *mèi* (昧) is corrected according to the original text in the annotation. The **Yuè** people killed their kings in three generations;
**Wángzǐ Sōu** feared this fate,
and fled to the **Dān Xué** cave.

The **Yue** state had no ruler, and though they sought **Prince Sou**, they could not find him. He followed them into the **Dan Xue** cave. **Prince Sou** refused to emerge, so the **Yue** people smoked him out with mugwort. They then conveyed him in the **Wang yu** [1].

**Prince Sou**, grasping the reins, ascended the carriage and, gazing heavenward, cried:
*"O ruler! O ruler! Why must you abandon me?"*

**Prince Sou** did not despise being ruler—he despised the calamities of rule. A man like **Prince Sou** may be said to have spared his life for the sake of his state, and this was precisely what the **Yue** people wished to find in their ruler [2].

---
**[1]**
**[Annotation]**
Sou was the name of the prince. **Dan Xue** was a cave in the southern mountain. The **Wang yu** was the ruler’s carriage. Some texts render this as *yu yu* [1], reading it as *yu li* (玉辂).

The people of **Yue**, having repeatedly slain their sovereigns, fled in terror to the cave. Though summoned, **Prince Sou** would not come out, so they smoked him with mugwort. Once they begged him to rule, they conveyed him in the **Yu yu**.

**[Annotation]**
*《弒其》* sounds like *shì*.
*《王子搜》* read as *sū* (素羔反), also *sōu* (悉遘反), or *yáo* (邀遘反). Li [commentator] says: "The prince’s name." The *Huainanzi* renders it as *yì*.
◎Yu Yu says: The annotation reads: *Sou*, the *Huainanzi* renders as *yì*. Yet there is no account of three generations of regicide before *Yì*. The *Shiji*’s *Yue shijia* *Suoyin* takes *Sou* as *Yì*’s son, Wu Zhen. According to the *Zhushu Jinian*, *Yì* was slain by his son, the **Yue** people killed his son, and installed Wu Yu, who was also slain, and Wu Zhen was enthroned. Thus, before Wu Zhen, the three rulers all met untimely ends—**Prince Sou** must surely be another name for Wu Zhen. The *Huainanzi* likely erred in transmission; the *Suoyin*’s correction should be adopted.
*《丹穴》* The *Erya* states: "The southern peak, where the sun rises, is called **Dan Xue**."
*《以艾》* read as *wèi* (五盖反).
*《王舆》* One text reads *Yu yu*.

「**Section II**
**Commentary:**
*Yuan* means "to draw" or "to pull."
*Suī* refers to the rope on a chariot.
When words fail to avert disaster, one sighs deeply and boards the carriage—not out of hatred for the ruler, but fear of calamity.
Since life is more precious than rank, one may be bent to serve as ruler.

**Textual Notes:**
*《Yuan》* pronounced *yuán* (as in "爰").
*《ér hū》* pronounced with the *huǒ-gù* rhyme.
The original may also read *tàn* (sigh).
*《yǐ shě》* pronounced *shě* (as in "舍").
*《fēi è》* pronounced *wū-lù* (乌路反).
The same *è* (恶) appears in the following passage and the next chapter.

**Collations:**
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s copy reads *wáng* (王) as *yù* (玉).
(2) *Yāo gòu* (邀遘) is likely a misreading for *yāo* (邀).

The states of **Han** and **Wei** clashed over borderlands.
**Zi Hua Zi** visited **Zhao Xi Xi Hou**, who wore a troubled expression **[1]**.
Zi Hua Zi said:
*"If I were to inscribe a maxim before you and write: ‘Seizing it with the left hand will cost the right, seizing it with the right hand will cost the left—yet whoever seizes it shall rule all under Heaven—would you dare to seize it?’ **[2]**"*

---
**Commentary [1]:**
Zhao Xi Xi Hou was the ruler of **Han**.
Zi Hua Zi was a virtuous man of **Wei**.
As neighboring states, **Han** and **Wei** contested territories, arms clashed, and victory remained uncertain. The ruler’s anxious demeanor reflected his unease.

**Textual Notes:**
*《Zǐ Huá Zǐ》* Sima [Bian] notes: "A man of **Wei**."
◎Yu Yu remarks:
*The Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *"Guì Shēng"* (貴生) cites **Zi Hua Zi** as saying:
*"Preserving life whole is supreme; partial loss is secondary; death is worse; and being forced to act against one’s will is the lowest."*
Again, in *"Miù Tú"* (誣徒), it cites **Zi Hua Zi**:
*"The sovereign rejoices in the means by which he rules; the fallen rejoices in the means by which he fell."*
Gao [You] annotates both passages, calling **Zi Hua Zi** an ancient Daoist recluse.
The terms *"zhī dù"* (知度) and *"shěn wéi"* (審為) appear in both commentaries.
*《Zhāo Xī Xī Hóu》* Sima [Bian] notes: "The ruler of **Han**."
◎Yu Yu observes:
**Han** had a **Zhao Hou** and a **Xi Wang**, but no **Zhao Xi Xi Hou**.

---
**Commentary [2]:**
*Míng* refers to inscribed records.
*Shuò* means "to grasp."
*Fèi* means "to sever" (or "to discard").
If an inscribed maxim were placed before you—*"Take it with the left hand, and the right is cut; take it with the right hand, and the left is cut—yet whoever takes it shall rule all under Heaven"*—would you dare to take it?
*(This is a metaphorical question addressed to the ruler of **Han**.)*

**Textual Notes:**
*《Shuò》* pronounced *jù-bì* (俱碧) or *jù-fù* (俱缚), or *shǐ-jué* (史虢).
Li [Fan] explains: "To take."
◎Lu Wenbin notes:
The old pronunciation *jù-bì* (俱碧) and *jù-fù* (俱缚), or *shǐ-jué* (史虢), are erroneous.
Now corrected according to the Song edition.
*《Fèi》* Li [Fan] explains: "To abandon."
Sima [Bian] explains: "To fall ill."
Another reading clarifies:
*"Shuò"* refers to grasping the inscribed maxim;
*"Fèi"* refers to severing the right hand.

**Collations:**
(1) The Gao Shan Temple edition omits the character *néng* (能) after *jūn* (君).
Zhao Xi Xi Hou replied:
*"I would not dare to seize it. **[1]**."*

Zhao Xi Xi Hou replied:
*"I cannot sever both arms to claim all under Heaven."*

Zi Hua Zi said:
*"Excellent! **[1]** From this perspective, one’s arms are heavier than the realm, and one’s life is heavier still than one’s arms. The weight of **Han** compared to the realm is already far lighter **[2]**, and what you now contend for is even lighter than **Han** itself. Your lordship is indeed burdening your body and endangering your life in vain distress over what you cannot obtain!"* **[1]**

**[1] Citation:** Praising the lord’s words as perfectly reasoned.
**[2] Citation:** *Zhì* (自) here means *from* (i.e., *from this perspective*).

When examined thus, one’s life weighs more than one’s arms, one’s arms more than the realm, and the realm more than **Han**—yet the disparity between **Han** and the realm is vast. **[1]**

**[3] Citation:** What you now dispute is merely a borderland, yet you fixate on it with such sorrow, harming your body and depleting your vitality—all for something you may never attain. Is this not perplexing?

**Textual Notes:**
*《其轻于韩又远》* pronounced *jué-jù* (绝句).

**Collations:**
(1) The character *yì* (亦) restored from the main text.

Lai Hou said:
*"Well spoken! Many have instructed me, yet I have never heard such words before."*

Zi Hua Zi truly understands the balance of weight and measure. **[1]**

**[1] Citation:** Astonished by his sudden enlightenment and its brilliance.

The ruler of **Lu** had heard that Yan He was a man who had attained the **Dao**. He sent envoys with gifts to precede him. **[1]**

Yan He tended his humble gate, clad in coarse hempen robes, and fed himself by plowing oxen. **[2]**

When the **Lu** envoy arrived, Yan He received him himself. The envoy asked:
*"Is this the home of Yan He?"*
Yan He replied:
*"This is my home."*

The envoy presented the gifts, but Yan He said:
*"I fear that if I accept, those who hear of it may misconstrue and blame the envoy. It would be better to verify this first."*

The envoy returned and confirmed the matter, then came again—only then did Yan He accept.

**[3]** Thus, one like Yan He truly despised wealth and nobility.

**[1] Citation:** The ruler of **Lu**—either **Lu Ai Gong** or, as some say, **Lu Ding Gong**—of the **Yan** clan, named **He**, a recluse from **Lu**. *Bì* (币) refers to silk.
Having heard that Yan He embodied the **Dao** of purity and integrity, the ruler wished to appoint him as prime minister, so he sent envoys bearing silk to convey his intent.

**Textual Notes:**
*《鲁君》* alternatively reads *Lu Hou* (鲁侯).
Li [Fan] explains: *"Ai Gong."*

「**[2] Citation:** *Jūbù*, coarse hemp cloth. *Fàn*, to feed. Dwelling in humble alleys, clad in rough garments, he himself fed the oxen—thus clearly demonstrating his poverty and frugality.

**[3] Citation:** *Yú*, to give. Not wishing to accept the gifts, he feigned these words to deceive the envoy.
◎Yu Yü said: The character *yú* (欲) is a redundant repetition. "Fearful that those who hear may err and blame the envoy" means he feared the envoy might be blamed for mishearing.

**Textual Notes:**
*Jū* (苴) is pronounced *cū* (粗), with the rhyme of *qīyú* (七余). Li Fan explains: "It is hemp cloth with child threads." The original sometimes reads *cū* (粗), but this is incorrect.
*Fànniú* (饭牛) is pronounced *fǎnwǎn* (符晚).

*Yú* (遗) here means "to give." The envoy’s hearing (*tīng*) refers to the envoy himself, not a single listener. The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Guìshēng* chapter correctly reads: *"Fearful that the hearing may be erroneous and blame fall upon the envoy."*

**Textual Variants:**
*《之使》* pronounced *suǒlì* (所吏).
*《家与》* pronounced *yú* (余).
*《而遗》* pronounced *wéiyí* (唯季).
*《复来》* pronounced *fú* (服) or *fúyòu* (扶又).
The following chapter follows the same readings.

Thus it is said: The **Dao/Way**’s true essence is for cultivating oneself, its residual **virtue/power** for the state, and its coarse **qi** for governing the world. From this perspective, the labors of the **emperors** and **sages** are but the remnants of **saintly** affairs, not what is needed to perfect oneself and nurture life **[1]**. Yet today’s common **scholars** often endanger their own lives and abandon their existence to serve trivial matters—how tragic!

In all things, the **sage** must examine both the **means** by which he acts and the **ends** he pursues **[2]**. Now suppose **[1]** there is a man here who uses the **Random Lord’s Pearl** to shoot a sparrow at a height of a thousand *rèn*—the world would surely mock him. Why? Because what he employs is precious, yet what he seeks is trifling.

Life itself—is it not far more weighty than the **Random Lord’s Pearl**? **[3]**

**[1]**
**Explication:** *Glǔ* (绪) means "leftover" or "remnant." *Tǔ* (土) is "dung," and *jū* (苴) is "grass." Those who apply the true **Dao/Way** to sustain themselves must regard state affairs as remnants and treat the world like dung and grass.

**Textual Notes:** *Glǔyú* (绪余) follows the reading as written. *Xū* (徐) is pronounced *shē* (奢) above, *jiē* (嗟) below. Li Fan explains: *Glǔ* means "leftover," referring to remnants. ◎Qìngfān’s annotation in the *Wénxuǎn* (文选) cites Li Fan’s note on *Sǐmǎ Zǐcháng Bàorèn Shǎoqiè Shū* (司马子长报任少卿书): *Glǔ* means "leftover" or "remnant." This is more concise than the **Textual Notes**. *Tǔ* (土) is pronounced *chìyǎ* (敕雅), *piànjiǎ* (片贾), or *rú* (如) as written. *Jū* (苴) is pronounced *zèyǎ* (侧雅) or *zhīyǎ* (知雅). Li Fan says: *Tǔjū* (土苴) is like dung and grass. Sima Qian notes: *Tǔjū* (土苴) means "worthless remnants," all untrue things. Another explanation: *Tǔjū* (土苴) describes the appearance of "being without purpose."

**[2]**
**Explication:** *Yùn* (殉) means "to follow" or "to pursue." The **sage** observes where people go and what they say, then acts accordingly.

**[3]**
The **Random Lord**’s state was near the **Pu River** (濮水), where the **Pu River** yielded a precious pearl—this was the one the **sacred serpent** bore in gratitude for a debt, which the **Random Lord** obtained. Thus, it is called the **Random Lord’s Pearl**. Now, if a sparrow is perched a thousand *rèn* high and one uses this pearl to shoot it, the object sought is light, yet the means employed are heavy. To risk one’s life for trivial matters—this too is such folly.

**Textual Notes:** *Suǒyào* (所要) is pronounced *yáo* (遥). ◎Yú Yè says: Below *Random Lord* (随侯) should have *Pearl* (珠). Without it, the meaning is insufficient. The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Guìshēng* chapter reads: *Life itself—is it not far more weighty than the Random Lord’s Pearl?* One should follow and supplement this.

(1) The **High Mountain Temple** edition omits the *mǎ* (且) above.

**Sima Zǐliè** (子列子) grew gaunt from hunger. A visitor spoke to **Zhèng Zǐyáng** (郑子阳), saying: *"Sima Zǐliè, the **Random Lord**—truly a man of **Dao/Way**—dwells in your lordship’s realm yet suffers want. Does your lordship not fear that this may be seen as a failing in your virtue?"* **[1]** Zhèng Zǐyáng immediately ordered an official to give him grain. **Sima Zǐliè**, upon seeing the envoy, bowed twice and declined **[2]**.

**[1]**
**Explication:** *Zǐyáng* (子阳) was the **Chancellor** of **Zhèng**. **Sima Zǐliè** (御寇) was a **Zhèng**-man with **Dao/Way** yet in poverty. **Zhèng Zǐyáng**’s cruelty drove away worthy **scholars**, and wandering guests criticized him.

**Textual Notes:** *Zǐyáng* (子阳) was the **Chancellor**. *Bùhǎo* (不好) is pronounced *hūbào* (呼报).

**[2]**
**Explication:** The **Chancellor** summoned the **Granary Overseer** and commanded him to give grain. **Sima Zǐliè**, being pure and exalted, declined and refused to accept it.

**Textual Notes:** *Jìlìng* (即令) is pronounced *lìchéng* (力呈).

As the envoy departed, **Sima Zǐliè** entered, and his wife, upon seeing him, struck her chest and exclaimed: *"I have heard that the wives and children of men of **Dao/Way** all enjoy ease and happiness, yet now he has a hungry look. When your lordship passed by and gave him food, he did not accept it—is this not a command from Heaven? **[1]!"**

**[1]**
**Explication:** Though given grain, he refused it—Heaven’s decree that he remain poor. She sighed and struck her chest, blaming her husband’s fault.

Thus, it is clear that **Sima Zǐliè**’s wife was far inferior to **Lǎolái**’s consort.

**Textual Notes:** *Fǔxīn* (拊心) is pronounced *fǔ* (抚) in **Xu**’s reading. *Déyì* (得佚) is pronounced *yì* (逸). *Lè* (乐) is pronounced *luò* (洛). *Jūn guò* (君过) is pronounced *wù* (卧) in the ancient form, or *yù* (遇).

**[Collation Note]**
(1) The **High Mountain Temple** edition reads: *"Is this not a command from Heaven?"* as *"Is this not Heaven’s decree?"* (岂非命也哉).

**Sima Zǐliè** smiled and said to her: *"Your lordship does not truly know me. He gave me grain based on others’ words, and when he blames me, he will again rely on others’ words—this is why I do not accept it."* Soon after, the people indeed rebelled and killed **Zhèng Zǐyáng**.

**[1]**
**Explication:** **Zhèng Zǐyáng** was harsh and cruel, and many resented him. His attendants had once broken his bow in error, fearing they would incur his wrath. When the people drove out a **wild dog**, they seized the opportunity to kill him.

**Textual Notes:** *Zùnàn* (作难) is pronounced *nàidàn* (乃旦). Below, the next chapter follows the same. *Shā Zǐyáng* (杀子阳): **Zhèng Zǐyáng**’s severity knew no pardon. His retainers, fearing his anger, killed him during the chaos of the people driving out a **wild dog**.

◎Yú Yè notes: The account of **Zhèng Zǐyáng** appears in the *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Shìwēi* (适威) chapter and the *Huáinán*’s *Fànlùn Xuàn* (泛论训). However, the *Shǐjì*’s **Zhèng** clan annals state: In the twenty-fifth year of **Zhèng Wū** (繻公), the **Duke** of **Zhèng** killed his **Chancellor**, **Zhèng Zǐyáng**. In the twenty-seventh year, **Zhèng Zǐyáng**’s followers conspired to assassinate **Zhèng Wū**, yet this differs from other texts.

When **Chǔ Zhāo Wáng** (楚昭王) lost his kingdom, **Túyáng Shuì** (屠羊说) fled and followed him **[1]**. When **Chǔ Zhāo Wáng** recovered his kingdom, he intended to reward those who had followed him, and when he reached **Túyáng Shuì**...

Túyáng Shuì said, *"Great King lost his kingdom, and I lost my position as butcher of sheep; Great King recovered his kingdom, and I also return to butchering sheep. My rank and stipends have already been restored—what further reward could there be?"*

◎Commentary: Great King **Chǔ Zhāo Wáng** was named **Zhěn**, a son of **Píng Wáng**. **Wǔ Shì** and **Wǔ Shàng** were executed by **Píng Wáng**, while **Zǐyú** fled to **Wú**, tilling the fields in exile. Later, in the reign of **Wú Wáng Hé Lǘ**, he requested troops to attack **Chǔ**, thus breaking into **Yǐng** and avenging his father’s **chóu** (仇).

At that time, **Zhāo Wáng** was in dire straits, abandoning his kingdom and fleeing first to **Suí**, then to **Zhèng**. There was a lowly butcher named **Shuì**, who followed the king in his flight. The reasons for his flight are detailed below.

◎Textual Notes: *"Chǔ Zhāo Wáng"* was named **Zhěn**, son of **Píng Wáng**. *"Túyáng Shuì"* is pronounced **yuè**, or sometimes read as the character. The king said, *"Force him!"* Túyáng Shuì replied, *"Great King lost his kingdom—this was not my crime, so I dared not submit to his punishment; Great King recovered his kingdom—this was not my merit, so I dared not accept his reward."* The king said, *"Show yourself!"*

Túyáng Shuì replied:
*"The laws of Chu decree that one must earn great rewards and perform mighty deeds before being granted an audience. Yet my wisdom was insufficient to preserve the kingdom, and my courage was insufficient to face the enemy. When the Wu army entered Yǐng, I feared the difficulty and avoided the foe—not out of loyalty to Your Majesty, but from self-preservation. Now, if Your Majesty would abandon the law and break the covenant just to see me, this would not be the conduct by which I wish to be known across the world."*

The king then said to **Sīmǎ Zǐ Qí**:
*"Túyáng Shuì, though of lowly station, has set forth lofty principles. Zǐ Qí, offer him the rank of one of the Three Edlers [or: Three Ministers]."*

---
**Túyáng Shuì** said:
*"I know that the rank of the Three Edlers is nobler than that of a butcher’s stall, and that the emoluments of ten thousand *zhòng* are richer than the profits of a butcher’s trade. Yet could I, for the sake of rank and wealth, allow my lord to bear the reputation of reckless bestowal? I dare not accept it. I wish only to return to my butcher’s stall."*

And so he refused.

*"Original Xiān resided in Lu, dwelling in a wattle-and-daub hut, its walls thatched with wild grass; its door of woven reeds was incomplete, its hinge made of a willow branch."*

「Yet the dwelling of **Yuán Xiān** was but a jar-windowed hut with two rooms, his coarse hempen garments serving as curtains. Rain leaked through the roof, dampness seeped from below, and he sat upright, playing his *xián* (一) and singing (一) in self-amusement.

(一) *Xián* here refers to *xián-gē* (弦歌), the plucking of strings and singing.

---

**Zǐ Gòng** rode in a grand carriage, draped in indigo inner robes and plain outer ones, so imposing that its canopy blocked the alleyway. He went to visit **Yuán Xiān**.

**Yuán Xiān** wore a cap of fine *huá* (一) (一) leather, his sandals without soles, and leaned on a staff of *lí* (藜) while answering the door himself (二).

(一) **Zǐ Gòng**, a disciple of Confucius, named Gòng (赐), skilled in speech and fond of splendor.

(二) *Yí* (縰) means to step lightly. **Yuán Xiān** used a cap made of fine *huá* (一) (一) wood’s bark, a staff of *lí* (藜) and *huì* (藿), and since he had no servants, he answered the door himself.

---

**Zǐ Gòng** exclaimed:
*"Ah! Master, what ails you?"*

Yuán Xiān replied:
*"I have heard this saying: Lack of wealth is called poverty, but learning without practice is called illness. Now, I am poor, but not ill."*

Zǐ Gòng hesitated and wore a look of shame.

Yuán Xiān laughed and said:
*"To seek the world’s approval in one’s actions, to curry favor with influential friends, to study for others’ gain, and to teach for one’s own—these are the deceits of benevolence and righteousness, the ostentations of carriages and horses. I cannot bear to do them."*

Thus, those who cultivate their spirit forget bodily comforts; those who nourish their form forget profit; and those who attain the **Dao/Way** forget their very selves.

Once, when **Zēng Zǐ** dwelt in **Wèi**, his patched robes had no outer layer, his skin was parched and cracked, his hands and feet calloused. For three days he did not kindle a fire, and for ten years he did not make new clothes. His hat’s cord frayed and snapped, his sleeves were torn so that his elbows showed, his sandals were so worn that the soles split apart. He dragged his unsoled sandals and sang the **Shāng** and **Sòng** hymns, his voice filling the heavens and earth, as if it came from metal and stone. Neither the **Son of Heaven** could secure him as a minister, nor the feudal lords could claim him as a friend. Hence, the man who nourishes his spirit forgets his body, the man who nourishes his body forgets gain, and the man who attains the **Dao/Way** forgets his heart.

「【Three】【Commentary】 His voice resounded like the **Shāng** and **Sòng** hymns (resonating), harmonizing with the **gōng-shāng** tones, and examining their lyrical meaning, it aligned with the **Yǎ**—the refined, cosmic order—echoing through heaven and earth. His **qi** and voice were pure and lofty, resonant like metal and stone, his demeanor noble and unadorned, surpassing the bounds of human conduct. Thus, neither the **Son of Heaven** could appoint him as a minister, nor the feudal lords could claim him as a friend.

【Four】【Commentary】 The **virtuous** and **accomplished** man does not let physical adversity diminish his resolve; the **humble and vigilant** do not let material gain harm their life. The man who attains the **Dao/Way** forgets the **heart-knowing** arts of ambition. Confucius said to **Yán Huí**: *"Huí, come! Though your family is poor and your dwelling humble, why do you not seek office?"* **Yán Huí** replied: *"I do not wish to take office. I have fifty *mǔ* of fields outside the city walls, enough to provide rice gruel; ten *mǔ* of fields within the walls, sufficient for flax and hemp. Playing the *qín* brings me joy, and what I have learned from my Master’s **Dao/Way** brings me contentment. I do not wish to take office."*

Confucius’ face grew grave, his expression changed, and he said: *"Noble indeed is Huí’s resolve! I have long recited: ‘The contented man does not burden himself with worldly gain; the man who knows his own worth loses nothing without fear; the man whose **virtue/power** is cultivated inwardly feels no shame without rank.’ I have chanted these words for ages, yet only now do I see them embodied in Huí—this is my true understanding."*」

The *Commentary* states:
*"Mí*—deer. *Zuò*—shame.*

The man who finds contentment in himself is not disturbed by gain or loss;
the one who cultivates his inner **virtue/power** feels no shame without rank!

Confucius had long recited these words, yet now he urged Huí to seek office—was this not a misstep?
Only when Huí reflected did he say, *"This is my true understanding."*

**Exegesis:**
*"Zhōu"*—reversed as *rán*.
Some texts render it as *"zhān"*—gruel.
*The Broad雅* says: *"Mí"*—also means *"ruined"* or *"broken."*
Another reading: *"jǐ yán"*—*jǐ* as in *"jǐ yán"* (to record).
*The Family Sayings* calls it *"thick gruel."*
One pronunciation: *"gān"*—as in *"gān □"* (now corrected from *"bǐng"* to *"yù"*).
*"Zhōu"*—sixth tone, also *"yù"*.
*"Zì yú"*—pronounced *"luò"*.
*"Qiào"*—seventh tone, *"xiù"* in *Jiǔ Zhōu*, also *"liǎo"* (seventh tone, *"liǎo"* as in *"liǎo"*).
*"Xíng xiū"*—below *"méng"* tone.
*"Bù zuò"*—*"luò"* tone.
*The Erya* says: *"shame."*
Also pronounced *"zuò"* (as in *"zuò"*).

**Collation:**
(1) The text omits *"xiàn"* (envy), citing *Jiāngnán Lǐ Shì*’s version as *"xiàn."*

**Middle Mountain Prince Móu** asked **Zhān Zǐ**:
*"Though I dwell upon the rivers and seas, my heart lingers beneath the **Arcade of Wei**—what should I do?"*

**Zhān Zǐ** replied:
*"Hold life most dear.
If life is held most dear, then worldly gain becomes light."*

**Middle Mountain Prince Móu** said:
*"Though I understand this, I cannot yet overcome myself."*

---
**Exegesis:**
*Zhān Zǐ*—a virtuous man of **Wei**.
Prince Móu of **Wei**, sealed as Middle Mountain, hence *"Middle Mountain Prince Móu."*
Though he harbored aspirations of retreat, lacking the **Dao/Way** of lofty detachment, he lingered between the rivers and seas while his heart clung to the splendor beneath the **Arcade of Wei**. Upon seeing a sage, he inquired of his method.

**Exegesis:**
*"Middle Mountain Prince Móu"*—Sima Qian says: A prince of **Wei**, sealed as Middle Mountain, named Móu.
*Zhān Zǐ*—a virtuous man. *Huáinán Zǐ* renders it as *"Zhān."*
*"Arcade of Wei"*—*Huáinán Zǐ* renders it as *"qí"* (later corrected to *"wèi"*).
Sima Qian’s text aligns, explaining *"qí"* as *"wèi"*—symbolizing the royal gate, where the sovereign’s heart resides in honor.
Xu Shēn states: *"The two observatories of the Son of Heaven."*

Lu Wénpiàn notes: *"Today, Huáinán Zǐ also renders it as ‘Wei.’"*

*Zhān Zǐ* said:
*"Hold life most dear.
If one cherishes the **Dao/Way** of life, then fame and profit become insignificant."*

**Exegesis:**
*"Hold life most dear"*—Li Shǒu explains: *"If one upholds the **Dao/Way** of life, then fame and profit grow light—lightness makes them easy to abandon."*

This man, though dwelling by the rivers and seas, still coveted honor and profit, so this admonition was given to him.

**Middle Mountain Prince Móu** said:
*"Though I know this, I cannot yet conquer myself."*

**Exegesis:**
*"Conquer"*—pronounced *"shēng"* (as in *"ascend"*).
Same below.

The **Zhānxian Zǐ** said:
*"If one cannot conquer oneself, then one should follow [one’s desires].
What harm can there be to the spirit?
If one cannot conquer oneself yet forcibly resists, this is called **severe injury**.
Those who suffer **severe injury** will have no longevity."*

**Exegesis:**
*"If one cannot conquer oneself, then one should follow"*—
If one cannot overcome desire, then one ought to yield to the heart’s will, lest one vainly generate resentment or ill will.

**Release Notes:**
*"Unable to conquer oneself, then follow"*—a complete sentence.
One reading breaks at *"god"* (神) as a separate sentence.
◎Yú Yì remarked:
*"The Release Notes say, ‘Unable to conquer oneself, then follow’ is a complete sentence—this reading is correct.
Again, it says, ‘One reading breaks at *god* as a separate sentence’—this is incorrect.
The *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* ‘*Examine Responses*’ chapter also records this matter, rendering it as ‘Unable to conquer oneself, then let go (纵之). What harm can there be to the spirit?’
The *Wénzǐ* ‘*Below Virtue*’ chapter and the *Huáinánzǐ* ‘*Dao/Way’s Response*’ chapter both repeat the character *from* (从) twice, as ‘*from it, from it*’ (从之从之), making clear that *from* (从) and *god* (神) should not be read together.
Again, considering that *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* uses *let go* (纵), it should be read with the *zì* (子) tone, yet the Release Notes provide no pronunciation, which is also incorrect.
*‘No harm’* (无恶)—as the character.
Also read as *wūlù* (乌路).
*‘Huh’* (乎)—a complete sentence.
One reading joins *‘unable to conquer oneself’* with the following as a single sentence."

---

**【II】【Commentary】**
Though emotions cannot be overcome, the heart’s purity is stifled, and its desires are already impaired—yet further it defies the natural course, hence the term *heavy wound* (重傷). Such a person will inevitably die young, and thus cannot be compared with those who live long and in good health.

**【Release Notes】**
*Heavy wound* (重傷) read as *zhíyòng* (直用).
Same below.

◎**Yu Yue** said: *Heavy wound* (重傷) means *double wound* (再傷). Unable to conquer oneself is already a wound; yet if one forcibly restrains it and does not allow it to flow freely, that is a double wound. Hence it is said: *This is what is meant by heavy wound*.

The *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* ‘*Examine Responses*’ chapter’s annotation by Gao Yu reads: *heavy* (重) as a repetition of *heavy* (重). This is correct. The Release Notes’ pronunciation of *zhíyòng* (直用) is incorrect.

**【Collation】**
(1) The Zhao Jiànyì edition lacks the characters *heavy wound* (重傷).

Now, **Wei Mou** (衛牟), a prince of the *ten thousand chariots* (萬乘) rank, though he dwelled in caves and secluded himself in rugged grottoes, it was hard for him to surpass the common scholar—though he had not yet attained the Dao/Way, he possessed its spirit.

**【Collation】**
**【I】**
Though born to great royal lineage and honored with noble status, he could still dwell in caves and hide in valleys, enduring hardship in body—though he had not yet ascended to the mysterious Dao/Way, he held a pure and lofty aspiration, sufficient to stir the greedy and inspire the common folk.

**【Release Notes】**
*Ten thousand chariots* (萬乘) read as *shéngzhèng* (繩證).

Though **Confucius** was hard-pressed between **Chen** and **Cai**, going seven days without cooked food, his gruel unsifted, his countenance wan, yet he played the lute and sang in his chamber.

**Preface** (子路) and **Zigong** (子貢) conversed, saying: *“Our Master has been twice exiled from Lu, his path cut off in Wei, trees felled against him in Song, he was hard-pressed in Shang and Zhou, surrounded in Chen and Cai. Those who slay our Master are guiltless, those who borrow from him face no prohibition. Yet he never ceases his lute and song—is this the shamelessness of a gentleman?”*

**【I】**
**【Commentary】**
The matter of **Chen** and **Cai** has already been explained in the outer chapters.

**【I】**

**【Release Notes】**
*"Hunger and privation"* (饥馁) read as *qíhuì* (齐会).
*"No cooked food"* (无火食) read as *wúhuǒshí* (无火食).
*"Gruel of broomcorn millet, unsifted"* (藜菜之羹，不加米糁) read as *líkǎi zhī gēng, bù jiā mǐchǎn* (gruel of broomcorn millet, unsifted).
*"Yet he sang and took delight in music"* (颜色衰惫而歌乐自娱) read as *his countenance wan and weary, yet he sang and took delight in music*.
The **Dao/Way**-attuned sage, does not deem such trials as matters.

**【Release Notes】**
*"No cooked food"* (不火食) lacks the character *火* (huǒ) in the *Yuán Jiā* (元嘉) edition.
*"Unsifted"* (不糁) read as *bùshā* (不沙).
*"Wan and weary"* (甚惫) read as *shìbèi* (时备).

**【II】**
**【Commentary】**
He served in **Lu** yet was exiled, wandered in **Wei** yet his path was cut off, lectured beneath the trees in **Song** yet **Sima Kuangui** (司马桓魋) sought to kill the Master, hating where he sat, so he felled the trees. Thus, those who would kill the Master should bear no guilt, and those who would oppress him should face no prohibition. **Zilu** and **Zigong** were yet unenlightened, so they voiced such words.

**【Release Notes】**
*"Felled the trees in Song"* (伐树于宋) refers to **Confucius** visiting **Song** with his disciples, practicing rituals beneath a great tree, when **Song’s Sima Kuangui** sought to kill **Confucius**, so he felled the tree, and **Confucius** then departed.
*"Oppress"* (藉) means *to harm* (毁) or *to trample* (凌藉); also *to bore* (凿) or *to bind* (系).
**【Correction】** The *Zhào Jiànyì* (赵谏议) edition reads *"release"* (释) instead of *"choose"* (择). **Yan Hui** had no response, so he entered to report to **Confucius**.
**Confucius** pushed aside his lute and sighed deeply, saying: *“Zilu and Zigong are petty folk. I shall summon them and speak to them.”*

Zilu and Zigong entered. Zilu said, *“To reach such a state—this may truly be called ‘exhaustion’!*”

**【Release Notes】**
*"Sighed deeply"* (喟然) is a sigh of lamentation.
*"Zilu and Zigong"* are petty, trifling men.
He summoned them to come and spoke to them of the **Dao/Way**.

In such hardship, how could one not be exhausted?

**【Release Notes】**
*"Sighed"* (喟) is pronounced *kuì* (去愧反) or *kǔ* (苦怪反).
*"Spoke to them"* (语之) is pronounced *yǔjù* (鱼据反).

**Confucius** said, *“What words are these?*
To be *thorough* in the **Dao/Way** is to be *thorough*—that is *thoroughness*.
To be *exhausted* in the **Dao/Way** is to be *exhausted*—that is *exhaustion*.

Now, I, Zhōu, cling to the **Dao/Way** of *virtue* and *righteousness*, yet encounter the calamities of a chaotic age—what *exhaustion* could there be?
Thus, in self-reflection, I am not exhausted in the **Dao/Way**;
when facing peril, I do not lose my *virtue/power*.
When winter’s chill arrives and frost and snow descend,
I thereby know the thriving of pine and cypress.

The straits of **Chén-Cái**—for me, this is indeed fortune!”

**【Release Notes】**
*"Fortune"* (幸) refers to how the cold of winter distinguishes trees—
one knows the true scholar in adversity,
and *virtue/power* is revealed through trials—
this is indeed fortune.

**◎ Qìng Fān’s Note:** *"What exhaustion could there be?"* (何穷之为) —*"for"* (为) here means *"to say"* (谓).
In ancient usage, *for* (为) and *say* (谓) share the same meaning.
The *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* (*Palamedes’ Spring and Autumn*) *Shènrén* ("Advising the Ruler") chapter renders it *"what exhaustion to say?"* (何穷之谓).
The *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* *Jīngyù* ("Explanations") chapter renders *"why not?"* as *"胡谓不可"* (胡为不可).
The *Hànshū* (*Han Records*) *Gāodì Jì* ("High Emperor’s Annals") renders *"for"* (为) as *"谓"* in *"Lì Shíjì"* (郦食其) as *"a village gatekeeper"* (里监门).
This is further evidence.

(*Note:* In the *Zhuàn* (*Leftist Commentary*), *"one"* (一) is used as *"to say"* (谓).
The *Hánshī Wàishuān* (*Han Poetry External Transmission*) uses *"What words"* (何谓) in *"King Wáng’s desire to use this speech."*
The *Xīnxù* (*New Sequence*) *Záshì* ("Miscellaneous Matters") uses *"What words"* (何谓) in *"How could it reach this?"*—
the character *say* (谓) is used interchangeably with *for* (为) in all these cases.)

---

**【Exegesis】**
In *"Confronting Peril"* (《临难》), it should read *"the great cold has arrived"* (大寒乃至). ◎ **Yu Yü** remarks: *"Tian"* (天) is a mistaken substitution for *"da"* (大). In the *Guoyu* (*Rulu*), *"Great Cold descends"* (大寒降), **Wei Zhao** annotates: *"This refers to the eleventh month (season of *Chou*), after the Great Cold."* If rendered as *"the cold of heaven has arrived"* (天寒既至), the meaning is lost. The *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* (*Palm Springs Annals*) *Shènrén* ("Cautious Person") chapter also records this event, correctly as *"Great Cold"* (大寒).

In *"The Narrow Pass"* (《之隘》), pronounced *è* (厄), also *xiè* (懈). **【Collation】**
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s copy reads *"lu"* (露) instead of *"xue"* (雪).
(2) The lacuna in the Jiangnan Ancient Cached Text inserts after *"mao ye"* (茂也): *"Huan Gong obtained it from Gu, Wen Gong from Cao, and the Yue King from Willow Ridge"* (桓公得之莒，文公得之曹，越王得之会稽), sixteen characters.

Confucius plucked his *qin* and sang with a *xuērán* (削然) sound, while **Zilu** brandished his shield with a *qǔrán* (扢然) vigor. **Zigong** exclaimed:
*"I do not know how high the heavens are, nor how deep the earth!"*

**【Citation】**
*SXuērán*—the sound of plucking the *qin*.
*Qǔrán*—a display of vigorous action.
This marks the mutual enlightenment of teacher and disciple, their shared joy.

**【Exegesis】**
*SXuērán*—as written. **Li Yun** says: *"The sound of plucking the *qin*."* Also written as *"shāo"* (梢), pronounced *xiāo* (消). ◎ **Lu Wenbian** notes: *"The Song edition reads 'shāo' as 'qiào' (俏)."*
*Qǔ*—pronounced *qì* (讫) or *jù* (巨), *yǔ* (鱼). **Li Yun** says: *"A display of vigorous dancing."* **Sima** says: *"A display of joy."* *Dryan*—a shield. Those who attained the **Dao** in antiquity found joy in adversity and in prosperity. Their joy was not in adversity or prosperity itself, but in **virtue/power** (德) manifesting here—then adversity and prosperity were but the sequence of cold, heat, wind, and rain.

**【Citation】**
*"Also joy"* (亦乐) pronounced *luò* (洛), same below. ◎ **Yu Yü** remarks: *"De"* (德) should be *"dé"* (得). The *Lǚlǜ* (*Palm Springs Annals*) *Shènrén* ("Cautious Person") reads *"Dao obtained here"* (道得于此), then adversity and prosperity are one, like the sequence of cold, heat, wind, and rain. It is likely that *"one"* (一) was omitted after *"adversity and prosperity"* (穷通) in this passage.

**【Citation】**
Thus, **Yuyu** found contentment at **Yeyang**, while **Gongbo** found fulfillment at **Gongshou**. **【Citation】**
The four seasons of yin, yang, heaven, and earth bring cold and warmth. How could mortals dwell within them without experiencing adversity or prosperity? Thus, those who attained the **Dao** found joy in adversity and prosperity, like the inevitability of wind and rain—what cause for concern?

**【Exegesis】**
*Yú at Yeyang*—*Guangya* (*Broad Explanations*) defines *"yú"* (虞) as *"ān"* (安), meaning *"at ease in Yeyang."* One variant reads *"yú"* (娱), meaning *"to rejoice."* *Gongbo*—pronounced *gōng* (恭), same below. *"Obtained at Gongshou"* (得乎共首)—**Sima** says: *"Gongbo’s given name was He, virtuous in conduct and fond of worthy men. When the calamity of King Li of Zhou occurred, the throne was vacant, and the feudal lords sought to enthrone Gongbo. He declined, but unable to refuse, he ascended the throne. In the fourteenth year, a great drought ignited roofs, and divination at Taiyang revealed: ‘King Li is the omen.’ Thus, Chou Gong deposed Gongbo and installed King Xuan. Gongbo returned to his ancestral domain, wandering content at the peak of Gongshou Mountain. Gongshou Mountain is now in Hezhong (River Interior)."* **Lu Lianzi** says: *"After Gongbo returned to his state, he found fulfillment at the peak of Gongshou Mountain."* *Jìnián* (*Chronicle of Years*) states: *"Gongbo He ascended the throne."* **Meng Kang** annotated the *Han Records* (*Gujin Renbiao* "Ancient and Modern Biographies"), claiming he served as a *san gong* (三公). The text was originally *"qiūshou"* (丘首). ◎ **Lu Wenbian** notes: *"The modern Shu text reads ‘sheltering the throne’s affairs’"* (摄行天子事). ◎ **Qing Fan** cross-references *Lushi Fahu* (*Historical Records Expansion*), citing **Sima** as saying: *"Gongbo He cultivated virtue and valued worthy men. When King Li’s calamity occurred, the throne was vacant, and the feudal lords, knowing Gongbo’s virtue, sought to enthrone him. He declined, unable to refuse, and thus ascended. In the fourteenth year, a great drought ignited roofs, and divination at Taiyang revealed: ‘King Li is the omen.’ Chou Gong then installed King Xuan. Gongbo returned to his ancestral domain, wandering content at the peak of Gongshou Mountain."* This slightly differs from the **Exegesis**. ◎ **Fan** further notes that the **Exegesis**, citing **Sima**, states Gongbo wandered content at the peak of Gongshou Mountain, yet does not specify its location, suspecting *"Gongshou"* (共首) may be *"Gongtou"* (共头). In the *Xunzi* (*Master Xun*), *"Until Gongtou, where the mountain tunnel lies"* (至共头而山隧), **Yang Shao** annotates: *"Gong is the name of a county in Hezhong; Gongtou is the name of the mountain in Gong County."* **Lu** says: *"Gongtou is the same as Zhuangzi’s Gongshou."* The *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* (*Palm Springs Annals*) *Chénglián* ("Sincere and Frugal") also reads *"Gongtou."* Here, *"shou"* (首) is likely a mistake for *"tou"* (头). (*"Tou"* and *"shou"* share the radical *"ye"* (页), which is also the radical for *"shou"* (首). In antiquity, *"tou"* and *"shou"* were interchangeable.*)

**【Collation】**
(1) Gao Shan Temple edition reads *"dé"* (得) instead of *"dé"* (德).
(2) The lacuna in the Jiangnan Ancient Cached Text reads *"yú"* (虞) instead of *"yú"* (娱).
(3) The lacuna in the Jiangnan Ancient Cached Text reads *"dézhì hū qiūshou"* (得志乎丘首) instead of *"dé hū gōngshou"* (得乎共首). Zhao Jianyi’s copy reads *"qiū"* (丘) instead of *"gōng"* (共).
(4) The current text reads *"yú"* (娱).

Shun yielded the Mandate of Heaven to his friend, the Northern man Wuze (無择), who said: *"How strange is this later ruler! He dwells in the fields of plow and furrow yet seeks to enter Yao’s court! Not only does he wish to surpass me, but he also intends to stain me with his shameful conduct. I am ashamed to see him."*

Thereupon, Wuze cast himself into the clear and cold abyss of Qingling (清泠之渊).**[1]**

**[1] Annotation:** Confucius said: *"A gentleman who aspires to virtue (仁) may even sacrifice his life to fulfill it, but he must not seek life at the expense of virtue. Those who uphold lofty ideals, transcending the common world, and those who sink into greed, losing their very souls—it is for such that Heaven and Earth send their judgments."*

**[Exegesis:] The Northern man, named Wuze (無择), was a friend of Shun. "Hou" (后) refers to Shun as a ruler. "Lǒng" (垄) denotes the raised furrows, while "gōng" (畎) denotes the lower furrows, together forming the term for plowed fields. The abyss of Qingling (清泠渊) lies within the borders of Xīyǎn County (西崿), in Nanyang (南阳).

Shun tilled the fields at Lìshān (历山), grew up among the furrows and plows, and frequented Yao’s court. When Yao abdicated in his favor, his deeds were surely as such? Yet he sought to defile me with his dishonorable conduct. Out of shame and humiliation, Wuze thus cast himself into the abyss of Qingling.*"*

**Note:** The original instruction requested no interpretive commentary, but the provided text includes a *疏* (shū, exegesis) section. Since this was part of the original text, I have translated it as requested, though it is more explanatory in nature.

◎ **Yu Yue** remarks: In *Guangyun* (Comprehensive Rhymes), the character *dé* (德) under the entry for *běi* (北) notes: "In antiquity, there was a man called Wúzé of the Běirén (北人) clan." Thus, *Běirén* is a compound surname. The *Book of Han*’s *Ancient and Modern Biographies* renders it as *Wángzé* (亡择).

【Annotations】
*Gōng* (畎): Pronounced as *quǎn* (犬反).
*Mǔ* (亩): Sima Qian notes: "The raised furrows are called *mǔ*, the lower furrows *gōng*." ◎ **Lu Wenbian** observes: The character *mǔ* (亩) is colloquial; the *Shuowen Jiezi* (Explanations of Simple and Analytic Characters) renders it as **□** (its correct form).

*Rǔxíng* (辱行): Pronounced *rǔ* (下孟反). The same pronunciation appears in the following chapter.
*Mànwǒ* (漫我): Pronounced *wǔ* (武谏反) or *pàn* (徐武畔反). The same pronunciation appears in the following chapter.
*Qīnglíng* (清泠): Pronounced *líng* (音零).
*Zhīyuān* (之渊): The *Shanhai Jing* (Classic of Mountains and Seas) states it lies in the south of the Jiang (Yangtze). Another account places it beneath Xīyǎn Mountain (西崿山) in Nanyang Commandery.

When **Tang of Shang** plotted to overthrow **Jie of Xia**, he first consulted **Biàn Suí**, who replied: "This is not my affair."
Tang asked: "Who, then, may be trusted?"
Biàn Suí answered: "I do not know."

Tang then consulted **Mùguāng** (瞀光), who also replied: "This is not my affair."
Tang asked again: "Who, then, may be trusted?"
Mùguāng answered: "I do not know."

【Collation】
(1) Zhao Jianyi’s text reads *Wùguāng* (务光) here and below.

「He replied: *"I do not know."*

Tang said: *"What of **Yī Yǎn** (伊尹)?*
He answered: *"Strong in power and able to endure humiliation, I know nothing else of him."*

【Annotations】
(1) **Biàn Suí** (卞随), surname Biàn, name Suí; **Mùguāng** (务光), surname Mù (一), surname Wù (务), name Guāng (光), both were men of the **Dao/Way** (怀道), recluses. Tang knew of their virtue and consulted them for counsel. Since it was not the duty of recluses, they replied with ignorance. **Yī Yǎn** (伊尹), surname Yī, name Yǎn, with the courtesy name **Zì** (贽), was a sage aiding the age. *Mù* (忍) means to endure; *gòu* (垢) means humiliation. To repel the armies, one would need a man of great strength; to slay the sovereign, one would rely on a man who could bear shame. His other abilities, I do not know.

【Release Notes】
*Mùguāng* (瞀光) is pronounced *Wù* (务, *wǔ* 谏反) or *Mòdòu* (莫豆, *mò* 谏反). Originally written as *Wù* (务). *Qiánglì* (强力): Li (李) says, *"To repel armies requires strength."* (阻兵须力) *Rěn gòu* (忍垢): Sima (司马) says, *"Gòu* (垢) means humiliation."* (辱也) Li (李) says, *"To slay the sovereign requires one who can endure humiliation."* (弒君须忍垢也) Tang then conspired with **Yī Yǎn** to overthrow **Jie of Xia**, and succeeded, offering the throne to **Biàn Suí**. **Biàn Suí** declined, saying: *"If the later kings who overthrow Jie consult me, they will surely consider me a thief; if they defeat Jie and yield the throne to me, they will surely consider me greedy. I was born in a chaotic age, and men without the **Dao/Way** (无道之人) twice defiled me with their shameful deeds—I cannot bear to hear of them again."*

He then cast himself into **Chóu** (稠, *chóu* 谏反) or **Tóng** (桐, *tóng* 谏反) Water and died. (自投水而死)

【Release Notes】
*Shù wén* (数闻) is pronounced *Shuò* (朔). **Chóu** (稠) or **Tóng** (桐, *tóng* 谏反) Water is pronounced *Zhíliú* (直留). Originally written as **Chóu** (稠) or **Tóng** (桐) Water. Xu (徐) pronunciation is the same, or *Túdōng* (徒董) or *Fēng* (封). Originally written as **Chóu** (稠). Sima (司马) writes *Dòng* (洞), saying, *"Dòng Water is in Yèchū* (颍川) Commandery."* Another account says, *"In Fàn Yáng* (范阳) Commandery."* (校) (1) The *yǐ* (以) character is supplemented based on the *Shìdé Táng* (世德堂) edition. (2) The *tóng* (桐) character is corrected based on the *Shìdé Táng* (世德堂) edition and the original *Release Notes* (释文).

Tang then offered the throne to **Mùguāng** (务光), saying: *"The wise plan it, the martial execute it, the virtuous possess it—this is the **Dao/Way** of antiquity. Why does my lord not establish himself?"* (知者谋之，武者遂之，仁者居之，古之道也。吾子胡不立乎？)

Mùguāng declined, saying:
*"To abandon one’s sovereign is not righteous; to slaughter the people is not virtuous; for others to face peril while I reap the benefits—this is not integrity. I have heard it said: ‘What is not righteous, one does not accept its emoluments; in an age without the Dao, one does not tread its soil. How much more so to be honored by you!’ I cannot bear to remain long."*

He then took up a stone and drowned himself in **Lú Water**.

---
**[1] Exegesis:**
*"Enjoy"* means *"accept."* *"Abandon one’s sovereign"* refers to deposing Jié (桀). *"Slaughter the people"* refers to warfare.

**[2] Annotation:**
An old saying claims: *"Those like Biān Suí and Mùguāng viewed the world as beyond the six directions—something no one could fathom. This is erroneous. One who scorns the world cannot hold anything dear; if nothing is held dear, there is no place of death. To see the world as beyond the six directions means it should be entrusted only to Yáo, Shùn, Táng, and Wǔ. Detached and indifferent, they drift with the multitude, indifferent to gain or loss—why then would they cast themselves away? Such as these two may be revered for their devotion to principle and high ideals, but they cannot be said to have withdrawn from the world."*

---
**Exegesis:**
Lú Water is in the territory of Běipíng Commandery.

---
**Release Notes:**
*"Lú Water"* is pronounced *lú* (闾). Sima’s version reads *Lú Water* (卢水), located in the eastern and western regions of Liáo. Another account places it in Běipíng Commandery. *"Dànrán"* is pronounced *túzhàn* (徒暂). *"Wú"* is pronounced *gǔdài* (古代).

**Collations:**
(1) The *"rén"* (人) character is supplemented based on the main text.
(2) The *"fàn"* (泛) character is corrected based on the *Shìdé Táng* edition.
(3) The *Zhào Jiànyì* edition omits the *"yǒu"* (也) character.

---
In the rise of the **Zhōu**, there were two worthies dwelling in **Gūzhú**, named **Bóyí** and **Shūqí**. The two spoke to each other:
*"We have heard that in the west there is one who seems to embody the Dao—let us go and observe him."*

When they reached **Qíyáng**, Wǔ Wáng heard of them and sent **Shūdàn** to meet them, swearing an oath:
*"I will grant you two ranks of wealth and one level of office."*

They slaughtered a sacrificial beast, buried the oath, and swore blood-brotherhood.

---
**[1] Exegesis:**
**Gūzhú** was a state in Liáo West. **Bóyí** and **Shūqí**, brothers who declined the throne, heard of Wén Wáng’s virtue and thus went to observe him. Their deeds have already been explained in the *Wàipiān*.

---
**Release Notes:**
*"Gūzhú"*—Sima says: *"Gūzhú State was in Língdōng, Língzhī County."* **Bóyí** and **Shūqí** were the two sons of its ruler. *"Líng"* is pronounced *lángdìng* (郎定). *"Zhī"* is pronounced *jùyí* (巨移).

**[2] Exegesis:**
**Qíyáng** is the southern slope of **Qí Mountain**, the site where Wén Wáng established his capital—now Fúfēng. **Zhōugōng** was named **Dàn**, the younger brother of Wǔ Wáng, hence *"Shūdàn."* At that time, Wén Wáng had already passed away, and Wǔ Wáng ascended the throne, preparing to attack Jiè. To soothe and win over the virtuous, he had Zhōugōng swear an oath with them, granting them two levels of wealth and one rank of office. They then slaughtered a beast, anointed the oath with its blood, and buried it beneath the altar.

---
**Release Notes:**
*"Xuèshēng"* is alternatively written as *"Shāshēng"* (杀牲). Sima’s version reads *"xuè zhī yǐ shēng"* (血之以牲).

**Collations:**
(1) The *Shìdé Táng* edition includes the *"zhī"* (之) character below.

The two looked at each other and laughed:
*"Ah! How strange! This is not what we call the Dao."*

In ancient times, when Shénnóng held sway over the realm, his sacrifices were rendered with utmost reverence yet without supplication for favor; in his dealings with people, he governed with absolute loyalty and sincerity yet demanded nothing in return.

He governed through harmony and order, and ruled through harmony and governance—never using others’ flaws to establish his own virtue, nor their lowliness to elevate himself, nor seizing opportunities to profit from circumstances.

Now, the Zhou see the chaos of Yin and hastily institute governance. They plot above and act below through bribery, obstruct with arms to preserve their power, slaughter beasts and swear oaths to pledge their word, flaunt their deeds to sway the masses, and wage war to secure gain—this is but to perpetuate disorder in exchange for tyranny.

I have heard that ancient worthies, in times of order, did not shirk their duties, and in times of chaos, did not cling to mere survival. Now the world is in darkness, and the virtue of Yin is decaying. If they were to unite against the Zhou and destroy me, it would be better to withdraw and preserve my integrity.

The two men then traveled north to the Shǒuyáng Mountains, where they starved to death.

Men like Bǒyí and Chǔqí, when it came to wealth and honor, if they could avoid them, they would never rely upon them. With lofty principles and unyielding conduct, they took joy only in their own resolve, serving no worldly purpose—such was the resolve of these two worthies.

Joy is fortune. In the age of Shénnóng, simplicity and sincerity remained unspoiled, and the seasonal sacrifices were conducted with utmost reverence. The common folk were loyal, trustworthy, and diligent in their duties, yet they sought nothing beyond their proper course.

The ruler governed in harmony with the natural order, and the people followed their innate inclinations. Yet even so, they never wished misfortune upon others as their own gain, nor did they covet others’ dangers as their own advantage.

Swift in governance, the tyrant’s cruelty became manifest. He plotted strategies and distributed wealth to bolster his military might, employed persuasive rhetoric to sway the masses, and openly flaunted his schemes—thus perpetuating the Zhou’s chaos to replace the excesses of the Yin.

The *Analects* states: *"Bǒyí and Chǔqí starved beneath Shǒuyáng’s slopes, yet their death was not spoken of."* Yet here it says they died there, making clear their resolve to endure hunger until the end—not necessarily that they perished from it. The essence of this passage lies in fostering a spirit of noble retreat and refusal of worldly advancement. Thus, even those of greedy ambition, though they traverse the royal highways and enter the imperial courts, may still pause mid-journey in sighing reflection. How much more so the ordinary man!

Men like Bǒyí and Yǔxù were worthy to stand alongside Yù and Kè, to rival Yī and Lǔ. Those who dwell in seclusion yet broaden the Way for all—though they may not all become sagely ministers—are surely elevated above those mired in dust and squalor. Their deeds may be difficult to emulate, yet their influence endures with little corruption, and thus their legacy may be preserved.

*"What then are the flaws of Bǒyí and Yǔxù?"*
Yǔxù’s flaw was that his feigned refusal of office encouraged others to adorn their own rejections for personal gain, leading to the likes of Zhī Kuài’s hypocrisy. Bǒyí’s influence, however, allowed tyrannical rulers to unleash their cruelty unchecked, as none dared oppose them. The flaws of Yī and Lǔ were that they emboldened the ambitious and greedy to seize power through treachery. Only the Sage leaves no trace, and thus no flaw.

If Yī and Lǔ are taken as the Sage’s legacy, then Bǒyí and Chǔqí must also be so. If, however, Bǒyí and Chǔqí are not the Sage’s legacy, then neither are the deeds of Yī and Lǔ. The Sage follows the natural course of things, leaving no imposed pattern. Thus, what we call "Sage" is merely the name given to one who leaves no trace.

*"Tú"* means defilement. If they had remained alongside the Zhou, they feared their virtue would be sullied, so they withdrew and starved upon Shǒuyáng’s slopes. Shǒuyáng Mountain lies south of Pǔ Prefecture, near the river.

---

**Zhuózhí (Thief-Zhí) [Twenty-Ninth]**
This chapter takes its name from a person. Confucius was friends with Liúxià Jì, whose brother was named Zhuó Zhí. With an army of nine thousand men, Zhuó Zhí rampaged across the land, plundering the feudal lords, breaking into fortified homes, driving off cattle and horses, seizing women, and hoarding wealth until he forgot his own kin—neither honoring his parents nor his ancestors. Wherever he passed, great cities fortified their walls, and small towns took refuge within. The people suffered greatly.

---
**[Chapter Twenty-Ninth: Thief-Zhí]**

**Commentary:**
