Surname Zhǎn (展), given name Qín (禽), courtesy name Jì (季), with the fief of Liǔxià (柳下) as his title—thus called Liǔxià Jì. Some say he dwelt beneath willow trees, hence his appellation. Zhǎn Qín lived during the reign of Duke Zhuāng of Lǔ (鲁庄公), roughly a century before Confucius. The mention of "friend" is likely metaphorical. Zhí (跖) was the name of Zhǎn’s brother, a notorious bandit, hence "Thief-Zhí."

He would **pierce holes in dwellings** and **unfasten door hinges**, seizing others’ cattle and horses. Some manuscripts read "空" (empty) or "驱" (drive) instead. *Bǎo* (保) refers to small fortified towns. His depredations were so vast that the common folk **suffered greatly** from them.

**Collation Notes:**
(《释文》) In *"Confucius and Liǔxià Jì as Friends"*, Liǔxià Huì (柳下惠) is surnamed Zhǎn (展), given name Huò (获), courtesy name Jì Qín (季禽). Some say his courtesy name was Zǐ Qín (子禽), and that he resided in Liǔxià while bestowing virtue and benevolence. Others claim *Huì* (惠) was his posthumous title, or that Liǔxià was the name of his fief. According to the *Zuòzhuan* (左传), Zhǎn Qín was a man of Duke Lǐ of Lǔ (鲁僖公), living **over eighty years before Confucius**, and if counted until Zǐlù’s death (子路之死), **over a century and a half**—thus, the term "friend" is metaphorical.

*Zhí* (跖) is read with the *shǐ* (石) radical. Lǐ Qí (李奇) annotated the *Hànshū* (汉书), stating that Zhí was a great bandit of the state of Qín (秦). **Yú Yì** (俞樾) notes that the *Zhèngyì* (正义) of the *Shǐjì* (史记) *Bóyí Transcription* (伯夷传) also claims Zhí was a great bandit of the Yellow Emperor’s time. The exact era of Zhí remains undetermined. Confucius did not contemporaneously know Liǔxià Huì, nor did Liǔxià Huì know Thief-Zhí; readers should not take this as literal history.

*"From"* (从) is pronounced *cóng* (才用反).
*"Coercive force"* (卒) is pronounced *zú* (尊忽反).
Below follows the same pronunciation.

*"Hinged doors"* (枢户) is pronounced *shūhù* (尺朱反), *kǔgōu* (徐苦沟反).
Sīmǎ (司马) explains: "To break into others’ homes by unfastening their door hinges and seizing their goods."

*Rú* (入) *bǎo* (保) is annotated in the *Lǐjì* (礼记) by Zhèng (郑): "Small fortified towns are called *bǎo*."

**Textual Correction:**
(一) The erroneous manuscript mistakenly cites Liú Dé (刘得) as reading *gōu* (枢) instead of *kǎo* (抠).

Confucius said to Liǔxià Jì:
*"As a man’s father, he must command his son;
as a man’s elder brother, he must instruct his younger brother.
If a father cannot command his son,
or an elder brother cannot instruct his younger brother,
then the bonds of father-son and brotherly love are lost.
Now, Master, you are a man of talent in the world—
yet your younger brother is Thief-Zhí,
a scourge to all under heaven,
and you cannot instruct him.
I, Zǐ (丘), am ashamed for you.
I beg to go and persuade him on your behalf."*

Liǔxià Jì replied:
*"Master says that as a man’s father he must command his son,
and as a man’s elder brother he must instruct his younger brother.
But if a son does not obey his father’s command,
or a younger brother does not accept his elder brother’s instruction,
even if you, Master, were to employ your eloquence,
what could you do to **subdue him**?
Moreover, Zhí’s nature is like a **gushing spring**—
his thoughts like a **whirling wind**,
his strength sufficient to **repel enemies**,
his words sufficient to **adorn wrongdoing**.
To act in accordance with his desires brings joy;
to oppose his desires brings wrath.
He is easily **provoked by words**.
Master, you must not go."*

Confucius refused to heed the warning, and Yán Huí drove the carriage while Zǐgōng sat at his right. They went to see Zhí.

Zhí was just then resting his soldiers on the southern slope of Dàshān, slicing men’s livers to eat raw. When Confucius stepped down from his carriage and approached, he addressed the attendant:

*"A man from Lǔ, Kǒng Qiū, has heard of your noble virtue and respectfully bows twice to announce himself."*

Zǐgōng rode beside him in the carriage.

The attendant led them in, and when Zhí heard of their arrival, he flew into a rage. His eyes blazed like stars, his hair bristled beneath his cap, and he shouted:

*"Is this not that cunning deceiver from Lǔ, Kǒng Qiū? Tell him this: ‘You fabricate words and contrive speeches, falsely invoking the names of Wǔ and Wǔ【一】. You wear a cap of twisted wood, gird yourself with the flank of a dead ox, spout empty rhetoric, eat without tilling, clothe yourself without weaving, wagging your lips and beating your tongue to stir up strife—you mislead the rulers of the world, causing scholars to abandon their roots and blindly chase titles and wealth under the pretense of filial piety and fraternal duty【三】. Your crimes are grave and extreme—be gone at once! Otherwise, I shall add your liver to my daily meal!’"*

*"【One】【Commentary】* The Sage Confucius followed the constitutional models of Wǔ and Wǔ【一】, tracing his lineage to Yáo and Shùn, refining rites and music, and leaving his legacy for posterity.

*【Explanation of Text】* *‘*发上*’* should be read with the tone reversed. *‘*此夫*’* is pronounced *fǔ*, also read as *cǐfú*.

*【Two】【Commentary】* *‘*胁*’* means *‘*rib*’*—the cap worn by the Master bore elaborate, ornate decorations, its leaves dense and flourishing like branches of a tree. Moreover, he used oxhide for his belt, broad and sturdy, resembling the ribs of an ox.

*【Explanation of Text】* *‘*冠*’* is read with an ancient reversed tone. *‘*枝木之冠*’* is read as-is. Sīmǎ [司马] says: ‘The cap is adorned with extravagant embellishments, like the branching of a tree.’ *‘*带死牛之胁*’* is pronounced *jié* [劫]. Sīmǎ says: ‘He took oxhide to make a wide, thick belt.’

*【Three】【Commentary】* *‘*儌幸*’* means *‘*to hope in vain*’*—to feign filial piety and fraternal duty while secretly aspiring to titles and wealth. Thus, though he repeatedly sought office, he was mocked by Jiēyú with *‘*Fèng fèng*’* [凤兮]; abandoning his roots and lingering in superficial pursuits, he earned the scorn of Zhī Jīn’s *‘*chúgǒu*’* [刍狗] reproach."

「【Explanation of Text】 *Móushuō* is pronounced *miù*. *Xiàodì* is pronounced *tì*. The original also reads *tì* [悌].
*Ér miù* is pronounced with the ancient *Yáo* tone. ◎Yú Yì says: *ji* [极] should be *zhì* [殛]. The *Er Yá* ["Explanations of Words"] states: *zhì* means *zhū* [诛, "to punish"]. It refers to a grave crime deserving severe punishment. *Ji* and *zhì* were anciently interchangeable. In the *Shū* ["Classic of Documents"], the *Hóngfàn* ["Flood Control"] chapter states *Gǔn zé zhì sǐ* ["Gun was punished and put to death"], the *Duōshì* ["Many Ministers"] chapter states *dàfá zhì zhī* ["great punishment was inflicted upon him"], in the *Lǐzhēng* ["Spring and Autumn Annals"] *Lǐ* 28th year, it says *míng shén zhì zhī* ["the divine punishment was clear"], and in the *Zhāo* 7th year, the *Zhuàn* ["Commentary"] states *xī Yáo zhì Gǔn yú Yǔshān* ["Emperor Yao punished Gun at Yǔ Mountain"]. The *Shìwén* ["Explanations"] all say: *zhì* was originally *ji* [极].

【Collation】
(1) Zhào Jiànyì’s [赵谏议] copy reads *dì* [弟] as *tì* [悌].
(2) Zhào’s copy reads *pú* [餔] as *fǔ* [脯].

Confucius replied to *Fùtōng* ["Complex Communication"]: *“Chóu dé xìng yú Jì, yuàn wàng lǚ mù xià.”* ["I have been fortunate to associate with my elder brother, wishing only to gaze upon his footsteps beneath the curtain."]

【Commentary】
He speaks of his fortune in associating with his virtuous elder brother, yet dared not look upon his face directly—only wishing to observe his footsteps beneath the curtain. Some versions read *qí* [綦] instead. *Qí* means "footprints," so "wishing to follow his footsteps" is akin to "looking at his feet."

【Explanation of Text】
*Fùtōng* is pronounced *fúyòu* [扶又], the same below. *Yuàn wàng lǚ mù xià* ["wishing to gaze upon his footsteps beneath the curtain"]—Sīmǎ’s [司马] text reads *qí* [綦] for *mù* ["curtain"], saying: "He dared not look upon the sole of his foot, only gazing at the laces and turning away."

【Collation】
(1) Zhào Jiànyì’s copy has *rán* ["thus"] after *xìng* ["fortunate"]. The *Yèzhě* ["Attendant"] *Fùtōng* ["Complex Communication"] stole *Zhízhé* ["Zhizi"]’s words, saying: *“Shǐ lái qián!”* ["Let him come forward!"]’»

Confucius hurried forward and advanced, then stepped back and withdrew, twice bowing before **Zhizi** the Bandit.

**Zhizi** the Bandit flew into a great rage, stretching out both his feet, gripping his sword, and glaring with eyes like a snarling tiger, he roared: *“Chou, come forward! If what you say pleases my will, you shall live; if it displeases my heart, you shall die.”*

【Explanation of Text】
*Hurry forward* (*qū ér jìn* 趋而进): swift movement. *Step back and withdraw* (*fǎn zǒu* 反走): retreat. *Stretching out both his feet* (*liǎng zhǎn qí zú* 两展其足): extending both legs.

【Collation】
(1) *Zhào Jiànyì*’s copy has *rán* ["thus"] after *zhǐ* ["only"]. The *Fùtōng* ["Complex Communication"] text reads: *“Chou, come forward! If what you say aligns with my desires, you shall live; if it opposes my wishes, you shall die.”* I have omitted the *rán* ["thus"] here.

*Swift movement* (*qū* 趋): swift walking.
*Retreat* (*fǎn zǒu* 反走): slight backward movement. ◎*Qīngfān*’s annotation in *Wénxuǎn* ["Literary Selections"] on *Xié Língyùn*’s ["Xie Lingyun"] poem *Cóngjīn* ["From Jin"] (with commentary on *jìn* ["walking"] and *zǒu* ["marching"] in the bamboo grove, crossing mountains, and traveling along streams) cites *Sīmǎ* ["Sima"] as saying: *zhǎn* ["exhibit"] means *shēn* ["extend"]. The *Shìwén* ["Explanation of Text"] is missing.

*Glaring* (*chēn* 瞋): pronounced *chìzhēn* ["赤真"] or *xúchìyí* ["徐赤夷"].
*Guǎngyǎ* ["Comprehensive雅"] says: *zhǎng* ["spread open"].

*Like a snarling tiger* (*rú rǔhǔ* 如乳虎): pronounced *rú shùhǔ* ["如树虎"].

Confucius said: *“Chou, I have heard that there are three kinds of **virtue/power** (*dé* 德) in the world: to be born and grow tall, beautiful and peerless, such that the young and old, noble and humble, all take pleasure in seeing you—this is the highest **virtue/power** (*shàngdé* 上德); to understand the **Dao/Way** (*wéi* 维) of Heaven and Earth, and to be able to distinguish among all things—this is the middle **virtue/power** (*zhōngdé* 中德); to be bold and resolute, gathering the people and leading armies—this is the lowest **virtue/power** (*xiàdé* 下德). For a person to possess even one of these three **virtues/power** (*dé* 德), he is sufficient to rule the south and claim sovereignty. Now, General, you possess all three of these **virtues/power** (*dé* 德): your stature is eight *chǐ* [尺] two *cùn* [寸] tall, your face and eyes radiant, your lips like red cinnabar, your teeth like polished seashells, and your voice harmonizes with the yellow bell. Yet you are known as **Zhizi** the Bandit—Chou privately feels shame for you and does not accept this name. If the General has the intention of listening to me, I request to dispatch envoys south to **Wu** and **Yue**, north to **Qi** and **Lu**, east to **Song** and **Wei**, and west to **Jin** and **Chu**. I will have them construct for the General a great walled city hundreds of *lǐ* [里] in circumference, establish towns with tens of thousands of households, and elevate the General as a **sovereign** (*zhūhóu* 诸侯). Together with the world, we will begin anew, disband the armies, and rest the soldiers. We will gather and nourish our brothers and younger siblings, and together honor our ancestors. This is the conduct of **sages** (*shèngrén* 圣人) and **talented scholars** (*cáishì* 才士), and the wish of the world.”*

「【One】【Commentary】 *Jī* (激) means "bright" or "illustrious." *Bèi* (贝) refers to "pearls." *Huángzhōng* (黄钟) is the name of one of the six *lǜ* (律) pitches in the ancient Chinese musical system.

The Bandit—Chou is deeply ashamed for you and does not accept this name. If the General truly possesses these three qualities—your stature of eight *chǐ* (尺) and two *cùn* (寸), your radiant visage, your lips like vermilion, your teeth like pearls, and your voice resonating with the pitch of *Huángzhōng*—yet bears the name "Bandit—Chou," then I, Chou, am ashamed and refuse to acknowledge it.

The General, if you have the intention of listening to me, I request to dispatch envoys south to **Wu** and **Yue**, north to **Qi** and **Lu**, east to **Song** and **Wei**, and west to **Jin** and **Chu**. I will have them construct for the General a great walled city hundreds of *lǐ* [里] in circumference, establish towns with tens of thousands of households, and elevate the General as a **sovereign** (*zhūhóu* 诸侯). Together with the world, we will begin anew, disband the armies, and rest the soldiers. We will gather and nourish our brothers and younger siblings, and together honor our ancestors. This is the conduct of **sages** (*shèngrén* 圣人) and **talented scholars** (*cáishì* 才士), and the wish of the world.

**The Bandit—Chou** roared in fury: "Come here, Chou! Those who can be swayed by profit and admonished with words are nothing but the foolish and common people! Now, my great stature and fine appearance, which others see and delight in, are the virtues bestowed by my parents. Even if you, Chou, do not praise me, can I not know myself? Moreover, I have heard that those who flatter others to their face often slander them behind their backs. Now you speak to me of great cities and countless people—this is to sway me with profit, as if the common people would raise me to endure forever! How can such a thing last long? The greatest cities are those that encompass the entire world. **Emperor Yao** and **Emperor Shun** ruled the world, yet their descendants had not even a place to insert a needle; **King Tang** and **King Wu** established themselves as **sovereigns** (*tiānzǐ* 天子), yet their posterity perished utterly. Is this not because their gains were too great?【One】【Commentary】 Speaking of great cities and countless people, implying that such prosperity cannot last long.

【Commentary】 The descendants of Yao and Shun were deprived of the throne because Yao passed it to Shun instead of his own son, **Dan Zhu** (丹朱), and Shun, in turn, passed it to **Yu** (禹), leaving no heir in the **Xia** (夏) and **Shang** (商) lineages.

【Commentary】 The descendants of the **Shang Dynasty** (商) and **Zhou Dynasty** (周) rulers, **King Tang** (汤) and **King Wu** (武), though they once held supreme authority, later faced usurpation and assassination. Is this not the consequence of the heavy burden of **prosperity** (*lì* 利) upon the **Four Seas** (四海) bringing about their downfall?

Furthermore, I have heard that in ancient times, wild beasts were numerous while humans were few. Thus, people lived in tree nests to avoid them, gathering acorns and chestnuts by day and resting in the trees by night. Hence, they were called **"Youchao’s people"** (*yǒuchāo* 有巢氏之民). In those days, people did not know clothing, so in summer they piled firewood, and in winter they burned it. Hence, they were called **"Zhisheng’s people"** (*zhīshēng* 知生之民). In the era of **Shennong** (神农), when people lay down they did so in comfort, and when they rose they were contented【One】, knowing only their mothers, not their fathers, living alongside deer and elk, tilling the land for food and weaving for clothing, without any intent to harm one another. This was the peak of **virtue** (*dé* 德).

Yet, **Huangdi** (黄帝) could not uphold **virtue** (*dé* 德), and fought against **Xiyu** (蚩尤) in the wilds of **Zhuolu** (涿鹿), spilling blood for a hundred *lǐ* [里]. **Yao** and **Shun** appointed ministers【Three】, **Tang** overthrew his ruler【Four】, and **King Wu** killed **King Zhou** (纣).【Five】 From that point onward, the strong oppressed the weak, and the many tyrannized the few. Since **Tang** and **Wu**, all have been disruptors of the people.【Six】」

「【One】【Commentary】 *Jūjū* (居居), the bearing of tranquility. *Yúyú* (于于), the appearance of self-contentment. 【Exegesis】 *Yú* (于) as in *Shāng* (橡), pronounced like *xiàng* (象). *Yú* (于) as in *Yáng* (炀), pronounced *yángliàng* (羊亮反).
◎ *Qìng Fān* notes that *yúyú* conveys vastness. In *Fāngyán* (方言), *yú* means "great."
In the *Rites of King Wén’s Heir*, where it says, *"Yú yú at his own person to better his lord,"* Zheng Xuan’s commentary reads: *"Yú is read as yú (迂),"* meaning expansive, vast.
In *Tán Gōng* (檀弓), *"Yú yú"* is explained in the *Zhèngyì* (正义) as also training *yú* in vastness. *Yúyú* is a reduplication.

【Two】【Commentary】 *Zhì* (至), meaning to attain. *Xīyú* (蚩尤), a feudal lord. *Zhuólù* (涿鹿), a place name—today’s *Yōuzhōu* (幽州) *Zhuó Commandery* (涿郡). *Xīyú* invented the Five Weapons and fought *Huángdì*, thus spilling blood for a hundred *lǐ*.
【Exegesis】 *Xīyú*, a feudal lord in *Shénnóng’s* era, the first to forge weapons. *Shénnóng’s* eighth successor was *Yúwàng* (榆罔). In *Xīyú’s* time, his clan grew strong, and he contested kingship with *Yúwàng*, driving him out. *Yúwàng* allied with *Huángdì* to slay *Xīyú*.
The *Hànshū Yīnyì* (汉书音义) states: *"Xīyú was an ancient sovereign."* Another account says: *"A greedy commoner."* *Zhuólù* (涿鹿), pronounced *zhuó* (卓). Also written as *Zhuó* (浊). Sima Qian notes: *"Zhuólù, a place name—its ancient city lies eighty *lǐ* southwest of today’s *Shànggǔ Commandery* (上谷郡)."*

【Three】【Commentary】 The appointment of a hundred officials.

【Four】【Commentary】 The exile of *Jiè* (桀) to *Náncháo* (南巢).

【Five】【Commentary】 The Battle of *Cháogē* (朝歌).

【Exegesis】 *"Wǔwáng shā"* (武王杀), pronounced *shì* (试). Same below.

【Six】【Commentary】 *Tāng* and *Wǔ* waged wars of conquest and regicide, their depravity unmatched. Now you, claiming to uphold the *Wén* and *Wǔ* **Way**, wielding the nation’s discourse to teach posterity, yet stitching coarse robes and binding narrow sashes, feigning speech and conduct to deceive the sovereign—seeking only wealth and honor—what greater thief than you? Why does the world not call you *Thief Qiú* (盗丘), yet brands me as *Thief Zhí* (盗跖)?

【One】【Commentary】 *Kǒngzǐ* modeled himself on *Wén* and *Wǔ*, elucidating *rén* (仁) and *yì* (义) as doctrine for posterity.

【Two】【Commentary】 You tailor shabby, narrow garments, feigning words and deeds to mislead the feudal lords—your harm surpasses even *Zhí* (跖).

【Exegesis】 *"Féng yī"* (缝衣), also written as *féng* (缝), pronounced *fúgōng* (扶恭反) or *fúgōng* (徐扶公反), also *féng* (冯).
◎ *Lú Wénpiàn* (卢文弨) notes: *"Modern texts write *féngyī* (缝衣)."*
◎ *Qìng Fān* cites *Xiàng Xiù* (向秀): *"Confucian robes were wide and long."* (From *Lièzǐ*’s *Huángdì* chapter.)
The *Shìwén* (释文) notes *féng* (摓) also written as *féng* (缝). *Féngyī* (缝衣), a large robe. Sometimes written as *féng* (逢); in *Hóngfàn* (洪范), *"Zǐsūn qí féngjí"* (子孙其逢吉), *Mǎ Róng* (马融) annotates: *"Féng means ‘great.’"*
In *Lǐ* (礼), *"Rúxíng féngyè zhī yī"* (儒行逢掖之衣), Zheng Xuan notes: *"Féng means ‘great.’"*
In *Xúnzǐ*’s *Fēi Shíèr Zǐ* (非十二子), *"Qí yī féng"* (其衣逢), and in *Rúxiào* (儒效), *"Féngyī qiǎndài"* (逢衣浅带), *Yáng Bīn* (杨注) states: *"Féng means ‘great.’"* Also abbreviated as *bó* (博); in *Mòzǐ*’s *Gōng Mèng* (公孟), *"Yī bó páo"* (衣博袍), where *bó* also means "great."
(*Jíyùn*: *Féng* (缝), sometimes abbreviated as *féng* (逢). In *Hàn Dānyáng Tàishǒu Guī Mǐn* (汉丹阳太守郭旻碑), *"Mǐn kǒu"* (弥衮口) is the character *féng* (缝).)
*Qiǎndài* (浅带): making the sash narrow and shallow.
*Jiǎoyán* (矫言), pronounced *jǐbiǎo* (纪表反).
You, with sweet words, persuaded *Zǐlú* (子路) to follow you, urging him to remove his tall crown and unsheathe his long sword to receive your teaching—yet the world declares *Kǒng Qiū* (孔丘) could curb violence and forbid wrong.
But in the end, *Zǐlú* sought to kill the ruler of *Wèi* (卫), the deed failed, and he was flayed alive at *Wèi’s* eastern gate—proving your teaching fell short.

【One】【Commentary】 A tall, dangerous crown and a long sword were the garb of the bold. Having submitted to *Kǒng* (孔), he discarded them.

【Exegesis】 *"Shuō Zǐlú"* (说子路), pronounced *shǐruì* (始锐反), also as written.
*"Qù qí"* (去其), pronounced *qǐlǚ* (起吕反).
*"Wēiguān"* (危冠), *Lǐ* (李) notes: *"Wēi means ‘high.’"* *Zǐlú* loved valor, his crown resembling a rooster’s crest, his back bearing a *fúdòu* (豭斗)—a boar’s tusk—to display his strength.
◎ *Lú Wénpiàn* notes: *"The *Shūyì* (书义) writes *fúdòu* (豭斗); the *Shǐjì* (史记) has *pèifúdùn* (佩豭豚)."*

【Two】【Commentary】 *Zhòngyóu* (仲由) detested evil with fierce resolve. He killed *Wèi’s* ruler *Kuǎi Dān* (蒯瞶), but the deed failed, and he was flayed—*Zhí* (跖) thus mocks him.

【Exegesis】 *"Qí cù"* (其卒), pronounced *zǐxù* (子恤反).
*"Shēn zhuó"* (身菹), pronounced *zhuāngjū* (庄居反).
【Collation】 (1) *Dòu* (斗) corrected based on *Shìdétáng* edition and *Shìwén* verification.

Do you claim to be a sage or a wise man?
Yet you were twice exiled from *Lǔ* (鲁), banished from *Wèi* (卫), impoverished in *Qí* (齐), besieged in *Chén-Cài* (陈蔡), finding no place in the world. You taught *Zǐlú* to suffer this fate—unable to protect himself or others—how noble is your **Way**?

The world holds *Huángdì* in highest regard, yet even he could not preserve **virtue** (*dé*), fighting at *Zhuólù* and spilling blood for a hundred *lǐ*.
*Yáo* was not filial,
*Shùn* was not pious,
*Yǔ* was one-sided and crippled,
*Tāng* exiled his lord,
*Wǔwáng* slew *Zhòu*,
*Wénwáng* was imprisoned at *Yǔlǐ* (羑里).
These six—whom the world extols—who examines them finds they were all seduced by self-interest, distorting truth and perverting nature. Their deeds are shameful indeed.

【One】【Commentary】 He refused to cede the throne to *Dānjú* (丹朱).

【Exegesis】 *"Wéi"* (以为), pronounced *yúwěi* (于伪反), same below.
*"Yáo bù cí"* (尧不慈): he did not pass the throne to his son.

【Two】【Commentary】 He was hated by his father.

「【Three】【Exegesis】 He labored tirelessly to tame the waters, enduring winds like combing one’s hair and rains like bathing, thus contracting the affliction of *piāncuì* (偏枯), rendering half his body paralyzed.

【Four】【Exegesis】 *Yǔlǐ* (羑里) is the name of a prison in the *Yīn* (殷) dynasty. *Wénwáng* (文王) endured the calamity of *Zhòu* (纣), confined in prison for seven years before finally being released.

【Exegesis】 *"Wénwáng jū yǔlǐ"* (文王拘羑里): In the *Zhòu* dynasty’s 20th year, *Zhòu* imprisoned *Wénwáng*.

【Five】【Exegesis】 The six "sages" refer to *Huángdì* (黄帝), *Yáo* (尧), *Shùn* (舜), *Yǔ* (禹), *Tāng* (汤), and *Wénwáng* (文王). All were seduced by the pursuit of *wànshèng* (万乘), thus losing their **Dao/Way** (*zhēndào* 真道) and forcibly defying nature (*zìrán* 自然). Hence, their conduct is truly shameful.

【Exegesis】 *"Ér qiǎng"* (而强): Pronounced *qǐqiǎng* (其强反).
*"Kěxiū"* (可羞): As written.
The original also reads *"kě'è"* (可恶), pronounced *wūlù* (乌路反).

【Correction】 (One) The *Jiāngnán Gǔzàng* (江南古藏) edition mistakenly cites six as seven.

The so-called **virtuous/accomplished men** (*xiánshì* 贤士) of the world are *Bòyī* (伯夷) and *Shúqí* (叔齐). *Bòyī* and *Shúqí* declined the throne of *Gūjǔ* (孤竹之君) and starved to death on *Shǒuyáng* (首阳) Mountain, their bones left unburied. *Bàojiāo* (鲍焦), by name, was a recluse of the *Zhōu* (周) era. He adorned his conduct with what was not of the world, carrying burdens while gathering firewood, and gathering acorns for food. Thus, he had no descendants, did not serve the Son of Heaven, nor befriend the feudal lords.

*Shēntú Dí* (申徒狄) remonstrated yet was not heeded, and so he took a stone and cast himself into the river, where he was eaten by fish. *Jièzǐ Tuī* (介子推) was supremely loyal, cutting off his own thigh to feed *Wén Gōng* (文公). Later, when *Wén Gōng* failed to acknowledge him, *Jièzǐ Tuī* grew angry and departed, perishing by fire while embracing a tree. *Wěishēng* (尾生) made an appointment with a woman beneath a bridge, but when she failed to come and the waters rose, he did not leave, and so died clinging to the bridge’s pillar.

These six **virtuous/accomplished men** (子者), no different from those who flay dogs or drive pigs to market while begging in broken pots, all abandoned reputation (*lì* 离) for a light death (*qīngsǐ* 轻死), unmindful of their own nurture and life span.

【One】【Exegesis】 The two died in poverty on *Shǒuyáng* Mountain, and no descendants buried them. *Bàojiāo* (鲍焦), whose surname is *Bào* (鲍), was a recluse of the *Zhōu* (周) era. He adorned his conduct with what was not of the world, maintaining strict integrity in his conduct. He carried burdens while gathering firewood, and collected acorns to fill his stomach. Thus, he had no descendants, did not serve the Son of Heaven, nor befriend the feudal lords. When *Zǐgòng* (子贡) encountered him, he said: "I have heard that one should not tread upon land whose government is not just, nor accept benefits from a ruler who is unworthy. Now you tread upon this land and accept its benefits—is this acceptable?" *Bàojiāo* replied: "I have heard that a **virtuous/accomplished man** (*liánshì* 廉士) values advancement while scornful of retreat, and the **wise** (*xiánrén* 贤人) feels shame easily but scorns death lightly." He then embraced a tree and stood until he withered away.

【Two】【Exegesis】 *Shēntú* (申徒) drowned himself; this has already been explained in the previous section. He remonstrated yet was not heeded, though it is unclear what his specific argument was. *Cuī Jiā* (崔嘉), though understanding, had no precise words of remonstrance.

【Exegesis】 *"Fù shí zì tóu yú hé"* (负石自投于河): *Shēntú Dí* (申徒狄) was about to cast himself into the river, when *Cuī Jiā* (崔嘉) stopped him, saying: "I have heard that a **sage** (*shèngrén* 圣人), a **virtuous/accomplished man** (*rénshì* 仁士), and a father of the people should not, even if their feet were wet, fail to rescue a drowning person—is this acceptable?" *Shēntú Dí* replied: "No. In ancient times, *Jié* (桀) killed *Lóngféng* (龙逢), and *Zhòu* (纣) killed *Bǐgān* (比干), and yet they lost their kingdoms;

「Wú killed Zǐxú, Chén killed Xiè Zhì, and yet their kingdoms were extinguished.
It was not that the sages were without virtue—it was because they were not employed.»

Thus, he drowned himself in the river and died.

【Three】【Exegesis】
Jìn Wén Gōng (晋文公, the Duke of Jin) was Wén Chǒu (重耳), who, fleeing the *Lì Jī* (骊姬) calamity, wandered to other states. Stricken by hunger along the way, he sliced his own thigh to feed his followers. Three days after his return, when he bestowed fiefs upon his retainers, he forgot Zǐtuī (子推). Zǐtuī composed the *Lóngshé* (龙蛇) ode, inscribed it upon his gate, and in fury fled. The Duke, ashamed and remorseful, pursued Zǐtuī to Jiè Shān (介山). Zǐtuī concealed himself, so the Duke set fire to the mountain, hoping he would emerge. When the flames reached him, Zǐtuī embraced a tree and burned to death.

【Release Text】
*"Yǐ shí"* (以食): pronounced *sì* (嗣).
*"Fán sǐ"* (燔死): pronounced *fán* (烦), meaning "to burn."

◎ *Qìng Fān* (庆藩) notes in the *Zuǒzhuan* (左传): "Jiè Zhītuī (介之推) spoke not of rewards, and rewards did not reach him." It further states: "The Duke of Jìn sought him but could not find him, so he granted him the fields of *Miánshàng* (绵上), saying: 'To mark my guilt and to honor the virtuous.'" The *Lǚshuō* (吕览) records: "Jiètuī carried a pot and a mat, unseen all his life." The *Shǐjì* (史记) states: "When messengers summoned him, he fled. It was heard that he had entered the mountains of *Miánshàng*, so the Duke enclosed those mountains and granted them as *Jiètuī Tián* (介推田), naming it *Jiè Shān* (介山). A thorough examination of the classics reveals no account of Jiètuī burning to death. The tale of *lìkū* (立枯) originated with *Qū Yú* (屈子) [(see *Chūyī Jiǔzhōu* (楚辞九章·惜往日): *Jiè Zǐtuī ér lìkū* (介子推而立枯兮))], while *Zhuāngzi* (庄生) introduced the account of burning death [(as noted in *Yóngzhāi Sānbǐ* (容斋三笔), which mistakenly attributes it to *Xīnxù* (新序), but this is incorrect)]. *Dōngfāng Shùo* (东方朔) in his *Qī Jiàn* (七谏) and the *Hànshū* (汉书) in the *Jǐng Jí* (丙吉) transmission all perpetuated this error. Now, we must correct it with the accounts from the *Zuǒzhuan* and *Lǚshuō*.」

「**Chapter Four: Commentary**

The Six Sons (六子) refer to **Bóyí** (伯夷), **Shūqí** (叔齐), **Báojiāo** (鲍焦), **Shēntú** (申徒), **Jiètuī** (介推), and **Wěishēng** (微生). These six men did not align with the **Dao/Way** (玄道), instead contorting their emotions and feigning conduct to stand out from common customs, thereby gaining fame and passing it down through the ages. What difference is there between them and **Zhāng Zhì** (张磔), who was flayed alive like a dog, drifting in water, or a destitute beggar carrying a gourd to beg for alms? Such trifling figures are not worthy of mention or hearing. The actions of these Six Sons are identical to these: all are those who value fame over life, neglecting to return to their roots and nurture their existence, failing to fulfill their natural lifespan. The character *豕* (shǐ) can also be read as *死* (sǐ), and *乞* (qǐ) can also be read as *走* (zǒu); *随* (suí) is read as above.

**Explanation of Text:**
The *Wěishēng* (微生) passage is also written as *Wěishēng* (尾生).
In the *Strategies of the Warring States* (战国策), **Wěishēng Gāo** (尾生高) is recorded, with **Gāo Yù** (高诱) identifying him as a man from **Lǔ** (鲁).
*磔* (zhì) is pronounced *Zhì* (竹客反).
The *Guǎngyǎ* (广雅) states: "To flay" (张).
*操* (cāo) is pronounced *Qiūcāo* (七曹反).
*瓢* (piáo) is pronounced *Píyáo* (婢遥反).
The phrase *而乞者* (ér qǐ zhě) is interpreted by **Lǐ** (李) as: "These four above did not meet their proper ends, just like pigs, dogs, and beggars wandering in ditches."
*乞* (qǐ) can also be written as *走* (zǒu).
*离名* (lín míng) is pronounced *Lìzhì* (力智反).
*本* (běn) can also be written as *卒* (zú).

**Corrections:**
(1) In the **Shìdé Táng** (世德堂) edition, the characters **Bóyí Shūqí** (伯夷叔齐) are not repeated.
(2) A missing character: *六* (liù) was mistakenly written as *四* (sì); the **Jiāngnán Gǔzàng** (江南古藏) edition states: *四* (sì) should be *六* (liù).
(3) A missing character: **Zhāng Jūnfáng** (张君房) edition has *利* (lì) instead of *离* (lí).

Among those called **loyal ministers** (忠臣) in the world, none surpass **Wángzǐ Bǐgān** (王子比干) and **Wǔzǐ Shū** (伍子胥).
**Wǔzǐ Shū** drowned in the river, **Bǐgān** had his heart carved out—these two are deemed loyal ministers by the world, yet they ultimately became the laughingstock of all under heaven.

**Chapter One: Commentary**
From the perspective of the **Dao/Way**, down to **Wǔzǐ Shū** and **Bǐgān**, none are truly worthy of veneration.

**Chapter One: Explanation of Text**
They are objects of scorn for those who follow the **Dao/Way**.

**Explanation of Text:**
*剖心* (pōu xīn) is pronounced *Pòkǒu* (普口反).

The reason **Qióng** (丘) speaks to me is this: if one tells me of matters concerning **ghosts** (鬼), I cannot understand them; but if one tells me of human affairs, they are no more than these examples—all of which I know and have heard. Now, I speak to you of human desires: the eyes wish to see colors, the ears wish to hear sounds, the mouth wishes to savor flavors, and the **spirit-qi** (志气) seeks fulfillment. Among humans, the upper limit of lifespan is a hundred years, the middle eighty, and the lower sixty. Subtracting the time lost to illness, emaciation, death, mourning, and suffering, the days one can truly open their mouth and laugh within a month are no more than four or five. The heavens and earth are boundless, yet human life is limited. With finite lives, we cling to boundless desires—suddenly, we are no different than **qílì** (骐骥), galloping past a narrow gap in an instant.

Those who cannot articulate their true intentions and cultivate their natural lifespan are not true **followers of the Dao/Way** (通道者).
All that **Qióng** (丘) has spoken of, I have rejected. Hurry away, return to your roots, and do not speak of such matters again!
Your **Dao/Way** (道) is a frantic, grasping, deceitful, and false affair—it cannot preserve the true self. Why should it be discussed at all?

**Chapter One: Commentary**
The eyes see, the ears hear, the mouth discerns flavors, and the **spirit-qi** (志气) seeks fulfillment—these are natural inclinations, given by **Nature** (造物). How could they be feigned? They are inherent to one’s being; the **Dao/Way** is embedded within them.

**Explanation of Text:**
*以说* (yǐ shuō) is pronounced *Yúshuō* (如字) or *Shǐruì* (始锐反).

**Chapter Two: Commentary**
The heavens endure long, the earth persists eternally—yet human life is fleeting, its limits pressing. With a finite body, we entrust ourselves to boundless desires—what difference is there from **qílì** (骐骥) galloping past a narrow crevice? The pronunciation *上寿* (shàng shòu) is read as *Shòushòu* (受) or as *Shàngshòu* (如字). The same applies below.»

**Translation:**

**《瘦》**—*sè* again reversed. ◎ **Master Wang Renshu** says: In the *Shìwén*, *shòu* (瘦) is pronounced *sè* again. I note that *shòu* should be *yǔ* (瘐), a scribal error. *Yǔ* also means *disease*. Diseases of wasting (*yǔ*) form one category, death and mourning another, and sorrow and affliction a third. The original character for *yǔ* was *yù* (愈). The *Ēryá* states: *"Yù* (愈), disease."* In the *Mao* transmission of the *Zhāngyǎ* *"Zhēngyuè"* (正月), *"Hú bǐ wǒ yù"* (胡俾我愈), the commentary aligns with the *Ēryá*. In the *Book of Han*, Emperor Xuandi’s annals record: *"Those condemned to death by flogging or imprisonment, if they die from hunger, cold, or wasting (*yǔ*) in prison,"* where **Sū Lín** explains: *"Yǔ* (瘐), disease—prisoners’ sickness, legally termed *yǔ*."* **Shī Gǔ** states: *"Yǔ* (瘐), pronounced *yǔ* (庾), sometimes written as *yù* (愈)."* The *Tablet of Prince Wáng Zǐhòu* reads: *"Fùhóu Lóng, imprisoned and dying from *yǔ* (庾)〔yǔ〕 (二)."*

**Chapter Three: Commentary**
*Jí* (亟), urgency. *Kuángkuáng* (狂狂), loss of nature. *Jiéjié* (伋伋), insufficiency. The **Dao/Way** of sages’ traces, the practice of **virtue** and righteousness—like that of **Sū Lú’s** hut or the sacrificial **chúdòu**—if clutched without release, only deepens their ruin. Madness (*kuángkuáng*) loses its truth, insufficiency (*jiéjié*) falls short—these hollow deceits, what merit do they hold for discussion?

**Phonetic Notes:**
- *Néngshuō* (能说) pronounced *yuè* (悦).
- *Jíqù* (亟去) pronounced *jílì* (纪力反), meaning *urgent*. Originally written as *jí* (极).
- *Wúfù* (无复) pronounced *fūyòu* (扶又反).
- *Kuángkuáng* (狂狂) as written, or *jiǔkuàng* (九况反).
- *Jíjí* (汲汲) also written as *jiéjié* (伋伋), pronounced *jí* (急) or *jí* (及).
- *Zhàqiǎo* (诈巧) pronounced *kǔxiào* (苦孝反), or as written.

**Collation Notes:**
(一) **Zhào Jiànyì’s** text reads *jiéjié* (伋伋).
(二) The character *yǔ* (瘐) follows the *Book of Han* correction.

Confucius bowed twice and hurried away, stepping out and mounting his carriage, where he grasped the reins three times in failure, his vision blurred as if seeing nothing, his face ashen like dead embers. Leaning against the handrail, head bowed, he could not catch his breath.

Upon reaching the eastern gate of Lu, he happened upon Gōuliú Xiàjì. Gōuliú Xiàjì said, *“You have been absent these past days, your carriage bearing signs of haste—have you gone to see Zhí the Robber by chance?”*

**Phonetic Notes:**
- *Shàngchē* (上车) pronounced *shǐzhǎng* (时掌反).
- *Sānshī* (三失) pronounced *xīzàn* (息暂反), or as written.
- *Mángrán* (芒然) pronounced *mògāng* (莫刚反).
- *Yǒuxíng* (有行) as written.

**Collation Notes:**
(一) **Zhào Jiànyì’s** text reads *rán* (然) [twice].

**Explanatory Notes:**
- *Shì* (轼): The horizontal bar at the front of a carriage, where one leans while seated.
- Zhí (跖): A legendary outlaw and bandit, renowned for his boldness and debates on *wùlǐ* (物理—principles of nature/human affairs).
- *Wéi* (微): Here, meaning "without" or "in secret."

Gōuliú Xiàjì added, *“Has Zhí perhaps gone against your will as before?”*

Confucius replied, *“Indeed.”*

Confucius sighed to the heavens and said, *“This is like one who, without ailment, sears himself with cauterization—racing to prod a tiger’s head and braid its whiskers, nearly falling prey to its jaws!*”

---
**Collation Notes:**
(一) The phrase *“as before”* refers to the opening of this chapter where Gōuliú Xiàjì says: *“To defy one’s will is to provoke anger—would it not be as if I spoke against your intentions as I did before?”* Confucius replied: *“Indeed, as you said.”*

(二) **Explanatory Note:**
This passage illustrates the principle that when acting in accordance with the desires of the multitude, even a tyrant like King Zhòu may be removed; yet without aligning with the people, even a bandit like Zhí cannot be governed. The metaphor of probing a tiger’s head and braiding its whiskers—nearly falling into its jaws—mirrors Confucius’ perilous journey to persuade Zhí, risking danger akin to this folly. The chapter’s intent is to disparage the pursuit of saintly deeds and scorn the pursuit of fame and gain, hence its critique of Yáo and Shùn while belittling Yí and Qí. The analogy of Confucius and Zhí serves this satirical purpose. Guō Xiàng’s interpretation, however, errs in its distance.

---
**Phonetic Notes:**
- *Zìjiǔ* (自灸) pronounced *jiǔyòu* (久又反).
- *Jízǒu liào* (疾走料) pronounced *liáo*.
- *Biānhǔ* (扁虎) pronounced *biānhǔ* (音鞭), or *púxiǎn* (蒲显反), *xúfúxiǎn* (徐扶显反). Some manuscripts read *biāntóu biānhǔxū* (编头编虎须), with *biān* (编) homophonous to *liào* (料).
- *Jībù* (几不) pronounced *qíbù* (祈不).
- *Kěqù* (可去) pronounced *qìlǚ* (起吕反).

---
Zǐzhāng asked Mǎn Gǔdé, *“Why not simply act?* Without action, one is not trusted; without trust, one is not entrusted; without entrustment, one gains no advantage. Thus, observing reputation and calculating profit, virtue is truly the path to follow. But if one abandons fame and gain, turning against one’s own nature, then the scholar’s pursuit of action cannot be for even a single day!”

---
**Collation Notes:**
(一) **Zǐzhāng**, a disciple of Confucius, bore the surname Zhuān Sūn, given name Shī, and the courtesy name Zǐzhāng—a man who followed the path of the sage. **Mǎn Gǔdé** is a fictitious name, implying one who satisfies his desires through greed and deceit. *“Swēi”* (盍) means *“why not.”* The passage urges him to abandon the pursuit of fame and gain.

---
Mǎn Gǔdé replied, *“The shameless grow rich; the overly trusting gain prominence. The greatest of fame and gain lie in shamelessness and trust. Thus, observing reputation and calculating profit, trust is truly the path to follow. But if one abandons fame and gain, turning against one’s own nature, then the scholar’s pursuit of action is but clinging to his innate purity!”*

---
**Collation Notes:**
(二) Without action in virtue, one is not trusted; without trust, one holds no office; without office, one gains no profit. Thus, action brings reputation, reputation brings profit—observing and calculating, virtue is truly the good deed worth pursuing.

(三) *“Fǎn”* (反) here means *“to defy.”* If one abandons fame and gain, it defies one’s nature; hence, the scholar’s conduct must never forsake virtue for even a day.

---
Zǐzhāng said, *“In the past, Jié and Zhòu, though noble as sons of Heaven and wealthy with all under Heaven, were now told to a thief: ‘Act as Jié and Zhòu did,’ and they would blush with shame, their hearts unwilling. Such is how the vulgar despise them. Zhōngní and Mò Dí, though reduced to commoners, were now told to an official: ‘Act as Zhōngní and Mò Dí did,’ and he would change his expression, praising their sufficiency. Truly, the noble are not defined by their station—whether as a son of Heaven or a commoner—but by the virtue or vice of their conduct.”*

---
**Collation Notes:**
(一) Jié, Zhòu, Zhōngní, and Mò Dí were discussed earlier. *“Zāng”* refers to Zāng Huò, and *“jù”* to theft—common rogues. Comparing a thief to a son of Heaven evokes shame and reluctance; comparing an official to a commoner elicits admiration and approval. Thus, nobility lies in conduct, not in rank.

---
Mǎn Gǔdé said, *“Small thieves are imprisoned, great thieves become lords; at the gates of lords, righteous men still dwell. In the past, Huan Gōng—Jiǎ Bái—killed his brother and wed his sister-in-law, yet Guān Zhòng served him. Tián Chéngzǐ—Jiāng Zhāng—murdered his lord and usurped the state, yet Kǒngzǐ accepted his gifts. In speech, they are condemned; in deed, they are revered. This contradiction festers within the heart—is it not discordant?”*

The Classics thus say:
*"Who is vile, who is fair?
The successful are honored as leaders,
The unsuccessful are scorned as followers."*

---

**Commentary:**
*"Treacherous"* means *contrary*.
*"Discordant"* means *perverse*.

Huan Gong—named Xiao Bai—slaughtered his brother’s son, Ji You, and took his sister-in-law as wife. Guan Zhong, though a sage, served him as minister and ultimately achieved the unification of the feudal lords and the rectification of the world. Tian Chengzi Chang murdered his lord, Duke Jian of Qi, yet Confucius bathed and attended court to accept his gifts.

To murder a brother and wed his sister-in-law, to slay a sovereign and usurp the state—no greater depravity exists in human relations. Yet Yi Wu served as his minister, and Ru’s Master received his tribute. In speech, they are condemned as base; in deed, they are revered. Is this not a warring within the breast, a contradiction between words and actions?

---
**Exegesis:**
*"To take his sister-in-law"*—early readings vary.
*Sima* explains: *"To take her as a wife in the household."*
*"As minister"*—some texts read *"as prime minister."*
*"To murder his lord"*—reads *shān zhì* (申志).
*"In speech"*—reads *lì dùn* (力顿).
*"Contradiction"*—reads *bù zhàn* (布内).
*"Discordant"*—reads *yì fú* (扶弗).

---
**Commentary:**
*"The successful are honored as leaders"*—they become lords and are served.
*"The unsuccessful are scorned as followers"*—they are censured and defamed.
Thus, the text speaks only of success or failure—it does not concern morality or its absence. Who then knows where true virtue lies?

The cited text has since perished in the conflagration; no original remains.

Zi Zhang said:
*"If one does not uphold conduct,
Then kinship and distance lack order,
Nobility and lowliness lack principle,
Seniority and juniority lack sequence—
How then shall the Five Roots and Six Relationships be distinguished?"*

---
**Commentary:**
*"Kinship"* means *affinity*.
*"Order"* means *proper arrangement*.
The *Five Roots* refer to ancestors and descendants, or the Five Phases (Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth), or the Five Virtues (Ren, Yi, Li, Zhi, Xin).
The *Six Relationships* refer to sovereign-subject, father-son, husband-wife, or parents, siblings, and spouses.

Zi Zhang said:
*"If one does not practice the Dao of Ren and Yi,
Then near and far lack proper arrangement,
Nobility and lowliness lack principle,
Seniority and juniority lack proper sequence—
Then how shall the Five Roots and Six Relationships be distinguished?"*

---
**Exegesis:**
*"Seniority"*—reads *dīng zhàng* (丁丈).

「The *Five Roots* [Sīmǎ’s commentary]: Year, day, month, stars, and celestial cycles.

The *Six Relationships*: Sovereign, minister, father, son, husband, and wife.

◎Yú Yì remarked: *"Sīmǎ’s commentary on the Five Roots as year, day, month, stars, and celestial cycles does not align with the meaning of near and far, noble and lowly, senior and junior. This is likely incorrect.*

Now, upon examination, the *Five Roots* are indeed the *Five Relationships* [Lún], and the *Six Relationships* are the *Six Roots* [Jì]. The *White Tiger’s Dialogue* [Bái Hǔ Tōng] in the chapter on *Three Halos and Six Roots* states: *"The Six Roots refer to uncles, brothers, kinsmen, maternal relatives, teachers and elders, and friends."* These are all the means by which distinctions of near and far, noble and lowly, senior and junior are made. Though it is not called the Five Relationships but the Five Roots, nor the Six Roots but the Six Relationships, this is merely the variation in ancient terminology.

In the *Family Sayings* [Jiā Yǔ], under the chapter *Entering the Officials*, the *Five Relationships* of servants are discussed. Wáng Shū’s annotation states: *"Relationships"* [Lún] are *"Roots"* [Jì]. Thus, *Relationships* and *Roots* can be used interchangeably.

*For distinction* [Wéi bié]—*bié* reads *bì* [彼列反].

The same below.

Mǎn Gǔdé said:
*"Did Yao kill his eldest son, Shun exile his younger brother, and thus establish distinctions of near and far? Did Tang exile Jié and King Wǔ kill Zhòu, and thus establish distinctions of noble and lowly? Did King Jì [Wáng Jì] act as the heir and the Duke of Zhōu kill his own brother, and thus establish proper sequence for seniority and juniority? If the Confucians falsify words and the Mohists advocate universal love, then how can the Five Roots and Six Relationships be distinguished?"*

【一】【Cōng】Yáo abandoned his eldest son Dān Zhū, not passing the throne to him (and) [therefore] [also] spoke of killing him. Shùn exiled his younger brother Xiàng to the state of Yǒuyú, commanding the officials of the realm to govern his territory, collect tribute, and levy taxes—hence the term *exile*. To abandon the heir and exile the younger brother, where is the principle of near and far?

【Shìwén】*"Yao killed his eldest son"*—Cuī [崔] reads: *"Yao killed his eldest son, Dān Zhū, as recorded in Kǎo Jiàn"* [考监明].
*"Shun exiled his younger brother"*—the younger brother refers to Xiàng. *Exile* [liú] means *banishment* [fàng]. Mèngzǐ states: *"Shun exiled Xiàng to Yǒuyú, preventing him from acting in his state. The Son of Heaven sent officials to govern his territory, and they collected tribute and levied taxes."* Hence, it is called *banishment*.

【二】【Cōng】Yīn Tāng banished Xià Jié to Náncháo, and Zhōu Wǔ killed Yīn Zhòu at Jì-jùn. How does this establish distinctions of sovereign-subject and noble-lowly?

【三】【Cōng】Wáng Jì, the younger brother of Zhōu Dà Wáng, was Jìlì [季历], the father of Wén Wáng. Tàibó and Zhòngyōng yielded the throne and did not ascend it, so the younger son Jìlì was made the heir. Guān and Cài, the elder brothers of Zhōu Gōng, wept and were slain—hence the phrase *"killed his brother"* [shā xiōng]. To abandon the rightful heir and establish the younger brother, and for a younger brother to slay his elder brother—how does this establish proper sequence for seniority and juniority?

【Shìwén】*"For heir"* [wéi shì] reads *dīnglì* [丁历反].

【四】【Cōng】The Confucians speak excessively, artificially creating distinctions of name and status; the Mohists advocate universal love, extending benevolence without discrimination. How can the Five Roots and Six Relationships then be distinguished?

*Though you uphold names as principle, and I uphold profit as principle. The substance of names and profit does not conform to reason, nor does it reflect the Dao/Way.*

I daily argue with you in the realm of *No Contract* [Wúyuē], saying:
*"The petty man pursues wealth, the noble man pursues prestige. The means by which they alter their emotions and change their nature differ; but when it comes to abandoning what they ought to do and pursuing what they ought not, they are the same."*

Hence, it is said:
*"Do not act as a petty man, and you will return to the Dao/Way; do not act as a noble man, and you will follow the natural principle of the Dao/Way.*

*Whether crooked or straight, they assist the Dao/Way to its utmost; facing all four directions, they harmonize with the rhythms of time.*

*Whether true or false, they grasp the Dao/Way’s subtle mechanism; standing alone yet complete in purpose, they wander with the Dao/Way.*

*Act without deviation, and you will not establish distinctions of virtue/power; you will lose what you ought to do.*

*Seek wealth without haste, and you will not achieve it; pursue prestige without abandon, and you will not attain it—you will abandon the Dao/Way itself."*

【一】【Cōng】*Reflect* [jiàn], means *illuminate* or *perceive*. Your heart’s inclination is fixed on prestige; my heart’s inclination is fixed on profit. Though prestige and profit diverge, both paths are not true substance—contradicting ultimate reason, how could they be clearly perceived in the profound Dao/Way?

【Shìwén】*"Though you uphold names"* [Qǐ zǐ zhèng wéi míng]—hypothetical speech. *For* [wéi] reads *yú* [于伪反]. The same below for *profit*.
*"Reflect"* [bù jiàn]—original text also reads *bù jiàn* [不鉴], same meaning.

【二】【Cōng】*Argue* [sòng] means *discourse* or *reason*. *Contract* [yuē] means *oath or agreement*. Abandoning what one ought to do means *forsaking oneself*; pursuing what one ought not means *chasing after external things*. To pursue profit is to be petty; to pursue prestige is to be noble. Though profit and prestige differ, the pursuit is the same. You and I, though differing in our inclinations, both speak of profound principles in the realm of *No Action* [Wúwéi], earnestly discussing the unspoken bond of mutual understanding.

【Shìwén】*"I daily"* [Wú rì]—*rì* reads *shí* [人实反].
*"No Contract"* [wú yuē]—*yuē* reads *yuē* [约], as in *agreement*.
*"Wander"* [pái huái]—*huái* reads *miào* [徘徊，于妙反].

【三】【Cōng】*You* [ér], means *thus*. Neither chasing after profit nor pursuing prestige, one can then follow nature’s root, aligning with the Dao/Way’s spontaneous principle.

【四】【Cōng】*Assist* [xiàng], means *aid*. Whether crooked or straight, one follows the Dao/Way’s natural course, observing all four directions and adjusting with the seasons’ ebb and flow.

【五】【Cōng】*Wander* [pái huái], means *to turn and vary one’s thoughts*. *Subtle mechanism* [yuán jī], means *the central pivot* [huán zhōng]. To grasp the central pivot’s Dao/Way in responding to truth and falsehood, to employ the heart of self-sovereignty in fulfilling one’s purpose—thus, one can fathom the boundless, ever-transforming principle.

【Six】【Commentary】 *What one does* [suǒwéi] is *true nature* [zhēnxìng]. Do not *turn your intent* [zhuǎn nǐ zhì], lest you perform the deeds of the sages; do not *fixate your mind* [chéng ér xīn], lest you study the Dao/Way of *ren* [仁] and *yì* [義]. To abandon oneself and imitate others will only cause you to lose your true nature.

◎ *Wang Yanzun* says: *"Do not turn and act"* [wú zhuǎn ér xíng]—*zhuǎn* is read as *zhuān* [专]. In the *"Shanmu"* [山木] chapter, it states: *"One dragon, one serpent, together transforming with the times, yet never willing to act in singularity."* This is the same as *"not acting in singularity"* [wú zhuān ér xíng]. This follows the earlier text—*"adjusting with the seasons’ ebb and flow"* and *"wandering with the Dao/Way"*—stating that one must follow the times and the Dao/Way without acting in singularity. If one acts in singularity and fixes upon *yì* [義], one will lose what one truly does.

Thus, the following text says: *"Rectify your words, and your actions must be true; thus, you will bear your calamities and avoid your misfortunes."* *"Your actions must be true"* is the same as *"acting in singularity."*

In the *"Qiushui"* [秋水] chapter, it says: *"Acting in singularity, it diverges from the Dao."* *"Singularity"* [yī] is also singularity. *"Not acting in singularity"* is the same as *"not acting in singularity."* The characters *zhuān* [专] and *zhuǎn* [转] were interchangeable in ancient times, and both could be written as *chuǎn* [抟]. In the *Records of the Grand Historian*, the *Wu Wang Pi* [吴王濞] transmission says: *"Yan Wang chuǎn* [抟] *the Hu troops into Xiaoguan."* The *Yaoin* [索隐] says: *"Chuǎn, pronounced zhuān, meaning to command and lead the Hu troops."* In the *Han Book*, *chuǎn* [抟] is written as *zhuǎn* [转].

---

【Seven】【Commentary】 Do not *rush toward* [mò bēnfù] wealth and nobility, nor *pursue success* [wú xúnzú]. If one rushes or pursues, one will betray one’s *natural* [tiānrán] nature.

【Collation】 (1) The text is incorrectly cited; the *Zhang Junfang* [张君房] edition reads *"xī"* [昔]. *Bi Gan* was flayed, *Zi Yu* was gouged out—these were the calamities of *zhōng* [忠] [1]; *Zhi Gong* [直躬] drowned to prove his father’s innocence, *Wei Sheng* [尾生] drowned in pursuit of fidelity—these were the misfortunes of *xìn* [信] [2]; *Bao Zi* [鲍子] stood upright to death, *Shen Zi* [申子] neglected his own affairs—these were the harms of *lián* [廉] [3]; *Confucius* did not see his mother, *Jiang Zi* [匡子] did not see his father—these were the losses of *yì* [義] [4].

These are the traditions passed down from antiquity and spoken of in later times, illustrating that a *scholar* [shì] must rectify his words and ensure his actions are true—thus, he will bear his calamities and avoid his misfortunes [5].

「**[1] [Commentary]** *Bi Gan* was loyal in his remonstrance against King Zhou, who declared, *"I have heard that a sage’s heart has nine orifices,"* and thus had his heart cut open to inspect it. *Zi Yu* remonstrated with King Fu Chai, who killed him, and Zi Yu said, *"After my death, gouge out my eyes and hang them at the eastern gate of Wu so that I may witness the destruction of Yue in its conquest of Wu."* These were all instances of extreme loyalty leading to their calamities.

**[Reading Note]** *"Gouged out"* (*loù yǎn*) is pronounced with the *wu* rhyme.

**[2] [Commentary]** *Zhi Gong* proved his father’s guilt for stealing sheep. *Wei Sheng* made an appointment with a woman beneath a beam and drowned while waiting for her. These were all cases of upholding trust and thereby inviting misfortune.

**[3] [Commentary]** *Bao Zi* (Bao Jiao) was upright and incorruptible; when ridiculed by Zi Gong, he embraced a tree and starved to death. *Shen Zi* refers to *Shen Sheng*, the eldest son of Duke Xian of Jin, who, falsely accused by Lady Li, was slandered and, without defending himself, hanged himself.

**[Reading Note]** *"Bao Zi stood upright"* (*Bao Zi lì gān*): Sima Qian says *Bao Zi* was named *Jiao*, a man of the late Zhou. When the times were corrupt, he refused office and lived by gathering wild greens. Zi Gong saw him and asked, *"Why do you not take office and accept stipends?"* He replied, *"There is no worthy ruler to serve."* Zi Gong said, *"If you despise the ruler, you should not dwell in his land or eat his produce. Now you despise his governance yet reside in his territory and consume his crops—how can your resolve and conduct be so contradictory?"* Bao Jiao then abandoned his greens and starved to death. The *Han Shi Wai Zhuan* agrees. Another account says he withered away by the Luo River. *"Shen Zi did not defend himself"* (*Sheng Zi bù zì lǐ*): One text reads *"Sheng Zi buried himself"* (*Sheng Zi zì mái*). Others say it refers to *Shen Tu Di* embracing a jar by the river. Another version reads *"Shen Zi did not defend himself,"* referring to *Shen Sheng*.

**[4] [Commentary]** Confucius, immersed in the pursuit of the sage’s path, traveled among states accepting invitations, and thus did not see his mother upon her death. *Jiang Zi* (Jiang Zhang), of Qi, remonstrated with his father, who exiled him; Jiang Zhang never saw his father again, though he remained devoted to benevolence and righteousness, so absorbed in study that he forgot to return home.

**[Reading Note]** *"Confucius did not see his mother"* (*Kǒngzǐ bù jiàn mǔ*): Li [Fan] says, *"This is unheard of."* *"Jiang Zi did not see his father"* (*Jiang Zi bù jiàn fù*): Sima Qian says *Jiang Zi* was named *Zhang*, of Qi, who remonstrated with his father and was banished, never seeing him again. This account appears in *Mencius*.
**◎** *Lu Wenpiao* remarks: *"It is likely that ‘father’ and ‘mother’ in these two cases should be reversed."*»

At the fifth chapter, the text states that if one values the three *Dao/Way*s (benevolence, righteousness, and propriety), one may fall into *jiaoyao* (excessive rectitude); if one esteems the *shi* (noble/gentleman), one may encounter *shiwei* (deception among gentlemen). Therefore, the sage disdains mere conduct and holds the common man in contempt to preserve his inner integrity, only then can his conduct be exalted and his noble status affirmed.

**[Commentary]** From Bi Gan onward to Jiang Zhang, all were men of loyalty, sincerity, and integrity who met with misfortune. These are accounts passed down from antiquity, recounted by later generations.
Thus, sincere and loyal gentlemen, virtuous and upright individuals, who straighten their words to remonstrate with their rulers and rectify their conduct to serve their lords, inevitably encounter calamity and suffer misfortune. Those who follow the *Dao/Way* should deeply guard against such dangers.

**[Reading Note]** In *"what is passed down"* (*shuǒ chuán*), the character 申 (*shēn*) is pronounced *shèng* (专).
**[Collation Notes]** (1) The *Shide Tang* edition reads 申 (*shēn*) as 胜 (*shèng*), and the reading note also uses 胜 (*shèng*).
(2) The *Shide Tang* edition has 不 (*bù*) beneath 子 (*zǐ*).
(3) The Zhao edition reads 尚 (*shàng*) as 上 (*shàng*).

Wúzú, a man of insatiable greed, asked Zhīhé, who understood the *Dao/Way* of harmony and moderation and upheld propriety in purity and integrity:

“There has never been a man who did not seek fame and profit. If one is wealthy, people gather around him; if he is humble, they honor him; if he is honored, he becomes esteemed. To see one held in esteem, this is the *Dao/Way* to ensure longevity, physical comfort, and joy in life. Yet you alone show no interest in this. Do you not know what is insufficient, or do you know but lack the strength to act? Or is it that you cling to righteousness and never forget it?”

**[Commentary]** Wúzú refers to those greedy and insatiable individuals who never have enough. Zhīhé refers to those who inherently understand the *Dao/Way* of harmony and moderation, and who maintain purity and integrity. The dialogue is hypothetical, illustrating the consequences of greed and virtue. Wúzú said:

“In the end, no one in the world fails to pursue fame and follow profit. If one is rich, people flock to him; if he is humble, they exalt him; if he is exalted, he gains honor. He who is humble and honored will have his desires fulfilled, his nature content, and his body at ease, thus living long. You alone have no desire for wealth and honor? Do you know that fame is insufficient and thus not seek it? Or do you know in your heart what is right, but lack the strength to act, so you adhere to righteousness and never forget it, thereby dispelling your greedy desires and not taking what you should?”

**[Reading Note]** In *"Wúzú"* (*wúzú*), one version reads 无知 (*wúzhī*).

「The *Zéxià* [1] reads *xiájià fǎn* [2]. Below follows the same reading. The *Lèyì* [3] is pronounced *luò*. Below follows the same reading. The *Zhībù* [4] is pronounced *zhì*. Below, *zhī* and *móu* share the same reading.

**[Annotation]** *Zhī* (知) and *bù* (不) are pronounced *zhì* (智) here.

◎Qìngfān [5] notes that *yì* (意) is a word, read as *yì* (抑). *Yì* (抑) was an ancient character also meaning *yì* (意). In the *Lunyu* [6] *Xuéér* [7] chapter, *yì* (抑) and *yǔ* (与) are used interchangeably, while the Han *Shíjīng* [8] renders *yì* (抑) as *yì* (意). In the *Mòzǐ* [9] *Míngguǐ* [10] chapter, *qǐ* (岂) and *nǚ* (女) are used for *yǔ* (与), while *Bào* (鲍) uses *yì* (意). These are all corroborating instances.

**[Translation]**

The *Zhībù* [11] passage states: "This person, assuming he was born alongside me and dwells in my native place, believes himself to be one who transcends the common and surpasses the world. Indeed, he is one who clings solely to his own subjective standards, thus failing to discern the shifts of time across ages or the true boundaries of right and wrong, and instead aligning himself with the vulgar. The world abandons what is most precious—life—and forsakes what is most exalted—the Dao [12]. He takes this as his own doing! Thus, his reasoning on the Dao [12] of long life, bodily ease, and joyous contentment is far removed indeed [13]!

The agonies of sorrow and the tranquility of delight do not manifest in his physical form [14]; the dread of fear and the exhilaration of joy do not enter his mind. Knowing only *what is done* (*wéiwéi*) [15] but not *the source of its doing* (*suǒyǐwéi*) [16], even if he were a noble emperor, wealthy beyond the world, he would still not escape suffering [17]!"

**[Annotations]**
[1] *Zéxià* (则下) – Likely refers to a variant reading in the text.
[2] *xiájià fǎn* (遐嫁反) – A phonetic annotation indicating pronunciation.
[3] *Lèyì* (乐意) – Pronounced *luòyì* (洛意).
[4] *Zhībù* (知不) – Pronounced *zhìbù* (智不).
[5] Qìngfān (庆藩) – A commentator.
[6] *Lunyu* (论语) – *Analects* of Confucius.
[7] *Xuéér* (学而) – "In Learning" (Chapter 1).
[8] *Shíjīng* (石经) – "Stone Classics," an ancient edition of Confucian texts.
[9] *Mòzǐ* (墨子) – Mencius (or the *Mozi*).
[10] *Míngguǐ* (明鬼) – "Manifesting Spirits" (Chapter 3).
[11] *Zhībù* (知不) – Likely a misrendering for *Zhībù* (知不), part of the original passage.
[12] *Dao* (道) – The Way/Path.
[13] Original parallelism preserved: "不亦远乎" (*bù yì yuǎn hū*) – "is not this far removed?"
[14] *bù jiān yú tǐ* (不监于体) – "do not manifest in his physical form" (监 *jiān* = manifest).
[15] *wéiwéi* (为为) – "what is done" (作 *zuò* or 动 *dòng* could also fit, but "doing" is preserved for consistency).
[16] *suǒyǐwéi* (所以为) – "the source of its doing" (无为 *wúwéi* = non-action/naturalness in context).
[17] Original parallelism preserved: "虽贵为天子，富有天下，而不免于患也" (*suī guì wéi tiānzǐ, fù yǒu tiānxià, ér bù miǎn yú huàn yě*) – "Even if he were a noble emperor, wealthy beyond the world, he would still not escape suffering."

**[Reading Note]**
[1] *Zéxià* (则下) – Variant reading.
[2] *xiájià fǎn* (遐嫁反) – Pronunciation guide.
[3] *Lèyì* (乐意) – Pronounced *luò* (洛).
[4] *Zhībù* (知不) – Pronounced *zhì* (智).

**[Codicil]**
[1] *Zhī* (知) and *móu* (谋) share the same reading as *zhī* (知) in this passage.
[2] *Guìwéi* (贵为) and *tiānzǐ* (天子) – "Even if he were a noble emperor."
[3] *Tǐ bù dài xiàng ér ān zhī* (体不待象而安之) – "his body does not require external form to find ease."
[4] *Tiānxià suī fēi wǒ, shú néng cí zhī!* (天下虽非我，孰能辞之) – "The world though not mine, who could refuse it!"

Wúzú [18] further states:

“Now, wealth bestowed upon a person benefits him in every way—it fulfills all desires, exhausts all pleasures, and reaches all limits of indulgence. Even the sage cannot attain it, the worthy cannot rival it, and the bold rely on it for their strength and might. The clever use it for their shrewdness, the virtuous [19] for their moral power, and the noble for their authority. It is not merely the enjoyment of a kingdom but the stern governance of a sovereign father [20].

Moreover, the sounds, colors, tastes, and political power—these bring joy to the heart without need of study and ease to the body without need of ritual form [21]. The inclinations toward pleasure and avoidance of pain, the pursuit of gain and shunning of loss, are inherent in human nature. If the world is not mine, who could refuse it?” [22]

**[Annotations]**
[18] *Wúzú* (无足) – As previously noted, variant as *wúzhī* (无知).
[19] *德* (*dé*) – Virtue/power.
[20] *Guìwéi guófù ér yán ruò jūnfù* (贵为国父) – Stern governance akin to a sovereign father.
[21] *Tǐ bù dài xiàng ér ān zhī* (体不待象而安之) – Parallel to earlier usage; "ritual form" here suggests *xiàng* (象) as outward expressions or conventions.
[22] *Tiānxià suī fēi wǒ, shú néng cí zhī!* (天下虽非我，孰能辞之) – Preserved as a rhetorical question, maintaining the original's force.

「【一】**[Annotation]** *Qióng* (穷) – Exhaustive; thorough.  *Jǐu* (究) – Ultimate; perfect.  *Shàn* (埶) – Pronounced as *shì* (势), meaning power or influence.
Exhausting all the good and beautiful things in the world, and thoroughly grasping the power and influence of humanity—who but the wealthy and noble could achieve such? Thus, even those of supreme virtue and sagely wisdom cannot reach them.

**[Annotation]** *Yīng* (雍) – Harmonious; concordant.  *Shàn* (善) – Good; virtuous.  *Shàn* (弒) – Usurpation (of throne).
Emperor Yao and Shun ruled in harmony, not because they cherished humanity’s benevolence, but because they did not let beauty and luxury harm life. The virtuous Shàn (善卷) and Xu You declined the throne, not out of false modesty in yielding, but because they did not let worldly affairs harm themselves. These were all cases of accepting what benefits them and declining what harms them, yet the world praises them as sages—this proves they had no intention of seeking fame, only avoiding peril.

**[Annotation]** *Yán* (阨) – Pronounced as *è* (厄), meaning calamity or distress; also *wǔmài* (乌卖) – same.
If one insists on upholding one’s reputation, enduring hardship to deny oneself sweetness, restraining nourishment to preserve life, then one is no different from a chronic invalid suffering long-term illness and prolonged distress, yet still clinging to life—though the days of such existence are already like those of the dying!

**[Annotation]** *Fèng* (冯) – To indulge in; to wallow in.  *Qì* (气) – Vital energy; also, in this context, refers to the breath or spirit of life.
The wealthy, enraptured by the clamor of bells and drums, the jingling of coins and keys, and the savor of coarse grains, livestock, and strong drink—these stir their desires, causing them to neglect their affairs. This is truly chaotic!

To wallow in the breath of luxury, like one burdened with heavy loads ascending a steep slope—this is truly suffering! To hoard wealth for comfort, to wield power to exhaustion, to indulge in ease when at rest, to revel in excess when bathed in prosperity—this is truly illness!

For the sake of becoming wealthy and pursuing gain, they grow full like walls yet know not to avoid danger, and wallow in excess without relinquishing it—this is truly shameful!

Wealth accumulates yet serves no purpose, luxuries are embraced yet never discarded, their hearts brimming with sorrow and distress, yet they still crave more—this is truly a cause for worry!

Within, the perils of suspicion and deceitful intrigues fester;
without, the dread of bandits and thieves looms.
Confined to guarded halls, yet daring not to walk alone abroad—
this is truly fear! **[Seven]**

These six afflictions are the gravest plagues of the world,
yet they are ignored and unexamined.
When disaster strikes, they exhaust their virtue and wealth,
only to find that even a single day’s reversal of fortune is unattainable. **[Eight]**

Thus, when sought by name, they are unseen;
when pursued for gain, they elude grasp.
Yet they fixate their minds and bodies in contention for these very things—
is this not bewilderment? **[Nine]**

---

As for the principle of equality bestowing blessings upon the virtuous
and drawing misfortune to those who hoard excess—
this is the natural order of Heaven.
All things follow this way, yet none more so than wealth. **[One]**

**[Codicil]** *Sāo* (嗛), meaning "to indulge to excess."
*Guanque* (管钥), flutes and pipes of the *xiaodie* (箫笛) class—
the wealthy, unrestrained in their licentiousness,
their mouths steeped in strong drink,
their ears deafened by *gongshang* (宮商) music,
their hearts slipping into wantonness at every turn,
stirred by every sensation—
their nature grows dim and confused,
their affairs forgotten, unnoticed—
how is this not chaos? **[Two]**

**[Collation Note]** *Guan* (管) pronounced as in the seal script.
Originally also written as *guan* (管).

「**《Pinyao》** pronounced as *yào* (药).
**[One]** originally written as *guanpinyao* (筦钥) or *xūn* (埙).
**《Kǒu sāo》** pronounced with *ku* as in *kǔ jiàn* (苦簟), *sāo* as in *kuài* (快).
**[Annotation]** Qing Fan (庆藩) notes: *sāo* (嗛) means "to delight."
*Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字): *sāo* (嗛), either "to take pleasure in" or "to hold in the mouth" **[four]**.
Zhao Ce (赵策) in *Shìshī* (食史) took delight in *sāo* (嗛) at Wei, while Qi Huan Gong (齐桓公) did not take pleasure in *Yíyá* (易牙) even at midnight.
Gao (高) in both cases notes: *sāo* (嗛) means "to delight."
In *Xúnzǐ Róngrǔ Piān* (荀子荣辱篇), "to delight in its stench without taking pleasure in the nose" **[sāo]**, Yang Shen (杨倞) reads *sāo* (嗛) as *qiàn* (慊), meaning "to satiate" or "to be weary of."
**[Error]** This reading is incorrect.

**《Láo》** pronounced as *liào* (力刀).
**[Three]** **[Codicil]** *Féngqì* (冯气), akin to *fènmèn* (愤懑).
When avarice and desire grow excessive,
toils and servitude become oppressive,
the heart is choked and submerged in *féngqì* (愤懑),
just as one burdened with heavy loads climbs a steep hill.
This weariness and exhaustion—
is it not suffering and hardship? **[Annotation]** *Féng* (冯) pronounced as *fèn* (愤), meaning "to be filled with resentment."
**[Note]** The same below.

**《Ér shàng》** pronounced as *shì zhǎng* (时掌).
**[Four]** **[Codicil]** Those who greedily amass wealth and treasures
to soothe their hearts,
or flatter and curry favor to exhaust their minds,
who dwell in ease and idleness—
their bodies sink into *chénnyì* (沉溺),
and when their physical and mental *qi* (气) are smooth and lustrous,
*féngmèn* (愤懑) arises.
Struggling in motion or stillness, burdened by suffering—
is this not a sickness? **[Annotation]** *Wèi* (慰) also written as *wèi* (畏).
**[Annotation]** Qing Fan (庆藩) notes: *Wèi* (慰) should be associated with *wèi* (蔚).
In *Huáinán Túzhēn Piān* (淮南俶真篇), "the five viscera lack *wèi* (蔚) *qi* (气)," Gao (高) notes: *wèi* (蔚) means "illness."
In *Miǎo Chēng Piān* (缪称篇), "dwarfs and blind teachers are those who suffer *wèi* (困慰)."
Gao (高) notes: *wèi* (慰) means "illness."
Thus, the terms *wèi* (蔚) and *wèi* (慰) were interchangeably used in ancient explanations.

**[Five]** **[Codicil]** *Dǔ* (堵), meaning "wall."
To seek wealth and profit is like a bottomless pit or a wall—
like a wall built with bricks and mud until it overflows,
the heart is filled with *féngmèn* (愤懑),
greed and covetousness never cease,
unaware of avoiding harm—
is this not shameful? **[Annotation]** *Shě* (舍) pronounced as *shě* (舍).
**[Note]** The same below.

**[Sixth Codicil]** *Qìjiào* (戚醮), meaning "affliction."
To accumulate without dispersing, to cling without release—
greed knows no satisfaction, affliction fills the heart.
If we examine it thoroughly,
is this not sorrow and distress?

**[Annotation]** Qing Fan notes: *Fúyīng* (服膺) while not releasing is the same as the earlier *féng* (冯) while not releasing.
*Fúyīng* (服膺) means "to rely upon."
In *Wén Xuǎn* (文选), the *Hàn Gāozǔ Gōngchén Sòng* (汉高祖功臣颂) has *féngyīng* (冯膺) but is missing the second character.
**[Annotation]** *Yīng* (膺) in *Wén Xuǎn* is mistakenly written as *yìng* (应).
Li Shàn’s annotation mistakenly takes it as "relying on auspicious omens," which is incorrect.
In antiquity, *yìng* (应) and *yīng* (膺) were homophonous and interchangeable.
In the *Kāng Gào* (康诰), *yìng* (应) means "to protect the people of Yin."
In the *Zhōu Gào* (周诰), *yīng* (膺) means "to bear the virtue of the people."
In the *Shī Jīng* (诗经), *Shì Gōng Yán* (閟宫篇), *yīng* (膺) refers to "the barbarians of Róng and Dí."
In *Shǐ Jì* (史记), the *Jiàn Yuán Lái Hóu Zhě Nián Biǎo* (建元以来侯者年表) writes *yìng* (应) instead of *yīng* (膺).
In *Mèngzǐ* (孟子), *Téng Wén Gōng Piān* (滕文公篇), *yīng* (膺) refers to "the barbarians of Róng and Dí."
**[Annotation]** *Yīngyì Yì* (音义) states: The *Dīng* (丁) edition writes *yīng* (膺) as *yìng* (应).

The *fúyīng* (服膺) of relying upon is akin to *fúshì* (伏轼) meaning "to rely upon the chariot pole,"
*(Shǐ Jì* (史记), *Lǚ Shēng Zhuàn* (郦生传): *fúshì* (伏轼) submits to Qi and yields seventy-odd cities; *Hàn Shū* (汉书) writes *féngshì* (冯轼).)
*fúqín* (伏琴) meaning "to rely upon the zither,"
*(Shǐ Jì* (史记), *Wèi Shì Jiā* (魏世家): *zhōngqín* (凭琴); *Suōyuàn* (索隐) states: *Spring and Autumn Annals* later editions write *fúqín* (伏琴).)
*yīnfú* (茵伏) meaning "to rely upon the cushion."
*(Shǐ Jì* (史记), *Kù Lì Zhuàn* (酷吏传): *yīnfú* (茵伏) never dared to equal; *Hàn Shū* (汉书) writes *yīnféng* (茵冯).)

**[Annotation]** *Qìjiào* (戚醮) is pronounced in the *yáo* (遥) rhyme.
Li (李) says: Also pronounced *yě* (也).
Again, pronounced *zǐmiào* (子妙).

**[Seventh Codicil]** *Yí* (疑), meaning "fear."
*Qǐng* (请), meaning "to seek."
An ordinary man, though innocent, bears the guilt of possessing treasure—
thus, at home, he fears the calamities of thieves and robbers,
abroad, he dreads bandits, plunder, and theft.
Hence, he surrounds his courtyard with walls, raises high windows and towers,
exposes his inner and outer chambers,
yet still trembles in fear with every passing stranger,
daring not to walk alone.
Such hardship—
is this not terror?

**[Annotation]** *Yí* (疑): Pronounced *xǔyè* (许业) or *qūyè* (曲业).
*[Nèizhōu Lóu Shū]* (内周楼疏): Li (李) says: "Inner towers encircle densely, outer verandas connect sparsely"—referring to defensive preparations.

**[Eighth Codicil]** The six [afflictions] refer to chaos, suffering, sickness, humiliation, sorrow, and fear.
*Pán* (殚), meaning "exhausted."
The gravest of calamities is overlooked until bandits strike suddenly—
life and death hang in the balance,
a lifetime of greed vanishes in an instant,
all wealth and treasures are stripped away,
and yet one seeks to return to a single day of poverty—
how could this be possible?

**[Annotation]** *Cáidān* (财单): Pronounced *dān* (丹).
Originally written as *qí* (蕲), pronounced *qí* (祁).
**[Annotation]** Family tradition states: The *Shìwén* (释文) originally wrote *qí* (蕲), pronounced *qí* (祁), but this is incorrect.
*Dān* (单) should be written as *dǎn* (亶).
In *Shǐ Jì* (史记), *Lìshǔ* (历书), *dān* (单) and *àn* (阏) are written together; Chuì Jǎn (崔骃) annotates: *Dānàn* (单阏) is also written as *dǎn’ān* (亶安).
*Dān* (单) and *dǎn* (亶) are interchangeable.
In *Hàn Shū* (汉书), *dàn* (但) is often written as *dǎn* (亶).
In *Jiǎ Yǔ Zhuàn* (贾谊传): "Not merely *dǎn* (亶) to invert the suspended."
In *Yáng Xióng Zhuàn* (扬雄传): "*Dǎn* (亶) expends spirit here."
*Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字): *Dàn* (但), meaning "to bare one’s upper body."
Thus, *dàn* (但) is the same as *chàn* (儃) written as *dàn* (但).
*Dān* (单) means "to return to a single day of nothingness," akin to saying "but to return to a single day of nothingness."
*Yùpiàn* (玉篇): *Dān* (单), meaning "one," also akin to "solely," sharing meaning with *dàn* (但).

**[Ninth Annotation]** This chapter speaks of those who know contentment always being content.
*Liáo* (缭), meaning "to entangle."
When bandits strike, the body is no longer one’s own—
at that moment, how could one still see name and profit?
Yet common folk invert this utterly:
their hearts are entangled in name and profit,
their minds are severed from all restraint in pursuit,
and thus, in this regard,
is this not the height of delusion?

**[Annotation]** *Liáo* (缭): Pronounced *liǎo* (了) or *yúdiào* (鱼吊), meaning "principle."
**[Collation]**
(1) Zhào Jiànyì’s (赵谏议) manuscript writes *guǎn* (管) instead of *quán* (筦).
(2) The *bǎn* (阪) character follows Chéng’s (成) annotation.
**[Annotation]** The text mistakenly cites Zhāng Jūnfáng’s (张君房) edition as *bǎn* (阪), which is the same as *bǎn* (阪).
(3) Zhāng Jūnfáng’s (张君房) edition writes *rǔ* (辱) instead of *wèi* (慰).
(4) The characters *xián* (衔) and *yě* (也) follow Guó Cè’s (国策) Gao’s (高) annotation.
